title: Tumble Near a City Epazote Patch Spawns Mexican Cookbook
description: A forthcoming volume on tortillas, tacos, enchiladas and related esculents may be the only cookbook in the world ever spawned by a jogging accident. It will be the work of Diana Kennedy, who must set the best Mexican table in all of Manhattan.

title: Dance: Variant Giselle
description: Despite its eccentricities, Peter Wright's version of Giselle reveals a clean dramatic conception that rewards even those who cherish the more dancefilled traditional version. Veronica Tennant danced sparklingly as the ill  used Giselle and Rudolf Nureyev partnered suavely Tuesday evening in this first appearance of the work during the current National Ballet of Canada engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Notes on People
description: The oftenoutspoken Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, suggested yesterday that if illinformed, fuzzythinking crusaders really want Americans to cut their living standards in order to save grain for hungry people abroad, they might start by reducing half the nation's 62 million dogs, cats and horses.

title: $500,000 in Securities Found in Central Park
description: A bundle of securities with a listed value of half a million dollars was turned in to the Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith brokerage concern yesterday by a member of a local rock group who found them during a walk through Central Park.

title: The Agreed Articles
description: Two years of this country's political anguish is distilled into some 1,450 solemn words that form the three articles of impeachment against the President of the United States. These three articles, now adopted by the Judiciary Committee, will go to the floor of the House of Representatives later this month.

title: LISBON CHARGES 10 IN DELGADO DEATH
description: LISBON, July 31Ten members of the secret police that served the rightist Government overthrown in April have been charged with the murder nine years ago of the opposition leader, Gen. Humberto Delgado.

title: ROBERT HOLDING, LED ALUMINUM CONCERN
description: Robert S. Holding, chairman of the Worcester Pressed Aluminum Company in Worcester, Mass., died Sunday at his summer home in Edgartown, Mass. He was 82 years old and lived also in Providence, R. I.

title: British Theaters Bombed
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, July 31 (Reuters)Four fire bombs were detonated in movie theaters here during the night and a fifth device was defused, the police reported today. They said the bombs caused little damage and no injuries. In Oxford, the police reported the city's first three explosions early today.

title: Taxi Owners Warn of Contract Termination
description: The city's taxi fleet owners warned yesterday that they would be forced to terminate their contract with the Taxi Drivers Union if the Taxi and Limousine Commission failed to act favorably on the companies' application for a fare increase by tomorrow.

title: U.S. AND 11 OTHERS PLAN OIL SHARING
description: BRUSSELS, July 31 The Energy Coordinating Group made up of 12 major oilconsuming nations including the United States agreed today on the outline of an oilsharing plan after a threeday meeting here.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: White House Fails to Appeal Order for Stans Fund Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) President Nixon and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H Stans allowed a deadline to pass today without appealing an order to turn over some of Mr. Stans's papers to a grand jury investigating campaign finaming.

title: MILLIONS MISSING FROM CITY VAULT WERE NEVER LOST
description: A special task force investigating the mystery of the $5.4million in securities reported missing from a city vault said yesterday that it had cracked the caseby tracing the discrepancy to sloppy bookkeeping in the Controller's office.

title: The Purloined Letter: A Case of the Obvious
description: In 1845, Edgar Allan Poe published a small tale known as The Purloined Letterthe story of a mysterious missing document stolen from the mistress of the King of France by a scheming minister who uses it for blackmail.

title: Gorman Extended In Opening Round
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 (UPI)Tom Gorman was extended as he led the way into the second round of the 5100,000 First National tennis tournament today, defeating Peter Doerner of Australia, 63, 75. Gorman trailed by 04 in the second set.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beanie announced yesterday the establishment of a task force to reduce air pollution caused by automobile traffic. Headed by Deputy Mayor James Cavanagh, the task force will seek to achieve Federal cleanair standards by the Dec. 31, 1976 deadline.

title: BRITISH SNIPPING FACES TAKEOVER
description: LONDON, July 31  The British Government announced plans today for the nationalization of the shipbuilding, ship repairing and marine engineering industries, and the stock market immediately sank to 15year low.

title: ABC Alone Omits A Reply by Bentsen To Nixon's Speech
description: ABCTV, alone among the networks, did not carry last night's television address by Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, replying to President Nixon's economic message last Thursday.

title: Union Carbide Expanding
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would build a $75million graphite electrode plant to serve electric arc steel mills in the United States. The plant would be similar to the one Union Carbide has at Yabucoa in Puerto Rico. The site is not yet chosen.

title: Gold Heads Soviet Jewry Unit
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn has been elected chairman of the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry, succeeding Stanley H. Lowell. The conference, with offices at 11 West 42d Street, is the central coordinating agency for 79 Jewish organizations in the metropolitan area.

title: 267 N.F.L. Players In Training Camps
description: The National Football League Management Council announced yesterday that a total of 267 established players, including 75 starters, had reported for preseason training.

title: Americans' Late Score Wins, 2118
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., July 31 (AP)Matthew Reed, playing quarterback in place of the injured George Mira, scored on a 9yard sweep with 2 minutes 12 seconds to play tonight to pull the Birmingham Americans to a 2118 World Football League victory over the Detroit Wheels.

title: Speedy Action in Oil Spill Averts Hudson Pollution
description: GLENMONT, N.Y., July 31A threat of serious damage to the upper Hudson River was narrowly averted today when quick action was taken to contain 500,000 gallons of fuel oil that had gushed out of a ruptured oil tank here.

title: BISHOPS TO REVIEW WOMEN'S ORDINATION
description: The Right Rev. John M. Allin, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, has called a special meeting of the House of Bishops in Chicago Aug. 1415 to consider how to deal with the ordination of 11 women as priests in Philadelphia last Monday.

title: Rites for McCafferty
description: TIMONIUM, Md., July 31 (AP)Funeral services were held today for Don McCafferty, head coach of the Detroit.Lions, who died Sunday at the age of 53. Hundreds of persons, including former coaching associates and players who were with McCafferty during his 14year career with the Baltimore Colts, attended.

title: WATER HELD VITAL TO DEVELOP WEST
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 31  Western Governors concluded a threeday meeting today on a note that the region faces its most serious test since the waning days of the frontier.

title: A10 Plan Is Approved For Fairchild Republic
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Defense Department gave a goahead today for production of the Air Force's A10 closesupport aircraft by the Fairchild Republic division of Fairchild Industries, Inc., at Farmingdale, L. I.

title: Sandman's Serenade
description: With the soothing effect of coarse sandpaper, the distinguished gentleman from New Jersey's Second Congressional district brought a contribution to the House Judiciary Committee that can only be described as without any redeeming social, moral or political value. Charles W. Sandman Jr. was always there in the heat of argument, injecting just the note of sarcasm, cynicism and demagoguery that the impeachment debate does not needand that virtually every other member of the committee, on both sides of the aisle, stayed far away from.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)The House Banking. Committee approved legislation today giving the Federal Reserve Board discretion to regulate notes issued by bank holding companies.

title: SENATE VOTES FUNDS BUT NIXON IS WARNED
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The Senate approved today a $5.5billion appropriations bill to finance operations of several agencies, including the White House. But the bill's floor manager warned President Nixon not to spend one nickel of the money defending himself if the impeachment proceedings should go to a trial in the Senate.

title: ExAddicts Growing Their Own Food on Hart Island
description: Last spring the administrator of the five Phoenix House residences on Hart Island began to despair about the rising cost of feeding 350 former addicts who are part of the therapeutic drug program on the island.

title: Bonds Steady
description: Bond prices stabilized yeslerday as the market awaited the Treasury's terms for its massive midAugust refunding operation, which were announced after the close of trading. The Treasury's terms were surprising in only one aspecta return to selling Government paper in denominations of $1,000, Recently, the Treasury had placed a minimum of $10,000 on its bills and other issues.

title: The Stage: By George
description: By George! is a cavalcade of Gershwin songs sung and danced by a unit of young people called the Intense Family, dramatically linked to a minibiography of surprising insight and impact. The show, playing Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays at the Universalist Church, 4 West 76th Street (8733645), couldn't be more charming.

title: Suspect in fire at Church Sent for Psychiatric Care
description: Gordon Earl Marais, 56, who is charged with burglary, arson and homicide in the killing of a priest during a fire at the rectory of St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church on Monday, was committed to psychiatiric care yesterday at Bellevue Hospital,

title: IRVING S. ROSSOFF
description: Irving S. Rossoff, chairman of the board of I. C. Herman & Co., Inc., manufacturers of handkerchiefs at 244 Madison Avenue, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital Medical Center. He was 75 year's old ana lived at 44 Gramercy Park North.

title: Utility Defers Project
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company said yesterday it had deferred construction of two electric power generating units  Unit 4 of the Chalk River plant, a 660,000kilowatt oilfired unit, and the Dickerson plant, Unit 4, an 800,000kilowatt coalfired unit. The two plants in Maryland are being deferred because of revised electrical load forecasts, the company said. Neither unit is nuclearfueled as indicated in a story in The New York Times last Monday.

title: Election Unit Asks Hirschfeld To Discuss Offer to Lowenstein
description: The State Board of Elections has asked Abraham Hirschfeld, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, to discuss an asserted offer of a $50,000 campaign contribution to Allard K. Lowenstein shortly after Mr. Lowenstein dropped out of the Senate race and before he announced his Congressional candidacy.

title: Greeks Relieved but Not Elated by Pact
description: ATHENS, July 3IGreeks seemed relieved today, if not overly enthusiastic, about the agreement on Cyprus.

title: UPI Names Business Editor
description: United Press International announced yesterday the appointment of Dorothea M. Brooks as business editor. Miss Brooks who has been the assistant business editor since 1959, replaces Dean C. Miller, who resigned recently.

title: EAST GERMANS GO HOME AFTER TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The United States Government advised East German representatives today that because of continuing incidents hampering traffic on the access routes to West Berlin it could not inaugurate diplomatic ties with East Germany now.

title: 5 BRIDGEPORT POLICE HURT IN DISTURBANCE
description: Five police officers were injured and five persons were arrested in Bridgeport, Conn., last night in a melee at a public housing project, the police here reported.

title: 2 in J.D.L. Sentenced In Hurok Bomb Case
description: A federal judge sentenced two Jewish Defense League members to a year in prison yesterday for refusing to testify at the trial of two associates accused of bombing the Manhattan offices of the impresario Sol Hurok.

title: HOPE FOR CHANGE HELD RUNOFF KEY
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., July 31  A desire for change was credited today with the unexpected political success of South Carolina's new Democratic nominee for Governor, Charles D. Ravenel.

title: XRay Rules Set To Spare Patients Unneeded Dosages
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The Food and Drug Administration today published rules designed to save millions of Americans unnecessary dosages of medical and dental Xrays.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court upheld a decision by Middlesex County permitting subdivision of 140 acres of land in East Brunswick for development of a housing project. The Appellate Division of Superior Court rejected charges conflict of interest against the Middlesex County counsel, Herman B. Hoffman, who represented two private concerns that had sold the land to a developer. But even if there were wrongdoing, the court added, it would be too late to rescind the county's decision because it would affect prospective homeowners who invested in the development, known as Willow Wick.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Because they piously maintain that justice must be impartial, certain members of Congress and the Senate urge the President's removal from office despite the impact such a disastrous decision could have on America's political image and the economy.

title: The Screen: A Disarming Bank Shot Crooks Prove Proper and Optimistic
description: Though at this point in history caper movies are less easily remembered than individual blades of grass, Gower Champion's Bank Shot is a disarming exception. It's not a great movie. It's not worth taking a taxi to see. Yet there are many less invigorating ways to waste one's time.

title: Farm Prices Up 6%
description: Prices of raw farm products climbed 6 per cent from June 15 to July 15 after four months of declines, the Agriculture Department reported. Details on Page 35.

title: NEWS INDEX
Floods Kill 140 in India And 100 in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI, July 31 (Reuters)Floods caused by monsoon rains have killed at least 140 people in two Indian states, officials said here today.

title: Nixon Studies Bid to Avoid House Debate on Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 President Nixon is considering a shift of strategy in which he would try to bypass an impeachment debate in the House of Representatives and take his case directly to the Senate for quick resolution, White House officials said today.

title: The Issues Behind BeameGoldin Feud
description: During his campaign to become Controller of New York City, Harrison J. Goldin promised to hire outside auditors to look into the office, which was held at that time by Abraham D. Beame. On July 14, he made the first of these audits public.

title: The Stage: By George
description: By George! is a cavalcade of Gershwin songs sung and danced by a unit of young people called the Intense Family, dramatically linked to a minibiography of surprising insight and impact. The show, playing Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays at the Universalist Church, 4 West 76th Street (8733645), couldn't be more charming.

title: Sammy Cahn Has Pocketfuls of Song
description: Every morning at five o'clock, Sammy Cahn rises with a song nudging up out of him, hums his way down the streets of New York, and enters the most incredible fairy tale of his career.

title: 6 Cadets Killed in Quebec
description: QUEBEC, July 31 (UPI)Six teenaged cadets were killed yesterday and 33 were wounded in a grenade explosion during a safety lecture on weapons and explosives. The cadets were part of a group attending summer camp at the Val Cartier base 15 miles north of here. An army explosives expert said today that the explosion could not have been accidental.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Almost half the workers in the state suffered losses in real earnings in the last five years despite average wage increases of 34.5 per cent, according to the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy.

title: Woman Killed as Gun in Bag Falls in IRT Station
description: A woman standing on an IRT elevated platform in the Bronx was shot and killed yesterday morning when a fellow passenger dropped a shoulder bag containing a pistol that discharged when the bag hit the platform.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Before his induction into the Pro Football Hall Fame, last week, Bill George, once the middle linebacker of the Chicago Bears, was visiting with George Halas, the Begs' owner. During the conversation, Bill George mentioned casually that he wished two of his teammates, Doug Atkins and Fred Williams, were going to Canton, Ohio, with him for the ceremony.

title: Fiasco on Transit
description: The mortal, if not fatal, blow dealt by the House the emergency masstransit bill this week demonstrates quite clearly that neither the Congress nor the Administration has yet fully comprehended the seriousness and the immensity of the nation's masstransit needs.

title: FINANCIERS PICKED BY MEADOWS BODY
description: LYNDHURST, July 31The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission an nounced today that it had selected the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers, Wall Street investment bankers, to develop a financing plan for the commission's proposed construction of solidwaste disposal facilities in the Meadowlands.

title: ONONDAGAS' COUNCIL TO GET GRIEVANCES
description: NEDROW, N.Y., July 31 (UPI), About 100. Onondaga Indians met last night with county and Federal authorities to discuss, differences between the Council of Chiefs and Indians opposed to last week's eviction of nonIndians from the reservation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TONONTO, July 31 (UPI) The players for Team Canada 1974, the allWorld Hockey Association squad that will compete in an eightgame series with the Soviet Union were announced today. Three of the players named to the 25man roster were also part of the National Hockey League's Team Canada ensemble in 1972. They were Paul Henderson of the Toros, Frank Mahovlich of the Toros and Pat Stapleton, playing coach with the Chicago Cougars.

title: Ecevit, a Hero in Turkey, Cites Gains in New Accord
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 31Premier Bulent Ecevit, whose frail Government's obituary was being written a few weeks ago, has become a national hero since Turkey's invasion and military consolidation on Cyprus.

title: J. STANLEY HALPERIN
description: J. Stanley Halperin, a lawyer who specialized in taxes and estate planning, died Tuesday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 46 Cedarhurst Avenue in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: Vice President Lures 13,500 Golf Partisans
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 31The $200,000 Pleasant Valley Classic, stimulated by the well ballyhooed appearance of Vice President Ford got off to a brisk start today with a proam prelude that drew 13,500 paying spectators. Few of them; presumably, knew that the autographed balls the Vice President used had been Xrayed for security by the Secret Service.

title: 2 in J.D.L. Sentenced In Hurok Bomb Case
description: A federal judge sentenced two Jewish Defense League members to a year in prison yesterday for refusing to testify at the trial of two associates accused of bombing the Manhattan offices of the impresario Sol Hurok.

title: Music Vintage Quartet
description: String quartets, like some line wines, improve with age, up to a point  like wines, quartets often weaken and lose their character if the aging process goes on too long. The Cleveland Quartet, now just five years old, is coming to maturity a hit early, but its concert Tuesday night at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall left no doubt that the group is ready to be savored by connoisseurs.

title: A GAS PRODUCER TRIPLES PRICES
description: North American Royalties, Inc., said yesterday that it would almost triple the price of natural gas at a field in Texas from 42 cents to $1.30 per thousand cubic feet, effective Aug. 1. The company added that adjustment for the B.T.U. content of the gas and liquid processing rights will add another 16 to 18 cents to the new base price, making the total price about $1.47.

title: Chou, Looking Pale, Appears in Peking After Hospital Stay
description: PEKING, July 31Premier Chou Enlai, looking pale but composed after his recent stay in a hospital, made his first public appearance in two months at an Army Day reception held here last night.

title: CHASE REALTY TRUST SETS A 90C DIVIDEND
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust yesterday declared a regular 90cent dividend, payable Aug. 29, for the period ended May 31. The trustees also announced a $9million increase in loss reserves to $14.3million,

title: HighLevel Crime Wave
description: The indictment of John B. Connally, former Governor of Texas and later Secretary of the Treasury, brought a sensational end a month in which an astonishing number of high public figures have been subjected to the processes of the law. Senator Edward J. Gurney Florida was indicted on charges of bribery and conspiracy, California's Lieutenant Governor Ed Reinecke was convicted of perjury. Representative Frank Brasco of New York was convicted of peddling his influence for money. In the same short span, Otto Kerner, once Governor of Illinois and until a few days ago a judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, started threeyear prison sentence for assorted crimes connected with the taking of a bribe. So did his former director of state revenue.

title: 55 Limit Extension Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee approved a measure today extending indefinitely the 55mileanhour speed limit on the nation's highways, The energysaving measure is to expire next June 30 under existing law.

title: TV and Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Some months ago, Thomas P. O'Neill, the genial Bostonian who serves as the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, was reflecting on the way his elevation to the leadership had changed people's perceptions of him. I used to be an Irish hack, he said. Now have become a statesman.

title: MemberFirm Outlook: Bearish
description: Robert H. B. Baldwin, one of Wall Street's more influential figures, forecast yesterday that from 100 to 200 brokerage firms were in danger of disappearing in the next 12 months.

title: Market Place: Do Low P/E's Signal Upturn?
description: Are stocks cheap at current prices?

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Electric Company received four Air Force and Navy contracts totaling $53.8million.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Bridge: Spingold Series of Upsets Started With First Round
description: National knockout team championships always furnish some upsets, but the Spingold teams here two weeks ago was more upsetting than most. Perhaps the biggest surprise occurred in the first full round of play, when a famous quartet was resoundingly defeated by four unknowns.

title: House Votes for Control On Nuclear Sales Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The House of Representatives voted today to require an act of Congress before nuclear materials or technology could be transferred to a foreign nation.

title: U.S. TO REFINANCE $4.3BILLION DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The Treasury announced today that it would sell at auction next week a 33month note, a sixyear note and a 25year bond to refinance $4.3billion of securities that mature in midAugust.

title: Defenses Against Rape Outlined As Women Rally Near City Hall
description: About 300 people, many of them members of women's rights groups, ignored the hot noon sun to gather in Police Plaza behind City Hall yesterday to hear speakers discuss ways to combat rape.

title: TURKISH TROOPS SHELL AND SEIZE 2 CYPRUS TOWNS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31Turkish forces violated the ceasefire today by shelling the central northern coastal village of Lapithos from a warship and then advancing on it with troops, official Greek Cypriote sources charged today.

title: Watchman in the Night
description: WASHINGTON, July 31In what it did not do, as in what it did, the House Judiciary Committee conveyed a reassuring sense of constitutional order. Even those most critical of the secret Cambodian bombing and of the President's tax returns may have found reason, in the debates, to accept that those wrongs were not proper grounds for impeachment.

title: People in Sports
description: The surprise showing of the Philadelphia, Phillies, pacesetters in the National League Eastern Division, has benefited Manager Danny Ozark. Philadelphia extended Ozark's contract through 1976 yesterday with a substantial pay increase. He has done an outstanding job in bringing this club along, said Paul Owens, director of player personnel. His club last year was much improved over 1972 and this year we're right in the middle of everything.

title: North Vietnamese Attack 4th Town Near Da Nang
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, July 31 (AP)North Vietnamese forces attacked in a fourth town yesterday in the northern coastal region below Da Nang as the fighting in the area entered its third week.

title: ARMS BUDGET CUT 370 BY HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee has made a largely symbolic cut of 3.5 per cent in the defense budget, signifying that the Pentagon will once again emerge victorious in the annual military debate on Capitol Hill.

title: Chess: The Great Moment Arrives, Then Vanishes for Evans
description: Larry Evans's moment for glory came and went in the 11th round of the United States championship at the LaSalle Hotel in Chicago. Paired with the tournament leader, Walter Browne, Evans could not come up with the victory that would have enabled him to share first place.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS CONFER ON RULES FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Congressional leaders met in closed session today to plan the next moves in both houses that eventually could remove President Nixon from office.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 856536

title: Poll Finds Jackson Would Achieve Tie In Race With Ford
description: If Vice President Ford and Senator Henry M. Jackson were to oppose each other in a Presidential election today, each would poll about 42 per cent of the vote, according to a Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: GOVERNORS BACK FUND DISCLOSURE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 The Governors of 12 Middle Western states endorsed today legislation that would require all candidates for state and Federal offices to disclose their income and net worth.

title: Air Force Spurns State Rule
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 31 (AP) The Air Force said today that it would not be bound by state environmental laws in the planning and building of a huge experimental radar complex in central Maine. In a statement, the Air Force said that it would cooperate with state and local environmental agenoies, but that it was not required to apply for state and local air and water pollution control permits or licenses for the construction or operation of facilities.

title: WAGNER ENDORSES CAREY CANDIDACY
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner endorsed Representative Hugh L, Carey for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday, saying Mr. Carey was free of boss ties and obligations.

title: CutRate Token Sales by Banks Among Yunich's Transit Plans
description: David L. Yunich, the longtime department store executive who became chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in May, is starting a merchandising program to attract new riders by having banks and businesses offer tokens at reduced rates.

title: Gullett Quiets Astro Bats To Tune of 40 Triumph
Brooklyn Youth Cangs Concentrating on Robbery
description: Six hardcore, antisocial youth gangs are responsible for more than half of the criminal gang activity in northern Brooklyn, a Police Department gang intelligence officer said yesterday.

title: Pitcher Is Knocked Out in 5th, Gives Up All Runs
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have yet to join Seaver's Believers this season.

title: Transitional Crown Heights Now in Midst of Comeback
description: The newsstand at Utica Avenue and Easten Parkway, one of Brooklyn's busiest intersections, tells the story of Crown Heights in a glance. Besides the city's mass circulation dailies, the stand carries thick piles of Jewish, Hebrew, West Indian, Haitian, black, Spanish and Chinese newspapers, which are snapped up briskly by the polyglot population of the neighborhood.

title: Texas Purse Snatchers Operate Off Motorcycle
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (AP)The motorcycle purse snatchers have struck.

title: FARM PRICES UP BY 6% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP Prices of raw farm products jumped 6 per cent from June15 to July 15 after four months of decline and averaged 1 percent above a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: COMMITTEE DRAMA INTERESTS EUROPE
description: LONDON, July 31  France was preoccupied with prison riots, Britain with Labor party squabbles, West Germany with traffic restrictions in Berlin, and all of Europe, of course, with Cyprus.

title: MidAtlantic Rift Vailey Found Spreading an Inch a Year
description: PONTA DELGADA, the Azores, July 31  Intensive manned exploration of the Me. dian Rift Valley that bisects the Atlantic Ocean has, according to the participants in dives, provided firm evidence that the valley is spreading away from its center line at the rate of about an inch a year.

title: Mrs. Hodge Indicted for Murder In Husband's Slaying in October
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted the widow of George Howard Hodge, a rockmusic arranger, on charges that she and two accomplices strangled Mr. Hodge in the couple's apartment near Lincoln Center nearly nine months ago.

title: Argentina Is Buying 3 Big TV Stations
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 31The Argentine Government has reached agreement to purchase the three nationwide privately owned television stations. Negotiations on details began today.

title: NBC Buys an AngloItalian Series on the Life of Jesus
description: A series of six onehour programs on the lire of Jesus, coproduced in Italy and Britain, has been purchased by NBCTV for presentation during Easter of 1976. The General Motors Corporation has already committed itself to full sponsorship of the programs, which will not be interrupted for commercials.

title: Huey Newton Hurt in Brawl
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 31 (UPI)Huey P. Newton, Black Panther party cofounder, was taken in leg irons to a hospital for treatment today after being arrested in a brawl with two black vice squad officers that ended with eight persons in ail. Mr. Newton and his 400bound, 6 foot 8 bodyguard, Robert Heard, were charged with assault with a deadly weapon, resisting an officer, conspiracy and other offenses.

title: California Standard's Earnings Up by 57% in Second Quarter
description: The Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday a 57 per cent increase in earnings for the second quarter and a 73 per cent advance in the first half over the comparable periods of last year.

title: Ford Quarter Net Slides 57% From '73
description: DETROIT, July 31The Ford Motor Company reported toJay that secondquarter earnings totaled $168million, a decline of 57 per cent from last year.

title: Transitional Crown Heights Now in Midst of Comeback
description: The newsstand at Utica Avenue and Easten Parkway, one of Brooklyn's busiest intersections, tells the story of Crown Heights ih glance. Besides: the city's mass circulation dailies, the stand, carries thick piles of Jewish, Hebrew, West Indian, Haitian, black, Spanish and Chinese newspapers, which are snapped up briskly by the polyglot population of the neighborhood.

title: Motion to Censure Premier Fails in Japan's Upper House
description: TOKYO, July 31 (Reuters)The upper house of Parliament tonight turned down an Opposition motion censuring Premier Kakuei Tanaka.

title: Mayor Swears In 2 Judges
description: Mayor Beame swore in two Family Court judges yesterday at City Hall. Before the ceremony, the Mayor had reappointed Philip B. Thurston to a third full 10year term in Manhattan Family Court. His salary is $42,451 a year. Mr. Beame also appointed Yorka Condeles Linakis, who served last year as an interim appointee to the Civil Court, to the Queens Family Court.

title: A MIGRANT CAMP CLOSED AS UNFIT
description: BRIDGETON, July 31Judge Philip A. Gruccio of Cumberland County Superior Court ordered a migrantlabor camp near here closed today as unfit for human habitation.

title: Man in Charge of Vault So Confident That He Left for Wedding in Florida
description: When the investigation into 65.4million in missing securities started two weeks ago, the longtime civil servant in charge of the vault where the securities were supposed to be was so sure nothing was missng that he refused to forgo a visit to Florida for a niece's wedding.

title: LoanTerm Accord of Grumman and Navy Helps Ease F14 Controversy in Congress
description: The Navy's new agreement with the Grumman Corporation under which the producer of the controversial F14 fighter plane would pay higher interest and submit to controls in the use of Government loans apparently has mollified most Congressional critics who had objected to a proposed additional $100million loan to Grumman.

title: Sets Win, 2725, As Women Star
description: UNIONDALE, LI., July 31 The New York Sets parlayed a 6.1 winning women's doubles performance by Virginia Wade and Sharon Walsh into, a 2725 victory over the Cleveland Nets in World Team Tennis match tonight before 1,702 fans in the Nassau Coliseum. The WadeWalsh combination beat Laura DuPont and Winnie Shaw Woodridge to provide New York with a 20.13 cushion.

title: Dance: Variant Giselle
description: Despite its eccentricities, Peter Wright's version of Giselle reveals a clean dramatic conception that rewards even those who cherish the more dancefilled traditional version. Veronica Tennant danced sparklingly as the ill  used Giselle and Rudolf Nureyev partnered suavely Tuesday evening in this first appearance of the work during the current National Ballet of Canada engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Music: Seeking Surprises in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I. July 31Hot weather, tourists, the America's Cup trials, parties all over the placeand, currently in progress, the sixth Newport Music Festival. This is the little festival held in the salon manner, in the great houses of Newport. Which is just as well, for a good deal of the music on the programs is admittedly salon. Summer after summer the Newport Music Festival continues to concentrate on minor and longforgotten 19thcentury composers.

title: U. S. Reactions in Cyprus Crisis: 2 Versions
description: WASHINGTON, July 31As so often happens when United States diplomacy deals with a major, fastbreaking crisis, details of what action Washington took on the Cyprus situation remain obscure even after the eventeither by design or in honest confusion.

title: Impeachment Process Enters Second Stage
description: WASHINGTON, July 31For all practical purposes, the first stage of the impeachment proceedings ended last night with the House Judiciary Committee's final vote. The second stage, a decision by the full House of Representatives, thus became inevitable  notwithstanding the possible White House strategy described today by President Nixon's aides.

title: NORMAN SILVERSTEIN
description: Dr. Norman Silverstein, professor of English at Queens College, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital, following a heart attack suffered last month. He was 52 and lived at 10 West 66th Street.

title: Little First Jet Starter to Penetrate Line
description: The united front put up by the Jets' first  stringers suffered a track yesterday when John Little, a deferslive tackle, became the first regular to report to camp.

title: XRay Rules Set To Spare Patients Unneeded Dosages
description: WASHINGTON, July 31,The Food and Drug Administration today published rules designed to save millions of Americans unnecessary dosages of medical and dental Xrays.

title: CutRate Token Sale by Banks Planned
description: David L. Yunich, the longtime department store executive who became chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in May, is starting a merchandising program to attract new riders by having banks and businesses offer tokens at reduced rates.

title: Suspected Arsonist Seized
description: NEW HAVEN, July 31 (UPI) The police today charged Fred Paluzzi, 20 years old, of Woodbridge, Conn., with having started the $1.5million fire at the Amity shopping center in New Haven last March 23. The fire caused heavy damage to seven stores in the shopping center, many of which are being rebuilt. Officials did not say why Mr. Paluzzi allegedly set fire to the shopping center.

title: Mixed Panel Drawing the Truce. Lines on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31A mixed military commission began drawing the lines between Turkish troops and Greek Cypriote forces today and President Glafkos Clarides of Cyprus declared that ceasefire concessions made by Greek Cypriotes had been very hard to bear.

title: Jersey To Hold Sweeps
description: New Jersey fired another salvo in its gambling war with New York yesterday by hitching its state lottery to a horse race that will be run next Oct. 26 at Monmouth Park.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: CHARLES A. LAMB
description: Charles A. Lamb, manager of press services for the Exxon Corporation, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Rockefeller Center last evening. He was 59 years old and lived at 606 Marietta Avenue, Thronwood, N.Y.

title: Reporters Play a Role in Siege at Prison
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., July 31  News reporters have become participants in a psychological clash between Texas prison officials and three armed inmates who have demanded freedom from the Huntsville State Prison in exchange for the lives of 13 hostages they have held for a week in the prison library.

title: ARMS BUDGET CUT 3% BY HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee has made a largely symbolic cut of 3.5 per cent in the defense budget signifying that the Pentagon will once again emerge victorious in the annual military debate on Capitol Hill.

title: Air Fares to Europe Up 5%; Third Increase in 7 Months
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board raised air fares yesterday between most American cities and Europe by 5 per cent and between Miami and Europe by per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: Stocks Drop by 8.14 to 757.43 To Approach a FourYear Low
description: Stock prices retreated along a broad front yesterday with the DowJones industrial average declining 8.14 points to 757.43, its lowest closing level in almost four years.

title: Agnew Gets Approval From U.S. to Own Gun
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew won Government approval today to own a gun.

title: Politics and Big Money: A Perilous Relationship
description: TRENTON, July 31  The indictment of another New Jersey Secretary of State on corruption charges illuminates once again the precarious and perilous relationship of aggressive politics and big money.

title: Detroit, Where Life Is Worth Living
description: DETROITFor months busing con sumed the Detroit area. How the hatred rose, a quilt that smothered the region!

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE NIXON ON DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A group of prominent Democrats has accused the Nixon Administration of seeking partisan advantage from its relations with the Soviet Union and of creating a myth of detente instead of adequately warning Americans about threats posed by the Soviet Union.

title: Bethlehem Steel Dividend Raised 10c as Net Climbs
description: The nation's No. 2 steelmaker, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, followed the United States Steel Corporation yesterday by one day in announcing an increase in its quarterly dividend.

title: Company Head Testifies In Fort Lee Bribe Case
description: NEWARK, July 31Norman Dansker, president and chairman of the Investors Funding Corporation, a large New York realestate investment and development concern, testified for more than two hours yesterday before a Federal grand jury here investigating the alleged attempt by shoppingcenter developers to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee.

title: MILLIONS MISSING FROM CITY VAULT WERE NEVER LOST
description: A special task force investigating the mystery of the $5.4million in securities reported missing from a city vault said yesterday that it had cracked the caseby tracing the discrepancy to sloppy bookkeeping in the Controller's office.

title: FrenchSoviet Pact Set
description: MOSCOW July 31 (UPI)France and the Soviet Union signed today a $220million agreementtheir largest ever to build four ammonia plants in the Soviet Union, French officials said. The agreement with the CreusotLoire enterprise calls for a combined production of about 1.8 million tons of ammonia per year.

title: ExHead of Milk Coop Pleads Guilty of Plot to Bribe Connally
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The former head of the nation's largest milk cooperative pleaded guilty today to a charge that he conspired to bribe former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, who was indicted Monday on a charge of accepting $10,000 in illegal payments.

title: 3 Americans Leave Goodyear In Argentina Over Cuba Exports
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)The three American officers of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's Argentine manufacturing subsidiary in Buenos Aires have resigned, because of conflicting United States and Argentine laws, the State Department said today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SHORT HILLS, July 31  Barely 5 feet 1 inch tall, Kathy Lindethal is called the little one by friends. When she gets up on a diving board, three or 10 meters above the water, she looks even smaller. However, her diving talents as well as her accomplishments belie her size.

title: Woman Slain on IRT Platform As Gun in Falling Bag Goes Off
description: A woman standing on an IRT elevated platform in the Bronx was shot and killed yesterday morning when a fellow passenger dropped a shoulder bag containing a pistol that discharged when the bag hit the platform.

title: Major League Leaders
description: (Includes games of July 30.)

title: Future of 35c Fare Remains Unclear
description: Does the rebuff by the House of Representatives to the $800million transitsubsidy bill mean that the 35cent fare here will go up next year?

title: CORN FUTURES UP THE DAILY LIMIT
description: The United States Weather Bureau's 30day forecast fa continued hot, dry weather in the Middle West and South west growing areas helped pus?? corn and soybean prices up th?? daily permissible limits yesterday on the Chicago Board o?? Trade.

title: Bargaining Continues In N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Aug. 1 (AP)Negotiations in the National Football League labr dispute moved into the early hours this morning with no signs of a resolution to the 32dayold strike and no word on what transpired behind closed doors in the daying meeting among the players, owners and the nation's top Federal mediator.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HATS OFF The hard hats are returning to the World Trade Center. This may not be startling news, but the format they're returning with is a bit unusual. Today marks the opening of a short exhibition titled Hard Hats in the Arts, a showing of art work by construction workers connected with the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Harmon Wins U.S. Pistol Title

title: FRANK A. KELLY
description: Frank A. Kelly, president of Frank A. Kelly Associates of Montclair, N.J., agents for the wire and cable industry, died Tuesday at the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research. He was 47 and lived at 200 Midland Avenue in Montclair.

title: Prospective Teachers Urged to Go Overseas
description: BOSTON, July 31 (AP)State Secretary of Education Joseph M. Cronin urged prospective teachers today to seek jobs overseas in the face of a sharply declining birth rate and a tight job market in Massachusetts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Soviet Vetoes U.N. Resolution Widening Duties of Cyprus PeaceKeeping Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31  The Soviet Union ?? a resolution tonight that would have enabled the United Nations peace force on Cyprus to take on expanded duties under the new Geneva agreement.

title: ExHead of Milk Coop Pleads Guilty in Plot to Bribe Connally
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The former head of the nation's largest milk cooperative pleaded guilty today to a charge that he conspired to bribe former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, who was indicted Monday on a charge of accepting $10,000 in illegal payments.

title: Market Averages
description: Wednessday, July 31, 1974

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Fishing, except in a most. peripheral way, should not be a competitive sport, nor should it be pursued with unswerving intensity.

title: Falstaff Is Dunked, Beaten and Singed Under the Stars
description: Poor unvirtuous, fat Falstaff! He is insulted, abused and made the fool; buried in a bin of soiled laundry and dumped into the Thames; pummeled while dressed in woman's clothes; singed with a taper. Does the old reprobate really deserve The Merry Wives of Windsor?

title: HOPE FOR CHANGE HELD RUNOFF KEY
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., July 31  A desire for change was credited today with the unexpected political success of South Carolina's new Democratic nominee for Governor, Charles D. Ravenel.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: House Panel Votes to Bar Eximbank Loans to Turks
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters)The House of Representatives Banking Committee today voted to bar all loans by the United States ExportImport Bank for Turkey until she agreed to stop growing opium poppies used in the production of heroin.

title: Dismissal of Otepka's Suit Upheld by Appeals Court
description: RICHMOND, July 31 (AP)A Federal appeals court upheld today a lower court's dismissal of a libel suit filed against The New York Times by Otto F. Otepka, a former State Department security official.

title: HelpWanted Index Up 1 Point to 116 in Jane
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that the helpwantedadvertising index rose 1 point in June to 116 per cent of the 1967 average, but stood 7 points below the level of June, 1973.

title: Impeachment Threat Held Disturbing for the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) President Nixon's chief economic policy coordinator said today that the threat of impeachment exerted a disturbing influence on the economy by creating uncertainty in nation's business community.

title: Retiring House Members Find Impeachment Issue Still Tough
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Representative Howard W. Robison, Republican of upstate New York, does not have to worry about political fallout in voting on impeachment. He is not seeking reelection.

title: Advertising: The 1984 Woman
description: At the behest of a major clientand no other behests are as impressive  Kenyon & Eckhardt has pulled together data from every conceivable source to predict what kind of a market the American woman will be a decade hence.

title: Shop Talk
description: The large glasswalled lobby of Lever House is filled with a good deal more than plants at the moment: it is also the site of the crafts show put on every year by ArtistCraftsmen of New York.

title: Nixon Studies Bid to Avoid House Debate on Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 President Nixon is considering a shift of strategy in which he would try to bypass an impeachment debate in the House of Representatives and take his case directly to the Senate for quick resolution, White House officials said today.

title: Music
description: It was Pierre Boulez's turn to conduct the New York Philharmonic at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night, and his appearance, a WagnerBeethovenStravinsky program, a nearly full moon, warm weather and, perhaps, a quantity of X factors, combined to insure a big picnic turnout for the event. There may have been many thousands fewer than showed up for Andre Kostelanetz and fireworks the week before, but the numbers were enormous nonetheless. Indeed, this reporter is inclined to feel that this sort of outdoor concert phenomenon is of sociological rather than artistic significance.

title: Music
description: It was Pierre Boulez's turn to conduct the New York Philharmonic at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night, and his appearance, a WagnerBeethovenStravinsky program, a nearly full moon, warm weather and, perhaps, a quantity of X factors, combined to insure a big picnic turnout for the event. There may have been many thousands fewer than showed, up for Andre Kostelanetz and fireworks the week before, but the numbers were enormous nonetheless. Indeed, this reporter is inclined to feel that this sort of outdoor concert phenomenon is of sociological rather than artistic significance.

title: Greece's Left Returning to Political Life
description: ATHENS, July 31  After more than seven years of repression under military dictatorship, the political left in Greece is returning to public life, with varying degrees of confidence and caution, through statements and news conferences.

title: Blind Subway Riders Protest Lack of Gates
description: Thirty blind subway riders and their escorts, protesting a lack of safeguards in some new subway cars, yesterday picketed an IND Station at Second Avenue and Houston Street where a blind man was killed by a train July 13.

title: Maybellene, Quaze Quilt Win at Spa
Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest weekly report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make such a list available yesterday.

title: CIRCLE IN SQUARE FILES ON SCAPINO
description: Circle in the Square, Inc., the nonprofit company of which Theodore Mann is artistic director, has filed an application in Manhattan Supreme Court to prevent the transfer of its production rights to Scapino to another management.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market fell acrosstheboard yesterday under the con tinuing weight of investors concern over the economy.

title: TURKISH TROOPS SHELL AND SEIZE 2 CYPRUS TOWNS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31Turkish forces violated the ceasefire today by shelling the central northern coastal village of Lapithos from a warship and then advancing ?? it with troops, official Greek Cypriote sources charged today.

title: Notes on People
description: The oftenoutspoken Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, suggested yesterday that if illinformed, fuzzythinking crusaders really want Americans to cut their living standards in order to save grain for hungry people abroad, they might start by reducing half the nation's 62 million dogs, cats and horses.

title: Market Basket Rose By 0.5% Last Week; Meats Up Sharply
description: Higher prices for most food items led to an increase of 0.5 per cent in the cost of feeding a family of four in the city last week.

title: Farm Prices Up 6%
description: Prices of raw farm products climbed 6 per cent from June 15 to July 15 after four months of declines, the Agriculture Department reported. Details on Page 35.

title: Increase in Productivity Reverses 1Year Trend
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The nation's productivity, or output per manhour, showed a small increase in the second quarter after four consecutive quarters of decline or no growth, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Irate Spectator Calle Noisy House to Order
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)House members, who often chat with each other and pay little attention during debate, were called to order today by a spectator in the gallery.

title: Smith's Party Wins A Sweeping Victory In Rhodesian Voting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 31 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's ruling Rhodesian Front has won total victory in a general election that has temporarily cleared the political atmosphere but left the country's longterm problems unresolved.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted the widow of George Hodge, a rockmusic arranger, on charges that she and two accomplices murdered Mr. Hodge in the couple's apartment near Lincoln Center nearly eight months ago.

title: Exxon Dividend Up 15c, To $1.25 in 3d Quarter
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, announced yesterday that it was raising its thirdquarter dividend to $1.25 a share, a 15cent advance over the $1.10 a share paid in March and June this year.

title: NORMAN L. BEERS
description: Norman L. Beers, who was a purchasing agent for the Western Electric Company for 37 years until his retirement last year, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Barnabas Medical Center In Livingston, N. J. He was 60 years old and lived on Whippany Road in Morristown, N. J.

title: Child Agency Chief Named
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Betti S. Whaley, former director of community development programs for the National Urban League, as commissioner of the Agency for Child Development. She succeeds Georgia McMurray, whose resignation became effective yesterday. She will receive $38,771 a year.

title: Personal Finance: Paying Funeral Bills
description: Funeral expenses and misunderstandings about them are one of the major causes of complaints made at the New York State Attorney General's office here.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC LIFTS ITS INCOME
description: The Southern Pacific Company, which operates the second largest (revenues) railroad in the country after the Penn Central, reported yesterday that it had succeeded in the second quarter in reversing a recent trend of increased expenses exceeding revenue gains.

title: Pedestrian Mall Is Planned
description: BIENNA (AP)  The city has announced plans to turn Kaerntnerstrasse, the Fifth Avenue of Vienna, into a pedestrian mall. The concept calls for an area where shoppers can stroll in a serene atmos phere, completely free of noise and air pollution.

title: Franklin Bank to Cut Staff
description: Reports that a major staff reduction was imminent at the Franklin National Bank were confirmed yesterday by Arthur G. Perfall, senior vice president of the bank. He said the reduction would involve 500 to 600 jobs.

title: Safety Tips for Women
description: The sexcrimes analysis unit urges women to observe the following safety measures:

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GETTING GAME, How to Get Things for Practically Nothing. 158 pages. Harper Row. $6.95. By George Daniels.

title: Halliburton and MCA Earnings Reach Records
Ehrlichrnan Is Sentenced To 20 Months to 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 John D. Ehrlichman, formerly President Nixon's chief adviser on domestic affairs, was sentenced today to 20 months to 5 years in prison for his role in what Judge Gerhard A. Gesell called a shameful episode in the history of this country.

title: Huskies Keeping Kanzlers Busy
description: Showing Siberian huskies is a family project with the Kanzlers. At a recent event, Trish, who is 18 years old, handled the winners bitch; John, 16, the winning puppy dog; Mrs. Kathleen Kanzler took the blue with a bitch in the open class, and Sheila, 14, showed a champion.

title: Grand Central Oyster Bar Shut, but May Reopen Soon
description: Another of the city's amenities went into limbo yesterday when the Oyster Bar and Restaurant at Grand Central Terminal closed suddenly.

title: People and Business
description: Joseph A. Rice, who is 49 years old, has been named president and chief administrative officer of the Irving Trust Company. He succeeds Arthur G. Boardman Jr., 64, who has been named vice chairman of the board.

title: LOEWS UNCERTAIN OF DEAL FOR CNA
description: The Loews Corporation expressed some doubt yesterday that it would be able to pursue its tender offer for 20 miltion shares of the CNA Financial Corporation. In a statement following the decision Tuesday of the Insurance Department of Illinois approving Loews's application, Loews said that it hoped that the board of CNA will now take constructive and responsible action to facilitate communication of the offer to shareholders in the best interest of shareholders and policyholders.

title: Trade Commission Assails Ads By Car Makers on Fuel Saving
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The Federal Trade Commission objected today to a series of fuel economy claims made by major American automobile manufacturers in the energy crisis early this year.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: New Jersey Secretary of State Indicted on BidRigging Charge
description: TRENTON, July 31  J. Edward Crabiel, the Secretary of State for New Jersey, was indicted today along with another man and three companies on charges of rigging highway construction bids.

title: Run in 8th Pins Loss On Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, July 31The New York Yankees, although frustrated by double plays for four consecutive innings, finally found the right combination of offense and defense to end their fivegame losing streak and topped the Milwaukee ?? ewers, 43, tonight before a crowd of 14,836 at County Stadium.

title: 5 MINUTES LOST FROM A KEY TALK
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The White House told Judge John J. Sirice today that more than five minutes of a Presidential conversation of April 17, 1973, had not been preserved by White House taperecording equipment.

title: DISTRIBUTION SUIT FILED AGAINST MGM
description: MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc.'s withdrawal from the motion picture distribution business late last year and its resulting distribution arrangements with other companies, were attacked earlier this week In a $66million lawsuit filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California.

title: CIRCLE IN SQUARE FILES ON SCAPINO
description: Circle in the Square, Inc., the nonprofit company of which Theodore Mann is artistic director, has filed an application in Manhattan Supreme Court to prevent the transfer of its production rights to Scapino to another management.

title: Stars Injure Two Shark Quarterbacks In the Dark Here and Triumph, 2416
description: Emerging from the obscurity of South Gwinnett High School in Snellville, Ga. Mars Hill College in the Appalachian Mountains of North Carolina; the inactive squad of the Jacksonville Sharks and the dim lights of Downing Stadium, Jeff Davis almost became a hero last night.

title: India Names Cup Team
description: NEW DELHI, July 31 (Reuters)India selected today a fourman team for the Davis Cup tennis interzone semifinal against the Soviet Union, to be played in this country in September. Named were Vijay Amritraj, Anand Amritraj, his brother; Jasjit Singh and Shashi Menon.

title: Liguori 2d As 5 Break 4 Minutes
description: OSLO, Norway, July 31 (AP)Five men, including Marty Liguori and Dick Buerkle of the United States broke the 4minute barrier in the mile today during the Martin Luther King Memorial track and field meet.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS CONFER ON RULES FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Congressional leaders met in closed session today to plan the next moves in both houses that eventually could remove President Nixon from office.

title: FRENCH JAIL RIOT LEAVES TWO DEAD
description: PARIS, July 31 (AP)  Two prisoners were killed today in France's twoweek wave of prison riots as the Government pressed forward on a program to humanize prisons and help released prisoners return, to normal life.

title: Ballet: Curious Details in Swan Lake
description: For sheer dancing, Natalya Makarova's and Ivan Nagy's first appearance this season in American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater was pure joy.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Leonidoff Is Retiring From the Music Hall
description: Leon Leonidoff, a leading member of the Radio City Music Hall's staff since its opening Dec. 27, 1932, retires today as a vice president and chief producer of stage shows.

title: People in Sports
description: The surprise showing of the Philadelphia Phillies, pacesetters in the National League Eastern Division, has benefited Manager Danny Ozark. Philadelphia extended Ozark's contract through 1976 yesterday with a substantial pay increase. He has done an outstanding job in bringing this club along, said Paul Owens, director of player personnel. His club last year was much improved over 1972 and this year we're right in the middle of everything.

title: Democrat Offers SixPoint Plan On Economy in Reply to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. of Texas said tonight that the Nixon Administration had engaged in too many trials and far too many errors in economic policy and had proved as bad for business as for the working people.

title: WITNESS DISPUTES RINALDI ON TALK
description: An assistant district attorney in Brooklyn testified yesterday in the trial of State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi that the justice had told him off the record in March, 1973, that he would not change the sentence of a convicted burglar who was asking for reduced sentence.

title: Ehrlichman Is Sentenced To 20 Months to 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 John D. Ehrlichman, formerly President Nixon's chief adviser on domestic affairs, was sentenced today to 20 months to 5 years in prison for his role in what Judge Gerhard A. Gesell called a shameful episode in the history of this country.

title: The Screen: A Disarming Bank Shot
description: Though at this point in history caper movies are less easily remembered than individual blades of grass, Gower Champion's Bank Shot is a disarming exception. It's not a great movie. It's not worth taking a taxi to see. Yet there are many less invigorating ways to waste one's time.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON PENSION REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  SenateHouse conferees agreed tonight on a pension reform bill that its advocates said would insure that American workers actually receive the pensions they contribute to.

title: The Inflation Vacation: Closer to Home and a Little Shorter
description: Last year Marvin and Penny Verbell spent their vacation at the luxurious El San Juan Hotel in Puerto Rico. This year they will go to a Howard Johnson motel in Lancaster, Pa.

title: TV: Two Midsummer Bright Spots
description: At this parched point in midsummer television viewing, CBS rates a small halo on two counts. One is a fiveweek revival of Your Hit Parade, starting at 8 tomorrow night, that fetchingly revamps old favorites with a dutiful handful of current songs added. The other is the extremely pleasant adventout of nowhereof three personable imp  musicians named the Hudson Brothers as a summer replacement for Sonny and Cher in a variety show that had its premiere last night.

title: Bell Workers Seen Authorizing Strike By Heavy Majority
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  Telephone workers appeared today to have voted overwhelmingly to authorize a nationwide strike against the Bell Telephone System. No date for a walkout was set.

title: Drifter Pleads Not Guilty In Murder of Detective
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 31 (AP) Roger Hayes, a 31yearold drifter who is charged with the murder of an offduty Mount Vernon detective, pleaded not guilty today in Westchester County Court.

title: SIX BLACKS WARN ON WALLACE IN '76
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31The Democratic party was warned last night by six black officials that under no circumstances could they support Presidential ticket that included Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: BRITISH SHIPPING FACES TAKEOVER
description: LONDON, July 31  The British Government announced plans today for the nationalization of the shipbuilding, ship repairing and marine engineering industries, and the stock market immediately sank to a 15year law.

title: Special Persecution Force
description: WASHINGTONIf we believe in the jury system, we must believe that a rich, white Southern Republican like John Connally will get a fair trial from a jury in Washington, D. C., that is predominantly poor, black, and votes overwhelmingly Democratic.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL ON GOLD OWNERSHIP
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters)Congress gave final approval today for Americans to own gold when the House passed a Senatesponsored amendment.

title: Millions in India Still Live in Bondage Despite, Government Effort
description: AMHARA, IndiaAt dawn the peasants leave their mud huts in this Bihar village to go to the rice fields, where they work until dark without tractors or fertilizer.

title: Nixon Gets Education Bill With Busing Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The House of Representatives, by a surprisingly large margin, approved today a major education bill that contained a compromise provision aimed ?? limiting the busing of children to achieve school desegregation.

title: Court Bars Move to Close Outpatient Abortion Clinic
description: JERSEY CITY, July 31 Judge Sidney M. Schreiber today permitted the state's first fullfledged outpatient abortion clinic to continue to operate here without a license. At the same time, the clinic and six others were notified that they would receive provisional state licenses.

title: 2 Are Seized in Barn Fire
description: MOUNT LAUREL, July 31 (AP)Two 20yearold men have been arrested and charged with setting a sevenalarm fire that destroyed a barn and caused about $75,000 in damage, the police said. The suspects, George W. Forbour and John Garlander both of this Burlington County community, are being held in Burlington County Jail in lieu of $10,000 bail each

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, AUGUST 1, 1974
description: International

title: Jersey Secretary of State Indicted for BidRigging
description: TRENTON, July 31  J. Edward Crabiel, the Secretary of State for New Jersey, was indicted today along with another man and three companies on charges of rigging highway construction bids.

title: An Explanation: How 3 Articles Sum Up Charges and Evidence
Events Today
description: Music

title: FRENCH DECLARED QUEBEC LANGUAGE
description: OTTAWA, July 31Legislation making French the only official language in the Province of Quebec, where French is spoken by more than 80 per cent of the population, became law today after a long, bitter and divisive controversy.

title: Byrne to Decide on Use Of Prisoners at Hospital
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1In an effort to decide whether to allow 90 inmates from Leesburg State Prison to live and work at the Ancora psychiatric hospital, Governor Byrne promised may ??rs and legislators from Glou??ester and Camden Counties ??oday that be would tour both acilities next week.

title: Shell Oil Co. Raises Wholesale Gas Price One Cent a Gallon
description: The Shell Oil Company raised the wholesale price of gasoline yesterday by 1 cent a gallon and of heating oil, diesel fuel, stove oil and kerosene by 1.4 cents a gallon. The company said that the increases were made according to the cost passthrough provisions of the Federal Energy Administration's pricing policies.

title: FLEETS WILL END TAXIDRIVER PACT
description: The city's taxifleet owners announced yesterday that they would terminate their contract with the Taxi Drivers Union as of midnight next Monday, thereby posing the possibility of a citywide taxi strike.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A group of Orthodox Jewish women in Lakewood, concerned about a religious injunction against bathing in the presence of men, have caught local officials off guard by requesting an allwomen's beach. John J. Franklin, a Township Committeeman, said yesterday the request had been turned down at first, but after a group of the women presented their case before local officials, it was reconsidered. It will come up for a vote at next Thursday's meeting, he said.

title: JUNE ORDERS FELL ON SOME MACHINERY
description: June orders for nonelectrical machinery dropped 9 per cent below the May level, the McGrawHill Department of Economics reported yesterday. The index, considered an important indicator of trends in industrial development, dipped to a seasonally adjusted 190 (1967 is taken as 100) from the'206 revised level in May. This also left the index 2 per cent below the June, 1973, level.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: Phone Company Challenged on Tax Bill
description: The tax colleotor of South Brunswick is challenging the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company over its method of paying corporate personal property taxes to the township.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: 2,000 on IRT Flee A RushHour Fire At Wall St. Station
description: Two thousand gasping and coughing subway riders groped their way out of the Wall Street station of the IRT Lexington Avenue line through acrid, blinding smoke at rush hour yesterday morning after an electrical fire broke out in a feeder cable leading to the third rail.

title: Elizabeth Davis, 64, Dies; Author of The First Sex
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 1 (AP)  Elizabeth G. Davis, author of the popular women's liberation book The First Sex, has died of a selfinflicted gunshot wound, the police said. She was 64 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: W. J. Usery Jr., chief of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, is regarded as a top practitioner of his art, a diplomatist who can ease frictions as axle grease reconciles hub to spindle. Theodore Kheel, labor counsel for the owners of the National Football League, is a negotiator of wide experience and celebrity. Ed Garvey and Bill Curry, the players' union leader and president, are articulate spokesmen for the labor force. In their efforts to resolve the dispute that has kept all but a few established players out of training camp, these experts do not need advice or instruction from this bystander. Nevertheless, there is a formula that has worked successfully in another professional sport. Football's disputants could do worse than emulate one of the arbitrators who fixed salaries in major league baseball last winter when players and employers couldn't agree. Peter Seitz, who heard and decided five cases, now reveals that h reached his conclusions through study, incantation and prayer.

title: Tax Unreform Bill
description: With Congress caught up in the high drama of impeachment, there is grave danger that essential reform of the nation's inequitable tax system may be forestalled.

title: Two Musicians Reinstated for a Year in Coast Dispute
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 The two nationally acclaimed members of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra who were denied tenure and, in effect, fired last May have been temporarily reinstated for one year, Joseph Scafidi, general manager of the symphony, announced here this week.

title: Marginal Cases at Least Worth a Try
description: Over the months, visiting anywhere from three to five restaurants a week and writing up only a couple as a rule, a reporter accumulates a file of places that have something to recommend them  sometimes a lotbut fail somewhere so that reviews don't seem justified.

title: Captivityfired Falcons Get Survival Lessons
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Aug. 1Two fledglings, peregrine falcong bred in captivity this spring, have been released here to learn to swoop and soar and hunt as the first lesson in their survival training for freedom.

title: U.S. SENATE DELAYS TOCKS DAM START
description: The United States Senate acted yesterday to delay further any start on construction of the $370million Tocks Island Dam, first authorized by Congress in 1962.

title: BRONX G.O.P. CHIEF CALLED A RENEGER
description: In a bizarre bipartisan deal, Patrick Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader, has endorsed the Bronx Republican leader, State Senator John D. Calandra, for reelection, but is now trying to undo the deal because of an alleged double cross.

title: RALPH H. KENNAN
description: WASHINGON, Aug, 1 (UPI)  Ralph H. Kennan, assistant managing editor of the Washington Bureau of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 42 years old.

title: Orantes, Gorman Gain at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 1 (UPI)The defending champion Manuel Orantes of Spain, defeated Jaime PintoBravo of Chile today, 6.3, 63, and moved into the third round of the $100,000 First National tennis classic.

title: Orantes, Gorman Gain at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 1 (UPI)The defending champion Manuel Orantes of Spain, defeated Jaime PintoBravo of Chile today, 63, 63, and moved into the third round of the $100,000 First National tennis classic.

title: Shepard Retires from Navy
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1 (AP)Rear Adm. Alan B. Shepard Jr. of Derry, N. H., retired from the Navy today after 30 years of service. Admiral Shepard, 51 years old, was America's first man in space and one of only a dozen men to explore the moon's surface. He plans to join the Marathon Construction Company of Houston as a partner and chairman.

title: DR. GEORGE N. WISE, OPHTHALMOLOGIST
description: Dr. George N. Wise, an ophthalmologist who was an authority on retinal vascular disease, died of a heart condition Wednesday evening at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 103 East 84th Street.

title: Indians Defeat Yankees
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 1The Indians taught the New York Yankees a strong lesson in the efficient use of offense tonight, bunching all of their 10 hits in three innings to roll to a 92 victory before a crowd of 16,178 at Municipal Stadium.

title: BARNES BAIL CASH WITHDRAWN HERE
description: The Detroit bondsman who recently put up $100,000 in cash to free a reputed narcotics figure here demanded his money back yesterday, and judge voided the bail. But three hours later, the prisoner, LeRoy Barnes, went free again on an insurance company's bond.

title: State Freeing Some Mentally Ill Convicts
description: Scores of mentally disturbed criminalssome of whom committed homicideare released almost routinely by the maximumsecurity Matteawan State Hospital to other state mental institutions, which, in turn, are discharging many of the inmates into communities for rehabilitation.

title: Turkish Truce
description: Turkey's continued violations of the Cyprus truce, right on the heels of a second ceasefire agreement, are an affront to its allies in NATO and the world community in the United Nations.

title: People in Sports
description: After watching Rodney Bobick pound out a onesided 10round decision over Ron Stander in Bloomington, Minn., for his 25th straight professional victory Wednesday night, Angelo Dundee, the seasoned trainer, has invited the 22yearold heavyweight to Miami Beachbut not for a vacation.

title: About New York
description: Subways are the arteries of New York, and they are things of which myths are made, too. In the movie Death Wish, a vigilante goes about looking for muggers, and knowing a thing or two about subways, he sets himself up to be mugged on one. He is mugged, of course, but then he zaps the muggers, and later gets a couple more on a subway platform. He is better, in fact, than any six cops.

title: 2d Closure Bid on Consumer Bill Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 Supporters of legislation to establish a, consumer protection agency failed today for the second time this week to force an end to debate in the Senate.

title: COLBY SCORES MOVE TO AMEND PRESS ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  William E. Colby, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that Congressional efforts to speed the declassification of Government documents would endanger the country's intelligence operations.

title: WALL ST, LEADERS SEEK U.S. AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 Four leaders of the securities and banking industries met with three top Administration officials here today and asked that a special new Governmerit office be created to insure continued vitality of the capital markets.

title: Notes on People
description: The director of the Peace Corps, Nicholas W. Craw, has resigned, effective the end of the month. Mr. Craw, a 37yearold bachelor who is an heir to the Smith & Wesson firearms fortune, was in the job slightly less than a year. A Republidan from Charlottesville Va., he has served for three years in other programs, including VISTA and the Office of Economic Opportunity. We're in good shape, he said of the Peace Corps, which he maintained has been growing solidly and steadily since its low point of 1972. It now has 6,800 volunteers serving in programs in 69 countries, Mr. Craw said.

title: Latest Tapes Data Vary From Prior Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1An analysis of the tape recordings of 20 White House conversadons prepared by President Nixon's chief defense lawyer appears at variance with the President's transcriptions of the tapes, other Presidential documents and sworn testimony.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: All Said and Done by Simone de Beauvoir (Putnam, $10). Volume five of an autobiography covering 196272.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City's taxifleet owners announced that they would go ahead with plans to terminate their contract with the Taxi Drivers Union as of midnight Monday, thereby posing the possibility of a citywide taxi strike.

title: Suspect Killed in IND Station Holdup
description: A holdup suspect was shot and killed by a plainclothes Transit Authority patrolman yesterday afternoon moments after the man had allegedly held up a change booth at the Church Avenue station of the IND line in Brooklyn.

title: New Jersey Sports
