description: U. S. Financial, Inc., announced yesterday that five whollyowned subsidiaries have filed petitions under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. The subsidiaries are the USF Capital Corporation, U. S. Guaranty Capital, U. S. Mortgage, Leasing Services, Inc., and the U.S. Financial Overseas N.V.

title: Revived Killing of Wild Horses for Pet Food Is Feared
description: RENOThe roundingup and slaughtering of wild horses for use as pet food may soon become legal again under changes proposed by the Nixon Administration in a Federal law enacted three years ago to save from extermination remnant herds of freeroaming horses and burros in the west.

title: PARENTS PROTEST PLAN AT LANE H.S.
description: Rezoning proposals by the central Board of Education aimed at correcting the racial imbalance at Franklin K. Lane High School drew criticism yesterday from parents and community activists from Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Canada and India Fad in Talks To End Rift Over Nuclear Blast
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 2A threeday conference of highlevel Indian and Canadian officials has failed to end the impasse between Ottawa and New Delhi over the Indian nuclear explosion last May in which material from a Canadian research reactor was used.

title: Mexico to Probe Charges Officials Are C.I.A. Agents
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  President Luis Echeverria Alvarez today ordered the Attorney General's department to investigate whether there are agents of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in the Government, a spokesman said.

title: Spokesman Terms Nixon Underdog in Current Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2President Nixon was described by a spokesman today as an underdog in the Congressional impeachment move.

title: Chemists Salute Priestley, 1774 Discoverer of Oxygen
description: American chemists have been celebrating an event this week in central Pennsylvania that revolutionized chemistry 200 years agothe discovery of oxygen.

title: HUGHES IS ORDERED TO APPEAR IN COURT
description: RENO, Nev., Aug. 2 (UPI)United States District Judge Bruce Thompson today ordered Howard R. Hughes and three others to appear in court Oct. 25 to answer a Federal indictrnent in connection with his acquisition of Air West Airlines.

title: President Calls for New Group To Monitor Wages and Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2President Nixon asked Congress today to establish by law a cost of living task force to replace the defunct Cost of ing Council but without mandatory wage and price powers.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: BRONX YOUTHS HELD IN GANGWAR KILLING
description: Two 17yearold youths were charged with murder last night, following a shooting war between two South Bronx street gangs that left one youth dead and another wounded, the police said.

title: Kent State Trial Delayed
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (AP)The trial of eight former Ohio National Guardsmen indicted in the shootings in 1970 of four students at Kent State University has been deferred from Sept. 30 to Oct. 15.

title: Notes on People
description: The latest great New Mexico treasure hunt for $250million in buried gold is off, according to Gov. Bruce King, because the United States Army has denied a party of wouldbe searchers permission to enter the White Sands missile range.

title: Jobs and Environment
description: In a scene reminiscent of the nineteenthirties, some 18,000 construction workers gathered in front of New Jersey's State House one day early this week to demand jobs. In a state with an 8 per cent unemployment rate and with 30 per cent of their own number out of work, the assembled hard hats were entitled not merely to a sympathetic hearing but to the promise of relief.

title: Volcano in Japan Kills 3
description: JOETSU, Japan, Aug. 2 (AP) Three climbers were killed when a dormant volcano erupted last Sunday 150 miles north of Tokyo, after 25 of silence, the police said to day.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Yanks Lose to Indians, 82; Droop Horne After 17 Trip
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 An eightgame road trip that the Yankees May remember grimly for a long while ended tonight with the Indians crushing New York, 82, before cheating crowd of 18,842 at Municipal Stadium. For the Yankees, it was their seventh loss against one victory since leaving home last Saturday.

title: A MusicLoving Insect Catches Violinist's Ear
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP)An insect flew into the ear of a violinist today and interrupted a rehearsal of Igor Stravinsky's Petrushka by the Philadelphia Orchestra. Irvin Rosen, violinist, left the Saratoga Performing Arts Center for a hospital, where the insect, identified as a greenleaf hopper, was removed.

title: UGANDA'S PRESIDENT DROPS INVASION PLAN
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 2 (UPI)President Idi Amin, who ordered his Sovietequipped army and air force on full alert yesterday, called off a threatened invasion of Tanzania today.

title: Nixon Sends Back the Savings Newark Couple Gave to Help
description: NEPTUNE CITY, Aug. 2 (AP) A retired roofer and his wife wanted to lend, without interest, their life savings and 22,000 pennies to President Nixon pennies everybody's throwing bricks at the poor guy and we wanted to help.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 2 INQUIRIES BEGUN ON GOLDIN CHARGE OF ALTERED BOOKS
description: Two rival inquiries began Yesterday into charges by Controller Harrison J. Goldin that the city's Investigation Commissioner had told a civil servant to put entries into a ledger that had not been there when auditors found $5.4million in discrepancies.

title: Cyril Smith, British. Pianist Who Overcame Paralysis
description: LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP)Cyril Smith, a British concert pianist who overcame paralysis to make a professional comeback, died of a heart attack today. He was 65 years old. Mr: Smith lost the use of his left arm after a stroke in 1956. He thereafter teamed with his wife, Phyllis, in a threehanded piano duo.

title: What Does He Want to Know That For
description: Let us try to imagine how hard it is being Vice President Ford these days. Here, to help in the exercise, is a summary of a meeting that might occur almost any day between the gentleman from Michigan and his old friend in the Oval Office.

title: Welsh Captures Best in. Show
description: LANSDALE, Pa., Aug. 2A 3yearold Welsh terrier, Ch. Licken Run's Two Pence Sam, owned and handled by Wilbert H. Etter of Quakertown, Pa., earned bestinshow laurels today in the Perkiomen Valley Kennel Club's 26th annual event on the grounds of the North Penn High School.

title: People in Sports
description: Willie Spencer, a 20yearold running back without any college experience, professes to be unworried about the competition from Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, when the two Miami Dolphins join him on the Memphis Southmen next season. I've got one thing, and he's got one thing, Spencer said of Csonka after rushing for 99 yards and scoring two touchdowns in Memphis's World Football League victory over Southern California Thursday night.

title: Bickering Hardens In Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  National Football League players and owners traded accusations today as the 33day strike continued with no settlement in sight on the eve of the first fullscale exhibition weekend.

title: House Panel Finishes Draft of Tax Revisions, With Rise in Oil Industry Levy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The House Ways and Means Committee completed work today on the first draft of a major revision of the tax laws, after first voting to incorporate in Its bill a new version of legislation it had approved earlier increasing the taxes of the oil industry.

title: Horse Show Awards
description: AT MIDDLETOWN, N. Y.

title: Naomi Becker, Designer And Sculptor, Dies at 47
description: Naomi Becker, an interior designer, a shopping consultant and a sculptor, died in New York Hospital on Wednesday. She was 47 years old and lived here and in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: DISCLOSURE LAW STIRS CHALLENGE
description: Citing concern about harassment, candidates of the Socialist Workers party for state and Federal offices declared yesterday they would not obey election law requirements for disclosure of campaign contributors.

title: QE2 Crossings to Increase
description: LONDON, Aug 2 (UPI)The British liner Queen Elizabeth 2 will increase transAtantic sailings next year by over a third, partly to compensate for the withdrawal of the liner France, Cunard announced today. She will make 31 crossings, 16 from Southampton and 15 from New York.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Friday, August 2, 1974

title: GREEKS AND TURKS CONFER IN CYPRUS OVER TRUCE ZONES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 2Greek and Turkish military delegates met, today to agree on buffer zones on Cyprus, where United Nations peacekeeping forces will separate troops that are still skirmishing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the courtordered conversion of Mark Twain Junior High School into a special school for the gifted we have yet another example of judicial assumption of the robe of omniscience in American education. By contrast, Justice Hugo Black in the, Des Moines armband case and Chief Justice Burger in the recent Detroit decision have admonished lowercourt judges not to deprive their local communities of control of their schools or substitute court judgment for that of the professional staff. Yet Judge Jack B. Weinstein steams right on to require what is an entirely new type of public school organization, a junior high school for the gifted.

title: 76th St. Hotel Managers Termed Fagins by state
description: The managers of the West Side Towers, a singleroomoccupancy hotel, were pictured as the Fagins in a chamber of horrors, spreading sickness, death and despair among community residents, in court papers filed against the owners and operators by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: 30,119 See Bills Lose To Packers
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Aug. 2 (UPI)  Jerry Tagge hit Steve Odom with a 50yard pass late in the first period, then went over from the 1 just after the second quarter began tonight to lead the Green Bay Packers to a 1613 victory over the Buffalo Bills in a National Football League preseason opener.

title: PRICES DAMPENED IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: For the second straight session, permissible daily declines were made by corn, soybeans and wheat in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, primarily because of rainfall.

title: MovingOut Expert Takes City to Task
description: The rapid outmigration of industry from New York City and the resulting slump in job opportunities can only be turned around by the city's adoption of a highpowered master plan, according to Leonard Yaseen, the dean of the industrial plant relocation business.

title: London Stocks Plunge To Mid1959 Depths
description: LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) Shares on the London Stock Exchange plunged further today to depths not seen since mid1959 as investors worried about inflation and political uncertainties. Prices have fallen more than 10 per cent in the last two weeks alone, wiping some $7.2billion off the valuations of leading companies.

title: CommodityPrice Index Up 10.2 to 247.4 in Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 247.4 from 237.2 last week.

title: Woman in Texas Jail Freed, 12 Hostages Remain
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 2Three armed inmates freed another hostage tonight from the library in the Huntsville State Firison where they have been holed up for nine days, a prison spokesman reported tonight.

title: ANSWERS ORDERED ON LB.M. DEALINGS
description: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, must answer Justice Department questions he refused to answer last March about three aspects of I.B.M.'s business, a Federal judge ordered yesterday.

title: Art: 6 Upstate Museums Join in Fine Show of American Works
description: BUFFALOThe AlbrightKnox Art Gallery here has a specific distinction: No other museum in the country has, in proportion to its size, a finer collection of the key works of the last 30 years. They are big works, almost without exception, and when the visitor has got through with Pollock, and with Still, and with Gorky, and with Johns, and with Rauschenberg, and with David Smith and Anthony Caro, he is likely to be impressed but winded. Rather than press on to see what has been cooking in the department of prints and drawings, he may well opt for a call at the museum's restaurant, where a prizewinning sandwich maker is on hand.

title: Dave Hill Leading With 134
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 2Dave Hill, who says all he wants to do is make enough money to meet his alimony payments, took the lead at the halfway stage of the $200,000 Pleasant Valley. Golf Classic today with a 65 for a 36hole total of 134. He is eight strokes under par and holds a twoshot lead over Tom Weiskopf, who also shot a 65.

title: Record Rate of 9% Put on U.S. Notes
description: The Treasury Department yesterday put a 9 per cent interest rate on $4billion of notes it plans to sell to investors next week. The rate is the highest on such a financing in the country's history for Treasury securities with maturities of more than one year.

title: LIQUIDATION IS SET FOR SHAMROCK CO.
description: ALBANY, Aug. 2 (UPI)State insurance superintendent Benjamin R. Schenck has obtained a court order permitting his department to liquidate the Shamrock Casualty Company.

title: New Zealand Driver Hurt
description: ADENAUR, West Germany, Aug. 2 (AP)  Howden Ganley of New Zealand was injured during initial training for the European Grand Prix today when his Britishbuilt Maki F101 Formula One racer spun off the Nuerburgring Eifel Mountain track. He suffered slight injuries to both feet and was taken to a nearby hospital.

title: The Ballet
description: The Grand Pas de Deux from Don Quixote is one of the staples of the international ballet repertory, and Natalya Makarova and Fernando Bujones performed it spectacularly Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Weisl Defends Queens Park on Kennedy Rail Link
description: Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. conducted a ramble through the wilds of Forest Park in Queens yesterday to make a spirited defense of his turf against plans for a 3,000foot rail passenger spur through a forested area.

title: People arid Business
description: It's purely a matter of personal desires, said Paul A. Conley, yesterday in announcing that he is leaving the chairmanship of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., after 40 years in the business. The, market, said Mr. Conley, doesn't have much to do with it. Neither, he added, does the firm's $13.4million losses after taxes (through May), which began two years ago, when Eastman Dillon took over Mr. Conley's old firm of Blyth &. Go.

title: India's Farmers Hit by Fertilizer Scarcity
description: CHANDIGARH, India, July 28  Charan Singh Maan, one of the farmers of the Punjao, India's most productive state, is frightened.

title: Dr. Lulu E. Sweigard Dies; Taught Dance at Juilfiard
description: Dr. Lulu E. Sweigard, since 1956 a member of the dance division of the Julliard School, specializing in posture and body alignment for young dancers, died Thursday at her home in Tomkins Cove, N. Y.

title: GREEKS AND TURKS CONFER IN CYPRUS OVER TRUCE ZONES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 2Greek and Turkish military delegates met today to agree on buffer zones on Cyprus, where United Nations peacekeeping forces will separate troops that are still skirmishing.

title: Accused on March of Dimes
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP)John C. Truxal, a retired banker and civic leader, was charged today with embezzling $28,589 from the Lancaster Chapter of the March of Dimes. The National Foundation of the March of Dimes said the alleged embezzlement may have been going on for the last 20 years and could involve as much as $80,000.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has received a $29.2million Navy contract for overhaul of the nuclearpowered attack submarine Skipjack.

title: Marichal Returns, Gives Red Sox Healthy Outlook
description: If one factor has been responsible for parity so far this season in the American League East  a division where the Baltimore Orioles are, generally conceded the title around Father's Dayit has been injuries to some key players.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS SHOW MIXED TONE
description: The stock market finished mixed in lethargic trading yesterday, which nevertheless was its best performance in seven sessions.

title: MORMONS PRESSED ON SCOUTS POLICY
description: SALT LAKECITY, Aug. 2 (UPI)Threatened with a civil rights suit, the Mormon Church revised today a policy that ex cluded blacks from the top leadership posts in churchsponsored Boy Scout troops.

title: Air Mail Is Facing Uncertain Future In Klassen's Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Like the Pony Express, the airmail stamp may soon fade into history.

title: Darby Dan's Star to Race Again Today
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 2 The public has seen nothing of Darby Dan Farm's Little Current since the Preakness and Belmont winner staged his two breathtaking comeback victories in May and early June.

title: CONSUMERS POWER IS DROPPING PLANT
description: The Consumers Power Company notified the Atomic Energy Commission yesterday that it is withdrawing its application to build a 2.3 million kilowatt nuclear plant near Quanicassee, Mich. Thus, Consumers made final a decision to cancel made tentatively on June 28.

title: Baskauskas to Aid Coach
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Mike Baskauskas of Yale, the third highest basketball scorer in the Ivy League last year, was named today as an assistant to the school basketball coach, Joe Vancisin.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KARLSTAD, Sweden, Aug. 2 (UPI)American athletes set three track records in the annual Tingsvalla track and field games tonight as Al Feuerbach, Steve Williams and Charles Foster won their events.

title: Secret Mine Union Talks Under Way on Coal Pact
description: NEW STANTON, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP)Harry Patrick, secretarytreasurer of the United Mine Workers of America, revealed today that secret contract discussions between the union and the basic coal industry began Wednesday in Washington.

title: A Bit of Luck, A Bit of Gall, You're Hired
description: Suzanne Eismann doesn't have a degree in education, still she taught elementary school for a year. She's had several jobs in the fashion business although she doesn't pretend to know much about clothes. She can't type; however, when she worked for Eliot Elisofon, the late photographer, she ran his office and answered his letters.

title: City's Loss on OTB Tax Put at $200,000 a Week
description: New York City is losing about $200,000 a week in revenue as a result of the 5 per cent surtax it imposed on offtrack payoffs, figures furnished, yesterday by the Offtrack Betting Corporation indicate.

title: Islands in the Sun
description: HEADQUARTERS, Allied Forces, (Naples), Southern Europethe latest Cyprus crisis again reminded the West that the Mediterranean is one of NATO's lifelines and that the lovely islands dotting its surface have a vital strategic function. Cyprus itself provides a base for British air forces although they cannot overtly work for the Alliance because of the republic's nonaligned status.

title: Crabiel Office Like Tomb For Aides After Indictment
description: The Trenton office of the Secretary of State of New Jersey was very, very quiet yesterday.

title: Stock Cars in Poconos: NewStyle Love Affair
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 2On a desolate piece of Yankee landscape, with nary a Confederate flag to wave in Southern breezes, the good old boys set up shop today in an attempt to show that bammin' and frammin' can be compatible with honeymooning.

title: Marcos Opens a Bank to Aid the Filipino Moslems
description: MANILA, Aug. 2President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in a dramatic bid for conciliation with Philippine Moslems whose violent acts in the south are one of the main concerns of his administration, today inaugurated a special bank that will lend them money at no interest.

title: MILK GIFTS LINKED TO HUMPHREY AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  An advertising executive, Barry Nova, has signed a statement saying that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign manager arranged for an illegal $12,000 corporate payment in 1970.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Charisma Sets Pace In Sailing
description: JAMESTOWN, B. I., Aug. 2 The New York Yacht Club cruise, racing down Buzzards Bay 81 strong in the fog, had some thrills and chills today.

title: Record Rate of 9% Put on U.S. Notes
description: The Treasury Department yesterday put a 9 per cent interest rate on $4billion of notes it plans to sell to inveltors next week. The rate is the highest on such a financing in the country's history for Treasury securities with may turities of more than one year.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Ioannides Is Released From Duty Six Months
description: ATHENS, Aug. 2 (Reuters) Brig. Gen. Demetrios loannides, strongman of Greece's deposed military regime, has been released from duty for six months, the armed forces high command announced here tonight.

title: Jobless Rate Edged Up to 5.3% in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The nation's unemployment rate edged upward in July while total employment remained stable, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Israeli Charges Egyptians Violated Disengagement
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 2Defense Minister Shimon Peres charged today that Egyptian military units had broken the troop disengagement agreement with Israel by conducting exercises in crossing the Suez Canal to the Sinai Peninsula.

title: U.S.Women Hold Lead In Curtis Cup Golf, 63
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP)  Maureen Walker, a Scottish teenager, upsetCarol Semple, but the United States team took a 63 point lead after today's opening matches in he 18th Curtis Cup ameteur golf competition.

title: JOSEPH H. FREDETTE
description: Joseph H. Fredette, market manager for aerosol container operations of the American Can Company, died yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., where he lived. His age was 57.

title: Venezuelan Bulgarian Ties
description: CARCACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  Venezuela and Bulgariasi gneda n agreement yesterday to estabilsh diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level. Venezuela established relations with China last month.

title: Rebozo With Nixon on Yacht
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) C. G. Rebozo, President Nixclose friend, arrived in Washington for a visit yesterday afternoon from his home at Key Biscayne, Fla. He and Mr. Nixon went for an evening cruise on the Potomac River aboard the Presidential yacht Sequoia.

title: House Given Schedule To Listen to Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)A schedule for listening to 19 taped White House conversations was distributed to all 435 members of the House today by the House Judiciary Committee at the direction of its chairman, Repreentative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Republican of New Jersey.

title: WINE TALK
description: Everybody seems to be drinking CtesduRhne. And why not? It is good wine, there is plenty of it and the price is right. The vogue for CtesduRhne is particularly interesting because, just a few years ago, hardly anyone had ever heard of it.

title: RANIERI RULED OFF THE BRONX BALLOT
description: Alfred J. Ranieri, former president of the Tax Commission, has been ruled off the primary ballot in an action that buoyed the bid by John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader, for reelection to the State Senate with Republican Conservative and Democratic endorsements.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug 2 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission has dropped a request for an injunction against the Real Lemon division of Borden, Inc., that would have forced the company to charge uniform prices in different parts of the nation.

title: Sets Are Trumped By Aces, 2520
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2  The Chicago Aces rallied to defeat the New York Sets, 2520, tonight at the Lake Shore Arena.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Pape 25

title: Former Maryland Senator Wins New Trial in Influence Peddling
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The United States Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial for former Maryland Senator Danlei B. Brewster, who was found guilty almost two years ago of accepting an illegal gratuity to influence his Senate vote on postalrate legislation.

title: Market Place: 9% U.S. Notes: Big Lure Seen
description: A 9 per cent coupon on a Treausy notea historic high is apt to attract hordes of individual investors across the nation next week. The Treasury is selling a total of $4billion in these notes next Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Who's in Control Here?
description: If it weren't so serious, the spectacle of some of this city's major public men alternating between statesmanship and fury, depending on who has just trumped whom, might be highly entertaining. The latest episode, for example, in the din over the state of the Controller's office was spiced with Controller Harrison J. Goldin's charges, made in a hasty transAtlantic news conference, followed by Investigations Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta's stormy suggestion, couched in colorful language, that the city's secondhighest elected official return from London by the most expeditious means possible.

title: The Old Fox of Sydney Does It Again
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaIn a move that caught the Australian financial world by surprise, the Old Fox of Swanston Street has scored another coup, outfoxing other parties to acquire a 50 per cent interest in Diners Club Australia Proprietary, Ltd., the country's leading creditcard operation.

title: Disability Pensions for Military Decline Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The number of military careerists receiving extra retirement benefits for alleged ailments has dropped sharply since the Secretary of Defense ruled that servicemen who are fit for duty are ineligible for disability pensions.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 53% FOR JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The nation's unemployment rate edged upward in July while total employment remained Stable, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 25

title: Horse Show Awards
description: AT MIDDLETOWN, N. Y.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AGENT IS INDICTED IN 2 GAS DEATHS
description: The managing agent of a Bronx apartment building has been indicted for criminally negligent homicide stemming from the deaths of two tenants from poisonous coalgas fumes, District Attorney Miro Merola disclosed yesterday.

title: Books of The Times On the Path to Enlightenment
description: A SEASON IN HEAVEN. By William Gibson. 182 pages. Atheneum. $6.95.

title: OFFER FOR SHARES OF ESB EXTENDED
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday that its tender offer of $41 a share for cominan shares of ESB, Inc., the big battery maker based in Philadelphia, has been extended to 10 A.M., Aug. 16. The original tender offer expires yesterday morning.

title: Pickets Set for Denver JetsBroncos auk
description: DENVER, Aug. 2With a new coach, Charley Winner, and a new quarterback, John Jones, the Jets arrived here today for tomorrow night's opening exhibition game with the Broncos that Jim Turner assured would be played.

title: Meat Purchase Program For Schools Lags Greatly
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The Government has spent only $11.6million so far of $100million it earmarked to buy beef and pork for school lunches next fall and winter, according to the latest tabulation by Agriculture Department officials.

title: Prospect of Gas Shortage Spurs Widespread Worry
description: The threat of a major natural gas shortage, particularly along the East Coast, is causing widespread worry among Federal and state officials and executives of the regional utilities.

title: BYRNE PROPOSES A CRABIEL LEAVE
description: TRENTON, Aug. 2Governor Byrne today publicly told Secretary of State. J. Edward Crabiel, who was indicted Wednesday on charges of rigging highwayconstruction bids, that it would be in the best interest of New Jersey if he took a leave of absence without pay until the charges against him were resolved.

title: GIANT COMPANIES GET A NEW NAME
description: GENEVA, Aug. 2  The giant companies that engage in business outside their home countries are henceworth to be called transnational rather than multinational corporations by the United Nations.

title: Bridge:
description: If a partnership climbs to a game contract in the face of an opposing opening bid, the declarer has one substantial advantage: he knows the location of virtually all the outstanding high cards, and can play the hand accordingly.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUTER BURROUGHS Tarzan movies this weekend. Some of you may have heard through the grapevine about the MGM, festival that began last Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art. Tomorrow all day, you can go ape at a showing of the first three in MGM's Tarzan series. These films cater especially to the swinging set, of course, but a word to the Weissmuller: children like them too because they learn such lessons as Cheetahs never prosper.

title: Tremors Felt Felt n Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Aug, 2 (AP) Moderate earth tremors shook portions of northern Georgia and western South Carolina early today.

title: FRENCH FARMERS PROTEST PRICES
description: PARIS, Aug. 2 (Reuters)French and Dutch farmers blocked traffic today to protest falling agriculture prices in the European Economic Community.

title: CeaseFire Violations
description: The State Department's apparent complacency about the continuing Turkish violations of the second Cyprus ceasefire and Turkish misuse of U.S.provided arms, is hard to accept. Turkish forces yesterday occupied four more Greek Cypriote villages in the Kyrenia mountain range, while tanks were seen attacking a nearby Greek outpost. Yet a high Washington official insisted that the Turkish movements were not enough to disturb anyone.

title: Weisl Defends Queens Park on Kennedy Rail Link
description: Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. conducted a ramble through the wilds of Forest Park in Queens yesterday to make a spirited defense of his turf against plans for a 3,000foot rail passenger spur through a forested area.

title: Curran Appoints Aide, 33 Chief of His Civil Division
description: Taggart D. Adanis was appointed yesterday as chief of the civil division in the United States Attorney's office.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING RETIRED PHYSICIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) To ease a critical shortage of military doctors, the Pentagor said today, it will hire retired military physicians and pay them full civilian salaries while they continue to draw their service pensions.

title: DEAN SENTENCED TO 1 TO 4 YEARS IN COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2John W. Dean 3d, once President Nixon's legal counsel and now his chief accuser in the Watergate affair, was sentenced today to a minimum of one year in prison and a maximum of four years for his admitted role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Sandra Berkowitz Wed
description: Sandra Ellen Berkowitz, daughter of Sidney Berkowitz of Hackensack, N. J. and the late Mrs. Berkowitz, was married last night to Harold Lawrence Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schneider of New York. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony in the Fairlawn (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title: Letters: The Battle Of Waterloo Refought
description: To the Editor: The thoroughly enjoyable feature on The Battle of Waterloo: Sunday Picnics on the Killing Ground by Linda Stewart (Travel Section, June 23) was read with much interest and delight. It is seldom that we military history buffs have such tender morsels served up to us.

title: Dorothy Jones Plans to Wed
description: Dorothy Hodgson Jones, who is with the international services division of the First National City Bank, and George Alexander Wrigley, an assistant secretary in the national division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, plan to marry Oct. 26 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Thomasville, Ga.

title: Bronx Man Is Shot In Seeking to Halt Neighbor's Robbers
description: A 29yearold Bronx man was shot by one of the two robbers he was chasing after they had forced their way into a woman neighbor's apartment.

title: WARREN HOPEFUL OVER WATERGATE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug, 3 (AP)Shortly before he died, former Chief Justice Earl Warren told a longtine friend he was optimistic that our country Will survive this tragedy of Watergate.

title: Integration Is Focus Of Actions By Schools
description: School officials and Federal judges were involved in three developments last week dealing with plans to promote integration of Brooklyn schools.

title: Godfrey Rockefeller Jr. Weds Regina Strazzulla
description: Regina Victoria Strazzulla, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Strazzulla of Vero Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday afternoon to Godfrey Anderson Rockefeller Jr. The bridegroom, known as Ande, is a son of Mr. Rockefeller of Gibson Island, Md., and Mrs. Hugh C. Wallace of Greenville, Del., and a greatgreatgrandson of William Rockefeller, who was associated with his brother, John D. Rockefeller, in the organization of the Standard Oil Company.

title: 28 ARE ARRESTED IN RAIDS ON I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 3The British Army announced that it had disrupted the command of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army in Belfast with the arrests of 28 suspects in a series of early morning raids.

title: No Time for Gimmicks
description: WASHINGTONThis is no timein fact, it perhaps is the least likely time in our historyfor a resort to gimmicks that would bypass the constitutional processes.

title: The Region/continued
description: The construction industry in the metropolitan region is in its worst crisis in decades: costs have risen greatly, the volume of new building is low and unemployment now so high that the industry's jobless skilled workers took to the streets in a major protest last week.

title: In a world of Peanuts and MAD
description: Ipresent here the first postwar, post  hostilities budget of the Department of Defense, intones James R. Schlesinger. Schlesinger is asking Congress for authority to spend about $95  billion, and Senator John Stennis, Chairman of the Armed Services Committee, has just given him permission to lay aside his prepared statement and speak offthecuff. An expert in his own right on defense matters for 15 years, Schlesinger has yet to use prepared texts in his Congressional appearances. The Senators sitting behind the raised platform the dark, austere, high ceilinged committee room, listen attentively.

title: Westhampton Bus Is Discontinued
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH Despite some indication that business for its shuttle bus was picking up, the Westhampton Beach Chamber of Commerce late last week discontinued the service that connected the village with the hamlets of East Quogue and Speonk and the Dune Road beaches.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Your article on Grumman and the F14 was a very fair review of the overall problem (How the Navy Buys Air Superiority, July 21).

title: Government Called Cause of Inflation By 48% in a Survey
description: Neatly half of all Americans, a record number, believe that the Federal Government rather than business or labor is chiefly responsible for inflation, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: ... No Single Remedy
description: Can this kind of inflation, stemming from escalating wage and commodity costs, he cured by keeping a tight grip on the rate of growth of the money supply? Chairman Burns of the Federal Reserve Board appears heroically determined to prove it can. Last week Dr. Burns told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that he regards the current 6 per cent rate of growth in the nation's money supply as still too high and would depress it further.

title: Visions of Electric Light In a Philippine Barrio
description: SAPANG PALAY, the Philippines, Aug. 3  Three men and three women chatted at midday here last weekend in the deep shade of a mango tree, visions of electric lights dancing in their heads.

title: GEORGE WALLACE, PENNSY EXECUTIVE
description: George R. Wallace, vice president for marketing of the Penn Central Transportation Company, died Friday when he fell from a New YorkPhiladelphia passenger train near the Tacony Station in Northeast Philadelphia. He was 55 years old and lived in Devlin, Pa.

title: Transit Police Focusing On Targets of Criminals
description: They mingle with the subway crowds on trains and platforms, looking for a markan inviting target of crime. It might be a woman careless with her pocketbook or a drunk asleep on a bench.

title: Dr. Judith Alexander Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Alexander of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Judith Alexander, to Charles Ward Brice of Cheyenne, Wyo.

title: Mary Ann Brockenbrough Bride of Robert Henley Lamb
description: Mary Ann Brockenbrough and Robert Henley Lamb, distant cousins descended from Moore Fauntleroy Brockenbrough, a settler of Virginia, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. George Evans Zahn performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Cathedral in Richmond, where the bride's parents were married 25 years ago. The Rev. Thomas Dabney Wellford, an Episcopal priest, assisted.

title: Film
description: THE EXORCIST may be the greatest thing since Bobby Riggs started playing against girls in getting otherwise sensible people to involve themselves in things they would ordinarily have the good sense to avoid. The movie has now reached the suburban rim of American life, having just cashed in on an elaborate and highly lucrative arrangement with exhibitors that made it something like the circus coming to town... Right this way to see the little girl spew pea soup over the good father Don't miss the scene with the bloody crucifix!

title: Dog Considered a Weapon In Massachusetts Robbery
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)A dog can be considered a dangerous weapon if it appears capable of inflicting serious bodily harm, according to ruling of the Massachusetts Court of Appeals.

title: Two Coast Shows Draw Large Crowds To See Record Dog Entries Compete
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. Aug. 3With the Santa Ynez Mountains at its head and the blue Pacific at its feet, the Brobdingnagian Santa Barbara Kennel Club Show made history here last Sunday. With 4,288 dogs, it was the largest to be held in the United States in 35 years, being exceeded only by Morris and Essex, which drew 4,456 dogs to Madison, N.J., the American record.

title: Artpark: A New State Park for the Arts
description: LEWISTON, N. Y.

title: Postal Garage Plan Fought in Chelsea
description: Residents of a West Side neighborhood have moved to block the construction of a planned $35million garage for the United States Postal Service at the Morgan Postal Station, charging that the new facility would be disastrous to the community's environment.

title: Maripat Mulvey Bride of Warren Fondu
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Maripat McKeever Mulvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Mulvey of Harrison, N.Y., to Warren H. Fondu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Fondu of Glenbrook, Conn.

title: Craftsmen and Museum: Out of Touch
description: When a museum has what is known as a touch policyvisitors may pat, stroke or otherwise handle the exhibitsand the organization running the show believes firmly in the principle of just look, there is bound to be conflict.

title: Two men of God in troubled times and places
description: Samuel Johnson, the great lexicographer, once observed, Much may be made of a Scotsman if he be caught young. John Knox was caught young. Despite his inclination for the quiet life of a scholar, he was early caught up by the forces of religious and political reform sweeping 16thcentury England and Scotland from the Continent and tufted into a powerful spokesman for the Protestant cause, the most influential religious leader in Scotland. Roman Catholic priest, Anglican vicar, Protestant minister and theoretician, he lived in a time of shifting loyalties values turbulent as our own.

title: Eloise G. McLellan Bride in Maryland
description: Eloise Gorton McLellan of Crofton, Md., and Lewis H. Hendrixson Jr. of Savage, Md., an analyst with the National Security Agency in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Carl Harris performed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Millersville, Md.

title: Apartheid And the Archbishop
description: In South Africa two Christianities meet to do battle, not so much against a common foe as against each other. One of them is the religion of the Dutch Reformed churches of the majority white group; the other is the religion of most other churches in the land, including that of the Anglican Church in South Africa. What sets these two versions of Christ's religion against each other is their total conflict on the issue of apartheidracial separation.

title: It is an African Gulag, a former diplomat said.
description: WASHINGTONIn July, 1971, two Americans were brutally murdered. and. their bodies burned by Ugandan Army officers in a remote southern proyince. Nicholas Stroh, a 33yearold freelance journalist, and Robert Siedle, 46, a lecturer at Makerere University, had been attempting to investigate reports of mass executions at Mbarara barracks. According to witnesses, now in exile from Uganda, these last words were uttered: You may kill us, but someday you'll anfor this.

title: Charter Groups For 1Man Rule
description: NEWARK  The Charter Study Commissions in nine counties are expected to recommend this week that control of each of the county governments be placed in the hands of one man.

title: Nixon Would Forfeit $60,000 Pension if Convicted; Some in G.O.P. See Financial Benefits in Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3President Nixon would suffer grievous financial losses if impeached by the House of Representatives and convicted by the Senate  losses that he could avoid by resigning.

title: TURKS PRESS ON IN NORTH CYPRUS; TALKS CONTINUE
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 3While Turkish and Greek military delegates continued negotiations today on separation of their forces under United Nations supervision, Turkish troops kept advancing in the mountains west of Kyrenia.

title: Jeanne Smith Is Bride Here
description: Jeanne MacPherson Smith, Who is with the Rockefeller Family & Associates, and John E. McCracken, a lawyer with the Shaheen Natural Resources Company, Inc., were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland.

title: Book: There Were Giants, And Others, in Those Days
description: The Macmillan Publishing Company as just come out with its revised and ??dated The Baseball Encyclopedia. ??he back of the bright green rust jacket ontains fatuous and clichefilled testi??onials from four levelheaded balllayers. Reggie Jackson informs us that, It's more than a book, it's a library. ??nfortunate.

title: Rising Soccer Interest Puts League Final on TV
description: CBS, Inc. announced yesterday it would televise nationally the North American Soccer League's championship game on Aug. 24 starting at 3:30 P.M.

title: Chess:Browne Coasts to U.S. Title As Benko and Evans Share 2d
description: Walter Browne, taking no chances, coasted to his first United States championship title by drawing with Norman Weinstein in the 12th round and with Kim Commons in the final round of the tournament, held at the LaSalle Hotel in Chicago.

title: The Region In Summary
description: There are more transit policemen than ever on the city's subways but also more crime. So much so, that the Transit Authority last week closed off half the cars on all nighttime trains in an effort to try to double the protection the patrol force can provide.

title: News of the Screen
description: Yukio Mishima, Japan's prolific authordramatistactorproducerdirector, whose suicide at the age of 45 in 1970 captured international headlines, will be represented on the screen in the first Englishlanguage, Western version of one of his noted novels, The Sailor Who Fell From Grace With the Sea. It will be produced by Martin Poll from a screenplay by Lewis John Carlino, who will also make his moviedirecting debut with the feature.

title: Catholic School Fills Post
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug, 3 (AP) The Rev. Robert F. Condron has been named headmaster of the Cranwell Academy, the first nonJesuit to head the private, Roman Catholic boys school. Father Condron, not affiliated with an order, has served as chairman of the school's theology department for the last three years. He succeeds the Rev. John W. Keegan, who is leaving Cranwell for further Jesuit training.

title: Parents' Giveaway Aids Crippled Girl's Hospital
description: GRISWOLD, Conn., Aug. 3 (AP)The Novaks are offering free food at their roadside fruit and vegetable stand this weekend to help a hospital that helped their crippled daughter walk for the first time in her life.

title: A U.S. PROSECUTOR IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: A charge that a Federal prosecutor here knew of perjury by the only Government witness in a 1972 narcotics trial and took no corrective action at the time is under investigation by a bar association committee.

title: David Irwin Weds Jacqueline Engel
description: Jacqueline Mary Engel, senior brandplanning manager for PepsiCola in Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to David Meredith Irwin, a lawyer here with Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. The Rev. Joseph Perozzi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, an interfaith minister, in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Duke Power, a Company That Needs a Friend
description: EVARTS, Ky.Each Saturday morning striking coal miners from the Brookside mine a few miles away gather at the modern Multipurpose Center here to pick up their $100 strike benefit checks. They praise, their union, the United Mine Workers of America, and reaffirm their determination to win their battle against their employer, the Eastover Mining. Company, based in nearby Harlan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The builder H. R. Shapiro [July 21] is quoted as saying: Architectural amenities are sheer noneiense. I deal with economics. Zoning determines architecture.

title: Man Held Here as Member Of LuxuryCar Theft Ring
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and accused of being a principal in a ring specializing in the theft of luxury cars.

title: Seattle's Milton Katims Heads This Way With Baton (and Viola)
description: SEATTLE, Wash. MILTON KATIMS, music director of the Seattle Symphony, was talking recently about how one defines oneself. He had asked a young man he knew the question, What are you doing these days? The young man had replied, Why do you ask what I'm doing? Why don't you ask what I'm being?

title: Miami Gets New SpanishLanguage Newspaper
description: MIAMI, Aug. 3  Greater Miami, with 500,000 Latin residents who make up onethird of its population, got a new Spanishlanguage newspaper this week.

title: Guide for West Queens
description: The West Queens Independent Democratic Club has published a community resource handbook, which advises residents in Sunnyside and Woodside on where to find trade schools, the offices of their elected representatives, legal aid, civic associations and drug prevention programs, through the entangled bureaucracy of New York City government to the Woodside Halfway Center.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Blasts and Fire Kill 12 On Train Near Bologna
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Sunday Aug. 4 (UPI)At least 12 persons were killed and 20 were injured in a series of explosions followed by fire aboard an international express train early today the police said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 4, 1974

title: 3 House Tours Set for Same Day
description: The East End will be alive with house hoppers Wednesday when three organizations hold their annual fundraising house tours.

title: Study Predicts Job Rise In Suffolk
description: A new study of transportation needs in the metropolitan area in the next two decades envisions an increase of a total of 213,000 jobs in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties by 1990, a gain of more than 10 per cent over the current figure.

title: 38 Lawyers Pass Up the Chance to Put It in Writing
description: Impeachment has always been described as a hybrid process, a curious amalgam of the legislative and the judicial. Alexis de Tocquevillet said its form was judicial but its substance political. That historical appraisal has now, suddenly, become contemporary reality to Americans. For they have seen the mixed nature of the process in the drama of the House Judiciary Committee and in its, three approved articles calling for the impeachment of Richard M. Nixon.

title: State Asks U.S. Guidance on CableTV Franchises
description: WASHINGTONThe New Jersey Office of Cable Television, facing a challenge by its own Advisory Council on establishing policy, has asked the Federal Communications Commission for guidelines to help it determine how to grant regional franchises.

title: Revamped Mariner Faces Test
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3To become a Valiant Mariner one must be both Intrepid and Courageous.

title: Midweek Shows Do Well At Four Seasons Farm
description: It was back sometime in April, Dave Witherington recalls, and he was driving through some of the back roads in Hunterdon County, N. J.

title: Southpaw Scatters 7 Hits by Expos in 4th Shutout
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 3With a New York MetsMontrealExpos series virtually a sweepstakeseach team having swept a series from the other this seasonthe idea tonight became a simple one: Win the first game.

title: SLIGHT PRICE EFFECT FROM DROUGHT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The impact of this summer's drought on consumer food prices may be less than many observers fear, an Agriculture Department official said today.

title: Michael Vicario 3d Weds Heidi Salzberg
description: Heidi Margarita Salzberg, daughter of Murray M. Salzberg and Katrina van Oss Salzberg, both of New York, was married here yesterday evening to Michael A. Vicario 3d, son of the Rev. Michael A. Vicario 2d of Landsdale, Pa., and the late Mrs. Vicario.

title: CITYUNION PACTS REACHED QUICKLY
description: In contrast to the recent past, the Beame administration has achieved quick contract settlements this summer with two of the three uniformed services and with major units of District 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes, including one agreed to yesterday.

title: Recordings
description: POSTERITY will have few excuses to offer if it forgets about Leonard Bernstein: No other musician, with the possible exception of Herbert von Karajan, seems quite so determined to make a permanent record of the complete life and works. Practically every major Bernstein project these days is preserved on both tape and film  not only the musical performance itself, but the rehearsals as well as additional explanatory embellishments from the conductor.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Morris County Restoring Public Transport
description: BOONTON  A trolley of sorts has returned to this Morris County town as the latest example of how the county and its communities are setting the pace in restoring longvanished public transportation at the local level.

title: Paula Roseman Is Wed
description: The marriage of Paula B. Roseman to Kenneth I. Saler took place yesterday evening at the Rye Town Hilton in, Port Chester, N. Y. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold D. Roseman of Scarsdale, N. Y. Her father, a lawyer here and in Westchester County, is a former acting judge in New Rochelle.

title: E.S. Mundy to Wed Sarah Hooper
description: Sarah Ellen Hooper, a granddaughter of the late Horace Everett Hooper of Bedford, N. Y., who was president of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, will be married this October to Edward Shackford Mundy, a grandson of the late Norris Havemeyer Mundy, president of W.A. Havemeyer & Co., sugar brokers in Chicago.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The special legislative session that Governor Byrne called to deal with tax reform and overhaul of publicschool financing ended amid frustration and bitter acrimony within the majority Democratic party.

title: It's no sissy sport played for laughs
description: Joan Joyce, a 33yearold righthander, is the. Babe Ruth of women's softball, still in her prime. In her 15year career, she has won 330 of 354 games she's pitched, collected 70 nohitters, struck out over 4,800 hitters and compiled a lifetime batting average of .316. Joyce's team, the Raybestos Brakettes of Stratford, Conn., are the New York Yankees of women's softball, still in their prime. Since being organized in 1947, they have won 10 national championships, been runnersup in five more and will represent the United States in the quadrennial women's World Softball Tournament to be held from next Thursday through Aug. 16 in Stratford.

title: Builders Are Glum on Housing
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The New Jersey Builders Association has issued a report showing that starts on new housing in the state have declined by nearly 40 per cent since 1972. The study also predicts a serious threat to the economic wellbeing of New Jersey unless the downward trend is reversed.

title: Fashion
description: It may be August, but for foreignfashion aficionados, winter has arrived. The European readytowear winter collections have hit the stores, and thoseintheknow know that now, right now, is the time to buy, no matter how wrappedup and muffled the clothes may be. In spite of the staggering price tags (up to $500 for sweater set and skirt), many women won't settle for anything but the real thing from their favorite French or Italian designers. That might account for the bargainbasement behavior when those cartons are opened: In some stores some customers are right there helping unpack, just to be sure their size doesn't leave the store with someone else. Stores say that the compulsive grabbiness stems from the uncertain deliveries European manufacturers and the fact that there may only be two size 10's in some items. A truetoherdesigner customer knows that if she misses the boat now, she'll have to wait until next seasonand may miss out on an entire look. That's why the foreignfashion devote buys now and mothballs for later.

title: A Snowball Going Downhill
description: WASHINGTON For many Tong months, when the investigation of the President seemed to be mired in the White House strategy of obstruction and delay, there were observers on Capitol Hill who predicted that if ever the impeachment process began, it would snowball. That is precisely what is happening now.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 3 (UPI)  Members of South Korea's Government majority party forced cancellation today of a National Assembly meeting to block debate over decrees giving President Park Chung Hee more power.

title: JOHN D. FRENCH
description: John D. French, vice president of American City BureauBeaver Associates, a Chicagobased fundraising organization, died of a heart attack Thursday aboard an airplane on the way from Albany to Kennedy Airport. He was 52 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: Nancy F. Peabody Wed to Pediatrician
description: Nancy Freck Peabody of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. William Wiley Whitten a pediatrician of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the Princeton University Chapel, performed the Protestant ceremony there.

title: Miss Lum Married To Physician Here
description: Audrey Siu Fong Lum, daughter of Mrs. Fong Lum of New York and the late Mr. Lum, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Gifford Yee Yen Lum, son of Mrs. Joo Lim Lum of Honolulu and the late Mr. Lum. The Rev. Ernest J. Kunsch performed the Lutheran ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Will the Cincinnati Reds be able to catch the Dodgers again this season? The drive continues this weekend as the Reds play a threegame series with the Mets beginning Friday night at Shea Stadium. Game times are Friday at 8:05 P.M. and Saturday and next Sunday at 2:15 P.M.

title: Opperman Races to Eat But Steers for Other Goals
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 3Jan Opperman's hair doesn't reach his shoulders any more and he says, for publication at least, that he no longer smokes marijuana. He still doesn't look like a race driver. He looks like a San Francisco Bay area flower child, which he was 15 years ago, but in addition to the battered moccasins and the faded Levis and dirty denim shirt there is a large gold cross and he is looking to buy a ranch in Colorado to set up a camp for city kids who are all screwed up, you know, hung up with drugs.

title: Pennsylvania Faces a Coal Shortage
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Aug.  Northeastern Pennsylvania faces this winter an acute shortage of anthracite coal, still a major heating fuel in this part of the state.

title: Sandman Adheres to Role of a Strict Constructionist
description: WASHINGTON  If anyone has any reason to be upset with President Nixon, it's Charlie Eandman, said Representative Lawrence J. Hogan of Maryland, a fellow Republican on the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Cards Beat Phils, 43, to Lead by 1
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (UP)Lou Brock singled home the tying run in the ninth inning and then scored on Bake McBride's hit to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 43 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: Fumbling Broncos Bow, 4119, Before 27,559
description: DENVER, Aug. 3On the eve of what Jim Turner of the Denver Broncos said could be the most important player representative meeting in the history of the association, a band of jeering pickets raucously greeted the New York Jets tonight as they arrived at Mile High Stadium for their opening exhibition game with the Broncos.

title: Open mouths and naked psyches
description: In his introduction to Supertalk, Digby Diehl asks if writer utilizing the Q&A interview form couldn't easily be replaced by a dachshund with a dictaphone. By the time got to page 293, I had the answerit takes a special kind of news hound, Digby Diehl species, to get mad dogs like Melvin Belli, Joan Baez, Huey Newton, Gloria Steinem et al. to bare their teeth, grrrowl meanly and bark out answers, answers that make Supertalk superreading, all the way from the bambamthankyouma'am verbal calisthenics of Harold Robbins to Hugh Hefner, who, on an excursion to Outer Megalomania, actually leads the reader to think that Hef thinks he's Hugh Hefner.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Joyce Krumbein Wed
description: Joyce Tobe Krumbein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Krumbein of Richmond, and Bruce Howard Slater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Slater of Bethpage, L.I., were married in Richmond yesterday afternoon at Temple BethEl by Rabbi Myron Berman. The bride's father is vice president of the HeiligMeyers Co., a 56store furniture and homefurnishings chain in Virginia, West Virginia and North and South Carolina.

title: Enter Joseph Papp
description: As the founder and producer of The New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp fills more stages, hires more actors, entertains more audiences and makes more headlines than anyone else in the American theater. It is a matter not just of his power but of his complex personality. He is a visionary and a pragmatist, a talker and a doer, a patron of the arts and a supersalesman. He is also very much a selfstarter somewhat on the order of those Hollywood mogulsand today all his batteries are charged. It is impossible not to have strong opinions about the volatile Papp and about the plays that he produces. It is with all this in mind that one turns to Stuart W. Little's book with anticipation and just a little trepidation at his imsubtitle.

title: Sarah Cheney Becomes Bride
description: All Saints Episcopal Church in Peterborough, N. H., was the setting at noon yesterday for the wedding of Miss Sarah Ann Cheney and Allen Leslie Oshana. The bride is a daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. Francis X. Cheney of New Haven and Troy, N.H. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Oshana of Farmington, Conn.

title: RADIO OFFICIAL WINS STAY IN HEARST CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (UPI)  Will Lewis, the radio executive ordered back to prison for refusing to give the Federal Bureau of Investigation the original of a taped message by Patricia Hearst, received another stay yesterday from United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

title: Stan Smith, the Tennis Player, Will Marry Marjory Gengler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Gengler of Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjory Logan Gengler, to Stanley Roger Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ken,neth Smith of Newport Beach, Calif.

title: RUDOLPH INGRISCH
description: Rudolph Ingrisch, who retired in 1971 as chairman of the hoard and chief executive officer of Binney & Smith, Inc., manufacturers here of crayons and artists materials, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: PENTAGON OPENS SECURITY REVIEW
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3The Defense Department's first open security clearance hearing was held here this week.

title: Two New Products for the Home
description: ALL kinds of plants, from small potted plants to medium size trees can be effortlessly sprayed with a new portable cordless electric sprayer that is powered by a builtin rechargeable battery. Made by the Power Tool Division of Rockwell International, 400 Lexington Avenue, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15208, and priced at just under $20, the Cordless Electric Yard and Garden, Sprayer can he used for spraying insecticides, weed killers, fertilizers and herbicides, and it will spray up to four quarts of liquid on a single charge. The battery is recharged by simply plugging into a household outlet overnight.

title: INVESTING POINT OF VIEW
description: As if the bear market weren't taking a harsh enough toll of investors, a new threat looms for most holders of stockpurchase warrants that could nearly wipe out their investments.

title: Headliners
description: Recent signs of thawing in relations between the United States and Cuba have been reinforced by comments made by Cuban Premier Fidel Castro in a recent interview. The Premier said he envisions a resumption of normal relations with the United States sometime in the near future. We took an important step when we signed the hijacking agreement, said Mr. Castro. Though he seemed disturbed by Washington's hard line toward Cuba despite United States dtente with the Soviet Union and better relations with other Communist nations, he added, We nonetheless see with satisfaction the cessation of the cold war.

title: SOVIET REPORTS LAG IN GRAIN THRESHING
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP)The Soviet Government reported this week that 22 per cent of the nation's grain harvest had been cut but complained that more than 22 million acres of unthreshed grain lay in the fields.

title: African Rhythm American Dance
description: I can't imagine a better biographical heroine than Katherine Dunham. In African, RhythmAmerican Dance, Terry Harnan chronicles he work of a woman who sought out the black dance transmitted by African slaves to the Caribbean Islands, then transformed this material into successful and valid theatrical entertainment for American and European audiences. Dunham gave an authentic black dance existence in a balletdominated cultural world, and she made black dancers visible as trained, cultivated artists instead of, simplistically, natural performers. Harnan also tells of a life begun in material and spiritual deprivation, a life of continual struggle with the self and the world.

title: Paula Uihlein, M.C. Schleicher Have Nuptials
description: Paula Marie Uihlein, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Uihlein of Grafton, Wis., and the late Mr. Uihlein, former president and chairman of the board of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, was married in Grafton, yesterday afternoon to Mark Christopher Schleicher.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: F.D.R., Truman Eisenhower, Kennedy, L. B. J. find George Pins?
description: FEELING smug and aristocratic, stood on the open observation platform of the private railroad car Pennsylvania 120, a car that at one time or another had carried Presidents Roosevelt, Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson and had borne the body of Robert F. Kennedy following his assassination. A Scotch on the rocks was in my hand, and in the gathering dusk the train to which the car was now coupled, the first section of the Southern Crescent, stretched ahead on Track 24 at Union Station in Washington, D.C. We were minutes away from a 7:20 P.M. departure for New Orleans. The dozen stainlesssteel coaches and Pullmans of the Southern Crescent were laden with Mardi Gras crowds; in the diner of our private car thick steaks were being charcoal broiled for passengers who had drifted in from the lounge.

title: Options MarketAction and Anxiety
description: There's a certain giddiness this summer enlivening the financial playground known as the Chicago Board Options Exchange. And little wonder. While the country's stock and bond markets have been practically moribund, the C.B.O.E. has been booming.

title: They May Be Puzzled, But Other Nations Are Paying Attention
description: WASHINGTONHas the Watergate scandal, culminating now in the possibility of Presidential impeachment, affected the conduct of United States foreign policy?

title: In This Corner, Robert Steele
description: While the country's attention was focused on the House Judiciary Committee, the Republicans in Connecticut, almost in spite of themselves, came up with what may prove to be one of their party's best available antidotes to the political poison of Watergate and impeachment: a candidate for Governor who won the nomination on a platform of driving big money and special interests out of politics and a promise not to accept contributions of more than $100.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AFTER a meeting at the White House on July 11, at which President Nixon solicited the views of leading businessmen and economists on the state of the economy and their recommendations for dealing with inflation, one prominent executive who had not been a political supporter of the Administration emerged from the session impressed with the scope and breadth of the briefing. He proclaimed:

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: 29 Years Later, Hiroshima Haunts Survivors in U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3Her ceremonial kimono hiding the ugly keloid scars on her arms and body, Yukiko Wanatabe will kneel before a small Buddhist altar in a corner of her bedroom Tuesday morning and repeat the Japanese sutras for the dead.

title: Lightner variation
description: If intelligent dwellers in some faroff galaxy play bridge, admittedly a remote chance in every sense, their bidding conventions would be quite unlike ours. The only terrestrial convention that one might expect to find duplicated is the oldest of all those in regular tournament use: the sophisticated Lightner slam double. It was devised some 45 years ago by Theodore Lightner of New York, who is still an active player at the age of 80.

title: Golden Eagle Predators To Be Shifted in Montana
description: DILLON, Mont., Aug. 4 Golden eagles that have been responsible for considerable lamb fosses in a 30squaremile area near, here will be trapped and moved to the Beaverhead National Forest, Charles Loveless, regional director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, has announced.

title: Five Killed in Auto Collision
description: SOCORRO, N, M., Aug. 3 (UPI)A car carrying six New Mexico National Guardsmen on their way home from summer camp slammed headon into another car on Interstate 25 last night, killing three of the Guardsmen and two residents of Juarez, Mexico. Dead were Delphino F. Gutirrez, Santiago R. Peralta, Johnny D. Vaiza, Tomas Hurtado and Juan Garcia.

title: Ring Title Is Retained By Napoles
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 3 (AP)Jose Napoles of Mexico stopped Hedgemon Lewis with a flurry of punches late in the ninth round today and retained his world welterweight championship at the Sports Palace.

title: Red Smith
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3A boy of 14 or so stepped up to the dais and pushed a piece of paper in front of Buddy Baer. While Max Baer's little brother scribbled an autograph, the kid's gaze moved uncertainly right and left, searching for a familiar face. Get Jimmy Crowley, a man suggested. Two seats over there. The name brought no look of recognition to the boy's face. Left halfback on the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame, the man said. Obediently the kid presented his paper as directed. He's never heard played their last season together exactly 50 years ago. You should have told him Jimmy was the coach who taught football Vince Lombardi.

title: Notes: Esperanto, A Lingua por Turisto
description: IN Rome an Italian guide, mispropouncing the English word wallets, cautions a party of American tourists to watch their walnuts because of proliferating pickpockets. In Moscow a sign at the airport reads: Aeroflot Soviet Airlines disposes of the latest equipment and experienced pilots. In Japan an announcement occasionally posted in a railroad station proclaims: All tickets for the train to Tokyo are soiled.

title: McDonnell Calls Talks in Taxi Dispute
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board said yesterday that he would meet with the parties in the taxi dispute today or tomorrow morning to try to avert a taxi strike threatened for midnight Monday.

title: Editors' Choice
description: CHRONICLES OF WASTED TIME, by Malcolm Muggeridge. (Morrow, $7.95.) With his instinct for the absurd and eye for the illuminating detail, Muggeridge carries on his worldweary, but worldly, autobiography.

title: Book Ends
description: Q.P.B.S. The idea of a paperback book club has been kicking around for years but now it appears that its time has come. Under the umbrella of the Book of the Month Club, the quality Paperback Book Service has been cautiously testing the water and now, according to Edward Fitzgerald, Book of the Month vice president, who can claim paternity, We're behaving as though the club is here forever. What has been accomplished thus far is a series of test ads and direct mailings, conducted in January, February and March, which lured 5,000 membersconsidered a successful effort. As a result Q.P.B.S. is pulling out the stops with a halfmillion dollar advertising campaign that began this month and continues to the end of the year. This push, they hope, will net them 50,000 members; the ultimate goal is 100,000 and with that complement they should be turning a nice profit.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 4, 1974

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH
description: Retailing is show business, but it's not a threering circus. An anonymous merchant.

title: Mall Is Named for Vince Lombardi
description: The late Vince Lombardi, coach of the Green Bay Packers during the mineteensixties when that team dominated professional football, was honored recently in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, where he grew up.

title: Alaskan Commander Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Maj Gen. James E. Hill of the Air Force will become Commander in Chief of the Alaskan command, the Pentagon has announced. General Hill, 52 years old, has been nominated for promotion to lieutenant general in his new assignment, which takes effect Sept. 1. He will replace Lieut. Gen. James C. Sherrill, who is retiring.

title: Miss Huffman Bride Of Philip Ruegger 3d
description: Rebecca Lee Huffman, daughter of Mr. sand Mrs. David Gibson Huffman of Charleston, W.Va., and Philip T. Ruegger 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruegger Jr., of Metuchen, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church in Charleston by the Rev. William A. Benfield.

title: Canada and Europe Sign AirTraffic Satellite Pac
description: PARIS, Aug. 3 (Reuters)Canada and the European ?? Research Organization ?? an agreement yesterday for ?? use of highflying space ?? lites in directing air traffic control over the world's busies air lanes.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: 2 Get 6Month Sentences In Fraud on Storm Checks
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP)Two Hazleton men have been sentenced to six months in prison for helping to defraud the Federal Government of more than $24,000 through an emergency employment program after tropical storm Agnes.

title: The Elderly Are Television's Forgotten Men and Women
description: THE aged owner of a jewelry store is robbed and murdered by a young thief in an episode of the popular CBS television series Kojak.

title: CARRASCO'S PAST: DRUGS An PRISON
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 3 I am a man of my word. Over and over again, Fred Gomez Carrasco had used those words. He had said that, as an atheist, his ultimate faith was in himself and in his devotion to doing what he said he would do.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The circumstances surrounding Senator Edward Kennedy's accident (Chappaquiddick + 5 by Robert Sherrill, July 14) remind me very much of the automobile accident in The Great Gatsby.

title: Labor Cheers Byrne on Highway Bonds
description: TRENTONIn a move that drew cheers, from organized labor, Governor Byrne has called for a $200million bond issue for highway construction.

title: Paterson Planning Annual Art Show
description: PATERSON  The seventh annual Art in the Park show will be held in Eastside Park on Sept. 15. Sponsored by the Mayor's Cultural Committee, the combined show and sale is expected to attract more than 500 artists. Prizes totaling $1,300 will be awarded.

title: Nuptials on Aug. 31 For Betsy Simson
description: Dr. Jerome Simson, an internist and director of the division of rheumatology and arthritis at Jamaica Hospital in Queens, and Mrs. Simson of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betsy Simson, to Dr. Michael Loukas Pappis.

title: Gas Sales In First Part of '74 Off by 8%
description: TRENTONGasoline sales in New Jersey in the first five months of 1974 were about 8 per cent less than in the same period last year.

title: The dimestore way to make movies and money
description: Samuel Z. Arkoff is not feeling well. Last night he tried acupuncture, allowing seven needles to be inserted into his face. Shingles is such an awful name for a painful disease. I feel like Camille. She died of consumptiona passe disease. For the young people to identify with her or me, we should make it a social disease.

title: Ballet: Canada's Superb Swan Lake
description: King Rudolf the Great, Karen Kain and the National Ballet of Canada made the company's first Swan Lake of the season a total triumph Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Watching an America's Cup Race Is Like Watching the Grass Grow
description: UP comes the old saw: Watching a yachting race is as exciting as watching the grass grow. True enough, but thence comes the pleasure. Personally, I can sit at home upon my lawn chair for hours on end, and watch the grass grow until it hides my lawn mower from view. The America's Cup Races, which take place every three or four years, and get under way this year on Sept. 10. provide me with a rare opportunity to indulge myself.

title: Winds of Fall Will Nip at Longer Skirts, Fewer Pants
description: Not every one of the thousands of dresses paraded down the runways of Seventh Avenue during the fall fashion showings a few months ago is destined to end up on somebody's back. For many it is also the last mile: they are ignored by store buyers because they are (a) too bizarre (b) too extravagant or (c) too dull.

title: Woman Raped and Stabbed Outside Her E. Side Home
description: A 35yearold East Side resident was raped, slashed with a knife and robbed early yesterday by a man who accosted her as she entered her residence, the police reported.

title: Barbara Fiscina Wed
description: Barbara Grace Fiscina, daughter of Dr. Joseph N. Fiscina of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mrs. Fiscina, and John Jeffrey Elliott, son of Mrs. John B. Elliott of Melrose, Mass., and the late Mr. Elliott, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Francis Manzo performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills. Mrs. Elliott was graduated from Manhattanville Colege and has a master's degree from Georgetown University, of which her husband is a graduate. He is a student at the School of Medicine at Georgetown.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Seven strokes. They prevent Gary Player from pursuing a Grand Slam this week at the Professional Golfers Association tournament in what might have been golf's most compelling drama. Instead those seven strokes have created a controversy over the liberty of touring caddies.

title: Queens and Nassau Move to Cooperate
description: A goodneighbor policy between Queens and Nassau Counties, to cope with mutual problems before they become crises, was the aftermath of a meeting last Monday at Queens Borough Hall between Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

title: The Olympic Spirit and the Frenzied World of Amateur Sports
description: Can Olympismthe Olympic movement, the Olympic spiritsave sport from its excesses?

title: The Philharmonic Finds a New Concertmaster
description: A WEEK AGO last Tuesday, the New York Philharmonic opened its 10th year of free park concerts before a recordbreaking crowd in Central Park, Somewhat lost in the shuffle of that extraordinary event was the presence of Eliot Chapo in the concertmaster's chair for the first time. The advent of a new principal violinist is worth attention, and here lie was slipping in almost unnoticed.
