Interviewed a few days later, Chapo said he didn't mind that there was no fuss, He was glad, in fact, because the park concerts and the orchestra's forthcoming tour of New Zealand, Australia and Japan would help him settle into the post and get acquainted with his colleagues before the opening of the new season in September.

title: Broadway and the Nonprofit Theater A Misalliance
description: ONE OF the issues raised at the First Annual Congress of Theater (FACT) held on the Princeton campus last Juneit is perhaps the central question facing the American theater at the present timewas whether the ailing Broadway theater might find some measure of financial and artistic relief through an alliance with the nonprofit theater movement. Could the old lion lie down with the young lamb? Was it conceivable that these two mutually suspicious, competing and opposing systems could establish a fruitful liaison, despite their traditional differences? It was certainly obvious from the flirtatious manner in which nonprofit theater representatives were being treated a this conference, most conspicuously by representatives from the League of Broadway Theaters, that they were being courted for romantic purposes, and if marriage wasn't being considered, then some kind of tentative commonlaw relationship was about to be ??.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FARM PRICES ROSE 6 per cent from midJune midJuly, the Agriculture Department reported. The farm price index stood at 175 per cent of the 1967 base on July 15, up from 173 per cent on July 15, 1973.... title: The Reluctant Ayes
description: Most of the American Constitution, written for a largely rural seaboard society two centuries ago, has proven its great flexibility through judicial and congressional interpretation, and executive action, to meet the changing needs of successive generations. But as the possibility of Richard M. Nixon's impeachment has grown the question became more pertinent whether the Constitution's stingy references to that ultimate process would be enough to make it workable when applied to a President in the midTwentieth Century.

After months of stalling, the House Administration Committee under the chairmanship of Representative Wayne Hays, Democrat of Ohio, has finally yielded up its version of a campaignfinance reform bill.

description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection has set up a special hot line to assist those motorists whose cars have been rejected for exhaust pollution.

title: The artist of solitude
description: Ingmar Bergman has directed more than 40 films. About half of these are known in America and occupy a special place in the imagination of any viewer: marked personal, set away in a corner but always remembered, they stand quietly with Chekhov, Long Day's Journey Into Night and certain pieces by Mozart. An artist of extraordinary consistency, Bergman has done much to earn the loyalty of his audience, so that aberrantly selfindulgent moments in his work seem merely irritating. Shame, with its frozen muggy landscape and floating cadavers; The Virgin Spring, where the director was admittedly touristic, a lousy imitation of Kurosawa'; Hour of the Wolf, sporting all those funny hysterical birds or demonsthese are odd rather than obvious lapses. Bergman's films, driven headlong by a powerful current, now and then tumble furiously, and it does not matter in the least.

title: Women Are No Longer FencedIn by Tradition of Men and Sports at Yale
description: NEW HAVENIn 1888, when the president of Yale proposed that an old rail fence be removed from the corner of College ad Chapel Streets to make way for a new campus building, a mass meeting of undergraduates was held in protest and a strong petition, containing names of 2,100 graduates from various parts of the world, was presented. The fence, constructed in 1833, had become the focus of Yale life, the inspiration of community living, where the poor boy and the rich boy sat side by sidethe scholar, the fraternity man, the athlete, the foreigner. It was the symbol of Yale democracy and it had added a dimension to collegefrom solely an institution of learning to a way of life.

title: Can the Administration Sustain OldTime Religion?
description: WASHINGTON  A question that frequently comes up in discussions of the course of the economy is: Will they panic?

title: Little Current Runs Second, Nose Back of $16.80 Winner
Maeve Brennan at home and abroad
description: To collect and publish stories written over a period of 20 years is a risk for any author. Readers can hardly avoid making comparisons, noticing inconsistencies and remarking the slightest signs of unevenness. In the case of Maeve Brennan, the risk is particularly great because of the sharp distinction in the subject matter of her stories. Roughly half of the works in this new volume by the New Yorker writer are Americanuppermiddleclass exurban New York; the other half are Irishlowermiddleclass County Wexford. Perhaps some contrast is intended between the styles and values of the two cultures. If so, the point of the contrast is lost in the extreme artistic disparity between the two groups of stories. The American pieces are shallow, obvious, illcomposed and all but devoid of fresh observation, intellectual subtlety and emotional depth. The Irish stories, though unsensational, have a fine, mature, well  knit quality to them. The lyrics may be mournful and repetitious, but the best of them do sing.

title: Brazil's Xavantes Live Uneasily on Frontier's Fringe

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: We have The Rev. Gerard LaMountain's word for it: he knows something about Spain. And his letter (June 30) in response to my review of Juan Goytisolo's Count Julian (May 5) shows us what he knows, and knows by heart: the ideological litany that the forces of Spanish oppression have been repeating during the past four centuries. Nothing new here: similar opinions can be read, day after day, in the editorial pages of the Franco press. I do not share LaMountain's ideology. Through such inanities as the longing of the Spanish soul for wholeness, he may go on justifying the Inquisition, the repression of religious and ethnical minorities and the politics of overseeing and suspecting the beliefs and practices of men and women. What is frankly ridiculous is his attempt at scholarship. LaMountain, alas, simply has not kept up with modern Spanish historiography.

title: The Nation
description: While reaffirming his oppostion to the mandatory controls that failed him, President Nixon has asked Congress to establish in the White House a Cost of Living Task Force that would have no enforcement powers but would monitor wage and price increases.

title: New &Novel
description: The sun is never going to set on Empire, not as long as there are such as James Hanley and John Masters to retell the stories of the bad old days. In this atmospheric adventure novel, the British Raj is preparing to abandon Mingora, a tiny protectorate which Masters has made room for between Thailand and Malaysia. But as colonialism ebbs, terrorism flows into the small country. Agrarian reformers with automatic weapons are getting ready to replace the Government of their queen with a People's Republic.

title: Art
description: THERE is something about the America of the 1770s that is now more than ever precious to us: a sense of moral energies intact and ready to go. People knew what had to be done, and they went out and did it. The People should never rise without doing something to be remembered . something notable and striking, John Adams wrote of the Boston Tea Party. This Destruction of the Tea is so bold, so daring, so firm, intrepid and inflexible that I cannot but consider it as an Epoch in History.

title: A NAZI GIRL STIRS DEBATE ON COAST

title: Wordsmith of the American Revolution
description: With one eye to the impending Bicentennial, a biographer or, for that matter, a moviemaker might well think that Toni Paine's story has everything. There are the first 37 years of his life in England, biding his time like Grant in Galena: poverty, scrappy education, dismissal from his job as an exciseman, bankruptcy, a marriage gone wrong. Bring him to Philadelphia in 1774, after a lucky meeting with Benjamin Franklin in London. Then his decade of glory as wordsmith of the American Revolution, the author of the matchlessly blunt and inspiring Common Sense and Crisis pamphlets.

title: Baseball, Hockey and Basketball OfferKey to Stalemate Over Rozelle's Role
description: Whatever the final details agreed to, it is already clear how some key issues in the football strike will be settled  because the other three major sports already have reached those positions. After last week's long but inconclusive bargaining sessions, and in the negotiations that will resume Tuesday, the truly unresolved questions, still involve muscle. On the owners's side is the continuing belief that somehow the strikers will give up and return to work, either a few at time or in a flood. On the players' side, there is the conviction that the owners intend no serious giveandtake bargaining until they come to the conclusion that the strikers won't simply quit.

Already many countries, including both the rich (the Soviet Union, Britain, Australia and others) and the poor (China, most African and LatinAmerican states), have indicated at least qualified support for the idea.

title: The Daughters

description: Debora L. Velsor Thornton, a senior mortgage analyst with the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America, was married yesterday morning to Raymond J. Betti, a teacher at the St. James School in Carmel, N.Y.

title: SOVIET BLOC TALKS ARE REPORTED SET
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 (Reuters)Communist party leaders of Warsaw Pact countries will meet in the Crimea within the next two days, the Belgrade newspaper Politika reported today.

title: The rules of the game: win
description: The main line of this wideranging, thoroughly fascinating book is an attack on something called strategic politics  the winning is the only thing politics of professional analysts and managers whose public purpose is defined by the power game. The chief commandments of strategic politics are keep your options open and maximize your power position. The players have no feel at all for the traditional political skills: persuasion, accommodation, listening, compromise and the development of constituencies on the basis of performance  if not of crystalclear policies.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Photography
description: I THOUGHT for a moment that I had walked into an exhibition of what used to be called, way back in the 1920's, Modern Photography. You know the sort I mean: photographs of eggs, roots, flower pots and rocks all in extremely sharp focus, all with great depth of field, all strongly, dramatically lit and framed in such a way that the spectator could not always tell exactly what was being photographed.

title: U.S. STRIKE ROUNDUP
description: During the period of wage controls, labor was docile since it was legally limited to a 5.5 per cent annual increase in wages. But on April 30 when controls were lifted, workers could begin for the first time in 33 months to bargain for salary increases that approached the doubledigit inflation rate.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS GET SUMMER AID
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3Help has been received by some of the thousands of foreign students across the country who are experiencing severe financial hardship as a result of a decision by the Federal Government prohibiting them from accepting summer employment.

title: Food
description: Robert Louis Stevenson once set down a haunting, poignant and much quoted reflection on food. He has Ben Gunn say in Treasure Island, Many's the long night I've dreamed of cheesetoasted, mostly. We recently thought of that line again in relation to displaced New Yorkers. In the Alaskan tundra or on the banks of the Ganges, New Yorkers yearn for the delis of Manhattan, particularly for their corned beef or pastrami, Over the years, we have had scores of requests from these displaced souls, asking for directions on how to cure one's own. If one can find the basics a slab of beef flanken or brisket of beef and a smokerthe recipe, basically simple, is here. Pastrami? In summer? Indeed, yes. And in winter, spring or fall as well.

title: Nations Are Now Exchanging Expertise and Equipment
description: Torture has now become a state institution in more than 30 countries, a rule of pain carried out by technicians, scientists, paramilitary officials, judges and cabinet ministers.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Religion, Veterinary Medicine
description: Women, in most JudeoChristian religions, may be leaders of their people, they may be prophets and evangelists and they may attain sainthood, but with still rare exceptions the sacerdotal, or priestly, function is reserved fox men.

title: Portuguese Say Rebels Trick 100 to Surrender
description: LOURENCO MARQTJE Mozambique, Aug. 3 (Reuters)The Portuguese high command alleged today that African nationalist guerrillas had tricked a garrison of 100 into surrendering.

title: Dave Pain's Dream of Track Meets For Over40 Athletes Huge Success
description: In this youthoriented society, Dave Pain has been bucking the tide. And, from all indications, this torch bearer for the over40 athlete appears to be winning hands down.

title: Craftsmen and Museum: Out of Touch
description: When a museum has what is known as a touch policyvisitors may pat, stroke or otherwise handle the exhibitsand the organization running the show believes firmly in the principle of just look, there is bound to be conflict.

title: What's Doing in NEWPORT
description: NEWPORT REVISITEDA halfcentury ago Newport, on the oceanswept tip of Rhode Island's Aquidneck Island, was an enclave surrounded, or nearly so, not only by the sea, but also by a formidable society moat. Five decades, however, have changed the old order. Today one of the great mansions (the Hutton's) has been converted into a motor hotel. Another is a condominium. (A third is reputedly a gambling resort.) Others are museums open to the public for a fee. The conspicuous expenditure of the turnofthecentury Vanderbilts is gone. Young people at the exclusive Bailey's Beach lounge around in the same shorts and Tshirts worn by commoners on the public beaches. The privateeyes of yesteryear are no longer around, since the diamonds worn at parties are usually fake.

title: Buffalo Meat Sales Turn Ranch Hobby Into Business Gain
description: LONGMONT, Colo., Aug. 3Buffalo meat, although it is retailing at a considerably higher price than cattle beef, is turning out to be a bonanza for ranchers who started raising the buffaloes as a hobby 10 years ago.

title: Sidonie Ann Miskimin Is Married
description: Sidonie Ann Miskimin, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Harry A. Miskimin Jr. of Woodbridge, Conn., and Thomas Fadden Clauss Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Clauss of Olyphant, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School. The Rev. Dr. Richard Warch, a Presbyterian minister and professor of American studies at Yale, and the Rev. Peter Fagan of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More performed the ceremony. A reception was given in the common room and the courtyard of the Sterling Divinity Quadrangle.

title: Death Wish Exploits Fear Irresponsibly
description: NEW YORK CITY, like all major American cities, has its problems: bad bookkeeping, polluted air, rising costs, reduced services, high crime rates, a fleeing middle class. Now you might want to add movie to the list, Michael Winner's Death Wish. It's a tackily made melodrama but it so cannily orchestrates the audience's responses that it can appeal to lawandorder fanatics, sadists, muggers, club women, fathers, older sisters, masochists, policemen, politicians, and, it seems, a number of film critics. Impartially. Its message, simply put, is: KILL. TRY IT. YOU'LL LIKE IT.

title: Stony Brook Adds PartTime Students
description: STONY BROOK  For the first time in the 12year history of the state university here, undergraduate and graduate classes will, be open to parttime students this September.

title: The Industry Has Bought Influence Wherever It Existed
description: WASHINGTONTrading political contributions for Government favors goes back to the days when warriors hauled in booty to gain favor with the king. In this city, few have followed this old profession with such an impact as the dairy farmers' lobby, and some of their actions have produced a scandal of bipartisan dimensions that stands out even in the massive shadows of the Watergate affair.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Steve Garvey, like most Dodgers, remembers last year's fall from pennant grace: None of us feels we lost the pennant last year. Cincinnati just had a super second half. I like Walt Alston's explanation when he said he might win a pennant one year and it wouldn't mean a darn thing the next season.

title: Reaction in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGENews that a Public Service Commission report had identified 39 sites in Suffolk County that it said would be suitable for electric power plants drew lukewarm and some heated responses in the area last week.

title: Lisbon Rescinds: Suspension of 3 Papers
description: LISBON, Aug. 3Portugal's military, leaders, faced with threats of a shutdown by the news media and a split within the armed forces, rescinded today an order suspending publication of three Lisbon newspapers.

title: A Michelin For Everything
description: Here is a book that reads like a Consumer's Report written by Dorothy Sayers. Full of energetic, crunchy distinctions isolating the best from the mediocre and the terrible, Leonard Ross and Peter Passell choose their motley favorites according to idiosyncrasy, snobbery and meandering scientific method. Their choice of things to consider is just as important as their actual stickingon of stars, so we have the best grand touring sedan, the best electronic calculator and the best ski binding, cheek by jowl with the best con game, the best strategy for investing in the stock market, the best illustration that irony wasn't invented by Oscar Wilde and the best way to stay alive.

title: Elizabeth May, Ralph P. Jessen Plan Matriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick May of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Shaw May, to Ralph Peter Jessen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner F. Jessen of So Paulo, Brazil, and Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Players Meet Today to ReEvaluate Strike
description: Striking National Football League players will hold club meetings today to decide whether to continue their strike in the wake of the latest breakdown in talks with league owners. The strike is in Its 35th day.

title: Korean Security
description: There can be no argument with the Administration's contention that the security of South Korea is integrally related to the security of Japan and the whole military balance in East Asia. But the legitimate question has been raised as to whether the repressive policies President Park Chung Bee are in fact promoting that securityor, alternatively, weakening South Korea's ability to withstand subversion or overt military attack from the North.

title: Charisma Wins Astor Cup
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 3Charisma won the Astor Cup today and Intrepid beat Courageous again as the New York Yacht Club's annual summer cruise came to an end with a slambang race in a smoky 25knot southwest breeze on Rhode Island Sound.

title: HERBERT BRUNER, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: Dr. Herbert B. Bruner, former professor of education at Teachers College of Columbia University; New York University, and St. John's University, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. His age was 81.

title: The New Model Fords
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 33  Almost everybody talks these days about the problems of the Nixons, but just for a change, consider the problems of the Fordsthe Vice President and his family.

title: Remodeling Picks Up As Home Sales Sag
description: The home improvement business is booming, according to industry officials, because of the scarcity of mortgage money, the high cost of new construction and consumer uncertainty generated by the energy crunch.

title: Baker Gains The Pole for Race Today
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 3  Bud Moore and Buddy Baker, who couldn't put it together while they were apart, combined today to win the pole position for tomorrow's Purolator 500mile stockcar race at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Drawings of Georges Lacombe: The Inward Vision of a Minor Artist
description: GEORGES LACOMBE, a French artist who lived from 1868 to 1916, is known chiefly for his wood sculptures and his membership in the group of painters called the Nabis. He is very little known, especially in America, even for all that. It is thus unlikely that the exhibition of his drawings currently at the Shepherd Gallery will attract much of the art public.

title: A New Look In Greece
description: ATHENS  The time has come for the United States to change both the substance and the symbol of its policy, toward Greece, and this dual move could best be accomplished by naming a distinguished American of international renown as ambassador.

title: RABBI ISADORE AARON
description: Rabbi Isadore A. Aaron, since last year rabbi emeritus of Congregation Mount Sinai at 305 Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 4 Fort Greene Place in Brooklyn. His age was 74.

title: Child to Goldmachers
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Steven Mark Goldmacher of Denville, N.J., on July 6 at St. Claire's Hospital in Denville. The child has been named Veronica Laine. Mrs. Goldmacher is the former Miss Barbara Gallagher of Valley Stream, L.I. Mr. Goldmacher is manager of corporate services for the RCA Coporation.

title: Happiness Is Playing a Lost Brahms Cello Sonata
description: THERE is one happy cellist in the world today, and his name Janos Starker. It was a week ago Thursday that he played, at the Ravinia Festival near Chicago, what might have been the American premiere of the Cello Sonata in D major (Op. 78) by Johannes Brahms.

title: News of the Stage
description: Terence Rattigan's latest play, In Praise of Love, starring Rex Harrison and Julie Harris, has been earmarked for Broadway on Dec. 10 by Arthur Cantor.

title: Senators Weigh TV License Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 With the strongly conflicting views of 108 witnesses for background, the members of the Senate Communications Subcommittee will soon meet in private to consider a bill the television industry contends is essential, but which many critics have denounced as a giveaway.

title: HERBICIDE SPRAYING STIRS COURT FIGHT
description: LANSING, Mich., Aug. 3The proposed spraying of chemical defoliants, used by the United States Army in Vietnam, on national forest acreage in northern Wisconsin and Michigan's Upper Peninsula, has becorpe the center of controversy between the two states and the Federal Government.

title: Carefree Succulents from South Africa
description: FOR those who do not have the time to fuss with plants, succulents fill the bill for most any location. Normally sun loving, some will grow well in partial shade. Of particular fascination are the Crassulas with over two hundred species, mostly from South Africa.

title: For the Moment, 11 Women Are Episcopal Priests
description: The Episcopal Church, which has been debating the ordination of women for almost five years, has now been placed in the position where debate is no longer appropriate to the problem.

title: 1,700 Fight Brush Fire
description: CABAZON, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI)Some 1,700 men chopped ground breaks today around the northern end of a 4,000acre timberbrush fire in the San Gor. gonio mountains after its advance had been halted by 100 retardant drops from airplanes.

title: Beth Rhude Bride Of Richard Colgate
description: Beth E. Rhude, a psychotherapist and minister in the United Church of Christ, was married here last evening to Richard Morse Colgate. The Rev. Lawrence Jones, also of the. United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony in the Lampman Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary, of which he is dean.

title: Whitey Ford's 16 Retired As Yanks' OldTimers Lose
description: The Yankees staged their first oldtimers' reunioninexile yesterday when they gathered their living legends into the home of the Mets and remembered when.

title: Once a Politician, Always an Actor
description: INSIDE the small room serving as a movie set it was as hot as a sauna. Lights in huge glass fishbowls hung from the padded ceiling. Thirty of usmembers of a British film unit, plus a handful of reportersstood in a petrified lumen forest as a bellow of rage swept through the room.

title: MARKETS, IN REVIEW
description: The stock market took a bad beating last week as prices tumbled acrosstheboard in continued lackluster trading.

title: Puppeteer Uses Variety of Talents
description: When Susan Delery Whedon was 10 years old, her parents gave her a set of puppets. She would entertain her friends for hours and became so good that the following year she staged a puppet show at a friend's party. That was her first performance, for which she was paid $3.

title: Latest Slide Ended. With 62 Victory Behind Dobson
description: The New York Yankees relived their distant past yesterday before 50,828 persons, the largest American League crowd of the season. Then they lived down some of their recent past when they overpowered the firstplace Boston Red Sox, 62.

title: Criminals At Large
description: How bent does a cop have to be to be really bent? Can a cop who takes a tiny bit of grafta free meal here, a $10 shakedown from a prostitute therebe described as just little bit pregnant? How can he handle himself among a group of cynical pals in the department who are entirely on the make? What is he to do when even a commission investigating police corruption acts in very peculiar ways indeed?

title: Ross Parker, 59, Lyricist, Dies; Wrote Always Be an England
description: LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP)Ross Parker, a lyricist and composer who wrote We'll Meet Again and There'll Always Be an England, song hits of World War II, died Friday at his home in Kent. He was 59 years old.

title: Miss Ryan Fiancee Of Edward F. Hewer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James V. Ryan of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Marybeth Ryan, to Edward Frederick Heuer, son of Mrs. John H. Heuer of Tamarac, Fla., formerly of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Heuer.

title: Gorks don't die, they just box
description: Joe Womack is a young resident in the neurology ward of a large city hospital, where come the poor, the rejects and flotsam of a sorry urban world. To many of the sleek, ambitious doctors these patients are not human beings but merely, like rats or dogs, something new on which to experiment. But to themselves, their families and the newest most idealistic internes, they are people. Amidst the filth, inefficiency, pandemonium and constant lifeordeath crises, however, one has to become impervious to the humanity of these human beings or else lose one's own sanity.

title: Coast Guard Saves 2, But It Takes 2d Effort
description: FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 3 (AP)Word came in to the Coast Guard that a small boat had run aground last night on the south side of Fishers Island, south of Mystic, Conn., in Long Isand Sound, and was sinking.

title: Infuriator Next in WhitneyTime Is 1:47 for 1 Miles
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3An invader from Hollywood Park in California, Fred Hooper's Tri Jet, contributed a recordbreaking performance today in taking the 47th running of the Whitney.

title: American Populism
description: A quietly, remarkably useful book, American Populism yields more pleasure than one at first expects. The clash of contradictions and differences proves intellectually exciting. Yes, one wants to say, this in its teeming variety is American: an energy, an intellectual subsoil, a dazzling luxuriance of contrary tendencies and contrary roots, interrelated.

title: How Long Can He Take It?
description: WASHINGTONOne day last week, while House and Senate leaders were making preparations for the impeachment and trial of Richard M. Nixon, Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon emerged from a long meeting with the President on foreign and economic policies. Because Mr. Nixon has been so seclusive and withdrawn of late, reporters wanted to know how he looked and acted.

title: Envelope for U.S. Tennis Centenary
description: THE 100th anniversary off the introduction of lawn tennis into the United States is being marked by a new innovative 10cent stamped envelope in free colors that will be issued on Aug 31 at Forest Hills, N.Y. during the 1974 U.S. Open Tennis Tournament that runs from Aug. 28 to Sept. 4.

title: NEW DELAY FOUND ON LITTON'S SHIPS
description: Representative Les Aspin disclosed yesterday that Litton Industries had incurred new delays of up to a year in build ing five amphibiousassaul ships that are already two to three years behind schedule.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Religion, Veterinary Medicine
description: The administrators of New Jersey's statewide educational assessment program share the fifth floor of the State Education Building in Trenton with an arm of the departmental bureaucracy known as the Division of Controversies and Disputes. The juxtaposition is entirely appropriate.

title: Sydney AdsHit DrinkerWho Drives
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 3 Fullpage advertisements in Sydney newspapers show a group of drinkers with the word slob in letters twoandahalf inches high at the top of the page.

title: SlumArea Home Plan Called Fraud
description: A Federal program to sell vacant slumarea homes to new owneroccupants was denounced as a gigantic fraud last week by an association of neighborhoodbetterment groups here.

title: Bombs in Paris Damage Three Offices
description: PARIS, Aug. 3  Three car bombs exploded outside the offices of two rightwing publicalions and a Jewish welfare organization early today. The police defused a fourth bomb outside the offices of the national television network.

title: Watergate, the Inescapable Issue
description: Even before the voters have their say on Watergate in November's Congressional and state elections, it is apparent that the most farreaching political scandal in the nation's history has had a profound impact on the electoral process in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Watergate fallout, even at this early stage in regional political campaigns, is falling across party and state lines.

title: EDWARD W. JOHNS
description: Edward W. Johns, a writer and lecturer on the history and art of pictureframing who retired in 1969 as Eastern representative of the NewcombeMacklin Company, Chicago, manufacturer of picture frames, died yesterday at the Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Consuelo Cotter Is the Bride Of Walter Mack Jr., a Lawyer
description: Consuelo Cotter, an account executive here with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, was married yesterday afternoon to Walter S. Mack Jr., who has been appointed an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. The Rev. J. Arthur Martin, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of Concord (Mass.) Academy.

title: Arizona Indians Seekto Live on Ancestors' Remote Plateau
description: SUPAI VILLAGE, Ariz.Red canyon walls rise above the Havasupai Indian Reservation like the cluttered shelves of an untidy professor's study, with cracked and buckled seams of massive rock sagging under the weight of the geological history of ages.

title: The Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Case For Boxing/The DI Factor in Baseball
description: To the Editor: The recent statement by Alan N. Cohen, new president of Madison Square, that boxing may be dropped from the schedule of events at the Garden comes as just another disappointing shock to sports' longest suffering and neglected fanthe fight enthusiast.

title: Dr. John Kirkwood Weds Gale Duncan
description: Gale Arcuni Duncan of Brookville, L.I., former editor for Corporate Reorganization Reporter, Inc., Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. John Robert Kirkwood of Bethesda, Md., a neuroradiologist and assistant professor at George Washington University Medical Center.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS GET SUMMER AID
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3Help has been received by some of the thousands of foreign students across the country who are experiencing severe financial hardship as a result of a decision by the Federal Government prohibiting them from accepting summer employment.

title: It's Maddox vs. Other Fellows In Georgia's Race for Governor
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 3The public style of Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox has mellowed a bit since the days when he gave away ax handles on the street for use as cudgels against civil rights demonstrators, but he is still flamboyant in facetoface meetings, just being Ole Lester, as he likes to be called.

title: Cecile Marie Doelger Is Bride Of John H. Pinto Jr., a Lawyer
description: Cecile Marie Doelger, a greatgranddaughter of Peter Doelger, founder of the family brewery and real estate, companies, both of which bore his name, was married yesterday afternoon in New Canaan, Conn., to John Howard Pinto Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pinto of Los Angeles.

title: Casino Gambling Forces Gird for Battle
description: TRENTON  The battle to determine whether New Jersey voters will authorize casino gambling in the state is about to begin.

title: Mortgage Hurdle Challenges Buyers
description: Many a potential home buyer or seller these days is being advised: Don't.

title: Music
description: When Leon Fleisher began his conducting career, it was the Mostly Mozart Festival that offered him a debut appearance here. That was in the summer of 1970. He was back with the festival in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, with a mansize programtwo Haydn symphonies and two Mozart concertosplayed before a capacity audience.

title: Peronist Guerrillas Take Responsibility In Death of a Leftist
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 (UPI) A splinter group of Peronist guerrillas took responsibility today for the machinegun death of a leftist congressman.

title: The World
description: Recent history in the Middle East and Vietnam has shown that wars end not when diplomats announce ceasefires but when soldiers stop shooting. Now there is a third example. Greece, Turkey and Britain last week met in Geneva and signed an agreement to end the fighting on Cyprus, but on that island the war went on because Turkey has an advantage it would not negotiate away.

title: 3 OFFICES EXAMINE GOLDIN'S CHARGES
description: Separate teams of investigators and auditors huddled at three different locations yesterdayin the offices of the City Controller, the Manhattan District Attorney and the special state prosecutorto delve into a tangle of accusations about late entries in the ledgers governing millions of dollars in securities in the Controller's vault.

title: Peaceful coexistence At a Craftsmen's Fair
description: AS recently as 1969, the craft fair Mount Sunapee State Park in New Hampshire was something yam could take in between lunch an dinner, and probably have time left ove to squeeze in an antiques shop and a dip in the lake. This year you'll need a ful weekend plus some knowledge of thi history and scope of the civil war within the handcraft worldto appreciate this exposition by some of the finest artisan; in America. It runs from this Tuesday through next Sunday.

title: Home Improvement
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036

title: The Future Of Cyprus Is As Cloudy As the Past
description: ATHENSOn Thursday, talks resume in Geneva over the political future of Cyprus. If past performance is any guide, it is likely to be a longrunning show.

title: Stamps
description: THE World Cycling Championships, usually held in Europe, are being held in Montreal, Canada, Aug. 14 to 25. It will be the first time in recent history that the event will be held in North America, so Canada, with pride, is putting out a commemorative stamp for the occasion.

title: Numismatics
description: IF it is true that misery loves company, everyone who is concerned about this country's current inflation will want to see the Newark Museum's special exhibit on the inflation that wracked Germany during and after World War I. Although it is entitled Inflation: How It Happened in Germany 19141923, the exhibit is not so much economic as numismatic, not so much an explanation of the underlying causes as a vivid look at the emergency coins, tokens and paper money which the German people were forced to use during those years of monetary chaos.

title: Prison Turmoil Disrupts French Judicial System
description: PARIS, Aug. 3Sporadic riots over the last 14 days and a continuing strike of French prison guards have now seriously disrupted the criminal justice system here. As a result, prisoners are not being released and new convicts are not being admitted to French prisons.

title: Griffin Urges Nixon Not to Defy Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Senator Robert P. Griffin wrote to President Nixon today that he would consider it an impeachable offense and vote accordingly in a Senate trial if the President defied a Senate subpoena for tapes.

title: Oilers Post Sloppy 167 Victory Before 15,501
description: HOUSTON, Aug.3Rookies and free agents of the New York Giants and Houston Oilers tried to convince a crowd of 15,501 in the Astrodome tonight that a National Football League game was being played.

title: An Old Scheme for Real Writers
description: It is no pleasure to disagree publicly with a writer who has given me as much grim enjoyment as Kurt Vonnegut Jr., but I take exception to his proposals in A New Scheme for Real Writers (Guest Word, July 14). He recommended that college creative writing Courses be replaced by noncredit tutorials, a sort of openofficedoor policy by which anyone, student or nonstudent, could bring in manuscripts, for criticism. Real writers would thus presumably be served, while weaker ones would promptly be weeded out  a sort of literary survivalofthefittest.

title: FUND CURB ALTERS CALIFORNIA RACE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3the hard lessons of the spring primary campaign and the impact of Watergate have caused deep changes in California political life that are visible as the autumn offyear campaigns begin.

title: Cities Are Strengthening Building Codes to Combat HighRise Fires
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3  When Lauren Ford, the fire chief of Troy, joined the volunteer fire department of that Detroit suburb in 1940, tie tallest buildings in the town were twostory homes and couple of churches.

title: Smith, Ashe Are Beaten At Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug, 3 (UPI)Topranked Stan Smith and secondseeded Arthur Ashe were defeated today in a wave of upsets that engulfed the quarterfinal round of the $100,000 First National Tennis Classic.

title: For the Folksy Rural Radio Station, No Service Is Too Humble to Put on the Air
description: CHARLES CITY, Iowa When Guy Burge lost one of his rubber overshoes somewhere on Clark Street here not long ago, he naturally telephoned KCHA, the local radio station.

title: Keystone Presto Wins At Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Aug. 3  Keystone Presto fought off challenges from two rivals and won the $15,000 Invitational Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: A Seashore Vacation, CommuneStyle
description: BEACH HAVENIt is not at all unusual if a vacation home at the seashore is owned by several families, none of whom occupies it at the same time. One week, the Smiths; the next week, the Joneses, and so on.

title: Tips On Growing Tarragon
description: Tarragon (Artemisia dracunculus) is the only useful culinary herb among the aromatic Artemisias. Its specific name, dracunculus, mean, ing little. dragon may refer to tarragon's supposed power to heal the bites of venomous insects or mad dogs. Or might it refer to the bite of tarragon's flavor?

title: Wealthy in Monterrey Live Heavily Guarded Lives in Fear of Guerrillas
description: MONTERREY, MexicoA limousine with darkened rear windows sweeps through downtown Monterrey, behind it two other large cars, each sprouting twoway radio antennas and carrying numerous bulky men who impatiently wave cars and pedestrians out of the way.

title: Miner Memorial Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)The United Mine Workers plans to call a 10day memorial period this summer to pay tribute to coal miners killed In the nation's mines. The union president, Arnold Miller has said that under the 1971 contract with the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, the union has a right to designate 19 days as a memorial period. During that period, no coal can be mined by operators who signed the agreement.

title: Spending The Oil Money
description: LONDONAn apocryphal story told in London's financial district is that Saudi Arabia will use its newfound oil wealth to buy control of General Motors and then announce: What's good for Saudi Arabia is good for the United States.

title: Point of View
description: During the next 12 months approximately 20,040 apartments subsidized by the Federal Government and started before the January moratorium on subsidies will come into the New York City housing market. Unless there are Changes in the income requirements, the Government may be spawning a mighty wave of racial segregation.

title: Bill to Block Dams on a River In Blue Ridge Area Is Periled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 A bill designed to block construetion of the controversial Blue Ridge hydroelectric project on the New River in western Virginia and North Carolina may get ensnarled in impeachment proceedings and die unless the House Interior Committee acts soon.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Dave Hill Retains Lead By 2 Strokes With 205
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 3While Dave Hill and Tom Weiskopf were flailing around the course with some erratic playing, Jim Wiechers, a chubby wine collector from the wine capital of Napa, Calif., sneaked in today and tied for second place in the third round of the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic.

title: All the stories he has ever heard
description: A new, hitherto unknown novelist swam into my ken, Floyd Dell wrote in his autobiography more than 40 years ago about a time back further still when a Midwesterner named Sherwood Anderson pressed a manuscript into his hands. I immensely admired it, Dell recalled about his reading of Windy MacPherson's Son. It had things in it about the Middle West which had never got into fiction, and a soulquestioning quasiDostoevskyan note in it too which I admired devoutly. . . . American readers can now enjoy a similar shock of recognition by picking up a copy of The Easter House, a novel by young Iowan named David Rhodes.

title: Mary Fogarty Bride of J. K. Kehoe
description: The Memorial Chapel at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Corleen Fogarty, daughter of William Everett Fogarty of Harmony, R. I., and the late Mrs. Fogarty, to John Kimball Kehoe, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Kehoe of Wilmington, III.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: C. E. Finn Jr. Weds Dr. Virmani
description: Dr. Renu Virmani, daughter of R. N. Virmani, an industrialist of Delhi and Amritsar, India, and the late Mrs., Virmani, was married yesterday afternoon to Chester E. Finn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finn of Dayton, Ohio. Judge Walter Rice of the Common Pleas Court of Montgomery County, Ohio, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Conservatively, Baryshnikov Is Overwhelming!
description: NEW YORK is a town that is accustomed to the best. But the event at Lincoln Center's New York State Theater last Saturday night was something special, even by local standards. For this was the American debut of Mikhail Baryshnikov, formerly of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet, and his first performance anywhere since he had defected from the Soviet Union a month before while on tour in Canada with a group of Bolshoi Ballet dancers.

title: 2 Women Hostages, 2 Convicts Killed After 10Day Texas Siege
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug 3Two inmates and two women hostages were killed tonight in an exchange of gunfire as the convicts tried to escape from the Huntsville State Prison with 12 hostages they had held for 10 days.

title: Texas Aide Defends Prison Siege Toll Of 4 Dead and 2 Wounded in Shootout
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 4The courtyard at Huntsville State Prison was quiet today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ATOM POWER FOE OBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 4The Texas Department of Public Safety has acknowledged having compiled a dossier on a commercial airline pilot who heads a group opposed to a proposed nuclear power plant near Dallas.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Soviet Union fives A Dissident WriterTwoYear Exit Visa
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Viktor P. Nekrasov, a prizewinning Soviet author who fell into official disfavor for liberal views, has been given an exit visa to live abroad for two years, friends said today.

title: N.F.L. Exhibitions
News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 5, 1974

title: Inmate Shot in Prison Brawl
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI)A 31yearold prison inmate shot in the stomach during a brawl between convicts and guards was reported to be in satisfactory condition today. The convict, Lawrence Alexander, was wounded with a 38caliber revolver by a guard during a melee yesterday involving 12 convicts and 20 guards, San Quentin prison officials said.

title: Franklin Savings Bank to Raze Building
description: Declaring that it is a dump the city would be better off without, in the words of Edward Rollins, executive vice president, officials of the Franklin Savings Bank have decided to demolish the monumental structure at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street that was the bank's home from 1901 until last year.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Pyramid sales schemes seem to have been around as long as someone has wanted to make a fast buck. Hundreds of people are duped in getrichquick schemes every year, losing thousands of dollars.

title: WHITE HOUSE TAPES REPORTEDLY CLIPPED
description: Time magazine said yesterday that a fiveminute, 12second gap in a White House tape of a conversation between President Nixon and his top aides had resulted from the end of one reel and the beginning of a new one being clipped.

title: SAIGON REPORTS BATTLE STEPS UP
description: SAIGON, Monday, Aug. 5 (AP)North Vietnamese and South Vietnamese forces suffered more than 350 casualties in a dawntodusk battle yesterday on the outskirts of the besieged district town of Duc Duc 20 miles south of Da Nang, the Saigon command announced today.

title: Franklin Savings Bank to Raze Building
description: Declaring that it is a dump the city would be better off without, in the words of Edward Rollins, executive vice president, officials of the Franklin Savings Bank have decided to demolish the monumental structure at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street that was the bank's home from 1901 until last year.

title: Bridge: Players Trained in Chess Can Analyze Card Moves
description: A surprising number of bridge experts were chess enthusiasts in their youth. But as they grew older, they turned from kings and queens in black and white to kings and queens in black and red.

title: Denyer Ineptness Helps in 4119 Victory
description: If the Jets 4119 opening exhibition victory over the Denver Broncos was typical of what the National Football League owners have in mind for the 1974 season, the striking players and the neophyte World Football League have it made.

title: Bombing Threats Continue in Paris; Suspect Is Sought
description: PARIS, Aug. 4  The Paris police responded to eight more bomb threats last night, but found no boobytrapped cars of the type that exploded in front of the offices of the Jewish Social Fund and at the offices of two antiArab newspapers Friday night.

title: Red Sox Top Yanks For Tiant's 17th, 73
description: The New York Yankees, oneday revolt against the Boston Red Sox subsided yesterday when Luis Tiant pitched Boston to a 73 victory and became the major leagues' first 17game winner of the season.

title: Two Missing Bronx Girls Are Found Safe Near Home
description: Two young sisters who were the object of a police manhunt since they were discovered missing Saturday were found safe yesterday after they spent the night walking around the South Bronx according to the police.

title: U.S. Sends Official to Assess Mood for a Cyprus Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The State Department announced today that Assistant Secretary of State Arthur A. Hartman had flown to Turkey on the first leg of a quick trip to assess the thinking of Turkish, Greek and Cypriote leaders on a settlement of the Cyprus problem.

title: Lutz Bows To Riessen In Net Final
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (UPI) Topseeded Marty Riessen won two tiebreakers from Bob Lutz today to win the $30,000 Western tennis championship.

title: Big Board Approves GoldBar Sales Plan
description: Samuel Weiss, who heads the New York Stock Exchange member firm of Samuel Weiss & Co., 111 Broadway, has announced that he has obtained exchange approval to sell gold in smallsized bars, ranging from a watersized  ounce, to 1 ounce, 5 ounces, 10 ounces, 25 and 50 ounces.

title: The Ballet: Notre Dame
description: PARIS, Aug. 4For T. S. Eliot, April was the cruelest month, and for Paris, July and August have traditionally been the deadest. Even now, August is pretty tough for theatrically minded tourists. Not only are a remarkfore or after), but in the therestaurants closed (and one of the noblest aspects of the French theater is eating before or after), but in the theater it is mainly such pillars of culture as the Lido, the Mayol, the Crazy Horse Saloon and Oh! Calcutta! that keep the tourists happy. There is also a comedy called Boeing, Boeing, which is to Paris what The Mousetrap is to London.

title: Atlanta Mayor Picks Black As Police and Fire Director
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 4Mayor Maynard Jackson said today that he would ask the city council to appoint former Boston Corrections Commissioner Reginald Eaves as public safety director.

title: Jenny Turrall, Aussie Star, Says Crowd Helped Her Set World 1,500 Swim Mark
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP)The newest swimming star from Australia thanked an American crowd for helping her break the freestyle world record at 1,500 meters for the fourth time in eight months.

title: Rain and High Winds Lead to Capsizing Of Small Craft here
description: A series of thundershowers accompanied by wind gusts of more than 50 miles an hour swept the metropolitan area from the southeast yesterday afternoon and evening, causing some minor flooding and pawer failures and trouble to many small sailboats and cabin cruisers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, in a letter from Pails made public yesterday, has endorsed the New York State gubernatorial candidacy of Howard J. Samuels. The former Mayor said he was delighted to endorse his former offtrack betting chief, and he expressed the hope that any endorsement will have some value somewheres.

title: About New York
description: A husband and wife in Queens have five children, the oldest of whom, a boy, has never been much good. Not long ago he joined the Army, which pleased his parents because they would no longer have him around, and particularly pleased his younger brothers and sisters because he would no longer be able to beat them. The other day, however, he returned, saying that he was A.W.O.L, and that he had come home to stay.

title: LILCO Rate Rise Is Opposed
description: MERRICK, L.I., Aug. 4 (UPI) State Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Merrick, said today that the chairman of the State Consumer Protection Board, Peter M. Pryor, had promised to intervene to oppose a Long Island Lighting Company rateincrease request. Mr. Levy said Mr. Pryor had filed notice with the Public Service Commission to represent Long Island residents in their opposition to the LILCO request for an $88million rate increase.

title: State University Aide Named
description: JEFFERSON, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP)Philip Dunlap, chairman of the University of New Hampshire board of trustees, was named acting chancellor of the state university system at a meeting of the trustees here yesterday.

title: Miss Haynie Golf Victor By 5 Shots
description: HORSHAM, Pa., Aug. 4 (UPI)Sandra Haynie, the United Stites women's open champion, carded a finalround 73 today to finish five strokes ahead of the field in capturing the 54hole George Washington women's golf tournament at Hidden Springs Country Club.

title: N.F.L. Strike Costly
description: The National Football League players' strike produced a drastic drop in attendance figures and revenue during the weekend's first full schedule of preseason games. Crowds were down 256,748 compared to the first 10 games last year and losses were estimated at more than $1.8million. Page 17.

title: Oklahoma Governor and a Bond Firm Linked to $25,000 Kickback on Pact
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 4 Wellplaced sources say a Federal grand jury has been told that secret meetings in a New York apartment, a Tulsa motel and the Oklahoma Governor's mansion preceded the award of a lucrative bond underwriting contract in return for a $25,000 kickback to Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma.

title: Controller Controversy: How and Why It Began, Who and What It Involves
description: The everburgeoning controversy over the City Controller's office and discrepancies in its boobs enters its third week today.

title: Tina Brodsky Has. Nuptials
description: Tina Brodsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin A. Brodsky of West Hempstead, LI., was married yesterday afternoon in Great Neck, LI., to David F. Benet. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Bellet of Teaneck, N. J.

title: . . . or Legal Chaos
description: Around these efforts at planning, good and bad, the courts have imposed what one scholar accurately describes as a legal labyrinth. To lump all the decisions, state and Federal, that have been handed down on the subject, Americans are constitutionally entitled to settle anywhere they pleasebut in effect communities have indirect power to keep them out, without ever saying so, in order to promote the welfare of citizens already ensconced. Thus Petaluma, in California, may neither directly nor indirectly place any numerical limit on its residents; but Ramapo, in New York, may keep itself from becoming one of the blighted ghettos of the nation by means of a delayedgrowth plan extending over eighteen years.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and ?? Page 25

title: LEO SAMLER
description: Leo Samler, a commercial artist in the fashion advertising field, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 55 years old and lived also at 311 East 50th Street.

title: Film Suspense Sustained In Escape to Nowhere
description: ESCAPE TO NOWHERE, directed by Claude Plnoteau; produced by Alain Poire for Gaumont International/Medusa; distributed by PeopercornWormser. At the Cinema II Theater, Third Avenue and 60th Street (in French with English subtitles); and at the Victoria Theater, Broadway and 46th Street (In English). Running time, 118 minutes. (This fling is classified PG.)

title: Guided Growth...
description: Will Americans of the next century be told that they can't move to Oregon, that southern California is closed to settlers, that St. Petersburg, Fla., has standing room only? Perhaps not that directly, but states, counties and cities across the country are already moving in arbitrary ways to check that booming growth that was once the sign and symbol of American progress.

title: College Gives Future Doctors a Look at Urban Medicine
description: When people ask Wai Hung Lee how he spent the summer of '74, he can tell them he discovered an active case of tuberculosis in Chinatown. Charles Wideska can boast about finding a case of diabetes, and Hope Rubin can reminisce about how she learned to test people for anemia.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: APPALOOSA Colt, 2 yr old, T188160, Sorrel with blanket Bald tale & 4 starkings, ?? disposition, $1200 or best offer. 2015843723 eves.

title: Ford, Stumping in South, Draws Exuberant Crowds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 4 One small, unusual sign appeared among the banners and placards of all sizes sprinkled through the enthusiastic crowd of 1,500 that greeted Vice President Ford at the Pine Belt Regional Airport near Hattiesburg, Miss., yesterday.

title: Shelley Berman Bound And Robbed in Queens
description: Shelley Berman, the comedian appearing in Flushing in a production of Room Service, was robbed at gunpoint of a watch and $60 in a Queens hotel room and left bound and gagged on the floor.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Aug. 4The shelves in Jack Simcsak's bedroom are lined with athletic trophiesalmost of themand his scrapbook is filled with reminders of his athletic achievements at Highland Park High at Fork Union prep school and at Virginia Tech. Once he was allAmerica high school quarterback and once, at Virginia Tech, he kicked a 56yard field goal.

title: 2 Die in Japanese Quake
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Two peoplea 20yearold woman and a 55yearold man died from shock when a predawn earthquake shook Tokyo and other parts of Japan today, the police said. No other casualties were reported.

title: Personal Finance: Plans For Credit Buying Vary
description: Consumers seeking to borrow money or make purchases on credit increasingly are being offered a choice of methods, seemingly similar, yet so different in their end results, that one would need a slide rule to choose.

title: Rain and High Winds Lead to Capsizing Of Small Craft Here
description: A series of thundershowers accompanied by wind gusts of more than 50 miles an hour swept the metropolitan area from the southeast yesterday afternoon and evening, causing some minor flooding and power failures and trouble to many small sailboats and cabin cruisers.

title: First Class to Europe: Food Doesn't Make It Easy to Get There
description: We were on the verge of writing that on a recent trip to Europe we traveled firstclass all the way. On rumination we amend that to say that we held a firstclass ticket and sat in what is designated the firstclass section of airplanes. While what we dined on was not exactly ship's biscuits and steerage stew, it was an unseemly altitude from Taillevent.

title: OFFICIAL DEPENDS TEXAS SIEGE TOLL
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 4The courtyard at Huntsville State Prison was quiet today.

title: But Greek Islander Asserts Invaders Must Withdraw
description: FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Aug. 4Cyprus will all burn before we allow the Turkish Army to stay on our island, vowed Kokos Hadjidimitriou, a Greek Cypriote who believes that Cyprus should be part of Greece.

title: Kalmbach Testifies That Ehrlichman Sought to Defame O'Brien
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4President Nixon's former personal attorney has told the

title: 30 East Side Tenants Accusing The Landlord of Cutting Service
description: Thirty tenants of an East Side luxury apartment building are fighting their landlord in the courts, in the streets and even at the race track, charging that he has violated the Rent Stabilization Law by reducing the staff and services since he bought the building a year ago.

title: Gains Found for Top Foreign Concerns
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Gallo Aide Slain at Synagogue Dice Table
description: A Brooklyn synagogue's fundraising Las Vegas Nite program ended in violence early yesterday when a reputed associate of the socalled Joey Gallo group in organized crime was killed by a shot in the head, apparently fired from outside the building.

title: Opera: Pasatieri's The Penitentes Sung at the Aspen Festival
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 4Thomas Pasatieri seems well on his way to becoming a 20thCentury Donizetti. Like that fecund composer of operas (there are more than 70 of them), Mr. Pasatieri is both prolific and, judging from the frequency with which his works pop up all over the country, successful. At the age of 28, he already has 10 operas to his credit, two of which have been given premieres this summer: Signor Deluso at Wolftrap Farm, Va., and The Penitentes, first performed last night in Aspen's diminutive Wheeler Opera House.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: Crabiel Still Silent on Proposal By Byrne That He Take a Leave
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel remained silent today on Governor Byrne's suggestion two days ago that he take a leave of absence until charges against him of contract bid rigging had been resolved.

title: Reverse Family Planning
description: BUENOS AIRES (UPI)Argentina plans to try to double its population to 50 million people by the year 2000, says the Interior Ministry. The ministry is studying plans to reverse emigration and attract at least 125,000 new residents annually.

title: ARAMCO TRANSFER WARPS STATISTICS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The change in ownership of an oil company thousands of miles away in Saudi Arabia accounts for the entire decline in the real United States Gross National Product in the second quarter, Government statisticians have discovered.

title: Rain, Rookies Sprinkle Wet Astrodome
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 4O.K., so the Houston Oilers beat the New York Giants, 167, last night. Does this mean that the Giants now become the worst team in the National Football League?

title: 30,000 in Mozambique Hail Independence Vow
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Aug. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)An estimated 30,000 people demonstrated here today to acclaim the Portuguese Government's pledge earlier today of early independence for Mozambique.

title: Marriage at Plaza For Ruth Sarasohn
description: Ruth Sarasohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu D. Sarasohn of New York, and Gady Reinhold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oskar Reinhold of Forest Hills, Queens, were married last evening at the Plaza by Rabbi Joseph Saffran.

title: Proprietary Homes Called Snake Pits
description: Mental patients released from state institutions and placed in hotelsized proprietary homes are entitled to a $5 weekly allowance from the $375amonth Government check they sign over to the homes.

title: RUDOLPH INGRISCH
description: Rudolph Ingrisch, who re: tired in 1971 as chairman; and chief executive officer of Binney & Smith, Inc., manufacturers here of crayons and artists' materials, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: Lindsay Supports Samuels In Race for Governorship
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, in a letter made public yesterday, has endorsed the gubernatorial candidacy of Howard J. Samuels.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 5, 1974 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Advertising: A Drive by Hertz
description: Hertz, the car rental concern (No. 1, in fact) which has been keeping a low advertising profile since the fuel crisis, will burst from cover Sept. 1 and start spending at an annual rate of some $15million.

title: Kate Robinson Butler Is Dead; Published Buffalo Evening News
description: Kate Robinson Butler, president and publisher of The Buffalo Evening News, died Saturday at her home in Buffalo after a long illness.

title: PHONE UNION GAINS TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4A nationwide strike by the Bell Telephone System's 750,000 employes was averted tonight as union and management negotiators agreed on a new threeyear contract.

title: NEWS INDEX
CYPRIOTES SEIZED BY TURKISH ARMY
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4Turkish troops arrested the ablebodied men and expelled the women and children from the last Greek Cypriote havens in the Turkishoccupied area of northern Cyprus today.

title: Police Call at Bicentennial
description: STARK, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP)This northern New Hampshire town's fiveman police department had to call on other police departments to quell a weekend disturbance at the town's 200th anniversary celebration. The police said between 1,200 and 1,500 people gathered at the bicentennial dance last Friday night when a brawl broke out.

title: STATE PESSIMISTIC ON JOBS OUTLOOK
description: Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, said yesterday that the high unemployment that New Jersey shared with other urban states would probably continue through this year, with only slight improvement.

title: JOHN A. RATHBUN
description: John Alden Rathbun, retired Buffalo district manager of Texaco, Inc., died yesterday in Beaufort, S. C., where he had been living. He was 68 years old.

title: TwoThirds in Poll Back Impeachment of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Twothirds of the American people believe that President Nixon should he impeached over Watergate scandals and tried in the latest Louis Harris Poll.

title: Falcons Pass Pickets and Beat Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP)Kim McQuilken, a Little AllAmerica quarterback from Lehigh University, tossed two touchdown passes tonight and the Atlanta Falcons beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 237, in a striketarnished National Football League exhibition game before 15,379 rainsprinkled fans.

title: News Summary and Index
description: At the end of a twoday conference in Lisbon, Secretary General Waldheim announced that Portugal was ready to recognize the territory of Portuguese Guinea as an independent state and to support its entry into the United Nations. Thus ended Portugal's long estrangement from the United Nations, Mozambique and Angola are expetcted to follow Portuguese Guinea into independence from Portugal and representation in the United Nations. [1:8.]

title: Italy's Netmen Top Rumania As Baruzzutti Defeats Tiriac
description: MESTRE, Italy, Aug. 4 (UPI)  Corrado Barazzutti routed ailing Ion Tiriac of Rumania, 63, 60, 60, today giving Italy the deciding match in a 32 victory in European Zone A Davis Cup competition.

title: Tiny's Gay Scores In Ruidoso Race
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M., Aug. 4(AP)Tiny's Gay galloped into quarterhorse racing history today when he nosed out Vim and Vigor to quarterhorse racing's triple crown, at Ruidoso Downs.

title: SIMON BARS SHIFT IN FISCAL POLICY, BACKS JOBLESS AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Treasury Secretary William E. Simon suggested today that the Nixon Administration would persist in its policy of budget and monetary restraint even if unemployment went above 6 per centthe level that has been considered recessionary.

title: It's Public Telephone Number One
description: A husband calling his wife, a mother calling her babysitter, a salesman calling his client, a guest calling his host....

title: 3 Holdup Men Get $5,000 At FastFood Restaurant
description: Holdup men tied up 10 persons in a Fifth Avenue fast food restaurant Saturday night and escaped with $5,000 in cash, the police said. Three armed men walked into the La Potagerie near 46th Street, about 7:45 P.M., the police said, announced a holdup and herded six patrons and four employes into the basement, where they tied them up.

title: 36 SENATORS SEEN AS NIXON BACKERS
description: Newsweek magazine said yesterday that it had obtained a list of 36 Senators the White House counts on to support (President Nixon if he is impeached and brought to trial in the Senate.

title: Jets' Statistics
Nudity on Increase at Public Beaches Here
description: FAIR HARBOR, L.I,, Aug. 4 There has been much talk of coverup on New York City and Long Island beaches this summer.

title: Helping the Schools
description: At long last, in a flurry of florid rhetoric about busing, the House has passed a $25.2billion bill continuing the basic Federal Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 through fiscal year 1978. This fouryear extension now goes to the White House, where prospects for prompt signature should be good since the bill passed both houses by vetoproof margins.

title: CYPRIOTES SEIZED BY TURKISH ARMY
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4Turkish troops arrested the ablebodied men and expelled the women and children from the last Greek Cypriote havens in the Turkishoccupied area of northern Cyprus today.

title: Gunman With 3 Hostages Gives Up in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP)  A gunman described as Vietnam veteran with guerrilla warfare training surrendered today after holding three persons hostage for three hours in Griffith Park.

title: Schedule Is Heavy For Federal Issues
description: Financing Follows a Week of Rising Interest Rates The Federal Government will undertake a heavy schedule of financing this week on the heels of a discouraging week of rising Interest rates and declining bond prices.

title: United Brands Says It Fears Panama Would Seize Boats
description: PANAMA CITY, Aug. 4 (UPI) The United Brands Company has ordered its banana boats not to put in at Panamanian ports for fear of Government seizure, a high company official said today.

title: Petty Best Man Twice at Pocono Stock Car Race
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 4 Richard Petty, who started the day as best man at a wedding in victory lane, returned to the nuptial scene later today as the winner of the first Grand National stock car race at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Regalado Wins by Shot at Sutton on 278
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 4The nicest thing about winning a golf tournament, aside from that fat $40,000 pay check, is that it means the end of those grim Mondays when a rabbit has to qualify his way into each tournament he plays. There is more pressure there than in the tournament itself.

title: Alleged Rapist Is Stabbed By 4 Rescuers of Victim
description: A 20yearold Brooklyn man who, police say, assaulted and attempted to rape a 43yearold woman early yesterday was set upon by four men who beat him up and stabbed him twice in the chest, injuring him critically.

title: SPRINGSTEEN SINGS WITH ANN MURRAY
description: Saturday's Schaefer Music Festival concert in Central Park suffered a severe case of audience division. Could Ann Murray, a mildmannered. Canadian folkoriented singer, overcome the heavier, even greasier sounds of Bruce Springsteen, a singer Whose star, in terms of audience appeal, appears to be in the ascendant? Perhaps it was a mistake to put Mr. Springsteen, who has been reviewed previously and is heavily into refashioning traditional rock 'n' roll into his own image, against Miss Murray, the headliner.

title: Sussex Area Cleaning Up Havoc in Storm's Wake
description: BYRAM TOWNSHIP, Aug. 4 (UPI)  Cleanup work began in this Sussex County community today after a severe storm yesterday damaged 20 houses, knocked down trees and utility, poles, and blew about 10 cars and a halfdozen trailer houses into nearby woods.

title: Plan Offered to Cut Waiting by Motorists For State Inspection
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)New Jersey's Motor Vehicle Director, John A. Waddington, he come up with a series of proposa?? ?? cut waiting time at inspection stations, including one that would enable motorists to have their cars checked once every 18 months, instead of the present 12 months.

title: Donnadella Fallon Bride
description: Donnadella Fallon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Fallon of Bellerose, Queens, and Leonard Langino, soh of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Langino of Floral Park, L. I., were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, by the Rev. Robert Vignola, a faculty member.

title: Boy, Pushed in Bay, Girl Rescuer Drown; Youth, 14, Charged
description: A 14yearold boy was charged yesterday with killing a 10yearold boy, who was pushed into Jamaica Bay and then drowned with a 12yearold girl who tried to save him.

title: Seoul's Leaders Draw on Confucian Heritage to Rationalize the. Crackdown on Dissidents
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 4Set in a grove of pine trees, the official dining room where South Korea's Premier entertains visitors is an old wooden pavillion built nearly 100 years ago during the nation's last royal dynasty.

title: F.D.A. Accused of Barring New Hypertension Drugs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)Americans suffering from hypertension, or high blood pressure, are being deprived of drugs found to be helpful in treatment of the disease in Britain, according to an editorial in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: S.I.P.C. IS SEEKING HIGHER COVERAGE
description: The Securities Investor Protection Corporation, which Congress erected in 1970 to protect stockholders in case their brokerage firms collapse, will ask Congress to increase the coverage of firms' individual accounts from $50,000 to $125,000.

title: Susan Sweedler Wed To L. E. Ach, Banker
description: Susan Sweedler and Lawrence E. Ach, an assistant treasurer with the investment research department of Bankers Trust Company, were married at noon yesterday at Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn.

title: NIXON CALLS AIDES IN POSSIBLE MOVE ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4President Nixon summoned his chief lawyer, aides and speech writers to his retreat at Camp David, Md., today, arousing speculation that some new move was contemplated as a result of the Congressional impeachment drive.

title: Lisa Kingsley Bride of R. A. Baroni Jr.
description: Lisa Christine Kingsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Edward Kingsley of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday atfernoon to Roland A. Baroni Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Baroni, also of Armonk. The Rev. Cletus E. Dollinger performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase.

title: Transit Officer Stabbed on El Steps; Fires Four Shots at Fleeing Attacker
description: A 55yearold Transit Authority patrolman on his way to work was stabbed in the chest on the stairs of an elevated subway station in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when he tried to resist a knifewielding robber who had taken his wallet.

title: ABUSES REPORTED AT H.R.A. CENTER
description: A Brooklyn office of the city's Human Resources Administration that handles publicassistance cases in the Brownsville section was accused yesterday in a state audit report of ineffective management and the overpayment of clients.

title: Aluminum Output Rises.
description: Primary aluminum producItion in the United States posted a gain of more than 400,000 tons in 1973 over its yearago level, according to the Aluminum Association. Primary aluminum production totaled 4.5 million tons for the year compared with 4.1 million tons in 1972.

title: Cypriote President in Athens for Talks
description: ATHENS, Aug. 4  Greek leaders met here today with the President of Cyprus, Glafkos Clerides, and its was assumed that they were planning strategy for the second round of Geneva talks on Cyprus, which begin Thursday.

title: How a Fragile Centrist Bloc Emerged As House Panel Weighed Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The verdict of the House Judiciary Committee came, in the end, from the President's own men.

title: National Park Visitors Down Sharply
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 1In Yosemite Valley, the roads are quiet and empty much of the time. In the high country, hikers can sometimes walk for hours without encountering anyone else. And in the camp grounds on most weeknights, newcomers can still find an empty spot to pitch a tent, even at sundown.

title: Missing Boy Found
description: CLINTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) John Burns, a 14yearold Mount Laurel boy who had been missing since last Monday, was found here early today, 70 miles from home, asleep in a vacant lot next to his bicycle, mosquitobitten but otherwise in good spirits.

title: N.F.L.'s Preseason Crowds Are Off By 256,748
description: The National Football League players' strike produced a dramatic drop in attendance figures and millions of dollars in lost revenue during the first full weekend of preseason games.

title: AT INDIAN HARBOR Y. C.
description: GRUNDOON TROPHY

title: PORTUGAL READY TO GRANT GUINEA ITS INDEPENDENCE
description: LISBON, Aug. 4  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations announced today that Portugal was ready to recognize Portuguese Guinea as an independent nation and to support its entry into the United Nations.

title: Laura Jean Smolian Has Bridal
description: Laura Jean Smolian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Smolian of Redding, Conn., and Winhall, Vt., and Georges Christophe Megroz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Megroz of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Bondville, Vt., were married yesterday afternoon in the garden of the Redding home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Irving Silverman of Easton, Conn.

title: COLUMBIA TO PRESS 5YEAR DRUG STUDY
description: Columbia University, has received a $3,156,000 Federal grant for creation of a center that will conduct a fiveyear study of drug use.

title: Ethnic Turk Says Minority Needs Ankara Troops
description: CHATOZ, Cyprus, Aug. 3We could live side by side with the Greeks, but never shoulder to shoulder, said Adnan Djelal, a Turkish Cypriote, who has been a policeman for 33 years.

title: Bomb on Italian Train Leaves 12 Dead
description: ROME, Aug. 4Twelve people were killed and 48 injured when a bomb exploded early this morning in a train packed with holiday travelers heading toward North Italy and Germany.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officials of financially ailing Bloomfield College, in Bloomfield, N.J., are expected to file a petition for bankruptcy proceedings in Federal Court in Newark today, sources at the fouryear unaergraduate institution have disclosed.

title: 6,000, Not 64,000, Paid To See BellStars Game
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP)  An official of the World Football League's Philadelphia Bell has confirmed a report that the team inflated attendance figures by not differentiating between paid and actual attendance.

title: Clear the Burning Deck
