description: CALL Pa?? Cooper on New York Telephone's DialAJoke (212) 9993838. ADVT.

title: '73 PRESSURE ON U.S. BY SAUDIS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) Senate testimony made public today suggests that a Saudi Arabian campaign in May, 1973, for a change in the proIsraeli policies of the United States included pressure against American companies that had interests in Saudi oil.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT ??
description: Chestnut TB Gelding, 6 Yrs.

title: Market Place: Guides Offerd To Utility Values
description: The utility averages, which plunged in the aftermath of the Consolidated Edison dividend omission on April 22, have begun to stabilize.

title: Crabiel Will Take Leave; Tells Byrne He's Innocent
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6Governor Byrne today announced that Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, who was indicted last Wednesday on charges of rigging highway construction bids for several years before he took office, would take a leave of absence without pay beginning Friday.

title: Text of Report on Kissinger's Role in Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Following is the text of the observations and conclusions of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee report on its most recent inquiry into Secretary of State Kissinger's role in the White House wiretap program:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: As calls from his supporters came into his office yesterday, Luis Fuentes, superintendent of District I in New York City, said he would fight any effort by the majority of the Community School Board to renew its efforts to suspend him.

title: Laos Premier Names A Communist to Fill In
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 6 (UPI)  Premier Souvanna Phouma has chosen the top Communist member of his Cabinet to serve as acting Premier while he recuperates for a month in France from a heart attack, sources in the Laotian coalition government said today.

title: ... the Constitutional Way
description: The interim alternative of stepping aside conditionally under the terms of the 25th Amendment would have some practical merit if there were any reason to believe that the rest of the impeachment process, now so far advanced, would be likely to drag on and on.

title: Kalmbach Arrives at Prison
description: LOMPOC, Calif., Aug. 6 (UPI)  Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's former personal lawyer, has arrived at the Federal minimum security camp here to serve the remainder of his 6to18 month prison term for Watergate related matters, it was disclosed today.

title: Increase Fight. Security, Garden Told by Dooley
description: A demonstration by Tans at the Felt Forum on Monday night during which bottles were sent flying and seats ripped up and set on fire, caused Edwin B. Dooley, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, to sound a warning note yesterday.

title: Policeman Freed on Bail
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 6 (UPI)A 43yearold Pennsauken police lieutenant, Dominic Terenzi, has been rleased on $1,000 bail after pleading not guilty to nine charges of perjury, false swearing and misconduct during an investigation into alleged corruption in the Township Police Department.

title: Laborer is Held in Murders Of Two Japanese Women
description: Acting Supreme Court Justice Irving Lang yesterday held a 25aborer without bail on an indictment charging him with the murders of two Japanese women last April in an Upper West Side hotel.

title: Latin Consulate Bombed
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 6 (UPI)  A highpowered bomb exploded yesterday in the entrance to the Venezuelan consulate here, the third bombing of a LatinAmerican consulate in San Juan this year. No one was injured. The police estimated damage to the building, situated at the edge of the city's Condado tourist section, at $40,000. Several small stores and houses beside the consulat were also damaged.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers picketed Western Electric offices in Newark and Kearny yesterday, and company official acknowledged that thousands of employesunion and nonunion stayed home.

title: McGraw's in 11th Allows Pirates to Win, 98
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 From hero to goat to hero to goat, to.... That seems to be the role Tug McGraw is playing this year for the New York Mets. Yesterday he won a game in Montreal with his bat. Tonight he lost a game, 98, to the Pittsburgh Pirates on his fielding. He threw a ball over the third baseman's head in the 11th inning to let the winning run score.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Bridge:
description: The members of the host units for the Summer Nationals here of the American Contract Bridge League, which included Long Island, Westchester County, New Jersey and the Hudson Valley, as well as New York City, went rather further than they intended in the area of hospitality and entertainment. Not only did they ensure that everyone had a good time, but they involuntarily contrived to arrange that all the major titles were won by players from out of town.

title: JURY IS DECIDING IF RINALDI LIED
description: The jury began deliberating late yesterday afternoon in the perjury trial of Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi, who has been charged with lying to a special grand jury that was investigating corruption in the criminaljustice system in Brooklyn last fall.

title: Psychotic Inmates Aided Little By the CelltoHospital Shuttle
description: An acute shortage of beds has created a breakdown in mental treatment for some of the city's most disturbed criminals and condemned them to a revolving door that spins them from jail, cell to hospital bed and back again.

title: ALLIES IN HOUSE SHIFTING ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6One by one, with mixed feelings of sorrow and relief, President Nixon's political friends in the House of Representatives joined today in a march toward impeachment.

title: Farmers Protest to Byrne On the State's Regulations
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6 (AP)Two dozen angry South Jersey farmers told Governor Byrne today that state farm regulations were hurting them and might eventually force them out of business.

title: ShaNaNa Projects WellScrubbed Look At Festival in Park
description: When rock n roll was young, some 20 years ago, mothers warned their daughters about those evil men with greasy hair in black leather jackets. But curiously enough, ShaNaNa, the nineteenfifties revivalist band that played at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park Monday night and returns there tonight, would probably be dear to most mothers' hearts today. It is hard to think of healthier group.

title: FUENTES TO FIGHT OUSTER ATTEMPT
description: As calls of support came into his office, Luis Fuentes, superintendent of District 1, said yesterday that he would fight any renewed effort by the majority of the Community School Board to suspend him.

title: HOUSE BARS FUNDS FOR A NERVE GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The House of Representatives eliminated funds today for the production of a new type of nerve gas and reduced military aid to South Vietnam by $300million, as it approved an $84billion Department of Defense appropriations bill.

title: Dealing With Moscow: EastWest Experts View Value and Risks
description: Last month, following the summit meeting between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, Secretary of State Kissinger said that he expected a national debate on the meaning of security in the nuclear age and on the value and risks of closer ties with the Soviet Union.

title: MOBIL TERMS SET FOR MARCOR STOCK
description: The Mobil, Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Marcor, Inc., to make a cash tender offer for Marcor common stock at $35 a share and Series A preferred stock at $70 a share. Coincident with the payment for the shares tendered, Mobil will purchase directly from Marcor $200million of a new series of voting preferred stock to pro. vide Marcor with additional equity capital.

title: Rumors on Nixon Decision Send Stock Prices Soaring
description: Conjecture that President Nixon might resign sent the stock market soaring yesterday, but gains were cut in half after the White House denied that the President would step down.

title: Turkish Tanks and Troops Take 2 Cyprus Villages
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 6Turkish armored infantry occupied the heavily bombarded villages of Lapithos and Karavas today while negotiations continued between Turkish and Greek military representatives on a ceasefire line.

title: RealEstate Fraud On F.H.A. Insurance Charged to Dealers
description: NEWARK, Aug. 6A group of 10 New Jersey realestate dealers and a major mortgage concern have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of filing fraudulent insurance applications with the Federal Housing Administration guarteeing about $3.5million in loans.

title: Music: A Katims and Mozart Evening
description: It was something of a Milton Katims night. The conductor of the Seattle Symphony not only took charge of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall, but also was one of the soloists in Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante, playing the viola alongside Jaime Laredo's violin.

title: Chris Evert Is 60, 60 Victor on Clay
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. (AP)Chris Evert, in pink and white, shrugged aside her first opponent today in the $130,000 United States claycourt tennis championships.

title: Kuh and Beame Letters On Inquiry on City Audits
description: Dear Mayor Beame: Almost three weeks ago, after my associates here and I had commenced our own investigation into the public suggestions of possible criminality involving $5.4million (the subject of Controller Goldin's comments of July 14, 1974), you requested that I serve with your Investigations Commissioner, the Controller and others on a task force inquiring into the same matter.

title: Business Briefs
description: Bendix and F.T.C. in Accord on Fram

title: Chest Pains Hospitalize Vida Blue
description: DALLAS, Aug. 6 (UPI)The Oakland A's star pitcher, Vida Blue, complaining of chest pains, was hospitalized today and doctors here said they had discovered a heart irregularity.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, P.M. (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.)

title: The Overriding Factor...
description: The issue now bearing upon the nation is how best to remove Richard M. Nixon from the power of the Presidency. Mr. Nixon's admission that he wrongfully withheld from Congress, courts, counsel and country evidence bearing upon the question of his impeachment has removed any serious doubt that the power will be transferred to Vice President Fordperhaps within days, perhaps weeks.

title: Citibank Asks Herstatt Be Declared Bankrupt
description: The First National City Bank said yesterday that it and others have petitioned the United States District Court here to have Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt declared bankrupt under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Dreyfus Censured On False. Reports In '72 Wheat Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) The Agriculture Department announced today a cease and desist order growing out of charges that the Louis Dreyfus Corporation of New York, one of the nation's largest private grain dealers, submitted false reports to the Government while engaged in the big 1972 United StatesSoviet wheat deal.

title: New Jersey Sports Help for Net Duffer
description: PRINCETON, Aug. 6  Bigtime tournament tennis is at its peak now with more topnotch players and prize money than ever before. But who is looking after the interests of the millions of new players appearing or the nontournament scene, those who want to enjoy the game as a recreational pastime?

title: SOVIET AND IRAN OPEN GAS TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6The Soviet Union and Iran opened talks today in Teheran on demands that Moscow pay more for Iranian natural gas.

title: Haydon Plans to Resign Post in American Samoa
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  John M. Haydon Jr. is resigning after five years as Governor of American Samoa, the Interior Department said otday.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN 2 QUEENS RAPES
description: A 22yearold unemployed paint sprayer who was arrested Monday morning while allegedly trying to break into Queens apartment was charged yesterday with the rape of two elderly women and is considered a prime suspect in 10 other rape cases, according to the police.

title: Orioles 41 Victors With the Aid of 3 2Base Miscues
description: Three errors, each the glaring sort that can't be hidden, yielded three runs last night and the inconsistent Yankees dropped a 41 decision to the Baltimore Orioles at Shea Stadium.

title: D. & H. PRESIDENT LEAVES THROTTLE
description: Carl Bruce Sterzing Jr., president of the Delaware & Hudson Railway, handed over controls of the diesel locomotive of Amtrak's new MontrealNew York train, the Adirondack, yesterday after pinchhitting as engineer Monday on the inaugural run.

title: DIAMOND HELD CLUE TO LIFE OF UNIVERSE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5Two Soviet scientists have concluded that terrestrial diamonds may provide valuable new insights into the evolution of the universe, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Dismantled Empire
description: The steps Portugal intends to take in divesting itself of its African empire, as announced in Lisbon by United Nations Secretary General Waldheim, give additional substance to the hopeful policy the Portuguese Government has been developing since the April 25 coup.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 97938
Bomb Explosion Kills 2 at Airport in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES; Aug. 6A bomb exploded this morning near public lockers at Los Angeles International Airport killing two persons. More than 20 persons were injured, five of them critically.

title: H. J. GAISMAN, 104, INVENTOR, IS DEAD
description: Henry J. Gaisman, inventor and philanthropist, died yesterday at St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 104 years old and lived at 150 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: HARRIS, UPHAM & CO. PUNISHED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Securities and Exchange Commission censured today Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., a New York City brokerdealer, and suspended its branch office at 445 Park Avenue from engaging in overthecounter stock activities for 15 days beginning next Monday.

title: 11 in Vigil Held at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The Pentagon police arrested II demonstrators today for impeding an entrance during vigil marking the 29th anniversary of the American atomic I bombing of Hiroshima.

title: Herb May Hide Traces Of Heroin in Urine Test
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 6Health food stores in Southern California are doing a thriving business in goldenseal, a herbal root Indians used for a variety of ailments. Heroin users now say it can conceal their addiction for the most thorough medical screening.

title: Greenwich Files Suit to Quiet Noise From Westchester Airport
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. The Town of Greenwich filed a $20million damage suit in Federal Court in New Haven today, charging that nearby Westchester County Airport subjected residents of its affluent rural back country to intolerable levels of air and noise pollution.

title: TAPES MAY AFFECT NIXON AIDES TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 President Nixon's admissions yesterday seemed certain to affect not just his own likely trial in the Senate but also the criminal trial of the six former White House and campaign committee aides indicted in the Watergate conspiracy.

title: RAYMOND E. HOLMES
description: Raymond E. Holmes, vice presidentemploye relations for R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., parent company of the departmentstore chain, died Sunday evening in Greenwich, Conn., where he lived. He was 50 years old.

title: Crabiel Tells Byrne He Will Take Leave
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6Governor Byrne today announced that Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, who was indicted last Wednesday on charges of rigging highway construction bids for several years before he took office, would take a leave of absence without pay beginning Friday.

title: Angola Threatens to Use Force in Capital Curfew
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  The military junta has warned that it may use force to disperse demonstrators who defy a curfew here in the capital of Angola.

title: TOP AIDES RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Despite a massive loss of support within his own Republican party in Congress, President Nixon told his Cabinet today that he would not resign but would remain in office while the constitutional process of impeachment ran its course.

title: ALLIES IN HOUSE SHIFTING ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6One by one, with mixed feelings of sorrow and relief, President Nixon's political friends in the House of Representatives joined today in a march toward impeachment.

title: New Rule Limits Rise In Propane Gas Price
description: The Federal Energy Administration said yesterday it had adopted a new regulation that would limit future price increases for propane at the refinery level.

title: Garrison Tries for Comeback in Louisiana Supreme Court Race
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6Jim Garrison, the former New Orleans District Attorney who was defeated last year, is attempting a comeback in a race, for the State Supreme Court.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: F. Lee Bailey and S. Edward Orenstein, lawyers who defended Police Officer William R. Phillips in his first murder trial in the death of a pimp and a prostitute, have told Justice Harold Birns of State Supreme Court that they do not want to defend Mr. Phillips in his second trial, which is about to start. The first trial ended in a hung jury, with the jurors reported to be 102 in Mr. Phillips's favor.

title: YORKERS MAYOR, ASKS DIRECT AID
description: The Mayor of Yonkers sought yesterday to have the State Office for the Aging award Yonkers its share of Federal funds directly instead of through Westchester County.The Mayor, Angels R. Martinelli, said at a hearing here that direct financing was the only way that his city could be assured of getting the $105,000, which he believes Yonkers deserves out of the $362,550 in Federal funds made available to the county for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Consumer Bill Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Backers of legislation to crelate a consumer protection agency postponed a showdown Senate vote today on the bill until Aug. 20.

title: World Freebie League? Sun and Stars Appalled
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 6Using such words as shocking, atrocious and bush, officials of the New York Stars and the Southern California Sun agreed today the free ticket disclosures in Philadelphia and Jacksonvjlle have damaged the credibility of the World Football League.

title: FULBRIGHT PANEL CLEARS KISSINGER  ON WIRETAP ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to clear Secretary of State Kissinger of allegations that he had misled the committee about his role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: IngersollRand Expanding
description: PAINTED POST, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP)IngersollRand Company has announced plans to con struct a $10million casting plant in Waverly, N.Y., about 25 miles from its headquarters here. The plant is designed to prduce and supply metal castings for foundries here and in Phillisburg, N.J., and Athens, Pa.

title: Polaroid Deal Shifted
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 6 (Reuters)  The Polaroid Corporation said today that the Bell & Howell Company had withdrawn from an agreement to make equipment associated with an instant motion picture system which Polaroid has had under development. Polaroid said the instant motion picture system was not intended for 1974 introduction and that accordingly Bell & Howell's action would have no effect on Polaroid's 1974 product line.

title: Bomb Explosion Kills 2 at Airport in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 A bomb exploded this morning pear public lockers at Los Angeles International Airport, killing two persons. More than 20 persons were injured, five of them critically.

title: Kuh Leaves Inquiry Into City Audits to Nadjari
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan announced yesterday that he was suspending his inquiry into charges by Controller Harrison J. Goldin that Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta had told a civil servant to make entries after the fact in the Controller's ledgers.

title: Meany Foresees Disaster for G.O.P. If Nixon Stays On
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6  George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, today predicted an election disaster for Republicans this fall if President Nixon remained in office.

title: Dow Climbs 13.38 On News on Nixon
description: Stock prices scored spectacular gains in early trading yesterday, but many of the advances were trimmed later in the session in heavy trading as speculation that President Nixon may soon resign dissipated.

title: Alleged Pimp Sentenced For IncomeTax Evasion
description: Nathaniel Stephens, listed by the Internal Revenue Service as a major New York pimp, was sentenced to three years is prison yesterday for incometax evasion.

title: Jurisdictional Conflict Clouding Future of PayTV
description: Even before it has gotten started, paytelevision by means of overtheair broadcast is caught between conflicting regulations of the Federal Communications Commission and the city's Bureau of Franchises, a complication that could impede the development of the new medium here.

title: Live TV for Debate Voted by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Without a trace of opposition, the House Rules Committee approved by voice vote today a resolution permitting live television and radio coverage of the House floor debate on the impeachment of President Nixon, which is scheduled to start Aug. 19.

title: Reagan Urges Nixon to See Congress
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that President Nixon should not resign and that the constitutional process should go forward toward further disclosures, including an appearance by the President before Congress where members would question him and total truth be sought.

title: TOP AIDES RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Despite a massive loss of support within his own Republican party in Congress, President Nixon told his Cabinet today that he would not resign but would remain in office while the constitutional process of impeachment ran its course.

title: NEWS INDEX
Surgery for Horton
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6 (UPI)Doctors decided today to perform an operation on the right knee of Willie Horton that will put the Detroit Tiger left fielder out of action the rest of the season.

title: MAYORS URGE SPEED ON IMPEACHMENT
description: The top officers of the United States Conference of Mayors urged Congress yesterday to settle the impeachment of President Nixon quickly so that the critical needs of cities can be met.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: 7 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: WEATHERFORD, Okla., Aug. 6 (UPI)A Greyhound bus ran off a rainslick Interstate 40 bypass here last night and overturned, injuring seven passengers. None of the injured were in serious condition today.

title: A Study of Basic Concepts of Chiropractic Planned by Institutes of Health
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The National Institutes of Health, one of the world's foremost medical and biological research organizations, is planning a study of the fundamental concepts of chiropractic, a form of health care that many physicians dismiss as a cult.

title: Advisory Board Proposes Full Renovation of Tombs
description: The City Board: of Correction an advisory body, yesterday recommended that the Manhat tan House of Detention for Mer be redesigned and renovated to meet all constitutional require ments.

title: Going Out Guide
description: TROUPE TROOPERS The Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, a highly acclaimed group of professionals that presents plays of vital social concerns, opens its series of free summer productions tonight at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Since its founding in 1967, the group has gained stature each year with its attention to drama of real substance and emotion.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
$50,000 in Jewelry Stolen In a Murray Hill Burglary
description: A Manhattan couple reported to the police yesterday that $50,000 in assorted jewelry was missing from their 17thfloor apartment at 201 East 36th Street in the Murray Hill section.

title: When Taste in Art Has Real Meaning
description: When Vicki Cobb tells someone that their art work looks good enough to eat, she means it.

title: SILVER FUTURES CLIMB IN PRICE
description: The silver futures market. told the story yesterday of uncertainties in many traders' minds about the political situation in the United States.

title: People in Sports
description: A new tune is being crooned by Bing Crosby that should make supporters of women's liberation happy. He has asked the Professional Golfers' Association for permission to invite women to take part in the 1975 Bing Crosby National proamateur tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif. Larry Crosby, brother of the famed singer, who directs the rich golf competition, disclosed yesterday that Bing wrote to the P.G.A. to see if it would be possible to have a couple of gals play.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time
description: Tomorrow, Aug. 8

title: Increase Fight Security, Garden Told by Dooley
description: A demonstration by Tans at the Felt Forum on Mondaynight during which bottles were sent flying and seats ripped up and set on fire, caused Edwin B. Dooley, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, to sound a warning note yesterday.

title: MOSCOW TV GIVES REPORT ON NIXON
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6  Soviet television viewers learned tonight, nearly a day after the fact that President Nixon had admitted to making mistakes and that he had referred to a possibility of his being removed from office.

title: Idaho Allows Knievel Stunt
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 6 (AP)This state granted Evel Knievel, a motorcycle stunt rider, a permit today for a jump over the Snake River Canyon on Sept. 8. He plans to use a rocketpowered motorcycle to jump the canyon, which is about a quartermile wide and about 500 feet deep. The motorcycle stuntman says he expects to sell up to 50,000 tickets at $25 each.

title: A Cloud Over Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The possibility of President Nixon's resignation hung like an uncertain rain cloud over Washington todaya cloud that could burst at any moment but very well might not.

title: Laver Gains, Will Bypass U.S. Open
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 6  Rod Laver, the from a 12week hiatus today to smash his way to an earlyround victory in the Volvo International tennis championship, then said he would take the rest of the year off, thus missing the United States Open.

title: Jurisdictional Conflict Elouding Future of PayTV
description: Even before it has gotten started, paytelevision by means of overtheair broadcast is caught between conflicting regulations of the Federal Communications Commission and the city's Bureau of Franchises, a complication that could impede the development of the new medium here.

title: Red Smith
description: While the parties to the dispute are making speeches about freedom and the future of the game, it is the fans who are bearing and will continue to bear the brunt this foolishness.

title: investors Queue Up To Buy U.S. Notes With Peak 9% Rate
description: Thousands of investors, most of them disgruntled with interest rates on their savings accounts and not interested in the stock market, flocked yesterday to buy the Federal Government's new 9 per cent notes the highest rate ever put on a Treasury issue maturing in more than a year.

title: Closing of 25 Bond Stores Is Approved by Directors
description: The directors of Bond IndusAries, Inc., which operates the Bond apparel stores, approved yesterday the closing of about 25 unprofitable Bond stores over the next 18 months to two years.

title: Detente: Value, Risk
description: Four public figures with interests in EastWest relations, in a panel discussion arranged by The New York Times, consider the meaning of security in the nuclear age and the value and risks of dtente. Page 33.

title: Israelis Report Readiness For Jordan Compromise
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 6Israel is prepared to negotiate a compromise agreement with Jordan involving some degree of military withdrawal from the Jordan River and a limited return of Jordanian civilian administration to the Israelioccupied West Bank, according to senior Government officials here.

title: A Sense of Gloom and Shock Pervades the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Gerald L. Warren, the deputy Presidential press secretary, seemed to be trying his best to pull a cloak of blandness over the whole thing.

title: Advertising: An Egg Campaign
description: The American Egg Board, promotional arm of the industry and funded by egg producers and allied businesses, is about to hatch its first bigcity advertising campaign. Its theme is The Incredible Edible Egg.

title: 65 Favorite Runs Last In Feature at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6To the chalk players in the crowd of 16,763 today, the feature race had an aptly named favorite, Splitting Headache.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP)California Angel hopes of trading Frank Robinson were blocked today when more than one team claimed the 38yearold slugger after he was put on waivers. Robinson reportedly was headed for the Boston Red Sox if he had made it through waivers, which are necessary because the trading deadline ended June 15. But New York, Baltimore and Cleveland also claimed him.

title: Retired SemiInvalid Found Dead in Brooklyn Apartment
description: A 62yearold retired switchboard operator, a semiinvalid for many years with a heart condition, was found dead yesterday afternoon in his ransacked basement apartment in Brooklyn's East New York section.

title: Kendall Captures U.S. Rifle Crown
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 6 (AP)Maj. Presley Kendall of Carlisle, Ky., won the national smallbore prone rifle championship with a 6,390 of a possible 6,400 in the fourday event that finished today.

title: Burns Asks Job Program If Unemployment Tops 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, proposed today a $4billion program of public service employment to create some 800,000 jobs in state and local government if the nation's unemployment rate should rise above 6 per cent of the labor force.

title: FULBRIGHT PANEL CLEARS KISSINGER ON WIRETAP ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to clear Secretary of State Kissinger of allegations that he had misled the committee about his role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: An Alleged Slayer Accuses a Witness
description: A man on trial in the murder of a Columbia University professor testified yesterday that minutes after the stabbing his brother and another youth clawed at the dying man.

title: ALMIRA SESSIONS, 85; 65 YEARS AN ACTRESS
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP)  Almira Sessions, a stage, film and television character actress, died at a convalescent home Saturday. She was 85 years old.

title: S.I. HOUSING PLAN TO GET U.S. HELP
description: The State's Division of Housing and Community Renewal has allowed the use of Federal housing subsidies to spur a lagging rental program in 453unit MitchellLama housing development in St. George, S.I.

title: DECLINE IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6President Nixon's support in the Senate crumbled today and with it, apparently, his chances of surviving for long in the Presidency.

title: Rangers' Jenkins Halts A's on 2Hitter
description: The senior citizens among the pitchers in major league baseball are proving that there is no substitute for experience.

title: FlagWearing Curb Vetoed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent pocketvetoed a bill today that would have made it illegal for people to wear the American flag on the seat of their pants or anywhere else on the lower half of the body. Sargent said that any attempt to legislate respect for the flag is doomed to failure.

title: Burns Asks Job Program If Unemployment Tops 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the F6deral Reserve Board, proposed today a $4billion program of publid service employment to create some 800,000 jobs in state and local government if the nation's unemployment rate should rise above 6 per cent of the labor force.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New York (at Felt Forum)Dominico Monaco, 131 pounds, Brooklyn, and Eduardo Santiago, 131, Puerto Rico, drew, 10 rounds.

title: Defender of Dog Is Slain
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6 (UPI)An elderly man was stabbed to death last night because he tried to save a dog's life. The police said Joseph Peoples, 64 year old, had tried to stop an unidentified man from slashing a dog's throat. The man killed the dog, according to witnesses, and said, shut up, old man, or I'll kill you, too. The assailant left, but returned later with four friends and repeatedly stabbed, Mr. Peoples in the chest. One of the assailants began shooting at random, wounding three persons.

title: Puerto Rico Doing Its Own Thing to Bolster Economy
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto RicoA mood of economic selfreliance appears to have overtaken Puerto Rico, as changing local conditions and increasing competition from Caribbean neighbors make inroads on the island's traditional ways.

title: Israel Reports Bombing Lebanese Area
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Aug. 7Israel reported today that her planes had attacked southeast Lebanon after infiltrators from the area abducted four Syrian Druse workers erecting an Israeli security fence on the frontier.

title: PrizeWinning Violinist Fills City Hall With Strains From a Guarnerius
description: City Hall, often enveloped in sounds ranging from chanting pickets to unctuous political palaver, was enraptured yesterday by the tone of a 1736 Guarnerius in the hands of Eugene Fodor, the 24yearold violinist who shared the top prize awarded at Lie recent Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow.

title: S.E.C. to Study InstitutionBroker Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Securities and Exchange Commission mission moved today toward a direct challenge of the position of managers of large institutional investors that they have a fiduciary responsibility to obtain the lowest commission rate available from brokers on their stock transactions.

title: Big Stores Here Show a Lag In Consumer Buying for July
description: Consumer buying in New York's big stores, which had reached its strongest tempo in the spring and early summer; in over a year, skipped a beat in July, but remained at or slightly above the inflation level.

title: That Bargain of the East the Hong Kong SuitIs the Victim of Inflation
description: HONG KONG  The Hong Kong suit, long considered one of the world's great bargains, has gone the way of inflation.

title: Problems of Transition
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The mood of Washington has been transformed by President Nixon's confession of guilt in the Watergate coverup. On both sides of the aisle in Congress, members are shocked but relieved by the evidence. The main question here is no longer whether the President will go, but how and when. He is not yet through, but he's finished.

title: Investors Queue Up To Buy U. S. Notes With Peak 9% Rate
description: Thousands of investors, most of them disgruntled with interest rates on their savings accounts and not interested in the stock market, flocked yesterday to buy the Federal Government's new 9 per cent notes the highest rate ever put on a Treasury issue maturing in more than a year.

title: Shell Concern Asks Hearing On a Ban on Two Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The Shell Chemical Company requested today an immediate hearing on the Environmental Protection Agency's ban on further production of the pesticides aldrin and dieldrin, the company announced.

title: Louisiana Land Net Up; Others Report
White House Says NixonColson Phone Call on June 20, 1972, Was Not Recorded
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The White House said today that a telephone conversation between President Nixon and Charles W. Colson three days after the Watergate break  in was never recorded.

title: GUNS ARE FOCUS IN TEXAS INQUIRY
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 6Investigators were checking today a possibility that the guns and ammunition used by three state prison inmates last Saturday night in a deadly escape attempt may have been mailed Into the institution or may have been delivered under the guise of library supplies.

title: World Bank Extends Loan
description: CAIRO, Aug. 6 (UPI)The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has approved the extension of a $200million loan to Egypt to finance an integrated program of schemes, Cairo newspapers said today. Al Ahram and Al Gomhouria newspapers said $165million of the loan would be repaid over 40 years at threequarters of 1 per cent interest and the remaining $35million over a longer period at 7.2 per cent interest.

title: Loss of an Island to Development Deplored in Carolina
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.This coastal barrier island, 22 miles south of Charleston, across the applegreen salt marshes is often called a semitropical paradise.

title: Lockheed Is Awaiting Audit Before Giving Data on Half
description: BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 6 (Reuters)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today it would not release its financial figures for the first half of 1974 until a general audit instituted in connection with a proposed refinancing by the Textron Corporation had been completed. Lockheed said it expected final figures from the general audit to be available late this month or in early September.

title: LAWYER WILL HEAD CONNECTICUT G.O.P.
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 6  Vincent Laudone of Norwich, a lawyer, was elected today as the new chairman of the Republican State Central Committee. He will succeed J. Brian Gaffney of New Britain, party chairman for three and a half years.

title: SUCREST UNIT LIFTS PRICES FOR SUGARS
description: The Sucrest Corporation said yesterday its Sucrest Sweetener division would increase prices on industrial sugars by $1.50 per hundredweight, effective Aug. 9, in the New England, New YorkPhiladelphia, BaltimoreWashington and MidCentral territories.

title: JOHN J. CARR
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP)  John J. Carr, a veteran motionpicture animator, died on Saturday. He was 73 years old.

title: City's Birth Rate Slips To a Low in 6 Months
description: Extensive familyplanning services and the liberalized abortion program were credited yesterday with giving New York City its lowest birth rate in 75 years of recordkeeping.

title: State Court Applies Judicial Surgery To Revive Outlawed '71 Obscenity Law
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6The State Supreme Court ruled today that a 1971 New Jersey antiobscenity law previously declared unconstitutional could be revived if it incorporated the standards of obscenity set out in the United States Supreme Court's opinion on the subject last year.

title: Thompson, Athas and Gogolak Check In at Fairfield
description: While 21 Jets and Giants expressed solidarity in support of the National Football League Players' Association strike at a news conference yesterday, three more Giant veterans broke ranks.

title: 2 REPORTED KILLED IN TANK CAR BLAST
description: WNATCHEE, Wash., Aug. 6 (AP)Two persons were killed and more than 60 injured today when a tank car, apparently filled with a volatile chemical, exploded in a railroad yard near here, officials said.

title: Greek Education ShakeUp
description: ATHENS, Aug. 6 (AP)The Government has announced the dismissal of university lecturers and professors appointed under the fallen militarybacked regime and the reinstatement of those ousted by the regime.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: TV Review
description: Musically, the television summer is already brighter, with Your Hit Parade continuing four more weeks over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Another incoming treat is The Boarding House, a sixweek series of taped halfhour concerts at the San Francisco night spot and music mecca of the same name. The series, produced by Station KQED in San Francisco and transmitted nationally by the Public Broadcasting Service, begins tonight at 9:30 o'clock (repeated Saturday at 8 o'clock) over WNET/Channel 13. Judging by the first two segments, this is relaxing listening and colorful viewing.

title: SEOUL PUTS ASIDE PROTESTANT PLEA
description: SEOUL, South Korea; Aug. 6 Premier Kim Jong Pil has reportedly rejected demands by senior Korean Protestant leaders that the Government withdraw its sweeping emergency ,decrees banning political dissent and release prisoners arrested under them.

title: New XRay Machine Foils BladeSmuggling at Jail
description: A recently installed Xray machine detected spots in the heels of a pair of men's shoes and as a result a 26yearold woman was arrested Monday for allegedly trying to smuggle hacksaw blades into the Brooklyn House of Detention, authorities said yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that the Japanese Government had approved the purchase of six longrange DC10 Series 40 aircraft for Japan Air Lines. The first delivery of the planes, costing more than $150million, is set for December, 1975, and follow on deliveries in 1976. Japan Air Lines holds options to buy an additional six planes.

title: Bush Is Confident Nixon Will Do What Is Right
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) George Bush, the Republican national chairman, said today that he was confident President Nixon would do what is best for the country in deciding whether to resign or face impeachment.

title: HELEN KAYES
description: Helen Kayes, formerly a field director of the New York Girl Scout Council, died Monday of congestive heart failure at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 58 and lived at 176 East 77th Street.

title: Israelis Report Readiness For Jordan Compromise
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 6Israel Is prepared to negotiate a compromise agreement with Jordan involving some degree of military withdrawal from the Jordan River and a limited return of Jordanian civilian administration to the Israelioccupied West Bank, according to senior Government officials here.

title: Beirut Reports Border Clash
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Aug. 6 (AP)Lebanese and Israelis exchanged artillery fire for 45 minutes today, the Defense Ministty announced. The communiqu said the clash began after four, Israeli halftracks had crossed the border. The Israelis apparently were searching for Palestinian guerrillas.

title: 670th Cosmos Launched
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has launched the 670th in its series of Cosmos satellites into an orbit very close to that of the currently unmanned Salyut 3 space station, the Tass press agency reported today.

title: STANDARDS RELAXED ON 7% MORTGAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Housing Secretary James T. Lynn eased today the standards for Federally guaranteed mortgages on which the home buyer pays 7 per cent interest. He took the action after a meeting with executives of the National Association of Home Builders.

title: Simon & Schuster to Become Subsidiary of Harcourt Brace
description: Two major publishers, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., and Simon & Schuster, Inc., have announced an agreement in principle to merge.

title: Lloyd of Marlborough Testifies On Rothko Works Sent to Europe
description: Frank Lloyd, head of the international concern of Marlborough art galleries and companies, testified yesterday that he did not learn of a court injunction forbidding sale or shipment of paintings by Mark Rothko until his arrival in New York a day or two after the injunction was issued.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ITALY PLANS STEPS TO CUT TERRORISM
description: ROME, Aug. 6The Government of Premier Mariano Rumor met today to discuss measures aimed at stemming the rising wave of terrorism in Italy, the latest episode of which was the bomb explosion Sunday on the RomeMunich express train that killed 12 persons and injured 48.

title: U.S. Seeks Ways to Ground New Airline's Plan for CutRate Flights Between Tijuana and Europe
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  Air Europe International, a new airline based here, isn't yet off the ground, but it already has a nickname: The Frijole Flyer.

title: CRISIS IS DENIED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: Denying reports that the Urban League of Greater New York is in grave financial trouble, Livingston L. Wingate, the executive director, said the organization's fiscal condition was better than it has been in six or seven Kars.

title: RATE RISE DROPPED BY MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., announced yesterday that it had rolled back a recent 5 per cent commission increase on institutional transactions. The increase still applies to accounts held by individuals, however.

title: Quake Felt in Anchorage
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 6 (UPI) A moderate earthquake registering 5.3 on the Richter scale shook the Alaska peninsula in the Iliamna volcano area yesterday, the Palmer Observatory reported. An observatory spokesman said that the quake has, been felt strongly in the Anchorage area 150 miles northeast of its center. However, no damage was reported.

title: Rumors on Nixon Decision Send Stock Prices Soaring
description: Conjecture that President Nixon might resign sent the stock market soaring yesterday, but gains were cut in half after the White House denied that the President would step down.

title: Dollar Shows Dip In Trading Abroad; Gold Price Rises
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 6 (UN) The dollar declined on several internatonal money markets today. The price of gold rose.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP)California Angel hopes of trading Frank Robinson were blocked today when more than one team claimed the 38yearold slugger after he was put on waivers. Robinson reportedly was headed for the Boston Red Sox if he had made it through waivers which are necessary because the trading deadline ended June 15. But New York, Baltimore and Cleveland also claimed him.

title: Sandman's Backers Hail His 2 Positions on Nixon
description: CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 6 Representative Charles W. Sandman's supporters in his Congressional district here appeared today to agree with the New Jersey Republican in his 180degree shift in favor of impeachment of President Nixon.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Philadelphia Balloonist Is Killed in a Crash Off Jersey
description: A Philadelphia man who, by his own account had never flown in a balloon before, was killed yesterday while apparently attempting to cross the Atlantic Ocean when his 12story, helium balloon crashed an hour after takeoff from Lakehurst Naval Air Station. The balloonist, Robert C.

title: State Department Affirms Confidence In Envoy to Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The State Department reaffirmed its confidence today in the reporting of Ambassador Graham A. Martin and his embassy in South Vietnam to. Washington.

title: Ambulance Attendant Held In Rape of Bronx Woman, 18
description: An 18yearold woman was raped in the Bronx last night by an ambulance attendant after she has accepted a ride in a Morrisania Hospital ambulance, the police reported.

title: Water the Fragile Plant
description: ATHENS  Democracy is still a fragile plant in postjunta Greece but every day that passes helps strengthen its shaky stalk. The strongman Premier, Constantine Caramanlis, has found himself enormously popular on returning from eleven years of voluntary exile in France. Moreover, there is some evidence that the customarily volatile Greeks have been matured politically by their sad experience of the last decadefirst a rabblerousing, selfparalyzed parliamentary regime; then stultifying, leaden dictatorship.

title: Miller Band Given A Broader Scope By Peanuts Hucko
description: Since Peanuts Hucko, the clarinetist, took over the leadership of the Glenn Miller Orchestra in January, the band has grown in two important, respects. At the Roof of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel, where it has just opened a threeweek engagement, its crisp, clean projection of the traditional Miller sound possesses a vitality reminiscent of the results that the demanding Mr. Miller got when he was leading the original band more than 30 years ago. At the same time, the hand is less dependent on the Miller sound than it has been in the past.

title: Licensing Rules Issued For Abortion Facilities
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The State Department of Health issued emergency interim regulations today for abortion facilities receiving temporary state licenses.

title: Representative Roy Wins In Bid to Run Against Dole
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 6Representative William. R. Roy was the winner today in the Democratic primary in an attempt to unseat Senator Robert Dole, the former Republican national chairman.

title: BRAZIL REPORTS MENINGITIS RISE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 6Official sources said today that a meningitis epidemic that had caused at least 360 deaths in the So Paulo area since July 1 was spreading.

title: Dolphins, Rams Favored
description: STATELINE, Nev., Aug. (UPI)  The Miami Dophins and the Los Angeles Rams have been installed as favorites by a Nevada bookmaker to meet in the Super Bowl next year. Harrah's Tahoe Race and Sports Book listed its opening line today with Miami a 21 favorite to win in the American Football Conference and Los Angeles a 52 choice to capture the National Football Conference title.

title: People and Business
description: John F. Nash, chief operating officer of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer, effective Aug. 12. Effective the same date he will resign as a cotrustee of the railroad, leaving behind him an unresolved salary dispute with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Tapes' Insight on Nixon
description: There's something for everybody in the newly released Presidential tapesfor politicians, political scientists, sports writers, the F.B.I., the C.I.A., H. R. Haldeman, John Mitchell, public relations experts, devotees and critics of the arts, Middle Americans and even economists. Never before have the mysteries of White House economic thinking and policy making been so marvelously disclosed.

title: Tristate G.O.P. Officials Fear Losses in Election
description: Republican party leaders and public officials in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey reacted with dismay yesterday to President Nixon's admission of his role in the Watergate coverup and expressed fear that Republican candidates would suffer if Mr. Nixon was still in November.

title: Miss Balukas Advances
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (UPI)Jean Balukas, the defending champion, and Mieko Harada, the Japanese champion, won firstround matches today in the United States open pocket billiards championship. Miss Balukas, 15, years old, defeated Sandy Patarino, 26, in 19 innings, 7515, and Mrs. Harada, 39, defeated Gloria Walker, 19, in 25 innings, 7544.

title: Ford Shuttles Between the Capitol and White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Vice President Ford appeared unnaturally solemn today as he moved rapidly through a schedule that took him from the Capitol to the White House and back again to the Capitol.

title: Amex Stocks Show Advances On Speculation Over Nixon
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished higher yesterday in steppedupped trading.

title: Two Horses for the Price of One
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6Something new in horse racingcontests in which only twohorse entries will competeis being introduced to Sportsman's, Park at a harness meeting. The idea is to enable fans to back two horses for the price of one at the mutuel windows. The two horses will have to be from the same stable. One 16horse race and pair of 18horse events have been Included on Thursday and Friday night's programs. The contests, to be staged over 1 38mile courses will be for $7,000 claimers.

title: People in Sports
description: A new tune is being crooned by Bing Crosby that should make supporters of women's liberation happy. He has asked the Professional Golfers' Association for permission to invite women to take part in the 1975 Bing Crosby National proamateur tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif. Larry Crosby, brother of the famed singer, who directs the rich golf competition, disclosed yesterday that Bing wrote to the P.G.A. to see if it would be possible to have a couple of gals play.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALL SAID AND DONE. By Simone de Beauvoir. 463 pages. Putnam. $10.

title: Justice Outlaws Sex Bias At Harvard Business Club
description: State Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Chimera ruled in Manhattan yesterday that the Harvard Business School Club of New York had discriminated illegally against women by denying an alumna of the oneyear HarvardRadcliffe Program job counseling.

title: Market Averages
description: Tuesday, August 6, 1974

title: Kuh Leaves Inquiry Of Audit to Nadjari
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan announced yesterday that he was suspending his inquiry into charges by Controller Harrison J. Goldin that Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta had told a civil servant to make entries after the fact in the Controller's ledgers.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: CALL Pat Cooper on New York Telephone's DialAJoke (212) 9993838, ADVT.

title: California Split' Deals Winning Hand
description: Robert Altman's "California Split," which opened yesterday at the Cinema I, is a fascinating, vivid movie, not quite comparable to any other movie that I can immediately think of. Nor is it easily categorized.It's the story of several weeks in the lives of two compulsive gamblers who meet in a Los Angeles poker parlor and become fast friends, more or less as a result of being jointly mugged in a parking lot.Charlie Waters (Elliott Gould) is your classic little league bettor, debonaire and incurably sloppy, existing happily on the brink of small-scale financial disaster. More to have company than because of emotional involvement, he sleeps in the apartment of two sweet, pretty Los Angeles girls who probably would be serious hookers if they had any ambition.Bill Denny (George Segal) is another kind of gambler. He's an upper middle-class fellow (a magazine editor) whose compulsion appears to be well on the way to wrecking his life. He's separated from his wife, in debt to his bookie and, in the course of the film, ready to sell everything he hascamera, tape-recorder, car and real estatein order to get the stake he needs to play poker with the big boys at the casino in Reno.Like Charlie Waters and Bill Denny, "California Split" spends a great deal of its time in poker parlors, at race tracks, in casinos and barrooms, mostly seedy places, smoky, overcrowded, either much too bright or dark as tombs. The sounds of these places  the voices of the croupiers, gamblers and hangers-on, and the songs of Phyllis Shotwell who belts out boozy ballads at a piano barare never long from the soundtrack. Even when Charlie and Bill go into the straight world, these sounds follow them.Mr. Altman has been quoted as saying that "California Split" is "a celebration of gambling," which is, I think, to underrate it, at least so it seems to someone who is not a gambling nut. The director, his screenwriter Joseph Walsh and the actors have created a movie of so many associations that it's impossible not to see "California Split" as something much more complex and disturbing.Most of the gambling here doesn't really look like much fun. It's as desperate as the woman at the track who furiously throws her pocketbook and several oranges at Elliott Gould because he's touted her off a winner."California Split" is sometimes very funny, but the world it depicts is as bleak as a landscape composed entirely of used-car lots. The present tense for everyone in the film is grim. The clocks are out of sync. A character has Fruit Loops and beer for breakfast. Someone says of a poker game: "It just got started yesterday."All hopes are pinned on tomorrow. Even those of the two would-be hookers (marvelously well played by Ann Prentiss and Gwen Welles), who have been promised a trip to Hawaii by a couple of otherwise unpromising johns. For the two gamblers, tomorrow is another visit to the track, another game. In the meantime one bets the other that he can't name all seven dwarfs.Like all Altman films, "California Split" is dense with fine, idiosyncratic detail, a lot of which is supplied by Mr. Gould and Mr. Segal as well as by members of the excellent supporting cast. Bert Remsen, who was the aging bank robber in "Thieves Like Us," apears briefly and hilariously as a fearful old transvestite much like Scobie, the ex-seaman who became a Muslim saint in Lawrence Durrell's "Justine" novels.Up to a certain point, "California Split" is, I suppose, a celebration of gambling. It's a movie that avoids as much as possible any simplified Freudian explanations. I say up to a point, because the ending has the effect of making us think back over everything we've seen earlier. To win at poker or anything else can sometimes be as devastating as losing.The compulsive gambler will put up with any loss or indignity in the hope of recouping later, thus placing a terrible burden on the future. For once he does win, everything is over.

title: Books of The Times
description: MR. NICHOLAS. By David Ely. 247 pages. G. P. Putnam's. $6.95.

title: The President's Power to Pardon Is Debated
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Speculation that President Nixon might soon resign from office has fostered a debate over the ways he might be protected, before leaving the White House, from criminal prosecution once he becomes an ordinary citizen.

title: Coal Miners End Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Officials of the United Mine Workers and the North American Coal Company reached an agreement today on steps to end a wildcat strike that has idled 4,600 millers at 18 coal mines in southeastern Ohio. The union said the company agreed to reinstate all miners suspended as a result of recent work stoppages without loss of pay or work.

title: City Seeks to Save Vistas at Parks and Promenades
description: The City Planning Commission announced yesterday an innovative program to preserve spectacular vistas seen from public parks and promeiades, such as the view of lower Manhattan and the Upper Bay from the Esplanade in Brooklyn Heights.

title: COURT FAILS TO GET TAPES OP 9 TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7President Nixon's attorney informed the United States District Court today that tape recordings of nine more of the 64 White House conversations covered by the special Watergate prosecution's subpoena were unavailable.

title: How Much Is Enough.
description: The President has concluded he would lose a trial in the Senate as a result of the latest firestorm. Since he has already admitted guilt, the question goes, why doesn't he quit?

title: WILLIAM SYWAK
description: William W. Sywak, general attorney and secretary of United States Steel International (New York), Inc., died Tuesday at Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, N. J. He was 61 years old.

title: Police Get 2 False Alarms Just Before Bank Robbery
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 7 (Al) Moments before a bank robbery in which two welldressed men wearing surgical masks got away with $12,426 yesterday, the police received two calls about emergencies that turned out to be false alarms.

title: Migrant Worker Charges Use of Force and Threats
description: BRIDGETON, Aug. 7  A young Puerto Rican field worker on the Rosario Sorbello & Sons farm near Swedesboro has accused the overseer of the farm's migrant  labor labor crew of using force and threats of violence to drive his men to work harder.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tour Cools Caso to L. I. Oil Drilling

title: FRED ALLISON, 92, PHYSICIST, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Fred Allison, a physicist and mathematician who stirred controversy in the nineteenthirties over the discovery of new elements, died on Friday at his home in Auburn, Ala. He was 92 years old.

title: PRICES ON AMEX ADVANCE BROADLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market made a broad advance yesterday fueled by reports that President Nixon would resign shortly.

title: Syria Restores Bonn Ties
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 7 (Reuters)Syria announced today resumption of diplomatic relations with West Germany, severed in 1965 when the West German Government decided to exchange Ambassadors with Israel.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: SUSSEX COUNTY SHOW

title: City Sells $151Million in Notes For Housing at Highest Interest
description: A total of $151.3million in shortterm notes were sold by the city yesterday at the highest interest rates it has had to pay to borrow for subsidized housing.

title: A DISTRICT CAPITAL IS LOST BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7  Communist troops overran a Government district capital in the hills southwest of Da Nang this morning, the Saigon military command announced.

title: Turnout in Kansas Disappoints G.O.P.
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 7 Watergate and impeachment scandals were blamed for the exceptionally low Republican turnout in yesterday's primary, elections in Kansas.

title: 2 Seized for Purchase of Guns Used in Prison Escape Attempt
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 7 (UPI)The San Antonio police said today that four south Texas men had purchased the three pistols used by Fred Gomez Carrasco and two other convicts in a desperate attempt to escape from the Texas State Prison in Huntsville.

title: Robert Rounesville, 60, Singer Of Opera and the Stage, Is Dead
description: Robert Rounseville, singer and actor, died here Tuesday of a heart attack in his Carnegie Hall Studio. He was 60 years old and lived at Garlen Road in Katonah, N.Y.

title: CAB LABOR OFFER BY OWNERS URGED
description: In an effort to avert a taxi strike tomorrow, Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board suggested yesterday that fleet owners consider making a proposal to the drivers contingent on a subquent fare increease.

title: EXCESSIVE OIL PRICES LAID TO 2 CONCERNS
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 7 (AP)The Nova Scotia Board of Commissioners of Public Utilities ruled today that Gulf Oil Canada, Ltd., and Irving Oil, Ltd., charged excessive prices for heavy fuel oil from early February until last week. The board ordered price reductions and reimbursements to customers of the two companies.

title: A BOSTON ENSEMBLE IN MOZART FESTIVAL
description: The most interesting piece in Tuesday night's Mostly Mozart Festival program, for this listener, was also the smallest, and it was neither the best work nor the best played. This was Haydn's Piano Trio in E (Hob. XV 28). The two fast movements had characteristic themes in their originality and quirky shapes, and the central Allegretto was a very curious Bachlike twovoice invention for the piano, with the violin and cello joining in briefly. Haydn never ceases to surprise.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Al Ullman, an Oregon Democrat, seemed assured of a key Congressional post yesterday when he was tapped by the Democratic caucus to head the new House Budget Committee.

title: Personal Finance: Divorce Shift
description: New York's divorce law denies alimony to a wife deemed at fault in a divorce action. Law, however, has a tendency to bend to the winds of change, and in New York recent judicial decisions have denied divorces in some cases where older wives would have been denied alimony.

title: Personal Finance: Divorce Shift
description: New York's divorce law denies alimony to a wife deemed at fault in a divorce action. Law, however, has tendency to bend to the winds of change, and in New York recent judicial decisions have denied divorces in some cases where older wives would have been denied alimony.

title: HUSSEIN PLANNING WASHINGTON VISIT
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 7  King Hussein of Jordan, who is on his first visit to Canada, said today that he planned to visit Washington at the end of his trip for consultations on the Middle East if circumstances permit.

title: SENATE PANEL ACTS ON COMMODITY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee agreed today to a plan to set up a completely independent regulatory commission to control commodity futures trading, committee aides reported. The action came as the committee moved toward final action, expected tomorrow, on legislation to strengthen and expand Federal regulation on the $500billionayear commodity futures trading industry.

title: GOLDWATER SAYS HE WOULD ACCEPT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Nelson A. Rockefeller figured prominently today in the early jockeying and guesswork about Vice President Ford's choice of a successor, If and when Mr. Ford succeeds President Nixon.

title: The Nightmare Fades
description: After a time, we shall ask ourselves in wonder how it all could have happened. How did the indecency, the lies, the contempt for human values go uncorrected as long as they did? When the truth was blazoned, why did so many persist in closing their eyes to it? How did Richard Nixon survive for so long in the unreality of his closed world?

title: House Votes Missile Site Planned for 6 Months' Use By LESLIE H. GELB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The House of Representatives voted $135million yesterday for the completion of a missile defense site that the Pentagon plans to place in mothballs six months after it becomes operative, according to a number of Congressmen and Administration officials.

title: Dance: At This Point in Time or Place
description: LEE Mass., Aug. 7Watergaterelated follies havebeen derided, discussed and analyzed, but until now they had not been choreographed. Pearl Lang took a hard look at the whole awkward mess and created At This Point in Time or Place, which her company presented for the first time at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Tuesday evening. The dance has a bitter, sarcastic bite at its best, though a few of its seven events could be trimmed profitably.

title: Goldwater in Senate Denounces, Lies About Him in TV Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, took the Senate floor today to describe the press as a rotten bunch.

title: PENNSYLVANIA LIGHT PLANNING AUSTERITY
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP)  A second look at electrical use forecasts has prompted the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company to revise construction plans for new power plants and to consider cutting back on staff, according to the company's president, Jack K. Busby.

title: Israelis Say Russian Arms Give Syria Might to Strike

Colonel Smith, a 1944 graduate of West Point, is professor and head of the department of mechanics at the academy. He would succeed Brig. Gen. John R. Jannarone, who retired last December.

title: The Screen:Lee Directs 'Return of the Dragon'
description: Kicking an enemy into oblivion with his flying feet, grunting and screaming triumphantly, achieving suspenseful pauses between blows, the late Bruce Lee is a pleasure to watch in his last kung fu picture, "Return of the Dragon," which opened Wednesday at neighborhood theaters. Lee's small compact face reveals a flurry of responses as he sends his opponents' torsos hurtling through the air, and he specializes in unpredictable movements.The picture concerns a Chinese restaurant in Rome which is menaced by gangsters who want to buy the property. On behalf of the owners, Mr. Lee has a duel with a vast American karate champion in the Roman forum. Unlike its predecessor, "Enter the Dragon," which was praised as a well-made movie, this picture is dreadfully slow and feeble whenever the cast isn't fighting. So you yearn for each battle, just as you wait impatiently for the songs or dances in a tedious musical. Mr. Lee scripted and directed this picture, and his dialogue  "Make some tea." "Sure, right away"wasn't up to his choreography.There's little bloodshed beyond a couple of discreet nosebleeds, and this brand of meticulous hand-to-hand combat seems rather refreshing, compared to our splashiest gun-flicks, such as "Magnum Force." Here, the audience cheers for quick wits instead of weapons, and skill defeats sadism. And it's regrettable that Mr. Lee didn't appear in some more substantial movies, since he did perform so nicely as a furniture-smashing villian in "Marlowe" in 1969.

title: Not Worth the Risk
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proceeds on the theory that where there is a reasonable risk of a pesticide's causing cancer it is better to stop its use at once than to wait a dozen years on the chance that the fear will prove groundless. Applying this commonsense rule, the agency has rightly suspended the use of aldrin and delldrinclosely related chemicals which have the same persistence as DDT, the same propensity for rising in the food chain and the same dangerous destination in the tissues of the human body.

title: Youths Seek Killer in 'Together Brothers':The Cast
description: Carbon-dating may well be the only way of determining precisely when it was that the basic story of "Together Brothers" first saw the light of a projector.Certainly anyone whose moviegoing experience extends into the pretelevision era or whose television watching spans only the last couple of years would be hard pressed to find any grounds for applying the adjective "original" to the plot of this modest and generally well-intentioned film."Together Brothers," which opened yesterday at the National and neighborhood theaters, is, after all, the tale of how a small band of youngsters goes about solving a crime, in this instance, the murder of a kindly policeman.What jerks the film out of the past, implants it firmly in the present and lends it at least a suggestion of novelty is that the policeman and the youngsters are blacks; the setting is not some neat little town but the rotting slums of Galveston, Tex; black-Chicano animosity is explored; and among the characters are whores, gangsters, pimps, transvestites and psychopaths.Insofar as he captures the present, William A. Graham, the director, has refreshed a tired story; but the performances tend toward unevenness, and one yearns for a more gifted directorial hand when the killer stalks the sole witness to the crime, a little boy struck mute by what he has seen.Preaching cooperation, brotherhood and a sense of obligation while stopping short of advocating vigilante justice, "Together Brothers" has its heart in the right place. Street-wise older children might find it to their taste; but all the new trappings cannot disguise the fact that "Together Brothers" is an old story, being retold perhaps wisely, but not exceptionally well.

title: Film: Chabrol's 'Ophelia':The Cast
description: When it takes 12 years for a renowned director's movie to reach our screens, the product is apt to be a jewel or a dog. Claude Chabrol's "Ophelia," made in 1962, has just emerged from the kennel, and although the picture has a bit of historical interest, much of it strays far from the film maker's own talents. "Ophelia" opened yesterday at the Playboy Theater.A wealthy young provincial suspects his mother (Alida Valli, a study in bitter restraint) and his uncle of having killed his father in order to marry each other. Clutching some clues from "Hamlet," he tries to expose them by shouting accusations at meals, pretending to be crazy, and by making a short movie about an incestuous crime. Obsessed with seeming and being, denouncing humanity at large, he trots about in the woods in a business suit and tie, hugging his divine discontentMeanwhile, he attempts to force a young woman (Juliette Mayniel) into the role of his Ophelia. Their relationship mainly consists of his murmuring claptrap about the beauties of nature into her ear, while she laughs skittishly and favors him with somber or demure smiles. Eventually, her father  who is of course labeled Polonius  dies in a tree after one of the funniest heart attacks I've seen in years. The quasi-Hamlet remarks that trees bear strange fruit these days.The movie is equally boring and pretentious, because of the characterization of the tormented hero. Played by Andr Jocelyn, he comes across as a huffy bundle of affectations, and between the bouts of hollering, his style is stiff and vapid.However, there are moments that will reward some students of Chabrol, such as the theme of individuals feeling guilty when they're innocent. The elegant camera-work lifts the woodland episodes above the general banality, and the formal meal scenes contain some of Mr. Chabrol's choicer observations of people chewing and swallowing while their pleasure in food is spoiled by the anger in the air. And there are a couple of nice thugs. But "Ophelia" hardly evokes Mr. Chabrol's best films, such as "La Femme Infidle"; instead, it recalls his creakiest earlier work, like "Les Cousins" and "Landru."

description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP)A 16yearold girl killed a 15yearold boy today after they faced each other with loaded pistols following an argument, the police said. The boy was identified as George J. Gatson. The police did not identify the girl, who was taken to a juvenile shelter.

title: RIVAL ACCUSES CAHN OF SHUNNING F.B.I
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 7The Democratic candidate for District Attorney of Nassau County, Denis E. Dillon, charged today that the Republican incumbent, William Cahn, had consistently refused to cooperate with the Federal Bureau of Inestigation and had seriously weakened Federal law enforcement efforts to combat organized crime in Nassau County.

title: House Votes Missile Site Planned for 6 Months' Use
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The House of Representatives voted $135million yesterday for the completion of a missile defense site that the Pentagon plans to place in mothballs six months after it becomes operative, according to number of Congressmen and Administration officials.

title: No Deal
description: The most redeeming element in the Watergate tragedy has been the confirmation its denouement is providing that no citizen is above the law. That reaffirmation of a concept basic to democracy and social responsibility will be subverted if eagerness in Washington to speed President Nixon's departure from office results in serious contemplation of a deal to induce his resignation.

title: On Market Legislation
description: With tax reform near the top of the current list of Congressional priorities, the nation's policymakers are taking an unusually sympathetic look at what the existing tax laws do to individual investors.

title: Denver Becomes Nuggets
description: DENVER, Aug. 7 (AP)The Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association changed their name today to the Denver Nuggets. Rockets had been the team's nickname since the franchise was started in 1967.

title: OUTFLOW AT PEAK AT SAVINGS BANKS
description: New York savings banks, beset by interestrate ceilings on deposits at a time when many other interest rates are soaring, lost a record $602million in July as savers pulled out their money.

title: CONCERT IS GIVEN IN WASHINGTON SQ.
description: Washington Square Park, with its bongo drummers, barking dogs, yelping children and allpurpose bustle, might seem a less the ideal spot for an outdoor concert of classical music, particularly that of the intimate sort. But that hasn't deterred the Washington Square Association, which offered the first of four free concerts Tuesday night, marking its 17th season of such events.

title: A FORD INTERVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Vice President Ford is fully aware that he is on the threshold of the Presidency but is uncertain when he will cross it.

title: Malaise in Britain
description: A new British election this fall seems unavoidable. The question is whether a second resort to the voters in 1974 will be any more effective than the first one in February in producing a Government that can govern. Available indicators are not hopeful: An election may only bring another minority administration, constantly in peril of defeat in Commons, unable to take the tough decisions necessary to head off economic disaster.

title: NIXON CRISIS CUTS PRICES OF SILVER
description: Gold prices moved down it London yesterday and silver futures in New York, which often follow the trend in gold abroad, responded with SOME nervous movements, ending or the downbeat.

title: A Blend of Singing and Acting Is Specialty of Novella Nelson
description: When Novella Nelson made her debut as a singer at the Village Vanguard five and a half years ago, she was moonlighting from Off Broadway. Her acting experience was reflected in her singing, giving her songs a dramatic projection that set her apart then from the largely rockinfluenced young singers.

title: Avon Products Prices Up; More Increases Planned
description: Avon Products, Inc., said yesterday that it was increasing prides 10.5 per cent in the current third quarter on 273 cosmetic and fragrance items and was planning additional price increases in 1975.

title: Californians in Poll Want Nixon Barred From Practice of Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7Voters in President Nixon's home state have turned against him to the point where they not only want him impeached, convicted and removed from office, but they also want him barred from the further practice of law, a polling organization reported tonight.

title: 5 Nominated for Board of Public TV
description: The White House yesterday submitted to Congress its five nominees to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for vacancies that have existed since March 26. The corporation, which provides leadership and coordinates funding for the public broadcasting industry, operates with a 15member board.

title: Stage: In 1 Corner, 2 British Musicals
description: LONDON, Aug. 7HeighHo for the British musical! Once upon a time there was a moment when it was believed that there might be whiter than white hopea British heavyweight boxing champion, There was, of course, Bob Fitzsimmons. For that matter, regarding the musical, Britain did produce John Gay's The Beggar's Opera. But since those days, for boxer and musical alike, the situation has not been bright.

title: Advertising: New Rickles Ride
