Msgr. William Nolan performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Stoney Hill in Watchung, N.J., where he concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Charles P. Platt.

title: Utilities Face A Worsening Money Pinch
description: For decades the nation's private electric power companies have been admired by investors for offering dependable returns on investments and by consumers for usually dependable service and cheap prices. The good times have ended though, at least for a while, and the industry is in a state of shock.

title: New Grounds Are Sought For Sussex County Show
description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10Dr. Robert C. Rost surveyed the grounds of the Sussex County horse show today and frowned.

title: Seaver Gets Runaround As Reds Down Mets, 53
description: On the bottom line, it would be hard to say which hurt mostthe seven bases the. Cincinnati Reds stole yesterday in full view of 40,359 persons in Shea Stadium or the three errors contributed by the New York Mets.

title: Alabama Won By Quaze Quilt
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y,. Aug, 10  Quaze Quilt became the surprise conqueror of Chris Evert in the $56,100 Alabama today, but the achievement required a stakes recordbreaking performance on the part of the winner.

title: Allamuchy Park Takes Shape
description: ALLAMUCHYThe state's Department of Environmental Protection has announced the purchase of 3,564 acres of land northeast of this township for $6.2million, the most expensive acquisition in the eightyear history of the Green Acres program.

title: Jose Miro Cardona, 71, Dies; ExCuban Premier, Law Expert
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 10 (AP)Dr. Jos Mir Cardona, who was Fidel Castro's first Premier in Cuba for three months in 1959 and then served as the Cuban Ambassador to Spain, died today of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: New Head Of HospitalInheritsAusterity
description: After one week as executive director of the Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, L. Roy Carmichael has not had enough time to solve the problem of a mandated budget cutback or take sides in a dispute over renovation or relocation of the center.

title: For and Mantle to Enter Hall of Fame Tomorrow
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y. Aug 10 (AP) Man?? and Whitey Ford, the glamour players of New York Yankee teams in the nineteenfifties and sixties, will be enshrined in baseball's Hall of Fame Monday.

title: Wanted in France: Grape Pickers
description: EARLY October, 1973. I am standing in a grape field in the French countryside, tireder and dirtier. than I've ever been in my life, handing a little curved knife to a sinning French winemaker. I have just completed a twoweek marathon grapecutting Session called the Vendange, my introduction to Frerich cultureto hard Physical labor.

title: Concrete Boat Christened With Champagne and Soup
description: PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 10 (AP)The Sojourner Truth, a 50foot sailboat made of concrete, has been christened with the traditional champagne and a bottle of homemade chicken soup for extra good luck.

title: Allison Cobb Broadhead Married
description: Allison Cobb Broadhead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Almet Norval Broadhead of Jamestown, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Andrew Neill Gordon Saxe of Stanfordville, N. Y., and Westport, Conn.

title: State Spurs Bilingual Classes
description: TRENTONA new bilingual educational law that will put New Jersey in the vanguard of states moving to close the language gap in their school systems will be in effect soon. The Assembly is expected to complete the necessary legislative action next month.

title: Brownout Protest Is Aimed At LILCO
description: MERRICK  A 30block brownout is sche??ed here tonight between 8 and 9:50 o'clocknot because of an overburdened electric system, but because customers of the Long Island Lighting Company are protesting what they consider to, be excessive electric bills.

title: Connors Advances On Clay
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors overpowered Onny Parun, 63, 62, today to gain the men's singles semifinals in the United States claycourts tennis championships at the Indianapolis Racquet Club.

title: The CeaseFire War in Vietnam
description: SAIGONA year ago, when the Vietnam ceasefire was six months old and the war was still thundering along, a sharppenned Saigon car toonist drew his analysis: two fighting cocksone tied to a stake labeled with a hammer and sickle, the other to a stake painted with the Stars and Stripesstraining at their bonds, lashing out with their beaks, determined to attack each other and keep the fight going no matter what restraints their backers devised.

title: Bridge
description: Trump suits, like the astronomers black holes, defy nearly all the usual laws. A highlow signal by a defender in the trump suit, ror example, promises exactly three trumps, whereas in another suit it would show an even number of cards if it is an indication of length.

title: Phone Traffic Union Wins In Votes Here and Upstate
description: The Telephone Traffic Union, both upstate and downstate, has defeated the Communications Workers of America in a representation election among traffic employes of the New York Telephone Company, officials of the National Labor Relations Board reported yesterday.

title: MEDIATOR MOVES IN TAXI DEADLOCK
description: The state mediator in the taxi dispute moved yesterday to get the owners and drivers to the bargaining table again in a fresh attempt to break their contract deadlock.

title: Janet Van Winkle Plans Fall Bridal
description: Janet Daingerfield Van Winkle of Prospect, Ky., and Edward Colston Newton of Newport News, Va, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lawrence Clendenning Newton, to Joseph Brewster Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Stevens Jr. of Princeton, N.J.

title: Wilhelm Reich Vs. the U.S.A.
description: Peer Gynt vs. the Button Moulder is a title Jerome Greenfield could have chosen for his account of the fatal hounding of Wilhelm Reich by the Food and Drug Administration. A perpetual outsider, Reich contributed enduringly to the psychoanalytic theory of character until he was expelled from Freud's movement in 1934 for political and sexual radicalism. Reich strongly identified with Peer Gynt, the subject of his first psychoanalytic paper. Reich saw Peer as the unconventional dreamer, bursting with energy, eager to change the world but certain to get his neck broken because of his daring curiosity. Like Peer, Reich was an inveterate optimist. Until he died in Federal prison in 1957, plane flying overhead signified to him that the Air Force and possibly President Eisenhower secretly were protecting the most important work of Reich's life.

title: Man Is Indicted in Death Of Priest in East Side Fire
description: Gordon Earl Marais was indicted Friday by a Manhattan grand jury on charges, of arson and murder in the death of a priest during afire July 29 at the rectory of St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, 869 Lexington Avenue.

title: The Chief Awards
description: VARIETY GROUPS

title: Resignation Stirs Blacks Here To Renew Criticisms of Nixon
description: There was little sorrow in the city's black communities over Richard M. Nixon's departure from the Presidency.

title: Byrd of Virginia Describes Call From Nixon Seeking Assurance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr.,Independent of Virginia, said today that he had received a telephone call from former President Richard M. Nixon early yesterday, just four hours after Mr. Nixon told the nation he was resigning.

title: Taiwanese Keep Fit With Ancient Boxing Exercise
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Just before dawn, while most of this city's twomillion inhabitants are still asleep, thousands of physicalfitness enthusiasts are already on the move.

title: Montrose, N.Y. Man Killed
description: NEW MILFORD, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP)A young Montrose, N. Y., man was killed last night when his car went out of control and smashed into a tree along Route 706 in New Milford

title: New Men Make Striking Impression On ArnspargerUp to 12 Could Stay
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 10 Coach Bill Arnsparger believes that as many as 12 rookies and free agents have a chance to win berths on the New York Giants' roster this year.

title: 79% in Poll Back Resignation; 55% Oppose Criminal Inquiry
description: More than threequarters of Americans believe that Richard M. Nixon did the best thing by resigning as President, but more than half oppose an investigation of possible criminal charges against him, according to a survey by the Gallup organization.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Rumor in London has it that Arab oil money has been seeking an investment outlet in the British stock market. Nothing too odd there, if you accept the theory that the recent 15year lows set in that market mean an opportunity to buy in at the bottom.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: RANDOLPH HALE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (AP)Randolph Hale, theatrical producer and actor died Friday of cancer. He was 65 years old. He was the husband of Marjorie Lord, who starred in the television series Make Room for Daddy.

title: Yankees Beat Angels, 21, On Throwing Error in 7th
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 10 An unearned run fashioned out of a walk, a sacrifice, a wild pitch and a wild throw by Ellie Rodriguez in the seventh inning enabled the New York Yankees to score a 21 victory for Rudy May tonight as the recently acquired lefthander faced his former team for the first time.

title: Study Gives Outboards Clean Bill
description: Do outboard motors harm water or its life systems?

title: Christine. A. Johnson Is Bride Of Jeffrey Tallackson, Lawyer
description: Christine Ann Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larrabee M. Johnson of New Canaan, Conn., and Jeffrey Stephen Tallackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Tallackson of Oak Ridge, Tenn., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., in the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: New Breed Horseplayers Are Rocking and Rooting at Monticello Raceway
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 10Harness racing's dwindling herds of hardcore horseplayers are being replenished here by young newcomers to whom The Bump means something that happens on the dance floor rather than on the track.

title: Editors' Choice
description: CHRONICLES OF WASTED TIME, by Malcolm Muggeridge. (Morrow, $7.95.) Volume (The Infernal Grove) of the English wit's autobiography, in which the stately sentences roll, the comic turns bubble, yet a serious moral accounting is rendered.

title: Sailors Go by Boat to Mystic For Seaport's Annual Meeting
description: MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 10Annual meetings may be a chore for members of some organizations. But for salty types going to the yearly sessions at the 400acre Mystic Seaport Maritime Museum here, it is a special opportunity to forsake conventional forms of travel with a relish and go by boat, big, or little, sail et powerand to pick up a tan en route.

title: Letters: Some Views On Frontier Justice
description: To the Editor: In connection with the horror story by Whitney North Seymour Jr., Frontier Justice: A RunIn With the Law (Travel Section, July 21), I say Mr. Seymour was flat out wrong! One does not ever park a car and trailer so that any part of eitherand certainly not an entire back wheel of the traileris on any part of the paved highway. That highway, as Mr. Seymour admitted, is clearly marked Do Not Park On The Roadway. That means any part of the roadway. It is not up to the individual driver to decide whether he has left enough room for someone to pass.

title: The Ragtime RevivalA Belated Ode to Composer Scott
description: OUTSIDE, it was a languid Sunday evening in Newport the weekend before last, with wisps of fog drifting in on a light breeze off the Atlantic. In the Great Hall of The Breakers, the mammoth Italian Renaissance summer cottage Cornelius Vanderbilt put up in 1895, a crowd of some of society's toniest namesincluding Auchinclosses, Drexels and Cauntess Szapary, Vanderbilt's granddaughtermoved to their seats through more marble, bronze, gilt, brocade and velvet than most people see in a lifetime. The event was the Patrons' Gala of the elegant Newport Music Festival, held in the town's grandest mansions and ordinarily devoted to chamber music by some of 19thcentury Europe's lesser lights. But it was not the strains of Albert Franz Doppler, Josef Holbrooke or August Klughardt that were to titillate the audience. Instead, the New England Conservatory Ragtime Ensemble, conducted by Gunther Schuller, launchedinto the syncopated sunniness of Scott Joplin's Maple Leaf Rag. It was the latestand perhaps the most refreshing splash in the ragtime tidal wave currently deluging America. into the syncopated sunniness of Scott Joplin's Maple Leaf Rag. It was the latestand perhaps the most refreshing splash in the ragtime tidal wave currently deluging America.

title: Jean E. Rose Has Nuptials
description: Jean Evans Rose and Thomas Tyson Gilpin, students at Princeton University, were married yesterday in the Sewickley (Pa.) Presbyterian Chuch by the Rev. Dr. Jack Maxwell. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Rose of Sewickley, is an alumna of the Sewickley Academy and Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn. Her father is a vice president of the Pittsburgh National Bank.

title: Five in Motor Home Burned
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI)Five Texans sleeping in the rear of a motor home were burned, two seriously, when a flash fire broke out as the home was being filled with gas at a service station. Debbie Griswold, 15 years old, and her brother, David, 13, both of El Paso, suffered second degree burns on their arms, legs and face. Also burned were Vivan Griswold, 34, her daughter, Denise, 14, and a nephew, Charles Davis, 11.

title: WestchesterFairfield
description: LOOK at a map of Westchester County and its neighbor across the Connecticut line, Fairfield County. Note all the beaches along the shore of Long Island Sound, But, if you follow the map to these beaches, You will find numerous signs saying: Open to Town (or County) Residents Only. Must you look elsewhere for a cooling dip on a hot day? Well, not exactly. There are two beaches open to the general public within reasonable driving time of New York City: Sherwood Island State Park, near Westport, Conn., which is about 55 miles away, and the Playland beach in Rye, N. Y., about 30 miles away. Some lakes in the area north of the city are also opea to the public, and perhaps the best is at the Blue Mountain Reservation near skill, N. Y., about 45 Miles away.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, AUGUST 11, 1971
description: THERE used to be a summertime rule of thumb in the record business: disks that became hits in the dog days were lightweights suitable for background noise to surf and sun. That school of thought has supposedly been unfashionable of late, but judging by the dearth of new releases worth listening to, let alone worth reviewing, I think it still seems to be prevailing.

title: That other impeachment
description: One thing that gives history its edge of priority and peculiar sense of immediacy in America is a national habit of mind. To find out where they go from here, Americans characteristically look, not forward, but backward to find what they did in the past. In moments of critical national decision such as the present, they search for precedents. History is seen to be full of parallels, analogieslessons. It is one of the few genuinely conservative traits of national character. But it is not without its perils.

title: POLICE SHOOT A MAN IN HOSPITAL
description: A 34yearold Brooklyn man, being treated for a cut throat went berserk in a hospital last evening and was shot by the police officer who had driven him there, the police reported. He died about an hour later.

title: GUARD SAID TO OFFER TO KILL A WITNESS.
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (UPI)  A security guard has been charged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with offering to kill a prosecution witness against a Mafia chieftain for $25;000.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A CONSENSUS among business leaders and economists indicates that the change of Administration will give the economy a psychological lift but cannot solve in a hurry the basic global aspects of inflation and recession. ... Wholesale prices jumped 3.7 per cent in July, spurred by large increases in farm and industrial commodity prices. ... Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, recommended a $4billion public service employment program if the unemployment rate hits 6 per cent.

title: Mr. Ford May Not Be Able to Help Until 1976
description: WASHINGTONBy the time the end came for Richard M. Nixon, his party was in almost as bad shape as he. Fewer than one American in four, according to the Gallup. Poll, was willing to describe himself as a Republican. The figures: 42 per cent Democrats, 34 per cent independents, and only 24 per cent Republicans. It was the Republicans' worst showing since the poll was begun in 1940.

title: Pamela Bontecou Becomes Bride
description: Pamela Bontecou and State Senator Michael Lukens Laughlin of South Carolina were married yesterday afternoon in the Lyall Memorial Federated Church in Millbrook, N. Y., by the Rev. Arthur Kinsolving, an Episcopal priest.

title: Red Smith
description: Word comes from rodeo country that The Rope is on the loose again, which means that not a calf or a cowboy or a quarter is safe between Kamloops, British Columbia, and Harlingen, Texas. The Rope is a skiing golfer named Dean Oliver, probably the toughest competitor this side of Cuchulainn. Starting life as a blue baby in Strong City, Kan. that's just across the Cottonwood from Cottonwood Fallshe grew up on raisins and beans from the Mormon welfare station in Nampa, Idaho, to become the absolute monarch of calf ropers.

title: Opposition To Shifting Of Inmates Increases
description: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP Opposition to a controversial state proposal to transfer 92 minimumsecurity prisoners from the Leesburg Prison Farm to the grounds of the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital here appears to be increasing, especially within the hospital's Board of Managers.

title: Democrats Battling In Island Primaries
description: A significant  and unusual  race for the Democratic nomination for Suffolk County district attorney is shaping up as a major contest in the Sept. 10 primaries in Nassau and Suffolk.

title: PAPER IS ASSAILED BY A HOMOSEXUAL
description: DETROIT, Aug. 10A homosexual here has filed a complaint with a city commission against his newspaper charging discrimination because of his sexual orientation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 11, 1974

title: Japan, China Tied In Softball Play
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 10  Japan, the defender, beat Venezuela, 130, yesterday to tie the Republic of China after two days, of the third annual women's world softball tournament.

title: The East German Music World
description: AMONG the Sovietbloc nations, one that is culturally blacked out for most Americans is the German Democratic Republic, or East Germany. For an area rich in cultural history, with cities such as Leipzig, Dresden, Weimar and, for that matter, East Berlin, not much is known here about the current general level of its cultural life. It is possible to travel there, and reports are forthcoming about new productions at Felsenstein's famous. Komische Oper in Berlin or at some of the rebuilt opera houses elsewhere. Individual artists, such as the soprano HanneLore Kuhse, have appeared here, and the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra will make its first visit, this fall. But what is it like for the average music student or professional musician?

title: Elizabeth Theater: A Stepping Stone to Fame?
description: ELIZABETH  For the many young people whose goal is Broadway, or even Off Broadway, the Elizabeth Town Theater may someday prove a major stepping stone.

title: Eskimos Match Skills at Arctic Games
description: TUKTOYAKTUK, Northwest TerritoriesAn Eskimo from the tiny hunting and fishing village of Sachs Harbour, on frigid Banks Island in the Canadian Arctic, loosened his furlined parka and said, Down here I feel like it's too far south for comfort.

title: Impeachment and Business in 1868
description: Politics and economics are linked together as the shoulder to the arm.

title: Denise Sweeney Bride of C. J. Lane
description: Denise Mary Sweeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sweeney of Wallingford, Conn., and Christopher John Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Lane of Houlton, Me., were married yesterday at noon in the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Wallingford by the Rev. Thomas P. Glynn.

title: CHARLES HALL DIES, MIAMI BEACH MAYOR
description: MIAMI, Aug. 11 (AP)Charles F. (Chuck) Hall, the silverhaired Mayor of Miami Beach who was official host of both 1972 national political conventions, died today apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: MEDIATOR MOVES IN TAXI DEADLOCK
description: The state mediator in the taxi dispute moved yesterday to get the owners and drivers to the bargaining table again in a fresh attempt to break their contract deadlock.

title: DEMOLITION URGED OF TWEED COURT
description: The final report on the old Tweed Courthousethe sooty, splotchy monument to 19thcetntury municipal corruption that hulks behind City Hallrecommends that it be demolished and replaced with a modest office structure of a design compatiable with City Hall.

title: Death of Executive Here Under Inquiry
description: Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., the head of a major shipping company, was found dead in a onebedroom East Side apartment Friday, and a medical examiner yesterday described the death as suspicious.

title: Gardens
description: CLEMATIS are among the most beautiful hardy flowering vines. The large flowered hybrids with wide  open flowers which frequently are eight inches across are the most popular. The vines are from six to ten feet high and open in their growth habits. The name clematis means slender vine. Their comb pound leaves are attractive all season and the fruits, which develop quickly after the flowers fade, are often showy in the garden and suitable for indoor decoration.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The precipitous decline in the productivity rate in the United States should be of the highest concern to corporate management. Yet management's approach to achieving significant gains in productivity remains tentative and timid.

title: SENATE NOMINEE SCORES TV REBUFF
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10Mayor Peter F. Flaherty, the Democratic senatorial nominee, today attacked the refusal of 10 Pennsylvania television stations to sell him four and onehalf hours of time for a fundraising telethon.

title: GrassRoots G.O.P. Feels the Economy Will Be Key Political Issue Facing Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Grassroots Republicans in 15 states, relieved that Watergate and Richard M. Nixon have left the White House, are full of ideas about what President Ford should do for their party.

title: Art
description: PARIS ONE of the great dates in the history of art is April 15, 1874, the day on which the French Impressionistsamong them Degas, Monet, Renoir, Pissarro, Sisley and Czanneopened the group exhibition in Paris that they had put on at their own expense. It was for art what the breaching of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, had been for public life: the definitive moment, after which nothing would be the same again.

title: Neil Amdur
description: The East German woman stood on the starting blocks, the skintight blue swimsuit hugging her taut body, accentuating the muscular arms and shoulders.

title: Robert Hartmann Sworn In As Counselor to President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) With President Ford looking on, Robert T. Hartmann took the oath today as Presidential counselor with Cabinet rank.

title: City Disputes State on Mental Facilities
description: The city's top health officials and the heads of psychiatry at leading hospitals here have clashed with the State Department of Mental Hygiene over state plans to reduce drastically the number of beds planned for the new Bellevue psychiatric center.

title: Paperbacks
description: Tintin (pronounced tantan) is a comic strip that began in Belgium in 1929 and spread to 26 countries (with hardcover sales of more than 25 million copies in 16 languages) before arriving here in paperback (though it has run here previously in Children's Digest magazine). Its eponymous hero is an ageless youngster (my opinion is about 14) who lives alone with his terrier Snowy, is identified as a newspaper reporter, wears knickerbockers and a pullover, and has a Skeezix shock of hair and solid dots for eyes.

title: Irwin in Hall of Fame
description: DENVER, Aug. 10 (AP)Hale Irwin, the United States Open champion, has been elected to the Colorado Golf Hall of Fame and will be inducted Sept. 12.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ELMWOOD PARKThis community used to be called East Paterson, and that is stillthe name seen on most signs. It is more like a suburban town than a city, but there are working factories, and a couple of factoryoutlet stores are well worth a trip.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Foreign Prospect
description: It may take some time for incredulous foreign governments to be really convinced; but the United States under President Ford is well situated to be a more stable, reliable and forthcoming partner in, the world polity than it has been throughout the lingering twilight of the Nixon Administration.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: 2 Things to Look for: Tradition and a Way of Listening
description: WASHINGTONGerald Rudolph Ford is Mr. Middle America, as solid and functional and comfortable as the furniture that used to come out of his home town, Grand Rapids.

title: INDIA SET TO RAISE AGE FOR MARRIAGE
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 10 (AP)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government is considering laws to raise the legal age for marriage in India. The objective is to reduce the number of child mothers, whose babies are helping to increase the population by an estimated 13 million a year.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayAmerican Motorcycle Association regional championship races at Orange County Fair Speedway, Middletown, N.Y.; time trials at 1 P.M., races at 2 P.M.

title: Susan Bierman Bride Of Steven Kessler
description: Susan Bierman, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Herbert B. Bierman of Sayreville, N. J., was married last evening to Steven Kessler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Dale L. Kessler of East Grand Rapids, Mich. Judge Richard Cohen of the Superior Court of New Jersey performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Kurtz of Madison Township, friends of the bride's family.

title: Cost of Drinking Linked To Lower Traffic Toll
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI)The number of California traffic fatalities is dropping because the price of a drink is going up, Walter Pudinski, Highway Patrol Commissioner, said. He said drinkers who used to have four or five at favorite saloon were now using the money to buy a bottle and consume it at home.

title: Forum Project Gives Hope to Prison Inmates
description: TRENTON  The simple storefront home of the Forum Project belies its urgent pur pose: to give new hope to prison inmates. But Hap Laws, a former Death Row resident, and his partner, Dar Obstein, are cautiously optimistic that they can restore a measure of human dignity to inmates at Trenton State Prison and help them to help themselves.

title: Sets Win by 2813 From Flamingos
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.The New York Sets won the first three sets by 61 scores and clinched their World Team Tennis match with the Florida Flamingos in the first half tonight. Leading, 183, at halftime, the Sets finished with a 2813 victory.

title: Samuels and Carey in Accord on Main Issues
description: For months now, Howard J. Samuels and Representative Hugh L. Carey have been moving around the state in search of votes in the Sept. 10 primary for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: The Sayings of the Earlier Mr. Ford
description: As his party's minority leader in the House of Representatives, and in the last nine months as Vice President, Gerald R. Ford has had to speak on behalf either of a consensus view or as the political alter ego of Richard Nixon. Thus his positions on major questions of national and international policy may not have been fully or accurately foreshadowed by what he has said in the past, but those statements, and his record as a Representative, nevertheless constitute the best available evidence. Here is what Mr. Ford has said on a number of major issues:

title: Freelandia Air Travel Club Is Down but Not Out
description: The Freelandia Air Travel Club was conceived and heavily promoted a year ago as the swinging, bargainfare way for the counterculture to travel to Hawaii, Europe or just across the country.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayAt California.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: City Council committees will hold the following meetings this week:

title: Double Amnesty Urged
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Aug. 10 (AP)Four Arkansans formed the Committee for Healing the Wounds of America today and then urged President Ford to grant amnesty to both former President Nixon and draft evaders.

title: Paperbacks
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: World News Briefs
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 10 (UPI)Communist gunners shelled a 14vessel convoy steaming up the Mekong River 43 miles south of Phnom Penh today and sank the Danish freighter Hayan.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market made an impressive advance last week, fueled by investors' expectations that President Nixon would shortly resign.

title: Texas Killer Begins Term; Plans to Study Sociology
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 10 (UPI)Elmer Wayne Henley, 18 years old, convicted in the Houston sex and torture murders, has begun serving sentences totaling 594 years in the state penitentiary where his mother says he will take college courses, concentrating on sociology.

title: Ms. versus Cosmo
description: To the Editor: I am a survivor. (What woman isn't?) Of a suffocating marriage, two destructive affairs, even thoughts of suicide. (I suppose that sounds melodramaticarsenic after black lace.) I was brought up to believe that a woman could live only through a man. And social and economic realities mane it hard to do anything else. But your magazine let me know that I wasn't alone, that I am not crazy, that there are women all across the country who are determined to start considering their own needs and to accomplish something for themselves by themselves. The support I find in your magazine has given me the courage to finally reorder my priorities.

title: Turkish Aide Urges Fast Geneva Action
description: GENEVA, Aug. 10The Turkish Foreign Minister, Turar Gunes, took issue in an interview today with a message from Secretary of State Kissin ger urging restraint in the GreekTurkish dispute over the future of Cyprus.

title: Newark Makes Strides in Effort To Save Distressed Housing
description: NEWARK  Last Valentine's Day, Vlado Filev, a Yugoslav immigrant who speaks little English, had a close call at a land auction held in the office of the city tax collector.

title: People and Business
description: Eight years ago, three young New Jersey engineers decided to pool their backgrounds, talents and resources and go into business. The company they formed is Interdata, Inc., an Oceanportbased enterprise that designs, manufactures and markets minicomputers.

title: A CATHOLIC GROUP ACTS ON ITS DEBT
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10The Attleboro, Mass, province of the Missionaries of Our Lady of LaSalette is selling a major portion of its $12million, in real estate assets to meet debts arising from the collapse of a $25million investment fund run by the Roman Catholic religious order, sources say.

title: Hospital on L. I. Agrees to Reduce Beds
description: EASTPORTThe proposed Hamptons Hospital and Medical Center, stalled over a dispute over its size with the governmental agency that will finance it, took a forward step recently when it agreed to reduce its number of beds from 260 to 194.

title: Blueberry Output Expected to Drop
description: TRENTONProspects for the 1974 New Jersey blueberry crop are for a smaller output than last year, according to Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi.

title: Suit Planned Over Rise in Rochdale Village Costs
description: Lawyers for residents of Rochdale Village who are protesting a 32 per cent increase in their maintenance costs are expected to file suit in State Supreme Court this week, challenging the legality of the state's action.

title: Miss Kelsey
description: Marjorie Voorhees. Kelsey and Richard Duvall White, graduates of Trinity College, plan to marry late next month. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. H. Burr Kelsey of West Orange, N. J., and Quogue, L. I., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. White of Catonsville, Md.

title: O'Learys Win in MG
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 10John and Renee O'Leary of Newark, Del., were the winners of the MG Car Club International 1,000mile rally which ended here yesterday. The O'Learys were victors for the third time in the 1,000mile test which began here Tuesday. A field of 60 entries drove to Kingston, Ontario, to Ottawa, back to Kingston and then back here.

title: Photography
description: PHOTOGRAPHY, and particularly the format of the photographic book, is becoming one of the major contemporary modes of autobiography. By now a steady flow of work in this vein is underway; in addition to those statements of self which have been considered in this space during the recent past, there have been significant explorations by Lucas Samaras, Judy Levy and Adrienne Landau, Wall Batterton and a host of others in the past two years.

title: Israel Destroys a Boat Carrying Guerrillas and Approaching Her Coast
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Israel reported today that an ?? patrol vessel had blown up a motor boat carrying guer?? to Israel under cover of ??arkness last night.

title: Miss Taylor, T. D. Jones 3d. Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Mills Taylor of WinstonSalem, NC., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mercer Taylor, to Thomas David Jones 3d also of WinstonSalem. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Hanover, Va., and greatgrandson of the late Jacob A. Riis, author, lecturer and philanthropist.

title: More Idle in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)Unemployment in Massachusetts creased to 8.1 per cent of the work force in June, the state Division of Employment Security announced Wednesday. It reported that 243,100 persons were out of work in June, compared with 199,900 in May and 193,200 in June, 1973.

title: Part of Walker Base Is Sold
description: ROSWELL, N.H., Aug. 10One of the United States Government's prime pieces of residential real estate in the South Westthe former Walker Air Force Base housing areahas been sold for $4.8million, the General Services Administration has announced. Hubert S. Hatch Jr., a Roswell realtor, was the high bidder on the 785unit complex that includes 2bedroom duplexes, and 2, 3and 4bedroom houses covering 191 acres.

title: CONDOMINIUMS GAIN IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10 (UPI)Condominiums will become the predominant form of unsubsidized multifamily housing in Westchester County, according to a county study.

title: State Acquires 2 Art Works
description: TRENTON  Thanks to a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, the State Museum is acquiring two key works by New Jersey artists.

title: Fire Code Is Effective, Essential And Timely
description: The following article, by the New York City Fire Commissioner, is a response to a criticism of the city's new fire law by Melvin Kaufman, an associate of the William Kaufman Organization, which appeared July 28. Mr. Kaufman contended that the law was adopted in panic arid has turned office buildings into potential death traps by making evacuation in case of fire a criminal offense.

title: Urban County Freeholders Form Lobby
description: ELIZABETH  In a move designed to offset what they view as domination of the State Legislature by suburban and rural counties, the directors of the Boards o. Chosen Freeholders in New Jersey's five most heavily urbanized counties have formed their own lobbying organization.

title: A Bountiful Border Of Wild Strawberries
description: FOUR years ago in December, I sent away for a dozen plants of fraises des bois (strawberries of the woods). They cost $10. a dozen. Sound expensive? Wait.

title: New in Paperback
description: Through The Unicorn, An Accidental Man and a dozen other novels, Iris Murdoch has led readers to expect a special compound of pleasures: ingenious storytelling, elegant design, provocations of myth and philosophy. But few of her characters have been memorable. In her latest, The Black Prince, the old virtues are all present plus a set of psychologically complex and interesting characters. The action centers about Bradley Pearson, an aging British novelist whose work on his great book is interrupted by a dozen frantic callers, complicating and tangling his life and art calamitously. The way Miss Murdoch tells it obliges the reader to keep revising and reevaluating what he hears, to himself play a role in a kind of epistemological detective story. The best novel Miss Murdoch has written in years, was the verdict Lawrence Graver rendered in this Book Review.

title: Staffs of Gubernatorial Rivals Digging Up Dirt in Campaign
description: As the New York gubernatonal campaign begins to heat up, negative research, or position, is fast becoming a highly refined political science.

title: James Wright, Daniel Hoffman, Jorge Luis Borgespoets Two Citizens
description: James Wright started out in the fifties with a great bolt of visionary silk, which he cut, in the fashion of the day, to symmetrical patterns. His poems won prizes, but were so hard to believe, so safely and slickly art, that they seemed only a vast closet of ceremonial robes to be taken out, worn as one bowed before the formal dignity of poetry, and returned, spotless.

title: After 9 Years, Los Angeles Is Still Seeking Official City Song
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10This city is searching for a song.

title: Msgr. George Ehardt, 80; Chancellor of Archdiocese
description: Msgr. George C. Ehardt, former chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and managing director of Calvary and Allied Cemeteries, died Friday in Cheshire, Conn., where he lived in retirement. He was 80 years, old.

title: Bureaucratic Politics and Foreign Policy
description: Any day now I expect to read that some great university, probably Harvard, has created a new department, a department of internal political science. That's an exaggeration, but it is true that more and more academics seem to be enchanted by the theory that all politics is internal politics. If you really want to know what's going on: cherchez le bureaucrat.

title: Music
description: THERE aren't many music festival consciously dedicated to the secondrate. The Newport Music Festival is one, and, paradoxieally, therein lies its charm. Yes, Mozart, Brahms and other giants occaclonally are played. But, as has been pointed out previously in this column, where else in the entire world can one bear a group of expert musicians delicate themselves to Ketelby's In a Persian Garden? Or, as in this season's festival (it ended a week ago Saturday), listen to the skillful Peter Basquin play five of Ethelbert Nevin's Water Scenes, the collection that contains the immortal Narcissus? (Has any pianist programed Narcissus during the past 50 years?) Or listen to a group of singers in Liza Lehmann's Up Into the Cherry, Tree, a cycle set to poetry by Morman Gale that contains such soulwrenching lines as:

title: Stamps
description: THE fight against pollution is a little more muted on this year's stamps, perhaps because of the recent global energy crisis. Nature protection is the key concern.

title: Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: BY dismissing The Tamarind Seed as a fancily made movie, Vincent Canby misses Its message. [Two Formidable Female Stars, July 21]. Espousal of puritanical sexual mores notwithstanding, The Tamarind Seed is an immoral film; Although rated PG, the film contains a scene as violent as any found in an Rrated war picture. In addition to a machinegun shootout, the scene includes the bombing  in vivid flameorange  of a cottage with napalm. Although injured in the explosion, Julie Andrews makes a miraculous recovery, supposedly precipitated by the discovery that Omar Sharif awaits her.

title: Kathleen White Wed
description: Kathleen Ann White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. White of New York, and John Wilbur Stakes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Stakes of East Patchogue, L.I., were married here yesterday afternoon at Our Savior Roman Catholic Church bythe Rev. Daniel J. Sexton. He was assisted by the Rev. Duncan MacKenzie, a Methodist minister. The bride, is a staff nurse at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases here. Mr. Stakes, who is in the last year at Cornell University Medical College, graduated cum laude from Williams College.

title: I.R.S. Examination Set for Sept. 2324
description: NEWARK  The annual special enroliment examination given by the Internal Revenue Service will be held here on Sept. 23 and 24.

title: Bert Lester Bennett 3d Weds Elizabeth L. Townsend on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Lowry Townsend and Bert Lester Bennett 3d were married yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., by the Rev. Samuel Davis, a cousin of the bride and rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Easthampton, L. I.

title: What's Doing in SARATOGA
description: THE LEGEND OF SARATOGAThe curious charm of Saratoga life to a student of human nature is the fact that beyond any other American resort it is a social microcosm in which our distinctive national traits are happily juxtaposed in miniature. Thus wrote one observer in the late 1800's when Saratoga, in upstate New York, was Queen of the Spas, rivaled only by Newport, R.I. But Saratoga was different: its social life centered on cavernous hotels, mineral waters, gambling casinos and race tracks, not in the millionaires' cottages that made Newport famous. Saratoga was impious, opulent and exuberant. Today, however, the gambling casino is a museum; the old hotelsincluding the United States Hotel where President Ulysses S. Grant liked to give partiesare almost all gone, replaced by modern, sleek homogenized motels; the mineral waters still flow but their consumption has dropped because of a controversy about radioactive materials; and the road that leads into town is the same strip of motels, gas stations and fastsnack places that desecrate most American cities. But Saratogaor Saratoga Springs, to give it its official nameis a good place to visit, a small city with a magnificent center for the performing arts, a famous spa, the site where one of the decisive battles of the world was fought, and many fine restaurants. And, in a throwback to its raffish past, for one month of the yearwhen the thoroughbreds return each AugustSaratoga is different againcrowded, gay, exultant, expensive.

title: Trevino's Surge Gains Lead by Stroke
description: CLEMMONS, N.C., Aug. 10 The third round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship became something of a dogfight today as nine players finished within three strokes of one another.

title: John H. Crocker And Miss Elliott Have Nuptials
description: In St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, L. I., yesterday afternoon, Jacquelyn Diane Elliott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Elliott of Huntington Bay, L. I., became the bride of John Howe Crocker.

title: Road Building Is Cut Back as Costs Rise
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.There is a new word these days in the official vocabulary of California's freeway builders, who in the last 20 years created perhaps the finest system of highspeed roadways in the world. The word is deadoption, and it means California's pellmell construction of superhighways is being slowed.

title: In Praise Of Darkness
description: Like Miguel de Cervantes, about whom he often writes, the Argentine Jorge Luis Borges sees himself primarily as a poet. But Cervantes's quixotic notion of being a great poet was wrong, for the Spaniard's verses are largely mannered imitations in the Italian style and meter of the other Golden Age poets. Conversely, Borges, known largely for his ficciones, has now published his fifth volume of poems, a unified sequence of profound observations about people and things, dreams and darkness, showing that Borges, in giving primacy to poetry, is right. Yet with typical shiftiness, Borges also claims there is really no difference between his ficciones and his poems, that anyway he would like to be remembered less as a poet than as a friend, that he too dislikes them [the poems], and finally, reversing himself, he speaks about the book which in the end may justify [him].

title: Jo An Howard Becomes Bride Of George Thomas Eckenrode
description: Jo An Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Stanley Howard Jr., of Woodcliff Lake, N. J., Ripon, Quebec, and Carefree, Ariz., and George Thomas Eckenrode, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. F. Eckenrode of Pocono Lake, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon in a garden wedding on the hillside of Le Ferme Deerfield, the family farm in Canada. The Rev. James D. Campbell, a Roman Catholic priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

title: CONFUCIUS'S FAME GROWS ON TAIWAN
description: TAIPEL, Taiwan, Aug. 10Confucius, the ancient sag?? whom Chinese Communists re?? vile was acclaimed here in a recent address by the Chinese Nationalist Vice President, C. K?? Yen.

title: Preseason Football
description: N.Y. Jets at San Diego.

title: Lakewood's Plan B Approved
description: LAKEWOODDr. Fred G Burke, the state's Commissioner of Education, has approved the use of a modified desegregation plan for the school district here.

title: Moscow Portrays Nixon as a Victim
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10In its first detailed explanation to the Russian people of the fall of President Nixon, the Soviet leadership tonight portrayed him as the victim of partisan politics, the economic situation in America and the malicious propaganda of the mass media.

title: Nancy C. Piskor, D.C. Twichell Jr. Have Nuptials
description: Nancy Calder Piskor, daughter of Dr. Frank P. Piskor, president of St. Lawrence University, and Mrs. Piskor, was married at noon yesterday to David Cushman Twichell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Twichell of Belmont, Mass.

title: Bilingual Courses Planned
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 10The New Mexico State Board of Education has directed the state's 60 school district to determine the number of elementary school children needing bilingual education and to complete plans for implementing an adequate bilingual program. The action follows a court ruling that Spanishsurnamed children should be provided an equal educational opportunity.

title: Ford's ChallengeNew Program and New Faces
description: IF Gerald R. Ford needed any reminder of the nation's premier problem as he assumed its highest office last week, it was presented to him rather bluntly on the very day that he learned he would have to assume the mantle of the Presidency.

title: Margaret Brady Bride Of John Hofmann Jr.
description: Margaret Mary Brady, a teacher at the Dalton School here, was married yesterday afternoon to John Thomas Hofmann Jr., an advertising copywriter with Montgomery Ward in New York. The Rev. Hilary Zanon performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Loreto Roman Catholic Church in East Providence, R.I.

title: Now the Something To Put the Pots In
description: The name of a shop is about as important as its location when it comes to attracting customers. So what would be alluring for a place whose specialty is both concealing and giving a dressdup look to flower pots and plant tubs?

title: How TV Producers Sneak in A Few Extra Commercials
description: EVERY time a commercial airliner is shown on TV's police serial Hawaii FiveO it is a United Airlines jet. Beginning next fall, the privateeye hero of Mannix will drive exclusively a Chevrolet Camaro. On his two game shows, host Bill Cullen invariably wears clothes from Barney's men's store. Caravelle watches, manufactured by Bulova are often given away to contestants on The Price Is Right.

title: The Missing Conservative
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10The United States now has a President who looks and talks somewhat like Dwight D. Eisenhower, thinks politically somewhat like Harry S. Truman and has the economic ideas of Herbert Hoover. It is an intriguing combination.

title: Recordings
description: BETWEEN the beginning of Schubert's mature composing career in 1814 and the death of Chopin in 1849 lay 35 years of fantastic musical productivity that, among many other things, provided pianists with much, if not most, of the repertory that sustains them today.

title: 4 INMATES ESCAPE FROM LEWISBURG
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug, 10 (UPI)Four inmates, including a former Mormon Sunday school teacher involved in a bizarre hijacking in 1972, commandeered a garbage truck today and broke out of the Federal penitentiary here, the state police said.

title: 5 GUARDS SUSPENDED IN BREAKIN AT TOMBS
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm yesterday reported the suspension of five prison guards for up to 20 days because they failed to perform their duties last April 17 when four visitors tried to free three members of the Black Liberation Army from the Tombs.

title: Queens School Keeps 'em Down on the Farm
description: While many of their classmates are frolicking at the beach, 60 students at John Bowne High School in Flushing are spending their summer tending chickens, tilling the soil and harvesting crops.

title: ExGov. T. R. McKeldin Dies; Dominated G.U.P. in Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (UPI) Former Gov. Theodore Roosevelt McKeldin, a friend of two Presidents and a Republican who dominated politics in Maryland for 25 years, died early today of cancer at his home. He was 73 years old and had been a vigorous and an early opponent of racial segregation.

title: Dance
Klan Sues for $200,000
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 10 (UPI)The Ku Klux Klan is seeking more than $200,000 in damages from the City of Shreveport for blocking the group from holding a convention and arresting several klansmen. The klan said in the suit filed Friday that it had a lease to rent the convention hall July 10, 1973, which was not honored by the city.

title: Connecticut Pension Fund Takes Loss
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 10The state's Pension Investment Fund took a $119.8million beating in the stock and bond markets over the last two years as the result of an aggressive new investment policy that plunged the fund into a falling stock market, Leo V. Donohue, the state auditor, reported this week.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodaySand and Sea K.C. allbreed and obedience, Ocean County Park, Ocean Avenue, Route 88, Lakewood, N.J.; 1,609 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: SCHMIDT IS LIFTING PARTY POPULARITY
description: BONNThe shift in West Germany's leadership less than three months ago has produced a notable change in the country's mood.

title: Notes: Convention for The Unconventional
description: SWING '74, described by its sponsors as the first international convention and symposium on alternate lifestyles, is scheduled to take place Sept. 26 to 29 in Buena Park, Calif. The sponsorsJet Set. Magazine and an organization called Wide World of Contemporary People  say those who will attend are swingers, which they define as believers in open marriage, nudism and similar forms of behavior.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE of the most frequent home improvement or repair jobs that pop up  for those who rent oneroom studio apartments, as well as for those who own their own housesis the task of hanging or fastening something fairly heavy to one of the inside walls. Small, nailtype picture hangers are fine, for lightweight picture frames, but something much stronger is needed for hanging large mirrors, or for mounting shelf, standards, heavy drapery rods, cabinets and other types of storage units.

title: Newark and New York Look Beyond Busing
description: The Supreme Court's ruling in the Detroit busing case, which outlawed plans to mix innercity black children with white students from the suburbs, came as New York City and its largest neighbor, Newark, are rapidly running out of local solutions to the problem of racial imbalance in their schools.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 11, 1974

title: Morton Says Transition Panel Should End Its Work in 4 Weeks
description: WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 10  Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton, a member of the panel appointed by President Ford to aid in the transition of Presidential power, said today that the panel would follow a very easy and orderly procedure and should be dissolved in four weeks at the most.

title: SUPPLEMENTAL AID TO POOR ASSAILED
description: A State Assembly study of the sevenmonth old Supplemental Security Income Program for aged, blind and disabled poor has branded the Federal effort a failure so far in promoting nationwide equity in economic and humanitarian terms.

title: Elizabeth H. Crummey Is Married
description: Eilzabeth Hamilton tzummey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Crummey Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y., was married yesterday at noon to Peter Robertson O'Keeffe, son of Mrs. Thomas B. Wheeler Jr., also of Loudonville and the late Dr. John C. O'Keeffe.

title: Merrill A. Hayden Dies; Deputy Postmaster General
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 10 (AP)  Merrill A. Hayden Sr.?? former Deputy Postmaster General of the United States, died Wednesday at a hospital here. He was 61 years old.

title: Congress Will Shift Focus To VicePresidency Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10The House and Senate, which had been gearing up for impeachment, will now gear up to confirm a new VicePresidential nominee to be submitted by President Ford in the next 10 days.

title: Pace Taken By Mitey Hanover
description: YONKERS, Aug. 10Mitey Hanover, the 3yearold Son of Tar Heel, who only got to the races once as a juvenile, demonstrated tonight that he could be a darkhorse in next Saturday night's $100,000 Cane Pace by winning with ease at Yonkers Raceway.

title: What's New at the Movies?
description: THE MAD ADVENTURES OF RABBI JACOB (G rating), directed by Gerard Oury from a screenplay by Danielle Thompson and Oury and starring Louis De Funes, was generally well received by the critics, Our man concurred.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES VOTER RESIDENCY
description: A lawsuit has challenged a requirement of the state's election law that bars voters from primaries if they have not lived in the same county since the beginning of the year.

title: Foolish Pleasure Triumphs
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 10 Foolish Pleasure went from promise to complete respectability today by winning the $144,995 Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park.

title: Minter, Craw Win Alabama Races
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 10 (AP)Milt Minter of Fresno, Calif., the series leader, narrowly defeated Mike Keyser of Towson, Md., in a Camel GT Challenge Series race today after Nick Craw, who resigned yesterday as director of the Peace Corps, won an accidentmarred event for smaller sedans.

title: Budget Consultant To Ford Is Given An Operations Role
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 10 (UPI)When President Ford turns to problems of inflation, the national debt and deficit trade balances that continue to threaten the economy, he will be assisted by L. William Seidman, an economist, a philanthropist and an expert on where the taxpayers' money and the industrial dollars come from and where they are distributed.

title: Rutgers Course Set On Criminal Justice
description: NEWARK  The nature of crime and delinquency, and society's responses to them, will be the focus of the School of Criminal Justice, a new unit at Rutgers University here.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Byrne Road Plan Calls for Realigning of Route 18 Freeway
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne's proposed $200million highway bond issue includes $93million for specific road projects and major bridge repairs in nine North Jersey counties.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Despite a falling birth rate, business in infants' and toddlers' apparel is booming. It appears that parents, grandparents, aunts and uncles are still intent on keeping babies well groomed.

title: Susan Bagger Married
description: Susan Wentworth Bagger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Bruce Bagger of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, Fairfield, to John Martindale Berge, son of Mrs. Evelyn Kennison of Spofford, N.H., and Robert Berge of Culver City, Calif. The Rev. Stanley M. Houston performed the ceremony.

title: Film
description: SINCE the Watergate disclosures, stories about conspiracy have captured the popular imagination. Therefore, it is not surprising that a number of recent moviesincluding The Parallax View, The Conversation, Chinatown, The Tamarind Seed, SPYShave dealt explicitly with political intrigue and conspiracies of varying magnitude. These films range from Incisive to inane, but as a group they illustrate an intriguing national obsession.

title: Soap Rush Kills 2 in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Aug 10 (Reuters)To people were killed and five injured in the rush to buy a piece of soap, which is scarce in Egypt these days, the newspaper AlAbram reported today. In a fight over the last piece of soap in a shop in Rozeik village, the grocer and his son were killed, the newspaper said.

title: Rules on Abortion Clinics Filed
description: TRENTON  The longawaited breakthrough in the fight to make abortions easily available and inexpensive for New Jersey women took place last week.

title: President Tells Brezhnev That Dialogue Will Go On
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10President Ford has sent a personal message to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, signaling that he intends to maintain the toplevel dialogue begun by Richand M Nixon in 1971, Administration officials said today.

title: International Group Attacks Peru Junta For Press Seizures
description: The InterAmerican Press Association says the nationalization of independent newspapers by the military junta in Peru last month was an arrogant abuse of power based mainly on the persuasive use of guns.

title: ManilaUS Air Pact Signed
description: MANILA, Aug. 10 (AP)The Philippines and the United States announced today that they had reached an interim agreement for improved and expanded passenger and cargo air services.Two, weeks ago, American authorities seized a Philippine Air Lines DC10 in San Francisco for making alleged unauthorized flights.

title: Greek and Turkish Foes Mingle in Geneva Hotel
description: GENEVA, Aug. 10Turkish troops may be having skirmishes with Greek Cypriote National Guard forces in Cyprus, but within the glass walls of the Intercontinental Hotel here the Greek and Turkish Foreign Ministers drink the same strong French coffee and pay the same high prices for it in the Brasserie coffee shop on the ground floor.

title: Power of Boston Airport Authority Is Under Attack
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10The airplanes rumble in and out of Logan Airport, the world's eighth busiest, only a few minutes' drive from the heart of the city, carrying 10 million passengers a year.

title: In This Home, Not a Single Inch Is Lost
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.  When the architect Paul Damaz came to build a house for himself and his wife in The Springs, a section of this venerable town on Long Island's South Fork, he decided to design an open house in which not a single inch is lost.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MANILA, Aug. 10, (UPI)North Carolina State, the 1974 National Collegiate basketball chanipion, opened its eightgame Asian tour with a 128101 victory today over team from the Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association in Quenzon City.

title: Throngs at White House Seek a Touch of History
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 10They came in droves to the White House today, reaching out for a touch of history.

title: Crash Kills 12 Filipinos
description: MANILA, Aug, 10 (AP)A bus and a train collided today in Calumpit, Bulacan Province, 15 miles north of Manila, killing at least 12 persons and injuring 14, the police said.

title: The Power Passes
description: WASHINGTONFor more than two years the mystery of Richard M. Nixon's role in Watergate, with all its ramifications and strange twists, had held millions of Americans transfixed. Last week, in a sudden rush of events, like the final pages of a detective novel, it was all over.

title: Threat of Red Tide Keeps State Alerted
description: TRENTONAlthough several beaches along North Jersey's coastline were invaded by a shortlived bloom of red tide late last month, the state's shore resorts have got more than halfway through the summer without a major waterpollution crisis.

title: Television
description: CBS made news a few weeks ago by refusing to sell an hour of air time to an oil company. The oil company wanted to promote its side of the energy crisis controversy. CBS took the position that if you sell air time to people with a political ax to grind  outside of 60second spots during election campaigns  then all the political axes are going to be ground by people with lots of money, which may be hazardous to the mental health of the nation. This position seemed sound up until the other Wednesday night when, on CBS, we had the debut of The Hudson Brothers variety hour, a summer replacement show. On the whole, an hour of oil company selfcongratulation would have been preferable.

title: Tragedy and Triumph
description: Behind the dazzling succession of events of this most extraordinary week in American political history lies one fact of surpassing importance: the long and unmistakable drift toward concentration of power in the hands of one elected official, the President of the United States, has been stopped. Mr. Nixon and his closest associates considered themselves above and beyond the law, unhampered by constitutional limitations, untroubled by moral constraints. Their subtle moves toward subversion of the Government and deception of the people have now been halted, and reversed, by the processes of law and the political system, but most of all by an aroused moral force that has united the nation.

title: The American Front Porch Following the Rumble Seat Into Oblivion
description: NORA SPRINGS, IowaThe American front porchlong a treasured site for rocking, sipping, swinging, courting, gossiping, and plain old watchingis dying a painfully slow death, the victim of airconditioners, television and a shifting society.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: When the Total Environment Is the Best Part of the Evening
description: A COUPLE of months ago, Walter Kerr observed in these pages that nowadays audiences often seem to be more attracted by the environment, or ambience, of a theatrical experience, than by the play or the performance itself. This week's new productions  The Merry Wives of Windsor outdoors in Central Park and Rip Van Winkle under a canopystyle tent, in Tarrytownare cases in point. Both plays are star vehicles presented without stars (except for those shining overhead); and both productions are, in varying ways, rather indifferentto put it kindly. In both cases, the environment, the ambience, is the best part of the evening. Of the two productions, Rip Van Winkle is far more ragged and less professional, rut it is also distinctly more entertaining because it is the right play in the right place. For it is not only the play and the production and the place that make up a theatrical experience; it is also the interaction among the three.

title: South Middlesex Area Library at Issue
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThis city and suburban East Brunswick are embroiled in a dispute over which town's library will be designated the South Middlesex County Area Library. A hearing before David C. Palmer, the state's assistant library director, on Aug. 21 is expected to lead to a decision on which municipality gets the designation.

title: Egypt Regulating Marriages Involving Other Arab Lands
description: CAIRO, Aug. 10 (Reuters)Egypt is making it harder for her women to wed men from other Arab countries because so many of these marriages end in divorce, the newspaper AlAhram reported.

title: It is like growing up black one more time
description: In 1963, when the N.A.A.C.P. secured the old Morrison Hotel in Chicago for its annual national convention, one of that organization's demands was the removal of two statuettes of black jockeys standing in the lobby. The hotel management reluctantly agreed, but before the statuettes could be temporarily removed, they were draped with sheets. Their eyes were veiled, the jaunty caps were shrouded, those sassy hiptwists hidden. No longer would those baleful faces offend the sensibilities of blacks or encourage the contempt of whites.

title: Gains Seen in Bid to Get Commercial TV Station
description: TRENTON  Several of New Jersey's top officials are beginning to see significant progress in the long, uphill fight to gain a commercial television station for the state's 7.3million residents.

title: The Resignation Proved Impeachment Works
description: It is a magnificent lesson, a politicial scientist said as he watched, in wonder, the end of Richard Nixon's Presidency. A lawyer who has experienced much cynicism spoke the same words of faith that President Ford used a day later: The Constitution works.

title: Chinese Ceramics Shown
description: SOUTHAMPTONThe exhibition of Chinese art ceramics at the Parrish Museum is a stunner, a dazzling esthetic tour de force. There is one item after another of awesome beauty. Superlatives are not out of order to describe this show. It is one of the best I have seen at the Parrish and is worthy of any big city display.

title: Computer Wins Title For Hunters
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 10For the last year Michele McEvoy, a 21yearold brunette from Summit, N. J., has roamed the world with her jumper, Sundancer, and has scored some notable triumphs.

title: Numismatics
description: THE numismatic capital of the country will be on the southern tip of Florida this week. The 83rd annual convention of the American Numismatic Association opens to the public Tuesday at 11 A.M. in the Americana Hotel in Bal Harbour (Miami Beach), to run through next Sunday, Aug. 18; the closing lour is 4 P.M.

title: Benjamin Fairless 2d Marries Miss Crowell
description: Constance Bell Crowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bruyn Crowell of Syras ruse, was married yesterday afternon to Benjamin Franklin Fairless 2d, grandson of the late Benjamin F. Fairless, retired chairman of the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Schools Begin Study on Meals
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Education will begin to survey all publicschool districts this week so as to determine which ones must start providing free and reducedprice lunches for students, beginning on July 1, 1975.

title: Paul Blackburn, Poet
description: The poet Paul Blackburn died of cancer almost three years ago, at the age of 44. He had published seven volumes of his poems, mostly very slender volumes printed by little presses with names like Divers and Totem and Trobar and Perishable, as well as five books of translations from the Spanish and the Occitan. Associated with the Black Mountain group, he was a gentle, affectionate person with devoted friends all over the country. As the moving force behind the readings at the Dr. Generosity Caf and what he called St. Mark'sintheBouwerie, he must have encouraged innumerable younger writers. He was accomplished but unpretentious, one of those poets whose work shows more than most how ridiculous the barrier is that separates the general reader from poetry.

title: Irish Setter Is Best at Gloucester
description: SEWELL, N.J., Aug. 10 I've handled many Irish setter bestinshow dogs, said Torn Glassford today as he prepared to go into the ring for the final at the Gloucester County fixture, but none has come along any faster than this one. He's done all his winning since February.

title: Ford Seeks Suggestions For a New Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10President Ford asked for VicePresidential suggestions today from Republicans in Congress, in governors' offices and on his party's national committee. He has asked that preferences be listed in onetwothree order, sealed in envelopes for his eyes only, and presented to the White House by next Wednesday.

title: Trophies of the Headhunters
description: Almost everyone calls them headhunters, a term that makes them wince slightly but not nearly so much as bodysnatchers or flesh peddlers. They'd really rather be known as executive search consultants or executive recruiting consultants.

title: Good Wishes of Pope Are Delivered to Ford
description: VATICAN CITY, Aug. 10, (Reuters)Pope Paul VI sent a message today to President Gerald R. Ford following Ford's inauguration.

title: A $150,000 Painting Vanishes on Way Home
description: DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP)United States Customs agents and the police are seeking the Renoir painting Lady in a Flowered Hat, insured for $150,000, which was reported to have disappeared during a plane trip Thursday from London to Minneapolis by way of Detroit.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST HIGHT'S GAMES

title: ETHIOPIANS. BAR PALACE AS REFUGE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 10 (Reuters)The Ethiopian armed forces, in an outspoken attack on the imperial household, said today that the Emperor's palace must not be used as a refuge for rogues.

title: New Jersey
description: NEW JERSEY is a checkerboard of resort towns that invite the public to use their bathing beaches and others that have tried to restrict beach use to area residents and hotel and motel guests. Although local court decisions have recently forced shore communities to offer beach access to everyone at a standard fee$3 a daymany towns still do not have facilities where day trippers can change into and out of their swimsuits. Moreover, some resorts that were once proud of their beaches have fallen into comparative disuse because of the decline of the railroads and the greater mobility of vacationers. Long Branch, for example, once known as the resort of Presidents and the site of the summer White House in the late 19th century, now resembles an aging urban center more than a resort, and its beach, once wide, has in many places actually been pushed back under the boardwalk by the surf. So the, family looking for the best beaches New Jersey has to offer on a oneday trip would do well to head for one of the following:

title: Pawns and twists
description: ACROSS

title: Redman Gains Pole In CanAm
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP)  The 1973 champion CanAm car, Roger Penske's turbocharged PorscheAudi 91730K, made its first appearance of the season today and Brian Redman gained the pole position in it for tomorrow's $81,750 Buckeye Cup CanAm race at MidOhio.

title: Miami Pair Wins Leg in Yachting
description: NAPLES, Italy, Aug. 10 (AP)  Augustine Diaz and Barry Cochran of Miami, sailed their yacht, Cuban Comet, to victory today on the sixth day of the weeklong 470Class world yachting championships.

title: For Summer Students, Aspen Is the Peak of Perfection

Bill.

title: The Signals Movie Actors Give

By what means, people used to ask, did an actor portray anger or joy or despair? What combination of facial attitude, body tension, or vocal edge would most emphatically indicate the feeling required? Both talented and untalented performers pursued the challenge, and their solutions formed the activity, the labor, or, if you were lucky, the art of acting.

title: Headliners
description: George Berlinger, long a critic of welfare administrators and New York City mayors, has quit his post as the state's first Welfare Inspector General to campaign for Governor Wilson. Mr. Berlinger spent three years as an unpaid investigator into the state's massive welfare programs. The result, he says, is $10million saved for the taxpayers. Better administrative supervision, he asserts, could save as much as $1billion. Wilson campaign strategists will probably use him to serve as liaison to his wide range of business contacts.

title: Ford's Noble Beginning

But in none has the transition been smoother or under more difficult circumstances than the United States.

description: What next?

title: Chess: Smashing Weak Pawns Is Fine You Aren't Carried Away
description: Pawnweakness exploitation fever is reaching epidemic proportions in contemporary strategy. Whereas it was once considered a momentous decision to cede the bishop pair for the sake of saddling the opponent with doubled pawns, that type of transaction is relished by the new wave of masters.

title: Book Ends
description: Leonardo. McGrawHill is aiming to make this the Year of Leonardo da Vinci. On September 30, they will bring out The Madrid Codices, a fivevolume set that includes facsimile reproductions of two hitherto lost Leonardo notebooks, plus a onevolume commentary by the translator, Ladislao Reti (who died last fall), and a twovolume translation of the notebooks into modern Italian and of course English. The codices were discovered by accident in 1965 in the National Library of Spain, where they had languished in obscurity for over a century due to a cataloguing error. McGrawHill's connection with the codices began almost instantaneously with the announcement of the discovery of the MS. Frank Taylor, then editor in chief, read about the find while deplaning at Kennedy Airport. He promptly replaned and headed for Madrid, where he negotiated with the Spanish Government for permission to publish. There was some reluctance on the part of Spanish authorities to agree to what amounted to publicizing a rather monumental goof before the world, but eventually they relented and are now wholeheartedly behind the project. The translation plus the legal and technical problems involved in mounting an international publishing effort took six years. Production and printing took place in four European countries and the total cost of the venture was $2million. The codices will be published in several countries simultaneously through a copublishing arrangement.

title: Manila Arming Civilian Croups To Aid Military Against Rebels
description: MANILA, Aug. 10Faced with growing insurgency in Moslem Mindanao, the Philippine Government has armed certain civilian groups to, relieve regular forces of minor peacekeeping functions.

title: Religious Sect Backs Ford

The predominantly black, rigidly Fundamentalist denomination, which has a membership of 30,000 passed a resolution expressing shock over the moral climate that contributed to Watergate where elected officials seek to control and manipulate Government agencies for personal gain.

title: The Constitution Is Alive and Well

Never before have we had a crisis that challenged the basic assumptions of our constitutional system itself, and the basic processes and mechanisms through which it worked.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories

Rinaldi has been acquitted of perjury and obstruction of governmental administration charges by a Brooklyn jury that was unaware that a verdict of guilty would have been set aside by the presiding judge. Murtagh, in an opinion sealed until after the verdict, said the prosecution had failed to prove that Justice Rinaldi had intended to lie to the special grand jury that indicted him last November.

description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10Mayor Ralph J. Perk has vetoed al gun registration bill that the City Council passed by one vote,

title: Question: How Do You Buy. A Work of Art Like This?
description: WTHIN the last few years, art lovers have been treated to some pretty wild experiences. In Berne, Switzerland, the artist Michael Heizer used a housewrecking machine to smash up the asphalt outside a museum where his works were being exhibited. This demolition was the main event of his show. Another artist built an igloo at the entrance to his exhibition at the Whitney Museum in New York City, and a fellow Whitney exhibitor dug away part of the foundation of the museum and ground it to dustpresenting the dust as a work of art. Walter de Maria filled a Munich art gallery with a threefoot level of dirt. Later, he planted tall, sharp steel spikes all over the floor of his New York dealer's showroom and then made viewers sign a document releasing him from legal liability in case they accidentally skewered themselves.

description: It isn't at every performance of La Sylphide that one of the characters, Madge the witch, hobbles out and is immediately greeted by bravos and applause in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Dropout was a word of opprobrium. That it might be good thing, not a bad thing, to escape the excessive continuity of academic pressure was rarely considered.

title: Timothy Leary, the Madness Of the Sixties and Me
description: The madness of the sixties seems very far away. This is the clich of the seventies, and it is also true. At least, Timothy Leary seems far away, locked in a prison cell in California, serving out an improbably long sentence for the crime of possessing less than one ounce of marijuana. The seventies man is more like Charles Slack, who wrote this story of his perilous journey through the sixties to the safe and complacent shores of 1974. Slack, a psychologist, and Leary were colleagues for a year at Harvard, and apparently they had a sort of drinkingbuddy friendship, with Leary playing psychic proselytizer and Slack, by his own admission, playing the game square.
