title: Reporter as entrepreneur, government by competition
description: The I.T.T. affair may have wrecked the Justice Department, demoralized the Republicans and doomed Attorney General Richard Kleindienst, but it did wonders for Brit Hume. Hume was the investigator who wrote the Jack Anderson newspaper columns in 1972 charging that the Nixon Administration had settled its antitrust suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for a $400,000 subsidy to the G.O.P. national convention in San Diego. What made the accusations stick was the famous memorandum attributed to Dita D. Beard, the conglomerate's Washington lobbyist, laying out the terms of a quid pro quo in embarrassing detail and containing the prophetic closing linePlease destroy this, huh?

But to cut down on crowding, many towns in Nassau and Suffolk Counties close their beaches to outsiders, usually by restricting parking near the beach to town residents and summer guests with identifying auto stickers. On some beaches, such as Belle Terre, near Port Jefferson, one cannot even set foot on the sand without displaying proof of local residence.

It takes for granted and ... helps make respectable ... abysmal greed.

description: PETERSBURG, N. Y., Aug. 10  The Fox Hollow Festival, a folk festival started in 1966 by Bob and Evelyne Beers, a wellknown pair of folk singers and instrumentalists, began its ninth annual series of programs Thursday, with its original principles intact and a following Unusual among festivals of any kind.

title: Maine Presses Control Of Lakefront Growth

title: Mondale, Against Immunity
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) Immunity for former President Nixon would make a double tragedy out of Watergate, Senator Walter F. Mondale said today, There is no blanket forgiveness in the law, the Minnesota Democrat told a news conference.

title: Late TV Listings

title: SAMOA VOTE BARS AUTONOMY MOVE
description: PAGO PAGO, American Samoa, Aug. 3For the third time in three years, the people of this United. States possession have rejected the right to choose their own governor and lieutenant governor. As a result some prominent figures here are calling for moves to force more selfgovernment on American Samoa.

title: The Nation
description: The outlook on inflation has darkened considerably, despite all hopes and Government predictions to the contrary. Newly released figures show that the wholesale price indexwhich foreshadows, though not exactly, what will happen to prices consumers pay in storesrose by 3.7 per cent in July.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: New Jersey is faced with a serious naturalgas shortage. Yet, all over the state there must be thousands of yard gas lamps burning day and night.

title: Samuels Chides Wilson on School Aid
description: Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that a new school aid formula adopted by the State Legislature this year would mean increases in school aid only during this election year and decreases in the years that follow.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThis anguished political town has often tended to pay rather little attention to the stock market and its gyrations.

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Ultimate Bird Watcher
description: It was just 40 years ago this last April that Houghton Mifflin took a chance on a young Boston schoolteacher. He wasn't an ordinary teacher: He spent most of his spare time taking his students on field trips, showing them the natural world he had loved since his own boyhood. It was a mission with him, and even then there was a sense of urgency. The teacher took some selected students away on longer trips, sometimes over extended holidays on Cape Codand among the lucky ones were Elliot Richardson and his younger brother.

title: J. B. Glendon, Susan Hastings Wed in Suburbs
description: Susan Packard Hastings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Hastings of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Bayard Glendon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Glendon of Scarsdale and Fishers Island, N. Y. The Rev. Jeffrey Newhall performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

title: Chargers Trouble Jet More Than Picket Line
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10Unlike the raucous reception they received in Denver a week ago, the Jets walked into San Diego Stadium for their National Football League exhibition with the Chargers tonight unimpeded by insultshouting pickets.

title: Burns, Kirkland Ousted In BestBall Quarterfinal
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 10Mark Etess, who said he never won anything worth mentioning and Doug Stein, a former Ivy League golf champion at Columbia, turned in a major amateur golf upset today when they defeated George Burns 3d and Dave Kirkland in the quarterfinals of the 38th annual Anderson Memorial bestball tournament.

title: Drug Science Program Set
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)Northeastern University will offer a parttime master's program in radiopharmaceutical science here this fall. The program, open to those who al??ady have the bachelor of science degree in pharmacy or in a related basic science, will train people to compound and manufacture radioactive drugs for use in diagnosis and ??erapy.

title: A Jazz Saxophonist Reexamines His Southern Roots
description: MARION Brown, an Atlantaborn alto saxophonist and composer, dropped out of Howard University in 1965 to perform with John Coltrane and Archie Shepp in New York. In 1970, after several years in Europe, he returned home for the winter. Though he has since migrated to New England, where he is teaching and studying ethnomusicology, his Atlanta winter has been the inspiration for much of his subsequent work.

title: From outer to inner space: the craze to explore the mystic areas of consciousness, by reason and by hoax
description: Every few days, as a spiritual exercise, former astronaut Edgar Mitchell, lunar module commander of Apollo 14, the sixth human being to walk on the moon, meditates with the aid of his portable biofeedback machine. Roughly the size and shape of my SmithCorona typewriter, Mitchell's custommade instrument connects to his scalp with small electrodes to register the four basic rhythms of the human brainalpha, beta, theta and delta. Between beta, the routine wakeful state of everyday consciousness, and delta, the rhythm of deep unconscious sleep, lie alpha and theta, the slower cycles registered in the state of meditation. Mitchell's contemplations are based on a variety of Eastern doctrines that he studied after the spiritual conversion he underwent on his lunar journey. He strains, for half an hour or so at a time, to get down from the busy level of beta into the more contemplative terrains of alpha and theta. Beep, beep, goes the biofeedback machine when Mitchell's mind wanders away from his exercises, reminding him to get back into alpha ... and the former astronaut, ever the fastidious monitor of electronic hardware, responds with a new bout of concentrated onepointedness.

title: News of the Realty Trade Koreans Buy Prime Park Ave. Building
description: The 22story office building at 460 Park Avenue on the northwest corner of 57th Street has been acquired by South Korean interests for almost $15million.

title: The Region

title: Consumer Buying Is Murky

description: The contenders for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, Toward J. Samuels and Representative Hugh L. Carey, differ more in style than in substance, a comparison of their public statements on the major campaign issues shows. Page 48.

Thyne performed the ceremony in the San Marino Community Church.

title: Oyster Bay Crew Wins At Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 10 Chris Allsopp and Nell Halleen, a combination double, today won the right to represent the United States in the world rowing championships at Lucerne, Switzerland, Sept. 8. The Oyster Bay R.A.University of Wisconsin crew covered the 2,000meter distance on a rough Lake Carnegie in 7 minutes 17.1 seconds.

title: Sporting Goods Industry to the Women.
description: When the nation's sporting goods industry met in New York last week one of its main interests was womenon the business agenda. Suddenly the industry is listening to women because housewives are dropping their brooms and taking to the outdoors by the thousands. Last year women spent approximately $100million on sports clothing alone, another $25million on nothing but tennis racquets and balls, and the sporting goods industry says women are just loosening up for what's coming.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The highflying Los Angeles Dodgers, occupants of first place in the National League's Western Division, come to Shea Stadium tomorrow night to start threegame series with the Mets. The first two contests will start at 8:05 and the last game will be played Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock. On Friday, the Yankees move onto the Shea scene to start a fourgame set with the Chicago White Sox. A twilight night doubleheader starting at 5:35 opens the series Friday, single games are scheduled for Saturday and Sunday afternoons at 2.

title: Rain Hits Areas of Midwest But Crops Need Much More
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10  Badly needed rains blanketed sections of the droughtstricken Middle West grain belt this weekend, easing crop deterioration and raising hopes that a large portion of the nation's withered soybean crop can be salvaged.

title: Adios Heats Final Won By Haughton
description: MEADOW LANDS, Pa., Aug. 10  Billy Haughton loves The Meadows, the track in the hills of Western Pennsylvania. Every time he comes here, he wins, and today he won better than ever.

The reports have tended instead to follow the official line of the South Vietnamese Government, particularly in its view of the progress of the war, and events have shown that line was part overoptimism and part distortion.

description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 11 Pakistan asked Afghanistan today to return immediately Pakistani Army helicopter and its crew of five that landed by mistake in Afghan territory near the border.

title: Egyptian Arrives In U.S. to Discuss Next Mideast Step

description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 11President Ford is puzzling over a list of about 15 names, with no surprises on it, for a man to fill the vacant VicePresidency. But he is still asking for ideas not only about who the choice should be but also about what it is he needs in a No. 2.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Kevin McCarey, a student at Villanova University representing the New York Athletic Club, won the Road Runner Club of New York 5,000meter Encore run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium. McCarey covered the course in 14 minutes 55.1 seconds, 200 yards ahead of Tom Nolan of the N.Y.A.C. Nolan's time was 15:22. Mike Hagen of Suffern, N. Y., the New York State high school mile champion, won the teenage race in 16:10.6.

title: Press Room at Laguna Beach Serves As Modest Museum of the Nixon Era
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 11  Quite unintentionally  for how could they have known?  the managers of the Surf and Sand Hotel here may have created something that is at once a modest museum of the Nixon years and a reminder of how quickly a sitting President can become an exPresident, and how total and even sad that transformation can be.

title: Chemise Shown Again in Paris, Stirs 7th Avenue Hope
description: Paris says the chemise Is coming back. If so, will it prove to be the rain for which droughtstricken Seventh Avenue has been praying?

title: The Meteors
description: Meteors will be flashing across the sky tonight and for a couple of more nights to come, for now is the time of the Perseids. They are the shooting stars whose orbit the earth crosses now. They are called Perseids because they seem to radiate from the constellation called Perseus, which rises in the northeastern sky around midnight. Those who watch meteors regularly say close 70 lightstreaking Perseids an hour can be. seen. The casual amateur may easily see twenty or twentyfive in an hour of watching.

title: New Jersey Briefs

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11For his first time as President of the United States, Gerald R. Ford went to church today, and then spent the rest of his Sabbath discussing a new, Vice President and working on the speech he is to make tomorrow night to Congress.

title: Skydiver Killed in Japan

The parachute of Nobutaka Yoshinoya, 23 years old, had struck the parachute of another jumper.

title: Miss Steinberg Bride of David Kessler

title: Evicted Woman's Suicide Stirs Questions on Care
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, Aug. 11  Marion Greenberg Parker said she would kill herselfand she did. Mentalhealth experts who generally regard any suicide threat as a desperate cry for help, said they never learned of her case in time to help. Other persons, who did hear her threat, said they did not think she would carry it out.

title: Plohn and 1 of 2'Partners Consent to S.E.C. Findings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Charles Plohn Sr. and Steven L. Gutman, former partners in the brokerage firm of Charles Plohn & Co., have consented to Securities and Exchange Commission findings of fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Ehrlichman Says Nixon Won't Rusticate
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 11 (AP) Richard M. Nixon, driven from the Presidency by the Watergate scandal, will not become a recluse, his former top domestic adviser predicted

title: Taipei Aide, 50, Is Detained, Queried on Youthful Activity
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 11A department chief of the Government Information Office has been detained by a security agency for more than two months, officials have acknowledged, for questioning about associations more than 25 years ago in mainland China.

title: Nixon Slide From Power: Backers Gave Final Push
description: This article was writen by James M. Naughton and is based on reporting by him, Bernard Gwertzman, Diane Henry, John Kifner, Douglas E. Kneeland, Robert B. Semple Jr. and Philip Shabecoff.

title: An End to Either/Or
description: WASHINGTON  Americans like most people need heroes, and the more unheroic the times the more determined becomes the search for symbols of our greatness and even decency.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 25

title: 9,000Foot Dive to a Valley in Atlantic
description: ABOARD RESEARCH SHIP KNORR, At sea, Aug. 9American participation in what has probably been one of the last great adventures remaining for those who would explore unknown regions of this planet has come to an end with the 17th dive by the submersible Alvin into the rift valley and transverse canyons of the midAtlantic.

title: S. Klein Plans a Comeback After Pruning Operations
description: Despite a $9.6million loss last year, the planned disposition of almost half of its 19 stores and much adverse publicity, S. Klein Department Stores, one of New York's most widely known chains, isn't quite ready or willing to join the ghosts of bygone retailers.

title: For the Divorced Man, Too, It's a Wrenching Experience
description: The man is young, personable, intelligent  and divorced. He is an individual again, not one of a pair, and the whole world is bright and shiny.

title: Scott Says Capitol Leaders Oppose Nixon Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Hugh Scott, the Senate minority floor leader, declared today that he had found growing bipartisan opposition in Congress to the possible criminal prosecution of former President Richard M. Nixon for his role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Poodle Gets Lakewood Top Award
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 11A young black standard poodle, whose favorite pastime at home is chasing squirrels and chipmunks, was chosen best of 1,634 dogs today at the Sand and Sea Kennel Club fixture at Ocean County Park, She is Ch. Bel Tor Blissful, owned by Mrs. Mary Heyman and Pamela Hall of Port Jefferson, L. I.

title: Some Progress on Cyprus Is Reported At the Geneva Talks on Peace for Island
description: GENEVA, Aug. 11Some progress was reported at the Cyprus peace talks here today. The Greek Foreign Minister, George Mavros, said that Greek Cypriote forces would begin evacuating Turkish villages and enclaves occupied since the outbreak of fighting last month.

title: U.S. Says Pikes Rise For Food Middlemen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)  Food middlemen's charges in 1974 may average aboute 20 per cent above 1973, the biggest annual increase on record, the agriculture Department reported today.

title: Jet Din Frays Nerves of Residents Near Los Angeles Airport
description: LENNOX, Calif.  Myrtie Fults prays for fog.

title: To Nixon People
description: WASHINGTONNot so long ago, about four out of ten adults in this ceuntry referred to themselves politically as Nixon people. How should they react to the forced resignation of the man who for so long embodied their beliefs and their prejudices?

title: Legal Abortion Clinic Opens in an Aging Hotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11South Jersey's first legal abortio nclinic  the second in the state  began operations here yesterday with its doctor performing 12 abortions.

title: Search Is Relaxed For 4 Escapees From U.S. Prison
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 11 (AP)The police relaxed their search today in a wooded area for four escapees, including a convicted airplane hijacker, who filed from the Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary.

title: Dance: A New Sylphide
description: All 19thcentury Romantic ballets do not look alike. This point was driven home at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon, when Karen Kain of the National Ballet of Canada made her local debut in the title role of La Sylphide.

title: Sets Top Lobster For 3Match Streak
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11Nikki Pilic and Charlie Owens won the key men's doubles tonight, 6.2, from Roger Taylor and Raz Reid, leading the New York Sets to a 2822 victory over the Boston Lobsters in a World Team Tennis match. A crowd of 2,464 watched.

title: Disputed Stretch of Henry Hudson Parkway Is Reopened
description: In a surprise move, the longdisputed stretch of the Henry Hudson Parkway between 79th and 72d Streets was reopened to southbound traffic late yesterday afternoon, pleasing many Sunday drivers as well as residents of nearby Riverside Drive, who remained critical, however, of the continuing heavy flow of detoured northbound traffic.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUT WEST The West End Cafe, right in the heart of Columbia University's offbeat environment of head shops, bookstores and boutiques, has been a popular place for years. Three and a half years ago, there was a fire in a laundromat next door and that began to change things. After the blaze the West End's owner decided to expand south by opening a new room for the restaurant area.

title: WOMAN TO OPPOSE OREGON SENATOR
description: BAKER, Ore., Aug. 11The Oregon Democratic Central Committee nominated State Senator Betty Roberts today to run against the Republican incumbent, Robert W. Packwood, Sor the United States Senate race this fall.

title: Credit Rationing
description: One of the shortcomings in a tight money policy as the prime weapon against inflation is its extremely uneven impact on different sectors of the economy. Some borrowers, the biggest or those who can pay the highest rates, can get all the credit they need, while other borrowers are cut off and threatened with financial disaster.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The head of the 25,000member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said he had commissioned an independent study to convince the city that policemen deserved higher pay than firemen or sanitationmen. Ken McFeeley, newly elected president of the association, said the question of which job was more hazardous was not at issue.

title: 10 Arrested at Gambling In a Brooklyn Synagogue
description: The police raided a Las Vegas Nite in a Brooklyn synagogue late Saturday night and early yesterday morning, arresting 10 alleged promoters of the gambling operation in what they said was the start of a crackdown on similar illegal activities.

title: CreditMarket Analysts Expect Yields to. Advance
description: Although the Captaincy of the Ship of State changed last week, the credit market continued to navigate between the Scylla of economic malaise and the Charybdis of inflation. But there was nothing mythical about the dangerous rocks and whirlpools that confronted the market in fixedincome securities.

title: The Slowest Draw in the East
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass., Aug. 11Sam and King are blazeLced Belgians from Chester, N, H., heavily muscled, with massive hindquarters and feet the size of dinner plates. Harness jingling, they came around in a semicircle with Skipper Smart jogging behind them holding the reins and assistants supporting each end of the doubletree, the iron crosspiece to which the singletrees and traces were attached. Smart steered the team across the bow of a flatbottomed stoneboat loaded with concrete blocks stacked five feet high. Whoa! he said, steadying the rig for an instant while the assistants fitted the opening in the middle of the doubletree over a hook on the prow, of the Times boat. As the metal clanged into place the horses lunged simultaneously, their great shoulders straining against the collars. Smart lunged with them, putting a shoulder to Sam's rump and fetching King a couple of swats with the slack of the reins. The sledge lurched over the bare, raked earth, slowed, shuddered ahead another foot or so.

title: Joan M. Ebert Has Nuptials
description: Joan Marie Ebert and Timothy Simes Rothermel, special assistants to the Under Secretary General for political and General Assembly affairs at the United Nations, were married last evening. The Rev. Kenneth E. Nye performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: 3 Candidates to Vie for 5th District Seat Occupied by Frelinghuysen for 11 Terms
description: SOMERVILLE, Aug. 11 Representative Peter H, B. Frelinghuysen's decision not to seek a 12th term in the Fifth Congressional District in central New Jersey has pitted 37yearold television news director against a 64yearold grandmother as the candidates of the major parties.

title: Leading Lawyers at Convention Disagree on Nixon Prosecution
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 11 (AP)Some of the nation's leading legal figures disagreed today about whether Richard M. Nixon should be prosecuted for alleged Watergate crimes.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE TIDE AT SUNRISE: A History of the RussoJapanese War, 19041905. By Dents and Peggy Warner. 627 pages. Charterhouse. $17.50.

title: Renee Lowen Married To Aaron Cahn on L.I.
description: Renee Susan Lowen, coordinator of newsfilm crews here for the National Broadcasting Company, and Aaron Ronald Cahn, who received a Juris Doctor degree in June from the Brooklyn Law School, were married at noon yesterday in Temple Israel, Lawrence, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Joel Y. Zion; the spiritual leader, assisted by Cantor David Benedict.

title: Stray Chest: It Was $258.12 (Plus Meals)
description: This is the diary of a woman who cheerfully wandered into a Fifth Avenue store, one day and set up such a chain of frustration that now she is wondering if she can charge her psychiatrist's bills to Major Medical. Her handwriting gets increasingly illegible and all (expletives) are of course (deleted). No, she is not you.

title: Harken Back to Age When Knights Were Knights
Street Fiesta in East Village A Showcase for Puerto Ricans
description: The East Village's Puerto Rican residents have taken their concept of fiesta, borrowed a bit of the experience of others in conducting street festivals, and have come up with their own weeklong Street Fiesta, which pis being held on Avenue C, between Fourth and Eighth Street, starting at 4 P.M. daily.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary aid Index, Page 25

title: Players Halt Strike 14 Days; Report to Camps Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)  National Football League regulars decided today to suspend their strike for 14 days, effective Wednesday, in an effort to resolve their labor dispute with the 26 club owners.

title: Bridging the Gap
description: ATLANTADuring a recent countryradio discussion of a new socalled sunshine lawone that requires open governmental meetingsa caller said to me: There are two things a person should never watch being made. One is potted meat, and the other is laws.

title: New Tree Will Replace Damaged 88th St. One
description: A new tree will be provided for East 88th Street, east of York Avenue, to replace a 40foot spreading plane tree that was cut down last Thursday amid neighborhood outcries, Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. said yesterday.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes Half Fare for Elderly Raises an Odd Nickel Fuss
description: The odd nickel is something like a bad pennyit keeps coming back to haunt both cardcarrying senior citizens entitled to ride the buses during offpeak hours at half fare and State Department of Transportation officials casting about for an administrative solution to numbers that, don't divide evenly.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police raided a Las Vegas Nite in a Brooklyn synagogue late Saturday, arresting 10 alleged promiters of the gambling operation in what they said was the start of a crackdown on similar illegal activities. The raid, by nearly 20 police officers of the public morals division, came one week after a reputed Mafia figure, Steven Cirillo, 31 years old, was shot to death at a dice table at a Las Vegas Nite at another Brooklyn synagogue.

title: Ballet Theater Foundation Amended Fiscal Statement
description: The New York State Council on the Arts, which initiated an audit of American Ballet Theater, has disclosed that the troupe's parent unit, Ballet Theater Foundation, submitted 29 pages of corrections and adjustments to its final financial statement for 197273.

title: Petty's Vandalized Car Wins by a Hood
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 11 (AP)Richard Petty stuck the nose of his Dodge in front of the Mercury of his old foe, David Pearson, at the finish line today and won the $147,000 Talladega 500mile stock car race hours after a dozen cars, including those of the two leaders, were damaged vandals,

title: Egyptian Arrives In U.S. to Discuss Next Mideast Step
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt arrived here today for talks this week with Secretary of State Kissingerand probably President Ford  that American officials hope will clear away uncertainties about the next round of Middle East negotiations.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: One Dies as Police in India Fire on Workers at Factory
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 (Reuters)  One person was killed and two were injured today when the police fired on a crowd of workers trying to take over a factory after a cut in takehome pay.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor: The basics soundness of your analysis of Turkish ceasefire violations (editorial July 27) does not extend to your conclusions and the assumptions underlying these. This indicates a misconception of Turkish objectives, a naivet regarding the nature and scope of the conflict, or both.

title: Dale Prince Is Bride of Explorer
description: Dale Prince, a dental hygienist, was married yesterday afternoon to David Sidney Humphreys, an explorer and ship owner. Police Judge Peter Garvan of Old Westbury, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ivin Bittker Prince in Old Westbury. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Sidney George Humphreys of Adelaide, Australia, and the late Mr. Humphreys, who owned a stevedoring company there: Dr. Prince is a dentist here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: N.A.S.D MEMBERS DROP 34%, TO 427
description: It's hardly surprising anymore that It's a bad time to be a stockbroker, last week's rallies notwithstanding. But as bad as things are for Big Board member firms, they are even worse for that segment of the securities business that specializes in overthecounter stocks.

title: Race Driver Injured
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 11 (UPI)A stock car driver was critically injured in a crash yesterday at the Orange County Fairgrounds. Listed in critical condition at Horton Memorial Hospital with numerous broken bones and other injuries was Thomas Harkins, 20 years old, of Carmel, N. Y.

title: UNION SAYS LAYOFFS DRAIN FUND AT G.M.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP)Layoffs affecting 84,000 General Motors workers have drained a G.M. unemployment benefit fund to the point where payments are being curtailed to some workers, a United Auto Workers spokesman said today.

title: Merits of CoolingOff Period Debated
description: Will the 14day coolingoff period settle the National Football League players' strike or will it serve to heat up already bitter feelings among owners, players and coaches?

title: Cab Owners Adopt Midnight Deadline For Pact Extension
description: The city's taxi fleets cluding perhaps 5,600 of 11,787 yellow medallion cabs  plan to notify their 30,000 drivers today that they will close their garages at midnight tonight there is no further extension their labor contract or a newcontract settlement.

title: Lisbon to Ask Security Council To Admit GuineaBissau to U .N.
description: LISBON, Aug. II (Reuters)Portugal will ask the United Nations tomorrow to recognize GuineaBissau and admit it to the world organization.

title: CAREY NARROWING LEAD OF SAMUELS IN FINAL WEEKS
description: With the Democratic gubernatorial primary only four weeks off, Howard J. Samuels is apparently still the frontrunner, but Representative Hugh L. Carey is closing the gap.

title: CLEO R. DUPRE
description: Cleo Robertson Dupre, widow of William Kent Dupre, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Bridgewater, Conn.

title: Boundary Dispute Delays New Community Projects
description: The Beame administration, trying to unsnarl the tangle of neighborhood programs set up in recent years, has become involved in a complicated political and governmental squabble with Councilmen and Borough Presidents. Until it is resolved, the variety of agencies that now operate the neighborhoodlevel programs are holding off on new projects, although $5million is available to them in the current budget for such projects.

title: Stewart Thomas Marries Susan Kanter
description: Susan Elizabeth Kanter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Kanter of Roslyn, L. L, was married yesterday to Stewart Thomas, a history teacher at the Westminster City School in London. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hywel D. Thomas of Bristol, England. Magistrate Francis O'Shea of the Night Court of Williston Park, L. L, performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Country Club in Roslyn.

title: Kristin, $9.20, Takes $114,700 Delaware Race
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 11 (AP)Harold I. Snyder's Krislin survived a foul claim to capture the $114,700 Delaware Handicap today by threequarters of a length over Twixt.

title: Doctor and 7 in Family Die Minnesota Crash
description: A leading physician from Plainfield, N.J., his wife and all of their six children were killed Saturday night when their twinengine private plane crashed during an emergencylanding attempt at a small Minnesota airport.

title: CAREY NARROWING LEAD OF SAMUEL IN FINAL WEEKS
description: With the Democratic guber natorial primary only foul weeks off, Howard J. Samuels. is apparently still the front runner, but Representative Hugh L. Carey is closing the gap.

title: States' Legislators Weigh Impact of Watergate
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 11 (AP)Some of the nation's state legislators say they expect the change of Presidents to have little direct effect on state governments.

title: Joan Weinberger Is Wed to F. J. Berman
description: Joan Marsha Weinberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Weinberger of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick J. Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn Berman of Verona, N. J.

title: Carol J. Brown And a Lawyer Married on L.I.
description: Carol Joan Brown and Michael L. Michael were married yesterday afternoon in East Rockaway, L.L. at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Brown. Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Michael of Flushing, Queens, are the parents of the bridegroom.

title: 17,992 See Giants Top Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 11After having been scorned by picketing teammates before the game, the nonstriking New York Giants took out their wrath on the New England Patriots and defeated them, 216, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: Calvin Hill Ailing
description: DALLAS, Aug. 11 (UPI)Calvin Hill, a 1,000yard groundgainer for the Dallas Cowboys last football season, has been released from Baylor Hospital following tests for a kidney ailment. Doctors were unable to diagnose the ailment and he is expected to return to the hospital for more tests in the future.

title: Vatican Is Said to Step Up Security
description: ROME, Aug. 11The Vatican has stepped up its security measures and ordered its police force to carry guns following threats of a?? terrorist attack, a source close to the Vatican said today.

title: Franklin National Bank Faces Shareholder's Suit for Damages
description: Stockholders of the Franklin National Bank's parent company filed a suit Thursday asserting that foreignexchange transactions that lost the bank more than $45million were unfair and improvident, the Associated Press reported late Friday night.

title: Windsurfer, 14, Wins
description: HENDERSON HARBOR, N.Y., Aug. 11  Matthew Schweitzer, a 14yearold from Pacific Palisades, Calif., won the national open windsurfing event today. Schweitzer defeated Bruce Matlack, 29, of Newport, Calif., the 1973 winner.

title: Advertising: World Team Tennis
description: About a year ago, after the announcement of the formation of World Team Tennis, the New York Sets engaged McCannErickson to study its marketing and advertising possibilities.

title: ETHIOPIA STUDIES NEW CONSTITUTION
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 11 (Reuters)Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia would lose all the autocratic power he has held for nearly 45 years over the Government and armed forces under a new draft constitution now being studied here, according to reliable sources.

title: MRS. GRASSO RENEWS OPPOSITION TO TAX
description: The Democratic gubernatorial candidate in Connecticut, Ella T. Grasso, renewed her stand against a state income tax. yesterday while her Republican challenger, Representative Robert H. Steele, questioned how Democrats would finance their proposed fiscal programs.

title: FORD PLANS A PLEA FOR NATION'S UNITY IN SPEECH TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11For his first time as President of the United States, Gerald R. Ford went to church today, and then spent the rest of his Sabbath discussing a new Vice President and working on the speech he is to make tomorrow night to Congress.

title: Scruggs, Bromberg and Daniels Try Little New at Park Concert
description: Country music came again to New York on Saturday, although on occasions, countrymusic purists may have found it hard to recognize at the Schaefer Music Festival Concert in Central Park.

title: Paris: Minister of Arts and Surprises
description: PARIS, Aug, 11  Michel Guy has been Ministeror rather, Secretary of Stateof Cultural Affairs little more than a month, yet there has been more activity on the Rue de Valois than during the whole Arts time that his predAbroad ecessor, Maurice Druon, was in charge. Merce Cunningham, and Peter Brook have received longterm appointments in Paris. National theater directors have been shifted about like prefects and ambassadors. The chief loser in the sudden shuffle appears to have been Jack Lang, director of the Theatre Nationale Populaire, who was sent back to Nancy, whose festival he had created and who understandably resigned, thereby becoming a martyr in the eyes of the left.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Mozambique's Mood: Anmety Amid Elation
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Aug. 11  At a sidewalk care in Beira, African waiters crowd excitedly around a white customer who is reading an Englishlanguage newspaper.

title: About New York The Punishing Game of Tennis
description: This, more than any other year, is the time of the tennis elbow  and of the sprained wrist, the blistered thumb, the mysterious backache, the ballooning calf, the wrenched knee, the snapped ankle, the toe rubbed raw. Tennis is booming, and even if Billie Jean King isn't hungry enough to really care any more, what she and Bobby Riggs wrought that night in Houston hasn't peaked yet in New York.

title: End to Paralysis
description: Now the true tests begin. Tonight President Gerald Ford will make his first appearance before a joint session Of Congress; this audience will greet him with an affection that few Presidents have been able to claim, with an outpouring of relief that he is now the man occupying the White Houseand with curiosity about the directions in which this unlikely President intends to lead the nation.

title: Turkish Bus Crash Kills 21
description: ANKARA, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Twentyone persons died and 41 were injured when two buses collided on the AnkaraIstanbul highway near Bolu early today.

title: Soviet Musician Reported Seeking Australian Asylum
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 11 (AP)  An 18yearold Soviet musician sought political asyhim today in Australia, the police reported.

title: Resignation Was Favored
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 11 11(UPI)A public opinion poll, commissioned by a Portland newspaper last week and printed today, showed that 56.5 per cent of the 216 Maine residents questioned on Thursday and Friday favored resignation for former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Delays in Handling Felony Cases Persist Here 4 Years After Riot
description: Four years after inmates in overcrowded city jails rioted to protest the absence of speedy disposition of charges lodged against them, delay in processing serious cases involving such crimes as homicide, rape and robbery continues to characterize the city's criminal justice system.

title: A G.O.P. Maverick Taking on Ribicoff
description: COLCHESTER, Conn.Longshot bets are a Republican specialty in this heavily Democratic state, so no one thought it very unusual when the party nominated James H. Brannen 3d last month to run against Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, the mightiest Democratic votegetter in the state.

title: Killebrew Thanks Fans With Bat as Twins Win
description: The Baltimore Orioles presented Harmon Killebrew with a check for $150 yesterday, lined up outside their dugout and tipped their hats to the Minnesota Twins' slugger. It was their way of helping to celebrate Killebrew Day in Bloomington, Minn.

title: HEALTH COST LAW PREDICTED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long, Representative Wilbur D. Mills and Representative Martha W. Griffiths said today that Congress would pass a national health insurance bill this year.

title: Bridge:Tornay's Team Sets Pace In Greater New York Play
description: A New York foursome held a substantial lead going into the second day's play of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship yesterday. Playing at the Deborah Building, Flushing, Queens, Claire and George Tornay, Bob Taylor and Gene Prosnitz headed a field of 34 teams with a score of 96 victory points.

title: Five Are Killed by Guerrilla Attacks in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 (Reuters)At least five people were killed when leftwing guerrillas staged synchronized attacks on army and police posts in central Argentina today, military sources reported.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Cyprus Discussed in Talks Between Kissinger and Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11(Reuters)President Ford had a halfhour meeting, with Secretary of State Kissinger today to review foreign policy issues, with special attention to the Cyprus problem, the White House said.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN RAPESLAYING
description: A 27yearold unemployed cook was arrested by Brooklyn detectives yesterday and charged with the rapeslaying of a 29yearold computer operator early Saturday in an alley near her apartment in Sheepshead Bay.

title: CoolingOff Period Angers Gillman
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 11 (AP)Coach Sid Gillman of the Houston Oilers labeled as ridiculous today the call for striking National Football League players to report to camp for a 14day coolingoff period.

title: Greenwich Nuptials For Debra Edelson
description: Debra Edelson, who has been studying law at Georgetown University, and Jeffrey S. Goldstein, a Georgetown law graduate, were married yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Arnold Sher performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Israel to Call Up Reserves For Day to Test Readiness
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 (UPI) Israel announced today plans to conduct a oneday, nationwide callup of military reservists to test procedures in the event of renewed war with the Arabs.

title: Learning From Error
description: Toward what ultimate point is society tending by its industrial progress? When the progress ceases, in what condition are we to expect that it will leave mankind?

title: Players Halt Strike 14 Days; Report to Camps Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)  National Football League regulars decided today to suspend their strike for 14 days, effective Wednesday, in an effort to resolve their labor dispute with the 26 club owners.

title: Luckenbach Death Held Natural But Some Suspicion Remains
description: The police said yesterday that Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., the New. York shipping magnate whose body was found in an East Side apartment Friday, had died of natural causes, but that a chemical analysis of the body would be made by the Medical Examiner.

title: WILLIAM P. DOHERTY
description: William P. Doherty, general traffic manager downstate for New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 17 Palmer Avenue, West Long Branch, N. J. His age was 52.

title: Bujones Excels in Balanchine Theme and Variations
description: It was a weekend for male dancers at Lincoln Center. At the Metropolitan Opera House, the National Ballet of Canada rounded off its seasons with roses galore and Rudolf Nureyev and Erik Bruhn starring in La Sylphide. To see the two greatest male dancers of our generation on stage together (even though the nowretired Mr. Bruhn was performing a mime role) was justifiably pretty heady stuff for the bouquet throwers.

title: Bobick Wins Again
description: FAIRMONT, W. Va., Aug. 11 (AP)Undefeated Duane Bobick scored a secondround technical knockout over Harold Carter of Cleveland last night in a heavyweight fight.

title: Koosman And Mets Bow, 104
description: Cincinnati's Big Red Machine clanked and rumbled in sunny Shea Stadium yesterday, flattening the New York Mets, 104, with blunt efficiency.

title: Suspended Police Officer Is Stabbed in Tenement
description: A suspended police officer awaiting departmental trial was stabbed in the stomach last night minutes after he and two other men entered a tenement at 601 East 11th Street at Avenue B on the Lower East Side, the police reported.

title: Morality? (Sigh)
description: PARISWhen he came to Paris last April to attend the memorial service at Notre Dame Cathedral for Georges Pompidou, Richard. M. Nixon succeeded in rousing some cheering crowds in the streets. He triumphantly concluded from that that the French people were for him. If he honestly believed that, he was the only one who did.

title: Spain Decides to Allow Bullfighting by Women
description: MADRID, Aug. 11 (UPI)Government officials said today that a decree would be published in tomorrow's official state bulletin opening Spain's arenas to women bullfighters.

title: Big Board Discloses 10% of Its Activity Originates Abroad
description: In the first of what will become periodic reports on foreign activity in stock markets here, the New York Stock Exchange released data over the weekend showing that foreign investment represents close to 10 per cent of volume.

title: GREEK CYPRIOTES BEGIN A PULLOUT
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug 11Greek Cypriote National Guard contingents began withdrawing today from occupied Turkish Cypriote enclaves, beginning in the Limassol area, according to United Nations sources.

title: Drought to Further Shrivel Consumer's Dollar
description: Severe drought conditions that have ravaged grain crops and some livestock In the Middle West this summer have already produced billions of dollars in losses to farmers in 16 states, despite weekend rains, and now consumers are bracing for their share of the trouble at the retail counter.

title: Arabs on Brazil Mission
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug, 11 (Reuters)A delegation of hankers and businessmen from Lebanon, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Jordan, Morocco and Libya arrived here today to tart a twoweek visit to examine the possibilities of increasing trade with Brazil.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Aug. 11You used to be able to tramp across Princeton University's weedchoked Lake Carnegie with snowshoes, area residents say, but now after a $1million dredging operation and some hard work by local rowing enthusiasts the 3.5milelong body of water is becoming one of the major centers of rowing competition the United States.

title: MEDICALCARE GAP CUT BY STUDENTS
description: TRUCHAS, N. M., Aug. 11Last winter, when a blizzard isolated this village high in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains of northern New Mexico, an 85yearold man was stricken with a severe case of pneumonia. The nearest doctor, 20 miles away, was unable to reach the community for a week because it was inaccessible to traffic from the outside.

title: Delays in Handling Felony Cases Persist Here 4 Years After Riot
description: Four years after inmates in overcrowded city jails rioted to protest the absence of speedy disposition of charges longed against them, delay in processing serious cases involving such crimes as homicide, rape and robbery continues to characterize the city's criminal justice system.

title: RICHARD N. ANDERSON
description: Richard N. Anderson, an executive of the McCannErickson advertising agency in Tokyo, died there last Monday, after a brief illness. His age was 46.

title: Grief and Outrage Mark Rites for Mugging Victim
description: Yesterday mulling on the Lower East Side, unnoticed among the bargain stalls and venders of colored ices, a black hearse slipped down the mean streets to take the body of a man named Arnold Roth to its resting place at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Queens.

title: Polo Results
description: AT BETHPAGE, L. I.

title: A PARTY IN INDIA DISSOLVES ITSELF
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 Fifteen years ago this month, a new political party was founded in Bombay and welcorned as an alternative to the dominant Congress party.

title: EDWARD T. FLYNN
description: Edward T. (Bus) Flynn, national alumni director of Niagara University, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Niagara Falls, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE TIDE AT SUNRISE: A History of the RussoJapanese War, 19041905. By Denis and Peggy Warner. 627 pages. Charter. house. $17.50.

title: Home of Mrs. Nixon As a Girl Firebombed
description: CERRITOS, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP)  The greenshuttered home where Mrs. Richard M. Nixon spent her girlhood was firebombed early today, the police said. The fire in the 4.4acre Patricia Nixon His. torical Park was discovered by a newspaper boy shortly after 6 A.M. a spokesman said.

title: Another Simone Beck Disciple Is Ready to Pass on the Word
description: The name Simone Beck is the equivalent, in France of Julia Child in America, and the two are longtime collaborators since before the days when they coauthored the two volumes that comprise Mastering the Art of French Cooking.

title: Ford Seeks to Curb U.S. Budget Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Ford's economic policy will concentrate on the long struggle to curb the growth of Federal Government spending. As it happens, thanks to events before he took office, he appears to face only one immediate economic problem  agriculture.

title: MADDOX TURNS ASIDE KLAN ENDORSEMENT
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (UPI)Lieut. Gov. Lester Maddox, frontrunner in Tuesday's Georgia gubernatorial primary, said today that he suspected dirty tricks were behind an apparent endorsement of his candidacy by the Ku Klux Klan.

title: GOLDIN DECLINES TO DISCUSS AUDIT
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday he would no longer comment on the substance of his allegation that the city's Investigation Commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, had instructed a civil servant to make belated entries in the Controller's ledgers.

title: FullTime Manager Named To Improve Central Park
description: In a new experiment, a fulltime manager has been named for Central Park, Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. disclosed yesterday. He estimated that increased supervision could raise park labor productivity 20 to 30 per cent.

title: 8 in Family Killed
description: A leading New Jersey hematologist, Dr. L. Michael Kuhn, was killed Saturday night with his wife and their six children when their plane crashed in an emergency landing attempt at a small Minnesota airport. Pag 53

title: Ford's Worth, Listed Last Fall At $256,000, Hasn't Changed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Gerald R. Ford enters the Presidency with a net financial worth of about a quarter of a million dollars, barely a fourth of the personal wealth his predecessor reported last year.

title: Scott Says Capitol Leaders Oppose Nixon Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Hugh Scott, the Senate minority floor leader, declared today that he had found growing bipartisan opposition in Congress to the possible criminal prosecution of former President Richand M. Nixon for his role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Trevino Captures P.G.A. Title by Stroke With 276 as Nicklaus Takes 2d Place
description: CLEMMONS, N. C., Aug. 11Last night Lee Trevino said he would go for broke, and that's just what he did today. He went for every flag and he shot a 69 and captured the 56th Professional Golfers' Association championship. His total for the 72 holes was 276, four under par.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: N.F.L. Strike Halted
description: The National Football League Players Association agreed, yesterday to suspend its strike for 14 days, effective Wednesday, and asked members to report to training camps then. The strike started July 1. Contract negotiations will resume Thursday, Details, Page 31.

title: Personal Finance: CreditCard Checks
description: People who rely on credit cards often feel frustrated when dealing with someone who does not accept cards.

title: Jets Find a Fifth Pefiod Is Too Much
description: Glen Bonner, a beneficiary of the players strike, has received an education in professional football in the San Diego Chargers camp the last several weeks. Now he knows about sudden death, too.

title: STATE SENDS CARDS TO REGISTER BY MAIL
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12 (AP)The state began distributing today 890,000 postcard voterregistration forms as part of a Byrne administration effort to make it easier to sign up to vote.

title: Floods in Bangladesh Are Reported Subsiding
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 Floods in Bangladesh were reported today to be subsiding.

title: Once More With Feeling: The Stokes Game
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 12Len Elmore was a 15yearold sophomore at Power Memorial Academy in New York when he first heard the name Maurice Stokes.

title: Australian Groups Act To Keep a Soviet Defector
description: PERTH, Australia, Aug. 12 (AP)A young Soviet violinist who changed his mind about defecting was given a second chance today when the Australians acted to prevent his return to Moscow.

title: SIZE OF CORN CROP SHARPLY REDUCED BY LONG DROUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Prolonged drought in the Corn Belt led the Agriculture Department to reduce its forecast of the corn crop drastically today, a development that will almost certainly mean higher meat prices next year.

title: Emergency Fonds Approved in Nassau For Medical Center
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12An emergency resolution authorizing the hiring of 146 additional employes for the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow at an estimated cost of nearly $2million was unanimously passed today by the County Board of Supervisors. In addition, the board ordered the expediting of the hiring of 42 persons already covered in the budget.

title: Business Briefs
description: July Home Costs Soared to Record

title: HYLAN CHESLER
description: Hylan Chesler, owner of the Pine Deck Hotel in Westhampton Beach, L. I., and Chesler's, a restaurant, in Palm Beach, Fla., died yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. John Boland of Westhampton Beach, with whom he had lived in recent years. He was 70 years old.

title: Potash Mine Expanded
description: LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Aug. 12 (UPI)The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has started a $35million expansion of its langbeinite potash mine and refinery at Carlsbad, N. M. Output of potash for the fertilizer and animal feed industries will be nearly doubled.

title: People in Sports
description: Brad Park, a member of the National Hockey League's AllStar team in each of the last five seasons, was named yesterday to captain the New York Rangers, succeeding Vic Hadfield who was traded to the Pittsburgh Penguins in May

title: Plan for the Tombs?
description: The let'swait reaction of Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm to the proposal by the City Board of Correction for renovation of the Tombs, Manhattan's House of Detention for Men, is a dreary repetition of a bureaucratic posture apparently rooted firmly in inertia.

title: Greeks Confer on Turkey; Armored Troops on Move
description: ATHENS, Aug. 12Greece's civilian and military, leaders met for the second day today to discuss continuing tensions with Turkey, their NATO ally and traditional enemy.

title: 550 At A&P.'S HERE ARE HIT BY STRIKE
description: Four locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America struck 550 A. & P. stores in the metropolitan area yesterday, crippling the company's operations.

title: Bridge: Tourney Is Won by a Blend Of Experience and Talent
description: A team blending experience and youthful talent in nice proportions won a convincing victory Sunday in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship played at the Deborah Building, Flushing, Queens.

title: House Votes to End Stiff Safety Rules For 197577 Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)The House voted today to void Government regulations requiring new automobiles to have seat belt interlock systems, buzzers or air bag restraints.

title: SANTANGELO FACES CONTEMPT ACTION
description: The office of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, yesterday moved in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to hold a former Representative in criminal contempt for failing to provide what the prosecution said was crucial evidence during the recent trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo.

title: Israeli Police Take Kahane Off a Plane Bound for U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 (AP)Rabbi Meir Kahane, former leader of the Jewish Defense League, was taken off an airliner bound for New York just forbidden by the police to leave the country.

title: 90DAY OIL SUPPLY CALLED JAPAN'S AIM
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The Government and the oil refining industry are planning to increase Japan's stockpile of oil and oil products to 90 days by 1978 from the present 63 days, official sources said today, at a cost of 1,500billion yen (almost $5billion).

title: Liggett & Myers Unit Closing
description: Liggett & Myers, Inc., announced yesterday that the Cleveland plant of its Allen Products Pet Foods division would close Aug. 31. The comsaid high operating costs and the cost of projected poluon control regulations had forced the decision.

title: Oct. 9 Opener Set for Rangers
description: The New York Rangers will make their earliest National Hockey League start in 14 years when they open against the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 9. During their 49th season in the N.H.L., the Rangers will play 21 home games on Sundays, 16 on Wednesdays, one on a Thursday, one on a Friday and one on a Saturday afternoon.

title: Canadian Pacific Reports Earnings Rose Substantially
description: Canadian Pacific, Ltd., which competes with the larger, Governmentowned Canadian National System railroad, reported yesterday substantially larger net income for the second quarter and first half of this year than in the 1973 Periods.

title: Bluegrass Contest Draws Fans to South St. Pier
description: There has been a good deal of talk of late about New York's clasping of country music to its collective bosom. But the country music in question is the modern Nashville style, slick and electrified.

title: Transit Strike Hits Toronto
description: TORONTO, Aug. 12 (AP)A strike by 5,700 Toronto transit workers today flooded the city's streets with 600,000 regular riders of subways, streetcars and buses. Extra private cars and taxis created huge traffic jams during rush hours.

title: Beech to Settle Lawsuit
description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 12 (AP)Beech Aircraft Corporation said today it would settle a law suit filed in 1971 charging that a defective fuel system in certain Beech models resulted in the deaths of four persons in a 1968 crash. The company said its insurance carriers had agreed to pay $1.8million to the plaintiffs. Beech said the suit consolidated several cases filed after a Beechcraft Baron crashed at Fullerton, Calif. in 1968.

title: Montanez Story: Obscurity to Stardom
description: In April of 1970, the St. Louis Cardinals released to the Philadelphia Phillies a young unknown first baseman named Willie Montanez. The deal was partial payment for the illustrious Curt Flood who refused to report after being traded to the City of Brotherly Love.

title: The Press as Villain of the Piece
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.The American press has destroyed a Presidency of the United States. Although it is too late to help the victims and relieve the enormity of this act, perhaps the press finally will realize the need to reform itself and to return to its basic and historical mission.

title: Mental Hospitals Assailed: On the Overuse of Pills
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12A state organization of social workers today charged that New Jersey's mentalhealth facilities were engaged in a massive misuse or overuse of tranquilizer drugs at the expense of other kinds of therapy.

title: Israeli Five Wins
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 12 (AP)Jack Eisner scored with 10 seconds to go in overtime and gave the Israel national team a 9088 basketball victory yesterday over the University of New Mexico.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York Telephone Company and five unions representing 48,000 telephone employes reached tentative contract agreements. The contracts are local supplements to nationally negotiated wage and benefit agreements tentatively settled on Aug. 4 in Bell Telephone System bargaining in Washington.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: City Hall Lunches: Mostly More of the Same
description: In a city remarkable for the variety of its restaurants and the variegation of their clientele, the three leading establishments down City. Hall way seemed remarkably uniform during a recent series of explorations and their customers looked downright homogenized.

title: Economic Test
description: The start of President Ford's first full week in office has provided three stunning evidences of the gravity of the problem he has inherited on the inflationary front.

title: U.N. Council Approves. GuineaBissau
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 12The 15 members of the Security Council unanimously recommended today that GuineaBissau be admitted to the United Nations even though. Portugal was still holding diseussions on transferring power to the West African territory.

title: Ford's Boyhood Home Taken Off Sales Lists
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.; Aug. 12 (UPI)The house at 649. Union Street here, which President Ford occupied for seven years after his mother came to Grand Rapids and married Gerald. R Ford Sr., came off the sales lists today on orders from the Veterans Administration.

title: House Unit Asks Hiatus In DaylightSaving Time
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (Reuters)A House subcommittee today approved a bill that would return the United States to standard time for four months this winter, modifying the current experiment with yearround daylightsaving time.

title: Humanitas Prize Is Added to Awards for TV Writers
description: There is the Gavel Award from the American Bar Association for programs on justice and the law, the Alfred P. Sloan Award from the Automotive Safety Foundation for program efforts on behalf of highway safety and the Freedoms Foundation Award for programs contributing to patriotism and a better understanding of the American way of life.

title: Survey Finds 74% Felt Nixon Knew of CoverUp
description: In the week before President Nixon left office on Aug. 9, 74 per cent of the American people had comb to believe that he knew of the Watergate coverup while it was going on, the Harris survey reported yesterday. Only 16 per cent thought he did not.

title: Evans Asks Vote by Strikers on Their Return
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 12  Striking regulars of the New York Giants began filtering into an empty training camp tonight as some teammates expressed reservations abodt returniing without a settlement in the Naional Football League labor dispute.

title: City Hall Lunches: Mostly More of the Same
description: In a city remarkable for the variety of its restaurants and the variegation of their clientele, the three leading establishments down City Hall way seemed remarkably uniform during a recent series of explorations and their customers looked downright lidmogenized.

title: 550 As&P.'s Are Affected By Walkout of Butchers
description: Four locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America struck 550 A.&P. stores in the metropolitan area yesterday, crippling the company's operations.

title: 8 Soviet Women Climbers Killed By Storm in Lenin Peak Ascent
Black Envoys Seek More NonAfrican Posts
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThere is a growing fear among black Americans in United States, Government service abroad that the concentration of their senior members in African assignments could lessen their effectiveness in Africa and around the world.

title: 27 Food Concerns, Cited for Violations Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department has cited 27 more food businesses for failing their second Health Code inspection and has warned that, closing orders could result if the violations persist upon a third and final visit by its inspectors.

title: Seoul Sentences ExPresident And Churchmen as Dissenters
description: SEOUL, South Korea; Aug. 12 A South Korean courtmartial today Sentenced a former President, a Roman Catholic Bishop, two Protestant leaders and respected historian to prison as opponents of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Pamirs: High and Rugged
description: Lenin Peak, the Central Asian summit on which a Soviet women's mountaineering team perished last week, is in some of the most challenging high mountain country of the Soviet Union.

title: Katherine Murray Dies at 80; Appeared in Ziegfeld Follies
description: Katherine Murray Shoninger, past president of the Ziegfeld Club. Inc., whose members appeared in the Ziegfeld Follies, died yesterday at her home at Park Drive North, Rye, N. Y. Her age was 80.

title: Economy of Puerto Rico Suffers 2.6% Net Decrease
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 12 (UPI)Puerto Rico's economy suffered a net decrease of 2.6 per cent in fiscal 197374, the first time the economy of the island showed a downturn since the beginning of Operation Bootstrap almost 20 years ago, the Government planning board reported today.

title: Beame Spurs Registration Effort
description: While a dozen or so politicians in fire helmets squeezed into camera range behind him, Mayor Beame rang a fire gong at the foot of the City Hall steps yesterday to signal support for a voterregistration drive.

title: SIZE OF CORN CROP SHARPLY REDUCED BY LONG DROUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Prolonged drought in the Corn Belt led the Agriculture Department to reduce its forecast of the corn crop drastically today, a development that will almost certainly mean higher meat prices next year.

title: Key Biscayne Accepts The Loss of a Neighbor
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 12Residents of this wealthy resort island are getting used to the idea that they will not have Richard M. Nixon around as a neighbor any more.

title: A Renoir Is Hunted
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Customs. authorities continued their search today for a $150,000 Renoir that vanished last week as it was being brought here from London. The painting, Woman in Flowered Hat, had been sent to Christie's auction rooms in London for sale by its owner, Samuel Masion, a Minneapolis lawyer, but the bidding was unsatisfactory and it was sent on its way back.

title: Beame and Other Mayors To Meet Ford Tomorrow
description: Mayor Beame and 13 other mayors from across the country will meet with President Ford tomorrow to discuss the economic plight of the cities and to press for an antiinflation program that will be equitable to everyone.

title: Some Delegates to U.N. Said to Fail to Pay Bills
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug, 12 (Reuters)The United States Mission castigated some United Nations delegates today for failing to meet their financial responsibilities. It citd a diplomat who left a rented house with damages costing $27,000 to remedy.

title: Mobil Beginning Its Tender Offer for Marcor Stock
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that had begun its cash tender offer for Marcor, Inc., common shares at $35 a share and Marcor preferred shares at $70 share. The offer, the company said, will expire on Aug. 23.

title: Professor Contends Play Is Something to Work At
description: Play, to Brian SuttonSmith, is serious business.

title: NEWS INDEX
Ryan Equals Record By Fanning 19 in Game
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI)Nolan Ryan, who came within two outs of a nohitter in his last start, equaled the major league single  game strikeout mark by fanning 19 tonight while pitching the California Angels to a 42 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Ford Causes Speculation He'll Seek Reelection
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)President Ford started a flurry of election speculation tonight when he said he would return to Congress at least three more times to deliver a State of the Union message.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Ticket refunds will be accepted for the GiantsJets exhibition game Saturday afternoon at Yale Bowl in New Haven, game officials announced yesterday, despite the 14day cooling off period in the National Football League players strike. In order to qualify for a refund, tickets must be returned in person or by mail to Yale University by the close of business on Friday. Refund requests may be sent to Yale Athletic Association, Box 402A, Yale Station, New Haven, Connecticut 06520. About 40,000 tickets already have been sold for the game.

title: Jury Said to Accuse Evers
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 12 (UPI)The New Orleans Times Picayune reported today that Federal grand jury had named a civil rights leader, Charles Evers, in a Federal income tax evasion indictment. Mr. Evers, 52 years old, confirmed last week, that Internal Revenue Service agents had been investigating, but he denied any wrongdoing.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: A. Lawyer in Brazil Urges Abrogation Of Curb on Rights
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12A demand for the abrogation of special legislation granting extraordinary powers to the executive under the military Government Vies made today at a national conference of the Brazilian Bar Association.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Ticket refunds will be accepted for the GiantsJets exhibition game Saturday afternoon at Yale Bowl in New Haven, game officials announced yesterday, despite the 14day cooling off period in the National Football League players strike. In order to qualify for a refund, tickets must be returned in person or by mail to Yale University by the close of business on Friday, Refund requests may be sent to Yale Athletic Association, Box 402A, Yale Station, New Haven, Conpecticut 06520, About 40,000 tickets already have, been sold for the game.

title: 11 OTHER DEMOCRATS VYING WITH MADDOX
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP)Lieut. Gov. Lester Maddox is seeking a second term as Governor tomorrow on the most crowded gubernatorial ballot in Georgia's history.

title: MIAMI AMTRAK TRAIN DERAILS IN CAROLINA
description: WAKE FOREST, N. C., Aug, 12 (UPI) An Amtrak train on a run from New York to Miami with 270 passengers derailed near here tonight, injuring eight) or 10 persons, officials said.

title: Reorganization Bid Cleared
description: After two years, the Sheffield Watch Company's plan of reorganization under Chapter XI, of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was approved here yesterday by Federal District Court Judge Edward J. Ryan.

title: Protesters Picket Opening Of Bolshoi Tour in Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)About 50 protesters picketed the opening of the Russian Bolshoi Ballet as it began a tour of the United States tonight.

title: Frozen Fish Prices Are DownBut Not Yet a Bargain
description: Prices for frozen fish in some markets have dropped significantly, from the high levels they reached in 1973, but not enough to gain wide consumer acceptance or make even a small dent in wholesalers' bulging inventories.

title: Meredith Candidacy Rejected
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 12 (AP)The State Election Commission has ruled for the second time that James Meredith, the civil rights figure, cannot be listed on the ballot as an independent candidate for Congress this fall. Mr. Meredith, the black man who integrated the University of Mississippi in 1962, said he would take the matter to court.

title: Ford's Speech: Same Priorities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12It was not an inaugural address. It was not a State of the Union Message. It came nearer than anything else to being just a little straight talk among friends, which was how President Ford described the remarks he made after being sworn in last Friday. The friends to whom he addressed his remarks this evening were friends indeed, the assembled members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives; a body in which Mr. Ford served for 25 years and where he says he, did not have a single enemy.

title: Stage: It's Revival Time
description: Reaching back to the 16th century for Gamma Gurton's Needle, one of the oldest farcecomedies in English, the American Theater Lab, scores a delightful bullseye at its ThursdaythroughSaturday showcase, 219 West 19th Street (6916210).

title: Dow Chemical in Iran Deal
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 12 (AP)A letter of intent was signed today between Iran's National Petrochemical Company and Dow Chemical Company for the establishment in the south of Iran of a $500million petrochemical complex, the Governmentowned Pars News Agency announced. No other details were disclosed.

title: Midwest Rain Dampens Corn and Soybean Prices
description: Heavy rains over the major growing areas of the Middle West dampened futures traders' enthusiasm for corn and soybean contracts yesterday. In a wave of selling, prices for corn and soybean futures contracts dropped their daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: FORD IN WARNING ON U.S DEFENSES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 President Ford warned other countries tonight against trying to exploit the change in administration, asserting that the United States would stand by its commitments and would not weaken its defenses.

title: Mansfield Sees Balance For Congress and Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)  Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today that Congress would try to restore the consitutional balance between the legislative and executive branches during President Ford's term.

title: No Spur in Forest Park
description: No one who has ever tried to get to Kennedy Airport in a typical traffic jam can doubt the need for a fast rail link from Manhattan. That commonsense project should long since have been in operation. It could be started at once, largely with Federal money, if the Metropolitan Transit Authority and the Port Authority would stop complicating the plan with a. highly controversial spur that has nothing to do with New YorktoKennedy travel.

title: Where City Hall Crowd Eats Lunch
description: The other day, Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh emerged from City Hall, looked about guardedly and, spotting no one who appeared ready to advance with pleas for jobs, or contracts or whatever, walked swiftly across Broadway to the Woolworth Building.

title: Seoul Sentences ExPresident And Churchmen as Dissenters
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 12 A South Korean courtmartial today sentenced a former President, a Roman Catholic Bishop, two Protestant leaders and a respected historian to prison as opponents of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Mrs. Ford's Tour Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug., 12 (AP)Mrs. Gerald R. Ford postponed a tour of the White House today because she was having such a busy day, including an appearance at the joint session of Congress with President Ford. She will tour the 132room mansion tomorrow.

title: Wood, Meld & Stream Helping the Salmon Survive
description: There is no more exciting and valuable family of fishes than the salmons, and none, perhaps, that so often brings the angler in such close contact with wild, magnificent surroundings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An emergency resolution authorizing the hiring of 146 additional employes for the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I., was passed by the County Board of Supervisors. In addition, the board ordered the expediting of the hiring of 42 persons already alloted for in the budget After receiving complaints of the shortage of nurses at the center, County Executive Ralph G. Caso paid an unannounced. visit to the center Aug. 1 and immediately asked for a complete review of its needs.

title: 24 ISLAMIC NATIONS SIGN BANK CHARTER
description: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 12 (Reuters)Twenty  four Arab and Islamic nation ssigned a charter here today fixing their contributions to a projected Islamic bank at a capital equivalent of $900million.

title: Decrease in Gambling Is Reported by Nevada
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 12 (AP)  People were less willing to gamble in the last fiscal year, but they still risked enough, to provide Nevada's casinos with a record $936.3million, the state Gaming Commission said today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Beame Asks Wilson to Reverse Limit On Bellevue Psychiatric Center Beds
description: Mayor Beame has asked Governor Wilson, by telephone and by letter, to reverse the State Department of Mental Hygiene in a bitter controversy between the state agency and the city's top mentalhealth officials over the facilities at the new Bellevue psychiatric center.

title: General Motors Replies
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12 (UPI)Che General Motors Corpora ion said today that its tests lid not support the claim of he Environmental Protection Agency that 500 million 1972nodel cars must be recalled to correct their emissioncontrol systems. General Motors was he first auto maker to answer he Federal agency, which, in ate June, said that it might rrder General Motors, Ford, Chrysler and Volkswagen to reall as many as 1.4 million cars.

title: Rockefeller Remains at Center of Speculation on Ford's Choice for Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The talk of Nelson A. Rockefeller for Vice President has proved a durable trial balloon. Nearly a week after the speculation began in earnest, the former New York Governor is still the man near the top of every listlists of names that President Ford is considering, and lists of favorites that party leaders are submitting to the White House.

title: ExHumphrey Aide Guilty in Milk Case
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 12The former press secretary to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, pleaded guilty today to charges of aiding and abetting illegal corporate donations to political campaigns by milk producers.

title: Mine Union Calls a National Shutdown Of 5 Days in Battle for a New Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 The United Mine Workers today called for a fiveday memorial period shutdown of the nation's coal mines for next week, exercising a clause in expiring contract with the coal operators to put pressure on them for a new agreement.

title: Aaron Pays Early Visit To Hall
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 12Henry Aaron, who will not be eligible for baseball's Hall of a Fame for six years, led off the batting order for the Atlanta Braves in the annual exhibition game here today before a record crowd of nearly 10,000 persons  three times the size of this upstate village.

title: LINES ON BALLOT ARE RULED OUT FOR 6
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12The State Board, of Elections ruled today that two State Senators and four Assemblymen, all Republicans seeking reelection this year, were not qualified to run also on the Conservative party line.

title: Manila Mayor Charges Aides
description: MANILA, Aug. 12 (UPI)The deputy mayor of Manila and 15 other city officials were accused today of unlawfully appropriating public funds. Manila's Mayor, Ramon Bagatsing, filed the charges. The charges stemmed from appropriations for pay increases for city officials approved by the Manila municipal board. Mayor Bagatsing vetoed the proposal.

title: Big Sugar Users Study Substitutes
description: The surge in sugar prices, which have tripled in eight months, has forced major industrial users to raise the prices of their products and give serious thought to alternatives.

title: 2 HOSPITALS SUED IN DEATH OF BABY
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 12 (AP)A $150,000 suit against two local hospitals and four of their employes contends that inadequate training to deal with the Spanishspeaking community led to the death of an 8monthold baby last year.

title: Connecticut General Earnings Drop
SCOTTISH VILLAGE CLOSED TO OILMEN
description: LONDON, Aug. 12The British Government today turned down a proposal to build North Sea oil platforms at the plcturesque village of Drumbuie on the rugged northwest coast of Scotland.

title: Issues in Taxi Dispute
