description: HONOLULU, Aug. 14The American Bar Association, highly sensitive over the involvement of lawyers in the Watergate scandals, is getting some sharply contrasting views of what should be done to repair the profession and the Government.

title: Stanfield to Quit as Canadian Party Head
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 14Robert L. Stanfield, leader of the parliamentary opposition, announced today that he intended to resign as head of the Progressive Conservative party and would not run in the next federal election.

title: Red Cross Cites Accord On Cyprus Safety Zones
description: GENEVA, Aug. 14The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that the opposing sides in the Cyprus conflict had agreed to make the Hilton and Cleopatra Hotels and the Kibis clinic in Nicosia safety zones for civillans.

title: Sloppy Strangers in Cameroon
description: CLEVELANDPeter Akpa, a 16yearold Ibo tribesman, stood in the motor park of Mamfe, a small, isolated town in the vast Manyu rain forest of Cameroon in West Africa. He was watching two grubby, hippylooking Americans,, with knapsacks and sleeping bags, board a crowded bus.

title: Black Samson' From Film Netherworld:The Cast
description: Out of the netherworld of cinema make-believe, where lone urban heroes, kung-fu experts and other assorted cool types have been defying credibility in recent years, has emerged a motion picture called "Black Samson." The film opened yesterday at the Forum and Roosevelt Theaters.Its hero, as the title indicates, is a black man named Samson, a towering barkeep who carries an even taller staff and employs it and his fists to belabor anyonebut particularly Mafia typeswho would sully his street and his people, especially with narcotics."Black Samson" is a cinematic masquerade. In the guise of presenting a story of courage against odds, it is, in truth, an ugly and brutal film, reveling in cruelty and the bloody abuse of women.The most admirable character in it is an old gangland boss who counsels wisdom and gentleness; but there is no reason to believe that the people who made "Black Samson" would recognize a real hero if they saw one.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Dog Fighting: Illegal, Brutal, Growing
description: CHICAGO  Pat Podzianowski is a construction worker by trade, a burly, ponderous man about 40 years old, with a great stomach. His bare tipper body, across the chest and back and over the arms, is covered with tattoos.

title: Iran Loan Offered Grumman for F14
description: Iran has offered to lend money to the Grumman Corporation to enable it to continue production of the controversial F14 fighter plane, Representative Otis G. Pike of Long Island disclosed yesterday. Iran has 80 F14's on order.

title: Crash Kills 47 on Venezuelan Plane
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 14 (Reuters)  A Venezuelan airliner crashed today into a hill on the Caribbean island of Margarita during a torrential rain storm, killing 47 of the 48 people on board.

title: Intended Victim Slays Boy, 14, In Attempted Brooklyn Holdup
description: A 14yearold robber was shot by one of his intended victims during a holdup attempt in Brooklyn Tuesday night, the police said, and died with an unloaded pistol in his hand.

title: WILLIAM KELLER, RAIL ENGINEER, 72
description: William McKinley Keller, retired, president of the Association of American Railroads, died Sunday at Lankenau Hospital in Overbrook, Pa. He was 72 years old and lived in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Choice of Vice President Faces a Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Fighting in Cyprus took President Ford's attention away from the vacant, VicePresidency today and might delay his choice of a successor in that job, according to the White House.

title: OILDOLLAR FLOW INTO U.S. EXPECTED
description: The first strong signal that substantial amounts of Mideast oil dollars will be flowing into the Treasury's, new special securities was received by the money market here yesterday.

title: U.S. MOVE TO CURB SPENDING IMPERILS AID FOR FARE HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 New York City's hope of saving the 35cent transit fare was doubly jolted today as Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar urged Congress to make localities assume greater responsibility for financing transit operations and Repub. lican Congressmen fought to cut a $20billion rhasstransit bill in half.

title: MRS. CHARLES RIVOIRE
description: Helen Murphy Rivoire, the wife of Charles W. Rivoire, trustee of the W. T. Grant Foundation, died Monday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 73 Steers old and, lived at Great Island, Noroton, Conn.

title: Yankees Halt A's, 41, on 3Run Ninth
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 14Key lateinning doubles by Graig Nettles and Elliott Maddox, and more spectacular pitching by Rudy May, gave the New York Yankees a 41 victory Over the Oakland Athletics tonight and allowed them to fly eastward with a satisfactory 33 wonlost record for their final California trip of the season.

title: Texts of Statements and Letters in Audit Dispute
description: Following are the texts of statements by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, and Mayor Beanie about an investigation of the role of Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scqppetta in a dispute involving a discrepancy of $5.4million in securities in a city vault. These are followed by the texts of a letter from Mr. Scoppetta to Controller Harrison J. Goldin and one from Mr. Goldin to Mr. Scoppetta.

title: Transit and Inflation
description: Welcome as is President Ford's generalized endorsement of Federal subsidies to cities for masstransit operating and construction costs, it would be more reassuring if he had not also made plain his coolness to the $20billion, sixyear program now being debated in the House.

title: Tropical Storm Hits Trinidad and Venezuela
description: MIAMI, Aug. 12 (UN) Alma, the first tropical storm of the season, crossed the Island of Trinidad today and then crossed the Gulf of Paria and struck the peninsula do the northwest coast of Venezuela.

title: Home Starts in State Drop $2.3Billion In a Troubled Economy, Report Shows
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Aug. 14 A combination of softening demand, tight mortgage money and environmental restrictions has cut residential construction in the state by $2.3billion, the New Jersey Home Builders Association said today.

title: Gold Sale Legalized
description: President Ford signed a bill yesterday that will allow United States citizens to buy and sell gold after Dec. 31 for the first time in 40 years. Details on Page 45.

title: Ashe Leads Advance in Ohio Tennis
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP)  Led by Arthur Ashe, the No. 1 seeded player, all the favored players easily scored openinground singles victories today in the $50,000 Buckeye tennis championships.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Election Law Enforcement Commission is investigating a $20,000 loan the State Republican Finance Committee obtained from an Essex County bank during the unsuccessful 1973 gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. David Norcross, executive director of the commission, said in Trenton that the agency was looking into a loan to the committee by the Livingston National Bank on Nov. 1, 1973, only days before the Democratic candidate, Brendan T. Byrne, defeated Mr. Sandman by some 700,000 votes to win the governorship. The loan was not reported to the commission until last April 26, almost six months after the required reporting date, according to Mr. Norcross.

title: Chess: Where Have All the Players Gone? Not to the U.S. Open
description: The 75th annual United States Open Chess Championship got under way at the Statler Hilton Hotel Suriday night with a field of 542 far short of the predicted 1,200.

title: Rail Aide Gets Transit Job
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP)David L. Gunn, former assistant to the president of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, has been namd director of rail commuter programs for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The authority's directors made the appointment today to the job, which pays $37,000 a year.

title: The Ailey Steps Up to Lincoln Center
description: Alvin Ailey, looking justifiably like a proud poppa, beamed effulgently from the stage of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center on Tuesday night. He was standing alongside his company, accepting the standing ovation that was greeting the troupe's first foray into Lincoln Center.

title: One day recently we were thinking out loud about our last visit to Haiti. We hungered, we said, for that Haitian rice dish made with small dried mushrooms. Almost reflectively, someone said, Haitian? The best Haitian cook in all of America lives in Manhattan. She's Josephine Premice Pales and we think she's in town.
description: We have stated before that we can remember in elaborate detail the taste and texture of a dish we dined on years ago, whereas we have faint recall of the surroundings in which we gourmandized.

title: Music and Dogs Prove a Happy Blend
description: Music and dogs have Played a leading role in the lives of Bob and Joy Messinger. We met in the entertainment world, said Bob. I had a talent agency for jazz, blues and folk singers. In the late sixties, for four years, I was stage manager for the Newport Festival. Joy was in music publishing. She helped to compile The Book of the Blues, The couple married and later decided they wanted a dog. We went to Westminster, said Bob, and I steered Joy over to the Northern breeds. You see, in World War II, I had been stationed in Labrador. Our chief of transportation was dog sled. I drove a team of 10 dogs.

title: RULING ON VETOES WON BY KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, won a court ruling today in battle over a bill that he said former President Nixon had illegally attemped to pocketveto.

title: Ford Criticizes Cuts in Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The first faint strain in what President Ford had hoped would be a good marriage with Congress appeared today when he criticized extensive cuts that two Senate committees made yesterday in defense and foreign aid bills.

title: BIG CLASH ON COAST REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Heavy fighting has erupted around Hoai Nhon, in the central coastal area near Route 1, a vital northsouth supply line, the Saigon command said today.

title: SEOUL PRESIDENT ESCAPES ASSASSIN
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Aug. 15An unknown assailant tried to assassinate President Park Chung Hee of South Korea this morning as he delivered a national day address. The President was not hurt.

title: A REMARK BY BUTZ STIRS GRAND RAPIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) A casual remark by. Earl L. Butz about President Ford's home town has produced angry reactions from Grand Rapids, Mich including a reported demand that Mr. Butz be dismissed as Secretary of Agriculture.

title: STATE IS UNYIELDING ON PRISON FACILITY
description: FISHKILL, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP)Despite the protests of suburban homeowners here, construction of a $30million downstate reception center for criminals will begin this fall near, Mattawan State Hospital, Governor. Wilson announced yesterday

title: ATHENS PROTESTS
description: ATHENS, Aug. 14  Greece withdrew her armed forces from the North Atlantic Treaty Organilation today, blaming her allies for not having prevented Turkey's new military advances in Cyprus.

title: Lynn Haney Bride Of Peter Burchard
description: Lynn Marie Haney and Peter Duncan Burchard, both writers, were married at noon yesterday in the United Church of Christ of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Sherwood Lowry performed the ceremony.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO FALL
description: Stocks continued to fall yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, closing sharply lower in light trading, as Wall Street turned nervous reports of renewed fighting in Cyprus and as the pall of inflation and high interest rates continued unabated.

title: A Compromise Preserves City's Sanctuary in the Bronx
description: Ever so discreetly, a struggle is coming to an end over the fate of 28 of the city's most placid acres, where no sound louder than a Hudson River foghorn disturbs pheasants nesting beneath hemlocks.

title: 36 Koreans Are Sentenced Amid Urgings of Leniency
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 14The South Korean Government continued to suppress President Park Chung Hee's political adversaries today as pressures to ease the campaign mounted at home and abroad.

title: The RA Expeditions of Thor Heyerdahl
description: Some of us are allergic to almost any kind of boat life: the equipment or the weather nearly always goes awry, and persons who are pleasant ashore can become raging authoritarians at sea. But you don't have to love boats in order to relish The RA Expeditions, a fascinating documentary record of the two long ocean voyages made by anthropologist Thor Heyerdahl in a small papyrus boat. The film opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: Two Missing Girls Found Dead In Montvale, Victims of Assault
description: PARAMUS, Aug. 14The nude bodies of two teenage girls, missing from their North Bergen homes since last Friday, were found this morning in a small wooded area of Montvale. Both girls had been sexually assaulted and apparently strangled approximately 36 to 40 hours before being found, the police said.

title: NADJARI'S INQUIRY CLEARS SCOPPETTA
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state, prosecutor, said yes. terday that no improper of criminal act had been corn. mitted by the city's Investiga. tion. Commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, in the controversy over two belated entries in the ledgers of the City Controller.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES SETS PROFIT RECORD
description: American Airlines had its best July ever last month, with a profit of $10.1million, or 35 cents a share, helping the carrier to report a sevenmonth profit of $12.7million, or 45 cents a share. In July of last year, American had a net income of $1.8million, or 6 cents a share, but for the first seven months of 1973 it reported a loss of $33.2million.

title: Transfer Option, Spurned For Inmates at The Tombs
description: A Federal appeals court proposed yesterday that the city grant the requests of inmates who want to be transferred from the Manhattan House of ??etention for Men to improved facilities on Rikers Island.

title: Antiabortion Curb Backed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP)The Massachusetts Executive Council voted unanimously today to support an antiabortion amendment to the United States Constitution, proposed by Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York. The council is a body that advises the Governor.

title: EDWARD WESTBURGH, PSYCHOLOGIST DEAD
description: Dr. Edward M. Westbutgh, a clinical psychologist and management consultant, died Friday in Holderness, N. H. He was 75 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Stocks Down for a Fifth Day, With Dow at Lowest Since '70
description: Stock prices dropped for the fifth day in a row yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest point in nearly four years.

title: Mets Defeat Dodgers in Ninth, 32, to Sweep Series
Film: 'Castaway Cowboy':Small Fry and Parents Enjoy Disney Tale
description: Thank heaven for a new Disney live-action movie that won't, for a change, make parents wince. Such is "The Castaway Cowboy," a cheerfully agreeable and picturesque little Western, set in, of all places, Hawaii. This is a homey, comfortably amusing and nicely colorful package about a Texas castaway who helps a pretty widow and her small son pioneer a Pacific isle cattle ranch. Yesterday the childrenflanked by smiling parentstook to it like popcorn, at the midtown Festival Theater, one of the metropolitan showcases double-billing the new picture with a vintage Disney feature. The film's rudder is James Garner, whose leathery, laconic expertise (minus that pat blandness) winningly sets the tone and flavor. Vera Miles and young Eric Shea are appealing, likewise a gallery of grinning, native islanders who play Mr. Garner's "pineapple cowboys." Robert Culp is the smooth villain of the uncomplicated little plot, steadily unwinding under Vincent McEveety's direction.The picture has genuine charm and sturdiness in the scenes of the natives becoming cowboys, learning to lasso and punch wild steers. For stand-bys, there are several crunching fights and a good old cattle stampede. The Hawaiian locale (the island of Lauai) makes an exotic, often luscious backdrop. It's hard to resist the sight of Tex Garner, Master Shea and those happy island buckaroos singing "Come-a-Ki-Yi-Yippy" as they hit the Hawaii trail.

title: MODERATION URGED ON RENT RISES HERE
description: The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy urged yesterday that little or no rent increases be permitted when leases are signed in a major category of apartments covered by the state's new rentstabilization law.

title: The Stakes and Objectives for Five Nations in Cyprus Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14What are the stakes in Cyprus for the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, Greece and Turkey? What is each seeking? A nationbynation breakdown follows.

title: VOLKSWAGEN LOSS WIDER IN QUARTER
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Volkswagenwerk, A.G., reported today in a letter to stockholders that its group loss in the first quarter, reported in May to be about $34million, increased in the second quarter. No figures were given.

title: $112 Million in Heroin Found in Furniture Here
description: Federal narcotics officials here said yesterday that they had seized $112million worth of heroin concealed in a shipment of simulated Louis XIII furniture from France.

title: Henry Murphy Jr., 53, Dies; Partner in Building Concern
description: Henry C. Murphy Jr., a partner in the E. W. Howell Company, of Babylon, L.I., and New York, died Tuesday of a heart attack. Mr. Murphy, who lived in Garden City, L. I., was 53 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOUNG ALUM Manuel Alum has been called one of the most inventive young choreographers in American modern dance, and his solo performances in this country and abroad have taken on an aura of excitement. Mr. Alum is a native of Puerto Rico who began his training 15 years ago in Chicago before coming to New York to study. Now he has opened a limited series of evening performances at the Washington Square Curch at 135 West Fourth Street, where he will be doing some of the offbeat dances that have won him so much praise.

title: Advertising: Grand Union's Bid
description: Last December, Cavenham, Ltd., a British food manufacturer and retailer, acquired 51 per cent of the Grand Union Company, the big American supermarket chain. Last April, James Wood, deputy managing director of Cavenham, became president of Grand Union. And last week, Mr. Wood took on the additional title of chief executive officer.

title: Discotheque Is Ordered to Shut For 15 Days and Change Name
description: PARSIPPANY, Aug. 14The ParsippanyTroy Hills Township Council today ordered the huge Jointinthewoods nightclub to close for 15 days for failure to advise the, township of a change of facts following the club's application for a liquor license.

title: Gold Sale Legalized
description: President Ford signed a bill yesterday that will allow United States citizens to buy and sell gold after Dec. 31 for the first time in 40 years. Details on Page 45.

title: Jean Kneppratli, 81, Dies; Headed Bowling Congress
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14 (UPI) Jean Knepprath, who served as president of the Women's International Bowling Congress for 36 years, died yesterday. She was 81 years, old.

title: EVERS SEES FOES BEHIND TAX CASE
description: FAYETTE, Miss., Aug. 14 (UPI)Mayor Charles Evers, contending that enemies whom he did not identify were trying to break him financially and politically, said today that he was innocent of Federal income tax evasion charges.

title: Boy Killed as Bottle With Dry Ice Explodes
description: An 8yearold Coney Island boy was killed and four other boys were injured last night when a soda bottle filled with dry ice exploded in the air, the police said.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Pitfalls for Experienced Anglers
description: If there are two nonproductive traits that the experienced angler exhibits most often, they are stubbornness and the failure to experiment.

title: House of Bishops Disputes Validity Of Ordination of 11 Women as Priests
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15  The House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church decried today the ordination of 11 women deacons in Philadelphia three weeks ago and expressed conviction that the ceremony was not valid.

title: Business Loans Up Only $24Million
description: Business loans at major New York banks rose a modest $24million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve of New York reported yesterday.

As he sits, lasso in his teeth, waiting for the little animal in the chute next to him to break into the center of the ring at Madison Square Garden, he is the very model of the aging Oklahoma rodeo calfroper he might like to have been.

description: ATHENS, Aug. 15Premier Constantine Caramanlis told the Greek people tonight that the country would not go to war in Cyprus to combat Turk; ish invaders.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 15 (UPI)  The Texas Railroad Commission authorized today another month of allout oil production by state regulated wells. The 100 per cent production allowable has been in effect each month since April, 1972.

description: Expressing bewilderment over the report that the New York Stars of the World Football League would be sold within a month, Bob Keating, the general manager of the club said the story was completely erroneous.

title: Cowboy From Brooklyn Pursues Dream of Rodeo Title
description: Roger Mancini sits short in the saddle, his paunch protrading over the brassbuckled belt that holds up his dungarees. As he sits, lasso in his teeth, waiting for the little animal in the chute next to him to break into, the center of the ring at Madison Square Garden, he is the very model of the aging Oklahoma rodeo calfroper he might like to have been.

description: LE HAVRE, France, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  Passengers on the liner France today delayed their landing on arrival here from New York by one hour in protest against the French Government's decision to retire the luxury vessel later this year.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15  Even from a distance they seem to scrape against heaven. Close up, they tower into baffling combinations of ice, rock and snow.

title: Yanks, Mets Face Common Foe: Time
description: With only six weeks left for salvaging the baseball season, the Yankees and Mets crossed paths yesterday as they maneuvered for the next 10 days of the schedule the Yankees flying home from California 6 games out of first place, the Mets heading for Cincinnati 8 games out.

title: New Bar Leader
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 15For most of its 180,000 members, the American Bar Association is a source of valuable contacts and educational aid, a professional fraternity, a political sideline or a provider of taxdeductible summer vacations in places like Waikiki. But for James Davison Fellers of Oklahoma City, it has been very nearly a way of life. When he becomes president of the association here tomorrow, it will be the climax of an undramatic, painstaking climb through the ranks of the nation's largest legal organization that took him nearly 40 years.

title: Events Today
description: PAYMENT AS PLEDGED, a play by Alfredo Dias Gomes. Presented by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater Company. At East 110th Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues, at 7:30.

description: TORONTO, Aug. 15 (AP)  Juan Gisbert of Spain toppled topranked Jimmy Connors, 76, 62, in today's third round of the $130,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

title: . . . Banishing Uncertainty
description: It is vital that these facts be stated clearly to establish the record of this episode; for it is vital that no miasma of uncertainty be left available for the revisionists of tomorrow. The Judiciary Committee report, plus its documentation, permanently explodes the grossly misleading nature of Mr. Nixon's own explanation that he resigned merely because he had lost his political base in Congress.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 15The wife of the President of South Korea, Mrs. Park Chung Hee, died tonight from an assassin's bullet evidently intended for her husband.

Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York and George Bush of Texas, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

In the latest week, the bank's deposits decreased $36million, up from the $30million outflow the week before.

The biggest of the bunch is the annual Eurovision contest, now 19 years old, which annually attracts millions of mesmerized television viewers for its finals.

It would be ideal if debate on such issues could be put off until he has had a chance to settle into his job, but some cannot be deferred, foremost among them the way to bring inflation  domestic public enemy No. 1  under control.

description: Governor Wilson yesterday announced the appointment of the nine members of a new state commission that will in vestigate complaints about the conduct and fitness of judges in the state. Only two of the commission's members are judges.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Prodded by President Ford, three key Senators said today that agreement was near on a compromise on free emigration of Soviet Jews, an issue that has threatened enactment of major trade bill.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)  Ten Republicans who originally voted against all impeachment charges against President Nixon have since agreed that he did commit one impeachable offense, and that history should show he was not hounded from office.

title: A Tape on Bombing Of Airport Scores Immigration Laws
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15A purported terrorist group calling itself Aliens of America has asserted in a taperecorded message that it bombed, the Los Angeles International Airport last week because of immoral and antiAmerican immigration laws.

I., seeded second, 63, 64, to win the Eastern senior tennis tournament at the Seawane Club tonight. The final had been postponed from last weekend. Lyhner and John Dunn of Huntington, L. I., won the doubles final, beating Mel Alpren of Short Hills, N. J., and Ed Kujan of Armonk, 46, 62, 76.

title: City Gets Most U.S. Aid For Manpower Training
description: The city received $75million yesterday from the Federal Gov. ernmentthe largest revenuesharing allocation in the country for manpower training programsbut there was such a conglomeration of demonstrators outside City Hall that the man with the money had trouble getting in.

title: JUDGE CHOATE, 83, OF FLORIDA, DIES
description: MIAMI, Aug. 15 (AP)Retired United States District Judge Emett Clay Choate, who had practiced law here since 1925 and was appointed to the bench in 1954 by President Eisenhower, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 83 years old.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15Satisfied that Chris Evert is in the best of condition, Joe Trovato, who trains the excellent filly for Carl Rosen, said today he would enter her in the Travers on Saturday. The decision came after long consideration in the wake of Chris Evert's defeat by Quaze Quilt in the Alabama, last Saturday's race for fillies.

description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has begun a drive to implement fully a fiveyearold health screening and treatment program that has reached only a fraction of the underprivileged children it was created to serve.

title: Troops Enter Famagusta And Push to Split Island
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Friday, Aug. 16  Turkish forces moved east and west across northern Cyprus yesterday in a continued drive to cut the island in two.

title: F.T.C. Sends Out Form Asking Data On Net by Product
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today it was sending out its controversial businessreporting form, although to fewer companies than originally planned.

title: Notes on People
description: In his address to Congress Monday night, President Ford noted that in my first campaign for presidentof my senior class in South High School in Grand Rapids, he was defeated. The natural question, by whom? The answer: William J. Schuiling, who has lived for the last decade in Washington. The victor, who is now president and chief executive officer of a bank holding company, told an interviewer yesterday that he won that election 44 years ago with a very comfortable margin.

title: BIG BOARD REPORTS A DROP IN EARNINGS
description: Earnings of the New York Stock Exchange have gone the same direction of a majority of its member firmsdown. Yesterday, the exchange reported that it earned only $193,000 in the second quarter this year, down from $2million in the same period last year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Premier Constantine Caramanlis of Greece told his country. that the Government would not go to war over Cyprus. He said that Greece could not land troops on the island because it was too far away, and that Turkey already had an overwhelming military advantage. An invasion, the Premier, said, could not be attempted without the risk of weakening the defense of Greece. [1:8.]

title: Yanks, Mets Face Common Foe: Time

title: Methadone Deaths in '73 Double Those Caused Here by Heroin
description: Methadone poisoning, virtually unknown only a few years ago, killed nearly twice as many people as did heroin in New York City last year, according to a confidential report by Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio, the city's Acting Chief Medical Examiner.

title: FALLING GOLD PRICES LIFT DOLLAR VALUE
description: LONDON, Aug. 15 (UP1)Falling gold prices rifted the value of the dollar today in most European markets. The Bank of England had to intervene to prop up the British pound.

title: Miss Loock Wins A.A.U. Diving Title
description: DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 15 (AP)Christine Loock of Fort Worth edged a teammate, Cynthia Potter of Houston, for the Amateur Athletic Union women's national threemeter outdoor springboard diving championship today.

title: Auto Halt Looms As Strikes Cripple CarParts Makers
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15Auto production will climb 21.6 per cent this week from the week before but supplier strikes could force major shutdowns in the weeks ahead.

title: I. Robert Kriendler of 21 Dies; One of 4 Brothers to Run Club
description: I. Robert Kriendler, president of the 21 Club, where he served as host to many of the nation's notables, died yesterday at his summer home at Westhampton Beach, L. I. He was 60 years old and had undergone openheart surgery in March.

title: HANS H. ZINSSER, UROLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Hans H. Zinsser, associate professor of clinical urology, at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and senior attending surgeon at Presbyterian Hospital, died Wednesday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and, lived at 120 East 80th Street.

title: Security Council Renews Call For a CeaseFire on Cyprus

title: ASSASSIN'S BULLET KILLS MRS. PARK

description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 15While Joe Namath will stay home practicing handOffs, John Jones, who not long ago was a budding service representative with a bicycle company, will start at quarterback for the Jets against the Giants Saturday.

title: Staggers Bids C.A.B. Head Step Aside in Key Cases
description: Representative Harley O. Staggers has urged the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Robert D. Timm, to consider withdrawing from several board cases, charging him with improper conduct in accepting a free Bermuda trip in early July.

title: 35C FARE SUPPORT AND TRANSIT AID SHRINK IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The House of Representatives narrowly upheld the concept of Federal subsidies for masstransit operations today and then voted to require localities to put up $2 for every Federal dollar received for such subsidies.

title: Auto Buyers Are Taking Loans Up to 48 Months to Meet Rising Prices
description: DETROIT, Aug, 15Rising automobile prices are leading more buyers to take extended 42 or 48month loans to keep their monthly payments down.

title: Wheat, Corn, Soybean Prices Fall on GoodWeather Forecast
description: Wheat, soybeans and corn fell sharply in price yesterday under heavy speculative dation of futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade. Continued rain in Iowa growing areas, and a forecast of good, moisture for the next 30 days, influenced the heavy selling.

title: Choosing the No. 2 Man
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Vice Presidents have been chosen for many reasonsJohn Nance Garner by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932 because he could deliver the Presidential nomination, Lyndon B. Johnson by John F. Kennedy in 1960 because he might help to carry the South in the general election; Spiro T. Agnew by Richard M. Nixon in 1968 because he symbolized the new, conservative, ethnic politics.

title: Miss Conley In Semifinal Of U.S.,Golf
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (UPI)The defending champion, Carol Semple; Debbie Massey, Cynthia Hill and Peggy Conley reached the semifinals of the United States women's amateur golf championship today with victories in two rounds of match play.

title: Ford Denounced by Vietcong For Continuing Aid to Saigon
description: PARIS, Aug. 15  The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, in its first public statement since President Ford took office, attacked him today for continuing aid to the Saigon Government.

title: INMATES IN TOMBS WILL GET A CHOICE
description: City officials agreed under court pressure yesterday to transfer some inmates who asked to be moved from the outmoded Manhattan House of Detention for Men to better facilities on Rikers Island.

title: People in Sports
description: John Williamson, whose backcourt play, helped the New York Nets win the American Basketball championship last season, was operated on yesterday for the removal of several large bone chips from the patellar tendon below his right kneecap. Dr. Theodore Himmelstem, an orthopedic surgeon, performed the surgery at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital.

title: Books of The Times
description: Death and ugliness are the constant companions of the men who go underground every day to mine the world's coal. Their lives are spent playing tag with disastera rooffall, an explosion in the bowels of a mountain or just the slow rot of their lungs from coal dust till they turn into black sponge. And the land above them, once all timbercovered hills and valleys of incredible beauty, is now a giant slag heap made drearier still by the ravages of 10storyhigh stripping machines.

title: CARAMMILIS ON TV
description: ATHENS, Aug. 15Premier Constantine Caramanlis told the Greek people tonight that the country would not go to war in Cyprus to combat Turkish invaders.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: MINE BILL PANELISTS EXEMPT ANTHRACITE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) House and Senate negotiators agreed today to exempt anthracite coal, mined primarily in Pennsylvania, from proposed nationwide standards for strip mining.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $995inillion, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $938million. Total retail store sales were about $10.37billion, up 9 per cent from last year's $9.52billion.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NO DOLDRUMS During the summer, when theater in Manhattan puts on the brakes, there are still a few random beehives of activity Off Off Broadway that try to keep up a normal pace. One of the most distinguished is the Manhattan Theater Club (2882500) at 321 East 73d Street. The posters in front and the colored arrows at the entrance indicate that, even now, several things are going on there at once, in a variety of settings and formats.

title: Parry's 6Game Slump Ends as Indians Win 42
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (UPI) Gaylord Perry, with relief help from Tom Buskey, snapped his sixgame losing streak tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Minnesota Twins, 42. Frank Duffy's basesloaded single drove in two runs in the sixth inning to help Perry to his 16th victory against seven defeats.

title: The Battle Against Inflation
description: Our country is now struggling with a very serious problem of inflation. in the past twelve months, the consumer price level has risen by 11 per cent; wholesale prices have risen even faster. When prices rise with such speed, inflation comes to dominate nearly every aspect of economic life.

title: Coal Price Soars as Electric Utilities Strive to Maintain Stockpiles
description: The price of coal has advanced sharply in recent months as the nation's electric utilities, faced with a possible coal strike this fall and increased demand for coal from foreign buyers, have scrambled to maintain their stockpiles.

title: Lava Believed Near Floor of MidAtlantic Rift
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, Aug. 11 Geologists who in recent weeks have explored the floor of the midAtlantic rift valley have concluded from its strange topography that molten lava, ready to erupt at any time, lies only skin deep along most, if not all, of its great length.

title: Poles, Blacks, Jews Given Equal Time By Mayor on Tour
description: Three ethnically disparate sections of Brooklyn were visited by Mayor Beame last night as his weekly walking tour took him to parts of Crown Heights and Greenpoint.

title: Affluent Families Spend Freely on Vacations
description: KAMUELA, Hawaii  At the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel here, where a room for two costs upwards of $95 a day, Robert Butterfield, the manager, proudly showed a visitor a check for more than $230,000 the other day.

title: CHAMBERS BROTHERS SING OLD SAY YEAH
description: The Chambers Brothers appear in New York too rarely their Schaefer Music Festival appearance on Wednesday was their first Manhattan gig for year. Fortunately they appear unchanged and untouched by the fads and fancies that have afflicted the rock scene still hewing close to the soul. Some freaky electric guitar modernisms may sneak, in, but basi cally the group still produces the old say yeah signifying soul gospel, heavy on the back beat.

title: BROOKLYN ESCAPE BY 3 IS THWARTED
description: Three inmates tried to escape from the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men yesterday. One was shot, one surrendered and the third was recaptured after a short chase in downtown Brooklyn. The wounded man, Henry Brown, allegedly a leader of the Black Liberation Army, has a record of attempted escapes from custody.

title: Late Spurt Helps Sun Top Texans
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)Fleming Jensen's 19yard field goal and Durwood Keeton's 66yard interception return for a touchdown in the closing minutes tonight helped Southern California post an 187 victory over the Houston Texans, giving the Sun the World Football League's Western Division lead.

title: Ford Cancels Speech
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 15 (AP)President Ford has canceled plans to attend a Republican fundraising dinner at Newport next Wednesday, the state party chairman, Thomas E. Wright, said today. Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Governor of New York, will speak at the $100aplate dinner instead, Mr. Wright said.

title: 35C FARE SUPPORT AND TRANSIT AID SHRINK IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The House of Representatives narrowly upheld the concept of Federal subsidies for masstransit operations today and then voted to require localities to put up $2 for every Federal dollar received for such subsidies.

title: Cyclist, 22, Killed
description: CORONA, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI)  Rickie K. Milner, 22 years old, of Riverside, Calif., was killed last night when he spilled his motorcycle during a race at the Corona Raceway and was struck in the neck by another cycle. Milner was leading the race on the half mile track when he went too high on the No. 1 turn after the first lap and hit soft ground. He laid his motorcycle on its side and was hit from behind by a motorcycle driven by Bill Matherson.

title: Is the Doctor In?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Nearly thirty years after President Truman first proposed the idea, a national health insurance bill has suddenly become a viable political proposition. President Ford endorsed it in principle in his address to Congress and some. Republican members have become considerably more enthusiastic about it.

title: DIRECTORS PROTEST DRUGCLINIC CUTOFFS
description: A group of program directors from cityfinanced drug programs held a stormy meeting with the head of the Addiction Services Agency yesterday, protesting the disclosure that some programs had been cut off from financing and that others faced the same action because of the poor quality of their services.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Consolidated Edison announced that its sills would now show the amount of each dollar billed in the preceding 12 months that went for taxes and fuel. Joseph Block, the utilitiy's executive vice president of division operations, said that for the year ended last June 30, 23 cents was collected for taxes and 33 cents for fuel.

title: Ottilie Malfliet Bride Of Jeffrey D. Levine
description: The marriage of Ottilie Malfliet daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Malfliet of SintNiklass, Belgium, to Jeffrey D. Levine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Wilfred Levine of New Rochelle, N. Y., took place yesterday evening at the Levine home. Rabbi Samuel Silver of Stamford, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had won orders for two turbine generators totaling $18.9million. One, a 410,000kilowatt generator, would go to the City Public Service Board of San Antonio, Tex., for $10.7million and is scheduled for operation in December, 1976. The second, a 236,000kilowatt unit for the Deerhaven Generating station at Gainesville, Fla., would cost about $8.2million.

title: Coach Gets 5Year Pact
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 15 (AP) The athletic council of Memphis State University approved today a fiveyear contract for its football coach, Fred Pan. coast.

title: Jury Fixing Is Charged To Acquitted Defendant
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 15 (AP)Louis Agnes of Philadelphia, acquitted here last month of murder charges, was indicted by a Camden County grand jury yesterday on charges of attempting to tamper with the jury that exonerated him.

title: Aetna Claims Fraud in Seeking $418,574 On Equity Funding
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (Reuters) The Aetna Casualty and Surety Company filed Suit infederal District Court here today against the Equity Funding Life In. surance Company, the Equity Funding Corporation of Amer?? 18 officers and directors of the two companies, five accounting firms, the Loews Corperation and several institutions.

title: Authors League Urges TV Time for Communities
description: The Authors League of America, in a submission to the Federal Communications Commission pertaining to its current review of the primetime access rule, has recommended that the agency allow some air time each evening to he controlled by representative community groups instead of by the networks and stations.

title: Market Averages
description: Thursday, August 15, 1974

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
A Grim India Marks 27th Anniversary
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15India celebrated 27 years of independence today in a mood darkened by food shortages, Axial tensions, accelerating inflation and bitter allegations against the Government.

title: BAR PANEL OPPOSES MESKILL JUDGESHIP
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 15The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary has voted to oppose the nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: BLOOMFIELD WINS $500,000 REPRIEVE
description: NEWARK, Aug. 15  Bloomfield College obtained a pledge of $500,000 in credit today, allowing it to open with a smaller faculty tihs fall under an agreement with the Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: Senate Passes Bill To Put 4 Months On Standard Time
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Senate voted today to repeal the yearround daylight time provision that Congress enacted in December in the energy crisis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Police Strikes and Reprisals

title: '74 PEANUT SUPPORT RAISED TO $366 ATON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)Rising farm costs have forced the Government price support level for the 1974 peanut crop to a national average of $366 a ton, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: The Weekend Fishing Report
description: AREA A Fishing in recent days has returned to normal after a northeaster on Saturday and Sunday drove, the fish out to sea. Around Manasquan Ridge, blues averaging 10 pounds have been plentiful for fishermen using bunker backs, butterfish and smelts. Fluke up to 5 pounds have been moving into Manasquan Inlet and have responded to smelt, squid and spearing. At Seaside Park and Island Beach State Park, the best catch has been striped bass of small size with, some small blues and weakfish mixed in. Tuna, averaging 10 to 15 pounds, have been caught along the New Jersey coast, particularly around Barnegat, with spoons and plugs. The biggest catch of the week was to be 150 pounds.

title: Ford Names Buchen, ExLaw Partner, To Head Legal Staff as Buzhardt Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 President Ford today chose Philip W. Buchen, his former law partner, as his counsel in charge of all legal matters.

title: A Mozambique News Plant Is Attacked and Damaged
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  An explosion and fire badly damaged the printing plant of the Mozambique daily newspaper Noticias early today after a group of men entered the building and overpowered the staff.

title: Korean Tragedy
description: United States support for an unpopular and repressive regime in South Korea is in danger of undermining the collective security interests which such support is intended to insure. Yesterday's assassination attempt against President Park Chung Hee and the subsequent death of his wife are tragedies which only underline the plight of the Korean dictator.

title: Methadone Deaths in '73 Double Those Caused Here by Heroin
description: Methadone poisoning, virtuSally unknown only a few years ago, killed nearly twice as many people as did heroin in New York City last year, according to a confidential report by Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio, the city's Acting Chief Medical Examiner.

title: SAMUELS SCORES WILSON ON STOCKS
description: Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that there was a clear conflict of interest between Governor Wilson's stoc holdings in seven organizations and his role as Governor with major appointive powers to the state agencies regulating them.

title: Intrepid Captures Cup Mal
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15 The way Intrepid and Courageous clawed at each other today on Rhode Island Sound, it may take a coin toss to pick an America's Cup defender.

title: Britain Seeks to Expand State Holdings
description: LONDON, Aug. 15  The British Government announced today a politically explosive package of proposals for industry calling for more state ownership and a bigger role in shaping the plans of major companies.

title: Affluent Families Spend Freely on Vacations
description: KAMUELA, Hawaii  At the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel here, where a room for two costs upwards of $95 a day, Robert Butterfield, the manager, proudly showed a visitor a check for more than $230,000 the other day.

title: STOCKS MEANDER BUT CLOSE LOWER
description: The stock market vacillated yesterday, wavering up and down and closing with a small loss. At the close of the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 2.66 points to 737.88.

title: And Just Think of the Lunches They'll Have
description: In the kitchen of the Plaza there is more than a soupon of excitement over the wedding tomorrow of 25yearold Madeline Carvalho, a cook in the cold food section, and 30yearold Joseph Lanciani, the pastry chef.

title: POLICE SEEK TIPS IN GIRLS' DUBS
description: NORTH BERGEN, Aug. 15Bergen and Hudson County police today pursued a welter of tips, rumors and false alarms in their efforts to find the killer or killers of two local teenage girls whose nude and sexually abused bodies were found in upstate Montvale yesterday, five days after their disappearance.

title: Police Pursue All Leads In the Murders of 2 Girls
description: NORTH BERGEN, Aug. 15Bergen and Hudson County police today pursued a welter of tips, rumors and false alarms in their efforts to find the killer or killers of two local teenage girls whose nude and sexually abused bodies were found in upstate Montvale yesterday, five days after their disappearance.

title: Coast Guard Marijuana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Eighth District headquarters of the Coast Guard confirmed today, that 17 crew members of the cutter Durable were being brought before a captain' mast for nonjudicial punishment because they allegedly had smoked marijuana. The Durable is based at Brownsville, Tex.

title: NOGROWTH IDEA REJECTED BY FORD
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. (AP)President Ford saicl day that zero growth environmental policies flew in the face of human nature and must he rejected in favor of reasonable compromises.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, August 16, 1974

title: Phils Lose Catcher
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP)  A knee injury will keep Larry Cox, the Philadelphia Phillies reserve catcher, out of action for the rest of the season.

title: Bay Infestation Laid to Nuclear Plant
description: NEWARK, Aug. 15 (AP)An engineering study prepared for the State Public Utilities Commission has concluded that reducing the temperature of liquid discharges from the nuclear generating plant at Oyster Creek would help curtail shipworm infestation in Barnegat Bay.

title: Flat Output Shows Little Gain Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Industrial production remained virtually unchanged in July for the second consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: UNIONDALE, L. I, Aug. 15The New York Sets will finish their first home season in World Team Tennis tomorrow night against the Philadelphia Freedoms. Match time at the Nassau Coliseum in 8 o'clock. The match will feature the women's singles contest between Billie Jean of the Freedoms, and Virginia Wade of the Sets. Mrs. King injured her thumb last night but said she would play against the Sets. The Freedoms have clinched their section title of the Eastern Division and are awaiting the playoffs next week. The Sets, with a 1527 wonlost record, have a 63 mark at home since league action resumed after Wimbledon. In that same period, the Sets have attracted 36,951 fans in nine matches at home for a leagueleading average of 4,105. The Sets conclude their season Sunday night, playing the Triangles at Pittsburgh.

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug, 15Everybody here talks about the weather and nobody wants to do anything about it. They just keep hoping against hope that it lasts the preposterously blue skies, the cool freshness of morning that hangs on stubbornly all day although everybody knows that Saratoga in August is a pressure cooker when it isn't being battered by electrical storms sweeping down from the Adirondacks. The race meeting is half over, and nobody here can remember another year when benign evening followed tranquil day in such serene comfort as the last two weeks have enjoyed. This was another morning like those of the recent past. Reggie Cornell, trainer for Calumet Farm, rested sweatered forearms on the backstretch rail and managed to keep a conversation going while his blue eyes swept the track where a set of his horses worked.

title: Memorable Rock From Crosby, Stills
description: At their first New York area appearance in four years, a week ago last night in Jersey City, Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young were clearly affected by both Roosevelt Stadium itself and the tensions inherent in the resignation of a President. But by Wednesday night at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, the first of two concerts there, things were most definitely back on the track. It was a memorable concert.

title: Business Briefs
description: American manufacturing, petroleum and mining companies plan to invest $21.6billion in foreign countries this year, or 32 per cent more than they invested in 1973, the McGraw Hill Publications Company said yesterday.

title: William Palen Conway, 93, ExHead of Guaranty Trust
description: William Palen Conway, who was chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, a predecessor to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, prior to his retirement in 1948, died yesterday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 93 years old.

title: Profit Mark Set By Harvester Co.
Troops Enter Famagusta And Push to Split Island
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Friday, Aug. 16  Turkish forces moved east and west across northern Cyprus yesterday in a continued drive to cut the island in two.

description: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX

description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP)  A knee injury will keep Larry Cox, the Philadelphia Phillies reserve catcher, out of action for the rest of the season.

title: U. S. Offering to Mediate In Negottattons on Cyprus
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The United States has informed Greece, Turkey and Cyprus of its willingness to play an active mediating role in ending the Cyprus crisis and asked for suggestions on how to resume peace talks. asked for suggestions on how to resume peace talks.

title: CONGRESS CLEARS BILL ON HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval today, 377 to 21, to a compromise $11.2billion housing bill, the first major housing measure to pass Congress since 1968.

title: Intrepid Captures Cup Trial
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15 The way Intrepid and Courageous clawed at each other today on Rhode Island Sound, it may take a coin toss to pick an America's Cup defender.

title: DAVID THOMPSON, 54, COUNSEL TO MEYNER
description: David C. Thompson, who had served as deputy attorney general and associate counsel to Gov. Robert F. Meyner of New Jersey, died yesterday of a brain tumor in Claramass Hospital, Belleville, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived at 61 Rensselaer Road, Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Strauss Defeats Reform Group, Tightens Grip on Party's Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, won a tactical fight against dissident reformers today.

title: Height and Weight Rules Relaxed for Police Jobs
description: TRENTON, Aug. 15 (AP)The State Civil Service Commission announced today that it had voted to abolish minimum height and weight requirements for candidates for municipal police jobs.

title: 'Confessions,' Film Study Of Bribery and Immunity:The Cast
description: A corrupt Public Prosecutorwhose guilt has just been discovered by his former disciple, a young District Attorneyasks the latter, "Is anything wrong?", and the line has almost as much dramatic impact as if it had been uttered by Richard M. Nixon to James D. St. Clair. "Confessions of a Police Captain", directed by Damiano Damiani, was made in Italy in 1971, but it's nicely up to date on the questions of political cover-ups, bribery and immunity. The movie is playing today and tomorrow at the First Avenue Screening Room.Martin Balsam has a brash, brisk authority as a police captain obsessed with nailing criminals who have stayed above the law, thanks to the aid of local politicians. He and Franco Nero, as the elegant District Attorney, both initially suspect each other of shielding the Mafia, which controls the construction trade. Meanwhile, official corruption flourishes, and uncooperative witnesses tend to wind up in cement.The elaborate plot is occasionally confusing. But this thoughtful, modest movie about the perversion of justice is worth seeingespecially for Mr. Balsam's performance as a man accused of fanaticism. This actor is always good at losing his temper, and he brings subtlety to a complex character who has come to feel that the police are the instruments of the gangsters and who breaks the law because he has lost all faith in the courts.

title: Meeting in Nairobi Is Set By World Churches Council
description: BERLIN, Aug. 15The World Council of Churches' 1975 general assembly, originally scheduled for Jakarta, Indonesia, will be held instead in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Senate Passes Bill To Put 4 Months On Standard Time
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Senate voted today to repeal the yearround daylight time provision that Congress enacted in December in the energy crisis.

title: Clay Shaw Is Dead at 60; Freed in Kennedy Plot
description: Clay L. Shaw, the businessman who was acquitted of plotting to assassinate President Kennedy after one of the nation's more sensational trials, died yesterday of cancer in his New Orleans home. He was 60 years old.

title: Greeks Still at Desks in NATO Despite Pullout
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 15 Greek military officers at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters stayed put and silent today following Greece's announcement yesterday that she was withdrawing her armed forces from the alliance.

title: Parents to Patrol Streets In the Central Park Area
description: A volunteer corps of 250 parents will patrol the streets in the vicinity of schools east and west of Central Park next fall to afford added protection for children.

title: INDEXATION TESTED IN PLANTERS SUIT
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 15 (UPI)What is possibly the first lawsuit in the United States to test the use bf indexation as a hedge against inflation has been filed by Union Planters National Bank of Memphis, against Aztec Properties,  Inc., a realty company.

title: Yankee Records
$300Million Borrowed By the Federal Reserve
description: The Federal Reserve borrowed some $300million of shortterm Treasury securities in the money market here yesterday as the first step in accommodating the expected large inflow of Mideast oil funds.

title: Stockton, Murphy Card 65's, Lead Hartford Open by Shot
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP)Dave Stockton and Bob Murphy shot widely dissimilar 65's, six under par, and tied for the first round lead today in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.  Greater Hartford open golf tournament.

title: CITY'S TAXI PANEL WEIGHS FARE RISE
description: The chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, Moses L. Kove, said yesterday that he thought that the re lief sought by the taxi fleet owners could be provided for less than the 25 per cent fare increase they have requested.

title: Methadone Mixed With Another Drag In Fight on Abuses
description: Bristol Laboratories announced yesterday that it was marketing a new product called Methenex, which is a combinatlon of two drugs now available individually on a prescription basis to treat drug addicts The two drugs are methadone, the heroin substitute, and naloxone, a narcotic antggnist.

title: Advertising: A.T.&T. Long Shot
description: Bill Russell, the basketball superstar who has become the spokesman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's longdistance division, will be filming another commercial for the company on Monday. This time, however, there may not be a basketball or basket in sight.

title: Cycle of Emotions In Carmina Burana By Ailey Dancers
description: Carmina Burana is one of John Butler's most fluent works, and Alvin Ailey's dancers brought it rippling and snorting to the State Theater on Wednesday evening. Stylistically it reflects a reconciliation between ballet and Martha Graham modern dance, and with its expanded gesture fills fills the big stage comfortably.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ELMWOOD PARK, Aug. 15Dick Vitale, the Seton Hall graduate and University of Detroit coach, returned to his native New Jersey last week to direct his Garden Stace summer basketball camp, how in its seventh year. However, he has been running around talking with prize prospects in the state, speaking at coaching clinics and attending summer league allstar games with his assistant, Dave Gaines, a former Globetrotter.

title: Treasury Might Sell Gold, an Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Jack F. Bennett, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, reiterated today that the Treasury might sell some of its gold if a large private demand develeps after ownership by American citizens becomes legal, at the end of the year.

title: LAWYER IS DENIED NEW BRIBE TRIAL
description: A Federal judge here denied yesterday a motion for a new trial for Edmund A. Rosner, a lawyer convicted in 1972 of bribing Detective Robert S. Leuci to obtain secret documents from the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan.

title: SHIFT BY BIG BOARD ON FEES IS LIKELY
description: The New York Stock Exchange is likely to reconsider its endorsement of a Government order that the brokerage industry unfix the commissions that Wall Street firms charge their customers for buying and selling stock.

title: EXECUTIVE LIMITS SOUGHT IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Seeking to restrict the long expansion of Presidential power, a special Senate committee is expected to introduce next week legislation to repeal wideranging Presidential emergency authority and establish new standards of public accountability by the President.

title: TWO MORE R.E.I.T.S. SUSPEND DIVIDENDS
description: Two fore real estate investment trusts announced yesterday suspension of dividend payments to shareholders, citing high interest rates and borrower defaults as reasons for their decisions.

title: Israel's Parliament Bars a Referendum On West Bank Fate
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 15The Israeli Parliament today rejected a call for a national referendum on the future of the West Bank of Jordan, captured in the 1967 war.

title: The President's Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  One of these days the moving vans will be backing up to the White House and carting off all of President Nixon's personal and official, papers to San Clemente, Calif. This is the way it has been since the beginning of the Republic: By tradition, which now has the force of law, the departing President decides which papers he wants to take away, and they are regarded as his private property.

title: About New York Mulberry Street's Magic
description: These nights Mulberry Street is busier than usual. Not that anything very different is happening. After dark the phi wood and new metal folding chairs still cluster into knots around stoops and tenement doors, and the inen talk about President Nixon's departure, Harrison Goldin's municipal checkbook, impending marriages and stilltobetaken vacations. The women look down on the men from apartment windows through thickets of geraniums and rubber plants.

title: Drea, Dietz, Klecatsky In U.S. Rowing Finals
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y. Aug. 15Sean Drea of Ireland, Jim Dietz and Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the New York Athletic Club, all won preliminary heats today and quailfied for Saturday's final races in the 98th national rowing championships on the Orchard Beach lagoon.

title: Mental Hospital Is Scored on Escapees

description: Top officials of the Bronx, State Hospital have been accused by highranking police officers of criminal negligence in failing to notify the police of the escapes of inmates transferred from Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane.

title: HARRIMAN ASKS CUT IN MILITARY OUTLAY
