Averell Harriman, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said today that the United States should reduce military spending and, at least temporarily, abandon plans for a naval base in the Indian Ocean if it desired improved relations with the Soviet Union.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES
Hearing Is Delayed On Addition of 45 To Controller Staff
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday postponed until Sept. 12 a hearing on a proposal to add 45 accountants to the Controller's staff to help straighten out records and books that have been depicted by a series of outside audits as sloppy, inaccurate and riddled with discrepancies.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Community Affairs Unit Given Grant

title: Wife of Top Westchester Relief Aide Indicted on 2 Counts of Welf are Fraud
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 15The wife of the Westchester County Commissioner of Social Services has been indicted on a charge of welfare fraud, it was announced today.

title: Ford Denounced by Vietcong For Continuing Aid to Saigon
description: PARIS, Aug. 15  The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, in its first public statement since President Ford took office, attacked him today for continuing aid to the Saigon Government.

title: 11 on Staff Accuse F.D.A. Of Harassment on Studies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Eleven physicians and research workers from the Food and Drug Administration testified today that their superiors harassed, transferred and at times overruled them when they produced negative findings in studies of drugs to be offered to, the public by the country's drug industry.

title: Impersonal Diplomacy
description: In the quiet unfolding of Middle Eastern diplomacy, the new Ford, Administration has an immediate task of demonstrating that former President Nixon's personal diplomacy was not strictly personal but rather that it embodied the strong interests of virtually all shades of this country's political thought in promoting a just ArabIsraeli settlement.

title: 300 Pay Court to Lawn Tennis in S.I. Celebration
description: The two ladies looked lovely in their long, white, bustled cotton dresses trimmed with lace, and their gentlemen partners were dashing in white suits and straw boaters.

title: And Now, the PostNixon Book Flood
description: More than a dozen Nixon Administration figures are involved in various stages of book projects, ranging from lofty appraisals to confessional  and even perhaps evangelicaloutpourings.

title: The Historic Record ...
description: The report and supporting documents of the House Judiciary Committee, now almost ready for presentation to the House of Representatives, constitute a statement of fundamental historic significance. They establish the incontrovertible fact that former President Richard M. Nixon would have been impeached and convicted under the Constitution of the United States had he not chosen to forestall the procedure by resigning his great office.

title: Rev. Laurence Fenninger, 89, Served Union Theological
description: The Rev. Laurence Fenninger, acting dean of Princeton College from 1944 to 1946 and assistant to the president of Union Theological Seminary from 1946 to 1952, died Wednesday in Princeton, N. J., where he lived. He was 87 years, old.

title: Housing Group's Track Gets an Olympic Image
description: An 18yearold boy carrying an Olympicstyle flaming torch around Macombs Dam Park just north of Yankee Stadium yesterday heralded a new format for the City Housing Authority's public housing track and field championships for boys and girls in age groups up to 16.

title: Offshore Drilling Expensive
description: The average cost of drilling an oil well off the Texas Coast is $647,000, eight times the average cost of an onshore well.

title: Four Men Die in Fire
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP)Four men died early today when flames trapped them on the second floor of a twostory tenement near the downtown area. A fifth man leaped from a window and was injured. Investigators believe that the fire was caused by a man smoking in bed.

title: Appeals Court Puts Limit on Application Of GunControl Law
description: TRENTON, Aug. 15 (AP) A state appeals court ruled today that the state's guncontrol law does not apply to rifles and shotguns purchased before its passage in 1966.

title: Split Session Is Discriminatory, Federal Judge Rules on P.S. 19
description: He made the statement, in a preliminary ruling at the end of a daylong hearing in Fedtral District Court on a suit filed by the Puerto Rican parents of children attending Public School 19 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The school, whose student body is 95 per cent Puerto Rican, has been on split session since 1961.

title: Trainer Won't Scratch 301 Shot in Cane Pace
description: YONKERS, Aug. 15  It's all one big puzzle to Harold (Buck) Gray, who will drive Mirado Hanover, the 301 outsider in Saturday's Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Australians Report Detonation Of Another French Nuclear Test
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Australian Government reported today that France had detonated a fifth nuclear bomb in her current Pacific test series, which has sent radioactive fallout over Australian territory.

title: Lava Believed Near Floor of MidAtlarztic Rift
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, Aug. 11  Geologists who in recent weeks have explored the floor of the midAtlantic rift valley have concluded from its strange topography that molten lava, ready to erupt at any time, lies only skin deep along most, if not all, of its great length.

title: Rifleman Scores 100
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 15 (UPI)Jack Sicola of Santa Cruz, Calif., the 1974 national highpower rifle champion, continued his winning streak today by shooting a perfect 100 with 20 centerhits in the longrange 1,000 yards Leech Cup match during the National Highpower rifle championships.

title: Soviet Order for Wheat Is Apparently Canceled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Soviet Union apparently has canceled an order for 13.3 million bushels of American wheat, an Agriculture Department report indicated today.

title: Brazil and China Agree To Establish Diplomatic Tie
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 15 Brazil and China announced tonight that they would establish diplomatic relations.

title: Bridge: Declarer Must Be Careful If He Loses Trump Control
description: Delicate, play is often called for when the declarer loses control of the trump suit at an early stage because he has been forced to ruff. If one defender outnumbers the declarer in trumps, the defense usually succeeds. The declarer may need to return the compliment by forcing a defender to ruff.

title: Wright Wins Met P.G.A. by 10 Stroke's
description: JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 15Jimmy Wright was assured of winning the 47th Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship when he took out his 6iron for a 165yard uphill approach shot at the Meadow Brook Club's par4 18th hole todaythe final hole of this 54hole tournament. The slim Oklahoman was the only player under par and he held an eightstroke lead over his nearest rivals.

title: LOUIS MELANCON
description: Louis Melancon, official photographer for the Metropolitan Qpera since 1947, died Saturday in Roosevelt. Hospital. He was, 73 years old and lived at 140 West End Avenue.

title: Duryea Backs Wife On Right to Criticize Role of Rockefeller
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea yesterday defended his wife's right to criticize former Gov, Nelson A. Rockefeller in telegrams she sent Thursday to President Ford and three Congressional leaders.

title: PreContract Data Asked On FeedGrain Exports
description: Such action is vital to assure that domestic needs will be met despite projected low crop output, the Georgia Democrat said in a speech prepared for Senate floor delivery.

title: London Theater: Classics and Sexism
description: LONDON  The London theater thrives on classicsold classics, new classics and indeterminate classics. Most of them are staged by the Establishment, subsidized theaters, such as the National Theater, but occasionally they do turn up in what is thought of, as the commercial theater.

title: Primus Wedding A Pulsating Dance By Ailey Company
description: The scope of Pearl Primus's contribution to black dance has yet to be fully assessed, but Alvin Ailey's decision to include her works in his repertory can blessedly spur the process. His company presented a pulsating performance of The Wedding on Thursday evening at the State Theater for the first time, this season.

title: JOBS DROP 41,000 IN CITY IN A YEAR
description: The number of jobs in the metropolitan area fell 6,000 between June, 1973, and last June, led by a loss of 41,000 jobs in the city that was only partly offset by a gain of 35,000 outside the five boroughs.

title: Karl E. Mundt Dead at 74; ExSouth Dakota Senator
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP  Former Senator Karl Mundt of South Dakota, stanch antir Comfnunist who fig ured in the Alger Hiss and Mc. earthy hearings hi the year following World War II, die?? today. He was 74, years old.

title: EARNINGS RAISED AT GREAT WESTERN
Dickie a Line Coach
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Emerson Dickie, an outstanding end at Boston College until his graduation in 1956, was named offensive line coach today by Northeastern University football team.

title: A.T.&T.'s $40Billion Man Will Lecture at Wharton
description: In September, the man who has helped the Bell System extract $40billion from the capital markets over the last 20 years will return to the Wharton School to tell graduate business students how it's done.

title: John F. Tobin, 51, Official Of Hughes TV Network
description: John F. Tobin, vice president of the Hughes Television Network since 1965, died Thursday at his home on Carrington Drive in Greenwich, Conn., apparently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Muzak, at 40, Develops Plan to Play a New Tune
description: Muzak, that ubiquitous aural backdrop, has reached middle age.

title: Art: Sculpture's the Thing as Newport Gets a Look at Monumenta
description: NEWPORT, R. I.When it was made known that Newport would play host this summer to Monumenta, an openair exhibition of largescale modern sculptures, no one knew quite what to expect.

title: RULES ON VITAMINS PUT OFF 6 MONTHS
description: The United States Court Appeals for the Second Circuit has postponed for six months enforcement of new Federal rules for labeling vitamins and minerals, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: HospitalEscape Inquiry Opens
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said yesterday that a critical developing emergency existed at Bronx State Hospital and announced the start of an investigation into the effects of a new state law that transfers inmates from Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane to state mental institutions with little security.

title: N.F.L.'s SuddenDeath Not a Sudden Creation
description: Although the new suddendeath rule was used for the first time last Saturday night when the San Diego Chargers beat the New York Jets, 2014, on a touchdown after minutes 17 seconds, it was not the first time a National Football League preseason game had gone an extra period.

title: COAST OILGAS PLAN IS APPROVED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  The Interior Department announced today approval of a controversial plan to develop oil and gas deposits discovered off the California coast near Santa Barbara. Acting Secretary John Whitaker said work could now begin on 17 tracts covering 83,000 acres, known as the Santa Ynez unit.

title: E. D. Loewenwarter Dies; Headed Accountants' Firm
description: Ernest D. Loewenwarter, senior partner in Ernest D. Loewenwarter & Co., public accountants here, died yesterday, at his home, 765 East 18th Street, Brooklyn. He was 73 years old.

title: American Film Institute Plans Women's Workshop
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The American Film Institute has established a pilot program aimed at giving women greater opportunities in directing television and feature films.

title: Ankara Reports Troops Have Won Their Goals Asks Negotiations
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 16Premier Bulent Ecevit said today that Turkey, having agreed to a ceasefire in Cyprus after all present military objectives had been achieved, was now prepared to resume negotiations in Geneva with Greece and Britain on the political future of the island.

title: Bridge: Fates Forgive Card Player
description: The average bridge player commits many sins for which the fates forgive him. He plays a shaky three notrump instead of an easy four spades, but the game comes home. He overlooks a 100 per cent line of play and adopts one that has a 75 per cent chance  but as this succeeds his partner is satisfied and he is not conscious of having erred.

title: WINE TALK
description: Despite the steadily growing interest in wine, relatively few drinkers have more than a vague idea of how it is made. So, from time to time, we hope to discuss various facets of the winemaking process.

title: U.S. Plays Soccer Tie
description: UMIYA, Japan, Aug. 16 (AP)The United States national soccer team and the Japan allstars played to a 11 tody in the opening match of a threegame goodwill series in Japan. There was no scoring in the first half. The teams meet again Sunday in Yokohama.

title: Tests Show Two Girls Were Suffocated
description: The Bergen County Medical Examiner has established that suffocation was the cause of death of two North Bergen, teenaged girls whose bodies were found in Montvale Wednesday morning, the Bergen County Prosecutor, Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., said yesterday.

title: Hussein Meets With Ford on Mideast Disengagement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan talked with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger at length today on the next stage in the resolution of the Middle East conflict a disengagement of Jordanian and Israeli troops along the Jordan River.

title: Press Operations in White House Revised, With Politics Ruled Out
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The White House announced today a major reorganization of its press operations, including the appointment of John W. Hushen as deputy press secretary.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An increasing number of state legislators have indicated a surprising, substantial and apparently growing support for major reform of marijuana laws, according to a report by a committee of the State Bar Association. Hortense Mound, chairman of the association's Committee on Revision of the Criminal Law, said that all Senators and Assemblymen had been polled.

title: Burke Issues Interim Plan For Brunswicks' Schools
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16North Brunswick students assigned to the racially mixed New, Bruns wick High School will be able to attend the, high school in their own township this year under an order issued by the State Education Commissioner Dr. Fred G. Burke.

title: INDIANS SUMMON ONLY 5 WITNESSES
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 16Dennis Banks and Russell Means, the leaders of last year's Indian uprising at Wounded Knee, S. D., rested their defense late this afternoon after calling only two authors and three Sioux Indians as witnesses.

title: Ethiopian Military Strips Selassie of Some Powers
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 16  Ethiopia's armed forces today stripped 82yearold Emperor Haile Selassie of some of his powers.

title: Books of The Times
description: PROPHETS WITH HONOR. By Man Barth 254 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Sets Beat Billie Jean, Lose Game
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 16.  The New York Sets, concluding their World Team Tennis home schedule against the Philadelphia Freedoms, did the unexpected tonight at Nassau Coliseum. They handled Billy Jean King defeats in both singles and doubles before a crowd of 5,487 fans.

title: Sholty Pacer Is Trainer's Dream Colt
description: YONKERS, Aug. 16Dreams sometimes come true, even the impossible ones.

title: F.B.I. Investigating Congressional Record Hoax
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Federal Bureau of Investigation began looking today into how false statements attributed to two Representatives were inserted in the Congressional Record yesterday morning.

title: Hitchhikers Unfazed by Killings and Police Crackdown
description: MANTOLOKING, Aug. 16 Despite the murder of two teenaged hitchhikers whose sexually abused bodies were found in Hudson County five days after the girls were reported missing, hitchhikers continue to appear along the Jersey shore.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)Investors who bought registered notes and bonds in last week's Government sale may have to wait more than two months before the securities are delivered, the Treasury Department said today. The delay stems from the heavy demand by small investors who flooded banks and brokerage houses with orders for the attractive 9 per cent notes and 8 per cent bonds.

title: Ear Association Endorses Amendment on Women's Rights and Promises to Help Seek Ratification
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 16The American Bar Association endorsed today the proposed amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women and promised to work for ratification by enough additional states to write it into the Constitution.

title: U.S. SILENT ON TALKS ABOUT SOVIET JEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP The State Department declined to comment today on reports that the Soviet Union would be easing its restrictions on Jewish emigration in return for trade concessions from the United States.

title: However, He Declares He Would Prefer to Mediate Dispute in WashingtonEarly Negotiations Called Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 16Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he would be willingif askedto go to Cyprus to mediate a political settlement between the Greeks and Turks on the island.

title: Fire Sweeps Nursing Home, Killing Six in Mississippi
description: BROOKHAVEN, Miss., Aug 16 (AP)  Fire that swept through a rambling frame nursing home today killed six persons and insured two others, one of them a nurse's aide, who had gone into the building to rouse the occupants.

title: Head of F.D.A. Vows Review of Staff Harassment Charges Against Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration promised today a thorough review of charges leveled yesterday against his agency by 14 research workers, physicians and consultants.

title: Intolerable Conquest
description: The United States and its allies cannot condone Turkey's military conquest of the northern third of Cyprus in flagrant violation of United Nations ceasefire orders and NATO pledges reiterated by Ankara at Ottawa less than two months ago. To accept Turkey's aggression as a fait accompli would be to invite an endless period of bloodshed on the island and to risk collapse of the Western security, system in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: HELEN MEDIAN, OPINION ANALYST
description: Helen Schneider Dinerman, a sociologist, died Wednesday in Emanuel Hospital in Portland, Ore. She was 53 years old and lived here at 179 East 70th Street.

title: Carol Semple, Miss Hill Gain Amateur Golf Final
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 16 (UPI)Carol Semple, the defending champion, and Cynthia Hill won semifinal matches today to advance into tomorrow's 36hole showdown for the 74th United States women's amateur golf championship.

title: Lewis freedman, Resigns As CBS Drama Producer
description: Lewis Freedman has resigned from CBSTV as executive producer of drama specials, reportedly over differences with network executives about the production of Bicentennial Minutes. Mr. Freedman, who had been responsible for such dramas as Catholics and The Lie last season and for the forthcoming series on Benjamin Franklin, could not be reached for comment yesterday.

title: Stocks Lag for 7th Day As Dow Sets 4Year Low
description: The stock market, keeping consistently to its downward path, continued to decline yesterday, just as it has for the seven days since it became clear that Gerald Ford would replace Richard Nixon.

title: JERSEY TO PROTECT GATEWAY POLICIES
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP)New Jersey announced today, that the financially troubled Gateway Insurance Company of Philadelphia has agreed to sign an order of insolvency in Pennsylvania.

title: Man, 31, Slain by Two In Williamsburg Section
description: A 31yearold black man was shot and killed yesterday in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn by two white gunmen who pumped a number of shots into him and then walked away, the police said.

title: Enter ERDA
description: After months in the legislative mill, the proposed new Energy Research and Development Administration (ERDA) has now passed both houses of Congress. The bulk of the new agency is to be a reorganized Atomic Energy Commission, with the important additions of the Office of Coal Research and the Bureau of Mines from the Interior Department, plus the solar and geothermal energy development programs now funded through the NationalScience Foundation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Mr. Nixon and the Peace Myth

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 17, 1974

title: Court Orders G.M. To Tell Truck Owners of Defect
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) A Federal appeals court ordered General Motors today to notify owners of a safety defect in the wheels of 200,000 G.M. trucks built between 1960 and 1965.

title: Weather: MidAugust to MidSeptember
description: After the water was shut off, the city operated off its fivemilliongallon reserve holding tanks for several hours, and then was without water for about 10 hours. Normal service had been restored by midweek, according to officials.

title: Victim Foretells Suicide
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 16 (UPI)A young man notified a television station of an impending suicide leap yesterday and then slipped through guard rails and plunged 600 feet to his death from the observation deck at the Tower of the Americas. The victim was Ronnie Wayne Scott, 20 years old, of San Antonio.

title: Peru, Alleging Plot By the Opposition, Seizes Party Chiefs
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 16 (AP)Eight opposition leaders were arrested after the police uncovered a plot to create chaos in Peru, the Government newspaper La Crnica reported today.

title: Direct Use of Soy Protein Cut by Taste for Meat
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 14If the world's human population is increasingly starving for protein, that is not apparent in the marketing of the single most efficient protein sourcethe soybean.

title: Sailboat Galley Expert Says: Use Fresh Foods, Cook Fast
description: Taking things by and large, as sailors say, I got on fairly well.... What I lacked of fresh meat was made up in fresh fish, at least while in the tradewinds, where flyingfish crossing on the wing at night would hit the sails and fall on deck.... Every morning except when the moon was large I got a bountiful supply by merely picking them up from the lee scuppers. All tinned meats went begging.

title: Tax Collector Seizes Jersey Bell Garage Over Unpaid $34,000 Levy
description: A South Brunswick tax collector, in a move reminiscent of St. George and the dragon, yesterday seized all the property and equipment at a New Jersey Bell Telephone Company maintenance garage over an unpaid $34,000 tax bill.

title: HospitalEscape Inquiry Opens
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said yesterday that a critical developing emergency existed at Bronx State Hospital and announced the start of an investigation into the effects of a new state law that transfers inmates from Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane to state mental institutions with little security.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesMonroe Brooks, 137 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Lino Cordero, 132, Venezuela, 3 rounds.

title: End to Arms Action On Cyprus Urged By Security Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 16 (Reuters)The United Nations Security Council adopted a French resolution tonight recording its formal disapproval of unilateral military actions taken against Cyprus.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SATURDAY, AUGUST 17, 1974
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16When Samuel Taylor, a meatcutter, was divorced last year, he lost his 1966 Ford and had to move out of his home in southwest Los Angeles to a home in suburban Inglewood.

title: Ohio State Dive?? Wins in A.A.U.
description: DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 16 AP) Tim Moore of Ohio State won the men's onemeter springboard event tonight in the National Ama??eur Athletic Union diving champions at the Point Mal??ard Aquatic Center. He tallied 555.36 points.

title: Two on Ship Get Four Years For Smuggling of Hashish
description: NASSAU, The Bahamas, Aug. 16 (AP)A Bahamian judge has sentenced an American ship captain and a member of his crew to four years in prison in the smuggling of 3,700 pounds of hashish, the largest amount of the drug ever seized.

title: Ethiopian Military Strips Selassie of Some Powers
3 Firemen Hurt in Brooklyn
description: Three firemen were slightly injured while fighting a threealarm fire yesterday in a vacant building at 220 Cornelia Street in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The flames swept through the attics of 11 adjoining buildings within a halfhour after the fire broke out shortly after 4 P.M. It was declared under control at 5:26 P.M. Assistant Chief Allan Haye, called the blaze possibly suspicious.

title: Chessie Sues I.C.C. To Revise Terms On Rate Increase
description: Chessie Systems, Inc., the railroad holding company, filed suit in Federal District Court in Richmond, Va., yesterday seeking to eliminate strings tied to a 10 per cent freight rate increase authorized last June.

title: Distraught Broker Kills Sleeping Son in Jersey
description: LITTLE SILVER, N. J., Aug. 16A 44yearold stockbroker, apparently distraught over his wife's impending death from cancer, allegedly shot one of his children to death and wounded another as they slept in their beds this morning.

title: Soviet Reports Decision By Turks Without Comment
description: MOSCOW, Aug, 16 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today reported Turkey's decision for ceasefire on Cyprus with unusual speed and without cornment.

title: People in Sports Sobers, To Cricketer, Retires
description: Gary Sobers, a West Indian regarded by many as the world's top cricketer, announced, his retirement in London yesterday from the sport he dominated in the midnineteensixties. Sobers, who played English county cricket for Nottinghamshire, as well as leading West Indies, said he would not play any more firstclass cricket after the end of the current season.

title: Ford Laughs Off Delay In Picking Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16President Ford laughad off the delay in choosing a Vice President and toll a reporter this morning, I haven't been thinking about it.

title: 48 POLICE OFFICERS GIVEN PROMOTIONS
description: Promotions were awarded at a ceremony yesterday to 48 police officers, including Sgt. David Durk, a key witness at the Knapp Commission hearings, and six officers who were reinstated to commands from which the previous Police Commissioner had demoted them.

title: Summer Brings Uplift for Hotel PayTV Movies
description: It has been an encouraging summer for the struggling fouryearold industry that provides movies to hotel guests over pay television.

title: $4MILLION U. S. AID GIVEN BANGLADESH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The United States has authorized a $4million grant to Bangladesh for building materials to restore homes damaged by the floods that have swept over more than half of the country, the State Department said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP)The University of Illinois would not confirm or deny today a published report that the school's basketball team might be under a threeyear probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Boy on West Side Highway Dies in Fall Through Hole
description: A 14yearold boy fell 35 feet to his death early yesterday through a gaping hole in the closed portion of the West Side Highway in lower Manhattan.

title: Army Is Asked to Phase Out Biological Warfare Test Area
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) A special committee has recommended that the. Army place on standby status the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah, once used to test germ warfare agents and nerve gases.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PARAMUS, Aug. 16The Winged Foot Country Club course in Mamaroneck, N.Y., which had the world's best golf pros seeking counsel and consolation in June as the United States Open scores soared, is the creation of A. W. Tillinghast, who also designed the Ridgewood Country Club layout, the scene of the United States Amateur championship Aug. 26 through Sept. 1.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Gas Prices Here Among U.S. Highest
description: Gasoline prices in the New York area dropped slightly this week, but they continued to be among the highest in the country, according to the Automobile Club of New York.

title: Market Place: Analyst Stirred Sales of Xerox
description: Yesterday was one of continued weakness for Xerox shares. The stock closed at its 1974 low of 85, Off , on a 61,000share turnover.

title: U.S. Defers Lifting Residual Oil Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Federal Energy Administration said today It had decided to defer its proposal to remove Federal allocation rules from residual fuel oil.

title: McGraw Is Victor as Staub Again Gets Key Hit
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 16Two teams with but a single thoughtmaking up ground in the pennant race  put their thinking on the line tonight at Riverfront Stadium. In the end, New York armpower proved mightier than Cincinnati brainpower as the Mets beat the Reds, 21, in 12 innings.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN A. & P. STRIKE
description: Negotiators for striking A. & P. workers in the metropolitan area reached a tentative contract agreement with the supermarket chain last night after a crippling fiveday strike.

title: Measles Epidemic in State Is Reported to Have Ended
description: SOMERSET, Aug. 16New Jersey's measles epidemic, which reached record proportions in the state's northern and central counties last winter and this spring, appears to have burned itself out, according to state and Federal medical authorities.

title: Alabama Mayor Wounded
description: BRIGHTON, Ala., Aug. 16 (UPI)Richard Lewis, the black Mayor of this Birmingham suburb, was wounded today by the former superintendent of the city street department the authorities said. Mr. Lewis, was shot while investigating a complaint that the former official, Joe Marsh, who is white, had put up a barricade outside his home to block traffic. Mr. Marsh was charged with assault with intent to murder.

title: Judge Refuses to Release Jerry Catena from Prison
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Jerry Catena will stay behind bars a while longer. His release had been approved by a Superior Court judge but Supreme Court Justice Nathan L. Jacobs today denied a motion for immediate release of the suspected mob boss.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SLEEPER FINALE This weekend marks the last of the middleofthenight tours for insomniac New Yorkers. This time it's sans bicycles. At 2:30 Sunday morning, meet at Shubert Alley, just off Times Square, where various guides will give you a tour on foot of landmarks of the midtown area, from the Circle Line pier at 43d Street, where you'll catch a breathtaking view of the Lower Manhattan skyline, to Grand Central Terminal and Beekman Park, where you'll have breakfast. (Bring your own breakfast.)

title: Jovial Meany, 80, Feted In Capital by Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 16 It was George Meany's 80th birthday today, and his colleagues at the A.F.L.C.I.O., which he heads, held a party for him complete with punch, sandwiches, a round of Happy Birthday to You and a tiered cakebut someone forgot the cake knife.

title: Housing Starts Dropped in July
Vengeance And Tortuga Win Cruise
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 16  The Centerport (L. I.), Yacht Club's Vengeance and Tortuga, representing Sagamore Y. C. of Oyster Bay, L. I., were winners of the International Offshore Rule Divisions I and II in the Junior Yacht Racing Association's Dorade trophy cruise series on Long Island Sound which ended today off Riverside Y C. The skippers were Robert Gentzlinger on Vengeance and John Cosulich on Tortuga.

title: Just 14 at Tombs Seek Transfers
description: Nearly all the eligible inmates at the Men's House of, Detentiongiven the option of staying at the outmoded, facility or transferring to better facilities on Riker's' Islandchose yesterday to stay, according to Benjamin J. Malcolm, the Commissioner of Correction.

title: S. I. Man Given Life Term In Narcotics Agent's Death
description: A 43yearold Staten Island man was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday on charges that he had participated in the murder of a narcotics agent lin a Manhattan motel two years ago.

title: RCA to Raise Prices 2% For Its Color TV Tubes
description: The RCA Corporation is increasing the price on color television picture tubes sold in the United States equipment and renewal markets, and the company indicated yesterday that there might be a second increase before the end of the year. R.C.A.'s electronics components division, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of television tubes, said there would be a 2 per cent increase on the price of color tubes sold to TV set manufacturers.

title: Atlantic Beach Is Embroiled in Bitter Controversy Over Sludge
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., Aug. 14  The ocean made Atlantic Beach what it is todaya sanctuary of private homes and cabana clubs and tanned healthy  looking residents.

title: Detroit B. C. Four Leads Qualifiers
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y. Aug. 16The Detroit Boat Club upset the University of California and Dartmouth in the Senior  Four  with  Coxswain event to lead the quailfiers in the 98th annual national rowing challipionships on the Orchard Beach Lagoon today.

title: Notes on People
description: Now that Richard M. Nixon, its intended beneficiary, is no longer in office, the National Committee for Fairness to the President will train its guns on a new target, according to its founder, Rabbi Baruch Korff. The commitee, said Rabbi Korff, will focus on the giants of the media, who, he believes, are fearful of history judging them as assassins. The Korff group will campaign for what the rabbi called curbs on the media. Asked for his committee's ultimate goal, Rabbi Korff said, for those leftists and liberals to go to hell.

title: Andres A. Valdespino Dead; LatinAmerican Scholar
description: Dr. Andres A. Valdespino, associate professor of Romance languages at Hunter College since 1969, died yesterday in. Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, after having suffered a stroke. He was 50 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: ABERNATHY GROUP ENDS CONVENTION
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16The Southern Christian Leadership Conference, beset by financial problems, ended today its 17th annual convention, which had drawn no more than 300 persons.

title: Grain Exports a Threat to Consumers
description: A dramatic rise in export orders for grain and soybeans in recent weeks is expected to do more damage to the consumer's budget than the recent drought in the Midwest.

title: Ankara Reports Troops Have Won Their Goals Asks Negotiations
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 16Premier Bulent Ecevit said today that Turkey, having agreed to a ceasefire in Cyprus after all present military objectives had been achieved, was now prepared to resume negotiations in Geneva with Greece and Britain on the political future of the island.

title: ARAB FUNDS LEAVE BRITAIN FOR U.S.
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP)Arab oil money is being pumped out of a weak British economy for reinvestment in the United States, bankers said today.

title: Red Cross Will Double 20Man Team on Cyprus
description: GENEVA, Aug. 16The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that in the next few days it would double the 20man team it now has on Cyprus.

title: Madrid Orders Newspaper Not to Publish for 2 Weeks
description: MALAGA, Spain, Aug. 16 (UPI)The newspaper Sol said today that it would not publish for two weeks starting tumorrow an orders of the Ministry of Infomation.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Girl Finds Way to Write in Dark
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Becky J. Schroeder, who is 12 years old, has invented what is formally entitled a luminescent backing sheet for writing in the dark. The inventor, who is just entering the eighth grade in Toledo, Ohio, will receive Patent 3,832,556 on Aug. 27. Her first application was filed nearly two Years ago. Statistics are not kept on inventors' ages, but Becky must be one of the youngest. Her father, Charles Fr Schroeder, is a patent attorney with the OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation in Toledo and is an inventor himself.

title: Benefit to Animals Seen In 55M.P.H. Limit
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)The 55 mileanhour speed limit will save the lives of 100 million animals this year, the Animal Protection Institute of America said today.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
FELTING GOES ON CLOSE TO SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  Persistent shelling and sporadic ground fighting continued northwest of here today after Communist tanks advanced closer to Saigon's city limits than they ever, had, reports from the field said.

title: Pop: Vignettes in Song
description: If this country had a healthier theater situation, a man like Oscar Brown Jr. would easily find his niche. As it is, Mr. Brown, now 47 years old, has had a curiously varied career, shifting among acting, playwriting, composing, singing, teaching and politics. Now, through Sunday, he is headlining an ostensibly musical program at the Bottom Line.

title: DRIVE COMPLETED
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Saturday, Aug. 17  Turkey's invasion forces completed the division of Cyprus into two areas yesterday and declared a ceasefire.

title: Sports Today.
description: BASEBALL

title: Borg Upset By Vilas at Toronto Net
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina the hottest player on the professional tennis circuit, over whelmed Bjorn Borg of Sweden, 76, 60, to advance today to the semifinals of the Canadian open tennis championships.

title: The Race for Lieutenant Governor: 3 Democrats in Search of Attention
description: Not everyone is as blunt as the young woman sitting on the grass in the Central Park Sheep Meadow who, puzzling over a pamphlet that Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri had just thrust into her hand, looked up at the smiling candidate and said: Lieutenant Governor? I didn't know we had one.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS WITHDRAWAL NOW OF NIXON RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 President Ford, acting through his new legal counsel, ordered today that all of Richard M. Nixon's tape recordings and other documents be held in White House custody until legal issues Involving the Watergate affair were resolved.

title: 2 Newsmen Wounded By Gunfire on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  An American and a West German, both newsmen, were wounded today when their car was hit by gunfire near the Nicosia airport.

title: Opera: Boheme, With Sets and All Given in Park
description: Vincent La Seiva puts on opera wherever he canchurches, hotel ballroomsand on Thursday night he and the New York Grand. Opera Company moved into the bandshell on Central Park's Mall, presenting Puccini's La Bohme. In doing so, he created a precedent.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: U.S. COURT SUSPENDS SMITH'S JAIL TERM
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 16 (UPI)California's Fourth District Court of Appeal has annulled an indefinite jail term imposed on San Diego financier C. Amholt Smith for contempt of court, court records showed today.

title: BROKER SLAYS SON, WOUNDS DAUGHTER
description: LITTLE SILVER, Aug. 16 A 44yearold stockbroker apparently distraught over his wife's impending death from cancer, allegedly shot one of his children to death and wounded another as they slept in their beds this morning.

title: It Didn't Work
description: So many people have announced that the system worked in the recent Presidential affair that we are in danger of believing it.

title: Mrs. Carner Leads Golf BY Shot on 68 at St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL,Aug. 16 (AP)The leading moneywinner on the 1974 women's professional golf tour, JoAnne Carrier of Lake Worth, Fla., scored an eagle and four birdies on the front nine today on the way to a firstround 68 and a onestroke advantage in the $35,000 St. Paul women's. tournament.

title: Only 14 at Tombs Choose Transfer to Rikers Island
description: Only 14 of the 261 inmates at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men who have been given the option of staying at the outmoded jail or transferring to newer facilities on Rikers Island have chosen to leave.

title: JOSEPH F. RUTH, 58, OF WESTERN ELECTRIC
description: Joseph F. Ruth, general manager of Western Electric's plant design and construction organization, died Thursday at his home, 3 Hampton Road in Scarsdale, N. Y., after a brief illness. His age was 58.

title: MOZAMBIQUE FRONT MEETS WITH SOARES
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Mario Soares of Portugal began talks today with the Mozambique Liberation Front on the transfer of power in Mozambique.

title: College Names President
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Dr. Walter L. Smith, 39 years old, provost at Hillsborough Community College in Tampa, Fla., has been named president of Roxbury Community College. He will begin his $30,000ayear job Sept.. 16, the Massachusetts Board of Regional and Community Colleges said today.

title: The Philosophy of Power
description: ANKARATurkey's immensely popular Premier, Blent Ecevit, acknowledges two men as having both influenced him, the military heroes Kemal Atatrk and Ismet Inn. Yet the book most, admired is the collection of prison letters from Pandit Nehru to his daughter Indira, now Indian Prime Minister. He says: If I had to choose one book to recommend to someone going to the moonor prisonthat would be it.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF; OTG SHOWS DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market moved lower yesterday for the sixth straight day. Volume on the Amex was the lowest in more than nine years.

title: Bargains in Justice
description: Manhattan District Attorney Richard Kuh has issued a sweeping directive to govern future handling of plea bargaining by his office. The order's stated aim is to achieve consistency in prosecutions and to insure that plea bargaining is conducted prudently in an effort give better protection to the community.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection an nounced a comprehensive waterqualitymanagement study in northeastern New Jersey. Commissioner David J. Bardin said the Louis Berger and Associates of East Orange and Ralph M. Field and Associates of Westport, Conn., had been retained as part of a $700,000 twoyear project of the United States Environmental protection Agency and the state agency.

title: Holder Approves Dow Bid for General Crude Oil
description: ST. DAVIDS, Pa., Aug. 16 (Reuters)The Dow Chemical Company said today that its proposed acquisition of the General Crude Oil Company had been approved by the company's majority shareholder, the Glenmede Trust, trustee of the Pew Memorial Trust, which holds 63 per cent of General Crude's common stock.

title: Two Cultures Clash In Canadian Arctic
description: INUVIK, Northwest TerritoriesThis raw frontier town, where the sidewalks are rough boards and the buildings have to be on stilts to avoid melting the sensitive permafrost, is the scene of a spirited struggle to establish Eskimo rights as white domination increases in the Canadian Arctic.

title: HighestPaying Jobs Ranked for Each Sex
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Women lawyers make more than women judges and both make about $10,000 a year less than male lawyers, according to data prepared by the Bureau of tabor Statistics.

title: Vengeance And Tortuga Win Cruise
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 16.  The Centerport (L. I.), Yacht Club's Vengeance and Tortuga, representing Sagamore Y. C. of Oyster Bay, L. I., were winners of the International Offshore Rule Divisions I and II in the Junior Yacht Racing Association's Dorade trophy cruise series on Long Island Sound which ended today off Riverside Y C. The skippers were Robert Gentzlinger on Vengeance and John Cosulich on Tortuga.

title: World Football League
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO CURB COAST ADS FOR MILK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would take action against a California advertising campaign in which athletes and film stars promote milk as a kind of preventative medicine that everyone needs to drink,

title: MinorityJournalists' Program Closes
description: The nation's major training program for minoritygroup journalists held an emotional final graduation ceremony yesterday at which its founder said that waning interest by the news media and financial backers had caused the end Of the program.

title: New Boys of Summer Feeling Pressure Again
description: It's, not the Ides of March the Los Angeles Dodgers fear. It's the night shades of August.

title: South Street Is More Than Fish and Old Ships
description: Carmen Toranzo sells pink silk sateen slips from the funky forties, Alex Dorin sells cast iron bits of old fire escapes, Danilo DeAngelis sells custommade wooden toilet seats, and Roy Albanese sells so many sausage heroes on a Sunday afternoon that he sometimes has to make a run for more bread in his bananacolored Cadillac.

title: Research Center Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) The Army. Materiel Acquisition Review Committee has recommended the establishment of an armament research and development center at the Aberdeen, Md., proving ground. Functions recommended for transfer to Aberdeen are conducted at Philadelphia's Frankford Arsenal; Picatinny Arsenal in Dover, N. J.! the Watervliet, N. Y., arsenal and the Rock Island, Ill., arsenal.

title: SAMUELS ASSAILS CAREY ON FUNDS
description: Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that Representative Hugh L. Carey, his rival for the Democratic nomination for Governor, had violated the spirit of the state campaignfinance law by accepting more than $1million in loans from his brother before the law went into effect on June 1.

title: Dickie a Line Coach
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Emerson Dickie, an outstanding end at Boston College until his graduation in 1956, was named offensive line coach today by Northeastern University football team.

title: WouldBe Hijacker's Term
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP)A man who tried to hi jack an empty airliner in May was sentenced today to spend 15 years in the Apalachee Correctional Institute. He is Ernest Eugene Smith, 20 years old, of Waterloo, Iowa.

title: World Team Tennis
description: (Includes matches of Aug. 15.)

title: Mrs. Camer Leads Golf By on 68
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 16 (AP)The leading moneywinner on the 1974 women's professional golf tour, JoAnne Carner of Lake Worth, Fla., scored an eagle and four birdies on the front nine today on the way to a firstround 68 and a onestroke advantage in the $35,000 St. Paul women's tournament.

title: Mariner Loses 2 Cup Tests
N.C. State Five Wins
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 16 (AP)  The North Carolina State basketball team, led by Mark Moeller's 19 points, routed the Bangkok Bank squad, 11680, tonight to remain undefeated on its tour of the Far East.

title: Part of Chinatown Tenement Falls
description: Twenty families were removed from a 19thcentury tenement on James Street in Chinatown yesterday afternoon after a corner of the brick building collapsed.

title: Spa Record. Forecast for 2 Top Stars
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16Chris Evert may not win the Travers tomorrowthe odds favor the Darby Dan Farm's Little Currentbut Carl Rosen's superb filly is quite likely to be a positive factor in a recordbreaking occurrence.

title: Stockton 2 Strokes Ahead After Second Straight 65
description: WETHERSFIELD Conn., Aug. 16 (AP)Dave Stockton, retaining his excellent putting touch from the first round, shot, a 65 for the second straight day and opened up a twostroke lead today in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open golf tournament.

title: Lockheed Unit Gets 1.3Billion contract For a Navy Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Navy awarded a $1.3billion contract today to the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company to start production of a new 4,500milerange Trident missile to be fired from submarines.

title: Prosecutor Says Two Jersey Girls Died of Suffocation
description: The Bergen County Medical Examiner has established that suffocation was the cause of death of two North Bergen teenaged girls whose bodies were found in Montvale Wednesday morning, the Bergen County Prosecutor, Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., said yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Turkey's invasion forces completed the division of Cyprus into two areas and declared a ceasefire. They had used some 30,000 men supported by tanks, artillery, Planes and warships to achieve what they had failed to win at the peace talks in Geneva. When the ceasefire was declared in effect at 6 P.M.. (noon Friday, New York time) the Turks had reached their objective of partitioning Cyprus into autonomous Turkish Cypriote and Greek Cypriote areas on the 14th anniversary of the independence of Cyprus from Britain. [1:8.]

title: NEWS INDEX
COPPER STRIKE NEARS END WITH NEW PACT
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 16 (AP) A nationwide copper strike that lasted 32 days and put nearly 23,000 workers out of work has virtually ended, with agreements on new threeyear contracts by the country's largest producers.

title: Police in Poughkeepsie Investigate Three Fires
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP)The police are investigating three suspicious fires today that struck businesses along Route 9 here, one of which heavily, damaged a bakery and a beverage store.

title: Subpoena for Nixon Delayed as Air Mail Replaces Teletype
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Former President Richard M. Nixon is not likely to receive his subpoena to testify in the Watergate coverup trial until next week, a spokesman for the director of United States marshals said today.

title: GAS PRICES HERE AMONG U.S. HIGHEST
description: Gasoline prices hi the New York area dropped Slightly this week, but they continued to be among the highest in the country, according to the Automobile Club of New York.

title: Raiders Top Lions, 4110, For 3 in Row
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP)4, rookie running back, Harold Hart, scored two touchdowns, giving him six in the exhibition season, to lead the Oakand Raiders to a 4110 National Football League preseason victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

title: Girl Swimmer, 16, Sets Record on Lake Ontario
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16 (AP) Cindy Nicholas, a 16yearold Canadian, swam 32 miles today from Youngstown, N. Y., to Toronto, trimming three hours off the previous record for the swim across Lake Ontario.

title: Kissinger Says He'd Go to Cyprus but Would Prefer Talks Here
description: ATHENS, Aug. 16The Greek Premier rejected tonight a Turkish proposal for resumption of the Cyprus peace talks in Geneva and an American invitation to visit Washington to discuss the crisis with President Ford.

title: Borg Upset By Vilas at Toronto Net
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina the hottest player on the pro fessional tennis circuit, over whelmed Bjorn Borg, o?? Sweden, 76, 60, to advance today to the semifinals o?? the Canadian open tennis championships.

title: POST AND PRINTERS IN TENTATIVE PACT
description: The New York Post and Typographical Union 6 have reached a tentative agreement on a contract running until March 30, 1984, that is similar to earlier pacts negotiated with The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: Music: Demus and Amati
description: Joerg Demus is an intelligent pianist with a modest but adequate keyboard technique, and the Aniati Quartet is an ensemble that plays with refinement and respect for the music at hand. So, if the combination did not exactly strike sparks of excitement at Thursday night's Mostly Mozart program in Avery Fisher Hall, the result was nonetheless enjoyable chamber music of a lowkey sort.

title: More Natural Gas in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Soviet geologists have discovered another large reserve of natural gas in the oilrich region of eastern, Siberia, Tass, the Soviet agency press, reported today. Situated near the intersection of the Lena and Vilyui. Rivers, prospected reserves approached 34 million cubic feet a day.

title: Joseph Durso
description: A little after 5 o'clock in the morning, Angelo Dundeeand Bundini drive down the road from the motel to the seven log cabins clustered around Aunt Coretta's Kitchen on the Pennsylvania mountaintop. They head straight for the gymnasium, rouse the sleek, sleeping man on the pullaway cot and, a few minutes later, Muhummad Ali stretches and yawns and faces the world for another day.

title: Margarita Gets Post
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Bob Margarita, a star running back for Brown University and the Chicago Bears in the nineteenforties, was named today receiver coach for the Boston University football team.

title: Court Panel Refuses To Disbar Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters)A threejudge disciplinary panel of Federal District Court ruled today that the disbarment of former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, who pleaded guilty in May to lying to a Senate investigating committee, was not warranted.

title: Homer by Munson Tops White Sox in Wild Opener
description: Thurman Munson's dramatic tworun, twocut homer in the bottom of the 13th inning gave the Yankees a 98 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the opener of a marathon twilightnight doubleheader last night at Shea Stadium. But in the second game, which just beat the 1 A.M. curfew, the White sox used one explosive inning to achieve an even break, winning 42.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Indiana Pacers the American Basketball Association obtained a restraining order today barring the New York Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association from negotiating with George McGinnis, the Pacers' star player.

title: E.P.A. ASKS EASING OP STATES' CURBS ON AIR POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today to let states pollute their air, if they decide industrial and economic growth is more important.

title: Notes on People
description: Nov that Richard M. Nixon, it Intended benafitaary, is no longer in office, the National Committee for Fairness to the President will train its guns on a new target, ac. cording to its founder, Rabbi Baruch Korff. The commitee, Said Rabbi Korff, will focus on the giants of the media, who, he believes, are fearful of history judging them as assassins. The Korff group will campaign for what the will called curbs on the media. Asked for his committee's ultimate goal, Rabbi Koff said, for those leftists and liberals to go to hell.

title: CORN PRICES RISE; SOYBEANS HIDE
description: Corn futures reversed direction yesterday, advancing the 10centabushel limit on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Outlook for Cotton Harvest Is Good as Demand Dips
description: With the start of harvesting of some part of the nation's cotton crop, the question uppermost in the minds of textile mill executives, cotton brokers, shippers and others is how much cotton will be available this year and how much it will cost.

title: Ervin Links Watergate To the Lust for Power
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 16 (AP). The men who brought about Watergate and then tried to cover it up were consumed by a lust for power, Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today.

title: Buying Office Tries a Vacation Closing
description: A New York buying office, SteinbergKass, Inc., recently took a step highly unusual in its field, closing for a twoweek summer vacation, creating a controversy in the process.

title: DR. KARL APPLBAUM
description: Dr. Karl Applbaum, a rabbi who had served as a chaplain in the Army until his retirement from the active reserve as a full colonel in 1970, died yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived at 13680 71st Road, Flushing, Queens. Dr. Appl baum, founder and associate rabbi of the Avenue M Jewish Center, Brooklyn, was also a lawyer.

title: Minister Under Pressure
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 12  He is a slight, softspoken man with an easy smile and a degree from a theological seminary, but there are plainclothes policemen in his office many hours of the day and others who follow him home at night.

title: DEAD FISH SAVES A CITY OF 32,000
description: YUMA, Ariz., Aug. 16 A passerby's observation of dead fish on a canal bank has been credited with saving this city's, water system from pesticide poisoning last week.

title: 2 More Air Crash Dead
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 16 (UPI)The number of fatalities in the crash of a Venezuelan turboprop airliner Wednesday was put at 49 today with the discovery that two 18yearold girls had hitched a ride in the crew's quarters. The two were friends of one of the stewardesses on the Linea Aeropostal Venezolana Viscount and were headed for Margarita, where the plane crashed.

title: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC SWEARS IN BALAGUER
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  Dr. Joaquin Balaguer was sworn in today for his third consecutive term as President of the Dominican Republic after a night shaken by 20 bomb explosions in the capital.

title: Rail Freight Tonnage Down
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that freight traffic on United States, railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 2.3 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 503,277 cars, 5.7 per cent below last year

title: Pink Driver's Licenses Due
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP)A new form of driver's license will be issued to New Jersey motorists starting at the end of this month, Motor Vehicle Director John A. Waddington announced today. The new licenses will be mostly pink with tan trim, Mr. Waddington said the state would save $25,000 a year, because the new licenses would cost less to print. He said that dirver's licenses presently in use would remain valid until they expired. He said it would be three years before all drivers had the new licences.

title: 5 Malaria Cases Found; California Areas Sprayed
description: The diagnoses of five cases of malaria this summer in a three county area in northern Sacramento Valley have led California officials to move to prevent a smoldering brush fire from becoming a forest fire.

title: Kissinger Says He'd Go to Cyprus but Would Prefer Talks Here
description: ATHENS, Aug. 16The Greek Premier rejected tonight a Turkish proposal for resumption of the Cyprus peace talks in Geneva and an American invitation to visit Washington to discuss the crisis with President Ford.

title: Grain Exports a Threat to Consumers
description: A dramatic rise in export orders for grain and soybeans in recent weeks is expected to do more damage to the consumer's budget than the recent drought in the Midwest.

title: Perjury Hearing Delayed
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (UPI) A hearing for two lawyers indicted for perjury on the ground they lied about the source of an article written by a reporter during the Charles Manson murder trial was postponed today until Aug. 26. Superior Court Judge Earl Broady said that he had not had time to read the briefs submitted by the lawyers, Vincent T. Bugliosi and Daye Shinn.

title: CHURCH UNIT ASSAILS SEOUL AND MANILA
description: BERLIN, Aug. 16A resolution charging the Governments of South Korea and the Philippines with abuse of power, repression and abridgment of justice and freedom and calling for the release of any persons detained in violation of human rights was adopted today by the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches.

title: Sheet Metal Workers Lift Threat of Railroad Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)  The National Mediation Board said today that the Sheet Metal Workers Union tied lifted a strike threat against the nation's railroads until Jana 1.

title: IRAQ AND JAPAN IN $1BILLION PACT
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Iraq and Japan signed a $1billion agreement today providing for Japanese credits to Iraq for economic development projects in exchange for crude oil and other oil products, the Foreign Ministry announced here.

title: Bernstein, Philharmonic Perform in New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 16 (UPI)Leonard Bernstein conducted his first major concert in 18 months when he led the New York Philharmonic at its opening concert here tonight.

title: Said Saphire, Yiddish Writer On Forward, a Novelist, dies
description: Saul Saphire, author of more than 100 novels serialized in Yiddish magazines and newspapers, died Thursday of cancer in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Ford to Speak in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug 16 (AP)Ohio State University officials confirmed today that President Ford would fulfill a commitment to address the university's summer commencement on Aug. 30. The commitment was made when Mr. Ford was Vice President.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 23

title: Citizen Nixon
description: The former White House loyalist, John D. Ehrlichman, ha's now forced the issue for his onetime chief. His subpoena of Richard M. Nixon as a defense witness makes it virtually inevitable that the former. President will be summoned into court to give testimony under oath and submit to crossexamination about the Watergate conspiracy.

title: GATEWAY INSURANCE ADMITS INSOLVENCY
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP)The state announced today that the financially troubled Gateway Insurance Company of Philadelphia had agreed to sign an order of insolvency next week in Pennsylvania.

title: Civic Banality
description: Stolidity has supplanted imagination at City Hall. In persisting in its determination to demolish the Tweed Courthouse, the Beame administration is turning the clock back ten years.

title: 2 POLICE OFFICERS SUED FOR $IMILLION
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a milliondollar damage suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn against two police officers who shot a 26yearold man who was later indicted and then acquitted of charges that he attempted tol murder them.

title: Seoul Connects Suspect to Communists
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 16 South Korean investigators began today to connect the wouldbe assassin of President Park Chung Hee with several of the President's adversaries the Communists, his 1971 opponent in the presidential election, and the Japanese.

title: What Course Cotton?
description: How much cotton will be available this year and how much it will cost are the questions uppermost in the minds of textile mill executives, cotton brokers and shippers as harvesting begins on the nation's cotton crop. Details on Page 31.

title: South Korea Keeps Labor Costs Down Through Exploitation of Work Force
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 12  It is over 100 degrees in Shop 349 these summer days, and the 20 teenage girls who work in the crowded, airless loft in Seouls Peace Market garment district get little relief from the one tiny fan.

title: Pink Driver's Licenses Due
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP)A new form of driver's license will be issued to New Jersey motorists starting at the end of this month, Motor Vehicle Director John A. Waddington announced today. The new licenses will be mostly pink with tan trim. Mr. Waddington said the state would save $25,000 a year, because the new licenses would cost less to print. He said that dirver's licenses presently in use would remain valid until they expired. He said it would be three years before all drivers had the new licences.

title: Hero of Williamsburg Siege Given A $5,000 Award for Valor by Beanie
description: The hero of the Williamsburg siege, Leo G. Riccio, who led nine hostages held by four gunmen to safety from his Brooklyn sporting goods store, yesterday, was awarded the $5,000 Carl M. Loeb Jr. Award for citizen valor.

title: Direct Use of Soy Protein Cut by Taste for Meat
description: HOUSTON, Aug, 14If the world's human population is increasingly starving for protein, that is not apparent In the marketing of the single most efficient protein sourcethe soybean.

title: DRIVE COMPLETED
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Saturday, Aug. 17  Turkey's invasion forces completed the division of Cyprus into two areas yesterday and declared a ceasefire.

title: Lawyer Gets 3 Years for Bribery; Sought Secret Prosecution Data
description: A disbarred lawyer was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for attempting to obtain by bribery secret documents from the United States Attorney's office here.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS WITHDRAWAL NOW OF NIXON RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 President Ford, acting through his new legal counsel, ordered today that all of Richard M. Nixon's tape recordings and other documents be held in White House custody until legal issues Involving the Watergate affair were resolved.

title: E.P.A. ASKS EASING OF STATEs' CURBS ON AIR POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today to let states pollute their air, If they decide industrial and economic growth is more important.

title: Contract Awards
description: The AllisChaimer Corporation announced yesterday that its hydroturbine division in York, Pa., has obtained a $25.3million order from the Army Corps of Engineers for six hydraulic turbines to be installed in the Little Goose and Lower. Granite power plants on the Snake River in Washington.

title: People and Business
description: Alan G. Dustin, was named by trustees of the Boston and Maine Corporation yesterday to succeed Paul W. Cherington, as president and chief executive officer of the railroad. Mr. Dustin, who is 45, has been serving as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the B. & M. since July 1, 1973. His appointment is subject to approval of the Federal District Court in Boston.

title: Collapse of Company in Britain Strands 50,000 Tourists Abroad
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Angry vacationers crowded a British airport today as a huge airlift got under way to rescue 50,000 other tourists stranded around the world by the collapse of Court Line, Britain's biggest packagetour company.

title: It Is Too Late for Declarations, for Popular Appeals

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board turned down today a request that it intervene to halt next week's scheduled shutdown of coal mines across the nation.

description: SHREWSBURY, N.J., Aug, 16 (AP)Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of. Arizona, said at a local Democratic party dinner here yesterday that he was testing his prospects for race for the Presidency in 1976.

description: NEW HAVEN, Aug 16Pro football's 14day coolingoff period has salvaged some of the glamour for tomorrow's skirmish at 2 o'clock between the Giants and Jets at Yale Bowl. But not much.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Senate passed a $21.2billion appropriation bill today with nearly twothirds of the money earmarked for the Veterans Administration.

description: A single gunman tried to assassinate President Park Chung of South Korea last week but missed the dictator and killed his wife instead. description: The A.&P. expects to reopen all of its 550 stores in the metropolitan area Tuesday as a result of the ratification, yesterday of a threeyear contract by 18,300 of its union employes, ending a fiveday strike against the food chain.

description: PRINCETON  The names of 24 Princeton University alumni who died while serving during this country's involvement in Southeast Asia are being inscribed in the Memorial Room of Nassau Hall.

description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 17 (UPI)  Chief City Court Judge John T. Desantis died today in Memorial Medical Center after suffering an apparent heart attack at his home. He was 60 years old.

title: Numismatics
description: NUMISMATIC collectors know that a turn of history can add a great new dimension to a coin, medal or banknote. When the Gerald R. Ford Vice Presidential commemorative medal was offered to the public last January, thousands of silver and bronze pieces were sold for approximately half a million dollars.

title: Allegations on Saigon Denied by U. S. Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17Graham A. Martin, the United States Ambassador to Saigon, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on July 25 that the embassy had carefully examined allegations about political prigoners in South Vietnam and we found no one in prison who could be regarded as a political prisoner.

title: Aldo Palazzeschi Is Dead at 89; Wrote Psychological CloseUps
description: ROME, Aug. 17Aldo Palazzeschi, an author whose works made him wellknown during the nineteenthirties for the closeup psychological study or provincial portrait, died today in a clinic here. He was 89 years old.

description: To the Editor: I and my family have been attending the national tennis championships, at Forest Hills for the last 15 years.

title: Mayor Gets Plumbing Order
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP)The city health department has given Mayor Joseph R. Bianco 30 days to install additional plumbing in an apartment he rents to a family of four. The health code enforcement officer, John Tafi, said the apartment. lacked hot water, a bathroom sink and a bathtub, all required by law.

title: Residents Gaining in Battle Over Park
description: After years of angry controversy, it appeared last week that legal action instituted by a group of Queens residents had moved them closer to their longstanding aim: Halting the use of Cunningham Park as a storage area for municipal vehicles and material.
