description: Lowry Igleheart, a recent graduate of Smith a College, and Aubrey Houston Keach Jr., who graduated from Vanderbilt University, plan to be married next July.

title: How Player Scores So Well in Golf: Every Shot Is a Separate Little Game
description: There is a story, probably not apocryphal, about Gary Player standing on the practice green and stroking a hundred consecutive onefoot putts. All of them were going in the hole, of course.

title: Baker Takes Governor's Cup at Red Bank Powerboat Regatta
description: RED BANK, N. J., Aug. 17  Like Secretariat in the Belmont, Stakes last year, George Baker pulled far away from the rest of the pack early in the Governor's Cup hydroplane race today on the Navesink River and crossed the finish line before any of his competitors had even reached the final turn In the oval course.

title: Courageous Victor by 2 Seconds
description: NEWPORT, R. L, Aug. 17Courageous and Intrepid, the two leading candidates for defense of the America's Cup, raced each other for four hours today on Rhode Island Sound and at the finish Courageous was ahead by two seconds. It was the third closest decision in the annals of America's Cup racing, which goes back 123 years.

title: Beame Approves Rail Spur Through Park to Kennedy
description: Ending a long and frequently bitter controversy among local government agencies, Mayor Beanie decided yesterday to permit construction of a 3,000foot rail spur through Forest Park in Queens to complete proposed masstransit line from Jamaica, Queens, to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Mr. Ford's Week...
description: In homespun American idiom, President Ford set forth to Congress and the nation last week the three themes that seemingly will characterize his Administration: personal simplicity, philosophical conservatism and an openness to diverse people and differing ideas.

title: Tara Hill Captures Jump Title
description: FREEHOLD, N.J. Aug. 17Mrs. Carol Hofmann Thompson, the former United States Equestrian Team star, dominated the preliminary and junior jumper divisions today at the Monmouth County horse show.

title: Barbara S. Williams Wed to W,M. Dunn 2d
description: Barbara Sally Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Philip Williams of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to William Merritt Dunn 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bain Dunn of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Robert B. Cunningham performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

title: Jeanne Brennan Wed
description: Jeanne Beatrice Brennan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Brennan of the Bronx, was married 1 yesterday afternoon to Arthur J. Kenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond T. Kenney of Eltingville, Staten Island. The Rev. Peter R. Pilarski performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady Star of the Sea on Governors Island. The bride is an alumna of Lehman College. Mr. Kenney, a graduate of Fairfield University, plays center and forward on the Sporting Club Moderne basketball team in Le Mans, France.

title: Wendy Allen Has Nuptials
description: Wendy Fahye Allan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stuart Allan of Longmeadow, Mass., and Governor's Island, Gilford, N. H., was married yesterday afternoon to Clifton Charles Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles McClure Johnson of Wilbraham, Mass.

title: Gila Bend, Ariz., Where One Can Be Miserable on a Normal 115Degree Summer Day
description: GILA BEND, Ariz.When the sun rose one recent Saturday, several Papago Indians were waiting patiently for the Owl Bar and Buffet to open so they could get inside to begin a The Talk day of cooling off. In Gila Bend, of which in the sumGila Bend mertime is one of the hottest towns in the United States, cooling off is drinking beer under the airconditioning in one of the town's five bars.

title: Newark Still Seeks CableTV System
description: NEWARKThis city, the largest in the state, is seeking a commercial television company to construct a cable system for its 382,000 residents. The deadline for applications is Sept. 1.

title: Photography
description: QUESTION: What is the difference between Peeping Tom and a paparazzo?

title: TheWorld/continued
description: GENEVAThe opening of new SovietAmerican nuclear missile talks, which Secretary of State Henry Kissinger announced last June in Moscow, has now been put off until after Labor Day. Mr. Kissinger's own busy schedule, delayed by impeachment politics, has not permitted him to devote much time to the subject. In addition, delay may be attributed to his attempts to reconcile Pentagon and State Department differences on the United States negotiating position.

title: S. C. Graham Weds Melanie Roome
description: In Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Melanie Lawrence Roome became the bride of Stephen Charles Graham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Seymour Flinn.

title: Stendhal
description: By Joanna Richardson. Illustrated. 344 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $10.

title: Burger King Planned For Heights Protested
description: The effort of Brooklyn Heights residents to prevent a Burger King franchise from being established on Montague, Street is the latest of several skirmishes in New York and in other cities in which communities are fighting the intrusion of fastfood restaurants into their neighborhoods. Ten days ago, for example, the McDonald's corppration announced that it would not open an outlet at Lexington Avenue and 66th Street in Manhattan because of community protests.

title: Soap Box Derby Is Won by Brother Of '73 Champion
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) Curt Yarborough of Elk Grove, Calif., the 11yearold brother of last year's champion, flashed under the checkered flag in a photo finish today to become the 37th AllAmerican Soap Box Derby champion.

title: Alabama Attorney General Asks Ban on Coal From South Africa
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 17The Attorney General of Alabama formally asked the United States Customs Commissioner in Washington this week to prohibit southeastern electricity producers from importing coal from South Africa on the ground that the coal was produced by forced labor.

title: They Put Their Best Ideas on Paper
description: Private Papers is not the title of Henry Kissinger's diary, an Agatha Christie thriller, or Queen Victoria's love letters to Prince Albert.

title: AuthorIllustrator Finds Subjects Near at Hand
description: GLADSTONE  A man who can write, It's so boring just being a hippopotamus, must have humor, imagination and whimsy. Above all, he must love children and animals.

title: U.S. Jet Hit by Rebel Fire In Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 17 (UPI)Rebel gunners hit an American C130 cargo plane over Angkor Wat today in the first such incident since the United states halted its bombing of Cambodia a year ago, reports from the field said.

title: Taiwanese Win Title
description: GARY, Ind., Aug. 17 (AP) Pingtung, Taiwan, continued that country's domination of the Senior Little League baseball World Series today, beating Charlotte, N.C., 51, for the championship, the third straight by Taiwanese teams. The Pingtung team scored four of its runs in the third inning, on two hits, two walks and a Charlotte, error.

title: Sports Complex Starts to Take Shape
description: EAST RUTHERFORD Work on the 588acre Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands is now moving at a pace that makes it possible to believe that the New York Giants will be able to play their 1976 football games in the new stadium.

title: Stamp
description: THREE new airmail stamps, presenting stylized variations of flight, are being issued by the United Nations on Sept. 16 to provide for higher international rates and to retire from service an 11year veteran airmail issue.

title: Record Rainfall Here
description: A record 2.871 inches of rain for an. Aug. 17 Jell on the metropolitan area in two storms yesterday. Highway flooding delayed traffic thoughout the city subways were slowed, and two IND trains were stuck the East River tunnel when water over the third rail caused a shortcircuit. Details on Rage 18.

title: The Art World Today: Manufactures, Dealers and Investors
description: AT this year's annual formal meeting of the Art Dealers Association. of America and their guests, a New York art critic spoke briefly to the general effect that dealers have superceded artists, critics and even such proselytizing institutions as the Museum of Modern Art as tastemakers to the 20th century. The dealers hardly seemed bowled over by the news; certainly they were not offended.

title: Holding Pattern Wins Travers by a Head
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17Holding Pattern held the lead exactly where it counted, in the final few yards of the Travers Stakes, and proceeded to register an upset victory in the 105th running of the famous event today. While a rain soaked crowd of 30,652 looked on, Mike Miceli guided the colt to a head success over the favored Little Current, with the courageous Chris Evert, the only filly in the field of 11, finishing third.

title: Sheila Miner Wolff Jersey Bride Of Edward McCrossin 3d, Lawyer
description: Sheila Miner Wolff, daughter of Mrs. Ronald Webb McCarthy of Rumson, N. J., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward John McCrossin 3d, who is with the New York law firm of Miller & McCarthy. He is the son of Mrs. McCrossin Jr. of Red Bank, N. J., and and the late Mr. MCCrossin.

title: Courses for the Mature Adult
description: CRANFORD  A special full  credit program for mature adults only, a project that is designed to open the classroom door to housewives and other adults who may feel locked in their kitchens and jobs, will be offered this fall at Union College.

title: Inside Talk
description: Today, while captains of capitalism and veteran antiCommunists are busy doing business with the Russians and telling us what a great guy Secretary Brezhnev is, many former critics of America's antiCommunist crusade come close to criticizing the Nixon Administration for being soft on Russia. Such confusion reminds us how powerful and simple was the consensus that came into existence in the late 1940's and continued to provide a foreign policy framework until Lyndon Johnson's Vietnam disaster in the late 1960's.

title: Harpist Ranges From Bach to Beatles
description: Not even the fingers of one hand are necessary to count the harpists who have used jazz in their repertories. Casper Reardon was the pioneer of jazz harp in the nineteenthirties: Robert Maxwell tried it after World War II, and in recent year Daphne Hellman has been mixing jazz and classical material. All three are classically trainedis there any other way to learn the harp?and, to some degree, they had to fight that training when they turned to jazz.

title: Golfs' Big Boys Back for Rich Westchester Classic
description: The pro golf tour, which breezed through here in June for the United States Open at Winged Foot, will make another stop in the metropolitan area this week. The occasion this time is the eighth Westchester Golf Classic from Thursday through Sunday at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison.

description: WHITE PLAINS; Aug. 17 Residents of Purchase, trying to incorporate their wealthy and onceexclusive area as a village, have gone to court in hopes of blocking the Town of Harrison's countermove against their secession threat.

description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 17 (AP)  Dave Stockton clipped two more strokes off par with a 69 today and expanded his lead to three strokes in the third round of the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr. Greater Hartford open golf tournament. His total of 199 is 14 shots under par.

description: CUMMAQUID, Mass.For James P. Gillilan, former assistant chief engineer at General Motors, fulfillment in retirement is found in the home.

description: Elizabeth Ann Keating and Frank Canfield Schroeder 3d were married yesterday afternoon in the Wayzata (Minn.) Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Harold G. S. King.

title: The Family Fight and NATO
description: LONDON  Not foe the first time, Cyprus has opened a rift in the NATO lute. What can be said of an alliance whose individual members step to the brink of war with each each other and go on to pull their forces out of the alliance or divert them to fight a national battle? What collective defense is possible when particular countries, in pursuit of national goals, turn their military backs on a common adversary?

title: Dobe Named Best in Show At Maryland
description: EASTON, Md., Aug. 17The Talbot Kennel Club at Easton, Md., saw Mrs. Cheever Porter's and F. and E. D'Amico's 3yearold Doberman take its 19th bestinshow today in an entry of 1,356 dogs, up 30 per cent from last year.

title: Acrostic puzzle
Ross and Tom
description: American writers die young; especially the men. For some it is a true death, and some administer it by their own hands. For others it is an artistic death, a visible and agonizing deterioration of their powers that leaves them spent at what should be midcareer. Whatever the form this early death takes, it follows a pattern of extraordinary consistency, striking both the large talents and the limited ones with equal cruelty.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  With a new and wellliked President just sworn into office, this ought not be a time to accentuate the negative. But it must be said that there is a certain amount of skepticism, both in and out of Government, about the prospects for success of President Ford's summit meeting of leaders of business, labor, both political parties and consumer groups, among others, in about a month.

title: Central Park Rape Of Girl, 18, Charged To West Side Man
description: A 21yearold West Side resident was arrested early yesterday morning after he allegedly forced an 18yearold girl into Central Park and raped her.

LEADER OF PANTHERS BOOKED IN ASSAULTS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)Huey P. Newton, Black Panther party leader, was booked today for investigation of two counts of assault with a deadly weapon in connection with the pistolwhipping of his tailor and the shooting of a teenager, the police said.

title: Yorkie Gets Top Award At Dryden
description: DRYDEN, N. Y., Aug. 17 After 30 years, the Finger Lakes. Kennel Club was drummed out of Ithaca so the organization's show today was staged on the grounds of Dryden High School.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Annapolis K.C. allbreed and obedience, Sandy Point State Park, Route 50, west end of Bay Bridge, 1,839 dogs; 8:30 A.M.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Big Day for Smallmouth
description: LAC DE SERT, MANIWAKI, QuebecShortly before midnight, the waning moon lifted over the dark hills and washed the long reach of Lac d Sert with a pale and holy light, and sitting in the dark on the porch of our cabin we watched meteors of the Perseids flash across the sky.

title: Sound of Music in Teaneck Is Jazz
description: TEANECKThis town may have more resident jazz musicians to the square block than any other community in New Jersey, but it was unable to boast of any live jazz performances until three months ago. That is when Bud Maltin, a 20yearold student at William Paterson College in Wayne, became the local pied piper for such music.

title: Parkway to Mark 20th Anniversary
description: HOLMDELThe New Jersey Highway Authority will mark the 20th anniversary of the Garden State Parkway with a special exhibition, Tomorrow's Transportation.

title: Queens Girl Found Murdered in Yard Of Bayside School
description: A 17yearold Rego Park, Queens, girl was found murdered and sexually molested in a schoolyard four miles from her home yesterday morning.

title: Bringing Horne the House
description: MADISON  When Sister Anita Richard, chairman of the home economics department at the College of St. Elizabeth here, needed a house so that eight homemanagement students could get some reallife training, she solved the problem by having an existing house moved to the campus.

title: JEWS PLAN SCHOOL WITHOUT WALLS
description: It is called the Academy for Jewish Studies Without Walls and among the first students to enroll were a prisoner serving a life sentence in a Texas jail, a Long Island physician, a Roman Catholic nun in Massachusetts and a sailor at sea.

title: 20 D THE NEW YORE TIMES,
description: ONE of the activities that engaged Pablo Casals during the last dozen years of his life was the performance of his oratorio El Pessebre in as many countries as possible. It was another of the ways in which he tried to spread his ideals of peace, purity of heart, hope and faith, for these are the qualities that inform the text and, as much as it can convey them, the music.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Soccer Season Starts With Rampage

title: Swimming pools
description: Everything costs more  pork chops, sneakers, champagne. So do swimming pools. In the last four months, the cost of an inground pool has gone up 10 to 20 per cent, Steel, (up 60 per cent) and concrete (up 30 per cent) can he blamed for most of the increase. What mystifies the swimmingpool industry is that pool construction has also gone upby 35 per cent in the first six months of the year. Some attribute it to the stayathome, reaction to the energy crunch. But yet, one wonders if the high price of gasoline or the hike in air fares means that much to people who are willing to spend from $10,000 to $50,000 to build and landscape an inground pool, One reason may be that pools are much more attractive, these days as architects and designers give them serious thought. The kidneyshape clich is a thing of the past. Pools are now treated as the nucleus of an outdoor room. In materials, there is not a great deal new under the sun. One innovation is a stone aggregate paving material. Its pebbly surface is nonslip, and it's porous so splashes don't make puddles.

title: BOP COMPLETING A FAIR PRESS BILL
description: BONN, Aug. 17  The West German Interior Ministry is putting the finishing touches on a bill, that would give journalists legal protection from editorial interference by publishers and impose fairness requirements for news coverage.

title: I Don't Drive My Automobile  I Drive My Radio
description: I'm a radiobuff In tare age of television, and that puts me behind the wheel, rather than behind the times. I drive a lot, both in this country and in Europe, on right and lefthanded roads, and I enjoy it gasoline crisis or no, as long as the sound waves are clear. I don't listen to the radio anywhere elsekitchen, bedroom, bathroom, sundeck. I listen just to the one in the car.

title: James T. Farrell
description: Organized baseball has had many problems. The Lords of Baseball have been subjected to their share of criticism; but there has not been a major scandal to rock the baseball business in decades. This during a time when scandals great and small have been endemic and epidemic.

title: FORD AIDE DENIES ROCKEFELLER LINK TO DIRTY TRICKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The White House announced today that a mysterious tip linking Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former Governor of New York, to dirty tricks in the 1972 Presidential campaign was dismissed as baseless after an investigation this week by the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: East Rutherford Wary Over Complex
description: EAST RUTHERFORD Each day, as construction progresses on the stateendorsed Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, many of the 8,600 residents of this Bergen County borough become more fearful of the effects that the finished product will have on them and their community. Who will provide police and fire protection on the new and improved roads around the complex, they, ask, and how will the borough deal with the increase in traffic after football games, and other sports events? And they are afraid that the loss of ratable land to the state will cause their tax rate to rise.

title: Dance: Prodigal Son, a Ragtime Ballet, Is Sellout
description: LONDON, Aug. 17In recent years the London Festival Ballet under the artistic direction of Beryl Grey has made valiant efforts to extend what was its once somewhat moribund repertory. Revivals of works by Leonide Massine (including Parade) and Antony Tudor's Echoing of Trumpets, have helped give its repertory a more serious credibility, but the difficulty has always been to come up with new works and, if possible, a choreographer permanently attached to the company.

title: Museum Shows of the 70's Will Have Less Art and More Context
description: THE banners are out in Basel, Switzerland, for someone who was born just 502 years ago. And he deserves them. As a painter, an engraver, an illustrator, a publisher and a polemicist, Lukas Cranach will never be dislodged from history. He was overdue for a major exhibition. Cranach's work was last seen in bulk in Berlin in 1937, and that place at that time was abhorrent to most of us. The Cranach show before that was in Dresden in 1899, and I have yet to find an esthetic Methuselah who can tell how it looked.

title: Builders Shift Role As Housing Slumps
description: Two years ago 11 electricians were working for James Kohl, an electrical contractor in Jersey City. Now his staff is down to five.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS ON CYPRUS AGAIN
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 17The ceasefire declared on Cyprus last night broke down today with a new thrust southward by Turkish forces.

title: Andretti Takes DirtTrack Race
description: SEDALIA, Mo., Aug. 17 (AP)  Mario Andretti took the lead and kept it all the way as five competitors were eliminated in firstlap crashes of a 100mile auto race on the dirt track at the Missouri Fair today.

title: `If He Makes a Mistake Against the People, Please Put Him Down, God
description: SEOUL  The Roman Catholic cathedral was jammed to overflowing. About 130 priests from all over Korea surrounded the high altar. Scores grayclad nuns filled the front rows. The congregation crammed into the aisles and spilled outside into the breathless hot summer evening. But everyone was attentive, even fervent when the celebrant the mass, Bishop John Choi Chae Seon, set aside the usual reading from Scripture and intoned: Please show us the way to push back Communism. Please help us to restore democracy. Please bless our struggle for the cause of freedom and civil liberty.

title: The Return of a OnceoElegant Tradition: Great Lakes Cruising
description: GREAT LAKES cruising has come back, at least for the summer. Recreating a once elegant travel tradition, the Stella Maris II, Greek liner that formerly sailed the Aegean Sea, is offering the first passenger service on the Lakes in nearly decade, at an allinclusive price of $50 to $100 a day. The atmosphere is very Greek, from bouzouki music with cocktails in the lounge to desserts of baklava in the dining room. The ship is cozy and comfortable, though perhaps somewhat confining for athletic, energetic types. (I could sure use a game of tennis, sighed one young woman after four days.) And the scenery along the route is varied and interestingrivers, locks, lakes, islands, the Canadian and American shores in all their majesty, clusters of waving, friendly natives.

title: Kathryn Anthony Wed to Amjid Sheikh
description: Kathryn Fisk Anthony, daughter of Lieut. Col. William H. Anthony, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Anthony of Heritage Village in Southbury. Conn., and Amjid Mohammed Sheikh, son of Dr. Mohammed Faquir of Soroti, Uganda, where he practices medicine, and the late Mrs. Faquir, were married yesterday afternoon at the Meeting House in Southbury. The Rev. Paul Koumrian of St. George'sbytheSea Episcopal Church in Rumson, N. J., performed the ceremony.

title: State Hopes to Ease Plight of Motorists
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration is preparing a farreaching reexamination of state rules governing motor vehicles and the drivers who operate them, with the ultimate objective of reducing long lines at inspection stations and making driving in New Jersey safer.

title: Limited by Shortage Of Food and Transport
description: SUNAMGANJ. Bangladesh, Aug. 15Mohammed Ahmadullah, a 45year old farmer from the nearby village of Icharcha, hungrily eyed the mounds of bread being dis gorged from a helicopter here for distribution to flood victims.

title: A CYCLONE KILLS 20 IN NORTHEAST INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 17 (Reuters)A cyclone in Northeast India on Thursday killed at least 20 and injured 100 in the West Bengal coastal area, officials said today. The cyclone then moved over eastern Bihar where 800 families were evacuated today from the industrial city of Jamshedpur.

title: The terror in Robert Frost
description: Robert Frost liked secrets. Don't trust me too far, he warned. Now, in the centennial year of his birth, it looks as if he has become America's foremost poet, its emblem poet. His picture is on a stamp: his residences are marked (Seven colleges claimed me, he once said); his books and books about him are everywhere. But he still holds his secrets, and presumably we still cannot trust him too far.

title: Manuel Alum Offers DarkHued Dances With Hint of Humor
description: Pausing once in a while to have a retrospective look at works done can be helpful both to the artist and his audience. At the very least viewers renew past pleasures, and the artist may clear his path for future work. Manuel Alum presented dances from 1966 to the present, Friday evening at the Washington Square Methodist Church.

title: Brooks Sawyer Marries Miss Boochever
description: Allison Jill Boochever, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Paul Boochever of Westwood, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Brooks Hitchins Sawyer. He is the son of Howard G. Sawyer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.

title: Marjorie Cammann Wed to Officer
description: The Hotchkiss School Chapel in Lakeville, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Marjorie Livingston Cammann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Cammann of Lakeville and Greenwich, Conn., to Second Lieut. William Alan Duns, U.S.A.F.

title: 9.5 Infuriator Triumphs In the $100,000 Hobson
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP)  Sigmund Sommer's 9.5 favorite, Infuriator, edged in front with a quarter of a mile to go and held on to win the, fourth running of the $100,000 Hobson Stakes today by a neck over Ecole Etage at Liberty Bell.

title: Troubled TakeOff for Air Freight
description: For the major airlines, the immense potential of freight carriage has been analagous to the pot of gold at the foot of the rainbow. The longer one chases it, the farther it recedes.

title: Coast Scientists to Study Seaweed Use for Energy
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 17 (UPI)  Scientists are look ing at kelp, a seaweed, as a new energy source.

title: 45 Europeans on a Tour of U.S. Find City Is Not So Dangerous
description: Fortyfive mostly young middleclass Europeans who ended a onemonth crash course about the United States yesterday found the country friendlier than they had expected, Washington a bit provincial, New York not as dangerous as advertised and prices similar to those in their own countries.

title: A Bid for Human Sculpting
description: The 44yearold Mr. Johnson, himself a sculptor who became involved with the art about three years ago, said in an interview that the institute would have two goals: to be an educational force and to give aspiring artists opportunities to work in relatively costly mediums.

title: Cane Pace To Boyden Hanover
description: YONKERS, Aug. 17With the ailing George Sholty rooting from the paddock, Billy Herman, his 34yearold assistant, drove Boyden Hanover to victory tonight in the Cane Pace final at Yonkers Raceway. Boyden Hanover captured the first leg of harness racings's triple crown for 3yearold pacers.

title: Linda. Baird Married
description: Linda Jeanne Baird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard K. Baird of Chillicothe, Ohio, and Scott Trowbridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Trowbridge of Westfield, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon in the summer home of the Trowbridges in West Cornwall, Conn. Justice of the Peace Helen Walker performed the ceremony.

title: The Confessions of a Penny Speculator
description: Where have all the pennies gone? Gone to piggie banks, old socks, bureau drawers, kitchen jars and handbags everywhere. But many have found their way into the hands of Edward and Arthur Malley.

title: New & Novel
description: The Bradley Beach Rumba

description: CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, Me., Aug. 17 (UPI)The efforts by the, Pittston Company of New York to build a $350million oil refinery at Eastport, Me., have hit still another snag.

title: Lincoln Jockey Set Down
description: LINCOLN, RI., Aug. 18 (AP) Lincoln Downs stewards have suspended Frank Corneille for five racing days beginning tomorrow for failing to persevere with his mount. The jockey was set down for his actions in a race last Thursday.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: P.S.C. Preparing For LILCO Hearings
description: HAUPPAUGE  Official preparation, will begin Tuesday for the first combined state and local environmental and siting hearing on a nuclear power plant in the state.

title: Catch22 for Composers: You Need Another Job to Support Yourself
description: (The composer of socalled serious music is perhaps the most neglected of all artists today. To begin with, his potential audience is minuscule. Then, too, the chances of having his works performed are severely limited. Record sales are most unlikely and public recognition and acclaim are all but out of the question. And sonot surprisingly  avant  garde composers often stick together and commiserate.

title: Saigon Says Charges Are Propaganda
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam  The South Vietnamese Government denies holding any political prisoners, and its view is upheld by the United States Ambassador to Saigon, Graham A. Martin Conditions in South Vietnam that the Government holds 200,000 political prisoners.

title: A Devil's Disciple Unencumbered by Shaw
description: ONE of our problems with contemporary dramatists is that we know too damned much about them. We only half see their plays; the other half of our decidedly divided attention is firmly focused on them. For instance, I haven't yet caught up with the Connecticut revival of Tennessee Williams's Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, but it is blazingly clear from the reviews that people aren't so much asking what Williams has to say about his characters as they are asking what the characters say about Williams. Our knowledge of a playwright's private life, personal philosophy and quondam whims can stand square in the way of his work.

title: Hard Hats in the ArtsNot a HippieBaiter in the Whole Show
description: To anyone not part of the, downtown labor force, a visit these days to the financial district can be quite shattering. The tip of Manhattan has long been the banking center of the world, and its charm, if that is the word, has traditionally been the spectacle of so many huge; buildings packed into so small a space. That things have changed drastically is not just a matter of the old and majestic being replaced by the new and tacky. It's more a matter of downtown construction having gone into a kind of frenzy. The banks seem to be vying with each other, in the friendly spirit of free enterprise, to see who can get up the most skyscrapers. My impression is that so far they are about even, with two and three apiece. Judging from the excavations in progress, there's no telling what the score will be next week.

title: Pirates Top Dodgers, 43, on Run in 8th
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP)  Al Oliver's eighthinning single drove home Richie Hebner with the winning run today and the Pittsburgh Pirates stung slumping Los Angeles, 43.

title: A Tour of Huntington Bay
description: HALESITEThe state of Connecticut, across the Long Island, Sound, had a pinkish glow the other day as the EverReady II left her berth here on a threehour excursion of Huntington Bay.

title: Daley's Long Absence Stirs Chicago Speculation
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17It has been more than three months since Mayor Richard J. Daley has occupied the fifthfloor City Hall office. from which he. has ruled the second largest city in the nation for 20 years..

title: Maine Oil Refinery Plan Criticized by Park Agency
description: CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, Me., Aug. 17 (UPI)The efforts by the Pittston Company of New York to build a $350million oil refinery at Eastport, Me., have hit still another snag.

title: Mailbag
description: I WOULD like to correct a possible misunderstanding resulting from Nancy Tobin Willig's article Artpark: A New State Park for the Arts [Aug. 4]. Community programs have hardly disintegrated here.

title: Mayor Gets Plumbing Order
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP)The city health department has given Mayor Joseph R. Bianco 30 days to install additional plumbing in an apartment he rents to a family of four. The health code enforcement officer John Tafi, said the apartment lacked hot water, a bathroom sink and a bathtub, all required by law.

title: Nation Chided by Butz For Poor Eating Habits
description: MANAWA, Wis., Aug. 17 (UPI)Madison Avenue advartising is helping to turn America into a nation of gulpers and snackers who often pay high prices for less nutritious foods, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz Said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: No passenger ship arrivals are scheduled for today or tomorrow

McAfee of Irvington, a widower and son of the late Rev. Jesse U. Mcafee, a Methodist minister, and the late Mrs. McAfee of Waco, Tex.

title: Music
description: THE Berkshire Music Festival already has paid tribute to the memory of Serge Koussevitzky. That was on the weekend of July 26. Koussevitzky had been born in Russia on July 26, 1874, and the centenary naturally was observed by the music festival so closely associated with his name.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information, about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Auto Racing Has Its Tires Deflated as Firestone Withdraws From Major Activity
description: Last weekend at Milwaukee, the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company was required to bring about 200 race tires, at an average cost of $80 each, to a United States Auto Club Championship Trail event. Only 50 tires were used. The rest are now obsolete, $12,000 worth of rubber to be added to the sport's junk heap.

title: Mary A. Love Bride in Oslo
description: Mary Ann Love, a vice consul at the United States Embassy in Oslo, Norway, was married there yesterday to Laurence L. Malinconico Jr., a graduate student in geology at the University of Oslo.

title: Last days in the bunker
description: WASHINGTON. We've known that something terrible was going to happen since last Thursday, Julie Nixon Eisenhower told a friend a few hours before her father's resignation, exactly one week after the President had revealed incriminating evidence to his closest aides.

title: Women Cadets Opposed
description: COLORADO SPRINGS., Aug. 17 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Tames Allen, at 48 years old the youngest superintendent in the Air Force Academy's history, says he is firmly opposed to proposed enrollment of women cadets.

title: ...Or Growing Vegetables in the City's Back Yards
description: MY nextdoor neighbor is delighted and astonished to find her tomato plants loaded with tomatoes. With the humility of a firsttime gardener, she had assumed that growing vegetables requires years of apprenticeship. To top off her satisfaction, (our plants came from the same seed packet), she picked tomatoes two weeks before my first one ripened.

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 George Cassidy, the race starter whom they call Flash because that's what he gets a field away from the post in, clambered into the station wagon and held the door open so a small boy could climb in after him. This is Gregory, Cassidy said. His mother works in the Stevens office and he helps me. Dr. Manuel A. Gilman, examining veterinarian for the New York Racing ing Association, was a passenger, making one of his nine daily trips to the starting gate for a lastminute check on the soundness of the horses. As they neared the gate, which was already in position behind the threequarters pole near the top of the backstretch, a runaway named Poker Maid overtook the wagon and sailed past the gate with Mike Venezia in the saddle and an outrider pounding in pursuit. When the wagon stopped, Dr. Gilman walked a little way after her, watching the outrider overhaul her at the far turn.

title: Decision to Parole Persico Associate Nettles U.S. Officials Here
description: Hugh McIntosh, the bodyguard and close associate of Carmine Persico, will be paroled from the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta later this month, and Federal law enforcement officials here are not happy about it.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery, number yesterday was:

title: Legislators' Group Approves Merger At Annual Meeting
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 17The merger of three groups representing state legistlators has received final approval at the 27th annual meeting here of the National Legislative Conference.

title: An American in China The Coldest War Russia's Game in China. By C. L. Sulzberger. 113 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $5.95.
description: Mr. Sulzberger intends to be disarming when he confesses, At least I know I am a fool to write about China, whose language I do not speak, Whose books or newspapers I cannot read, whose immense history I cannot pretend to know, and where I have no wellinformed Chinese friends given to frank confidences. All too true, but Mr. Sulzberger is no more fazed by these difficulties than have been a number of Western visitors to China over the past few years.

title: Letters
description: Proverbial wisdom

title: The Vandenberg Connection
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17President Ford has recently been reading and praising George E. Reedy's excellent little book, The Twilight of the Presidency, and passing it out to members of his staff. This tells us something about the new skipper, and his appreach to his job.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Both residents and businessmen alike have asked me to comment on the article on Coney Island in this section last Aug. 11, There are three areas that we find in error.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Ecology and Zoning Study Focusing on L.I. Coastline
description: HAUPPAUGELong Island officials and representatives of state and Federal agencies hays begun a series of studies that are expected to provide new information on Long Island's ecology and recommendations for zoning and other governmental actions affecting the Island's 1,000 miles of coastline.

description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 17Doug Kotar was the last player to leave the Giant dressing room today after their 2113 victory over the Jets.

title: Women and Analysis
description: This book is a delightful invitation to share in the exploration of one of our era's most vexing issues: the nature and status of women. Set in the form of dialogueswith 10 new essays paired in response to 10 classic analytic essays  the discussion is at once substantive and full of personal flavor, a lively presentation of the large, interesting variety of views and revisions and departures which compose psychoanalytic thinking about women.

title: U.S. Crews Picked for Title Rowing at Switzerland
description: More than 60 oarsmen were invited to a camp in South Kent, Conn., the first week in July for the purpose of drills and the eventual selection of a United States national rowing team.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you have a question, or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: German Soccer Star Is Sold for $1Million
description: MADRID, Aug. 17 (Reuters) A West German soccer star, Paul Breitner, has signed for, the Spanish club, Real May drid, at an estimated transfer fee of $1million. A Rea Madrid spokesman, announcing the transfer today, dedined to specify the fed, though the milliondollar figure was thought likely, here.

description: TEHERAN, Aug. 17 (AP)The Soviet Union agreed today to nearly double the price it pays Iran for natural gas, officials here said.

title: MARGARET MACY
description: Margaret Macy, director of adtlertising, display and publicity for Bergdorf Goodman from 1933 to 1941, died Aug. 7 in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived here and in Sagaponack, L.I.

description: The celebrated pension reform bill that the President is expected to sign by Labor Day is an explosive concoction of good intentions and bad law.

description: SEATTLE, Aug 17 (UPI)Cynthia Hill defeated the defending champion, Carol Semple, 5 and 4, today to win the 74th United States Women's Amateur golf championship.

title: CALIFORNIA CURBS JUSTICES OF PEACE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17The California Supreme Court has ruled that justices of the peace who are not lawyers may no longer act in any case that might result in a jail sentence.

title: U.S. STILL WEIGHING TACTIC ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 King Hussein of Jordan said today that in talks with American officials he had received sympathy but no commitments that the United States would meet his desire to press for. JordanianIsraeli negotiations as the next step in the Middle East.

title: Bright Days at Bethlehem Steel
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.  For longtime steelwatchers, it seemed as though the industry had suddenly turned on its head. The steel companies were inhabiting a strange new world characterized by product shortages, barelyadequate productive capacity, soaring prices and swelling profits.

title: WEISS FOR CAREY; SAMUELS GETS AID
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey and Howard J. Samuels picked up additional endorsements yesterday in their contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: WATER PLEA STIRS PORT CHESTER IRE
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y. Aug. 17 The Port Chester Water Works, whose 10,000 customers pay the state's highest and the nation's secondhighest water rates, has touched off a howl of protest by asking the Public Service Commission for a 43 per cent rate increase.

title: Pamela Ann Castle Wed to D. H. Bayly
description: Pamela Ann Castle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harmon Castle of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel Helms Bayly, an investment banker with Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith in Chicago. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Vail Bayly of Hubbard Woods, Ill.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: William Bowman, Law Student, Marries Elizabeth Kay Spencer
description: Elizabeth Kay Spencer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Cole Spencer of New York and Mamaroneck, L.I., was married yesterday at noon to William Judkins Bowman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bowman of Elm Grove, Wis. The Rev. George R. Bailey performed the ceremony in the United Methodist Church in Mamaroneck.

title: Television/Radio
description: BEHAVIOR Control Through Media was the title of a conference held last spring, and it caused one network news executive to blow his stack. The executive, replying to an invitation to participate in the conference, called the whole thing a waste of time. The very title of the conference, he fumed, was an insult. His reaction to the idea of such a conference, which took place at the headquarters of its sponsor, the Institute of Society, Ethics and the Life Sciences in Hastings, N.Y., was predictable: Nobody in television likes to think of himself as a controller of behavior. There is an Orwellian ring to that sort of selfimage  too much like Big Brother coming onto the TV screen to inform the citizenry that, peace is war and freedom is slavery.

title: The Sandlot Story (Pride, Joy, Hustle, a Can of Soda) and the N.F.L.
description: It's Saturday, about noon. My 9yearold son is standing in the kitchen, his head tilted back as he takes a long drink from a can of soda. His baseball cap pushed back on his head in the typical game's over position. His face is caked with the brown dust you only pick up from sandlot fields. The sweat has etched its standard steaks down the side of his face. He stands ever so jauntily, still wearing his rubber cleated all sports shoes, He's tired, he's proud, he's happy.

title: Boy Scout Aides Censured On False Membership Data
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UPI)The top administrators of the Boy Scouts in the Chicago area have been censured and placed on one year's probation because their membership rolls were dishonest.

title: The Kennedy Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17In going over the side, Richard Nixon may have taken Edward Kennedy down with him.

title: Book Ends
description: September. And things are perking up a bit. Publishing people are trickling back from the Hamptons, the Rockaways and various Fire Island ports of call and the pace of new titles begins to quicken.... We might as well begin with some wouldbe blockbusters (their publishers hope) as well as books by tried and true bestselling authors.... There is, for example, James Michener's novel Centennial, for which the BookoftheMonth Club paid a lot of money; it's about a million years or so in the life of the flora and fauna and homo sapiens in and around the fictitious town of Centennial, Colo.... Dee Brown (Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee) also looks at the settling of the West in The Westerners. ... Cornelius Ryan is represented by A Bridge Too Far, nonfiction about an aborted World War H action. John Hersey's My Petition for More Space is a futuristic nightmare about, well, a man standing in line. Len Deighton returns to the spynovel genre and his new book is titled Spy Story lest there be doubt. Robert Ludlum, a prclific, prosperous thriller writer is represented by The Rhinemann Exchange while the inimitable (except to his imitators) Harold Robbins is back with The Pirate, all about an Arab tycoon who learns he's Jewish and whose daughter joins the Fedayeen andoh never mind. Lastly, a sleeper for which commercial success is prognosticatedThe Reincarnation of Peter Proud, by Max Ehrlich, about a man who has strange dreams could they be of other lives?

title: DoItYourself College Credit
description: HOBOKENUnder a somewhat unusual program that was concluded earlier this month, 31 high school students taught themselves collegecredit science and mathematics at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: Gardens
description: ONCE past the faces of manicured lawns, white picket fences and clipped hedges, there is an authentic flavor to Cape Cod. You can glimpse it in the thick stands of scrub pines along Route 6, the jewellike min?? iature ponds and the harbors where seagulls swoop, and soar.

title: Food: Wine and Delicacies in Deal
description: DEAL  The Wine and Whiskey Basket at 100 Norwood Avenue has altered its image. Once a liquor and wicker store, it is now a vintage wine, cheese and gourmet food center. It took the new owners Tom and Marie Murray, six years to do it.

title: Deborah Koff Married
description: Deborah Joan Koff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Koff was married yesterday evening to Seth Mark Guggenheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Guggenheim of Demarest, N.J. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mr. Nixon's resignation has been followed by demands that he now be indicted and prosecuted for crimes that he allegedly committed during his tenure in office.

title: PORTUGAL'S ABSURD EMPIRE
description: PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands. It is here, in this cluster of barren volcanic islands, that Portuguese colonialism reaches the heights of its sad absurdity. Before the Portuguese explorers, soon followed by settlers, arrived late in the 15th century, no one lived here. Even now, when 275,000 people scratch for a living in the Cape Verde province of PortugalPortugal decolonized semantically by calling her colonies provincesonly about 10 per cent of the archipelago's 1,557 square miles are under permanent cultivation, unless there is a catastrophic drought as there has been in the last six years. Then all of Cape Verde looks like the Sahara.

title: Saigon Police Fight Subversion But Also Curb Political Dissent
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17On the floor of a Saigon hospital ward a young seamstress named Dang Thi Hien lay handcuffed to an olivedrab stretcher. Her legs, covered with a blanket, were paralyzed a result, she said of beatings and torture during police interrogation.

title: Cincinnati Trans Dodgers by 3
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 17The weight removed from their shoulders by the news of the Los Angeles Dodgers' fifth straight loss, the Cincinnati Reds shook their lethargic bats and defeated the New York Mets, 62, tonight before 47,274 fans at Riverfront Stadium.

title: Niarchos Gift to Greek Navy
description: ATHENS, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Stavros Niarchos the Greek shipping magnate, informed autnorities here today that he was donating $3.83million to strengthen Greece's Navy.

title: THEODORA WARD, WRITER, 83, DEAD
description: Theodora Van Wagenen Ward, a writer and authority on the life and poetry of Emily Dickinson, died Friday in Keene, N. H., at the age of 83. She had lived in Cambridge, Mass., and AlsteadCenter, N. H.

title: Miss Leidner Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Victoria Deane Leidner of Philadelphia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson J. Leidner of Huntington Valley, Pa., to Henry John Gerken of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gerken of New Fairfield, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Ideas & Trends/continued
description: It is hardly news that the explosive rates of world population growth threaten to overwhelm the development efforts of the Third World and lead to Malthusian famine, disease and despair. The alarums have been raised worldwide. Why, then is there a need for the big United Nations conference on population, starting tomorrow in Bucharest?

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: In the End, Allies
description: WASHINGTONSo we Washington reporters were not divorced from the pulse of heartland America, after all. The alarum bells we sounded in the capitaldescribed by critics in the Nixon Administration as the litist clamorings of jaded Nixonhatersproved in the end to toll as well for the rest of the country.

title: The New Movies
description: CALIFORNIA SPLIT, directed by Robert Altman from a screenplay by Joseph Walsh and starring George Segal and Elliott Gould, received a mixed reaction from the critics. Vincent Canby reviewed it favorably.

title: The Truce Settled Nothing: the Syrians Are ReArming
description: JERUSALEMBy Middle Eastern standards, the 12 weeks that have elapsed since the IsraeliSyrian troopseparation agreement was signed have been tranquil time. There has been the odd skirmish on the Lebanese border, the occasional shelling of suspected Palestinian Guerrilla targets by Israeli gunboats. But in this fractious corner of the world, that sort of activity passes for peace.

description: NEWARKIn a move designed to give it three times as much room for storage and public use, the New Jersey Reference Division of the Newark Public Library has moved its operations to the library's first floor. It formerly was on the third floor of the building, which is at 5 Washington Street.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 119 communities thoughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

description: MIAMI, Aug. 17 (AP)The Miami Toros moved to within a game of the North American Soccer League championship tonight by downing the Dallas Tornado, 31, in a semifinal playoff game. Derek Watts had two goals in the rain before 5,045 fans.

title: The New President: Unemployment, a Potential Recession Also Confront Him
description: WASHINGTONMy instinctive judgment, said President Ford in his address to Congress, Is that the State of the Union is excellent. But the state our economy is not so good.

title: M.S. Hilgendorf, Cynthia Bricker Wed in Suburbs
description: Cynthia Anne Bricker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Bricker of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday morning in the chapel of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale to Mark Steven Hilgendorf. He is a son of Judge and Mrs. Howard W. Hilgendorf of Milwaukee. The bridegroom's father serves as Federal Bankruptcy Judge for the Eastern District of Wisconsin. Mr. Bricker is national director of the Boys' Clubs of America.

title: Bronx Industry Expands
description: A leading manufacturer of kitchenware is moving into a large industrial facility in the Bronx that the city bought for $4.7million and leased to the company.

title: Harmonica BrouHaHa Seeks to Lift Instrument's Image a Few Octaves
description: The South Street Seaport Museum Was the setting yesterday for the first Annual Harmonica BrouHaHa, sponsored by the Hohner Harmonica Company to debunk the traditional image of the harmonica as the country bumpkin in the musical instrument family.

title: Is There Any Future for Bad Taste?
description: EVERY society has its unspoken taboos. They linger in the twilight of public consciousness until something called bad taste brings them into the open. Bad taste triggers a kind of shock by the very fact that the unspeakable has been spoken, and the unpresentable presented. The effect may be to stimulate a reconsideration of those taboos which have been violated. Bad tastewell employed by a comedian such as Lenny Bruce, a novelist like Philip Roth or a playwright such as Joe Ortoncan become a force of liberation. In other cases, where lesser artists are playing with this kind of social dynamite, the result may be that the taboos become reinforced.

title: AliForeman Fight in Africa: Public Relations vs. Pugilism
description: Oh, the times they are a changin' ... A heavyweight championship bout fought for a purse of $10million at 3 A.M. in the midst of an African Woodstock certainly reflects the sentiment in Bob Dylan's song. No runofthemill title fight is this. It transcends the sport. At the basest level, it is a contest between the most charismatic sportsperson of the century and an adequate foil. At another, it is a questionable Brobdingnaglan public relations campaign put on by a fledgling country, and on a third plane, it is the precursor of an event.

title: DogFight Reports In Chicago Set Off Inquiries by Police
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17  The Cook County State's Attorney here and the suburban police have begun investigations into reports of illegal dog fights and betting on then in the Chicago area.

title: China Mail in Hong Kong Publishes Its Last Issue
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 17. (AP) More than 125 years of BritishAsian newspaper history ended today when the afternoon Englishlanguage China Mail published its last issue.

title: Donna Fidelibus Bride of Leo Jarmusz
description: Donna Ann Fidelibus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix N. Fedelibus of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to Leo John Jarmusz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Jarmusz of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Joseph P. Meehan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

description: The best things in life may not always be free  indeed, someone, somewhere has to pick up the tabbut New York has a bumper crop of attractions that charge no admission, thanks to subsidies, bequests, grants and simple generosity. Hero are some of them:

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TomorrowMinnesota at Shea Stadium, 8 P.M.

title: Janice Portnoy Wed
description: Janice Portnoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Portnoy of Great Neck, L.I. was married last night to Robert Zimerlis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Zimerlis of Eastchester, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: Fashion
description: Sunday in Central Park: steel bands, hawkers, gawkers, cyclists and sun bathers. Add a couple of models being photographed in fur coats in midsummer, and the scene is complete. What kinds of furs will be worn in the parks and on city sidewalks when winter blows in? The popular pelts this year seem to be raccoon, natural or dyed, nutria and fox. They all tailor well into the currently fashionable big shapes and fit nicely into the casual mood of today's clothes. Their prices, however, are not so casual. Anyone whose last fur purchase was one of those $100 rabbit coats back in the sixties will find that even the humble rabbit is hard to come by for less than $300 these days. Longhaired furs such as raccoon and fox have doubled and in some cases tripled in price in the last few yearsthanks, of course, to increased demand. Now for the good news: Furriers think prices will not be going up again in the near future.

title: Rabbis Active as Jersey Land Dealers
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J.Two young Orthodox rabbis, discouraged by the difficulty of raising money for a religious school, have turned to land speculation as a way to help keep such institutions going.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: In the securities markets, the first full week of the Ford Administration closed. Friday afternoon and the word was hardly a vote of' confidence. In contrast to the cooperative spirit reigning in Washington, it was gray days in the stock market, which dropped lower all week. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its lowest point in four years. Interest rates continued to rise.

title: Miss Parker Wed To C. M. Barsalow
description: Angela Adele Parker, assistant professor of sociology at Green Mountain College in Poultney, Vt., was married yesterday morning in Poultney to Charles Michael Barsalow, proprietor and manager of the Country Dollar Markets of Essex Junction, Vt., food and variety stores.

title: Information, Please!
description: WHERE do people planning a trip abroad go for information? Well, quite a few of them go to a small area of midManhattanthe forties and fifties, mostly around Fifth and Madison Avenues. Here the governments of many of the world's nations have tourist offices where answers are availabletheoretically, at leastto all sorts of questions a prospective visitor to a country might ask. Questions about climate, food, money, accommodations, sightseeing, coming events and a host of other things.

title: Unwed Mother Sues Army
description: TYLER, Tex., Aug. 17 (UPI) Cheryl Williams is suing the Army over its refusal to induct her because she is an unwed mother. Miss Williams sued in United States District Court, saying she had passed written and physical entrance tests three times and had been told once that she could enter the Army if she would give custody of her child to her mother. Later, she said, she was told she had to put the child up for adoption.

title: Headliners
description: New York Times correspondent Christopher S. Wren is also an experienced mountain climber. When the Soviet Government opened an international mountaineering camp this summer, Mr. Wren, who As assigned to The Times Moscow Bureau, joined the American contingent.

title: Red Hook Terminal Advances
description: The planned $30million marine terminal in the Red Hook Section of South Brooklyn moved closer to realization last week.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be, addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: 23 Middlesex County Communities Join to Fight Zoning Suit
description: NEW BRUNSWICKA suit charging 23 Middlesex County communities with exclusionary zoning that discriminates against poor people and minorities will be fought jointly and on an individual municipal basis, Paul Beck, chairman of the Middlesex County Conference of Mayors, has announced. Mr. Beck is Mayor of Highland Park, one of the accused towns.

title: World Perched on Recession...
description: Talk of world recessioneven depression was one of the products of the spate of oilcrisis rhetoric spawned around the turn of the year.

title: ANKER AND U.F.T. IN WORK DISPUTE
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker, rebuffed in an effort last December to limit the earnings of teachers who were supplementing their regular salaries through persession jobs, such as coaching or advising student publications, is now trying to enforce a contract provision that limits teachers to one such job a year.

title: 5 Mountain Climbers Killed In Plunge in the French Alps
description: MEGEVE, France, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Five mountain climbers, roped together for an ascent in the difficult Meije area of the French Alps, were killed today when they fell off a sheer cliff, police officials said.

title: Domestic Politics and National Pride Limit Their Options
description: LONDONIt is one of the crueler ironies of the GrecoTurkish crisis over Cyprus that just when both countries simultaneously enjoy civilian government for the first time in years, their leaders are trapped into hostility by the equal and opposite demands of Greek and Turkish national pride, military imperatives and internal factional rivalry.

title: The New Season Means New Operas and a Flood of Puccini
description: WITH the opening of the New York City Opera's 1974.75 season only 10 days away, this seems like, a good time to make a brief resume of what the American companies will be doing during the next nine months. To plunge right in, there will be few new works, a standard condition for almost any year. (The following two seasons, involving the Bicentennial, can be expected to see a relatively large number of premieres scheduled across the country.) There will, however, be a fair amount of revived rarities.

title: Good Samaritan
description: To Dwight Macdonald he was an epigone of Fitzgerald and Hemingway, but lacked their passion and their sense of literary form. To Philip Rahv he was easy pickings for a hostile critic because of his cheap snobbism. To Lionel Trilling he was a student of manners with a passionate commitment to verisimilitude. If it is surprising to learn that these critics were all talking about the same writer, John O'Hara, there is still more surprising knowledge in store: they were all, in some measure, right.

title: AROUND THE
description: Dry summer annuals for winter bouquets.... Feed vegetables just coming into flower to encourage generous harvest ... Water weekly in dry periods. Evergreens can be transplanted anytime now until midSeptember.... Seed or sod new lawns.

title: Atlantic Ave Given Approval on Zoning
description: Final approval was given by the Board of Estimate last week to a special zoning district for a sevenblock stretch of Atlantic Avenue between Court Street and Fourth Avenue in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Judge Cites Four on Coast School Board
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug, 17 A Federal District judge has held four of the five Pasadena Board of Education members in civil contempt of court for failing to comply with an integration order.

title: A Small Museum With Big Ideas
description: SOUTHAMPTON  Since art became a prestigious item in the country a few years back, smallcommunity art museums have been sprouting up almost as fast as golf courses. And one of the most remarkable of the smallcommunity operations is the Parrish Museum.

title: National Airlines and Union Recess Talks to End Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Talks between National Airlines and the machinists union on a fiveweekold strike that has shut down the airline have been recessed indefinitely, the chairman of the National Mediation Board said today,

title: 28 HURT IN CRASH OF CHARTERED BUS
description: A Bronx woman's leg was severed and 27 other persons were hurt last night when transit workers and their families from an outing upstate crashed off a rainslickened highway exit ramp in the Westchester County town of Harrison, state police reported.

title: SHOP OWNER IS SLAIN IN TWOMAN HOLDUP
description: A haberdasher, who moved to New York City from Pearl River, N.Y., last October to take over a Washington Heights store, was shot and killed in the course of an apparent robbery of the store yesterday.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television progranis was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: BIAS IN CONGRESS ON HIRING DENIED
description: Congressmen identified in a Fort Worth newspaper article as practicing racial discrimination in hiring staff members angrily denied the allegation last night.

title: Poll Fear a Depression Is Ahead; Ford's Vow to Curb Inflation Stirs Hope
description: Nearly half of the adults questioned in a nationwide survey have despaired of the nation's economy and believe the country, is headed for a depression, according to a Gallup Poll taken two weeks ago and released yesterday.

title: Cuba Spares No Expense as Host of Amateur Boxing
description: HAVANAThe city's largest hotel, the 25story Havana Libre (formerly the Havana Hilton) has been turned over to the Cuban Boxing Federation as an olympic village during the first amateur boxing world championships being held here.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Staffordshire Bull Terrier to Become A.K.C.'s 121 st Registered Breed Oct. 1
description: The Staffordshire bull terrier has made it. This mediumsized, compact, shortcoated dog is to be admitted for registry in the American Kennel Club stud hook starting Oct. 1. It is the 121st to be accepted. Next March 5, the Stafford becomes eligible to compete for breed, group and bestinshow awards. He will compete in the terrier division.

title: Fashion Is Big in Japan  if It's French, British or American
description: TOKYO  Japanese women in Utamaro's 18thcentury woodblock prints clopped along on black lacquered geta, or wooden sandals, that raised them three to five inches above ground.

title: Nixon Backer Will Keep His Poster on Window
description: SOUTH WINDSOR, Conn., Aug. 17 (AP)Betty Walker, reminding her neighbors that former President Richard M. Nixon is human not divine, says she may keep a fourfoot color poster of Mr. Nixon on her front picture window forever.

title: 5 Mountain Cambers Killed In Plunge in the French Alps
description: MEGEVE, France, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Five mountain climbers, roped together for an ascent in the difficult Meiji area of the French Alps, were killed today. When they fell off a sheer cliff, police officials said.

title: Kuhn Presses Owners, Says Now Is Time for Black Pilot
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that now is the time for the major leagues to have a black manager and warned that I could not function as commissioner if a decision were long delayed.

title: Getting Ready for the Big Brooklyn Carnival
description: Hidden in abandoned gasoline stations, deserted storefronts and makeshift leanto's on the corner lots of BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, there exist multitudes of secret fantasy lands.

title: Sixty Sails, $10.40, Victor at Arlington
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP)Sixty Sails, coming from far. back, opened a threelength lead early in the stretch run, then hung on to beat Protectora by half a length in the $66,300 Matron Handicap at Arlington Park today.

title: Education Still Haunts Legislature
description: TRENTON  Members of the State Legislature will have a number of important issues to consider when their sessions are resumed next month, but perhaps the most pressing will be defining and funding a thorough and efficient education, as mandated by the State Supreme Court.

title: Chess: 16 Boast Perfect Records After 4 Rounds of the Open
description: After four rounds of the United States Open Championship at the Statler Hilton Hotel, 16 players held perfect scores.

title: A Slice of New England on Long Island
description: EARLY morning fog rolls off Long Island Sound and over the flat fields of green potato plants, to drift in puffs across the winding twolane highway. I drive east on the North Fork of Long Island at 15 miles an hour, behind a John Deere tractor hitched to a wellused cultivator, hearing the gulls squawk above the treecovered bluffs that nudge the shoreline of the Sound. The tractor turns off at a farm advertising vegetables and strawberries for sale on a handwritten Sign and disappears into a barn of silver gray boards that leans slightly to one aide and sags noticeably at the roof. An old woman in a faded print dress trudges around the corner of the barn, a milk pail full of berries swinging from the end of each.

title: Even U.S. Aid Is Drying Up
description: CHICAGOThe drought that is burning up grass on the Western ranges compounds the bad news for the livestock industry. Some ranchers are being forced to reduce their herds by sending unfattened animals to the slaughter houses, and that will make for leaner financial returns in the months ahead. But the cattlemen were counting their losses even before the drought got this bad, and many of them are blaming not the weather but Washington for their difficulties.

title: Solutions to Lust Week's Puzzles
Psychologist Is Hired To Spruce Up an Image
description: The masculine image, which the public often associates with women's athletics, is perhaps the No. 1 reason why women's sports have been slow to gain public acceptance. The Women's Professional Basketball Association, which will put a touring pilot team on the court this seasonthe Pink Panthersbefore league operations begin in 1975, has hired a female psychologist to combat the problem.

title: Hillside Fighting Pingry Sale
description: HILLSIDEA storm of protest against the proposed sale of Pingry School's 32acre tract to Union County for government offices and recreational facilities has clouded the private school's plan to move to Bernard's Township.

title: Old Favorites in New Films
description: Will Garbo ever make a comeback? It's not too likely. Yet many of her contemporaries show no shyness about facing the cameras. Last year, for example, Sylvia Sidney proved you don't have to be under 30 to be terrific when she copped an Academy Award nomination for Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams. And John Houseman actually won an Oscar for The Paper Chaseat the age of 72.

title: The Nation
description: The new President, who had characterized himself eight months ago as a Ford, not a Lincoln, said in his address to Congress last week, I am still a Ford but I am not a Model T. It may have been a clue as to the economic policies he intends to adopt.

title: Drivers Disconnecting Seat Belt Locks
description: DETROIT, Aug 17  Hundreds of thousands of new automobile owners, maybe more, have apparently joined the great interlock revolt and disconnected the safety system that was designed to guarantee that they were fully buckled into the cars before driving.

title: GREASE THIEVES PUZZLE FT. WORTH
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 17Equipped with tank trucks, welding torches and suction equipment, thieves are stealing each week waste grease worth $6,000 to $10,000 from area restaurants and cafes.

title: Challenging the Olympian Fed
description: WASHINGTONOn Monday night, President Ford told Congress inflation had now become America's public enemy No. 1. Yet the only policeman in sight of late has been Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve. Not only has he been saying just this about inflation for some time but he has tried to do something about it, by tightening credit and forcing up interest rates to record heights.

title: Mrs. Keneally Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Keneally of Dummerston, Vt., on Aug. 5 at Brattleboro (Vt.) Memorial Hospital.

title: Bridge
description: Few players ever reach the moment of truth when it seems that their lives depend on the outcome of a single dealtheir bridge lives, that is. Success will mean fame and fortune. Failure will mean obscurity.

title: Caryl Seip Bride Of Richard Pollard
description: Caryl Seip, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Seip of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Pollard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William 13. Pollard of Wimbledon, Ebgland. The Rev. Henry E. Green performed the ceremony in the North Greenwich Congregational Church.

title: A RevolutionaryWar Show
description: In a preliminary event in the developing plans to mark the country's bicentennial, the Long Island Historical Society is sponsoring a colorful exhibition of Revolutionary War documents, guns, maps, powderhorns and sworls this month at the Brooklyn Public Library's main building at Grand Army Plaza.

title: L.I. Town To Weigh Restrictions On Zoning
description: SOUTHAMPTONA measure to sharply reduce the number of units in new motels, hotels and apartment buildings is to be taken up by the Town Board here Tuesday night.

title: Twostar choices
description: If Michelin awarded two stars to my favorite French restaurant in New York, it would list it as follows:

title: John Bloom Is Fiance Of Wendy V. Donald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas. D. Donald of New York and Dongan Hills, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Virginia Donald, to John E. Bloom, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Bloom of Chesterton, Ind. The wedding is planned for Nov. 23.

title: Chris. Evert Wins Title At Toronto
description: TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP)Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., breezed past Julie Heldman of Houston in straight sets today to capture the women's singles title in the Canadian open tennis tournament.

title: Joan Tugendhaft to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert I. Tugendhaft of Massapequa Park, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Tugendhaft, to Barry Mills. son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mills of Warwick, R. I. The wedding is planned for Dec. 28. Miss Tugendhaft is a senior at Syracuse University, where her fianc is a candidate for a doctoral degree in biology. Her father is director of radiology at the Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L. I.

title: Alien and Drug Seizures Up In Pacific Southwest Area
description: SAN PEDRO, CALIF., Aug. 17 (UPI)Federal immigration officers say they apprehended 686,669 ilegal aliens and seized $26million in drugs and marijuana in the 10 states of the Pacific Southwest during the last fiscal year.

title: Congress Emerges From Ordeal Confident and Proud
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17Congress has emerged from the crucible of impeachment wearing a smile of selfassurance.

title: Giants Beat Jets, 2113, on Disputed Play Before 35,431 Fans in Rain at Yale fowl
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 17In a stadium more empty than filled, the Giants beat the Jets in their midsummer football folly today, 2113.

title: If Michelin rated our restaurant oh, l l!
description: Some 5,000 dinnertimes ago, Life magazine persuaded a junior inspector of the Guide Michelin to tour this country's leading restaurants and give a snap judgment. He was really impressed by one house, Le Pavillon, which he thought deserving of  (worth a voyage). He also scattered a few  (the second highest rating in Michelin's code, translated as worth a detour) and perhaps even single stars (ambiguously described as a good restaurant in its class), but he dismissed a number of our most highly reputed, and highly priced, establishments as unworthy of Michelinage. While straining to be polite even to our custom of drinking ice water with our meals, he found the cuisine in our most famous New Orleans restaurants rather funny; it was not Creole but pseudoFrench food that he was rejecting, and he was only anticipating by a decade or so the sad conclusion of native connoisseurs that the glory of New Orleans cookery was fading. And not only in New Orleans. The man from Michelin concluded: Of the three countries I have seen, France is No. 1, England is No. 2 and No. 3.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Wholesale prices of men's, women's and children's clothes are up by 8 to 10 per cent this fall over last year. It is obvious that what is already bad news to the retailer will also be bad news for the consumer because store price tags will soon refleet the new rises.

title: Kiss Hollywood Goodby
description: Anita Loos commenced selling scenarios to movie producers when she was a slip of a girl. In 1912, while she was still wearing sailor blouses and her hair in pigtails, the great D. W. Griffith himself directed her first picture to hit the screen. Its name was The New York Hat, a onereeler starring Mary Pickford; also in the cast were Lionel Barrymore, playing a clergyman, and those wonderful Gish sisters, Lillian and Dorothy. Four years later, Miss Loos was writing the subtitles for Intolerance, Griffith's second supercolossal. Meanwhile with John Emerson (her future husband) directing, she had started scripting a series of delightful comedies built around that bounding, beaming, irresistible juvenile with the patent leather hair, Douglas Fairbanks, who couldn't really act for nuts, but, could he beam and bound!

title: MAJOR BLAST RIPS LOS ANGELES SITE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17A powerful explosion leveled a warehouse and set off fires In an industrial area in east Los Angeles tonight.

title: 3 Bicentennial Sites Picked
description: TRENTON  The state's Bicentennial Celebration Commission has selected three historically oriented sites for development into major tourist attractions during the nation's 200th birthday observance in 1976.

title: FUND FOR HALDEMAN STARTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (UPI) A close friend of H. It. Haldeman has set up a legal expense fund for the former Presidential assistant and is soliciting business executives for contributions, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Concert: From Intimate to Grandiose
description: The Friday evening Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall stretched from the most intimate Mozart (if you count the preconcert recital) to the most grandiose, and threw in a little Sissmayer and Schubert on the side. It was a highly successful night of musicmaking in nearly every respect.

title: Christine di Scipio, Teacher, Wed
description: Christine Ann di Scipio, a teacher in St. Anthony's Grade School in Washington, and Michael Benson Soper, a senior at Georgetown University, were married at noon yesterday in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ARMY SHIFT URGED IN WEAPONS BUYING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17, (Reuters)The Army has made public a report saying it has not done a good job in the developinent and purchase of weapons.

title: Once More, Dancing at the White House
