description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17President and Mrs. Ford gave their first state dinner last night, and any resemblance between this bouncy evening and state dinners of recent years was purely protocol. The menu was standard, there were the usual toasts and trumpets, but everyone, it seemed, was having fun.

title: Dance
description: IN dance things have been pretty cool for a hot August. At Lincoln Center, where American Ballet Theater and the National Ballet of Canada were playing across the plaza from one another, we saw some pretty remarkable dancing, The other Friday night, for remarkable example, we had Rudolf Nureyev and Erik Bruhn dancing in La Sylphide at the Metropolitan Opera House, while Mikhail Baryshnikov was dancing the Don Quixote pas de deux at the New York State Theater, for the first time in New York.

title: Hackettstown Pondering Proposed Condominium
description: HACKETTSTOWN  A proposal to build a $24million condominium development here is being opposed by local residents.

title: Nursery School Enrollment Rose as Population Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Census Bureau says that the number of children in nursery schools more than doubled over the last 10 years while thee nation's population of 3to5yearolds declined.

title: 7 killed in Texas Car Crash
description: SANTO, Tex., Aug., 17 (UPI) Seven personss, including four children, died last night in an automobile collision at a busy intersection in north central Texas. The Texas Departnient of Public Safety said six of the victims were members of an Oklahoma family. The drivers Of both cars were

title: World News Briefs
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 17 (Reuters)The Ethiopian armed forces committee announced today that it had arrested Emperor Haile Selassie's chief bodyguard, Maj. Gen. Tafesse Lemma.

title: Airlifts Returnmg Britons Stranded By Firm's Collapse
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) Four thousand British vacationers stranded in Spain by the financial collapse of the Court Line tourist company wer flown back to Britain late today in an emergency airlift. Another 45,000 were still waiting at European tourist resorts from Spain to Greece.

title: Home Improvement
description: REGARDLESS of whether a carpet is made of wool or one of the newer synthetic fibers, there are certain rules that should be followed in its care and maintenance if long life is to be insured, and if its inherently attractive appearance is to be preserved.

title: Can't Regret Wins
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP)Steve Rowan rode Can't Regret through the rain to a onelength victory over Mountain Man today in the $4,550 featured eighth race at Finger Lakeszace track.

title: Dr. Peggy Anne McGuirk Is Betrothed
description: Dr. Peggy Anne McGuirk and Dr. Andrew John Franzone, attending physicians at Lenox Hill Hospital, will be married here Sept. 7 in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church.

title: Seoul Says North Ordered Park Slain
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday Aug. 18South Korean investigatora charged late last night that the President of Communist North Korea, Kim Il Sung, had ordered the attempted assassination of the President Park Chung Hee of South Korea last Thursday.

title: Criminals At Large
description: With The Billion Dollar Sure Thing, published just a little over a year ago, Paul Erdman established himself as the Adam Smith of the crime novel. Erdman, it will be remembered, was the financier who came to grief as president of a bank in Switzerland and served some time in a Swiss jail. It was there that he started his first novel, and it was a smash hit on publication. Smart, smart, Erdman. Talented talented Erdman. The man was born with a busy brain, and it also would appear that he was born to make money, one way or the other.

title: RECORD RAINFALL IS RECORDED HERE
description: A pair of torrential downpours drenched the metropolitan area yesterday, creating darkness at midday, snarling traffic on the city's highways and in its subways throughout the afternoon, and disrupting electrical power. A record 2.82 inches of rain fell.

title: Medich, Rain Defeat White Sox
description: It took the Yankees just about four hours to receive credit for a wellpitched 21 victory over the Chicago White Sox at Shea Stadium yesterday. Rain delays were the problem, and fewer than 1,000 persons were around from the original crowd of 14,587 when the umpires called the game at 6:30 P.M.

title: BRAZIL AND CHINA SET A TRADE COMMISSION
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17A joint ChineseBrazilian economic commission has been established to handle trade, communications and transport between the two countries.

title: A Gut Issue: Who Shapes Up Best, Athletes or Dancers?
description: BALLET dancers don't like to be compared with athletes, nor even to be mentioned in the same context, but to anyone familiar with both activities, comparison is inescapable. The fact is that the physical demands upon (lancers are at least as strenuous as those faced by professional athletes, and dancers are at least as well conditioned for their endeavors as athletes are for theirs, and, in many instances, dancers are better conditioned.

title: The Guns Talked Louder
description: Turkey has given the classic answer to diplomatic failure. In 60 hours, Turkish troops slashed across Cyprus to impose the partition that Turkish diplomats could not win in weeks of talks with Greek negotiators. The fighting is now generally over, but its effects are widespread and will not quickly diminish.

title: Ford's First Nine Days in the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17For the first time in the memory of most people in Washington, a President of the United States is actively seeking to restrain the prerogatives and the powers of his office.

title: Colleges Seek Studens
description: The fall term Is only two or three weeks away, but most of Long Island's colleges are still looking for students to fill their classroomsand their budgets.

title: French Cup Crew Is Watching Its Diet
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17At first glance, France's latest America's Cup effort suggests a kind of elegant for tomorrow we die fatalism.

title: Bergen Drug Fight a Success
description: HACKENSACK  Bergen County's fight against drug traffic will be carried on without interruption, thanks to the extension of a leave granted to Lieut. Joseph Delaney of the Paramus Police Department. Lieutenant Delaney, who heads the county's Narcotics Task Force, feared that he would have to return to the Paramus department next month or run the risk of losing 18 years of pension credit.

title: Two Edges of Amnesty
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. Richard M. Nixon denied forgiveness to the Vietnamwar resisters because they would not admit that they had done anything seriously wrong. He once said that to grant them amnesty would be en immoral thing.

title: Grace Regan Is Bride Of John J. Conway 3d
description: Grace Mary Regan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mahon Regan of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John Joseph Conway 3d, son of State Supreme Court Justice Conway Jr. and Mrs. Conway of Rochester. The Rev. Leo J. Daly performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: FosterChildren Aid Raised
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 17 (UPI)Connecticut Department has announced that clothing allowances for foster children under state care will be increased $6.25 a month. The Welfare Commissioner, Nicholas Norton, said yesterday that the increase would affect some 4,500 children and 2,000 foster parents.

title: GREECE EXPECTED TO CURB U.S. BASES
description: ATHENS, Aug. 17American and Greek officials are now assuming that the United States will eventually be asked to vacate or reorganize at least some of the seven major military installations it maintains in Greece.

title: The Fiddlers
description: All summer long we have had the buzz and rattle, the shrilling and hum of beetles, grasshoppers, cicadas, mosquitoes and all their insect kinfolk. The sounds have become a part of the summer days, unheard unless we specially listen. But now comes the rasp and the monotonous scratch of cricket and katydid, and who Can ignore these sounds? They are a forecast of autumn frost and November silence.

title: In search of love
description: The late Catherine Drinker Bowen was a woman and a biographer of great style and force, and I recall a luncheon during the summer before last when she spoke feelingly about the relation between literary success and guilt.

title: Tennis Sill Expanding
description: Construction has begun on two new tennis centers in the city in response to stillgrowing demand.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: George Nutman is redeveloping the former Schlitz Brewery in the Wyckoff Heights section of Brooklyn for $5million. The project, known as the Central Industrial Park, consists of four buildings containing a total of 322,500 square feet of space. Four of the brewery's old buildings are being demolished.

title: Mrs. Career Leads by 5 At St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 17 (AP)JoAnne Carver of Lake Worth, Fla., scored the first holeinone of her career today and stormed over the windswept Keller golf course with a threeunderpar 70 for a fivestroke advantage in the $35,000 St. Paul Ladies open golf tournament.

title: Moving Art Is an Art in Itself
description: Moving the sculpture collection of Joseph H, Hirshhom from his Greenwich, Conn., estate was an event that, in its own way, was in a class with the art itself.

title: Miss York Is 10Meter Dive Victor
description: DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 17 (AP)Teri York of Vancouver, British Columbia, won the women's 10meter event today during the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor diving championships.

title: CollegeBased Consumer Advocates Keep Busy
description: NEW BRUNSWICKAt a time when campus activism seems to have simmered down, a studentsponsored organization that originated here is agitating aggressively to correct what it considers to be social injustices.

title: WATER PLEA STIRS PORT CHESTER IRE
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y. Aug. 17The Port Chester Water Works, whose 10,000 customers pay the state's highest and the nation's secondhighest water rates, has touched off a howl of protest by asking the Public Service Commission for a 43 per cent rate increase.

title: Jersey City Is Out As STOLport Site
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Transportation has formally requested the Federal Aviation Administration to abandon any plans for a STOL (short takeoff and landing) airport on the western fringes of Jersey City. In a letter to the Federal agency, Alan Sagner, the Commissioner of Transportation, asked that an F.A.A.financed study of the proposed Meadowlands site be terminated.

title: Notes: How Dangerous Can Air Cargo Be?
description: PASSENGERS aboard United States airliners in the next few weeks may notice a transparent plastic badge, about two inches square, on the uniform of one of the flight attendants serving drinks and meals. The badge is called a thermal luminescent dosimeter, or T.L.D., and it contains five crystal beads that absorb radioactivity. About 200 attendants are wearing these badges in an experiment aimed at measuring the extent to which they (and their passengers) are exposed to emissions from radioactive materials carried in the cargo holds of commercial aircraft. The attendants are putting on their T.L.D.'s every time they fly during an eightweek period. The badges will then be sent for examination to the Atomic Energy Commission, which supplied them to the Transport Workers Union and the Association of Flight Attendants, the two organizations that stewardesses and stewards.

title: Cigarette Sales Ban Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Senator Prank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, has filed a suit that seeks to ban the sale of cigarettes in interstate commerce. The suit, filed in United States District Court Tuesday, seeks to have the Consumer Product Safety Commission declare that cigarettes cannot be sold in interstate commerce be cause they are a hazardous substance.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: MAKER TO BUY BACK SUBSTANDARD CRIBS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)The manufacturer of potentially dangerous fullsize baby crib has agreed to buy back thousands of the beds because they fail to meet minimum Federal safety standards.

title: Correction
description: A summary on Page 1 of last week's Review said erroneously that Gerald R. Ford had been sworn in as President on Thursday; he took the oath of office on Friday, Aug. 9.

title: Nixon, Day Before He Restgned, Sealed PrePresidential Papers for 11 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17On the day Richard M. Nixon anflounced his intention to resign the Presidency, he also wrote a letter changing the terms of his gift of his prePresidential papers to the National Archives.

title: Citizens Panel Charges Kingston Jail With Repression, Bad Administration
description: A citizens committee looking into the 11monthold, $3million county jail in Kingston, N.Y., has reported that the institution is plagued by a disorderly administration, a lowpaid staff and by repressive procedures that exceed the state's correctional facilities in restrictive practices.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress reports based on, Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Epilogue
description: Those Changing Minds

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut has approved the creation of 21 new administrative positions in the State Energy Agency to formulate an energy planning program. The fields they will study, generally, according to Lynn Allen Brooks, director of the Energy Agency, will be and use, the environment and transportation. The salaries of the 21 aides will total more than $250,000 a year, officials said. In Hartford, while announcing the new positions, Mr. Brooks added that he expected spot shortages of petroleum products in the state this winter, but not a critical situation.

title: An Underground Art Shop
description: MAPLEWOODFrom the outside, the whiteframe house on Baldwin Road looks like any other comfortable family dwelling. However, its basement houses Atelier 3, a cooperative graphics workshop organized by three gifted local housewives.

title: TURKS PUT DEATHS IN CYPRUS AT 250
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 17 The Turkish armed forces suffered 250 dead and 550 wounded in their operations on Cyprus, which began more than three weeks ago, according to Gen. Semih Sancar, the chief of the Turkish General Staff.

title: Domres Star As Colts Top Browns, 373
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP)  Marty Domres passed for one touchdown and ran for another as the Baltimore Colts rolled up a 373 victory over the Cleveland Browns in a National Football League exhibition tonight.

title: The Poor and Huddled Now Come from South America
description: Drawn by dreams and dollars, Latin imigrants are coming to the New York area, from as far south as Argentina and as near as Cuba and the Dominican Republic. Most come here illegally, as did the 58 Ecuadorians who suffered through six days in the cargo holds of a New Yorkbound freighter only to be deported last week by Federal immigration officials. Jobless, penniless and with scant hope for a better life in their own countries, they search for ways circumvent the restrictive quotas imposed on immigrants by United States immigration laws.

title: Maria Duke Is Fiancee Of Frederic de Peyster 3d
description: Maria Luisaiddle Deke, the daughter of Angler Biddle Duke, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Public Events, plans to be married next month to Frederic Ashton de Peyster 3d, a descendant of Mayor Abraham de Peyster of New York (1692 1699).

title: Bruce Kendall Weds Julia Dominick
description: The marriage of Julia Jay Dominick to Bruce Michael Kendall, son of Walter Nelson Kendall of Henton, Lincolnshire, England, and Helen Doris Ezzy of London, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, L. I.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: MENTION the name of Ford overseas and you're likely to call to mind an image of the United States automobile industry. The Ford Motor Company, after all, is the major American auto name abroad, and foreigners might he forgiven if they think it is a member of that company who has become President of the United States. They might not be entirely off the mark.

title: Marcia Dixcy Married to James A. Carr
description: Marcia Dixcy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dixcy of Verona, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to James Andrew Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Carr of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Give a Wild Horse An Inch, and ...

title: Catholic Schools Face Strike
description: Lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens have threatened to strike when school starts on Sept. 3 unless significant progress is made during negotiations over the renewal of a contract that expires on Aug. 31.

title: Tension Grips a U.S. Base on Crete
description: IRAKLEION AIR STATION, Crete, Aug. 16It was an uneasy Friday at the American air station at Irakleion on the north shore of Crete, 300 miles due south of Athens.

title: U. N. Population Talks to Open in Bucharest
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 17The first World Population Conference, a governmentlevel meeting convoked by the United Nations, opens here Monday with 100 nations due to participate.

title: Nixon: A Truce, But Not Yet Peace
description: WASHINGTONThere is a law in California proclaiming that the beaches belong to the people, but, as President, Richard M. Nixon had taken over a beautiful stretch of sand called Red Beach and frequently went there by helicopter to while away the hours.

title: American folk art and Shaker faith
description: Picture a bright blue book jacket with a headandshoulders color photograph of a lumpy snowman, with a carrot nose and a nut for one eye and a prune for the other. Open the book and find (what could be more sensible?) a gate, two gates, in fact, one from the 1870's and the other from contemporary Vermont, each painted red, white and blue in imitation of Old Glory!

title: The Mad Honey of Pontus
description: TRABZON, TurkeyWhen Xenophon's Ten Thousand hacked their way out of the Ciscaucasian Mountains east of here 25 centuries ago, they screemed: Thalassa, Thalasse as they sighted the sullen Black Sea and stumbled down to the slatecolored rollers. Shortly afterward they were devastated by the famous mad honey distilled by frenzied bees from the azales of this Bantus region.

title: The Guest Word
description: Johanna Davis was killed in a brutally freakish traffic accident on July 25, 1974, at the age of 36. She was the author of one novel, Life Signs, published, by Atheneum, and very well received last year, a polished, comic, poignant piece of work done, after much struggle, perfectly in her own voice. Its paperback edition was issued, by Dell, three weeks before her death. She looked forward with absolute lust to public recognition; she saw some.

title: Doubt on MentalFignae Curbs
description: The people of the Rockaways, for years inundated by assorted griefsfrom eroded beaches to crazyquilt urban renewalhad reason to be happy last week.

title: Hal Stern Marries Marjorie J. Block
description: Marjorie J. Block, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Block of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Hal T. Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig S. Stern of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Tortured Woman Bewildered by Plight
description: SAIGON, South VietnamArrests by the South Vietnamese Government are not always calculated, often having a random aspect, touching not only those who know they are taking risks but also those who apparently do not.

title: Food
description: We can recall in clearly etched detail some fairly fancy spreads we've been privileged to enjoy around the world fresh caviar in Iran; fresh foie gras in A??ace; bouillabaisse and bourride in restaurants around the Vieux Port in Marseilles. But it literally is true that truffles and champagne are no more apt, to aggravate and appease the appetite than humbler foods taken at a country outing. Five dishes for al fresco dining are offered here: an escabdche of fish; marinated beef to be grilled over charcoal; spareribs, vaguely Hawaiian; roasted peppers with anchovies; and sugared mango slices with champagne.

title: State Seeks to End Dispute Over Dam
description: MEDFORD  Many residents of this Burlington County township were upset over the fact that untreated sewage from neighboring Evesham Towoship was flowing down the southwest branch of Rancocas Creek.

title: Drought on the Plains Is A Recurring Calamity
description: WASHINGTONThey pray for rain in England, and in that blessed isle the prayers are always granted. But in God's Own Country they pray for rain and the rains do not always, come. In the old days, on the dry Great Plains, people prayed and set off explosives to pry rain from the pitiless blue skies. There is no proof that one method was more effective than another, or less.

title: C. D. Braver Fiance of Jill Seligson
description: Rabbi and Mrs. David J. Seligson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Seligson, to Charles David Braver, a managing editor at MEDCOM, where the bridetobe is an editorial assistant.

title: News of the Stage
description: A new production of Eugene O'Neill's Hughie, with Ben Gazzara returning to Broadway in the title role, has been scheduled for a local premiere on Oct. 15 at the Booth Theater, following successful runs in Chicago, where it played for three months, St. Louis and Los Angeles. The oneact, onehour, twocharacter drama concludes there on Aug. 31 at the Huntington Hartford Theater.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT FORD rebuked the General Motors Corporation for raising prices of its 1975 cars by 9.5 per cent.... With buyers seeking to beat the price increase, car sales the first 10 days of August rose 2.2 per cent over the level of the comparable period in 1973.

title: Dispute Still Rages as West Village Houses Meets Its Sales Test
description: ... The fate of that development [West Village Houses] will, I'm sure, be watched closely.John E. Zuccotti, Chairman, City Planning Cornmission, in a speech, The Death and Life of Great American Cities Revisited, given at Columbia University last February.

title: Letters: Dirty Rest Rooms
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a trip through Southern New England, I want to say that I was aghast at the generally slovenly and in many cases filthy condition of the rest rooms in all of the halfdozen or so gas stations in which we stopped.

title: Two Yablonski Murderers Are Given Probation and. New Identities
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 17 (UPI) Two admitted murderers were given probation and new identities today In return for confessions that ultimately led to the conviction of W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, for the 1969 Yablonski slayings.

title: Federal Bailouts...
description: Where to get the money the Grumman Corporation needs to continue production of F14 fighter planes has become an international mare's nest. The Senate has voted to halt projected advance payments of $100 million by the Navy to bail out Grumman. The Iranian Government, with eighty F14's on order, is eager to ease the problem by lending the company what it needs.

title: Sharks of W.F.L. Oust Head Coach
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP)Bud Asher, head coach of the World Football League's Jacksonville. Sharks, was dismissed today and replaced by one of his assistants, Charley Tate.

title: Ann R. Ruderman Sets Sept. 5 Bridal
description: The engagement of Ann Roberta Ruderman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel L. Ruderman of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Pompano Beach, Fla., to Robert Margolis, son of Mrs. Abe Margolis of Clifton, N. J., and the late Mr. Margolis, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Lack of Training and Execution Shows in Jets' Performance
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 17 At first glance, it appeared that the mammoth crew of a Cecil B. DeMille epic film had encountered the tiny cast of a lowbudget movie.

title: Mobile Unit. Cuts Inspection TieUps
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK  A mobile motorvehicle inspection unit, operating next to the permanent onelane inspection station on U.S. 1 South, has cut driver waiting time from more than an hour to 20 minutes or less.

title: Lawyers for Two Indians Seek Curbs on Marshals
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 18Defense attorneys for Russell C. Meane and Dennis J. Banks have asked that Federal marshals not be allowed to communicate with the jury when it begins deliberating the charges against the two for their part in last year's Indian uprising in Woun?? Knee, S.D.

title: District Town in Vietnam Falls to Communist Force
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Communist troops have captured a second district capital in their monthlong campaign in South Vietnam's northcentral provinces, the Saigon command announced today.

title: Tackling the World Food Problem
description: WASHINGTON We have a new President and it is a time for new beginnings. It is an opportunity to grapple with the great problems that confront our nation and the world.

title: '74 Soap Box Derby Smaller and Quieter Because of '73 Scandal
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug, 18Fred Mohler, a thin, small, shy mai who had won the AllAmericar Soap Box Derby in 1953, sat by himself at the former champion's table at the banquet for this year's winners and looked around for a friendly face.

title: Woman Doctor, 72, Is Stabbed to Death In Jersey City Home
description: A partly disabled 72yearold woman physician was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in the kitchen of her apartment on a quiet resider tial street in Jersey City.

title: KRIENDLER RITES ATTENDED BY 1,500
description: A funeral service for I. Robert Kriendler, president of the 21 Club, brought 1,500 persons to Temple EmanuEl yesterday in a mingling of civic leaders, Mr. Kriendler's Marine Corps and Reserve comrades and What many of those present called the 21 crowd. Mr. Kriendler died Thursday at the age of 60.

title: Cyprus Fighting Goes On South of Turkish Sector
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 18Fighting continued in Cyprus today well south of the line presumed to mark the Turkishcontrolled area, despite the ceasefire declared Friday after Turkish forces had seized the northern third of the island.

title: Baptism Issue Reflects Massachusetts Abortion Split
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Aug. 18 John P. Grasso figured he was ready. At 42, he had spent six years on the City Council. Now, redistricting had made this central Massachusetts manufacturing city of 30,000 the biggest population center and thus the key to the new WorcesterMiddlesex state senatorial district.

title: Cynthia Marsh Bride of Alvan Fuller 3d
description: Cynthia Lee Marsh, daughter of Theron Ludlow Marsh of Bernardsville, N.J., and Mrs. Virginia Marsh of Asheville, N.C., was married yesterday to Alvan Tufts Fuller 3d of Andover, Mass. He is a son of Mr. Fuller of Palm Beach, Fla., and Mrs. Reynolds Fuller of Boston. He is a grandson of the late Gov, Alvan T. Fuller of Massachusetts.

title: What You Need, Pet, Is a Week at Camp
description: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y.At Campo Lindo near here, a camper named Dino is scared of thunder, according to a note from his home in the Bronx. Winston must be fed corn flakes with milk every morning, and a snack before bedtime  preferably an Oreo or a chocolate chip cookie. And Sandy has to be watched closely so she doesn't snatch food from the other campers' dishes.

title: Swim Mark Broken by E. German
description: VIENNA, Aug 18 (AP)Ulrike Tauber of East Germany swept to the first world record of the European swimming championships today and showed that her country was still the team to beat.

title: Saigon's Military Courts Dominate Judicial System
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18  The small courtroom is lit dimly by a few bare bulbs on the ceiling. From behind the heavy black judicial bench five army officers in battle fatigues peer out at the prisoners, who stand silently among their families and friends. In an aisle a military policeman fingers half a dozen handcuffs, getting them ready. The chief judge, lieutenant colonel, reads the verdicts.

title: POLICE SPECULATE ON GIRL'S SLUM
description: Queens detectives and resi dents agreed yesterday that whoever sexually molested and killed 17yearold Leslie Zaret in a lonely, darkened Bayside schoolyard was likely to have known his way around there, miles from where she was last seen late Friday night.

title: LeBoeuf, in Third Fastest Hydroplane, Takes Prize
description: RED BANK, N. J., Aug. 18 A fat carrot dangled in front of six starters in the Sea Colony Grand Prix hydroplane race todaya $2,000 first prize, And it was claimed by a man who had traveled a long way for it, Jules LeBoeuf of Valleyfield, Canada. But not before officials yanked the carrot away from Larry Lauterbach of Portsmith, Va.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug 18 (AP)Chris Evert, who failed to beat male horses in the Travers Stakes yesterday, will not ran against them in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup Sept. 14. She will make her next start against fillies and mares in the $100,000added Beldame Sept. 21, at Belmont Park, Joe Trovato, her trainer, said today.

title: Israelis Arrest Greek Catholic Archbishop on Weapons Charges
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 18Archbishop Hilarion Capucci, the head of the Greek Catholic Church in Jerusalem, was arrested by Israeli police today and charged with smuggling weapons and explosives to Palestinian guerrillas operating on the occupied West Bank.

title: Legion Expansion Proposed,
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18 (AP)The American Legion has been told that it can increase its mem bership by nearly half. A Roper Organization survey estimated the veterans' organization could increase its 2.7 million members by as much as 1.3 million or 1.8 million in today's climate of opinion.

title: A Woman Doctor, 72, Found Slain in Jersey City
description: A partly disabled 72yearold woman physician was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in the kitchen of her apartment on a quiet residential street in Jersey City.

title: Cyprus Fighting Goes On South of Turkish Sector
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 18Fighting continued in Cyprus today well south of the line presumed to mark the Turkishcontrolled area, despite the ceasefire declared Friday after Turkish forces had seized the northern third of the island.

title: Miss Lerner Wed to Harold Rabinovitz
description: Sharon Holly Lerner, who graduated cum laude from Vassar College in June, was married yesterday afternoon to Harold Rabinovitz, a cum laude graduate of Princeton University and a student at the University of Miami Medical School.

title: About New York
description: Barely a month ago, in the third week of July, Joe Cook and Greg Coverdale thought that they would like to celebrate their August birthdays by giving New York City a gift of themselves and their talent with a free jazz and rock guitar concert in the park. Any park would have been fine with them, but Central Park on a Sunday afternoon the most ideal of places and times  was what they really wanted.

title: Soviet Border Negotiator Quits China
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18The Soviet Union's chief negotiator in its border dispute with China, Leonid F. Ilyichev, flew home today, less than two months after he went to Peking to try to resume the stalled negotiations.

title: Next Steps on Cyprus
description: Greece's rejection of American mediation in the Cyprus disaster and the unwillingness of either Athens or the Greek Cypriote Government to enter new negotiations with Turkey are entirely understandable. But these refusals cannot justify diplomatic timemarking either by the United Nations or by the United States, which bears heavy responsibility for the Cyprus tragedy.

title: Hunt Says Seven Cartons Had No Rockefeller Data
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18E. Howar Hunt Jr. said today that, as far as he knew, the seven mysterious cartons stored in his White House office after the Watergate breakin in June, 1972, contained hundreds of copies of a booklength criticism of television news reporting but no information concerning former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York.

title: Youth Badly Burned
description: A 16yearold youth was critically burned last night when a gas explosion touched off a fire that damaged several apartments on the first and second floors of an East Village building, at 376 East Eighth Street, fire officials reported. They said the youth, Ralph Garcia of 555 F.D.R. Drive, was taken to Bellevue Hospital with second and thirddegree burns.

title: Diane Regan Bride of P. S. Doniger
description: Diane Gordon Regan and Peter Scott Doniger, students at the University of Rochester, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Thomas Regan in Morristown, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. William Doniger of Rye, N.Y. and the late Mr. Doniger.

title: Time Is Running Out for Clockmaker
description: A company that first made clocks for sale by horsebackriding Yankee peddlers 143 years ago and went on to produce dollar pocketwatches by the millions now faces shutdown within four to six weeks.

title: Tkac Wins World Title In Cycling
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (UPI)Anton Tkac of Czechoslovakia won the gold medal inn the sprint and Jean Breuer of West Germany the motorpace title today at the 1974 world amateur cycling championships.

title: A Belated Note of Tribute Paid To Ragtime's Scott Joplin Here
description: When Scott Joplin died on April 1, 1917, at the age of 48, he was buried at St. Michael's Cemetery in Astoria, Queens, without ceremony or gravestone. He died penniless and friendless, although he was recognized as the preeminent ragtime pianist of his day.

title: Mandel and Mathias in Maryland Face Unusual Opposition in Elections in Fall
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 18Two very different Maryland politicians. Gov. Marvin Mandel and Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., face unusual opposition this fall.

title: Rhodes Expects Nixon Will Admit His Guilt
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Muse minority leader, John J. Rhodes, said today that it would be useful if former President Richard M. Nixon publicly admitted his guilt in the Watergate coverup, and predicted that eventually Mr. Nixon Would do so.

title: Ford and Hussein Agree to Seek JordanianIsraeli Troop Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) President Ford and King HusSein of Jordan announced an agreement today to work toWard a troop disengagement accord between Jordan and Israel at an early date.

title: Homer by Burroughs Lifts Rangers, 10
description: Everything is big in Texas, including the turnaround of the Texas Rangers.

title: Anti.Abortionists Step Up Drive Against Court Ruling
description: VERONABouncing her 9monthold baby on her hr while her 2yearold napped upstairs, Sarina Reeves sat on a wroughtiron patio chair the other day and talked optimistically about the steppedup efforts in this heavily Roman Catholic state to prevent abortion and to overturn the 1973 United States Supreme Court decision permitting it.

title: International Banking Activity Now Curtailed
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  The collage of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt or West Germany seven weeks ago and the troubles experienced by the Franklin National Bank of New York and a number of leading European institutions have brought about a drastic contraction of international banking activity.

title: FUEL DEALERS SEE PRICES STEAM
description: Fuel dealers in the metropolitan area, looking beyond the current summer days, report that the supply of heating oil seems adequate for this winter, and they say it is unlikely that the price of the fuel will go up sharply from its present levels.

title: Primus Fanga Enchants
description: Editing requires its own kind of genius, and Pearl Primus did a marvelous job when she distilled Fange into a brief solo from an extended group dance.

title: Kissinger's Role in Cyprus Crisis Criticized
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  The monthold Cyprus crisis has left the Turks satisfied, the Greeks dismayed and angry and European experts in bewilderment over whether Secretary of State Kissinger has lost his diplomatic touch.

title: Joe, 7YearOld Borzoi, Chosen Best at Elmira
description: HORSEHEADS, N. Y., Aug. 18A 7yearold borzoi, Ch. Loral's Iossif Ivanevitch, the oldest dog in the ring, gave the five other finalists a lesson in showmanship today and took the top award at the Elmira Kennel Club's fixture. The event was held in the Golden Domes of Elmira College.

title: LINDSAY RETURNS; PLANS UNCERTAIN
description: John V. Lindsay, his suitcases bursting, his mood jovial and his political future uncertain, arrived home yesterday afternoon after an eightmonth vacation in the Caribbean and Europe for decompression from the rigors of being an eightyear Mayor of New York.

title: Doorman Holds Up Tenants of Building On West End Ave.
description: A tall intruder donned green, illfitting doorman's uniform in the lobby of a West Side luxury apartment building just after noon yesterday and, with polite greetings and a menacing gun, robbed tenants in bunches as they strolled in.

title: SamuelsCarey Campaign Heats Up as Charges Fly
description: Their early summer pledge not to attack one another apparently abandoned for good, the two candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination traded charges and countercharges yesterday as the campaign headed toward the final full three weeks before the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Santa Clara Drums Win
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Snta Clara, Calif., Vanguard marched and played its way to the Drum Corps International Championship today at Cornell University.

title: Canadian Farmers' Hopes Dashed for Peak Wheat Sales
description: WINNIPEG, Alberta, Aug. 16 As the farmers across Canada's broad, golden prairies begin their annual wheat harvest, they have disappointing news for eager buyers around the world:

title: Irving F. Singer, 56, Dies; Chemical Concern Official
description: Irving F. Singer, retired vice president of the Hugo Stinnes Company, a chemicals concern, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 336 Summit Avenue in Mount Vernon.

title: Portugal Ends 2Day Talks With Mozambican Guerrillas
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Mario Soares of Portugal has left here after, two days of private talks with guerrilla leaders from Mozambique On the political future of the Portuguese territory.

title: Retailers Cautious on Fall Buying Plans
description: Retailers across much of the country are exhibiting unusual caution on their inventory, and merchandising plans for fall, winter and next spring.

title: PENTAGON'S CHIEF CAUTIONS TURKEY ON CYPRUS DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, employing Washington's toughest diplomatic language thus far in the Cyprus crisis, warned Turkey today against using her military superiority to drive the new Greek Government into a corner.

title: Jockey Killed in Race
description: CHESTER, W. Va,. Aug. 13 (UPI}Johnny Hathaway was fatally injured last night at iaterford Park when hismount stumbled and threw him into the path of a charging thoroughbred. The 23yearold Hathaway, the secand leading rider at the current meet, was the second jockey to die in a race at Waterford Park this year. Mike Tornambe was killed in February when he was thrown from his mount.

title: Amoskeag Official Seeks Rail Merger
description: Frederic C. Dumaine Jr. is urging a common management and eventual merger of the three northern New England railroads, to be followed by a merger with the Delaware & Hudson Railway.

title: Books of The Times
description: FIGURE 8. By Mark Dintenfass, 222 pages. Simon & Schuster, $6.95. Michael Silversmith chooses to be a silversmith in fact as well as name because he imagines he is extending a long line of ancestral continuity, a history of craftsmanship as a paradigm for integrity. He is a maker, shaping with his hands what he considers to be palpable proofs of order. His perfectionism in his work is a form of prayer, an offering to an absolute standard that serves him as an organizing principle or religion. He is a true believer, a superior example of the Zenintheartofsandalmaking movement that is sweeping America.

title: LONG RENOMINATED IN LOUISIANA VOTING
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 18 (UPI)Russell B. Long won renomination to another term in the Senate in yesterday's Democratic primary, getting 75 per cent of the vote and carrying all of the state's 64 parishes.

title: Qaddafi Meets Sadat in Egypt In Endeavor to Settle Quarrel
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18 (AP)President. Anwar elSadat and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elOaddafi, attempted today to settle their differences following the surprise arrival of Colonel Qaddafi in Alexandria.

title: Ford's Old Friends Include Big Corporate Lobbyists
description: President Ford's circle of friends from the business community includes several of Washington's most powerful corporate lobbyists, some of whom are helping shape his Administration during the transitional period.

title: 17Hit Attack Paced by Murcer, Munson in 94 Victory
description: The Yankees got back to the .500 mark yesterday with one of their biggest offensive barrages of the season. They pounded four Chicago White Sox pitchers for 17 hits while coasting to a 94 victory before a crowd of 18,493 on a lovely, sunny day at Shea Stadium.

title: Dr. Victor W. Cohen Dies; A Physicist at Brookhaven
description: Dr. Victor W. Cohen, a physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory since 1947, died Saturday of cancer at his home, 63 Everett Street, Patchogue, L. I. He was 63 years old.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: New Jersey's smallclaims courts, theoretically the poor man's court, where the consumer with a gripe can have his day, have been weighted in the balance and found wanting.

title: U.S. Indians Press Drive To Get Independent Status
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16American Indians, spurred by a fouryearold promise from the White House of selfgovernment, are making everincreasing demands that their reservations be given commonwealth status.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 19, 1974

title: Giants Show Drive Under Arnsparger
description: Larance Jones jogged off the field, disconsolate after his exciting 50yard punt return for the New York Giants had ended with a fumble recovery by the Jets.

title: IranianSoviet Gas Accord
description: TEHRAN, Iran, Aug. 18After 10 days of negotiations, a new price of 57 cents for every 1,000 cubic feet of natural gas sent from Iran to the Soviet Union has been agreed upon. The old price was 30.7 cents.

title: VERY REV. PERCY URBAN
description: The Very Rev. Dr. Percy Linwood Urban, who was named dean emeritus of the Berkeley Divinity School in New Haven in 1957, died Friday in New Haven, where he lived. He was 88years old.

title: Major Bills in Congress
2 Mounted Policemen Robbed of Their Bikes
description: Two police officers on anticrime patrol in Central Park were held up at gunpoint yesterday and robbed of their bicycles.

title: International Banking Activity Now Curtailed
description: Retailers across much of the country are exhibiting unusual caution on their inventory and merchandising plans for fall, winter and next spring.

title: U.S. Indians Press Drive To Get Independent Status
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16American Indians, spurred by a fouryearold promise from the White House of selfgovernment, are making everincreasing demands that their reservations be given commonwealth status:

title: Controls to Battle Inflation Favored By Half in Survey
description: A return to wage and price controls'as a way to fight inflation was favored by half the persons interviewed in a recent Gallup Poll. Survey.

title: Voice for Consumers
description: This week, for the third and probably last time, a majority of the United States Senate will attempt to break a determined filibuster being carried out in opposition to the establishment of a Federal Government agency promote and protect the consumer interest.

title: FORD'S SELECTION OF VICE PRESIDENT IS SET TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18President Ford, on his way to the golf course this afternoon, told reporters that he would choose a Vice President on Tuesday.

title: GEORGE C. CLARK
description: George Crawford Clark, a former partner in Clark, Dodge & Co., investment bankers now part of Kidder, Peabody & Co., died Friday in Princeton, N. J., where he lived. His age was 95.

title: Ford's Old Friends Include Big Corporate Lobbyists
description: President Ford's circle of friends from the business community includes several of Washington's most powerful corporate lobbyists, some of whom are helping shape his Administration during the transitional period.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
N.A.A.C.P. Chapter Requests Parley on National Problems
description: The New York State chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday for a White House conference to consider not only inflation, but also the problems of unemployment, housing and other national concerns.

title: 100 Roll Out the Ball at Boccie Contest
description: Tony Picano wrinkled his face in concentration and slowly rolled the red boccie ball down the smooth, oblong dirt court. It careened off the sideboard and stopped inches from the jack, a smaller, white ball. He smiled as shouts of That's my paesenor accompanied his winning point.

title: Siri Swenson, Lawyer, Is Married
description: The Barrington (RI) Congregational Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Siri Swenson, a lawyer and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Swenson Jr. of Barrington, to Robert Patterson Marshall Jr., a lawyer of New York, and son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Youths Alcohol Abuse Called Alarming Here
description: Alcohol abuse, alcoholism, and the combined use of alcohol and other drugs among adolescents in New York City has become an alarming problem, according to Joel Bennett, president of the New York Council on Alcoholism.

title: Watergate Backwash
description: How difficult it will be to banish from American political life the dark suspicions born of Watergate indicated by the brief attention given at the White House to a malicious effort by enemies of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller to knock him out of consideration for the Vice Presidency. On the basis of shadowy allegations from an even more shadowy informant, a chain of overresponse by government and press created a momentary sense that a nauseating new instance of political chicanery in the 1972 campaign had been uncovered.

title: Saigon's Military Courts Dominate Judicial System
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18  The small courtroom is lit dimly by a few bare bulbs on the ceiling. From behind the heavy black judicial bench five army officers in battle fatigues peer out at the prisoners, who stand silently among their families and friends. In an aisle a military policeman fingers half a dozen handcuffs, getting them ready. The chief judge, a lieutenant colonel, reads the verdicts.

title: ShortTerm Rates Rise Although Fed Holds Steady Rein
description: The Federal Reserve kept its hands firmly on the credit wheel last week, although money market experts professed to be a bit, uncertain as to what direction the central bank was taking. Outwardly, the indicators pointed to where the Fed apparently wants them: Federal funds (interbank lending charges) were frozen in the 12 to 12.5 per cent range. The prime bank rate held at 12 per cent, along with the interest on large certificates of deposit.

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N, Y., Aug. 18Throughout the race, Mrs. Carl Rosen sat frozen, both hands clenched in front of her in an attitude of supplication. Mrs. Rosen and her husband own the admirable filly, Chris Evert, who was out there in the mud giving battle to 10 males in the 105th Travers Stakes, the oldest and one of the most distinguished events still contested in this country. The first filly ever to win the Travers was Ruthless, one of the doughty daughters of the mare Barbarity who were acclaimed a century ago as the Barbarous Battalion, and if Chris could bring it off she would be only the sixth. It was a searching assignment for the tough young lady, her second mileandaquarter chore in a weekshe had been beaten a neck last time out in the Alabama Stakes for filliesand this field included not only Little Current, winner of the Preakness and Belmont Stakes, but also Little Current's recent conqueror, Holding Pattern.

title: India's Presidency: Pomp or Power?
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18  The two  decade debate over whether the President of India is an ornamental figure or a political power was renewed this weekend as Indian legislators voted for a new President.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 27

title: Triangles Beat Sets
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Pittsburgh Triangles ended their regular World Team Tennis season tonight with a 3219 victory over the New York Sets. It was the Triangles' seventh straight triumph.

title: Ann Thomas Has Nuptials
description: Ann Freda Thomas and Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz, who are students at the Yale Law School, were married yesterday at Congregation Sons of Israel in Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Leon Katz performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Bernard Rothman.

title: NO PROGRESS MADE IN 2 GIRLS' SLAYINGS
description: NORTH BERGEN, Aug. 18 (UPI)The North Bergen police continued this weekend to question relatives and friends of two girls who were raped and murdered last week, but they said there had been no progress made in their investigation of the murders.

title: Los Angeles Police Report Explosion Was Not Bombing
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18The explosion that leveled a city block and did substantial damage in a fiveblocksquare downtown industrial area last night was not caused by a bomb, the police said today. At least four persons were injured and the damage was placed in the millions of dollars.

title: Vilas Victor In Canadian Net Final
description: TORONTO, Aug. 18 (AP)Guillermo Vilas overpowered Manuel Orantes, 64, 6.2, 63, today to win the men's singles title in the $130,000 Canadian open tennis tournament.

title: NEW U. S. FIGURES GAUGE HONE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Commerce Department published today two major new statistics to help describe the American economy  a new measurement of capacity utili. zation in manufacturing and the first detailed information on how much is being spent by business for pollution abatement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Holly Mottershead, the 13yearold daughter of a New Jersey stockbroker who is accused of wounding her and of murdering her 10yearold brother, Michael, was reported in extremely critical condition and worsening at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank. The father, Robert E Mottershead, 44 years old, of Little Silver, who is thought by police to have been distraught about his wife's pending death from cancer, is being held in lieu of $100,000 bail in Monmouth County Jail. Mrs. Wanda Mottershead, the victim's grandmother, was reported in satisfactory condition at the hospital with a broken shoulder she suffered when she was informed of the shootings and fainted.

title: 2 Policemen Robbed Of Bicycles in Park
description: Two police officers on anticrime patrol in Central Park were held up at gunpoint yesterday and robbed of their bicycles.

title: Manhattan Plaza: Quality Housing to Uprade 42d St.
description: A lot of people say I'm nuts to be doing this, says Richard Ravitch, the New York builder who has done a number of unorthodox things in the last few years, including creating Waterside, the muchacclaimed fourtower apartment complex built on a platform in the East River above 23d Street.

title: Like Broadway, London's West End Is Playing It Safe
description: LONDON, Aug. 18In New York, we have become conditioned to believe that London is wonderfully hospitable to the new and adventurous in drama, This may be true, but I suspect it is not nearly so true as we so fondly believe.

title: LEGAL DIVORCES URGED IN BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18The Brazilian Bar Association has called for the legalization of divorce as a basic human right in this large Roman Catholic country.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 27

title: Advertising: Industrial Changes
description: Industrial advertisingthe messages businesses send to other businesses rather than to consumersis changing, and no one realizes this more than the agencies concerned.

title: Ethiopian Church Protests Military's Plan for Charter
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18  The powerful Ethiopian Orthodox Church today challenged the armed forces, which are in effect running the country, by protesting against their draft for a new constitution.

title: SUMNER COOPER
description: Sumner Cooper, a textile representative and silversmith, died Friday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 63 years old.

title: Mariner Wins One Race and Loses Another
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18Over the protest table and not at sea, the yacht Mariner won one race and lost an other today in the America's Cup final trials. No competition was scheduled but the New York Yacht Club Race Committee cleaned up the matter of three protests hanging from last Friday's races.

title: GARAGE EMPLOYE SLAIN BY YOUTHS
description: A 64yearold attendant in a midtown garage was shot to death on the garage ramp shortly after midnight yesterday as he sought to chase away five youths he had apparently believed were after the money he kept in his cashier's cage.

title: Personal Finance
description: Millions of people buy land for investment, but few really understand the tax regulations that allow some land sales to qualify for capitalgains treatmentand lower taxesrather than treatment as ordinary income.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PLAINFIELD, Aug. 18 Kathy Linney is a Working woman, a computer programmer with a master's degree mathematics. But she works just enough to support her habit, which is golf. Some days she gets up and plays golf, then goes to work. Some days she goes to work until noon and then plays golf, and some days she just plays golf.

title: Fuel Supplies Good
description: There are adequate supplies of home heating oil for this winter and the price is not likely to rise sharply from present levels, according to fuel dealers in the metropolitan area. Page 26.

title: RATE RISE OF 12.2% IS SOUGHT BY Hit
description: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has applied for a twostage, 12.2 per cent rate increase that would add more than $3 a month to group family coverage and cost the city an extra $3.3million a year as its share of the prenriurns for municipal employes.

title: Stockton Wins by 4 Strokes
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP)Dave Stockton capped his frontrunning, recordsetting performance with a twounderpar 69 today and breezed to a fourstroke victory in the Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open golf tournament. His total was 268.

title: Preseason Football
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Jobless Rate Put at 7,9 Per Cent; State Resuming Posting of Data
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) The State Department of Labor and Industry, resuming publication of unemployment statistics, said yesterday that statewide unemployment for June this year was 7.9 per cent.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Toros, Aztecs To Vie for Title
description: The North American Soccer League's championship gaine, which will be televised nationally from the Orange Bowl on Sunday, will be between the Miami Toros and the Los Angeles Aztecs.

title: Martha Grodd Married
description: Martha Louise Grodd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Grodd, was married here yesterday afternoon at the Delmonico to HaroldL. DeMoss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth DeMoss of Longdale, Okla. Rabbi David Eichhorn performed the ceremony. The bride graduated in May from Lesley College. Her husband is student at the Medical School of Oklahoma University.

title: Strike Takes Its Toll in Jets' Performance
description: The National Football League Players' Association strike took its toll on the New York Jets, just as Coach Charley Winner had fretted about.

title: Young, of Plumbers, To Be Oxford Student
description: OXFORD, England, Aug. 18 (AP)David R. Young, Jr., a former White House aide who was a member of the special investigative unit known as the plumbers, has been accepted for graduate studies at Oxford University, a university spokesman said today.

title: Concepcion's Blast Off Matlack With 2 On Decides
Reutemann Prix Victor In Austria
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. If (UPI)Carlos Reutemann of Argentina won the Austrian Grand Prix today in the fastest and hottest Formula One race of the season.

title: Neal Brown Weds Adina D. Salomon
description: Adina Deborah Salomon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Salomon of Manhattan, was married yesterday evening to Neal H. Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Brown of Manhattan and Long Branch, N.J.

title: Jersey Field of 57 Is Seeking 15 Seats In U.S. House Races
description: Fiftyseven candidates, the largest field in the memory of New Jersey political observers, are vying for the state's 15 Congressional seats in the November elections, according to records on file at the office of the Secretary of State in Trenton.

title: Purdy's at Buddy's Place
description: An instructive change of drummers has taken place at Buddy's Place, Second Avenue at 64th Street. Normally this is the home base of Buddy Rich, but while Mr. Rich is, on the road with his sextet, another drummer, Bernard (Pretty) Purdy, has moved in with his sextet.

title: Minority Has Nuances in City Hall Job Disbursements and Favors
description: On the surface, it was a simple New York City politicalracial disputean effor to appoint a black man to a middling municipal job that had been held by a Puerto Rican. But connoisseurs of the city's political intricacies could find a richer tale in the obligatory oratorical posturing and the muttered asides at a City Council session the other day.

title: 17Hit Attack Paced by Murcer, Manson in 94 Victory
description: The Yankees got back to the 500 mark yesterday with one of their biggest offensive barrages of the season. They pounded four Chicago White Sox pitchers for 17 hits while coasting to a 94 victory before a crowd of 18,493 on a lovely, sunny day at Shea Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The political masters of our nation's financial affairs appear to have a double standard of morality as between the borrowing practices of the Federal Government and those of the investment community.

title: No Detention Facilities, So Illegal Aliens Go Free
description: Seven apparently illegal, aliens were seized by the police in the Bronx early yesterday and then set free when the Immigration and Naturalization Service reportedly told the police that there were no available detention facilities and no investigators on duty.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A complete rendition of Arnold Schoenberg's infrequently performed cantata Gurrelieder will make up the final concert next Sunday afternoon of the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood.

title: IranianSoviet Gas Accord
description: TEHRAN, Iran, Aug. 18After 10 days of negotiations, a new price of 57 cents for every 1,000 cubic feet of natural gas sent from Iran to the Skiet Union has been agreed upon. The old price was 30.7 cents.

title: DISSIDENTS LEAVE DEMOCRATS' UNIT
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 The fifth and final meting the Democratic Charter Commission dissolved today in confusion and acrimony, as black and reform members of the party commission walked out, and through a parliamentary maneuver, cut off a series of drastic revisions of the draft document.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOLY CITY In the hushed, rambling spaces of the Jewish Museum at 1109 Fifth Avenue (at 92d Street), the faces of many generations brood from the walls, participate in celebrations and go about their daily business. The faces are in photographs at an exhibition called Jerusalem: City of Mankind, a collection of startling views of a city of legendary contrasts.

title: The President's Press Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18President Ford and J. F. terHorst, the new White House press secretary, share common backgrounds, common ideologies and common tastes, and like to ally themselves with the common man. They even go by the same first name, Jerry, although the President is Gerald Rudolph and his aide of 10 days is Jerald Franklin.

title: Pistol Team Wins Title
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP)A sixman team from the markmanship training unit at Fort Benning, Ga., fired a score of 2,897 of a possible 3,000 to win the National Trophy Team Match today.

title: PENTAGON'S CHIEF CAUTIONS TURKEY ON CYPRUS DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, employing Washington's toughest diplomatic language thus far in the Cyprus crisis, warned Turkey today against using her military superiority to drive the new Greek Government Into a corner.

title: Soviet Press Assails NATO on Cyprus
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18The Soviet press published a new round of denunciations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today, accusing it of open aggression on Cyprus.

title: Elizabeth Evarts Cox Is Wed To Keith D. Avedon, Pianist
description: Elizabeth Evarts Cox, a sophomore at the University of Colorado, was married yesterday to Keith Duggan Avedon, a pianist and composer for the proposed Denver Arts Center. The Rev, Rowland J. Cox, uncle of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mrs. Archibald Cox of Windsor, Vt., the bride's grandmother.

title: Miss Weiner Bride Of Michael Miller
description: Phyllis Weiner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Myer Weiner of Brookline, Mass., and Michael Shlomo Miller, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Miller of the Bronx, were married yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Boston.

title: Personal Finance
description: Millions of people buy land for investment, but few really understand the tax regulations that allow some land sales to qualify for capitalgains treatmentand lower taxesrather than treatment as ordinary income.

title: Builders Hope to Lure Richer Tenants to Project
description: The biggest real estate gamble currently being taken in Manhattan is the construction of a pair of apartment towers that will soar 45 stories from a blocksquare site on West 42d Street.

title: Levitt Says His Audits Show State Could Save $100Million
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that recommendations lie had made over the last two years to tighten the financial procedures of state agencies could mean a total savings of more than $100million.

title: EVANGELIST BACKS ARRESTS IN KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18The president of the Campus Crusade for Christ International, Dr. Bill Bright, asserted today that President Park Chung Hee of South Korea was justified in putting Korean Christians into prison for opposing him politically.

title: William J. Broadhurst, 62, Senior Social Worker, Dies
description: William J. Broadhurst, who was in the steel business for many years before becoming a senior social worker in 1965 for the city, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 880 Fifth Avenue.

title: Exxon to Resume Drilling In Santa Barbara Channel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The Exxon Company has been given Government permission to resume development of oil and gas leases in the Santa Barbara Channel. The leases had been idle since the oil blowout in the California channel in 1969.

title: Interception By Broncos Beats 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP)Randy Gradishar, Denver's prize linebacker from Ohio State, intercepted a pass and ran 83 yards for a touchdown with four minutes remaining today to give the Broncos a 103 National Football League exhibition victory over the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Youth, 17, Faces Questioning In the Suicide of Girl, 14
description: SOUTH AMBOY, Aug. 18 (UPI)A 17yearold youth is scheduled to be questioned tomorrow by the South Amboy police in connection with the suicide of Donna Marie Hibbs, who shot herself to death in front of his home over the weekend.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A recent column that limned and deplored airline cooking elicited a somewhat enthusiastic response from a host of readers who agreed that half a loaf stuffed with firstclass delectables would be preferable to the traditional Swiss steak and mashed potatoes served on most flights.

title: Builders Hope to Lure Richer Tenants to Project
description: The biggest real estate gamble currently being taken in Manhattan is the construction of a pair of apartment towers that will soar 45 stories from a blocksquare site on West 42d Street.

title: Wilson Says He'll Bar Campaign Aid by Ford
description: Governor Wilson said last night that because President Ford is a resident of either Grand Rapids, Mich., or Washington, D.C., the President would be neither invited nor welcomed to come to New York to campaign for Republican candidates this year.

title: Pistol Team Wins Title
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP)A sixman team from the markmanship training unit at Fort Benning, Ga., fired a score of 2,897 of a possible 3,000 to win the National Trophy Team Match today.

title: Manny Reiner, Executive Of Paramount TV Sales
description: Manny Reiner, executive vice president for international sales of Paramount Television, died Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his summer home in Westhampton Beach, L. I. He was 59 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

title: Fuel Supplies Good
description: There are adequate supplies of home heating oil for this winter and the price is not likely to rise sharply from present levels, according to fuel dealers in the metropolitan area. Page 26.

title: Communist Court Systems in Vietnam Reflect Military
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Since neither North Vietnam nor the Vietcong have allowed newsmen or other outsiders to subject their societies to the close examination that the South Vietnamese Government has permitted, only a sketchy picture of the Communist judicial systems emerges from captured documents and statements of prisoners and defectors.

title: Bronx Is Beautiful Becomes Cry of Loop Bus Riders
description: Oh, sighed Patricia Stevens of Manhattan as she stared out the windows of a Culture Loop III bus. The Bronx is so beautiful.

title: Turks Accuse Greek Cypriote Troops of Murdering 6
description: ANKARA, Turkey Aug. 18Turkey officially accused the Greek Cypriote National Guard today of killing six Turkish Cypriote civilians and called on international organizations to protect Turkish hostages in Cyprus.

title: Vice PresidenttoBe
description: The unexpectedly long time it is taking President Ford to make up his mind about his designee as Vice President could be all to the good if it means that he is using Presidential potentiality as his measuring rod.

title: 19 MEN IN I. R. A. FLEE IRISH JAIL
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 18Nineteen prisoners, all members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, escaped today from Portlaolse jail, 50 miles southwest of here. They were still free late tonight.

title: Bridge: Deceptive Maneuvers Used To Hide Location of Queen
description: In less sophisticated times visitors to American fairgrounds used to demonstrate a consistent inability to locate the queen of spades at threecard Monte. They would thus provide a steady living for the board tossers who could flip out three cards face downward with such dexterity that the queen was never where the sucker expected.

title: Concepcion's Blast Off Matlack With 2 On Decides
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 18History began repeating itself this afternoonbut not for the Mets. By defeating New York, 651 the secondplace Cincinnati Reds moved to within 2 games of the slumping Los Angeles Dodgers, who lost their sixth game in a row. At this time a year ago the Reds were also 2 games behind the Dodgers, whom, they ultimately passed to win the National League West.

title: Youths' Alcohol Abuse Called Alarming Here
description: Alcohol abuse, alcoholism, and the combined use of alcohol and other drugs among adolescents in New York City has become an alarming problem, according to Joel Bennett, president of the New York Council on Alcoholism.

title: Piston Honored by MacDowell Colony
description: PETERBOROUGH, N. H., Aug. 18Walter Piston could not be on hand today to receive the Edward MacDowell Medal for his outstanding contribution to music, but some 400 other guests showed up for the 15th annual, award ceremonies at the MacDowell Colony here. The medal was accepted for the 80yearold composer who is recovering from a broken hip, by Michael Steinberg, music critic of The Boston Globe.

title: On Presuming Innocence
description: WASHINGTONA man is innocent until proven guilty, Great words, the cornerstone of our legal system. Who said them?

title: Edward W. Kilpatrick, 68, Dies; Headed Jersey's Education Unit
description: Edward W. Kilpatrick, former Acting Commissioner of Education in New Jersey, died yesterday of congestive heart and kidney failure in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 68 years old and lived in New Providence, N. J.

title: German Cuisine, as It Were, Described
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany I saw again on my plate horrible things mit Kompott and in my glass the mediocre but chilled beer. I saw again the preposterous beds, enemies of sleep and lovemaking, their sheets too short, the mosaictype mattresses in three sections.

title: New Books
description: Image of a Lover, by Elisabeth Ogilvie (McGrawHill, $7.95). Murder and, madness invade a summer vacation.

title: Manhattan Plaza: Quality Housing to Upgrade 42d St.
description: A lot of people say I'm, nuts to be doing this, says Richard Rayitch, the New York builder Who has done a number of unorthodox things in the last few years, including creating Waterside, the muchacclaimed, fourtower apartment complex built on a platform in the East River above 23d Street.

title: DOORMAN ROBS TENANTS IN LOBBY
description: A tall intruder donned a green, illfitting doorman's uniform in the lobby of a West Side luxury apartment building just after noon yesterday and, with polite greetings and a menacing gun, robbed tenants in bunches as they strolled in.

title: LINDSAY RETURNS; PLANS UNCERTAIN
description: John V, Lindsay, his suitcases bursting, his mood jovial and his political future uncertain, arrived home yesterday afternoon after an eightmonth vacation in the Caribbean and Europe for decompression from the rigors of being an eightyear Mayer of New York.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Alice McLaughlin Wed to Karl Brenner
description: Alice DeLaurier McLaughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McLaughlin of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Karl Anthony Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Brenner of San Mateo, Calif. The Rev. Christopher Johnson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of Salve Regina College in Newport, R.I.

title: CLEVELAND FIGHTS SUBURB FOR PLANT
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 18  A large, longvacant industrial plant and the 227 acres surrounding it have become a bone of contention between Cleveland and one of its suburbs. The state's Republican party's two top campaigners are on opposite sides of the issue.

title: Bonnie Yablon Is Bride
description: The marriage of Bonnie Michele Yablon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Yablon of Harrison, N.Y., to Robert Hurwitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hurwitz of New Rochelle, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon at the Yablon home. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony. Mr. Yablon is executive vice president, of Forbes Magazine. Mr. Hurwitz's father is president of the Charm Craft Corporation in Mount Vernon, N.Y., jewelry manufacturer.

title: New Offer By Players Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)The installation of an impartial arbitrator  not Commissioner Pete Rozellein daytoday grievances has become the major obstacle in reaching an agreement in the National Football League dispute, the players union said today.

title: N.Y.A.C. Oarsmen Win Title
description: Dr. Larry Klecatsky, with four victories, and Jim Dietz, with three, led the New York Athletic Club to the team championship in the 98th annual national rowing championship yesterday on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: 4 Hurt in Suspicious Fire
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 18 (UPI)A fouralarm fire at an apartment building here early today was declared suspicious by city fire authorities, who said the basement fire started the same place where another fire started about three months ago. The fourhour blaze, at 23 North Columbus Avenue, forced the evacuation of 30 families and injured four firemen slightly.

title: RailSpur Plan Saddens Park Visitors
description: In the dappled shade of Forest Park in Queens yesterday habitus talked sadly of the looming disruptions in their tranquil corner of the city.

title: Episcopal Leader Quits; Protests Curb on Women
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 18  Dr. Charles V. Willie, a sociologist and Episcopal layman, resigned today as vice president of the church's House of Deputies to protest the House of Bishops' rejection of the ordination of 11 women to the priesthood.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Arthur West, president of the Farm Bureau Federation of New Jersey, criticized Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, Democrat of Bergen County, whose arm was broken when he went to investigate worker conditions at farm in South Jersey.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 19, 1974

title: MAN CROSSING ROAD DROWNED IN FLOOD
description: ELIZABETH Aug. 18 (UPI)Robert A. Hogan of Elizabeth, who attempted to cross an intersection yesterday after the Elizabeth River had risen above road level, drowned after he was swept into the river.

title: Humane Aftercare
description: The release of mental patients from state hospitals to city neighborhoods for rehabilitation has proceeded without adequate supervision of these troubled and troublesome individuals and without proper preparation and facilities in local communities.

title: Facing the Problem of Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The final, agonized months of the Nixon Administration and the first ebullient week of the Ford Administration seem to have left much of the nation with a curiously inconsistent sense of the ability of the Government to handle what is widely regarded as the most urgent problem facing President Ford: inflation.

title: FORDS SELECTION OF VICE PRESIDENT IS SET TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18President Ford, on his way to the golf course this afternoon, told reporters that he would choose a Vice President on Tuesday.

title: Illinois Five Given 2Year Probation
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 19 (AP)The University of Illinois basketball team was placed on probation today for two years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for recruiting violations.

title: Dolphins Conquer Vikings
description: MIAMI, Aug. 19 (AP)Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, the stellar running backs who are headed for the World Football League next year, started their final season with the Miami Dolphins tonight by leading the way to a 219 exhibition victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Neil Amdur
description: A historic event in the world of tennis passed almost unnoticed recently: a professional player was defaulted during a singles match for stalling and foul language.

title: 258 Alligator Hides Seized
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 19 (AP) Federal agents arrested five men and seized 258 alligator hides worth $12 a foot on the illegal market, a spokesman for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service said today. The arrests were made last night in New Orleans. The hides varied in length from two feet to eight feet.

title: COOL ROBBER GETS $157,000 AT BANK
description: Armed with a valise he said was filled with eight sticks of dynamite, a young holdup man walked into a Yorkville savings bank last night; calmly waited 120 minutes while a terrified bank officer made two trips to the vault to fill an attach case with money and then walked out with $157,000 in cash.

title: Erotic Movie, Once Banned, Has Become a Hit in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug, 19 (Reuters)Emmanuelle, France's answer to a wave of American sex fantasies like Deep Throat, has become one of the biggest boxoffice successes in French movie history.

title: Drought Could Raise Mayonnaise Cost
description: The price of mayonnaise is soaring, and the indications yesterday were that still more increases could be expected next week.

title: A New AntiAmericanism in Greece
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19  On square in downtown Athens stands a statue of Harry Truman. It expresses Greece's gratitude to the United States for the Truman Doctrine, and the outpouring of aid in the nineteenforties and fifties that helped Greece recover from the devastation of World War II and resist Communist subversion during the civil war that followed.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: To Saigon, All Dissenters Are Foes, All Foes Reds
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam After two decades of fratricidal warfare the Government of South Vietnam has been left with a legacy of corrosive suspicions directed in large measure against its own citizens.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1974

title: Brooklyn Bridge Museum Is Planned
description: The deserted little twostory white frame fire boat house stands alone at the foot of Cadman Plaza West in Brooklyn Heights and in the shadow of the vaulting Brooklyn Bridge. Its trim tower is framed by thosee of the World Trade Center, which soar into the sky directly across the East River. The green paint around the windows at the top of the tower isweathered, and handbills adorn the walls below the peeling flagpole.

title: SELASSIE'S FUTURE RAISING QUESTIONS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 19An armed forces group is ruling Ethiopia in all but name now, and the big question here is whether it will push aside Emperor Haile Selassie completely.

title: Mr. Ford's Economics. . .
