description: President Ford is seeking to put his own stamp on economic policy. In terms of style he has already done that by his public recognition of the gravity of the economic problems facing the country and by his open and broad search for the best answers.

title: City Police Purchasing Smaller Patrol Cars
description: With an eye on costcutting and better performance, the Police Department has begun replacing its standardsize radio patrol cars with a smaller, intermediate model that drivers say handles better and has more zip.

title: Knicks Pursuing M'Ginnis
description: George McGinnis a Knick? The wheels are in motion to bring one of the American Basketball Association's more valuable properties to New York. Apparently, only the law courts stand in the way of it happening before the start of the National Basketball Association season in October.

title: Kissinger Seeks To Assure Athens On Cyprus Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Secretary of State Kissinger, seeking to persuade Greece too resume peace talks with Turkey in the Cyprus crisis, pledged today that the United States would use its influence in any negotiation to take into full account Greek honor and national dignity.

title: School Plan Fought by North Brunswick
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19 (AP)A lawyer for the North Brunswick Board of Education argued today that the state should dismiss New Brunswick's suit seeking school regionalization in Middlesex County.

title: Fed Acted to Curb Any Expectations Of Easier Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 19The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted at its midMay meeting to keep the key Federal funds interest rate within a narrow range of 11 to 11 per cent, it was disclosed today.

title: A, & P.'S EMPLOYES BACK ON JOB HERE
description: More than 18,000 A.&P. employes returned to work yesterday after a sixday strike that won them wage increases of about 35 per cent over three years and improved fringe benefits.

title: City Seeks Private Development Of Big Brooklyn Queens Tract
description: The city said yesterday it would solicit bids for the private development of the largest tract of its undeveloped land other than on Staten Islandmore than 400 acres on the BrooklynQueens borderfor a housing, recreational and industrial complex.

title: TWO ARE INDICTED IN STOCK FRAUD CASE
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted two partners in a nowdefunct stock brokerage firm on charges that they conspired five years ago to violate Federal securities laws.

title: Aaron Hits His 730th; Braves Beat Cards, 116
description: Claude Osteen, obtained b3 St. Louis earlier this monta from Houston as pennant insurance, made his first start last night for the East em Divisionleading Cara nais and promptly ran into barrage of Atlanta base hits led by an old nemesis.

title: Ford Goes First Class But Remains Informal
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19  As President and Mrs. Ford stepped out of Air Force One here this morning, a voice boomed importantly over an airport mocrophone: Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States and Mrs. Nixon.

title: Issue of Granting Amnesty Echoes Division Over War
description: Twenty months after American troops stopped fighting in Vietnam, the issue of what to do about the tens of thousands of young men who avoided military service remains a bitterly divisive one.

title: INTEREST RATES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Interest rates continued to move upward yesterday as investment bankers were forced to put more attractive yields on new issues to entice investors to put their funds to work.

title: Chess: Hort Continues Perfect Score And Takes Lead at U.S.
description: Vlastimil Hort, the Czech grandmaster, managed to open a crack between himself and the rest of the field competing in the United States Open championship at the StatlerHilton. Hort won his sixthround game from Pal Benko, a leading rival, thus continuing his perfect score.

title: New Trophy Set For Golf Winners.
description: City Recreation Commissioner Joseph P. Davidson announced yesterday that champions in the four divisions of the citywide public links tournaments would receive a golf award to be known as the Mayor's Trophy. He spoke at the LaTourette course, Staten Island, where qualifying started for the men's amateur championship. Qualifying has been held for junior, senior and women's amateur competition at all 13 municipal courses.

title: Greek Catholics Seek U.N. Aid To Free Archbishop in Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 19The Greek Catholic, Church, which has its highest seat in Lebanon, has begun efforts to obtain the release of the Greek Catholic Archbishop of East Jerusalem who was arrested in Israel yesterday on charges of smuggling weapons for Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Ford Narrows VicePresidential List and Is Expected to Name Choice Today
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 19 President, Ford has narrowed his VicePresidential list to five or six Republicans with varied experience in political office, the White House said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Westchester Board Votes 160 For a WasteDisposal Network
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 19The Westchester County Board of Legislators today unanimously adopted County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's solidwastemanagement plan committing the county to total responsibility for the disposal of all solid waste generated within its municipalities.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Couple Charge Doctor Thwarted Implantation
description: A Florida couple filed a $1.5million damage suit in United States District Court here yesterday, alleging that a New York doctor last year had maliciously destroyed a testtube culture from which they had hoped to have a baby.

title: Smoking San Widened
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 19 (AP)The State Attorney General, Robert Killian, has ruled that smoking prohibited signs must be posted in rooms where public meetings are in progress;. A new state law prohibits smoking at public meetings held in public buildings.

title: Quads to Row for World Berth
description: The New York Athletic Club won the chance to challenge the United States team quadruple sculls crew for the right to represent the United States in the world championships at Lucerne, September 4 to 8. No competition appeared yesterday for a qualifying race against the Winged Foot boat on the Orchard Beach lagoon.

title: Coyotes' Best Friends End Sheep Research
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Aug, 19 (AP)A statefunded study on ways to train coyotes not to eat sheep came to an end here this weekend when eight sheep being used as study animals were eaten by dogs.

title: LEON BRODY, LED SAFETY RESEARCH
description: Dr. Leon Brody, director of research and publications at the New York University Center for Safety since 1952, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 110 Bleecker Street.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A new threelevel underground garage for public parking was opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: LITTLE CROP HELP SEEN FROM RAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) August rains apparently were not enough to significantly improve the gloomy 1974 corn production outlook caused by the drought in June and July, a special Agriculture Department report said late today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 100 policemen and some of their wives picketed outside Police Headquarters in support of Officers Thomas J. Shea and Walter Scott, who are facing departmental trial in the death of a 10yearold Queens boy. Delegates from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and a few members of the Policemen's Wives Association took part in the demonstration, led by the P.B.A. president, Ken McFeeley.

title: McDowell Chased Early by Twins at Shea
description: Thanks to a totally ineffective performance by Sam McDowell as the starting pitcher, the Yankees never had a chance in the opener of a threegame series against the Minnesota Twins last night at Shea Stadium. The Yanks absorbed a 6.2 setback that dropped them once again beneath the .500 mark in the American League East standings.

title: Hoffman to Close Division
description: EL MONTE, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI)The Hoffman Electropics Corporation has announced that it will discontinue its metal products division as a result of the loss of an Air Force contract on the BL U63B aircraft. The Air Force offered to stretch the Contract price, but Hoffman said failure of certain of its subcontractors to meet commitments made it inadvisable to carry on with the program. The division accounts for 16 Per cent of Hoffman's sales and its closure will result in a $1.5million writeoff.

title: TAXI UNION TO MEET ON CONTRACT SEPT. 4
description: The Taxi Drivers Union, representing 30,000 taxi employes in the city, has scheduled a special membership meeting for 8 P.M. Sept. 4, in Manhattan Center for a vote on ratification of its tentative contract with the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade.

title: Offers Are Outlined for the General Crude Oil Co.
description: The International Paper Company considers itself to be in the running for the General Crude Oil Company even though the principal stockholder of the oil exploration and producing company appears to have committed itself to a competing offer from the Dow Chemical Company.

title: Housing Fund Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Under the new housing bill, seven existing grant programs for such purposes as Model Cities, urban renewal, and neighborhood facilities would be combined into a new $8.4billion program of community development block grants for the next three years. In addition, the Department of Housing and Urban Development will seek additional funding to spread the block grant program to six years.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BICENTENNIAL GUIDE TO THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION. Volume I, The War in the North. 391 pages. Cloth, $12.95; paper, $4.95. Volume II, The Middle Colonies. 173 pages. Cloth, $8,95; paper, $3.95. Volume III, The War in the South. 217 pages. Cloth, $8.95; paper, $3.95. By Sol Stember. Saturday Review Press/E. P. Dutton.

title: U.S. Professor Says Moscow Bars Exit of His Russian Wile
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19Soviet authorities here have refused to allow a visiting. American professor to take his new Russian wife to the United States, contending that the woman, a Moscow teacher, has had access to state secrets.

title: Davies Viewed as Real Professional
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Rodger Paul Davies, the American Ambassador killed in Cyprus, today, was regarded by his colleagues as a real professional quiet, solid and skilled.

title: New Veterans' Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Applauding, whistling and cheering, members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars were on their feet today before President Ford could finish his sentence naming their former commander in chief as the new Administrator of Veterans Affairs.

title: WALLACE ACCUSED OF BIAS ON BLACKS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 19 (UPI)A lawsuit filed in Federal District Court here today charged that Gov. George C. Wallace had fulfilled a 1963 pledge of segregation now, segregation tomorrow and segregation forever by discriminating against blacks in making appointments.

title: CBS PLANS SHOW ON THE PENTAGON
description: Three years after the presentation of The Selling of the Pentagon, its controversial documentary on the public relations efforts of the armed forces, CBSTV will televise on Sept. 6 a report on the United States military during peacetime, including an examination. of defense spending.

title: Ireland Launches Wide Hunt For 19 Fugitive I.R.A. Men
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Thousands of soldiers and policemen today hunted for 19 Irish Republican Army guerrillas who used explosives to blast their way out of the country's most heavily guarded jail and escaped in cars hijacked at gunpoint.

title: Notes on People
description: Ruth Bates Harris, a black woman who was dismissed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after she wrote a report accusing NASA of having the worst record in the Government in hiring minorities and women, returned to the agency yesterday in a new and betterpaying job.

title: RESULTS DIFFER AT RETAIL CHAINS
Westinghouse Plant Layoff Totals About 250 Persons
description: NORMAN, Okla., Aug. 19 (AP)  Approximately 250 persons have been laid off at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's plant here.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: 2 German Women Set World Swim Records
description: VIENNA, Aug. 19 (AP)Carla Linke was the star of the second day of the European swimming championship today as the East German women went on another worldrecord shattering spree.

title: Frederick A. Gilbert, 62, Of FMC Corporation, Dies
description: Frederick A. Gilbert, who retired last year as chemical group vice president of they FMC Corporation, diversified manufacturers, died Sunday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 293 Middlesex Road, Darien, Conn., and in Osterville, Mass.

title: Car Kills Boy, Hurts Two
description: CORAM, L. I., Aug. 19 (UPI) A 2yearsold boy was killed and his two brothers injured, one critically, today when a stroller being pushed by their mother was struck by a car, the police said. They reported that Kristopher Tinn was dead on arrival at Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, that his twin brother, Dennis, was in critical condition and that his brother, Eric, 5, was treated for facial cuts and released. Their mother, Mrs. Nancy Tinn of Coram, was unhurt.

title: William L. Chenery, 90, Dead; Headed Collier's for 25 Years
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP)William Ludlow Chenery, who for 25 years headed Coldier's magazine, died Sunday. He was 90 years old.

title: LOSSES ARE SHARP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Investors' concern over the inflationary trend and the unsettled situation in Cyprus sent prices down sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: Ford Applies to Press Club
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)President Ford has applied for associate membership in the National Press Club to further his aim of improving White House relations with the press, club sources said today. Mr. Ford's application, dated Aug. 13, was forwarded for consideration by the next meeting of the membership committee.

title: WOMAN AIDE DIES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 19The United States Ambassador to Cyprus was shot to death today during a demonstration of Greek Cypriotes at his embassy.

title: Shift in MentalHospital Theory
description: The widely accepted theory that mental patients should be released from large institutions and placed in community facilities for rehabilitationa subject of bitter controversy here is now being viewed with important reservations by leading British expert s who pioneered in this program.

title: N.F.L. Hats Refunds on Preseason Tickets
description: After three strikeweakened preseason games in which National Football Leagues teams lost hundreds of thousands of dollars, the league decided yesterday to stop giving refunds on exhibition games.

title: People in Sports
description: Archie Clark, who had a troubled career of injuries and contract disputes with the Washington Bullets, was traded yesterday to the Seattle Supersonics for Dick Gibbs and a 1975 thirdround draft choice. The 33yearold Clark, one of the outstanding backcourt men in the National Basketball Association, began his pro career in the 196667 season with the Los Angeles Lakers. He was traded to the Philadelphia 76ers in 1968 as part of the deal that brought Wilt Chamberlain to the Lakers. Philadelphia sent him to the Bullets during the 197172 season.

title: Morris Sprayregen, 84, Dies; Railroad Securities Expert
description: Morris Sprayregen, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lived since last year. He was 84 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday was awarded a $75.8million Army contract for M60A1 combat tanks.

title: State Asks P.U.C. to Deny 155Million Bell Rate Rise
description: NEWARK, Aug, 19An attorney from the Public Advocate's office asked the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners today to dismiss the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company's request for a $155million rate increase.

title: Levitt Assails Finance Practices At State U. Hospital in Brooklyn
description: The financial and operating practices of the State University Hospital of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn shave been criticized in an audit released yesterday by the office of State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: Greeks Protest in Paris Against U.S.Cyprus Role
description: PARIS, Aug. 19Three hundred Creeks and Greek Cypriotes demonstrated today in central Paris to protest against the crisis.

title: Cuban Red Cross Revives Boxer
description: HAVANA, Aug. 19 (Reuters) The first world amateur boxing championship had its first drama last night when a Swiss competitor had to be carried out on a stretcher after being knocked out by a Bulgarian middleweight, Alexander Yanakiev. It took Cuban Red Cross officials several minutes to revive Guido Corpateaux after he was knocked flat on his back by a left to the chin. This was the last of the eight bouts in, the evening session of the second day of the championships. The crowd of 14,000 in Havana's Sports City also saw two other knockouts. Zbigniew Kicka, a Polish welterweight, knocked out Miguel Pena of the Dominican Republic in the second round after being outboxed in the first. In a middleweight bout, the Soviet champion, Rufat Riskiev, stopped Stan Williamson of Canada.

title: Labor Federation Joins the Lobbying For a Power Plant on the New River
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The A.F.L.C.I.O. has joined forces with the American Electric Power System in an effort to defeat a bill designed to place 70mile stretch of the New River in western Virginia and North Carolina in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Alleged Mob Figure Gets Six Months for Contempt
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 19Nassau County Judge Alexander Vitale today sentenced Armand Pollastrino, 54 years old, of 5 South 16th Avenue, Mount Vernon, to six months in the Nassau County jail in East Meadow for criminal contempt of a 1970 grand, jury investigating infiltration by organized crime into legitimate business operations.

title: False Tests Peril Psychic Research
description: The effort of scientists to demonstrate the existence of extrasensory perception (E.S.P.) and other socalled psychic phenomena suffered what many observers consider a serious setback recently when it was discovered that the direrfor of one of the bestknown parapsychology research centers had been falsifying his experimental data.

title: Ford Urges Leniency for War Resisters
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19President Ford said today that he favored leniency for the nation's estimated 50,000 military draft evaders and deserters to bind up the nation's wounds.

title: STEEL OUTPUT FELL 2.1% FROM WEEK AGO
description: Steel production fell to 2.68million net tons in the week ended Aug. 17, a decline of 2.1 per cent from the previous week, The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Levi Strauss Gets Loan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19, (Reuters)  Levi Strauss & Co. said today it had arranged a 71/2 year $100million revolving bank loan with a group headed by the Crocker National Bank of San Francisco. Up to onethird of the loan may be drawn in currencies other than United States dollars, the company said, Interest rates were not disclosed.

title: MARION WILLIAMS SINGS FROM SOUL
description: Marion Williams is perhaps the most loved and respected of the presentday gospel singers, yet her appearances here are distressingly rare. Thus it was a pleasure to welcome her. to the generally comfortable ambiance of an outdoor concert yesterday noon in Bryant Park, even if the sound system didn't always do her justice.

title: Silver Springs Claims Mark
description: Silver Springs, near Ocala, Fla., is the largest of all Florida springs and claims to be the world's largest.

title: Civil Liberties Unit Asks. Ouster of Mental Chief
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union assailed the State Department of Mental Hygiene yesterday and said that unless the head of the agency and his chief aides were ousted, the entire concept of releasing mental patients from institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation could be jeoparidized.

title: NEWS INDEX
CREDITS UP SHARPLY FOR EUROCURRENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Announced mediumterm and long tern Eurocurrency credits in the first half of this year nearly equalled the total for all of 1973.

title: 4 U.S Boats Look at Sea During Final Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 19 The crew aboard the France, potential challenger next month for the America's Cup, was exultant today after watching two potential defenders, Intrepid and Mariner, butcher a yacht race in the final United States trials.

title: Body Found in River
description: RIDGEFIELD, Aug. 19 (AP) The body of Eudene Ward, 32 years old, of Carlstadt, who disappeared after the explosion of a cabin cruiser in the Hackensack River here yesterday, was found today in the river in nearby Little Ferry. Miss Ward's escort, Walter Paskenalis, 37, of Hillsdale was rescued by a passing boat.

title: Bomb Threat Cuts Short Ray Charles Show in Park
description: A bomb threat last night cut short the Ray Charles Show at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, causing Mr. Charles, who is is blind, to be led off the stage after only four songs.

title: Grumman's $100Million: The Questions Are Where and How Soon
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Aug. 19The central: question in the Grumman F14 controversy now is how soon and from where will the money, come that is needed to continue production of the sophisticated fighter plane. It is a question that will not only affect the present fortunes, or misfortunes, of the Long Islandbased corporation but may also very well determine its survival.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 13.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Smithsonian Posts Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The appointment of Dr. Murray Gellmann, a theoretical physicist of the California Institute of Technology in Paudena, to the board of regents of the Smithsonian Institution was approved today without opposition by the House. The House also approved the reappointment of Dr. Caryl P. Haskins of Washington and Dr. William A. M. Burden of New York.

title: Crowding, Waiting Deject Welfare Families in Bronx
description: Charlotte Taylor slept on granite doorstep Sunday night though she ached to be at the hospital bed of her 10yearold daughter Deosa.

title: Westchester in Bosnia
description: An axiom of modern  day travel is that the more worthwhile a tourist attraction is today, the less worthwhile it will be next year and the year after.

title: Ankara Says Tragedy Echoes. Ordeals of Turks on Cyprus
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 19Turkish officials said the killing today of Rodger P. Davies, the United States Ambassador in Cyprus, was an example of the kind of violence that the Turkish Cypriote minority on the island had faced for years from Greek Cypriotes.

title: To Repeal Dishonor
description: The House of Representatives has the opportunity today to remove a blot on the honor of the United States and of Congress at the same time that it strikes a blow for traditional American ideals: selfdetermination, government by majority, the rule of law and the bolstering of the United Nations. At issue is repeal of the infamous Byrd amendment under which this country has violated the sanctions for which it voted in the United Nations Security Council against the white racist regime in Rhodesia.

title: South Orange Gives Net Tour A Tourney and Family Reunion
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 19The $50,000 MediQuik tennis open began today and if Paul Gerken is lucky, Mrs. Ida Mae Gocke will cook him a terriyaki dinner.

title: Met Is Reviving Its Innovative MiniMet Opera Series
description: The Metropolitan Opera's innovative MiniMet is being revived this coming season, Schuyler G. Chapin, general manager, confirmed yesterday. The MiniMet performances, begun in February and March, 1973, were suspended last season for lack of funds.

title: Agency Concedes Job Bias in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Congressional Office of Placement and Office Management acknowledged today that some Congressional offices had requested that it send white applicants only for interviews to fill staff job vacancies.

title: 25 Food Outlets Cited for Failures On 2d Inspections
description: The Health Department yesterday cited 25 more food outlets for having failed a second healthcode inspection and warned that violations found during a final inspection later this month could result in closing orders.

title: Peru and Heinz in Venture
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The Government of Peru has signed an agreement with a subsidiary of the H. J. Heinz Company to set up a new joint company to fish for ?? and mackerel in Peruvian waters. The new company will have $4.5million in capital and seeks to establish a fishing fleet of 30 boats.

title: HOUSE PANEL OFFERS HEALTH CARE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The staff of the House Ways and Means committee disclosed today a compromise health insurance plan containing a new tax for medical catastrophes.

title: Col. McClelland Named New Presidential Pilot
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) President Ford named Lieut. Col. Lester C. McClelland today as his official pilot. The colonel was at the controls today when Mr. Ford in his first Presidential flight arrived here to address a convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

title: Jon Lucien Strums As He Sings of Love To Rapt Audience
description: Love may or may not make the world go round but it certainly makes Jon Lucien's concerts go on and on. Listening to Mr. Lucien's lyrics (he is, a singer from St. Thomas, West Indies, and made his Avery Fisher Hall debut Sunday) it is easy to see that he is of the love generation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rodger P. Davies, the United States Ambassador to Cyprus, was killed by a bullet that penetrated his embassy in Nicosia during an antiAmerican demonstration by Greek Cypriotes who believed that the United States had sided with Turkey. Antoinette Varnavas, an Embassy secretary who went to his aid, was also killed. [1:8.]

title: Gulf and Western Offering Debentures to Stockholders
description: Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it expected to make an exchange offer to holders of its common stock that would, provide $7 cash and $24 principal amount of its 7 per cent, Series B nonconvertible subordinated debentures due in 2003 for each share of Gulf and Western common stock. The offer is for up to 1 million common shares. The debentures will bear interest from July 1, 1974.

title: SIRICA DECLINES TO DELAY OPENING OF COVERUP TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Federal District Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that the trial of the defendants in the Watergate coverup case would begin as scheduled on Sept. 9, notwithstanding requests by both the prosecution and four of the defendants for a delay.

title: Volunteers Needed to Aid At Festival for Retarded
description: One to One, a nonprofit organization that aids the mentally retarded, will hold its annual festival for the retarded on Thursday, Aug. 29, in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. About 2,000 volunteers are still needed to help.

title: House Due to Vote Today On Impeachment Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The House, will be asked tomorrow to accept its Judiciary Committee's report on the impeachment case against former President Richard M. Nixon and order it printed as a House document.

title: NEW COMPANY SET FOR OIL IN KUWAIT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 19 (AP)  A new corporation has been formed in Kuwait to take charge of Kuwait's interests in oil and gas operations in and outside the country, according to the Middle East Economic Survey.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE DENY BOMB ACCOUNT
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) The police said today that they did not believe an assertion by the alphabet bomber that his terrorist organization set off an explosion that occurred Saturday in a downtown industrial area.

title: EGYPT TO RECEIVE WHEAT FROM U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The United States has agreed to provide Egypt with $16.5million in wheat on a lowinterest, longterm basis as part of efforts to improve relations, a State Department official said today.

title: GROUP SUES TO BAR A GAS TANK ON S.I.
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19 (UPI)A group of New York and New Jersey residents filed suit today in Federal Court here to block construction of a giant naturalgas storage tank that they contend is intended to store the destructive equivalent of 37 atomic bombs.

title: Bridge: Theory of Restricted Choice Is Confusing but Important
description: A theoretical area that many players find confusing is restricted choice. For practical purposes this can be summed up like this:

title: Velasquez Rides Fairway Flyer to Victory in Diana
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19Jorge Velasquez's riding generalship and Fairway Flyer's liking for the turf made for a winning formula in the $58,450 Diana Handicap today. The 5yearold mare owned by William Floyd moved up from seventh place in the field of nine to take the 1mile grass race by two lengths.

title: Gottfried Beats Dibley In Two Sets
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 19Any hopes Cohn Dibley of Australia had of winning the MediQuik open tennis tourney for a second straight year were quickly dashed today. Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eliminated him in the final round at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Europe Is Said to Ship Subsidized Cheese Here
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The European Community has been shipping large quantities of subsidized cheese into the United States despite an announcement last month that the subsidies would be stopped, American agriculture officials say.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Wrigley and Chicle Raise Prices for Chewing Gum
description: The price of chewing gum was raised yesterday for the second time this year by the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the leader in the field, and by the American Chicle Company, a division of the WarnerLambert Company. Wrigley's new price for its Spearmint, Doublemint and Juicy Fruit gums is $1.50 per box of 20 packages of seven sticks each, a 30 per cent increase.

title: 130 NATIONS BEGIN POPULATION TALKS
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 19The likelihood of any decisive international action soon to defuse what many experts have called the global population bomb seemed dim today as the United Nations World Population Conference opened here.

title: 4 ARE ACQUITTED OF FRAUD CHARGE
description: A Federal judge acquitted four former officials of a Floridabased corporation here yesterday of charges of criminal conspiracy to violate securities and fraud laws; saying that the Government has failed to sustain its burden of proof.

title: Top Aides in South Korea Offer Their Resignations
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Tuesday, Aug. 20  Almost every leader of the South Korean Government and ruling party submitted his resignation today to take responsibility for the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee last Thursday.

title: Women Are Taught To Fend Off Rapist
description: More than 350 women, may of them black and Puerto Rican mothers, learned how to avoid becoming victims of sexual attack, when the New York City Police Department and Rape Coalition Educational Outreach Van visited the South Bronx.

title: Ford Urges Leniency for War Resisters
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19President Ford said today that he favored leniency for the nation's estimated 50,000 military draft evaders and deserters to bind up the nation's wounds.

title: Dallas Attorneys Say Police Cannot Arrest Mexican Aliens
description: DALLAS, Aug. 19  City attorneys have ruled that Dallas policemen may no longer arrest Mexican aliens for being in the country illegally.

title: Whose Crisis?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Ford Presidency has begun with another of those futile irrelevant crises that have distracted and worn down American Presidents for so many years now.

title: CityState Proposal On Pollution Called Inadequate by U.S.
description: The first draft of the revised citystate plan for meeting Federal airquality standards was criticized yesterday by the Federal Government as inadequate in its present form.

title: CareySamuels Democratic Rivalry Heats Up More
description: The quietly simmering campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination heated up a bit more yesterday as the two candidates held news conferences to repeat charges and defenses they had made over the weekend.

title: To Saigon, All Dissenters Are Foes, All Foes Reds
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam After two decades of fratricidal Warfare the Government of South Vietnam has been left with a legacy of corrosive suspicions directed in large measure against its own citizens.

title: WITNESSES SOUGHT IN 2 GIRLS' DEATHS
description: NORTH BERGEN, Aug. 19Prosecutor Joseph C. Woodcock, Jr., of Bergen County, said today his office and the Hudson County Prosecutor's staff were centering their investigation of the murders of two local teenage girls on the North Bergen area, in the hope of finding possible witnesses who might have seen the girls shortly before their deaths.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Civil Liberties Unit Asks Ouster of Mental Chiefs
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union assailed the State Department of Mental Hygiene yesterday and said that unless the head of the agency and his chief aides were ousted, the entire concept of releasing mental patients from institutions into community facilities for rehabilitation could be jeoparidized.

title: 3 Biggest Cities Would Gain Under New Housing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The $11.3billion housing bill that Congress has sent to President Ford for his signature would provide major increases in grants for community development and urban renewal in the nation's three biggest cities  New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

title: CBS PLANS SHOW ON THE PENTAGON
description: Three years after the presentation of The Selling of the Pentagon, its controversial documentary on the public relations efforts of the armed forces, CBSTV will televise on Sept. 6 a report on the United States military during peacetime, including an examination of defense spending.

title: Roy Cohn Home Ransacked
description: The town house at 39 East 68th Street that serves as both office and residence for Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, was broken into over the weekend, the police said yesterday. Mr. Cohn, reached in Miami, said he had been told that papers and files weer strewn about several floors of the sixstory building but that little of value was apparently taken.

title: Picatinny Arsenal Reprieve
description: WASHINGTON, N. J., Aug. 19 (AP)Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that he had received assurances from Secretary of the Army, Howard H. Callway that no major decisions would be made this year on proposals to consolidate Picatinny Arsenal with three other arsenals.

title: LAURA BARNEY DIES; SERVED U.N. GROUPS
description: PARIS, Aug. 19Laura Dreyfus Barney, a member of the International Council of Women, died yesterday at her home here. She was 94 years old.

title: 2 Men Rescue 5 Children From a Blazing Tenement
description: Two young men, out for an early morning bicycle ride yesterday, pulled five children out of a fire on the Lower East Side, The men said it was the third time in the last year and a half that they had rescued people from fires in their neighborhood.

title: Coal Miners Begin WeekLong National Memorial Shutdown, Supporting Utility Strike
description: HARLAN, Ky., Aug 10Union coal miners from across the mountain region began descending on this violent and strifetorn coal town today, signaling the start of a weeklong, nationwide mine shutdown that is expected to cut the nation's coal production by eight million tons before it is over.

title: Fezler Cards 63 For Course Mark
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Aug. 19 (AP)Forrest Fezler shattereed a course record today with an eightunderpar 63 to take the lead in the $50,000 Insurance Youth golf tournament at Alpine Country Club. He had eight birdies and 10 pars.

title: Kosygin Awaited in Bucharest for 30th Anniversary
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 19With Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin due here later this week, President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today delivered a speech that appeared aimed at smoothing Rumania's sometimes ruffled relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Sate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The rates of Treasury bills rose today as the Government borrowed $2.7billion on 91day and 2billion on 180day bills.

title: GRANT IS AWARDED TO COUNSEL TENANTS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19The Department of Community Affairs announced today that a grant of $83,725 had been awarded to the Black People's Unity Movement in Camden to establish tenant counseling and education program in the four lowincome apartment developments it manages.

title: ForeignPolicy Advice
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.President Ford tells us that he will remain true to the foreign policy of Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger. The media applauds and Congress sighs with relief. This is one area, perhaps the only one, where continuity is hailed as a good thing.

title: Gregory Is Being Fined $200 a Day in Holdout
description: The New York Giants set into motion yesterday the machinery to get rid of still another wouldbe jumper to the World Football League. At the same time, they started ploy No. 1 to keep one of their heroes, Jack Gregory.

title: Defect Is Cited in 337 Card
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was notifying the owners of 337 1974 Plymouth Trail Dusters and Dodge Ramchargers that the vehicles contained a safety defect in the sparetire mounting bracket. The company said that contact between the sparetire wheel and the bracket could wear away the wheel to a point where it could fail in use.

title: DISPUTE ON FUENTES BACK IN STATE COURT
description: Judge Richard Owen ruled in Federal District Court here yesterday that a legal dispute between Community School District 1 and Luis Fuentes, the district's superintendent, should be sent back to State Supreme Court.

title: S.E.C. Is Initiating Action Against N. R. Maison & Co.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was initiating administrative proceedings against N. R. Maison & Co. of New York over possible registration and antifraud violations.

title: Fords' Family Belongings Moved to White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)By the titme President and Mrs. Ford returned from their trip to Chicago today, their family belongings were all moved into the White House and the family cat was asleep in the Presidential bed.

title: A Second Chance
description: In his wise and compassionate statement on the muchdebated subject of amnesty for Vietnam draft evaders, President Ford has demonstrated his fidelity to the principle that the rule of law applies to all Americans but that its application necessitates no conflict between the noble aims of mercy and justice. He took the opportunity to say what he did in the lion's denthe annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, which has heretofore taken a hard line on amnestyand emerged unscathed and newly respected.

title: SOVIETIRAN PACT SPURS GAS COSTS
description: PARIS, Aug. 19  Another round of increases in the cost of energy may have been heralded by an agreement the Soviet Union has just signed with Iran, which nearly doubles the price Moscow wil?? pay for Iranian natural gas

title: RINALDI'S LIBEL SUIT CITES VILLAGE VOICE
description: Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn filed a $5million suit yesterday, charging that he had been libeled by Jack Newfield in a series of articles originally published in The Village Voice and later as a book, Cruel and Unusual Punishment.

title: People and, Business
description: The Amstar Corporation the nation's largest manufacturer of sugar and sugar products, has named Barbara Scott Preiskel as a director of the company. Mrs. Preiskel is vice president and legislative counsel of the Motion Picture Association of America, Inc.

title: Alcoa Plans to End Production Of Household Aluminum Foils
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's leading aluminum producer, announced yesterday that it would no longer produce and market Alcoa wrap, its household aluminum foil, which has been on the market since 1931.

title: Swiss Top Saving List
description: The Swiss keep more rainyday money in the bank than any other people, but that does not necesarily reflect unique thriftiness, according to a study by the International Savings Banks Institute. Page 54.

title: WOMAN AIDE DIES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 19The United States Ambassador to Cyprus was shot to death today during a demonstration of Greek Cypriotes at his embassy.

title: For the NotSo  Young Set, Dancing in the Afternoon
description: Thursday afternoon, 3 P.M. Manhattan. Most people are toiling away at their 9toS jobs, occasionally daydreaming about the weekend ahead. Typists are typing. Executives are still out to lunch. Stockbrokers are muttering under their breaths about the market quotations.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Daylight Time

title: Ear Parasite Blamed in Whale Deaths
description: One of the many mysteries of the sea is why some whales beach themselves and die.

title: Gas Shortage Seen, With a Loss of Jobs
description: John C. Sawhill, head of the Federal Energy Administration, said yesterday that there would likely be curtailment of natural gas supplies in the Northeast next winter, leading to plant closings and loss of jobs.

title: Stocks Hit a 4Year Low As Dow Index Falls 9.70
description: The stock market registered its eighth consecutive loss yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell to its lowest closing level in four years.

title: Byrne to Tour Dam Site At Tocks Island by Boat
description: Rushing down one of the East's great scenic whitewater routes, Governor Byrne will lead a fleet of 25 canoes and power boats on a 10mile Delaware River excursion today to inspect the site of the controversial Tocks Island Dam and the region that would be flooded if it is built.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CENTER OF ATTENTION Lincoln Center observes the closing of the summer with an explosion of creative activity, starting today. The festival of free music, comedy, dance and drama goes on for 48 performances and takes place in the parks and plaza areas of the cultural center.

title: Prof. Howard D. Roelofs, 81, Of U. of Cincinnati, Is Dead
description: Prof. Howard Dykema Roelofs, head of the department of philosophy at the University of Cincinnati for many years, died Aug. 12 at his home, Arden Farm in East Aurora, N.Y., where he had lived since his retirement in 1959. He was 81 years old.

title: GREECE SHAKES UP ARMY'S COMMAND
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19The Greek Government today made changes in the command structure of the armed forces in a major step to break the power of the military, which ruled for seven years.

title: Advertising: Dalmatian's 100
description: There's a new advertising service company in town for minority and small businesses whose aim is to provide clients with some of the same sophisticated marketing tools that big businesses enjoy.

title: China Excavation Yields 2,000YearOld Writings
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Aug. 20The discovery of a hoard of historical manuscripts, philosophical treatises and medical texts dating back more than 2,000 years was announced yesterday by Jenmin Jilt Pao, the official party daily.

title: COLIN J. H. BROWNING
description: Colin J. H. Browning, who was manager in Japan for the Chartered Bank of London before retiring in this country, died yesterday in Morristown (N. J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived on HainsburgRiver Road in Know!. ton Township, N. J.

title: JAWORSKI PRESSES NIXON FUND STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Watergate special prosecutor confirmed today, in court papers filed here, that he was investigating charges that campaign funds had been used to finance improvements to former President Richard M. Nixon's Florida home and to purchase platinum and diamond earrings for Mrs. Nixon.

title: SIRICA REFUSES TO DELAY OPENING OF COVERUP TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Federal District Judge. John J. Sirica ruled today that the trial of the defendants in the Watergate coverup case would begin, as scheduled on Sept. 9, notwithstanding requests by both the prosecution and four of the defendants for a delay.

title: Funeral Director Suspended
description: ALBANY Aug. 19 (UPI)The State Health Department has fined a Suffolk County funeral director $3,500 and suspended his license for five years for violations of laws involving delayed burials and falsifying burial permits, the Department announced today. The penalties were levied against Albert E. Seay of 711 Harrison Street, Riverhead, L.I.

title: ROMOLA C. BENDA
description: Romola Campfield Benda, widow of W. T. Benda, illustrator and artist known for his modern masks, died Friday in Southport, Conn. She was 70 years old.

title: Cool Sand Sure Beat Hot Asphalt
description: They stormed the sands somewhere in the vicinity of the West Bath House, and soon a little patch of Jones Beach was theirs.

title: Fords' Family Belongings Moved to White Howe
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)By the titme President and Mrs. Ford returned from their trip to Chicago today, their fainily, belongings were all moved into the White House and the family cat was asleep in the Presidential bed.

title: They're Natural Cereals, but Are They More Nutritious?
description: The major cereal manufacturers, late converts to the natural cereal craze, have made up for their early reluctance with a purerthanthou competition that has resulted in bigname natural breakfasts stripped of all things artificial, the nutritious as well as the extraneous.

title: City to Ask Private Firms To Develop Brooklyn Land
description: The city said yesterday it would solicit bids for the private development of the largest tract of its undeveloped land other than on Staten Islandmore than 400 acres on the BrooklynQueens borderfor a housing, recreational and industrial complex.

title: WAVE OF SELLING DEPRESSES GRAIN
description: Many nervous traders holding large paper profits were stampeded into selling their grain and soybean contracts yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Powell Denies Calley Bid To Be Free During Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. refused today to free William L. Calley Jr. on bail while the former Army lieutenant appealed his courtmartial conviction in the My Lai massacre.

title: Biggest Factory Building In City Fighting Seizure
description: The owner of the largest manufacturing building in the city is making a last legal effort to hold off a foreclosure of the building, which is more than 40 per cent vacant.

title: Resurrection
description: Just a little over a year ago it seemed probable that Saturday Review, a magazine of quiet distinction and taste, might follow such mastodons of mass circulation as Life, Look, Colliers and The Saturday Evening Post into oblivion. Instead, it is celebrating its fiftieth birthday with two bulging anniversary issues, a healthy financial balance and a deserved hold on the affection of its readers.

title: Richard Maas Gets White Plains Post, Succeeding Keating
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 19 (UPI)  The Common Council took four ballots tonight to elect Richard Maas, a Democrat, Mayor of White Plains replacing Acting Mayor Michael Keating.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19Public defenders and prosecutors are battling it out on the diamond as well as in court their teams fight for the lead in the Newark Lawyers League, featuring some of the higher paid amateur softball players around. The league has an unusual structure: seven teams from private law firms and seven from local, state and Federal public defenders' and prosecutors' offices.

title: Dr. John Morsell, Sociologist, Key N.A.A.C.P. Aide, Is Dead
description: Dr. John A. Morsell, assistant executive director since 1964 of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday in Kings County Hospital after suffering a massive arterial hemorrhage at his home, 95 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.

title: Murder Suspect Arrested
description: JACKSONVLILE, N. C., Aug. 19 (AP)  A father of five has been arrested and charged with murder in, the slaying of a hostage taken during a bank robbery Friday, the police reported today. Marcus Schrader, a 33yearold Navy corpsman, was charged with murder in the death of Sheryl Potter Boyd, 19, of Jacksonville, who was held hostage during a robbery of the North Carolina National Bank.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: ALEXANDER JANTA, WRITER, DIES AT 66
description: Alexander Janta, a Polish writer, poet and translator and former director of the Paderewski Foundation, died yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 88.28 43d Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, and in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Rockefeller Breaks His Vacation For Critical Choices Parley Here
description: Still awaiting word from Washington on his possible nomination as Vice President former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller took a business as usual attitude and presided yesterday over a meeting of a panel of the Commission on Critical Choices for Americans.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state has exempted pickup truck owners and operators of leaf composting facilities from payment of state solidwaste fees.

title: Van Buren Home Designated
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The House voted today to create a new national monument and five historic sites, one in New York, at a cost of $18.5million. A bill sent to the Senate by voice vote would establish the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument in Oregon at a cost of $4.4million. Among the proposed historic sites is the Martin Van Buren home in Columbia County, New York, at an estimated cost of $2.7million.

title: ...or Still Mr. Nixon's?
description: A correct diagnosis of the economic situation facing the United States and other countries is crucial to a correct solution. Admittedly, an allout policy of monetary and fiscal tightness could eventually stop the inflationbut at the cost of putting the economy into a steep recession or depression.

title: Neighborhoods: New Northside
description: What we proved is that you can fight City Hall if you think your cause is right. But the only way we won our battle was by breaking the law and getting news coverage.

title: Koreans Offer to Quit
description: President Park Chung Hee's Cabinet members offered to resign, as did almost every other South Korean leader, to take responsibility for the attempted assassination of the President last week, in which his wife died. Details on Page 12.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Striper Tests
description: Early this month the Consolidated Edison Company planted 30,000 young, hatcheryreared striped bass in the Hudson River at several places between Newburgh and the Palisades.

title: HewlettPackard Net Rises 118% on Sales Gain of 42%
description: The HewlettPackard Company, maker of electronic instruments and data processing equipment, yesterday reported a 118 per cent increase in earnings for the third quarter ended July 31 on a sales gain of 42 per cent. Ninemonth earnings rose 72 per cent and skies 41 per cent.

title: Jaworski Affirms Study of Fund Diversion Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Watergate special prosecutor confirmed today, In court papers filed here, that he was investigating charges that campaign funds had been used to finance improvements to former President Richard M. Nixon's Florida home and to purchase platinum and diamond earrings for Mrs. Nixon.

title: ROBERT COCHNAR
description: Robert Cochnar, who as vice president of the T. F. Hall Company designed and installed heating and ventilating systems in major buildings here, died yesterday in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old and had lived in PassaGrille Beach, Fla., since 1955.

title: Fire Disaster Spurs Action
description: Santiago's first firemen's company was formed in 1863 after a fire in a church killed 2000 churchgoers.

title: Swiss savings Top World List
description: GENEVA, Aug. 19  The Swiss keep more money in the bank against a rainy day than any other people, but this does not necessarily mean they are the world's thriftiest people.

title: Velasquez Rides Fairway Flyer to Victory in Diana
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19Jorge Velasquez's riding generalship and Fairway Flyer's liking for the turf made for a winning formula in the $58,450 Diana Handicap today. The 5yearold mare owned by William Floyd moved up from seventh place in the field of nine to take the 1mile grass race by two lengths.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAVANA, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The first world amateur boxing championship had its first drama last night when a Swiss competitor had to be carried out on a stretcher after being knocked out by a Bulgarian middleweight, Alexander Yanakiev. It took Cuban Red Cross officials several minutes to revive Guido Corpateaux after he was knocked flat on his back by a left to the chin. This was the last of the eight bouts in the evening session of the second day of the championships. The crowd of 14,000 in Havana's Sports City also saw two other knockouts. Zbigniew Kicka, a Polish welterweight, knocked out Miguel Pena of the Dominican Republic in the second round after being outboxed in the first. In a middleweight bout, the Soviet champion, Rufat Riskiev, stopped Stan Williamson of Canada.

title: 2 HOUSES SUPPORT INFLATION PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Senate and House, passed today slightly differing versions of legislation that would create a Federal antiinflation panel to help President Ford monitor the national economy, and perhaps use jawboning to curb excessive price and wage rises.

title: POLAROID TO LAY OFF BAY STATE WORKERS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP)The Polaroid Corporation, with 1974 second quarter earnings down sharply from last year, says it will lay off workers in many eastern Massachusetts plants.

title: Passing of Bogus Money Declines 25% in the State
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19 (AP)Counterfeiting in New Jersey decreased sharply in the last year, according to the Secret Service.

title: Gas Shortage. Seen, With a Loss of Jobs
description: John C. Sawhill, head of the Federal Energy Administration, said yesterday that there would likely be curtailment of natural gas supplies in the Northeast next winter, leading to plant closings and loss of jobs.

title: Ford's Remarks to V.F.W. on Amnesty
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19 Following is the text of remarks by President Ford on amnesty, made during his address today to the 75th annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars:

title: Neighborhoods: New Northside
description: What we proved is that you can fight City Hall if you think your cause is right, But the only way we won our battle was by breaking the law and getting news coverage.

title: 2 HOUSES SUPPORT INFLATION PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Senate and House passed today slightly differing versions of legislation that would create a Federal antiinflation panel to help President Ford monitor the national economy, and perhaps use jawboning to curb excessive price and wage rises.

title: milt May's Single Off Seaver Wins for Astros
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19Tom Seaver, the New York Mets' strongboy, turned in one of those superb performances against the Astros tonight that has enabled him to become the major league's highest salaried pitcher.

title: INDIAN STANDOFF IN ONTARIO ENDS
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 19For a month, armed Ojibway milltants have occupied a 14acre park in the resort town of Kenora in northwestern Ontario to call attention to longstand ing grievances against tile white authorities. As with what happened at Wounded Knee in South Dakota last year, the Kenora case has aroused wide interest in Indian causes.

title: Dollar Hits 5Month High As Pound and Mark Slip
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The United States dollar made fresh gains on world money markets today, climbing to its highest level in five months here and in Frankfurt. Gold prices moved irregularly, but closed the day, with gains.

title: Crucial Turkish Pledge
description: One modest but essential step toward restoring peace on Cyprus will be taken if Turkey makes good its promise to Secretary of State Kissinger for a negotiated pullback from some of the territory it has occupied and for reduction of its forces on the island. It would be better still if the Turks unilaterally ordered some territorial and troop withdrawals in advance by way of creating a better climate for new negotiations.

title: Placement Agency Concedes Job Bias in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Congressional Office of Placement and Office Management acknowledged today that some Congressional offices had requested that it send white applicants only for interviews to fill staff job vacancies.

title: Labor Federation Joins a Utility In Lobbying for Dam on New River
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The A.F.L.C.I.O. has joined forces with, the American Electric Power System in an effort to defeat a bill designed to place a 70mile stretch of the New River in western Virginia andNorth Carolina in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the last thirty years four of our Vice Presidents have gone on to become President. That is a rather large number over a relatively short period. Is it not time we did something truly meaningful to enhance the role of the Vice President so that he will be fully prepared should he succeed to the Presidency?

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Kissinger Seeks To Assure Athens On Cyprus Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Secretary of State Kissinger, seeking to persuade Greece to resume peace talks with Turkey in the Cyprus crisis, pledged today that the United States would use its influence in any negotiation to take into full account Greek honor and national dignity.

title: House Votes for a Return To Standard Time in '74
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The House of Representatives voted today, 381 to 16, to return the nation to standard time from the end of this October until the end of next February.

title: Robber of Yorkville Bank Calmly Collects $157.000
description: Armed with a valise he said was filled with eight sticks of dynamite, a young holdup man walked into a Yorkville savings bank last night, calmly waited 20 minutes while a terrified bank officer made two trips to the vault to fill an attach case with money and then walked out with $157,000 in cash.

title: Nixon Photographer Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Ollie Atkins, who was President Nixon's personal photographer, has been named director of the White House photographic department. He will continue on leave from the Curtis Publishing Company, Inc.

title: GREECE SHAKES UP ARMY'S COMMAND
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19The Greek Government today made changes in the command structure of the armed forces in a major step to break the power of the military, which ruled for seven years.

title: On Flunking Prison
description: Most of the debate about whether it Is fitting to jail an exPresident is so highflown that one feels a bit timid about injecting some realism into it.

title: Du Pont to Change Accounting Method, If I.R.S Approves
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. said yesterday it would adopt the complete lastinfirstout (Lifo) inventory accounting Method for domestic purposes this year, subject to approval of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Field Goal Gives Bills Triumph
description: Bills Triumph by 1615

title: Con Son: Tiger Cages to Buffalo Pens
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam About 5 A.M. Dec. 26 we were handcuffed together and transferred to a ship, No. 504, about 450 or more prisoners. We were put into the hold of the ship, shackled to bars. There were four policemen guarding us.

title: Jamaica Policeman Slain Trying to Make an Arrest
description: A city officer was shot to death last night in a neighborhood of South Jamaica, Queens, that has been marked by periodic flareups and animosity between the police and residents.

title: RACHE PURCHASES 2 STEINER BRANCHES
description: Bache & Co., the New York City brokerage house, announced yesterday that it had purchased two branch offices of Steiner Rouse & Co., Inc. in Mobile and Birmingham, Ala. for an undisclosed amount.

title: G.M.'S 1976 MODELS ON SALE THIS WEEK
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19The General Motors Corporation is putting its 1975 model cars on sale this week, earlier than any of the other auto producers and more than a month ahead of the official introduction date in September.

title: Byrne Approves Transfer Of 90 Prisoners to Ancora
description: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP, Aug. 19 Governor Byrne approved today a controversial plan to house 90 minimumsecurity prisoners from Leesburg State Prison on the grounds of Ancora Psychiatric Hospital here where they operate the laundry equipment.

title: AMSTAR TO INCREASE CORN SYRUP OUTPUT
description: Responding to rising demand by food and soft drink makers for an inexpensive substitute for sugar, the Amstar Corporation said yesterday it was spending more than $20million to expand its capacity to make highfructose corn syrup.Amstar, the nation's largest sugar manufacturer, said it would more than double its highfructose syrup output at its Dimmitt, Tex., plant under the trademark Amerose R.

title: Coal Shutdown Begins
description: Union coal miners began a nationwide shutdown in support of a strike by 400 men against two mines in Harlin County, Ky. The stoppage is expected to involve 125,000 men in a dozen states and cut coal production by eight million tons. Page 27.

title: Connecticut Bishops Admonish Doctors Who Do Abortions
description: Connecticut's three Roman Catholic Bishops spoke out against abortion yesterday, charging that physicians who performed abortions violated the Hippocratic Oath and noting that Catholic health workers who participated in them faced excommunication.

title: AIRLIFT AIDS VICTIMS OF PHILIPPINE FLOOD
description: MANILA, Aug. 19 (UPI)American and Philippine military helicopters began a joint airlift of food, candles, medicine and clothing to more than half a million refugees from floods in central Luzon provinces north of Manila today.

title: ALBERT L. LEWIS
description: Albert L. Lewis, managing editor of Aerofile Books since 1972 and aviation editor for Conde Nast Publications from 1960 to 1972, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home in Bellmore, L. I. His age was 59.

title: Business Briefs
description: A Federal district court in Richmond yesterday granted Chessie Systems, Inc., a railroad holding company, a temporary injunction it had sought restraining the Interstate Commerce Commission from requiring all railroads to earmark funds derived from a 10 per cent rate increase permitted on June 20 for deferred maintenance and postponed capital improvements.

title: State Agency Picks S.I. as Possible Site For a Power Plant
description: The State Power Authority has added Arthur Kill, an industrial section of Staten Island, to the list of possible sites for a projected generating plant whose output would power the city's subways and commuter trains after 1980.

title: SOLIDWASTE FUEL IS URGED FOR CITY
description: The energy crisis could help solve two of this city's most critical problemssolid waste and the sludge generated by sewagetreatment plants, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, Robert A. Low, said yesterday.

title: About New York
description: It's over, no more vacation, the heavyset type said to his wife as they deplaned from a London flight at Kennedy International Airport the other day. Nobody looked at a bag in Europe. Here they'll look. They'll argue and we'll be lucky to get a cab to Queens without calling in the police commissioner. Anywhere in the world you can get a cab, but at Kennedy you're taking the bread from the mouths of their children if you want a cab to Queens.

title: Giants' ExDoctor Tied to Bookies In a Conspiracy
description: Two bookmakers were indicted yesterday in connection with a $26millionayear sports gambling operation that focused on professional football and involved the orthopedic surgeon of the New York Giants.

title: Seltzer Keeps Bubbling, but the Business Has Gone Flat
description: When the Grand Concourse was the ChampsElyses of the workingclass Bronx, seltzer was its Chateau Lafite.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: 70,000 Refugees Flee New Vietnam Clashes
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 16At 5 o'clock this morning, Mrs. Le Phi Ba finally gave up. She and her husband had held out for 20 days, living in their own sandbagged bunker, subsisting on meager rations of rice, trying with every ounce of strength to stay in their tiny vilage of Son Phuc despite incessant shelling by North Vietnamese gunners.

title: 2 Gunmen Force Woman Into Withdrawing $8,000
description: Two young gunmen forced their way into a woman's East Harlem apartment at about 10 A.M. yesterday, seized $400 and then forced her to withdraw $8,000 from a nearby bank while three members of her family were held hostage, the police reported.

title: Franklin Asks a Curb On Trading Till Sept. 1
description: The Franklin New York Corporation, the parent of the Franklin National Bank, announced yesterday that it had again requested the Securities and Exchange Commission to continue the suspension of trading in the securities of the bank and the holding company.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: HARLEM COALITION ASSURED ON JOBS
description: A coalition seeking jobs for Harlem residents in the construction of an academic complex for the City College of New York yesterday won a commitment from the State Dormitory Authority's special projects coordinator that half A the jobs would go to the irea's minorities.

title: House Passes Transit Bill Providing $11Billion Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20In a major victory for President Ford, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a sixyear masstranspottation bill after slashing it from $20billion to $11billion.

title: Brick Township Man Seized By F.B.I. on Obscenity Charge
description: NEWARK, Aug. 20 (AP)A Brick Township man was art rested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on a charge of interstate transportation of obscene matter for allegedly taking a copy of the X rated film Deep Throat to Tennessee.

title: Webster, ExGiant, In Jersey Hospital
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 20 (UPI)  The former New York Giants' head coach, Alex Webster, was admitted to St. Elizabeth's Hospital in guarded condition today following an apparent heart attack.

title: Crisis Cut Road Deaths
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (Reuters)The fuel crisis helped to reduce the number of people killed on American roads last year to 55,800 from 56,600 in 1972, the National Safety Council said today. The death rate dropped during the last two months of 1973 at the outset of the fuel shortage, the nonprofit organization said.

title: Senate Fails to End Debate on Agency To Aid Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The Senate failed by three votes today to end debate on legislation that would create a new agency to represent consumer interests within the Federal Government.

title: AMEX STOCKS DIP; OTC AREA MIXED
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday for the eighth consecutive session. Prices on the overthecounter market were mixed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Press comments indicate that to many people President Nixon's resignation is not a satisfactory settlement of the charges in the recommended articles of impeachment, The statement accompanying the resignation admits no guilt, asserts that no impeachable offense was committed, and merely decides not to contest the matter wih the Congress at present.

title: Colson's Father Dies
description: DOVER, Mass., Aug. 20 (UPI) Wendell B. Colson, father of Charles W. Colson, former White House aide, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 75 years old. Mr. Colson had worked as a lawyer for many years for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SOUTH VIETNAMESE LOSE BORDER POST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 21 (AP) North Vietnamese forces overran a Government outpost on the Cambodian border used to keep watch against infiltration into South Vietnam, military officials said today.

title: Brazilians Fight Meningitis Epidemic, Fatal to 800, With Mass Vaccinations
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 16 Latin America's largest, fastestgrowing industrial capital has been stricken by a serious meningitis epidemic.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Summer JobCutoff Protesters Storm Into City Hall in Newark
description: NEWARK, Aug. 20More than 200 shouting adults and, teenagers invaded City Hall this afternoon, angrily demanding that officials resolve the problems surrounding the premature closing of a summer youthjob program.

title: Music: Piano Concerto by F. X. Mozart
description: F. X. Mozart it said, and it was not a typographical error, The great composer had two sons; and one of them, Franz Xaver (17911844), became a professional musician. The other, also musically talented, ended up in government service.

title: FarrellBeck Group And a Singer Alter Musical Direction's
description: A little more than a year ago, the saxophonist Joe Farrell and the guitarist Joe Beck formed a jazz quartet and, at the same time, Teri Thorton, a singer who had had a flash hit in 1966; Somewhere in the Night, resumed her career after a period of semiretirement. Now, both Miss Thorton and the FarrellBeck quartet are at the Halfnote this week.

title: Harvard Gets H.E.W. Grant
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP)The Harvard School of Public Health has been awarded a $152,047 grant from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for a study of agents that cause venereal diseases. The money will support the first year of the Harvard school's Center for the Study of Sexually Transmitted Diseases.

title: House Passes Transit Bill Providing $1 1Billion Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20In a major victory for President Ford, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a sixyear masstransportation bill after slashing it from $20billion to $11billion.

title: High Weight to Forego
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 20 (AP)Lazy F. Ranch's Forego, winner of six straight stakes, was assigned top weight of 129 pounds today for the 22d running of the $100,000 United Nations Handicap at Atlantic City Aug. 30. Darby Dan Farm's True Knight, who defeated Forego in the Suburban, drew the next high weight of 127 pounds.

title: A Relaxed Nominee Fits Mood Sought by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20This uptight town has not lately seen a more relaxed politician than it saw today in Nelson Rockefeller.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 20 (UPI)Lack of adequate financing and a reduction in projected electricity consumption today forced the Duke Power Company to impose delays of up to two years on proposed nuclear generating facilities. Duke has thoroughly investigated all available means of financing and is convinced that it is impossible to raise the huge sums needed to maintain the former construction schedule, said Carl Horn Jr., president of the utility.

title: Westchester Dealer Sees Civil War Over Milk
description: ALBANY, Aug. 20A detailed picture of what he called a civil war in the milk industry in Westchester County was drawn here today by an independent dealer who is facing the loss of his license to operate.

title: 3SCHOOL PROFESSOR RELINQUISHES 2 JOBS
description: CALIFORNIA, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP)  A professor who hopscotched among teaching jobs here and in two New York colleges has agreed to work only for California State College.

title: Connors Advances at Jersey Net
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 20  The Wimbledon champion, Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., and Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, the first and secondseeded players, respectively, survived firstround matches today in the $50,000 MediQuik open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: World Swim Mark Set By Hargitay of Hungary
description: VIENNA, Aug. 20 (AP)Andras Hargitay of Hungary accomplished today a 10year dream when he smashed the world record for the 400meter individual medley at the European swimming championships.

title: Solo Atlantic Sailor Sighted
description: NORTH KINGSTON, R.I., Aug. 20 (AP)A 21yearold East Greenwich sailor undertaking a solo voyage to England in a 22foot sailboat has been sighted about 250 miles from Land's End, the southwest tip of England, the Coast Guard said today. Robert Gainer was sighted by the liner Queen Elizabeth, 2. The sighting was the first since, Mr. Gainer sailed for Falmouth, England, from Wickford Harbor here June 29.

title: City and Odyssey House Clash Over Drug Program's Practice's
description: Investigators of the city's Addiction Services Agency have charged irregularities in the financial and admission practices of Odyssey House, one of the largest drug rehabilitation programs here, and say that the program has violated its funding contract with the city.

title: Quality First
description: Vermont's Governor, Thomas P. Salmon, and a number of other Vermonters seem to have gotten the issues all twisted around in their reaction to the appointment of Dr. Jahn Froines as the state's Director of Occupational Health. Governor Salmon is upset because of what he calls a bad, bad public reaction to the presence of a former antiwar activist on the state payroll. Dr. Froines, you see, was a defendant in the Chicago Seven trial which followed the riots at the Democratic National Convention in 1968. He was acquitted on all counts.

title: Israelis Annoyed at Kissinger For Saying Rabin to Visit Soon
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 20Secretary of State Kissinger we criticized in Israel today for having announced at a news conference yesterday that Premier Yitzhak Rabin had been invited to Washington in the first half of September.

title: President's Instincts Shaped Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20It was an entirely individual choice, and it was President Ford's secret, strictly speaking, until he first told Netson A. Rockefeller flatly this morning that he had been summoned to Washington to he nominated to be Vice President.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Taiwan Little Leaguers Triumph

title: Between rage and reaction, anticolonialism and subservience
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N. Y. At the African Liberation Day rally in Bridgetown, Barbados, the handsome black Barbadian in a white teeshirt, his muscles taut with anger, jumped up with his fist clenched, shouting: Barbados no blasted paradise now!

title: Holiday Inn Plan Disclosed
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and Hyprops, a general partnership headquartered in Georgia, announced yesterday they had formed a $50million joint venture to acquire and develop Holiday Inns throughout the United States. Hyprops is one of the largest, franchisees of Holiday Inns.

title: U.M.W. Fights Plan For Power Project On the New River
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The United Mine Workers of America came out today against construction of a mammoth hydroelectric project by the American Electric Power system on the New River in western Virginia and North Carolina.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1974

title: BUSINESS CHEERS DECISION BY FORD
description: I think its sensational, said James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, in response to the nomination yesterday of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President. I'm very confident about the future. Before, I was just confident.

title: Exxon Finds Oil in South
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20 (UPI)  A unit of the Exxon Corporation has announced the discovery of an oil field in Lee County, Fla. The company said additional drilling would be needed to determine the size of the well area, which is just northwest of the company's Lehigh Acres field.

title: Leaders Basking in Sun, Not the Limelight
description: LONDON, Aug. 20Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain is on an island, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is on a lake, President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France is on the Riviera. In short, Europe's leaders are on vacation.

title: Red Smith
description: A spokesman for the National Football League Management Council says the idea is no longer operative that customers should receive refunds on exhibition tickets they didn't want to buy in the first place. A lawyer tells Federal judge that the N.F.L. is of itself a conspiracy restraint of trade. A dozen members of the Congress the United States warn the club owners that unless they shape up and start bargaining with their employes in good faith they'll find themselves caught in a wringer on Capitol Hill. Negotiators for the players scale down their demands to the limit, the bottom limit we can recommend to our members, and Management Council rejects the proposals out of hand. Assuming that the arrival veterans in camp meant the strike had been broken and not merely suspended, a club like the New York Giants proceeds with a purge of players planning jump to the World Football League next year.

title: Gulf Oil Plans to Resume Drilling Off South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20 (AP)The Gulf Oil Corporation plans to resume in October its test drilling in the fourth block of South Korea's continental shelf, west of Cheju Island, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED
