description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21The police said today that they believed a 31yearold Yugoslav suspect in the Aug. 6 bombing of the Los Angeles International Airport had been acting alone, although a police spokesman said that the authorities are not closing the door on the possibility that others had been involved.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Treasury Department today announced that it sold oneyear bills at an average discount rate of 9.73 per cent highest one record for such an issue.

title: Democratic Example
description: Promising a government of peace and development, President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen has launched Colombia an ;experiment of great importance for Latin America. It is especially important because Colombia is nation that has practiced democracy since 1958, one whose new President was freely elected in a landslide with large majorities in both houses of Congress.

title: Westmoreland Blames Politics for His Loss
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 (AP)Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the former Army Chief of Staff, said today that it was state politics, not the Watergate scandals, that stopped his bid for the Republican nomination for the South Carolina governorship.

title: $16 Crafty Khale Takes Seneca on Saratoga Turf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21  Crafty Khale, in front most of the way, held off a late surge by Golden Don today to win the $38,875 Seneca Handicap. A field of nine participated in the 12th running of the 1mile turf event and Crafty Khale, ridden by Heliodoro Gustines, beat Golden Don by 1 lengths.

title: Too Little for Transit
description: Although disappointingly inadequate in its funding provisions, the sixyear masstransit bill passed overwhelmingly by the House represents a significant advance Federal support for public transportation. If adopted by the Senate and signed by President Fordboth reasonable prospectsthis pioneering legislation would establish the concept of sustained subsidies for masstransportation systems throughout the country, in both urban and rural areas.

title: Bembridge Golf Victor
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Aug. 21 (UPI)Maurice Bembridge, a British Ryder Cup member, carded a fourunderpar 66 today for a 136 to win the 36hole Benson and Hedges individual golf championship by a stroke from Bob Charles of New Zealand.

title: Canadian Output Raised
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Canada's real domestic output increased by 0.2 per cent in the second quarter following a 2.4 per cent gain in the first quarter, Statistic's Canada reported today. Most manufacturing industries recorded declines in the quarter, with a large number of labor strikes an important factor, the agency said.

title: Water Music Runs Its Course Smoothly At Park in Village
description: Johannes Somary was the conductor and one of the composers Tuesday night for the third of the four free chamberensemble concerts in Washington SquarePark. His work in the former capacity was rather more persuasive than in the latterbut that is really saying that he condudied well, not that he composed poorly.

title: CNA Says Larwin Subsidiary Received Default Notice
description: The CNA Financial Corporation announced yesterday that the Larwin Group, Inc., its homebuilding subsidiary, had received notice of an event of default in a $145million agreement that Larwin has with group of banks.

title: Ramirez, Metreveli Gain at Net
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 20  Raul Ramirez of Mexico and Vijay Armitraj of India, the fourth and seventh seeded players, respectively, Survived tough firstround tests today in the $50,000 MediQuik open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Dance: With Pantomime
description: LEE, Mass., Aug. 21Mixing laughter and tears, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival presented. Lotte Goslar's Pantomime Circus and members of the Jose Lim6n Dance Company in repertory pieces for its last week. The groups appeared Tuesday night at the Tad Shawn Theater.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart
description: Contrary to the impression one might gain from talking with those Great Gatsby types who hibernate for the summer in the Hamptons or Oyster Bay, there actually are people in Manhattan during August. Lots of them, in fact, as the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall has been proving. The heavily attended series overreached itself on Tuesday night when an overflow audience had to be seated on stage to hear the Tokyo String Quartet, the flutist JeanPierre Rampal, and the pianist Gary Graffman.

title: FORD DISCLOSES HE EXPECTS TO ASK NOMINATION IN '76
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 President Ford served notice today that he would probably run in 1976 for the office he has held for less than two weeks.

title: Seaboard Coast Line Buying 145 Diesels
description: Seaboard Coast Line Industries, the holding company that, owns the railroad of like name as well as the Louisville & Nashville and several other roads in the Southeast, announced yesterday it was purchasing 145 new diesel locomotives for the consolidated system.

title: Americans Rally, Stay Unbeaten
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 21 (AP)Matthew Reed stepped in after George Mira was injured tonight and quarterbacked the unbeaten Birmingham Americans to two touchdowns in the fourth quarter for a 1514 World Football League victory over the Jacksonville Sharks.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ROCKEFEIER SETS TALKS IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, who faces an intensive inquiry into his finances before he is confirmed by Congress, will spend tomorrow in Washington, making a round of visits with members of the House and Senate committees that will hold hearings on his nomination.

title: 78 Dead as Philippine Floods Recede
description: SANTO TOMAS, the Philippines, Aug. 21Floods that have left 78 persons dead and more than a million homeless in central Luzon are receding, and here in this town 40 miles from Manila stranded cars line a thin strip of highway just emerged from the brown waters.

title: Herstatt Creditors Group To Seek Bankruptcy Move
description: COLOGNE, Aug. 21 (Reuters) A group of Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt, A.G. creditors', including the City of Cologne, savings and giro banks and agricultural and industrial cooperatives, said it would apply to the Cologne court for bankruptcy proceedings to begin.

title: SUSPECT CHARGED IN ARSON HOMICIDE
description: A 40yearold Brooklyn man was accused of having set fire yesterday morning to the tenement in which he lived, thereby causing the death of his brotherinlaw, who had earlier served him with divorce papers.

title: TURKEY PROMISES CYPRUS RESTRAINT
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 21Highly placed Turkish sources denied today that any moves toward annexation of territory were being made in Cyprus that would preclude a negotiated settlement with Greece on the future of the island.

title: Stage: Spirited Revivals
description: You have to look hard these days, on Broadway or off it, to find a genuinely adult drama about man and God, or a musical with real music and real characters. In a welcome splash of color Off Off Broadway, the Malachy Company has appealingly revived Graham Greene's The Potting Shed, while a new unit of youngsters called the Octagon Theater Club is reprising 110 in the Shade with freshness and verve.

title: CRANE UNFAZED BY HEAT OF RAG
description: The state Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, sal yesterday that he did not believe that the trading of personal charges by Howard J. Samuels and Representative Hugh L. Carey in the last few days signaled a deterioration of the campaign for his party's gubernatorial nomination.

title: JAWORSKI TO APPEAL A RULING BY GESELL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, filed notice today that he will appeal an order by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of Federal District Court setting aside the guilty verdict in one of the three counts of perjury of which John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's former chief adviser on domestic affairs, was convicted July 12.

title: State Discloses Distribution Plan For VoterRegistration Forms
description: TRENTON, Aug. 21 (AP)The state announced today procedures for distribution of voterregistration applications lunder the new state postcard registration law.

title: Jersey Meadows Group Plans Racing at Monmouth This Year
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 21The winner's circle is lost in a sea of dirt and rocks at the embryonic Hackensack Meadows race track.

title: Hospital Graduates First of Patamedics For Service in City
description: In an effort to bring the hospital emergency room closer to the community, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday graduated its first class of paramedics at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

title: Hospital Graduates First of Paramedics For Service in City
description: In an effort to bring the hospital emergency room closer to the community, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday graduated its first class of paramedics at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

title: 8 Seized in City Hall Protest
description: Eight men who said they were members of Fight Back, the group that has been protesting discrimination against blacks and Puerto Ricans in the construction trades, were arrested yesterday at City Hall Plaza shortly after noon. The men, all in their 20's, were charged with disorderly conduct, after staging a sitdown demonstration at the site of a construction project.

title: Nurse's Illness to Force TB Test for 1,300 Infants
description: Almost all the 1,300 babies born in Yonkers since midDecember may have been exposed to tuberculosis, and Westchester County health officials have begun notifying parents to bring their infants in for tests.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 21 (UPI)  The dollar went into a slow decline on world money markets today, reversing a recent steady rise, in generally quiet markets. The price of gold also fell, after showing gains on all markets yesterday.

title: The Screen: 'Pink Floyd':Rock Group's Music Is Focus of the Film The Program
description: "Pink Floyd," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli Theater, Eastside Cinema and other theaters, is an 85-minute commercial for an English rock group called Pink Floyd.It is a fan-magazine article dressed up as a movie, with lots of close-ups of its heroes and an off-screen interviewer who occasionally drops in a question or a commentabout their equipment or their compatibilityand is satisfied with whatever he is told.With an ancient amphitheater and a recording studio as settings for the group's music and an eatery of some sort as the setting for the musicians' uncomfortable efforts at banter, "Pink Floyd" has recourse to an assortment of effectssplit screens, montages, rapid cuts, clips of flowing lava and masksin an effort to rescue itself from visual boredom. The pictorial result ranges in quality from picture postcard, to album cover.Since its principals possess neither interesting personalities nor captivating philosophies, it is fortunate that the bulk of the film is given over to their music. It is unfortunate that their music, which ranges from traditional rock to sci-fi, fails the test one of the group sets for itmoving the listenerdespite the array of electronic equipment marshaled in its behalf."Pink Floyd" may be for Pink Floyd fans. It may be for rock fans. But it's not for movie fans.

title: Indian Scientists Insist That MuchDeplored Nuclear Effort Is Needed for Progress
description: BOMBAYOn a spare hilly track overlooking the Arabian Sea, hundreds of nuclear physicists, chemists and engineer are struggling to lift India out of the industrial and economic backwardness of centuries.

description: George (Doc) Medich, the pitching medical student, carried the New York Yankees to a 41 victory over the Minnesota Twins yesterday and kept alive the Yankees' lingering chances in the American League East.

title: Teacher Union Chief
description: TORONTO, Aug. 21When the inevitability of Albert Shanker's election as president of the American Federation of Teachers became obvious here yesterday in a floor battle at the federation's convention, a vice president of the California delegation said sardonically to the man next to him: Now we will crown the king. Mr. Shanker's victory was made official tonight with the casting of ballots and while there was, of course, no coronation, jubilation broke out among his supporters over Mr. Shanker's elevation to the head of the 425,000member organization.

title: Lambs Offer Plan to Save Clubhouse
description: A plan to prevent the sale at auction of the clubhouse of The Lambs, 128 West 44th Street, by expanding it into a fine arts and theatrical center in a privateclub setting was described yesterday in Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Phone Call Leads to Arrests in Slayings
description: A tape recording of an anonymous telephone call to the police led yesterday to the arrest of two men on charges that they had stabbed to death a 28yearold woman and her 9yearold daughter Tuesday in a Harlem housing project.

title: ' Newman's Law' at the Neighborhoods
description: August is the month for very dumb action pictures aimed at the drive-in trade. Some are the too-familiar urban Westerns  where the city cop stands in for the local sheriff, while the Indians are replaced by drug dealers  and they tend to be pitifully poor of plot, with almost no suspense to link the shoot-outs or chases. In fact, I'd love to learn why many action movies have to be so dull."Newman's Law," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, trots out the mossy formula that should be given at least one month's rest: an incorruptible detective is accused of being on the take and is therefore suspended. Hence the outraged law-lover continues to investigate the case on his own. There's hardly an episode in this picture that you haven't seen before, from the man with a gun on top of a vast tank (a bumbling reference to James Cagney's great moment in Raoul Walsh's "White Heat") to a stabbed waterbed ("The Terminal Man"), and much of it resembles "McQ," John Wayne's dud of last winter Still, there is one original detail: a man who's been beaten by thugs falls bleading onto a pile of giant toy pandas.It's disheartening to see George Peppard playing the quasi-Serpico. I've always had a soft spot for this actor, partly because he often makes one feel that he's more intelligent or sensitive than the characters he personifies. But in recent years, he's shown a gift for picking dreary scripts. Here, he hardly bothers to act. Below the blazing blue eyes, he grits his teeth, clenches his jaw, wipes his mouth with the back of his wrist (a gesture that means tension), or flares his nostrils  all in all, he seems to be auditioning for a parody of the warm-hearted hard head. Meanwhile, several good black actorsRoger Robinson, for example  are wasted in this movie, which is also far too gloomy to pass for entertainment.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sears, Roebuck, Inc., is seeking permission from the town of New Canaan, Conn., to build a multimilliondollar regional shopping center and residential and commercial complex on 305 acres. It has obtained an option to purchase the large tract, formerly known as the Hoyt Nurseries, from the RCA Corporation. RCA encountered considerable opposition from the wealthy community when it wanted to build an office facility for 1,000 of its executives. The. Sears proposal for the project bordering Route 123 is its first venture in the East with a multiplepurpose complex. It is currently building four new town centers near Chicago.

title: Bicentennial Candidate

Even before Congress starts action on Nelson Rockefeller's confirmation, Mr: Ford's press secretary has let it be known that the President has abandoned his old view that he would not want to run for a full term two years hence.

The first week's survey, last year, showed the Market Basket Cost to be $50.68.

title: Screen: 'The Longest Yard' With Burt Reynolds:Prisoners and Guards in Football Match The Cast Film Turns on Violence and Humiliation
description: Perhaps we'll get a substantial movie about contemporary prisons and prisoners one of these daysa picture that can actually tell us what it means to be a captive. Meanwhile, we're stuck with splashy fabrications, such as Robert Aldrich's "The Longest Yard," which opened yesterday at Loews State 1 and Loews Orpheum. While we know that prisons throng with sadistic guards, the ones in this movie behave like leering sci-fi monsterswhich makes it easy to forget that atrocities occur off screen as well as on.The picture dwells on the preparations for a ferocious football game between prisoners and guards. Both sides look forward eagerly to mangling one another. Burt Reynolds, as an imprisoned former football star who coaches the convicts' team, contends with Warden Eddie Albert, who's determined that the guards must win and that the prisoners must be humiliated.I suspect that Mr. Reynolds may have watched "On the Waterfront" at least a dozen times just before this movie was shot, since he apes Marlon Brando's performance all through "The Yard." Pursing or smacking his lips, chewing gum or smirking or wrinkling his nose, he surpasses flattery with his lumbering imitation. Mr. Reynolds departs from mimicry only in his style of wearing clothes: he manages to make even the prison chains look like fashionable men's wear, as though he were modeling the latest in metal accessories.The discomfort of watching Mr. Reynolds is alleviated by Eddie Albert's sly, silky characterization of the sinister warden. He comes on like a restrained but toothy college dean who's welcoming the freshmen"It's nice to have you here"smiles especially when he's angry, and recoils with an academic's sternness when he doesn't like what he hears.Though "The Yard" is a terrible picture, I'll admit to having unwillingly enjoyed some of the football practice and parts of the final gameeven though it's much too long. There's no thrill in the sport, since it's the movie director who decides who wins or loses. But the plot does yield some dramatic tensionbecause of what winning or losing represents. The prisoners are playing for their dignity, and even the most reluctant spectator is forced to respond to that theme.Some may want to ponder Mr. Aldrich's appeals to the baser instinctswith references to his "The Dirty Dozen." But that seems like an unnecessary exercise, since the issue itself can be better discussed in light of other recent movies. Still, this picture will enlarge the director's dossier of nasty buildups to violence: a man we know will become a human torch delays that torching by pausing to comb his hair before the inevitable explosion, and it's one of the cheaper tricks to grace our screens of late.

The 76ers hold the National Basketball Association draft rights to McGinnis and have allowed the Knicks to negotiate with the powerful 6foot8inch forward.

title: FRANCIS LLOYD DIES; JERSEY LEGAL AIDE
description: Francis Van Duyne Lloyd, who was Deputy Attorney General of New Jersey in 1950 and earlier was a district court judge in Bergen County, died Tuesday in Hackensack, N. J. He was 78 years old and lived in Layton, N.J. an Delray Beach, Fla.

title: ' Buster and Billie,' High School Youth in Rural Georgia of '48:The Cast
description: The time machine that transported audiences of a year or two ago back to the summer of '42 and the class of '44 is open for business again. And in this summer of '74, a trip to the springand the classof '48 in rural Georgia is being offered in the form of a film called "Buster and Billie," which opened yesterday at the Columbia II and neighborhood theaters."Buster and Billie" is at once an alluring and fiercely disappointing movie that leaves one full of regret for what might have been. Chief among its virtues, at a time when so many film makers, either through sloth or contempt, treat originality with disdain, is the focus of its story.Billie (Joan Goodfellow) is an unusual heroine. Bovine in her submissiveness, she is the silent and undemanding dispenser of ultimate sexual favors for the coterie of her teen-age high-schoolmates who surround Buster (Jan-Michael Vincent).Unlike his fellow members of Tomorrow's Farmers of America, Buster, an otherwise unexceptional youth, does not seek out Billieat least at first. He is faithful to, if, not content with, his fiance, Margie (Pamela Sue Martin), who allows him frustrating liberties but busily preserves her virginity during their contortions at night in the front of his little truck.And then, one day, Buster decides to seek out Billie, at first furtively and for the same reason as his classmates; later he dates her openly, to the disapproving astonishment of his townsfolk and because he has come to cherish her as a person. Billie has changed, but the townspeople, especially Buster's classmates, remain the same, with disastrous consequences.But if art resides in the quality of revelation, "Buster and Billie" is a failure. For all that the movie suggests, Billie's past is a side effect of impoverished and laconic parents in a community no table neither for its riches nor the garrulousness of its inhabitants.In dealing with Buster and Billie and their schoolmates, Daniel Petrie, the director, and Ron Turbeville, the screen writer, have contended themselves with types, observed keenly but unexplained, remote rather than real, remembered but not revealed. The film suffers, too, from a monotony of judgment that assigns each scene an equal value, whether it is a trimmable segment involving a softball game or a fatal encounter.It's too bad. One wishes this film were less like the early Billieto be visited because it's available  and more like the laterto be cherished because it's special.

title: Consumer Notes Nutritionists Delighted By Soaring Sugar Coste
description: In the view of some consumer and nutrition experts, the snaring cost of sugar in recent months is the best inflation news yet, Since Jan. 10, the price of a fivepound bag has doubled to $1.80.

title: Amex, Chicago Board and PEW Exchanges Would Team on Clearance

description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  One day next month, Mrs. Sydney Tyler expects to pick up a telephone in her San Jose home and call 2874200. She will be among the first customers for one of the nation's most ambitious efforts yet to entice motorists out of their automobiles.

title: PRICE RISES SET BY CHEMICAL UNIT
description: The United States Industrial Chemicals Company, a subsidiary of National Distillers & Chemical Corporation, announced yesterday an increase in prices of all its ethylenebased products, effective Sept. 1. Price Polyethylene resin Changes prices will be raised an average of 5 cents per pound. Vinyl acetate monomer delivered price will also go up 5 cents a pound, while ethyl alcohol will increase an average of 15 cents a gallon. These increases more nearly equalize feedstock values for plastic and chemical products, a spokesman explained.

title: War Exacts a Huge Toll in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, CambodiaCambodia has about the same number of people as New York City, and if the war in Cambodia were happening in New York, by now the equivalent of the entire population of Staten Island (295,443) would have been killed or woundedtwice over. Or, superimposing the Cambodian situation on a more populous borough, nearly half the people in Manhattan would have fallen as casualties.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Wampeters, Foma & Granfallons: (Opinions)
description: There was a time not to long ago when I desperately clung to Kurt Vonnegut's name. It was the one that came most readily to mind whenever I was asked who among the newest American writers would make the literary galaxy. Without racking my brain too much I could have come up with the names of other writers of equal reputation: Barth, Pynchon, Barthelme and so on. Mr. Vonnegut's was the surest. One could admire the others, but the author of "Player Piano" and "God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater," one enjoyed. And nothing in literature lasts that is not enjoyed. Not that Mr. Vonnegut's work was exactly cheering: with all its freewheeling manner, if involved readers in a conspiracy of doom that was perversely calming--what's left to be done after the funeral? Long before "moonwalk" his imagination had sought a far-off planet from which to view the earthlings below. What he saw so simplified and enlarged the present moment that it could be grasped in its totality. From "Cat's Cradle" on he has been our cultural critic and guru.

title: CoverUp Trial Postponed For Three Weeks by Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Federal District Judge John J. Sirica today postponed the Watergate coverup trial for three weeks at the urging of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

description: PARIS, Aug. 22 (Reuters)France will soon announce plans to ration supplies of home heating oil this winter, but does not at present envisage similar curbs for industry, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Torrential Rains Flood Drought Belt in Africa
description: ROME, Aug. 22, (AP)The subSahara area of West Central Africa, stricken by a devastating sixyear drought, has been hit by torrential rains, a United Nations spokesman reported today.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur D. Lewis, chairman of the newly formed United States Railway Association has nothing hut deadlines ahead of him for the next 12 months.

title: Elections to Be Held For New Delegates To Black Assembly
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22Imainu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, today announced plans for elections in Plainfield on Saturday for 13 new state delegates to represent New Jersey at the National Black Assembly to be held in Columbus, Ohio, on Sept. 21.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 (UPI)  Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines arrived here today to begin a fourday official visit to Yugoslavia, his first since the two nations established diplomatic relations two years ago, the Belgrade radio said.

description: For Halbrecht Associates, strange silence ended yesterday with the welcome ringing of telephone.

title: Connors Gains; Ramirez, Parun Upset
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 22  Jimmy Connors, the tournament favorite here and the topseeded player in next week's United States Open, scored an impressive secondround victory today in the $50,000 MediQuik Open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: PENSIONS REFORM PASSED BY SENATE AND SENT TO FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Senate passed and sent to the White House a landmark pension reform bill today as Congress adjourned for a Labor Day recess.

title: JerseyNew York Bus Fares Are Rising by 5 Cents a Ride
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 22Thousands of bus commuters who travel between New Jersey and New York each day will find their fares increasing by 5 cents a ride tomorrow.

title: TURKEY'S PREMIER OFFERS TO FILL IN ANY GAP IN NATO
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 22Premier Bulent Ecevit said today that Turkey could compensate for any weaknesses in United States defenses in the Mediterranean caused by Greece's military withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Walkout on Health
description: The surprise walkout by the House Ways and Means Committee on efforts to enact a national health insurance bill is all the more deplorable because the need for such legislation has never been greater and the conditions for its passage have never seemed more promising.

title: 2 HARSH DECREES LIFTED BY SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Aug. 23President Park Chung Hee lifted two politically represisve decrees this morning in his first move to ease his campaign against opponents since January.

title: JAMES P. CANNON, TROTSKYITE, DEAD
description: James P. Cannon, a Trotskyite who helped to found the Socialist Workers party in 1938 and who later became its national chairman, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old.

title: State Displays Crop Versatility
description: BRIDGETON, Aug. 22The latest developments in vegetable harvesting techniques and progress reports on new strains of plants and seeds, to make more efficient use of the farmlands of New Jersey and the country were described today by experts at the Rutgers Research and Development Center.

title: Aluminum Workers' Raise
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (UPI),  About 30,000 employes of three major aluminum producers will receive a 14centanhour costofliving increase on Sept. 1, the United Steelworkers of America said yesterday. The union said that the increase for employes of the Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and Kaiser Aluminum had been authorized under terms of the 1974 wage contract negotiated earlier this year.

title: Pressured Teachers
description: In trying to limit the number of separately compensated teaching and coaching jobs a fulltime public school teacher may undertake, Chancellor Irving Anker is clearly trying to protect the quality of education offered to the majority of New York City pupils. Teachers who add two or more such assignments to their regular teaching load may be more interested in the additional payin some instances $6,000 or morethan they are in the services provided to the children.

title: Kent State Suit Set
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP)Civil suits brought by students and parents of students shot by National Guardsmen at Kent State University in 1970 will go to trial next spring, a Federal judge said yesterday. United States District Judge Don J. Young agreed to combine 12 suits against former Gov. James A. Rhodes and other state officials. The suits seek a total of $11million.

title: Market Place
description: A week ago, when Goldman, Sachs & Co, put out a 90  page review of retail stocks, most were at depressed levels in the stock market.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company yesterday received a $29.9million Air Force contract for Minuteman missile procurement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Discotheque Fire Suspect Sets His Jail Cell Ablaze
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP)Peter Leonard, held on murder and arson charges in a discotheque blaze that killed 24 persons, set fire to his cell at the Westchester County jail here, prison officials said today.

title: Amoco Chemicals to Expand
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UPI)  A subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has announced plans to construct a twin to an, ethylene plant now under construction near Alvin, Tex. Both plants of the Amoco Chemicals Corporation will be capable of producing a billion pounds of olefins annually. The first plant is scheduled to be in operation early next year; the second one, in 1977.

title: Boston U. Picks Gibney
description: BOSTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)Richard Gibney, head wrestling coach since 1969, was named acting director of athletics today at Boston University effective Sept. 1. Gibney, 31 years old, replaces Warren Schmakel, who resigned to become athletic director of Illinois State University.

title: Fire Trounces Wheels On 2dQuarter Burst
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Aug. 22 (AP)Walter Rhone's 90yard kickoff return highlighted a fourtouchdown burst in the second quarter tonight that carried the Chicago Fire to a 3523 victory over the Detroit Wheels in World Football League play.

title: Greek Bases Worry U.S. and NATO
description: The possibility that the United States may be denied the use of air bases and naval facilities in Greece has caused concern among senior Defense Department officials, military chiefs in Washington and among planners at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

title: News Summary Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 23, 1974

title: SEARS NET DROPS ON HIGHER SALES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the nation's largest retailer, reported yesterday record sales for the second quarter and halfyear ended July 31, but declines in net income for the periods because of a strike and other adverse factors.

title: People in Sports
description: Barry Ashbee, whose career ended when he was struck in the right eye in a Stanley Cup playoff game against the Rangers last April 28, was named yesterday an assistant coach of the champion Philadelphia Flyers. The former defenseman will work with the Flyers defense corps according to Keith Allen, the club's general manager.

title: 3 More Say Thief Robbed Their Boxes in Paris Dank
description: PARIS, Aug. 22  Three more persons have reported that they were victims of a thief who disappeared after emptying a number of safedeposit boxes in three visits to a bank vault.

title: 2 HARSH DECREES LIFTED BY SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Aug. 23President Park Chung Hee lifted two politically represisve decrees this morning in his first move to ease his campaign against opponents since January.

title: Theater: Sheba Is Back
description: At first, watching an updated production of Come Back, Little Sheba, a viewer uneasily senses that William Inge's dramathe one that elevated Shirley Booth to Broadway famemay be headed for derailment. Not at all. It takes a little time, for those of us who saw the 1950 original and the film, to accept some now refurbishmentssplashes of offstage music that cue In quick, dreamlike tableaus, and the casting of a black youth in the key role of the athlete. It works well.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Man Wins
description: The election of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's handpicked candidate, Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed, as President of India offers another dramatic example of the extraordinary political strength and staying power Mrs. Gandhi has in the face of adversity.

title: FreedomofInformation Statute Still Lacks State Ground Rules
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22Although a new freedomofinformation law designed to make public records more easily available to reporters, ordinary citizens and publicinterest groups takes effect in 10 days, a committee that will administer the law must still define what is meant by a public record, the committee secretary said today.

title: LOPEZ KIDNAPPERS CET PRISON TERMS
description: Two men who took part in the June kidnaping of Orlando Lopez in West New York, N.J., were sentenced in New York City yesterday to prison terms of three and five years.

title: Saratoga Bet Pays $63,624
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22A teacher who bet the ages of his children today won a $63,624 triplethe biggest payoff in the history of New York State thoroughbred racing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: James Williams, a convicted White Plains gambler, was freed unharmed after being kidnapped Tuesday for the second time in two years. No ransom was paid for his release.

title: DOLLAR UP WIDELY AS POUND DECLINES
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (UPI) The U.S. dollar climbed strongly at the expense of Britain's. pound today and strengthened against most other currencies. The rebound came after a oneday slump yesterday that interrupted a steady, monthlong climb.

title: Ford Is Found to Be in Excellent Health
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Ford, after undergoing his first physical examination since taking office, was found today to be in excellent health and mentally fit for the Presidency, though a little overweight and yarning for a swimming pool.

title: Attendance In W.F.L. Is Dropping
description: At halftime of the New York Stars' 4310 rout of the Houston Texans before a sparse crowd of 12,042 on Wednesday night, Bob Schmertz, the Stars' owner, held an impromptu press conference to assure everyone of his financial solvency and to deny rumors that he had sold or was actively looking to sell the World Football League club.

description: BASEBALL

description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 22 (AP)Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., overcame a secondset scare to post a 62, 75 quarterfinalround victory over Janet Newberry of La Jolla, Calif., today in the $30,000 women's grasscourts championships.

title: Girl From Petrovka on Screen Here
ROCKEFELLER PAYS VISIT TO CONGRESS

title: CarpetBacking Costs Rising
description: General Felt Industries and its subsidiary, the National Sponge Cushion Company, yesterday announced price increases for carpetunderlay products. The price of rebond will be up 10 per cent on Sept. 6. Increases of 7 to 10 per cent on rubber, 12 to 15 per cent on prime urethan and 5 to per cent on felt will become effective Sept. 13.

title: Jet Prototype Tested
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)The Northrop Corporation's second prototype of the world's newest jet fighter, the YF17, has made its first flight test from this Southern California desert base. During a 61minute flight yesterday, the lightweight, twinengine jet reached an altitude of 27,000 feet and a speed of 615 miles an hour. The YF17 is competing with General Dynamics' YF16 for possible fullscale production by the Air Force.

title: Red Smith
description: When Jim Colbert set out to make his fortune as a tournament golfer, he entertained no manner of doubt, no probable, possible shadow of doubt, no possible doubts whatever regarding his manifest destiny. Since winning the Kansas City junior championship at the age of 16, he had known that his mission in life was to press pursttit of a white ball measuring 1.68 inches in diameter and weighing no more than 1.62 ounces. Preparing for his future, he had won the amateur championships of Missouri and Kansasin the border country of Jesse James, Tom Pendergast and Harry Truman, a man is supposed to vote in only one state but he may play in twohe had been runnerup for the national intercollegiate title and had attended the Professional Golfers' Association's first tryout school for tour candidates.

title: TURKEY'S PREMIER OFFERS TO FILL IN ANY GAP IN NATO
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 22Premier Bulent Ecevit said today that Turkey could compensate for any weaknesses in United States defenses in the Mediterranean caused by Greece's military withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

description: The Department of Performing and Creative Arts at Staten Island Community College will present a sixweek Eugene O'Neill Festival beginning Sept. 18.

title: Four KnifeWielding Thugs Slay A Brooklyn Father of 6 for $7
description: A 39yearold telephone company foreman just back from a Pocono Mountains vacation with his wife and six children was dragged from his rented car by four knifewielding thugs on a dark Brooklyn street early yesterday and stabbed to death in a robbery that netted his killers $7.

title: ROBERT WILDER, WRITER, 73, DIE
description: Robert Wilder, a journalist and publicity man who became the author of a score of popular novels, several of which were adapted for movies, die yesterday in La Jolla, Calif., where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: BUSINESS LOANS UP FOR THE WEEK
description: Business loans increased at New York and Chicago banks in the week ended Wednesday and shortterm interest rates moved up enough to push the prime rate on corporate loans to 12 per centperhaps as soon as this morning.

title: American Medical Obtains 9Million to Expand Abroad
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (Reuters)American Medical International, Inc., said today that it had completed arrangements for $9million in mediumterm European bank credits to be used for overseas expansion.

title: Greek Town Disappointed by U.S. Friends
description: NEA MAKRI, Greece, Aug. 21As the president of this seaside town, Vassilis Tzilavis used to visit the American naval station down the road several times a weekmaybe a sailor had trouble with his landlord, or there was a party celebrating an American holiday.

title: Advertising:A Shift for Winston
description: The longrumored move of the Winston cigarette account finally took place yesterday when the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company picked DancerFitzgeraldSample as its agency.

title: Lawyer in Watergate Suit Slain by Youth in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)  John D. Black, a Washington lawyer who was a member of one of the firms that took part in the Democrats' Watergate civil suit against Republican campaign officials, was shot and killed in an apparent robbery attempt, the police reported today.

title: FORD SIGNS BILL TO AID HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Ford signed the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 at a White House ceremony today and declared, The housing industry needs a shot in the arm and this bill can be extremely helpful.

title: Marijuana Seized
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)Agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration boarded a Lockheed Constellation aircraft today at Winder, Ga., and seized 11,000 pounds of Columbian marijuana valued at $3.3million, it was announced here.

title: Brick Township Patrolman Indicted on Assault Charge
description: TOMS RIVER, Aug. 22 (UPI) The first indictment in an investigation into reports of police brutality in Brick Township was returned today, charging Patrolman Charles Kelly with atrocious assault and battery.

title: Father Accused of Beating His Daughter, 2, to Death
description: A 21yearold Bronx postal worker was charged yesterday with beating his 2yearold daughter to death.

title: Franklin National Lost $65Million in Deposits
description: The Franklin National Bank lost $65million in deposits in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Clearing House Association.

title: Clark Asks End to Politics In Department of Justice
description: Former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark called on President Ford yesterday to depoliticize competely the Justice Department, suggesting that John M. Doar, the House impeachment counsel, would be an ideal man to head the department.

title: 4 Lead Westchester With 67's
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 22 The opening of the Westchester Golf Classic today produced a mob scene at the front of the 150man pack, with four players tied for the lead at 67, five under par, and a dozen tied at 68.

title: Perfection? For These Tasters, It Was Simply Enjoy, Enjoy
description: Although their palates perhaps aren't as educated as those of the Chevaliers du Tastevin, 100 elderly people enjoyed a winetasting experience of their own the other day.

title: Harcourt, Schuster Drop Merger Plan
description: Less than a month after announcing agreement in principle to merge, two major publishers, Harcourt grace Jovanovich, Inc., and Simon & Schuster, Inc., announced termination of their negotiations.

title: WESTINGHOUSE WINS YUGOSLAV CONTRACT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22, (Reuters) The greatest single construction project ever undertaken by an American enterprise in Yugoslavia will be built by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: Jets Plan to Look at Pair Of Untested Rookie Feet
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22When the Jets play the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow night, they will have their two experienced kickers  Bobby Howfield, placekicker, and Julian Fagan, punteravailable together for the first time.

title: Sir Charles Wheeler, 82, the English Sculptor
description: LONDON, Aug. 22  Sir Charles Wheeler, the sculptor, died tonight at his home in Mayfield, Sussex. His age was 82.

title: Bridge: World Champions Can Flout Basic Principles in a Game
description: Students of the game tend to be both surprised and irritated when they find that world chamipons can flout basic principles and get away with it.

title: U.S. Hears Report that Arabs Sought to Bar It From Azores
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The State Department said today that it had received reports that some unidentified Arab nations had offered Portugal $400million to deny the United States the use of the Azores, which served as a refueling point for the American airlift to Israel during last October's ArabIsraeli war.

title: Police Need Shea, Trial Told, to Guard City From Animals
description: Police Officer Thomas Shea was extolled by his lawyer at a departmental hearing yesterday as a good policeman who was needed in hiss job to protect us from the animals who roam the streets of New York.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday it sold one of its memberships for $75,000, unchanged from a sale on Wednesday. Seats are now quoted at $70,000 bid and $100,000 offered.

title: Corporate Profits Advance As Decline in G.N.P. Slows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Corporate profits rose further in the second quarter, even after allowing for the partly artificial element of inventory profits, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WALL ST. DISTRICT LOSING 6 BUILDINGS
description: The Cities Service Company disclosed plans yesterday to demolish six of eight buildings it owns on Wall and Pine Streets and thus leave a vacant tract of more than an acre in the heart of the financial district.

title: Rodino Unit Issues Report Describing Case Against Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The final impeachment report of the House Judiciary Committee was published today, providing for history the official record on which Richard M. Nixon, had he not resigned, would have been brought to trial in the Senate and probably removed from the Presidency.

title: Commack Wins Jr. Hunter Title
description: READINGTON, N. J., Aug. 22Commack, a smartstepping fox chaser owned and handled by Nina Ross of Harrisburg, Pa., won two classes and took two secondPlace ribbons to capture the junior working hunter championship today at the Four Seasons Farm horse show.

title: N.B.A. Votes To Expand Its Playoffs
description: If an agreement can be worked out with the players' association, the National Basketball Association playoffs will take on a new look next April.

title: MOSCOW PRAISES FORD LEADERSHIP
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22  The Communist party newspaper Pravda today made an optimistic assessment of President Ford's first two weeks in office, suggesting that initial Soviet nervousness over Mr. Nixon's suddenideparture was rapidly being assuaged.

title: E. German Swimmers Set 4 Marks
description: VIENNA, Aug. 22, (AP)East German women mounted another attack today on world records at the European swimming championships, setting four more marks in less than an hour. Kornelia Ender, Rosemarie Kother, Renate Vogel and Ulrike Richter carved world records at Vienna's Stadionbad like hungry sharks on the rampage.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Aug. 22, 1974
description: New York690866

title: Morgan Leaves Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP)Tom Morgan resigned today as pitching coach of the California Angels after learning the American League club was not renewing his contract for next season.

title: Dismantling of Health Agency Planned; 2 Other Super Units Face ShakeUp
description: Details of plans to dismantle the Health Services Administration, one of the nine city super agencies created by former Mayor John V. Lindsay, were announced yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: About the Jets ...
description: The Jets have won one of three exhibition games while St. Louis has taken three of four.... In thrashing San Diego, 4814, last week, the Cardinals used many experienced players, while the Chargers, who beat the Jets in suddendeath the week before, played primarily rookies.... The Cardinals will divide tonight's quarterbacking between Jim Hart and Dennis Shaw, whom they acquired from Buffalo in the offseason. Hart, who played for five years under Charley Winner when he coached St. Louis, will be playing in his first game, just as Joe Namath will be.... Donny Anderson also will be seeing his first action, teaming at running back with Ken Willard, who played nine years with San Francisco. Another Cardinal running back is Terry Metcalf, who scored two touchdowns last week  one on a 76yard run and the other on a 45yard pass play from Shaw.

title: White Plains Gambler Freed Without Ransom
description: James Williams, a convicted gambler, was released unharmed yesterday after being kidnapped Tuesday for the second time in two years. No ransom was paid for his release.

title: Bulgaria Releases ExU.N. Economist, Who Goes to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 22  The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced tonight that Dr. Henrich Schpeter, a Bulgarian Jewish economist who had been condemned to death in Bulgaria on an espionage charge, had arrived in Israel today.

title: Jacob Bronowski Is Dead at 66; Leading Popularizer of Science
description: Jacob Bronowski, a leading popular exponent of the philosophical basis of scientific research, and since 1964 a resident fellow of the Salk Institute lin La Jolla, Calif., died after a heart attack yesterday morning in the East Hampton home of friends, where he and his wife were vacationing. He was 66 years old.

title: Howard Puts Skill Into a Special Art: Background Music
description: Reno Sweeney, the West 13th Street supper club, that, in the last year and a half, has established an enviable reputation as an innovative room and a springboard for new talent, has managed a topsyturvy organization of the program it is offering this week and next. In a lineup that includes an opening act, Bruce Roberts, and a headline act, Judith Cohen, the most attractive element is a pianist, Peter Howard, new, to Reno Sweeney, who plays during dinner and before the late show.

title: At Coney IslandKosher Burgers
description: As an Orthodox Jew who grew up in Brooklyn near Coney Island, Joe Bijou was haunted by one smell throughout his adolescencethe aroma of hamburgers, hot dogs and french fries wafting over from Nathan's.

title: FORD AGAIN BACKS RIGHTS PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Ford, who supporter the Equal Rights Amendment when it first came before Congress in 1970 and then backed away the next year, in the face of criticism from his Michigan constituents, returned to a position of ardent support for the amendment today.

title: Richard, Poor Richard Maligned In Memoriam
description: The movement to win forgiveness for King Richard III was penetrated yesterday by a latterday prankster.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Gov. William T. Cahill said Yesterday he would gladly testify at a court hearing that could win a new trial for former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin. On Tuesday, Mr. Sherwin's attorney filed papers asking the Superior Court In Monmouth County for a new trial. The former Secretary of State faces one to two years in jail on conviction for extorting a $10,000 political contribution to the state Republican party.

title: Jet Prototype Tested
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)The Northrop Corporation's second prototype of the world's newest jet fighter, the YF17, has made its first flight test from this Southern California desert base. During a 61minute flight yesterday, the lightweight, twinengine jet reached an altitude of 27,000 feet and a speed of 615 miles art hour. The, YF17 is competing with General Dynamics' YF16 for possible fullscale production by the Air Force.

title: 10 Cases of Brutality to Blacks Reported by Rhodesia Churches
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 22Leaders of the Anglican, Ranan Catholic and Methodist churches of Rhodesia have circulated a report charging members of the Rhodesian security forces with 10 cases of brutality to blacks.

title: Triborough Workers Vote Strike If No Pact Is Won
description: Toll collectors for the Titborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority voted yesterday to walk off the job at 6 A.M. today if a new contract was not reached during a planned allnight negotiating session.

title: SUBWAYS REPORT INCREASE IN FIRES
description: The city's subway system had 52 fires this year that disrupted or momentarily delayed underground service, compared with 42 in the comparable period last year.

title: Women Priests: Episcopal Ordination Controversy
description: Last month, 11 women were ordained to the priesthood in the Episcopal Church in a ceremony that set off waves of controversy in the 3.1millionmember church.

title: Small Town in Maine Calls Rockefellers Neighbors
description: SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22  According to the local gentry, the people who spend their summers here are really quite ordinary folks who do ordinary things in an ordinary way. Neighbors, that's all they are, Mrs. Christie Skillin, the proprietor of the only restaurant around, insisted today We don't think of them any other way.

description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 22  Mom? said 7yearold Phillip Marriott, adjusting the earphones on his headset today at the Westchester Country Club.

description: A group of New York business, labor and civic leaders opened a drive yesterday to increase Federal aid for mass transportation and to save the city's 35cent fare.

title: Week's Auto Output Up 22.3% Despite Some Strikes
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22Strikes kept some auto plants from starting 1975 production this week but output still climbed 22.3 per cent from last week. Domestic auto production was expected to total 105,592 cars compared with 86,351 cars last week, according to the trade paper Automotive News. This week's output will he down 15.1 per cent from the 124,376 in the comparable week a year ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PARLOR GAME Along with the fastfood phenomenon, there's the fast ice cream phenomenon, bringing to New York's streets a variety of outlets for America's favorite frozen dessert. But, alas, most of those outlets are soulless affairs where the service is rushed and the surroundings antiseptic. Now comes a place near Lincoln Center that brings back the flavor of oldfashioned ice cream parlors along with the flavor of the best of commercialbrand ice cream.

title: Quick Action by Byrne Urged to Prevent Collapse of State's Building Industry
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22Two Democratic Assemblymen today called on Governor Byrne to declare a state of emergency in New Jersey's homebuilding crisis and seek stateinsured construction loans to prevent a collapse of the industry.

title: The Object of Their WineTasting Was Absolute Perfection...
description: Looking a bit nervous, four welldressed women gathered in a private dining room off the Rainbow Room the other night. This was their big test. Would they pass? Would their tasting dinner taste all right?

title: Local Fishing Report Shows Blues on the Run
description: AREA AA large variety of fish is available in this area. At Manasquan Ridge, about 15 miles off Barnegat Inlet, blues averaging 10 pounds are responding to oily bait. The Holiday, a party boat owned by Capt. Jack Endean, has been bringing in 300 to 400 blues twice a day. In offshore wrecks, porgies and sea bass have been taken in abundant numbers with clams. The porgies are only a pound average but we ain't seen them for so long, they look like giants, according to a resident of Barnegat. Fluke in the 4to10 pound range are running well at Seaside Park and in Barnegat Inlet, with squid, smelt and spearing the favorite bait. Small blues are reported at Island Beach State Park. Tuna of a wide variety of sizes have been caught at Manasquan Ridge.

title: Suit Filed Against E.P.A. Chief In Move to Halt Sports Complex

title: At the WaldorfClassic Tempura
description: Behind the temple facade and heavy wooden doors that brighten the 49th Street side of the WaldorfAstoria, there is a beautiful new Japanese restaurant called Inagiku. It's hardly an inexpensive place, but four distinctive dining experiences in four distinctively different dining rooms await those who venture inside. For instance, in the Kamakura room (the main dining room), Japanese girls in Samurai kimonos glide silently, serve graciously and cook on tabletop burners in the low, beamedceiling Hida room, which resembles a Japanese farmhouse, master chefs broil food over charcoal. Plates are passed to diners on the end of longhandled paddles.

title: Bond Prices Still Off in Light Trading

description: HARLAN, Ky., Aug. 22  A spirited band of 2,000 union miners and their supporters paraded today through the narrow streets of Harlan without incident in the climax of memorial week, which has shut down most of the nation's mines.

title: Notes on People
description: A Federal Judge in Las Vegas, sharply criticizing the Government's case, said that Meyer Lansky, the ailing reputed underworld figure, may never stand trial on charges of illegally skimming $36million in profits from the Flamingo Hotel. Declining to dismiss charges against the 74yearold Mr. Lansky, United States District Court Judge Roger D. Foley nevertheless ruled that the case will lie dormant on the calendar until either the defendant dies or Government counsel acts responsibly and dismisses the indictment.

title: Bulgarian Film Proves Excellent
description: A movie of extraordinary beauty, so replete with accomplishment on every level  visually, aurally, in its story, its acting and its directionthat it seems almost effortless, is playing at the First Avenue Screening Room today and tomorrow at noon and midnight.Its title is "The Goat's Horn"the object, used as a dagger, that is the most singular weapon employed in this engrossing tale of the perversion of love. "The Goat's Horn" is a Bulgarian film, made two years ago in black and white with English subtitles by Methodi Andonov, one of those increasingly rare film makers, capable of telling a story by pictures alone. "The Goat's Horn" is an eloquent film with little dialogue. Set in 17th-century Bulgaria, it begins with the rape of a young mother by a band of Turks as her little daughter watches in horror.Determined to spare his child her mother's fate, her father, a burly goatherd, takes her to live high in the hills. Telling her there is no place for woman in their world, he shears her hair and raises her as a manskilled in the deadly uses of the staff, the dagger, the blunderbuss. Together, they extract vengeance from the Turks. And then, into her unchanging life, comes a young shepherd and a love that shatters everything.The performances, especially by Katia Paskaleva as the girl and by Anton Gortchev as her unsparing father, are brilliantly expressive.
