title: Steinbrenner Pleads Guilty to Two Counts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company and the principal owner of the New York Yankees, pleaded guilty today to two Federal charges arising from the illegal expenditure of thousands of dollars in corporate funds for both Democratic and Republican political campaigns.

title: Distinctive Role for Rockefeller Is Forecast by Soviet Premier
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 23. (AP) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union praised the new Government of President Ford today and predicted that Nelson A. Rockefeller would not be just another Vice President, a United States official said.

title: Tiant's 20th Fuels Red Sox Flag Fever
description: From the rockstrewn coast of Maine, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the verdant valleys of Vermont, the village greens of rural Connecticut and the industrial cities of Massachusetts, all of New England's fans are rejoicing over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Nixon Fund Inquiry Focuses on Bribery and Tax Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Federal grand jury investigating charges that campaign funds were used for President Nixon's personal benefit is considering allegations that official Government favors were granted in return for some of the contributions, according to papers filed in court this week.

title: Snow Goose Wins Title
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 23Snow Goose, owed and ridden by Sara Sullivan of Dover, Mass., won the American Horse Shows Association's national pony hunter championship today with 767 points at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: Amateur Shares Lead In Women's Golf on 67
description: GOLDEN, Colo., Aug. 23 (AP)Carol Flenniken, an amateur, shot a fiveunderpar 67 today to tie JoAnn Washam for the lead after the first round of the $35,000 National Jewish Hospital Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Argentine Race Canceled
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 (UPI)The International Automobile Sports Commission said today the Argentine 1,000kilometer race at Buenos Aires set for Oct. 21 had been canceled because of an insufficient number of entries.

title: Airline Talks to Resume
description: Contract talks between National Airlines and representatives of 1,600 striking mechanics will resume in Washington next Tuesday, Reuters reported yesterday. Talks were suspended by mediators recently after a stalement developed in peace talks.

title: The New Friendly Ford Place
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The new friendly open White House called up and said to come right over.

title: Mother of 8 Killed in Crash
description: WESTFIELD, N. Y., Aug. 23 (AP)Elvera N. Lindstrom, a 37yearold mother of eight, was killed early today in a collision between her automobile and a tractortrailer truck in front of her home. The police said Mrs. Lindstrom was backing out of her driveway to go to work when the accident occurred.

title: Cuba: Will Ford Act?
description: Will President Ford's fresh approach to longentrenched problems include a willingness to scrap an increasingly bankrupt policy of trying to maintain a Western Hemisphere boycott of Cuba? This question, being asked in nearly every LatinAmerican country, takes on greater timeliness with Panama's decision to restore normal relations with Fidel Castro's government.

title: Mental Patients Recaptured, but Muddle Goes on
description: One of four former inmates of the Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane who escaped from Bronx State Hospital after being transferred there was arrested for burglary while at large and then was sent to a third state hospital without anyone at Bronx State's being told.

title: Democrats Sense Upset By Clark in the Primary
description: Despite the three candidates' campaign efforts, delivered in a gentle Texas drawl, a joyous Jewish accent and the Lindsaylike tone of urban urgency, Democratic politicians are sensing the sort of voter ennui toward the United States Senate primary election that invites an upset.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: DROUGHT IS LIKELY.. TO INCREASE PRICE OF FOOD BY 3 TO 4%.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The drought in the Middle, West, with its impact in smaller crops, means that food prices will continue to rise in the last half of this year instead of leveling off as expected earlier, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: Net Loss of $20.5Million Is Posted by Grolier, Inc.
Millicent Harkness Is Dead; Active in Cancer Society
description: Millicent Pierce Harkness, who had long been active in the American Cancer Society, died Thursday night at Carrotton Hospital in Newton, Conn. She was 68 years old and lived in New York and Southbury, Conn.

title: Market Place: Stock Slip Hits Pension Plans
description: Think of it. The total value of shares of eight of the nation's leading companiesInternational Business Machines, General Motors, General Electric, American Telephone, Avon Products, Polaroid, Xerox and Searsis down a total of $80billion from the highs of 1973.

title: HOME OF CITY AIDE UNDER POLICE GUARD
description: The home of Joseph Christian, chairman of the City Housing Authority, has been under 24hour police guard for the last three weeks because of threats and harassment from neighborhood youths, an authority spokesman said last night.

title: White Homers, Bats in 4 Runs to Lead 104 Spree
description: Again failing to make up any ground on the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees last night at least demonstrated that their recent ability to pound out hits and score runs seemed an authentic talent. They pounded four pitchers for 14 hitseight for extra basesas they defeated the California Angels, 104, in the opener of a threegame series at Shea Stadium.

title: Soviet Soccer Tour Off
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Promoters announced today cancellation of a threematch tour by a Soviet Union soccer team which they say will cost them $250,000. The Russians said the team couldn't come because of a transportation problem. They had no confirmed flight back to Moscow for a scheduled game on Sept. 3.

title: Korean Leader Praised for Easing Curbs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 23president Park Chung Hee won general applause today for lifting two decrees that suppressed political activity, but he faced criticism for his refusal to be lenient toward those imprisoned under the measures.

title: A Slain Girl's Kidneys Are Transplanted Here
description: The kidneys of 13yearold Holly Mottershead of Little Spring, N. J., who died last Tuesday from a gunshot wound allegedly inflicted by her distraught father, were removed to assure someone with serious kidney disease a normal life, a spokesman for Riverivew Hospital in Red Bank, N. J., reported yesterday.

title: Oil Properties Purchased
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 23 (AP)The Government of Trinidad and Tobago has purchased Shell Oil holdings here for $48.8million, Prime Minister Eric Williams announced yesterday.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX.
description: Page

title: Sales of Chain Stores Rose 10.7% in July
Jumping Title To Doc Moon
description: READINGTON, N. J., Aug. 23Karen Petersen spent today dashing between the indoor jumping ring and the outside hunter course and finished with two championships at the closing session of the twoday Four Seasons Horse Show.

title: Jersey Parkway at 20: Safe, Successful
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., Aug. 23The Garden State Parkway, 173 miles of scenically designed highway that has changed the social and economic lives of many New York and New Jersey users, will, observe its 20th anniversary with a major 10day transportation show here, beginning tomorrow.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: F.E.A. TO GIVE FORD 4 ENERGY OPTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23President Ford will not receive a blueprint on Nov. 1 for achieving national independence in energy supplies as originally planned, but instead will be presented by the Federal Energy Administration with at least four options from which to choose.

title: Ethiopian Military Is Urging Austerity
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 23The armed forces, opening an austerity drive, urged Ethiopians in a series of broadcasts today to work harder and to shun alcohol and prostitutes.

title: CABOT CABOT ASKS BIG BOARD INQUIRY
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Cabot Cabot and Forbes Land Trustin a statement resulting from heavy trading in its stock and a price decrease asked the New York Stock Exchange today to investigate.

title: Notes on People
description: The Veterans of Foreign Wars, for the first time in its 75year history, yesterday elected a black to a national leadership position. He is Franklin W. Morton Jr., 54 years old, a New York State Supreme Court justice who sits in Brooklyn, who will be judge advocate general, or chief legal adviser.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The Finance Ministry annouced today a series of measures to ease foreignexchange controls to facilitate an inflow of United States dollars into Tokyo foreignexchange market, effective Monday. The Ministry said nonresidents would now be permitted to acquire shortterm Government bonds and unlisted private bonds and debentures that mature within a year acquisition.

title: A Major Chicago Paper to Close Sept. 13
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22  Chicago Today, one of Chicago's four daily general circulation newspapers, will cease publication on Friday, Sept. 13, it was announced today by Stanton R. Cook, chairman of the Chicago. Tribune Company.

title: Hugo H. Heksoh, 76, Dies; A Founder of Oppenheimer
description: Hugo H. Heksch, who retired in 1963 as a partner in Oppenheimer & Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm, died Thursday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: Communications Device Aids Cerebral Palsy Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The inventor of a number of communication systems for the handicapped was granted a patent this week for one aimed primarily at persans with cerebral palsy, which is marked by muscular incoordination and speech impediments. Haig Kafafian, president and research director of the Cybernetics Research Institute, a nonprofit organization here, received Patent 3,831,147.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 75%
description: The State Labor Department said yesterday that unemployment rose sharply from June to July, jumping from 6.8 to 7.5 per cent in the city and from 6.1 to 6.7 per cent in the state.

title: Wilson and Beame Move to Fight Street Crime
description: Governor Wilson and Mayor Beame directed their top criminal justice advisers yesterday to set up a more coordinated approach to the problem of crime in the street.

title: Pay Increase Sought For Seven Members Of Education Board
description: At Mayor Beame's request, a bill has been introduced in the City Council to pay the seven members of the new Board of Education $115 a day for their services.

title: Film Institute Accepts A Top Aide's Resignation
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23The American Film Institute said today its board of trustees had reaffirmed an earlier decision by the institute's executive committee to accept the resignation of the dean of its Center for Advanced Film Studies, Frank Daniel.

title: DROUGHT IS LIKELY TO INCREASE PRICE OF FOOD BY 3 TO 4%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The drought in the Middle West, with its impact in smaller crops, means that food prices will continue to rise in the last half of this year instead of leveling off as expected earlier, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: PAN AM APPEALS FOR U.S. SUBSIDY TO AVERT CRISES
description: Pan American World Airways formally appealed to the Government yesterday for an emergency $10millionamonth subsidy to stave off the imminent financial crises facing it because of stillclimbing fuel prices and slumping passenger loads. It asked that the payments be retroactive to last April 3.

title: People in Sports
description: Ken Triekey, who put Oral Roberts University on the basketball map by compiling a fiveyear wonlost record of 11823, was named head coach at Iowa State University yesterday. He replaces Maury John, who retired from the Big Eight Conference school because of health reasons.

title: TRIMS IN G.I. BILL OBTAINED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23As far as the new G.I. Bill is concerned, President Ford has succeeded, for the moment at least, in solving one of his problems with inflation and one of his problems with Congress. In addition, he appears to have diverted the anger of Vietnam veterans.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Turkish Government is organizing a major relief and development program for the Turkishoccupied sector of Cyprus whose economic life has been seriously disrupted by the war. The TurkishCypriote minority was economically dependent on the more prosperous GreekCypriote sector, where many TurkishCypriote workers were employed, largely as day, laborers, and where TurkishCypriote farmers sold much of their produce and livestock. [3:56.]

title: Hospital Better Than Willowbrook, and Yet . . .
description: Sixtythree retardates, most of them children and all of them survivors of abuses at the state institution at Willowbrook on Staten Island, are enduring a different kind of neglect in a secluded building on Wards Island to which they were transferred by the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Namath Clicks for Score As Jets Rout Cards, 207
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23The Jets had to be pleased with their winning, 207 effort against the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. After all, Joe Namath made his initial exhibition appearance, he looked reasonably good for his first time out and he was as healthy at the end of his half of play as he was at the start.

title: Newton Fails to Appear at Arraignment
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 23A bench warrant was issued today for the arrest of Huey P. Newton, a founder of the Black Panther party, when he failed to appear for arraignment on charges of assault. Bail of $47,000 was declared forfeited.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 24, 1974

title: Visting Syria Minister Implies Peace Is Linked to Palestinians
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria indicated to Secretary of State Kissinger tonight that peace in the Middle East might depend on recovery by the Palestinians of territory occupied by Israel.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: GLEN RIDGE, Aug. 23A few years ago, Jeff Podesta imagined that he could promote a successful tennis tournament, but felt he might never be able to prove it. Now his future and reputation depend upon his abilities.

title: Israel to Hold Practice CallUp Despite Arab Tensions Over It
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 23 (AP)  A senior Israeli military officer said today that Israel was going ahead with preparations for practice mobilization of many thousands of reservists despite the tensions that the plans for the exercise have produced in the Arab world.

title: 1,500 OffDuty Police Protest Departmental Trial of Shea in '73 Killing
description: More than 1,500 offduly policemen, some of them accompanied by their wives and children, gathered outside Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon to protest a departmental trial against Officer Thomas J. Shea.

title: A Store Rushes to Open a Chemise Boutique
description: The lunchtime shoppers at Saks Fifth Avenue got a taste of fall fashion the other day when the store opened its chemise boutique on the seventh floor.

title: Chain Sales Gain
description: Sales of the nation's leading retail chain stores rose 10.7 per cent in July over the level of July, 1973. The results were better than in June, when the gain was 8.9 percent, but not so strong as in the first five months of the year. Page 34.

title: City Transit Deficit Put at $119Million In Last Half of '73
description: Every day during the last half of 1973, Transit Authority operating losses were more than a halfmillion dollars.

title: Uncertain Trumpet
description: President Ford has thus far sounded only an uncertain trumpet in his war against inflation.

title: Marjorie Peterson Dead; Actress, Singer, Dancer
description: Marjorie Peterson, an actress, singer and dancer who made her New York debut in the Greenwich Village Follies in 1922, died Monday of a heart attack in her apartment at the Wellington Hotel. She was 68 years old.

title: MAYNARD IS FREED IN VILLAGE DEATH
description: The Controversial case against William A. Maynard, who spent six and a half years in prison fighting charges that he shot a Marine sergeant to death in Greenwich Village in 1967, was dismissed in State Supreme Court yesterday at the request of District Attorney Richard H. Kuh.

title: Buildings Already Rising and Projected May Make Rego Park Center of Queens
description: A variety of construction projects, some under way and others on the drawing board, seem likely to transform a 10block area of Rego Park into the downtown in central Queens. These residential and commercial developments pose a serious threat to the city's hopes of making Jamaica the commercial center of the borough.

title: Turks Planning Redevelopment Of Occupied Sector of Cyprus
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 23 The Turkish Government organizing a major relief and development program for the Turkishoccupied sector Cyprus, where economic life has been seriously disrupted by the war.

title: G. M. Planning to Close Danish Assembly Plant
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 23. (UPI)The General Motors Corporation will close down its assembly factory in Copenhagen as of Oct. 18 this year, leaving 750 workers unemployed, a G.M. spokesman said today.

title: ALLEGHANY PLANS TENDER FOR MSL
description: The Allegheny Corporation, a trucking company with diversified financial interests, has been holding discussions with MR Industries, Inc., regarding it tender offer for all of MSL's common stock at about $50 a share, F. M. Kirby, Alleghany's chairman and president, announced yesterday. MSL, an outgrowth of the defunct Minneapolis of St. Louis Railway and now a conglomerate of companies in steel washers and tubing, computer, vending and copying equipment, has a total of 1,136,998 shares outstanding. The value of the acquisition could reach $56.8million if all of the MSL shares are purchased by Alleghany.

title: Rain Kill 4 in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Torrential rain over the last 24 hours has killed at least four persons in shantytowns here. An official said that three persons were killed yesterday when mud and rocks smashed through their dwelling and one man was carried away by flood waters.

title: Mr. Ford's Open Door
description: The cordial meeting between President Ford and members of the Congressional Black Caucus in the Cabinet Room this week was a refreshing departure from the cold and acrimonious exchanges that marked relationships between the White House and the black Representatives in the Nixon years.

title: Farm Loan Plan Ready
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (UPT)The Department of Agriculture announced today that financial assistance for the state's livestock and poultry producers is now available through a new loan guarantee from the Farmers Home Administration.

title: Meat Prices ta Raise Costs of Backyard Barbecues
description: People in the New Yorknorthern New Jersey metropolitan area outside of Connecticut, who will be planning Labor Day barbecues next week, had better go oriental or vegetarian  or at least Southern  in their backyard cuisine.

title: REV. THOMAS AUSTIN
description: The Rev. Brother Thomas Austin, former Provincial of the Marist Brothers and the first American to become an assistant general of the Catholic order, died Aug. 14 in Kobe, Japan. He was 77 years old and had been in Japan for the last 12 years, including 10 as Provincial Visitor.

title: PAUL VILLIARD
description: Paul Villiard, an author of children's books, including a pet series published bye Doubleday, died Sunday at his home in Saxton, N. Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Freedoms Seal Division Crown
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP)Fred Stolle won all four service points in the mixed doubles match tonightto clinch the Philadelphia Freedoms' Eastern Division title in their World Team Tennis playoff with the Pittsburgh Triangles.

title: A FREEZER PIER OPENS IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23Dedication ceremonies were held at the port here today for a new $3million freezer transit terminal, one of the most modern of its kind in the world.

title: Conyers Promises Inquiry it Killing of Michigan Girl
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23 (UPI) Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said that the House Subcommittee on Crime would investigate the slaying of Edith Perchman, a 12yearold Highland Park newspapergirl.

title: No Article
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Music: Relaxed Tashi
description: The chamber ensemble in which Peter Serkin plays the piano, not as leader but as first artist among equals, has been casting around for a name for several years. For a while, the young members considered calling themselves the Earn While You Learn Quartet, a modest suggestion that obviously did not stick, for at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night the group was identified as Tashi. According to one who keeps her ear closer to the underground than does this reviewer, that means good fortune in Tibetan.

title: Japan Air Lines Raising Fares on Three Routes
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI)Fare increases that Japan Air Lines will post for its Asian, Pacific and European routes will be identical with those of competing companies on the same routes, a spokesman for the airline said today.

title: NEW POLICY IS URGED ON MOVING PATIENTS
description: The Community Council of Greater New York urged the State Department of Mental Hygiene yesterday to stop sending elderly mental patients from its institutions into community facilities that lack medical and psychiatric programs.

title: Molly J. Hall Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Molly Josephine Hall, daughter of Georgine, Fleming Freedman and Herbeit Joseph Hall, both of Princeton, N.J., to Charles Herbert Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard W. Levin of Los Angeles, took place in the Princeton University chapel yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Richard Chrisman, a Congregational minister and assistant dean of the chapel, performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: Rockefeller Asserts Nixon Should Not Be Prosecuted
description: SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23 Nelson A. Rockefeller indicated today that he did not feel former President Nixon should be prosecuted.

title: Connors Metreveli Gain at Jersey Net
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 23Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., and Alex Metrevell of the Soviet Union, the No. 1 and 2 seeded players, turned back youthful challengers today and earned quarterfinal victories in the $50,000 MediQuik open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Conyers Promises Inquiry In Killing of Michigan Girl
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23 (UPI) Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said that the House Subcommittee on Crime would investigate the slaying of Edith Perchman, a 12yearold Highland Park newspapergirl.

title: Brifge: Sometimes a Routine Play May Be a Defense Mistake
description: There are some defensive plays that are so straightforward and routine that one tends to snake them from force of habit, even when a little reflection would show that some other course would be more desirable. Forcing the declarer to ruff, or pumping him, is normally a sound move, but it may well hurt the defense in the long run if one defender has a substantial trump holding.

title: John D. Maddox Weds Sara Specht
description: Sara Ann Specht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Specht of Venice, Fla., and Chicago, was married here yesterday evening to John Davies Maddox, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Callahan Maddox of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WOUND WITHIN, America in the Vietnam Years, 19451974. By Alexander Kendrick. 432 pages. Little, Brown. $12.95.

title: Market Plunges 17.83 to Thrust Dow Average Below 700 Level
description: Increasing inflationary pressures sent the stock market into a steep retreat yesterday and dropped the Dow Jones industrial average at the close below the 700 level for the first time in more than four years.

title: AUTO MAKERS HELP WORKER ADDICTS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23 The Big Three automobile companies concerned about increased drinking problems and drug abuses by some of their workers, are conducting, programs to help the employes.

title: People in Sports
description: Ken Trickey, who put Oral Roberts University on the basketball map by compiling a fiveyear wonlost record of 11823, was named head coach at Iowa State University yesterday. He replaces Maury John, who retired from the Big Eight Conference school because of health reasons.

title: 9 Arrested in Drug Raids
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP)The authorities seized an estimated $8.75million worth of heroin and cocaine today, arrested nine persons and broke up a major narcotics Smuggling ring in the Chicago area. In several simultaneous raids, 25 local policemen and Federal and state agents confiscated eightandahalf pounds of Mexican Mud heroin and a halfpound of cocaine, the public information officer of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration reported.

title: YOUTH, 19, CHARGED IN KNIFE SLAYING
description: A 19yearold youth was arraigned on a murder charge in Brooklyn yesterday in the robbery slaying of a father of six children as the police intensified a search for three other. suspects.

title: 2 in Elite Narcotics Unit Charged With Taking Bribe
description: A retired sergeant and a former detectiveonce members of what was the Police Departments elite narcotics investigations unitwere indicted yesterday on charges that they accepted a $3,600 bribe to release a reputed underworld figure picked up during a narcotics transaction in the Bronx. He also was indicted.

title: Barley Gives Bucharest a Taste of Overpopulation
description: SUCHAREST, Aug. 23 There was Margaret Mead, the intrepid anthropologist, tapping her way along the corridors with a Yshaped wooded wand almost as tall as her short, square self and saying that far too much nonsense was being talked in Bucharest. Towering Germaine Greer, her head a mass of wet ringlets from the heat, an intense Betty Friedan and the NonMalthusian Coalition from the third world also weighed in this week at the Population Tribune.

title: 2 LAWYER JAILED AT INDIANS' TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 23United States marshals arrested and jailed two defense attorneys today and used disabling Chemical Mace to remove several spectators from the Federal courtroom at the 7monthold Wounded Knee trial.

title: 2 LAWYERS JAILED AT INDIANS' TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 23United States marshals arrested and jailed two defense attorneys today and used disabling Chemical Mace to remove several spectators from the Federal courtroom at the 7monthold Wounded Knee trial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Federal Judge Morris Luker has rightly decided that changes be made at the Tombs jail or that it be closed. Corrections Commissioner Ben Malcolm's response to that decision is to request a new jail or at least a wholesale refurnishing of the Tombs. And John E. Zucotti, Chairman of the City Planning Commission, has said that renovation would cost $12 to $15 million and a new 600bed jail would cost $37 million.

title: GREECE ACCEPTS SOVIET CYPRUS BID
description: ATHENS, Saturday, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister George Mavros of Greece said today that Greece accepted the Soviet plan for a solution of the Cyprus cribs.

title: RULING ON IUD DEVICE WITH HELD BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) A panel of outside advisers told the Food and Drug Administration today that there was not enough evidence yet to approve or condemn the Dalkon Shield intrauterine device.

title: Stars' Gladietix Cited
description: NEWPORT, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP)Bob Gladieux, a reject from the National Football League, has injected the New York Stars with what he calls a winning factor. As a result, he was named today as the World Football League's Player of the Week. Gladieux scored four touchdowns in the Stars' 4310 victory over Houston Wednesday night.

title: Jim Walter Payout Cut
description: The board of trustees of Jim Walter Investors announced yesterday a 20cent redtiction in its quarterly dividendto 25 cents from 45 centspayable Sept. 30 to shareholders of record Sept. 19.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: AGENCY ACCUSED OF JOB PARTIALITY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Civil Service Commission says it has found evidence of improper political influence over nonpolitical jobs in the Small Business Administration.

title: Jewish Woman in Hijack Plot Is Released From Soviet Prison
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23Silva I. Zalmanson, a Soviet Jewish woman who was serving a 10year sentence for her role in a plot to hijack a Soviet airliner in 1970, was released from prison yesterday, Jewish sources here reported today.

title: GOING OUR Guide
description: KINGS SIZE Outdoor entertainment has been filling the air all summer long at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, but good things all come to a close, and this weekend marks the last time you'll be able to take in the sounds of music and theater at perhaps the greatest example of Brooklyn's civic generosity.

title: CAR SALES RETURN TO SLIPPING TREND
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23  Auto men report many American's are rushing out to buy new 1974 or latemodel used cars now and beat the price increase on the 1975 models. However, new car sales in midAugust were still off 8.1 per cent from last year.

title: Collapse Leaves 800 Britons Stranded in North America
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) Eight hundred British tourists were reported stranded in Canada and the United States today by the collapse of another British travel agency.

title: Contract Awards
description: Dresser Industries, Inc., and Norsk Hydro A. S. of Norway said yesterday they had executed a memorandum of intentions to jointly establish a $50million processing plant near Bodo, Norway, to produce premiumgrade magnesia from seawater and dolomite.

title: Transit Agency Upheld In Tunnel Fire Inquiry
description: The Fire Department's official report on last Tuesday evening's rushhour fire in a Seventh Avenue IRT tunnel finds no fault with how the Transit Authority handled the blaze.

title: Engineering Lags as a Field of Study
description: Despite a growing shortage of college graduates in engineering, which is expected worsen at least until 1977, only a slight increase has been recorded in the number of students entering the field.

title: Unhallowed Soil
description: A few days ago a bottle of inaugural champagne was cracked against a hideous steel leg of the 307foot tower that looms like a giant Tinker Toy over the Gettysburg battlefield and cemetery. Now, for $1.35 a head plus all the candy, Tshirts and junk they can buy at two souvenir stands at the foot and top of the tower, tourists are enticed to get a view described as an educational experience.

title: French Supermarke't Feud Turns Violent
description: PARIS, Aug. 23  Another battle of the supermarket has been fought in France, this one with sticks and stones, and an uneasy truce has settled on the battleground, the small town of Rochefort near the Bay of Biscay.

title: Bishop Said to Report Fatah Blackmail
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 13  The Greek Catholic Archbishop of Jerusalem, who was arrested last. Sunday on charges of smuggling weapons for Palestinian guerrillas, has reported. ly told his interrogators that he had been forced into guerrilla service by threats of blackmail.

title: Ash Hints at Need to Cut SocialProgram Benefits
description: One of President Ford's economic advisers hinted broadly yesterday that the Government would not be able to balance the budget in the next fiscal year without reducing future benefits in some social programs legislated long ago.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLIMB THE LIMIT
description: Soybean and soybean meal futures advanced by the daily permissible limits for the second straight day on the Chicago Board of Trade, spurred by continuing strong export demand.

title: Ash Hints at Need to Cut SocialProgram Benefits
description: One of President Ford's economic advisers hinted broadly yesterday that the Government would not be able to balance the budget in the next fiscal year without reducing future benefits in some social programs legislated long ago.

title: 4 KILLED AS A PLANE CRASHES INTO HOUSE
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI)A pilot, his passenger and two young brothers were killed today when a light plane crashed into a house in which five members of a family were sleeping.

title: The Opium Of the People
description: KONYA, TurkeyThe opium of the people in Turkey is not religion but poritics or, put another way, opium is the politics of the people in terms of an agitated argument with the United States that is not adequately understood by either side.

title: WINE TALK
description: The subject last week, you might reecall, was on how grapes are picked. Which raises the question: Justwhere do all those grapes come from?

title: STEPHEN KEILEY OF GRAND CENTRAL
description: Stephen T. Keiley, the retired manager of Grand Central Terminai, died Thursday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. He was 67 years old anis lived in Cohasser, Mass.

title: Ford Seeking Package Of Economic Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)President Ford is trying to delay any Major economic policy announcements until after his inflation summit this fall, the White House said today.

title: Art: Refreshing Museum Shows
description: The last week in August is to the museum visitor what 4 o'clock in the morning is to the nervous system: the point of maximum weakness. Demoralization lurks. The main staircase at the museum looks to be as high as the Great Pyramid. We cannot find the elevator. The new exhibition fills 104 galleries and the only entrance is a mile from where we stand. The crowds are as big as they were at 8:52 A.M. in Grand Central Terminal in the nineteentwenties. August for the people and their favorite W. H. Auden once wrote, but he had not yet been to Manhattan at the time.

title: S.E.C. Hearing Is Urged On Utilities' Stock Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Justice Department today urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to hold a public hearing on the suspension of rules requiring competitive bidding on the sale of common stock in regulated public utilities.

title: Steinbrenner Pleads Guilty to Two Counts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company and the principal owner of the New York Yankees, pleaded guilty today to two Federal charges arising from the illegal expenditure of thousands of dollars in corporate funds for both Democratic and Republican politibal campaigns.

title: Meat Prices to Raise Costs of Backyard Barbecues
description: People in the New Yorknorthern New Jersey metropolitan area outside of Connecticut, who will be planning Labor Day barbecues next week, had better go oriental or vegetarian  or at least Southern  in their backyard cuisine.

title: Ruffian Sets Stakes Mark At Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y. Aug. 23Ruffian, the wonder filly, showed the 18,878 fans at Saratoga today the qualities that have made her a champion even before the year is threequarters gone.

title: Ford Plans Coast Layoffs
description: MILPITAS, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPJ)The Ford Motor Company announced today that 2,000 employes at its Milpitas assembly plant wold be laid off for 12 days in September and 700 employes will go on definite furlough with the start of production of 1975 models.

title: Douglass, at 66133, Takes Stroke Lead
BreastStroke Mark Set By West German Woman
description: VIENNA, Aug. 23 (AP) Christel Justen of West Germany stole some of the glory from the runaway East Germans today with a world record in the women's 100meter breaststroke at the European swimming championships. It was the 13th world record set in the meet, and was the only women's event so far not won by the East Germans.

title: People and Business
description: Representative Henry S. Reussyesterday called on Treasury Secretary William E.Simon to oppose a sugBested revision of the international monetary structure that would give more power to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Libganda, or Ugibya, if a Match Can Be Made
description: PORTLAOISE, IrelandLibya has twice loved and lost. Everyone who in his pimply youth was cruelly jilted by the teenage queen he adored can only feel comradely sympathy at Libya's gawky proposals and the heartless spurnings she has received.

title: Courageous and Southern Cross Have a Good Day at Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 23 It was a big day for Courageous and Southern Cross in America's Cup racing today. Courageous beat Intrepid twice in the New York Yacht Club's final trials, leaving the loser in trouble with the club's selection committee.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Boston Accused on Rights
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP)An organization of women municipal employes said yesterday that it had filed complaints with state and Federal agencies accusing the City of Boston of sex discrimination. Terry Murray, spokesman for the City Women for Action, told a rally here that the city does not pay women equally with men for doing the same work, that it harasses women filing discrimination complaints and promotes men over qualified women.

title: Bantam/Times to Publish Impeachment Report in Fall
description: Bantam Books announced yesterday that, in cooperation with The New YorkTimes, if would publish the complete final impeachment report of the House Judiciary Committee with an introduction prepared especially for the book by R. W. Apple Jr., political correspondent of The Times.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: The President's Doctor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23He is from Michigan, his wife is from Grand Rapids, and they prefer informality. He played football, and spends his few free hours exercising with his family. Though he has a pool in his backyard, he has a book about building swimming pools on the desk in his office at the White House. He wishes he had more time to golf.

title: First National City Will Keep 12% Rate on Corporate Loans
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday morning at 12 per cent its base interest that it would keep unchanged rate on corporate loans.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A book by Samuel Dash on the impeachment proceedings involving former President Richard M, Nixon is in preparation for publication by Macmillan.

title: Judging Judges
description: Of all the tasks confronting Supreme Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, the state's administrative judge, none is more pressing than the development of standards by which both the quantity and the quality of judicial performance in this state may effectively be judged.

title: Snead's Knee, Arm Have Date With Steelers Tonight
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23Norman Snead will find out in a hurry tomorrow night how far back he has come from knee surgery and one of his most agonizing seasons in pro football.

title: Refugees of Cyprus: How the Rich Live
description: XYLOTYMBOU, Cyprus, Aug. 23In the wake of the Turkish Army offensive, which captured some of the most prosperous towns on Cyprus, many of the welltodo Greek Cypriotes who fled Famagusta have settled their families along roadsides near this town 14 miles from the southeastern port city.

title: Blondie, Dagvvood, Jiggs, Maggie, Us
description: LATTINGTOWN,, N.Y.I have begun asking my husband questions. I ask him what makes planes fly and if the sky is blue. He searches my face to see if I'm asking in fun or if I'm serious, and when he sees I really want an answer he gives it to me in the simplest way.

title: Vietnam Villagers Are Victims of both Sides
description: QUANG NGAI, South Vietnam  Just off the major highways along South Vietnam's central coast, the patterns of Government and Communist control shift and glide and overlap like shadows.

title: O'Dwyer Acts to Save Tweed Building
description: In lastditch effort to save the 102yearold Tweed Courthouse from demolition, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer has won a unanimous recommendation from the New York State Board for Historic Preservation that it be added to the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Dangerous Research and Public Obligation
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N. Y.It is not very often that the world gets treated to two events straight out of science fiction in the same week, but in midJuly genetics managed to wrest some frontpage space from impeachment and inflation.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Friday, August 23, 1974

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Bank Closes in Germany; Sindona Owned Half of It
description: PARIS, Aug. 23  A small West German private bank in which the Italian financier, Michele Sindona, has a half interest closed its doors today raising to four the number of banks that have gone out of business in West Germany in the last two months.

title: ROBERT ASSAGIOLI, PSYCHIATRIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Roberto Assagioli, an Italian psychiatrist who worked with Dr. Carl Jung, died yesterday of pneumonia at his summer home in Capalona, Italy. He was 82 years old.

title: Hospital Better Than Willowbrook, and Yet ...
description: Sixtythree retardates, most of them children and all of them survivors of abuses at the state institution at Willowbrook on Staten Island, are enduring a different kind of neglect in a secluded building on Wards bland to which they were transferred by the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Court Frees Maynard in Village Slaying
description: The controversial case against William A. Maynard, who spent six and a half years in prison fighting charges that he shot a Marine sergeant to death in Greenwich Village in 1967, was dismissed in State Supreme Court yesterday at the request of District Attorney Richard H. Kuh.

title: GEORGE LESTER HUNT
description: George Lester Hunt, a retired Vice president of the New Engand Mutual Life insurance Company, died Tuesday in Camden Me. Where he lived. His age was 85.

title: Dutchess Votes Betting Plan
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 23 (AP)The Dutchess County legislature voted 28 to 4 last night to approve the creation of a MidHudson Offtrack Betting Corporation to serve Dutchess, Putnuam and Westchester Counties. The proposal still must go before legislators in the other two counties.

title: Garden State Parkway Marks 20 Safe Years With Exhibition
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., Aug. 23The Garden State Parkway, 173 miles of scenically designed highway that has changed the social and economic lives of many New York and New Jersey users, will observe its 20th anniversary with a major 10day transportation show here, beginning tomorrow.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 35yearold man charged with murder and assault for the shotgun murder of a motorcycle shop owner pleaded not guilty in Freehold before Superior Court Judge. Thomas L. Yaccarino, who ordered the suspect held without bail. The defendant, William A. Brower of Brick Township, was also charged with wounding two other persons, including an offduty patrolman. He was arrested after he allegedly fired two shot gun blasts at policemen pursuing him. The victim, Charles Rosenstein, 51, was the owner of Stumpy's Motorcycle Shop on Route 35 in Neptune Township.

title: Shaw, Miss Babashoff Swim to Marks
$15Million Asked Of Pepsico in Suits By 2 Distributors
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Two PepsiCola distributors in Windsor, Conn., have filed a pair of antitrust suits in Boston and New Haven against Pepsico, Inc., asking a total of $15million in damages.

title: MACK TRUCKS PLANS TO LIFT PRICES 510%
description: Mack Trucks, Inc, a unit of Signal Companies, Inc., announced yesterday that it would increase prices somewhere, between 5 and 10 per cent, effective. Oct. 1. Henry J. Nave, chairman and president, cited rising costs. Mack raised truck prices by a total of 10 per cent in April and July but the company has lagged the industry on price increases this year, Mr. Nave said.

title: PPG Schedule Layoffs
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 (Reuters)PPG Industries, Inc., citing a drop in orders, announced today layoffs and a temporary plant shutdown in Cumberland, Md. The company is laying off 80 workers at its Cumberland glass plant, effective Sunday.

title: Joseph Durso
description: Dick Williams woke up in New York yesterday as the manager of the California Angels, dropped into the Stage Delicatessen at lunch for a sandwich and ran into Gabe Paul, the man who hired him as manager of the Yankees last winterbefore it was decided that Williams was still the property of the Oakland A's.

title: Miss Nobis Bride Of Thomas Figge
description: Jennifer Anne Nobis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Nobis of Davenport, Iowa, was married there yesterday afternoon to Thomas Kahl Figge, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. O. Figge, also of Davenport. Msgr. Sebastian Menke performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Cathedral. He was assisted by Dean Edward MacBurney of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral.

title: MALAYSIA TO VOTE AMID RACE TENSION
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 23The people of this Southeast Asian country vote tomorrow in a general election whose outcome, while certain, is clouded by the same issue that pervades all of Malaysian life  race.

title: A Greek, on the Monarchy: Who Cares?
description: ATHENS, Aug. 23King Constantine would enhance his chances of returning to the throne of Greece if he agreed to assume a ceremonial role with no political functions. But many Greeksprobably a majorityfeel that a monarchy of any type would be an outdated and useless institution in a modern democratic state.

title: OIL POLICY CHANGE IN BRAZIL OPPOSED
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23Hints that the Brazilian Government is thinking of modifying its tight monopoly of petroleum exploration to admit foreign enterprise have provoked important political opposition.

title: Dr. Antoine Gaudin Dies at 74; Mineral Expert for Atom Bomb
description: Dr. Antoine Gaudin, a mineral engineer who led development of the oreprocessing, techniques that made uranium available for the first atomic bombs during World War II, died yesterday at the Massachusetts General Hospital hi Boston. He was 74 years old.

title: NIXON'S AIDES GET ACCESS TO PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23President Ford's legal counsel agreed today to permit aides to former President Richard M. Nixon to examine papers that they had left behind them at the White House.

title: Rain Can't Keep Golfers From Appointed Rounds
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 23 When the first rumbles of thunder hit the nearly washed  out Westchester Classic today, a young caddie standing outside the pro shop said, They should call 'em in.

title: Hudson County Given the Right To Seek $11,036 Taken in Raid
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (AP)A state appeals court gave Hudson County a new opportunity today to claim $11,036 that law enforcement officials said they had seized from an illegal lottery.

title: A Cup of Wine, A Loaf of Bread and Crowds
description: SONOMA, Calif., Aug. 22Stephen Shoemaker said he had gone into advertising when he left San Jose State College, but three years ago, when he was 24, he decided that it smacked to him of dishonesty so he became a fireman.

title: JOHN P. STACK DIES; OWNED HISTORIC INN
description: John Paul Stack, manager of the Henry Hudson Hotel from 1940 to 1955 and of the Harvard Club from 1963 to 1970, died yesterday at his home in Chatham, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 5.1 From WeekAga Leve
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials fell to 238.6 from 243.7 last week.

title: Pan Am Decline Began With Order for 747's
description: Smiling broadly, Juan T. Trippe, the visionary pilot who in 1927 founded Pan Amerlcan World Airways and built It into a globecircling airline colossus, announced on April 13, 1966, the most exciting decision of his aviation career. Pan Am had just signed an order for 25 models of a new widebodied jetliner called the Boeing 747  that would be more than 2 times larger than any previous jet.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Fans have no fears that two professional football leagues will, dilute playing talent or saturate the television audiences' thirst for action, according to a Louis Harris Poll. On another issue, the National Football League players' strike, more of those polled sided with the players than with owners. Combined with other opinions, the poll concluded that the crisis for owners with the fans these days is real, and foreshadows demands for change in many professional sports.

title: PRICES ON AMEX HIT A 4YEAR LOW
description: The American Stock Exchange posted its eleventh consecutive loss yesterday and closed at its lowest level in more than four years. Prices in the overthecounter market also declined.

title: NIXON'S AIDES GET ACCESS TO PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23President Ford's legal counsel agreed today to permit aides to former President Richard M. Nixon to examine papers that they had left behind them at the White House.

title: BRIDGE OFFICERS REACH AN ACCORD
description: Tentative agreement on a 3month contract headed off strike yesterday against the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

title: NEWS INDEX
Taiwan Will Play For 5th Title Today
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23, (UPI)A Nationalist Chinese team will attempt to capture its fourth straight championship tomorrow when Kao Hsiung, Taiwan, meets Red Bluff, Calif., in the Little League world series.

title: Squaw Valley Developer Hits Financial Problems
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 23 A major Australian property developer will be looking into the sale of land acquired at Squaw Valley, Calif., site of the 1960 Winter Olympic Games, and the liquidation of other American investments after running into severe financial problems.

title: CAREY TAKES TOUR ALONG 5TH AVENUE
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey took his gubernatorial primary campaign to the lunchtime crowds along Fifth Avenue yesterday, joined by former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, whose familiar figure at times threatened to upstage the candidate.

title: Women's Rights: Federal and State Amendments Face Trouble
description: Federal approval of the Equal Rights Amendment, only a few states shy of final ratification, is proving to be an elusive prize for its proponents.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: DelBello Aide Refuses to Resign

title: Slain Police Officer Is Mourned By Hundreds in Queens Church
description: Solemnfaced and fighting back tears, hundreds of policemen and civilians led by Mayor Beame filed past the open coffin of Officer Thomas V. Pegues yesterday at the little brick church in South Jamaica where the young officer had been baptized and married.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 27

title: Braves Tie First Game in 9th, Win It in 10th
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 23The New York Mets opened their fourgame series with the Braves on a dismal note tonight, They let a ninthinning, onerun lead slip away in the opener of a twilightnight doubleheader and lost in the 10th. Then, dociely,, they accepted defeat in the second game.

title: Democrats Sense Upset By Clark in the Primary
description: Despite the three candidates' campaign efforts, delivered in a gentle Texas drawl, a joyous Jewish accent and the Lindsaylike tone of urban urgency, Democratic politicians are sensing the sort of voter ennui toward the United States Senate primary election that invites an upset.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Fans have no fears that two professional football leagues will dilute playing talent or saturate the television audiences' thirst for action, according to a Louis Harris Poll. On another issue, the National Football League players' strike, more of those polled sided with the players than with owners. Combined with other opinions, the poll concluded that the crisis for owners with the fans these days is real, and foreshadows demands for change in many professional sports.

title: PAN AM APPEALS FOR U.S. SUBSIDY TO AVERT CRISES
description: Pan American World Airways formally appealed to the Government yesterday for an emergency $10millionamonth subsidy to stave off the imminent financial crises facing it because of stillclimbing fuel prices and slumping passenger loads. It asked that the payments be retroactive to last April 3.

title: Rockefeller Asserts Nixon Should Not Be Prosecuted
description: SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23 Nelson A. Rockefeller indicated today that he did not feel former President Nixon should be prosecuted.

title: CANDIDATE IS GIVEN DEMOCRACY LABEL
description: John Valean Mahalchik, an independent candidate for Congress in the Sixth Congressional District south of Trenton, has been given the right to run as a member of the Regular Democracy party.

title: Kissinger Assures Greek Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Secretary of State Kissinger told a delegation of Greek Americans today that the United States opposed the partition of Cyprus and was not pursuing a proTurkish policy.

title: Indian Stories
description: The hero of today's teenage fiction often suffers from a double hangup. Not only must he survive psychological and physiological assaults on his emerging selfhood, he is also frequently asked to wrestle with a thornier dilemmathat of being the prototype and spokesman for some embattled minority group. The chief function of the three young Indian protagonists of the stories reviewed here is to serve as grievanceladen couriers for a people deeply wronged.

title: Iran Reports Iraqis Killed 3 In Raip Across the Border
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  Iraqi infiltrators killed three Iranian farmers when they attacked a border village this week, the governmentowned Pars News Agency said today.

title: Parents of Disabled Fear School Change
description: Confusion surrounding a change in the method of providing government tuition aid for severely handicapped New York City children has put many parents of such emotionally disturbed students through a period of agonizing uncertainty.

title: Klein Says Nixon Became Captive of Deceitful Men
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24Richard M, Nixon's personality, his principles and his regard for the American people were distorted early in his Presidency, in the view of Herbert G. Klein, because he allowed himself to become a captive of men whose political creed was compounded of deceit, secrecy and cynicism.

title: Brooklyn School District Will Study Child Abuse
description: Community School District 18 in Brooklyn has been granted $135,496 by the United States Office of Education to conduct an experimental program aimed at reducing child abuse and neglect. The grant was the largest of three awarded on a nationally competitive basis.

title: The Nation
description: As he had done many times before, Representative Peter W. Rodino, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, rose on the House floor and said, Mr. Speaker, I submit a privilege report. In the same barely audible voice he had used on hundreds of similar occasions, Representative Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, responded, This report will be referred to the calendar.

title: Judge Denies an Injunction To Bar Army Gold Search
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 24An Injunction sought by the New Mexico Attorney General to prevent the United States Army from searching for gold at the White Sands Missile Range was denied here this week. Federal officials pledged that the Army had no interest in looking for or gaining the legendary treasure.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Book of Changes
description: The Book of Changes is a great Chinese box of a novel, strewn with conundrums, masks, misleading clues, disintegrating landscapes, false starts, fake quotations, magicians, werewolves, bumbling detectives, severed hands and heads, and a sinister German dwarf who bumps from scene to scene in various disguises, sexes and shapes. Nothing remains intact for long: Men become women or change into screaming woives; women appear in men's boxer shorts; suburban folk under the names of Herbert Hoover, Oscar Wilde and the brothers Marx drift in and out of the novel; even that ingenious puppetmaker and puller of strings, Vladimir Nabokov, shows up briefly. The very title of the novel shifts to The Book of Dillards by R.H.W. Change on a laundryman's list. Behind these transmogrificatinns is a world in which the skin begins to flake away revealing nothing but scaling bone and mold, gray, puffed and swollen, living, dead, decay.

title: On Millionaires' Row, Today's Issues Find An Echo in History
description: Parkside Fifth Avenue, that ribbon of relentless success, exists in a continual state of siege. The first disgruntled denizens were doubtless the squatters displaced by Central Park more than a century ago. The avenue hasn't known a tranquil day since. The lifestyle of one decade has tumbled to accommodate the freshly conceived statusseeking of the next. Presentday problems only echo the past.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Patricia Stern Has Nuptials
description: Patricia Mainwaring Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Anthony Stern of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to David Gordon Clark, son of Mrs. Benn W. Jesser of HoHoKus, N. J., and the late. Thomas R. Clark. The Rev. Bowen Shattuck performed the Episcopal ceremony in the North Shrewsbury (Vt.) Church.

title: George Vecsey
description: Call her Shortstop. She earned her nickname in the fifth grade, competing with the boys in intramurals. Then she taped her nickname on the back of polo shirt and began dreaming of higher competition. This is a time of rising expectations for women athletes, Every evening, the sports news seems to carry an item about a 12yearold girl somewhere who has just been admitted to a youth league. In her first game, the girl hits a solid single and the boys grudgingly admit, She's not so bad, after all.

title: FEDERAL PAY STUDY BACKS HIGHER RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24A survey by the President's Advisory Committee on Federal Pay supports a contention by Government unions that the proposed 5.52 per cent pay rise for Federal whitecollar employes is too small.

title: Kathleen Gross Bride Of Lawrence Roberts
description: Kathleen Terese Gross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gross of Warren, N. J., was married yesterday morning to Lawrence C. Roberts, an assistant state attorney in Florida. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Roberts of Pompano Beach, Fla., and the late, Mr. Roberts.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Catch 65 (by Robert C. Alberts, Aug. 4) only touches on one of the gyps of the Social Security system.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: The Captain's War Is Often Fought Only on Paper
description: The conventional wisdom for the Democratic state primary in two weeks is that it is essentially a captain's war. That is to say, the voter turnout is expected to be low and the support of the Democratic organization and its supposed shock troops, the electiondistrict captains, is vital.

title: On Your Mark ... Get Set ... Steal! Herb Washington Of A's Learns Art of Baseball's 90Foot Dash
description: Herb Washington, A 23yearold bachelor from Flint, Mich., found himself in a strange position one night last April. He was standing at first base in Chicago's White Sox Park, talking to a famous homerun hitter named Dick Allen, who was wearing a first baseman's mitt. Washington, a world class sprinter and football wide receiver at Michigan State, and more recently a sports broadcaster in Lansing, Mich., was wearing one or another of the garish uniforms used by the Oakland A's, for whom he had just entered an American League game as a pinchrunner.

title: Golfers' Wives Keep House on Move And Cheer Mates From Tee to Green
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 24 Some time tomorrow, during the final round of the Westchester Classic, Jerry Heard will search the gallery until he finds a woman named Nancy, whereupon they will exchange an unspoken message. Dave Stockton will probe the thousands of faces until he finds Cathy and their eyes will lock, several times perhaps.

title: Back to City Conference Set
description: National and local preservation groups will sponsor a nationwide fourday conference in the city next month to call attention to the potential for revival of innercity neighborhoods.

title: WILLIAM H. SHEDDEN
description: William H. Shedden, a founder in 1955 and chief executive officer of Rubber and Silicone Products, Inc., of Fairfield, N.J., died on Friday of a heart attack in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J. He was 59 years old and lived at 27 Melrose Drive, Livingston.

title: Salem Is Bewitching Still
description: HER face was fiendlike, full of smiling malice as if an evil spirit possessed the child and had just then peeped forth in mockery. Her mother sometimes wondered fearfully if she had given birth to a freakish imp of evil, and the townspeople bruited it about that the little girl was a demon offspring placed on earth to promote some foul and wicked purpose.

title: Police in Baltimore Offer $50 Bounty To Curb Firearms
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 24The Baltimore Police Department, in an effort to reduce the number of guns in private hands, has initiated a program of offering a $50 bounty to persons turning in firearms.

title: Jet Seized in Texas Is Third Impounded After Use by Vesco
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The seizure of a jet aircraft in Texas marks the third time this year that the authorities have confiscated a plane used by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: Stott Auto Victor
description: SEDALIA, Aug. 24 (AP)Ramo Stott of Keokuk, Iowa, captured a 100mile United States Automoble Club stock car race today at the Missouri Fair in a Plymouth. Ernie Derr, also of Keokuk, was second.

title: Greenburgh ExSupervisor Was Partner of Venders Who Dealt With Town
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y.Cigarette vending machines installed in the Greenburgh Town Hall, Police Headquarters and Town Court during the administration of former Supervisor Nicholas C. Russo belonged to a vending company in which Mr. Russo was an undisclosed partner.

title: Chester Alan Wolfley Weds Heidi Gerber
description: The marriage of Heidi Gerber to Chester Alan Wolfley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Wolfley of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in Darien, Conn. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Gerber of Darien.

title: Tower Against Amnesty For Any Draft Evaders
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 24 (UPI) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, saying he adamantly opposed any form of amnesty for draft evaders, called armed forces deserters creeps last night.

title: The Big Look
description: The unknown is unnerving, which explains why no oneexcept for the fanatic handfulwaits impatiently for a significant fashion change.

title: Richard Cantatore Weds Miss Castellano
description: Linda Castellano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vito J. Castellano of Armonk,. N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Cantatore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas P. Cantatore of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James A. Garrity performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: The Play's the Thing
description: BELLPORTTo everybody except the members of the Poet's Repertory Theater, it was an unusual place for drama. A dining roomeven one where the furniture has been pushed aside to accommodate stage props and audience seatshardly fits the popular concept of playgoing.

title: Sometimes the Important Figures Are Just Memories
description: Economists, financiers, consumer pulsetakers and others who take a professional rather than personal view of money have never doubted its emotional content.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  The Knoll, Suffolk Avenue, Brentwood, L.I. Green, amateurowner, special, baby, junior and children's working hunters; intermediate and junior jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Letters: Portraying History as Pop Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: MICHAEL WEISS: LIVING TOGETHER The kitchen was a gathering place. . . . The living room was where we entertainedourselves and our friends and visitorsbut the kitchen was more often where we lived, and where the visitors to our house who were really comfortable hung out.

title: Allessandroni Wins Predicted Log Test
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 24Hugh Alessandroni, vice commodore of the Eastern Cruiser Association, won the 15th annual Huguenot Yacht Club predictedlog contest today. He took his 35foot Annina over the 32mile course with 1.5693 per cent error.

title: CITY HALTS PLAN FOR PARK THEATER
description: The life of a great idea can be short, especially in New York City, as Richard Grace Jr., president of Theater  in  the Round, Inc., has discovered.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market took another beating last week as prices retreated broadly in somewhat heavier trading.

title: FREED SOVIET JEW SEES JAILED MATE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24A Soviet Jewish woman pardoned two days ago for her role in a plot to seize a Soviet airliner in 1970 was permitted a twohour visit tonight with her husband, who is still serving a 15year sentence for the same offense.

title: Photography
description: THE photographs by Lewis Carroll and Julia Margaret Cameron which are in the current exhibit at the Scott Elliot Gallery share multiple connections. Some are obvious; both were eminent Victorians, amateurs (in the best sense of the word) as photographers because they could afford not to be professionals. They had friends in common and photographed some of the same peopleand there is even a gravely gentle portrait of Mrs. Cameron with her children which was made by Carroll.

title: U.S. Rider Leads
description: OSBERTON, England, Aug. 24 (AP)Bruce Davidson of Westport, Conn., held the lead today at the end of the first event of a twoday equestrian competition. Davidson, riding Irish Cap, had 19 faults.

title: Dallas to Vote on Proposal For 1 % Tax on Commuters
description: DALLAS, Aug. 24  This could become the first city in the South to levy an earnings tax on commuters from bedroom communities, provided voters overwhelmingly endorse the idea next month.

title: Second DynamiteRuse Robber Slain in East 5.9th Street Bank
description: A man carrying a valise that he said was filled with 12 sticks of dynamite was shot and killed by a police officer here yesterday as he tried to imitate last Monday's bank robbery in which the holdup man made off with $157,000.

title: THIRD CABLE LINK TO HAWAII FINISHED
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 24The cable ship Long. Lines completed the last link of a $70million undersea telecommunications system connecting Hawaii with California when she anchored off the surfing beach at Makaha.

title: Who Makes Music and Where

title: About words about words
description: Whether you know it or not, you are bilingual. Everyone who has made it at least through high school uses two languagesboth of them English. They are not vastly different, yet they are distinct. One is spoken English, often colorful, cigar in its intended emphasis and assisted by facial expression, tone and gestures. The other is written English.

title: Farm Exemption Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Senate has adopted a proposal by Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, to exempt $200,000 of the value of a family farm from the Federal estate tax. The present exemption is $60,000, applying to all estates.

title: The Eye of Conscience
description: Reading this book is a little like those times in school when you went in for a session with the guidance counselor: the man meant well, but the points he made, even about important things, were so predictable, and the terms he used were so solemn, and he repeated himself so much, that you were never sure, by the end, whether you were more bored or more annoyed with him. Like the guidance counselor's, the language in The Eye of Conscience isn't the kind that's geared for having fresh perceptions, or even for presenting old perceptions in a lively way. It's a shame everything is so smothered, because the book presents good subjects for its audience: how photography helps affect social change, or mirrors social problems, and how the camera, when used daily and continually, is an instrument that tells us about our instincts and feelings.

title: Pop Stevie Wonder and John Denver  A Study in Contrasts
description: No two recording artists could be farther apart in style and sensitility than Stevie Wonder and John Denver. The former creates music fired by the passions of urban America today while the latter makes music inspired by visions of a pastoral America, long gone. Yet both Denver's Back Home Again (RCA CPL10548) and Wonder's Fulfillingness'First Finale (Tamla T6332S1) have recently ascended the popularity charts with astonishing speed. The fact that two such different singers are both guaranteed million selling albums indicates the diversity of taste in the rock audience today. But while Denver is as interesting as a greeting card, Wonder proves that it is possible to be commercial without selling out.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The practice of parapsychology has long been vulnerable to frauds and opportunists, and just as it seemed to be making solid headway toward scientific acceptability, it has been hit by a scandal involving fakery by a leading researcher.

A disco dance record with wailing electric guitars and a chunky backbeat might have originated in New York or Lagos. The producer who goes to Muscle Shoals to record his rhythm tracks, to Memphis for horns, to Miami for strings, and to London for lead vocals is no longer eccentric.

title: Gulag and the Men of Peace
description: Last winter Alexander Solzhenitsyn's The Gulag Archipelago was published in Paris in Russian, and appeared in the bookshops of the Westincluding two Swiss bookshops long licensed to sell on United Nations premises in the Palais des Nations at Geneva. The DirectorGeneral of the United Nations Geneva office, clandestinely acting at the instigation of the Soviet Government, promptly caused the book to be removed from the Palais shelves, along with Solzhenitsyn's other works. Shortly thereafter, one of the bookshops  Messrs. Payot  closed. At the surviving establishment, that of Navine & Co., the subsequent English and French editions of The Gulag Archipelago likewise briefly surfaced and submerged.

title: Encounter: A Veiled Stranger in the Mosque
description: MOST of the passengers on the bus from Teheran to Iran's holy city of Mashed were Shritte, Moslems on the annual pilgrimage to the site where their prophet Immam Reza had met a martyr's death eleven centuries before. But I had made a friend, an Englishspeaking history professor returning home to Mashed from a family visit. Gray, balding and paunchy, he wore thick glasses and spoke in deferential, soft tones. In response to his questions, I explained that I was on my way to New Delhi to work on an educational television project. I had traveled with friends by car to Istanbul; from there the bus route seemed the best way to absorb everything I wanted to see.

title: Red Smith The Road Back to Du Quoin
description: As a driver, someone has said, Stanley Dancer is driven. Yet fame is not the spur, nor pride, nor lust for gain. The quiet man from New Egypt, N. J. savored long ago all the rewards his world of harness racing has to offer, but he cannot rest. For years he has lived with pain. Last fall he underwent spinal surgery, and a heart attack followed the operation. Still he could not stop. Nevele Diamond wouldn't let him, and won't let him now. Nevele Diamond is a trotter that may win the Hambletonian Stakes next Wednesday. Whether he does or not, Stanley Dancer will be in the sulky behind him when the field goes away in Du Quoin, Ill.

One can try to make history more vital by inventing a dramatic form to cover a failure to illuminate the meaning of events.

title: Book Ends
description: Teddy Bared. Although drowned out by the Watergate din, there are signs that Chappaquiddick has been quietly ticking away all this time. During a program covering President Nixon's resignation N.B.C. reporter Edwin Newman brought it up, saying that viewers kept asking, What about Chappaquiddick? The issue of The New York Times Magazine containing an article on the death of Mary Jo Kopechne in Senator Edward Kennedy's black Oldsmobile in the waters.beneath Dyke Bridge is a surprise best seller at The Times's back copy department. Another indicator of continued interest in the case was the appearance of a book called Teddy Bare, by Zad Rust, on the most recent Trade Paperback Best Seller List. Teddy Bare, which purports to tell the true story of Chappaquiddick, was first published in 1971 and has kept selling and selling. The publishers, Western Islands in Belmont, Mass., report that sales have increased markedly in the past few months, especially in California, where it exploded after former Los Angeles Mayor Sam Yorty mentioned it on his radio show in June. All told, the company said, 400,000 copies have been sold. Asked if it was selling largely in Massachusetts, Elaine Bechtel, an editorial assistant, replied, It largely isn't selling in Massachusetts. That's Kennedy country.

Then the sun rises and the whole filmy curtain begins to lift.
