title: OKLAHOMA'S HEAD PREDICTS VICTORY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 24 Oklahoma's Governor, David Hall, predicted this weekend that he would lead the ticket in Tuesday's Democratic primary despite polls showing him running third.

title: Henry Hornblower 3d to Wed Patricia Bandler on Sept. 28
description: Mr, and Mrs. Richard Bandler of Katonah, N. Y., and Montego Bay, Jamaica, have announced the engagement of Mr, Bandler's daughter, Patricia Bandler, to Henry Hornblower 3d, son of Mrs, Edward P. Durfee of Milford, N. H., and Mr. Hornblower 2d of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: In Saigon, Homeless Children May Find Themselves in Jail
description: SAIGON, South VietnamThere are prison ells in South Vietnam that are filled with children.

title: News of the Camera World
description: REGISTRATION is now going on at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street, New York, N. Y. 10010, for a series of, 21 evening courses in photography and 14 courses in film and video production. Each class will. meet from 6:40 to 9:40 P.M., with the term to begin on Sept. 18.

title: Good sense at 24
description: Most people have a skeleton or two in their closets. Sometimes more. Fashion skeletons; that is. But not Katy Kiarnet King, a young woman who has her foot on the first (or possibly second) rung of thecareer ladder. Hers is advertising.

title: The Tartar's Sword
description: The Tartar's Sword is solidly in the bookwithamoral school of writing for the young audience. Mr. Kimmel is an assistant professor of Language Arts and Children's Books at Indiana University with a special interest in the influence children's books have on the values of youth, and it shows. His concern, while laudable, tends to get in the way. It is too bad, for Mr. Kimmel has a good story to tell with a nice feel for the traditionally structured historical novel.

title: Whatever happened to Father?
description: In the last generation, the position of theAmerican father has begun to pale, to fade into the background of our society and our family life. He is still there, above the children and slightly to one side of the mother (is he still a little above?) but his figure begins to dissolve among other kaleidoscopic changes in the pattern.

title: Not in the civics textbook
description: How Your Local Politicians Work, Why Your Government Doesn't and What You Can Do About It. By Bill and Nancy Boyarsky. 330 pp. Los Angeles: J. P. Tarcher. $8.95.

title: Clare Drury Is Married to Paul J. Hudson
description: Clare Drury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Dray of Atlanta, was married yesterday afternoon to Piaui J. Hudson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hudson of West Nyack, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Emory Presbyterian Church in Atlanta by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McMullen Jr.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Bronx grocer, despite being shot in the arm during a robbery at his store in the Morrisania section, managed to grab a pistol and hold three of four young suspects until authorities arrived, the police reported.

title: ALFRED KANFER, GRAPHOLOGIST 72
description: Alfred Kanfer, a graphologist whose handwriting test for Incipient cancer is being evaluated by medical institutions, died Friday in the New York Infirmary. He was 72 years old and lived at 62 Leroy Street.

title: A.E.C. Penalizes Few Nuclear Facilities Despite Thousands of Safety Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Atomic Energy Commission regularly uncovers safety violations in more than one of three of the facilities it inspects but imposes a penalty in only a small fraction of even the most serious of these cases, commission records glow.

title: Suzanne Freeman Bride of a Banker
description: Suzanne Thorpe Freeman and Richard Shaw Minturn were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Douglas M. Morrill performed the ceremony in St. Mary's bytheSea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me., assisted by the Rev. Arthur Foote, a retired Unitarian minister.

title: Johnson Statue Unveiled
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Aug. 24 (AP)A largerthanlife statue of Lyndon B. Johnson was unveiled today at the LBJ State Park near here. Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, and the former President's widow, Lady Bird Johnson, unveiled the eight foot bronze statue, which was carved by Jimilu Mason.

title: Nation's Highway Death Toll For July Found Off by 16%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 241 (UPI)Despite heavy summer vacation driving, the highway death toll for July dropped by 16 per centthe ninth consecutive monthly decline.

title: Dancing in the White House But, Still, a LetDown Feeling
description: WASHINGTONA few days after the change Presidents, Mike Mansfield, the durable Senate Majority Leader who is known for understatement, said to a colleague, for the, first time In months. am sleeping well.

title: Safer Pensions
description: The long march toward a law that would establish Federal safeguards to take the heartbreak out of private pension programs has finally achieved firstrung success. The pension reform bill, passed by both houses of Congress and now awaiting signature by President Ford, falls far short of perfection. But it does provide a governmental reinsurance fund designed to remove the risk that promised pension protection will evaporate because an employer goes bankrupt or closes his plant.

title: . . . and a Plan for Sharing
description: The scheme recently agreed on in Brussels by the highlevel Energy Coordinating Group (E.C.G.) of the twelve major oilimporting nations, based on an Americanproposed Integrated Emergency Program, calls for a buildup of oil stocks for use, should there be another embargo or similar crisis. Meanwhile, conservation measures, added to present high prices and business recession, are expected to keep demand down. Production now is rising and an oil surplus, which already is developing, could start prices moving down. However, Kuwait and Venezuela have announced their intention to cut back oil production as a means of keeping prices up, and others may follow suit.

title: Diabetes Research
description: The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation has begun a $2million fundraising campaign for 197475 to be used for education and research in diabetes, according to Ellen Furman, president of the foundation's New York chapter.

title: Economic Trouble of Western Lands Is Deepened by Their Interdependence
description: PARIS, Aug. 25The economic gloom is deepening in Western nations as stock markets crumble, bankruptcies rise, inflation rages and unemployment climbs toward what many fear will be unacceptably high levels this winter.

title: Carmen V. Freda, Builder, Served Jersey G.O.P. Unit
description: SEA ISLE CITY, N. J., Aug. 25 (AP)  Carmen V. Freda, a resort builder who was active in Republican politics, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 52 years old.

title: Haller, Heart of Tigers' Bull Pen, Wins 15th Game
description: During the offseason, the speculation was that John Hiller Could not duplicate his feat of last season, when he established a major league record of 38 saves. Even the Detroit Tiger lefthander agreed, especially after a rule change made it more difficult for a pitcher to be credited with a save. He must now face the potential tying run at the plate or pitch a minimum of three full innings before he can be awarded a save. Also, there was the law of averages for him to contend with.

title: Ship Knocks Down Bridge And Closes Welland Canal
description: PORT ROBINSON, Ontario, Aug. 25 (AP)  A freighter rammed a lift bridge on the Welland Canal today, sending the bridge plunging into the water and blocking the canal.

title: Feminism and Scholarship
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.A new wrinkle has appeared on the face of the women's liberation movement: How does a contemporary feminist orientation affect scholarship?

title: A Swinger in His Own Groove John Laurence Miller
description: HARRISON, N, Y., Aug. 25 Johnny Miller, who won the Westchester Golf Classic today, is an embarrassment to the other pros on the circuit, and he admits it. Not because he won $50,000 or leads everybody this season with earnings of $255,383 or because he broke the tournament record at the Westchester Country Club with a fourround total of 269, 19 under par, or even because he became just the fifth player in the last two decades to win six or more tourneys in one year.

title: Ozawa Plumbs Depths of Gurrelieder
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 25Arnold Schoenberg's massive, dentate, Gurrelieder, is the Moby Dick of music, a legendary monster often discussed but rarely encountered.

title: Postgraduate Programs In Clinical Psychology Set
description: The New School for Social Research and the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health have established new master's and doctoral programs in clinical psychology that will admit their first students this fall.

title: Spain and Morocco Clash Over Sahara
description: MADRID, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Spaniiih Sahara, is an arid desert colony on the northwest cdast of Africa. But beneath, its uninviting surface lies vast mineral wealth and squabbles over Ownership have now led to a bitter dispute.

title: Flea Market's First 2 Days Busy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 25 A decaying twoblock area, that was a shopping hub at the turn of the century, bustled with business, activity today as several, thousand New Jersey residents, jammed sidewalk stalls on a bargainhunting spree.

title: BLACK LAG FOUND IN COLLEGE ROLLS
description: A report released yesterday under the sponsorship of the Ford Foundation concludes that, despite large gains during the nineteensixties, the number of blacks enrolled in colleges and universities remained substantially lower than the black percentage of the population.

title: 10 Drown in Java Sea
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Ten people were drowned when a small boat carrying 20 passengers sank in heavy seas near Madura Island, some 500 miles northeast of Jakarata, in the Java Sea, Antara News Agency reported today.

title: Demagogy in Bucharest
description: Approximately onequarter of all the people who have ever lived on this planet are alive today. That dramatic statistic was invoked last fall by Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, in a message proclaiming 1974 as World Population Year. The human race has doubled its numbers in the last fifty years and, at present growth rates, should double them again in the next thirty.

title: Road Back to Paris
description: I had thought of the whole war as a road back to Paris, and now that I was on the real one, I momentarily felt let down. The car barely crept; I might as well have been riding home to Manhattan on a Sunday night from a weekend in Norwalk. After we got through Longjumeau, though, we made better time, and then, as we approached the Porte d'Orlans, we began to meet cyclists coming out of the city to greet us.

title: Maine Dam Project Sparks New Debate
description: DICKEY, Me., Aug. 25They are talking about building a dam larger than the Aswan Dam in Egypt here on the St. John River in the northernmost part of Maine, where the pavement ends and the roads become dirt logging trails leading into thousands of miles of forest in the Allagash wilderness.

title: Springer Spaniel Judged Best In Field of 3,162 at Ohio Show
description: CHAGRIN, FALLS, Ohio, Aug. 25A liverandwhite English springer spaniel, Ch. Salilyn's Classic, following in the paw prints of his grandsire, Ch. Salilyn's Aristrocrat, was named best of 3,162 dogs at the Chagrin Valley Kennel Club show today. It was Classic's third top award in eight days and his 13th over all.

title: World Team Tennis
description: SUNDAY'S CHAMPIONSHIP PLAYOFF Denver 27, Philadelphia 21

title: The Change in Presidents: Plans Began Months Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Planning for the orderly elevation of Gerald R. Ford to the Presidency began months before President Nixon decided to resign. The preparations were kept secret from Mr. Nixon and, at first, from Mr. Ford.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his inaugural address President Ford emphasized the goal of maintaining America's strength in world affairs at least as heavily as the goal of damping domestic inflation.

title: Mets' Southpaw Allows 5 Hits, Bats In Run
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 25  Ray Sadecki, the southpaw who ordinarily is a bullpen tenant, turned in a fullgame performance today against the Braves that had his Met teammates marveling.

title: Third Road Cycling Title, to Merckx
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (UPI)Eddie Merckx of Belgium won his third world professional road race, edging Raymond Poulidor of France at the finish line of the final event at the cycling championships. Mariano Martinez was third. More than 150,000 spectators cheered wildly as Merckx started his final sprint in the straight to overtake the 38yearold Poulidor.

title: 2 Shadotus Break Down, Patrick Wins in CanAm
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 25 (AP)Scooter Patrick of Lomita, Calif., was the surprise winner today when mechanical problems sidelined the heavily favored Shadow team of George Follmer and Jackie Oliver in a Canadian  American Challenge Cup race at Road America.

title: Giant Attack Continues to Be Offensive to No One
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers' 177 victory over the New York Giants on Saturday night again showed that the Steelers have enough talent and muscle to reach the Super Bowl.

title: Physician, Hail Thyself
description: WASHINGTONShould doctors and lawyers advertise?

title: Miller Wins Westchester Golf
description: HARRISON, N.Y. Aug. 25, The others made brief runs at him, but the outcome was never in doubt and it was Johnny Miller all the way.

title: Berry Paces 3213 Victory For Vikings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 25 (UPI)  Bob Berry threw two thirdquarter touchdown passes to lead the Minnesota Vikings to a 3213 National Football League exhibition victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight. It was the Vikings' first victory in three games. They held O. J. Simpson of Buffalo to 18 yards rushing in seven carries.

title: Grayson Predicts Some Price Rises Under New Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The man who was in charge of the mandatory price control machinery tried by the Nixon Administration said today that the voluntary approach being advocated by President Ford. would in some cases lead to higher rather than lower prices.

title: AARON DANIELS
description: Aaron Daniels, founder and president of the Miss America Loungewear Corporation and Miss Hollywood Loungewean Company, Inc., died Saturday in University Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: 3 Killed in Copter Crash
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 25 (UPI)A couple from Georgia died yesterday when the helicopter in which they were sightseeing caught fire and plunged into the ocean. The pilot also died. The victims were identified as Mr. and Mrs. Robert Overman of Milledgeville, Ga., and the pilot, John Hig of Daytona Beach.

title: Nettles Single in 9th Sinks Angels, 21 Gura Victor
description: Catching Nolan Ryan on a day in which his overpowering fastball was on holiday, the Yankees finally made an upward move in the American League Eastern Division pennant race with a tidy 21 victory over the California Angels before a crowd of 17,745 yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Bridge: A Fib During the BiddingCan Sometimes End Happily.
description: The Munchausens of the bridge world are seldom successful. If you make a, habit of telling big lies in the bidding, your partner will often be e d eceived and your opponents quite uite rarely. But a small deviation from the path of orthodox rectitude, can sometimes bring good results.

title: California Board Is Challenged By F. T. C. on Milk Commercials
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 The state of California and a Federal agency have come into conflict over television commercials for milk that have been seen for the last two years by viewers in this state as well as Oregon and Washington and parts of Arizona and Nevada.

title: Tool Orders for July Up By 33% From '73 Month
description: New orders for machine tools were relatively steady last month, totaling 244.25million, compared with $244.2million in June. July orders, on the other hand, showed a 33 per cent increase from the same month a year ago, according to the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Ethiopians Say Palace Of Emperor Is People's
description: ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 25, (Reuters)  The Ethiopian Armed Forces Committee announced today that Emperor Haile Selassie's residence, the Jubilee Palace, had been nationalized and now belonged to the people.

title: Road Back to Paris
description: I had thought of the whole war as a road back to Paris, and now that I was on the real one, I momentarily felt let down. The car barely crept; I might as well have been riding home to Manhattan on a Sunday night from a weekend in Norwalk. After we got through Longjumeau, though, we made better time, and then, as we approached the Porte d'Orlans, we began to meet cyclists coming out of the city to greet us.

title: Sandra Haynie Wins by Stroke
description: GOLDEN, Colo., Aug. 25 (UPI)  Sandra Haynie, enjoying the most successful year of her career, shot birdies on the final two holes today in a rally that won the $35,000 National Jewish Hospital open golf tournament.

title: Red Smith
description: Mike Royko, the gifted columnist of The Chicago Daily News, seems to have succumbed to a condition endemic in his village, known as the Second City Syndrome, a municipal state of mind that besets all 3,369,359 inhabitants at any mention of New York, oral or printed. It is marked by the sort of hyperactive defense mechanism that caused the late Col. Bertie McCormick of The Chicago Tribune to have Cook County changed briefly from Central to Eastern time so Sandburg's City of the Big Shoulders wouldn't tag along an hour behind Manhattan, the same mechanism that prompts cab drivers in the Loop to advise visitors that the Sears Tower is exactly 204 feet taller than the Empite State Building. Doctors think the Cubs or White Sox might ease this civic inferiority complex, but they don't.

title: Malaysia Government Sweeps Elections
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 25Prime Minister Abdul Razak and his National Front coalition Government won a striking victory in yesterday's national election, but the landslide did not remove racialism from Malaysia's political life.

title: World Team Tennis
description: SUNDAY'S CHAMPIONSHIP PLAYOFF

title: GREEKS TO STAT CONFERENCE Al
description: ATHENS, Aug. 25Gre will tell the Soviet Union morrow that any internati conference on Cyprus must centrate on finding ways means to carry out Secu Council resolutions calling the removal of foreign tro from the island, according authoritative Greek sources.

title: QUEBEC CRITICIZED ON LANGUAGE LAW
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 24Quebec's new language law, which has been the subject of bitter controversy here, is also increasingly attracting opposition across Canada's nine other provinces.

title: Peter Houghton Beats His Father In $150,000 Trot
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (UPI) Armbro Omaha, with Peter Houghton in the sulky, won the $150,000 Prix d'Et trot at Blue oBnnet Raceway to day.

title: War Evaders' Parents Favor Total Amnesty
description: At the time their sons went into exile or hiding, some parents thought they were wrong. Today, although few deserters and draft dodgers have had second thoughts about their decisions, many of their parents have.

title: About New York
description: New Yorkers are a mobile lot, moving to the dictates of Chance. Time was everyone moved in October, to a betterplace if fortune had smiled, to cheaper digs if there had been reversals. Sometimes they moved because the rent was due and could not be Paid. It's a town with itchy feet.

title: Australians and Bernstein Hit It Off
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 25Leonard Bernstein walked off the stage of the concert hall at tthe Opera House and fell into the arms of a member of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra in a state of mock collapse.

title: Liberated 30 Years French Family Prospers but Grieves
description: PARIS, Aug. 25When Melvin Stock of Pittsburgh liberated Bivre, a village on the southwestern outskirts of Paris on Aug. 25, 1944, Georges No was there to snap his picture in front of the pharmacy on the main square.

title: Saigon Gives Up Another Coastal Post
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Manday, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Government forces gave up another position near the central coast of South Vietnam yesterday and elsewhere, 15 civilians were killed and 58 wounded when Communist gunners fired mortar shells into a crowded market place, the Saigon command reported today.

title: LEADER OF CYPRUS WARNS THE TURKS OF GUERRILLA WAR
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 25President Glafkos Clerides warned today that continued Turkish occupation of areas of Cyprus formerly controlled by the Greek community might lead to guerrilla warfare against the Turks.

title: LIGHTNING KILLS MAN, DAUGHTER
description: Lightning struck two members of a Morris County family vacationing in Maine over the Fweekend, instantly killing the father, 38yearold John C. VanCleve, and his 9yearold daughtter, Elizabeth.

title: 3 Convicts in Killing Wave Flee Into Forest in Texas
description: STEPHENVILLE, Tex., Aug. 25 (UPI)Three escaped convicts disappeared today into mesquite forests in northern Texas while hundreds of lawmen moved in to end a threeday swath of killings and random violence.

title: French Detonate Another ABomb In South Pacific
description: PARIS, Aug. 25Frande exploded another nuclear device in the South Pacific today, the seventh in a controversial series of atmospheric tests that began June 16.

title: A Passaic Girl, 14, Is Stranded but Safe on Cyprus
description: YIALOUSA, Cyprus, Aug., 25 (AP)Lucy Savvides, who is 14 years old and is stuck in this village behind the Turkish lines, just wants to go home tot Passaic, N.J.

title: Samuels Presents First TV Ads Since Nomination
description: Howard J. Samuels yesterday began a twoweek $150,000 schedule of television commercials that will continue until Primary Day, Sept. 10, The Samuels television commercials, his first since, the Democratic gubernato rial campaign started early this year, were viewed by politicians as another signal that his lead over Representative Hugh Carey of Brooklyn, was getting smaller. A top Samuels aide conceded that we don't want to take any chances.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DU QUOIN, Ill. Aug, 25 (AP)The largest field in 11 years met today's entry deadline for the Hambletonian Stakes, harness racing's premier event. The entry of 22 trotters  two fillies, one gelding and 19 coltsforces the race Wednesday into divisions for the first time since 1957, when 21 trotters competed. The Hambletonian had its largest field in 1953 with 23 entries.

title: ARAMS ENDORSES CAREY, WHO GIVES RETURN SUPPORT
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, who is widely regarded as the frontrunner for the Democratic nomination for Attorney General, endorsed Representative Hugh L. Carey for Governor yesterday and was endorsed by him in return.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Man Dies in Bronx IRT Subway Fall

title: This Is No Puzzle for Cryptanalysts., But Read On for a Test of YOUR Wits
description: Clue: In this article, which pertains to the annual meeting of the American Cryptogram Association that ended yesterday after three days of ciphersmashing, there is a hidden message. It is, however, not much of a message.

title: Downtrodden of India Burst Angrily Into Literature
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25A wave of angry writing by impoverished and lowcaste authors has burst across the literary landscape of India.

title: The Change in Presidents: Plans Began Months Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Planning for the orderly elevation of Gerald R. Ford to the Presidency began months before President Nixon decided to resign. The preparations were kept secret from Mr. Nixon and, at first, from Mr. Ford.

title: 4 on Bus Injured in Skid
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP)A Transport of New Jersey bus bound for New York City from Newark skidded on the rainslick New Jersey Turnpike this evening and came to rest in a ditch beside the highway. The State police said four or five passengers were treated for minor injuries at North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken. About 35 were aboard.

title: Rabin's Cabinet Agrees To His Meeting Ford
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 Premier Yitzhak Rabin's mission to meet President Ford in Washington in the first half of September was approved unanimously today by the Cabinet at its weekly meeting in Jerusalem.

title: De Seversky, 80, Dies
description: Alexander P. de Seversky, a zealous proponent of strategic air power whose inventions were major contributions to military and civil aviation, died at the age of 80. Page 32.

title: ALEXANDER OPENS ATTACK ON CLARK
description: Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse, contending that he has become the underdog in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination, began a new tack yesterday, directly attacking the man he regards as the frontrunner, former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark.

title: AMTRAK GROWTH SOUGHT BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The bill passed by the Senate for the improvement of Amtrak, the national, rail passenger system, provides major incentives to the states to begin regional Amtrak services.

title: The Horses Return Today Stymie at Belmont
description: Thoroughbred racing returns to the local area today after a fourweek run at Saratoga, N.Y. Belmont Park opens a 42day meeting that will extend through Oct. 12. The 18th running of the $28,100 Stymie Handicap features today's card. Billy Come Lately, 21 in bees Boy, who were at Saratoga but failed to race there, figure to be the favorites. They both last raced duly 13 at Monmouth Park in the Haskell Handicap, in which Arbees Boy finished fourth and Billy Come Lately sixth.Billy Come Lately, 21 in the morning fine, has been a pleasant surprise in the handicap Division's, R. W. Palmer's 4yearold has been out 13 times this year and has finished in the money 10 times with four victories. The brown ridgeling has won $103,277.

title: DIX IS TRIAL SITE OF COED BARRACKS
description: In another retreat from its once Spartan lifestyle, the Army has picked Fort Dix to test the idea of allowing met and women enlistees to live in the same barracks.

title: Black Steam fitter's Quest for Job
description: Edward Abrahams is a 31yearold black steamfitter who came to this country from Jamaica in 1967. In the seven years since, he has not been able to find a job in his trade despite persistent efforts.

title: A Hard Look at Drugs and the MiddleClass Woman
description: Much has been said lately about middleclass women: That they are the leaders of the women's liberation movement, that they are enjoying more consumer luxuries than ever before, that they are finally being admitted to colleges and companies once only open to men.

title: Bertolucci, in Shooting 1900 in Italy, Seeks a Fusion of Politics and Poetry
description: PARMA, ItalyBerriardo Bertolucci, clad in blue jeans, sport short and cowboy boots, a floppy panama perched carelessly on his thick dark locks, sat in a canvas chair watching the preparations.

title: With Freedom at Hand, The Refugees Go Home
description: ZIGUINCHOR, Senegal, Aug. 24Hundreds of refugees are leaving southern Senegal daily to return to their homes in Portuguese Guinea, where fighting has ended after an 11year guerrilla war.

title: Taming O.M.B.
description: With submission of the report of his Transition Committee, President Ford has an opportunity to take concrete action that will help fulfill his intention to maintain an open Presidency. Adoption of its recommendations for breaking the stranglehold over other agencies which the Nixon Administration tried to give the Office of Management and Budget would be a major step in the direction Mr. Ford says he wants to go.

title: Nuclear Reactor Test Plan Assailed as Too Expensive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  In just one year, the estimated cost of the nation's first fast breeder nuclear reactor for generating electricity has more than doubled, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin said today.

title: De Seversky, 80, Dies
description: Alexander P. de Seversky, a zealous proponent of strategic air power whose inventions were major contrihutions to military and civil aviation, died at the age of 80. Page 32.

title: Ford Lauds Sermon on Women's Status
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)  President Ford heard a woman deacon of his church plead today for swift acceptance of women in the Episcopal priesthood and later called her sermon superb, although he withheld his opinion on the controversial subject.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW EGYPT, Aug. 25Dancer vs Dancer. That's what the Hambletonian may develop into when the harness racing classic is renewed Wednesday at the State Fairgrounds in DuQuoin, Ill.

title: WATERGATE ISSUE FOUND STILL ALIVE
description: EVANSTON, III., Aug. 25One of the crucial politica questions today is whether th?? Watergate scandals will leave a permanent legacy for American politics. Will Republican candidates continue to suffe?? its aftereffects or has Presiden?? Nixop's resignation cleanse?? the party in the minds o?? voters?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Miss Wade Upset By Miss Naglesen
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 25 (AP)  Betsy Naglesen of St. Petersburg, Fla., pulled another upset today by defeating Virginia Wade of Britain, 63, 36, 64, in the semifinals of the $30,000 women's grasscourt tennis tournament.

title: AMVETS Oppose Amnesty
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug, 25 (AP)The American Veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam took a stand today against amnesty for draft dodgers. More than 1,800 delegates representing nearly a quarter million veterans voted at their national convention here.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS BAR NEW CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Three of America's leading businessmen said yesterday they were opposed to reimposition of wage and price controls to battle inflation.

title: Shaw Sets World Swim Mark, His 3d
description: CONCORD, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP) Tim Shaw, the 16yearold Long Beach (Calif.) swimmer, broke the world 1,500meter freestyle record tonight and became the only active competitor in the sport to hold three world marks.

title: M. J. Coldwell Is Dead at 85; Led Canadian Political Party
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 25 (AP)M. J. Co(dwell, former leader of Canada's socialistoriented party, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 85.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: MRS. HAROLD WEINBERG
description: Diana Leiberman Weinberg, wife of Harold It Weinberg, retired vice president and treasurer of W & J Sloane, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: Impeachment: Final Report
description: A slipout section consisting of excerpts from the final report by the House Judiciary Committee on its inquiry into the question of impeaching former President Richard M. Nixon will be found on Pages 11 to 18.

title: Bluegrass Plants Roots in Folk Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 25Bluegrass music, in the past a peripheral item, at best, in the Philadelphia Folk Festival, has run rampant during the first two days of the festival's 13th annual presentation.

title: Impeachment: Final Report
description: A slipout section consisting of excerpts from the final report by the House Judiciary Committee on its inquiry into the question of impeaching former President Richard M. Nixon will be found on Pages 11 to 18.

title: EXPLORATIONACCORD ON OIL SIGNED IN IRAN
description: TEHERAN, Iran Aug. 25 The National Iranian Oil Company today concluded the last of six agreements it has signed with oil companies from France, West Germany, Italy, the United States and Canada for exploration.

title: Infernal Issues Agitate Germans
description: BONN, Aug. 25A mood of intense preoccupation with domestic and local matters has spread over Weft Germany this summer. But some of the domestic concerns touch on international issues, particularly the growing anxiety about the world economic situation and its dependency on the United States economy The fears are particularly acute because four of this country's small, private banks have failed in the last three months.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CREWS AT WORK TO FLOAT TANKER
description: Crewmen from barges an lighters began efforts yesterday to refloat the 800foot tanker Aeolus, which went aground Saturday night two miles northwest of Ambrose Light when engine room flooded.

title: Jacob's Pillow Bounces Back From Defeat
description: When the doors closed on the Ted Shawn Theater at the end of the nineweek Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in 1973, boxoffice receipts of $140,000 had been registered, a record for the festival. Nevertheless, expenses exceeded income by so much that the Jacob's Pillow board was faced with an accumulated deficit of $73,000, and was on the verge of closing the 42yearold school and terminating the festival.

title: MORE RISES SEEN FOR BOND YIELDS
description: Interest rates continued to move higher in the credit markets last week and participants face what appears to be more of the same in the week ahead in the face of a moderately heavy corporate calendar and a rather light taxexempt calendar. The Treasury Department itself will be the heaviest borrower this week with three auctions of bills on the slate. In addition to today's regular weekly auction, the Treasury will auction on Wednesday $2billion of bills, maturing June 30, 1975, to help meet September cash needs.

title: Marit Bergson Gentele Wed to Sydney Gruson
description: Merit Bergson Gentele, widow of Goeran Gentele, who was general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, and Sydney Gruson, an executive vice president of The New York Times Company, were married yesterday afternoon at Hillandale, the home of Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger in Stamford, Conn.

title: Books of The Times
description: TATLIN! Six Stories. By Guy Davenport, Illustrated. 261 pp, Scribners, $7.95.

title: Senator Williams of Jersey Weds Legislative Assistant
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, and Jeanette Smith were married Saturday evening in a garden ceremony at Cragwood, the Far Hills, N. J., home of Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard. A Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ace Tubbs, former assistant pastor of the Presbyterian Church of Westfield, N. J.

title: Aztecs Top Toros, 43, for Soccer Title
description: The Los Angeles Aztecs defeated the Miami Toros, 43, in overtime in the nationally televised North American Soccer League's championship game yesterday at the Orange Bowl in Miami.

title: SIDNEY L. COHN
description: Sidney L. Cohn, president of the Jamaica Food Company, Inc., and a director of the Greater New York Wholesale Grocers Association, died Thursday of a heart attack in Paris. He was 55 years old and lived in East Rockaway, L. I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Brooke Vosburgh Bride of John H. Ghent
description: Brooke Voshurgh, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lee Frederick Vosburgh of Plandome Manor, L.I., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Hennessey Ghent, son of Col. Daniel T. Ghent, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Ghent reAtlanta.

title: As the Dow Went, So Went the BrokersInto Other Jobs
description: Until last December, Jerry Regenstein of St. Louis was a $20,000ayear stockbroker for the firm of G. H. Walker & Co. Then, with his income fading as fast as the Dow Jones averages, Mr. Regenstein decided to get out of the securities business and take a job as a tennis pro at the posh St. Louis Country Club.

title: Connors Ill, Defaults in Net Final
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 25A sudden illness forced Jimmy Connors, the No. 1seeded player in the tournament, to default to Alex Metreveli, seeded second, in the men's singles final today of the $50,000 MediQuik open tennis tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Prisoner Leave Program Termed 99% Successful
description: Despite a spate of recent escapes, the state's prisoner furlough program, has been pronounced better than 99 per cent successful and likely to expand in the future.

title: War Evaders' Parents Favor Total Amnesty
description: At the time their sons went into exile or hiding, some parents thought they were wrong. Today, although few deserters and draft dodgers have had second thoughts about their decisions, many of their parents have.

title: TV, in Time for Bicentennial, Is Catching Up With U.S History
description: American history has never been a staple of television in the United States, but in anticipation of the bicentennial celebration in 1976, television and radio networks are looking back on the nation's past with series and specials whose numbers will proliferate in the next two years.

title: Apparel Makers Hope September Reorders Will End Doldrums
description: The summer lull on Seventh Avenue has an air of expectancy. Manufacturers are sweating out a quiet period in the hope that retailers next month will come in with a sufficient quantity of reorders to pull the trade out of the doldrums.

title: D. F. Epstein Weds Ruth Seligson
description: Ruth Louise Seligson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Seligson of Woodbridge, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to David Friedman Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Epstein of Madison, Wis. Rabbi Arthur A. Chien performed the ceremony in the chapel of Congregation B'nai Jacob.

title: Marx vs. Malthus: Ideas Stir Rancor at Population Meeting
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 25The United Nations World Population Conference, at midpoint, is shaping up as a struggle between the doctrinal ghosts of Malthuswho stated that population, increasing geometrically, would inevitably outstrip the growth of food suppliesand Marxwho contended that the population characteristics of a society were determined by its political and economic structure.

title: LEADER OF CYPRUS WARNS THE TURKS OF GUERRILLA WAR
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 25President Glafkos Clerides warned today that continued Turkish occupation of areas of Cyprus formerly controlled by the Greek community might lead to guerrilla warfare against the Turks.

title: ABRAMS ENDORSES CAREY, WHO GIVES RETURN SUPPORT
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, who is widely regarded as the front runner for the Democratic nomination for Attorney General, endorsed Representative Hugh L. Carey for Governor yesterday and was endorsed by him in return.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Department of Labor and Industry reported that nonfarm wage and salary employment in New Jersey declined by more than 33,000 jobs in July. Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman said the July employment total was 2,808,900, or 33,600 less than the June total.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: New fallout from the wreckage of the Gateway Insurance Company, declared insolvent last week by the Pennsylvania Department of Insurance, keeps dropping almost every day.

title: Tremor Is Felt in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25 (UPI)A minor earth tremor was felt in a section of Japan, including Tokyo, this morning, the Weather Bureau reported, The bureau said the epicenter was about 25 miles under the Pacific, east of HachijoJima island, about 168 miles south of Tokyo. There were no reports of damage or injuries.

title: PROPERTY INSURANCE TO COST LESS IN STATE
description: TRENTON, Aug, 25 (AP)Rate reductions averaging 13.7 per cent will go into effect later this year for fire and extendedoverage insurance on commercial properties, New Jersey Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran announced yesterday.

title: Kuwait Takes 60% Share In Japanese Oil Concern
description: KUWAIT, Aug. 25 (UPI)Kuwait and the Japaneseowned Arabian Oil Company signed a participation agreement yesterday that turns over 60 per cent of the company's shares and assets to the Kuwaiti Government.

title: Music: A Theater Piece
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 25At the climax of Hotel for Criminals, a giddily offcenter theater piece by Richard Foreman and Stanley Silverman, four fiendish thugs are metamorphosed into bishops who proceed to do a stately flamenco dance while the body of the hero, if that is what he is, lies on view in an open coffin. Or perhaps they are not bishops, and it is not a coffin. Perhaps, indeed . . . but why speculate on the cryptic events that took place on the cryptlike stage of the Lenox Arts Center here last night. All you know and all you need to know, perhaps, is that Hotel for Criminals has a sinister power to make you laugh outright when you halfknow why.

title: KUWAIT MAY SEEK JOINT OUTPUT CUT
description: KUWAIT, Aug. 25  Kuwait plans to ask members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to adopt a program of production management for crude oil that could reduce output by 10 to 20 per cent, according to sources in this nation's Ministry of Finance and Oil.

title: LAOS REDS TO FREE LAST U.S. PRISONER
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 25 (UPI)A senior official of the Communistled Pathet Lao has confirmed that Emmet J. Kay, the last known American prisoner in Indochina, would be released Sept. 12 when other prisoners of war are exchanged in Laos.

title: Doomsday Clock Moves 3 Minutes Closer to Midnight
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (Reuters) The hands of the doomsday clock, which symbolizes the threat of nuclear doom hovering over mankind, moved today three minutes closer to midnight.

title: Brant Are Making a Comeback Along the East Coast
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 25Atlantic brant, a species of goose depleted in numbers last year along the East Coast, are making a comback.

title: Malaysia Government Sweeps Elections
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug, 25Prime Minister Abdul Razak and his National Front coalition Government won a striking victory in yesterday's national election, but the landslide did not remove racialism from. Malaysia's political life.

title: HAIM DOUEK, 70, DIES, EGYPT'S CHIEF RABBI
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25Rabbi Haim Douek, the last Chief Rabbi of Egypt, was buried on the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem on Friday.

title: Therapist Turns a South Bronx Street Into a Couch
description: Gilberto, 12 years old and shy, ducks a hollow plastic baseball, squats in his blue sneakers over a broiling sidewalk, and explains that he lives with his mother and his two sisters.

title: Israeli Reservists Are Called Up in Test.
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25Responding to codeworded calls such as birthpangs, slaughtered chicken and Sampson and Delilah, thousands of Israeli war veterans today immediately joined their reserve units in a test mobilization.

title: Malone Set To Turn Pro With Utah
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 3 hind Miller going to the ninth tee.

title: Doomsday Clock Moves 3 Minutes Closer to Midnight
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (Reuters) The hands of the doomsday clock, which symbolizes the threat of nuclear doom hovering over mankind, moved today three minutes closer to midnight.

title: Laura M. Gordon, Philip Fisher Wed
description: Laura Mavis Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaiah Gordon of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Lloyd Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin B. Fisher of Gates Mills, Ohio. Rabbi Gerald B. Zelermyer performed the ceremony at Eliot House of Harvard College.

title: ALEXANDER OPENS ATTACK ON CLARK
description: Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse, contending that he has become the underdog in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination, began a new tack yesterday, directly attacking the man he regards as the frontrunner, former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark.

title: Higher Pay to Be Sought as Incentive For State Prisoners to Go to School
description: In an effort to induce more prisoners to go to school, the State Department of Corrections plans to ask the Legislature to authorize payment of incentive allowances to inmates, Commissioner of Corrections Peter Preiser has disclosed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN SEARCH OF BUSTER In 1920, Buster Keaton had had a threeyear apprenticeship with Fatty Arbuckle when he was chosen to appear in his first featurelength film, The Saphead. The movie was based on a hit Broadway play, The New Henrietta, but because of a contract provision that gave the performance rights to the original stage producers, The Saphead has been tied up in legal tangles that have shown publicly for nearly five decades.

title: Old Hotel in Cape May to Bea Museum
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 25The Windsor, one of the larger of Cape May's 19thcentury may never again register guest for any of its 125 rooms, but visitors can now see more of the onceopulent Windsor than ever before.

title: NICKEL BID MARKS ALASKA'S PRIMARY
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 25The governorship race and a proposition to move the, state capital are the key attractions expected to draw a record 60,000 voters in Alaska's open primary election on Tuesday.

title: Struggle Over Oil . . .
description: The commitments the International Monetary Fund has received from the major oilexporting nations to put up $3.5 billion to help oilimporting nations pay their bills can provide some welcome relief to the poorest developing countries. But that sum is a drop in the bucket measured against the total imbalance in international payments created by the quadrupling of oil prices in the last year.

title: Allons Personnes de la Patrie . . .
description: PARISSo, he really meant it, Valry Giscard d'Estaing, a man who knows what he wants, has now moved to implement his stated intentions regarding the situation of women in French society.

title: Lisbon Signing Pact Today On Guinea's Independence
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 25A Portuguese Government delegation will sign an agreement here tomorrow granting independence to Portuguese Guinea, the Algerian Foreign Ministry anmounced today.

title: Party Leader Punches New Zealand Hecklers.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 25Robert D. Muldoon, the controversial leader of New Zealand's opposition National party, exchanged punches in the street here tonight with hecklers.

title: West Virginia Fire Wipes Out a Block; 7 Dead, 6 Missing
description: BERKELEY SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 25 (AP)Seven bodies were dug out of the rubble of a fire that leveled almost a block of buildings today in this small town in the state's eastern panhandle.

title: Ellen V. Futter, Jahn A. Shutkin, Lawyers, Marry
description: Ellen Victoria Futter and John Arthur Shutkin, who graduated from the Columbia Law School in May, were married yesterday afternoon in the Sands Point (L.I.) Bath & Tennis Club by State Supreme Court Justice Hilda Schwartz.

title: Peter Haughton Beats His Fathe In $150,000 Trot
description: MONTREAL., Aug. 25 (UPI) Armbro Omaha, with Peter Haugbton in the sulky, won the $150,000 Prix d'Et trot at Blue Bonnet Raceway to day.

title: Miller Wins Westchester Golf
description: HARRISON, N.Y. Aug. 25 The others made brief runs at him, but the outcome was never in doubt and it was Johnny Miller all the way.

title: Why We Oppose Votes For Men
AUDREY HESS, LED UNIT FOR FAMILIES
description: Audrey Stern Hess, president of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York from 1970 to 1972, died yesterday of a heart ailment at her summer home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 50 years old and lived at 19 Beekman Place.

title: Advertising: Chock Full O'Beer
description: Although the recriminations of his company's breakup last month with the J. Walter Thompson Company may not have ended, William Black, chairman of the Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation, is looking ahead to his new advertising campaign for Rheingold beer.

title: Alexander P. de Seversky Dies at 80; Early Strategic Air Power Proponent
description: Alexander P. de Seversky, a zealous proponent of strategic air power, who flew more than 50 World War I combat missions after losing his right leg and whose inventions were major contributions to military and commercial flying, died Saturday at Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

title: Despite Changes, an Older Paris Remains
Nancy Robinson Wed to Lee Miringoff
description: In the Blitzer Chapel of the Central Synagogue at noon yesterday, Nancy Ellen Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray. Robinson of New York, became the bride of Lee M. Miringoff. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Miringoff of Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

title: Personal Finance: Seizure of Goods
description: The United States Supreme Court appears to have retreated from a position it held up to now that a creditor could not seize property without prior notice and a court hearing.

title: Cedarhurst Ties Brookville in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Aug. 25 The Cedarhurst and Brookville polo teams battled to a 77 tie today, at Bethpage State Park. Peter Daly's goal, his third of the match, earned Cedarhurst the tie. with a minute and a half left In the final period.

title: Liberated 30 Years, French Family Prospers but Grieves
description: PARIS, Aug. 25When Melvin Stock of Pittsburgh liberated Bivre, a village on the southwestern outskirts of Paris on Aug. 25, 1944, Georges No was there to snap his picture in front of the pharmacy on the main square.

title: Accounts
description: Nashua Corporation to Arnold & Co.

title: British Warn of Bombs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25 (UPI)The police reported today that they had intercepted two booksized letter bombs destined for Britain at the main postoffice in Londonderry and warned residents of Northern Ireland to be careful of suspicious packages in the mail.

title: Grayson Predicts Some Price Rises Under New Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The man who was in charge of the mandatory price control machinery tried by the Nixon Administration said today that the voluntary approach being advocated by President Ford would in some cases lead to higher rather than lower prices.

title: Courageous Wins and Intrepid Protests
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 It was an almostbutnotquite day for Intrepid and France at the America's Cup races today. Intrepid lost a protested race to her archrival Courageous, by 10 seconds at the end of a 24.3mile course and France got close to Southern Cross before their race was abandoned because the 5hour time limit was reached.

title: Despite Changes, an Older Paris Remains
description: PARIS, Aug. 25When the first French and American troops rolled into a delirious Paris 30 years ago the city was grubby, hungry and wan but physically intact.

title: Vast Tracts in the Northland of Canada Are Claimed by Indians and Eskimos
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23  Land claims covering huge areas of potentially rich wilderness in northern Canada are being made by Indians and Eskimos, and there are some threats of backing the claims with legal action against the Government.

title: A Retired Top Policeman Will Head School Security
description: Sydney C. Cooper, who earned a reputation as one of the city's straightest and toughest police officers before he retired in 1972, Is scheduled to become the head of school security as part of a planned new Board of Education effort to curb crime and violence when the fall term begins Sept. 9.

title: Borg Routs Okker for Pro Title
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP)Bjorn Borg, the 18yearold Swede, won the $100,000 United States pro tennis tournament by trouncing Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 76, 61, 61, tonight at the Longwood Cricket Club.

title: MANILA CHARGES JESUIT IS A REBEL
description: MANILA, Aug. 26The martiallaw Government announced today that charges of rebellion had been brought against a Jesuit priest and one of his students who were among 21 persons arrested at a suburban novitiate last Saturday.

title: Bear Hunting Ban Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Ten major conservation groups have asked to ban hunting of grizzly bears in the vicinity of Yellowstone National Park.

title: Athens Said to Rebuff U.S. in Accepting Soviet Plan
description: ATHENS, Aug. 26  in accepting a Soviet proposal fog an international conference on Cyprus, Greek officials ignored an appeal from Washington to reject the plan, authoritative sources said today.

title: DR. PROCOPE COSTAS, CLASSICIST, 74, DIES
description: Dr. Procope S. Costas, who retired last year as professor of classics at Brooklyn College, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived at 235 Lincoin Place, Brooklyn.

title: Woman Dies in Plane Crash
description: MADISON, Conn., Aug. 26 (AP)  A singleengine plane crashed today during a landing attempt at the shoreline Griswold Airport, killing a Madison woman and injuring the airport's owner, the police said. The woman, Maureen Malovany, 36 years old, was killed at about 12:15 P.M. when the plane crashed. The airport's owner, Sherman Griswold, suffered a broken leg and was admitted to Middlesex Memorial. Hospital in Middletown in fair, condition, a hospital spokesman said. It was not certain which person was at the controls at the time.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Dispersal3 Arabian

title: Fire Hero Seized for Questioning in Fatal Arson
description: Wilberto Diaz went to City Hall yesterday morning to be honored for rescuing four children from a burning tenement, but instead of shaking hands with the Mayor, he was taken into custody for questioning about a fire five hours earlier in which one man was killed.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified oases distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: Kerner to Ask Parole
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UPI)Otto Kerner, the former Federal judge and Governor of Illinois, will ask to be paroled in October, according to Thomas Patton, one of his lawyers. Mr. Kerner, 66 years old, entered the Federal penitentiary at Lexington, Ky., on July 29 to serve a threeyear sentence for mail fraud, conspiracy, perjury and income tax evasion. His sentence carried a provision that made him eligible for parole immediately, rather than after serving a third of the prison term, as is customary.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices of stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued to, decline yesterday. Prices finished mixed in the overthecounter market.

title: Modern Art Stirs Anger In Geneva
description: GENEVA, Aug. 26Eighteen modern sculptures that are temporarily on public display in the principal shopping district and its adjoining lakeside promenade have driven many of this conservative city's citizens into a state of frenzy.

title: 13 Believed Dead in Fire In Hotel in West Virginia
description: BERKELEY SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 26 (UPI)The authorities said today that at least 13 persons died yesterday in a fire that destroyed a 150yearold brick and wood hotel and leveled a block of stores in this small town.

title: Sawhill Foresees Oil Production Off Nab England in 2 to 3 Years
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)John Sawhill, head of the Federal Energy Administration, said today that he expected oil drilling off the New England coast within two or three years.

title: Lincoln Hospital Dispute Goes Before Court Today
description: Two South Bronx antipoyerty leaders, one of them a candidate in the City Council prima ry, face a court hearing today on criminal charges that have revived simmering tensions a Lincoln Hospital.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The semester before she was to enter the Fashion Institute of Technology, Ann Peerce got a temporary job in the repair department of Kenneth Jay Lane, the costume jewelry designer. She liked the work so much that she abandoned her college plan and stayed on to become Mr. Lane's assistant.

title: Nixon, in a Phone Call, Says He Has Problems With Jaworski
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 26 (UPI) Former President Richard M. Nixon in a brief telephone call today to Representative Dan Kuykendall, Republican of Tennessee, said he had problems with Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 10162

title: DR. JOSEPH RONGETT
description: Dr. Joseph R. Rongetti, an attending surgeon in the head and neck service at St. Vincent's Hospital, died there yesterday, He was 66 years old and lived at 40 Fifth Avenue and had his office at 42 Fifth Avenue.

title: Parents of Two Missing Bergen Girls Join Police in Vain Hunt in Manhattan
description: Anguished parents, their fears intensified by New York City's jungle image and by the memory of the stillunsolved murders of two teenage New Jersey girls this month, augmented the police yesterday in the search for two 12yearold cousins who ran off Saturday from Ridgefield Park, N.J., to Manhattan.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SOVIET LAUNCHES 2 ON SPACECRAFT
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 27 The Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 15 has been launched into orbit with two space rookies aboard, and everything is going as planned, the press agency Tass reported early today.

title: Parisians Stop, Recall Le Jeune Americain
description: PARIS, Aug. 26Jean Ordonnier still remembers listening as a boy of nine years to the crowds who sang the May evening away on the night that Charles A. Lindbergh landed at Le Bourget Airport, just north of Paris.

title: Daring Lindbergh Attained the Unattainable With Historic Flight Across Atlantic
A Distant Peace for Cambodians
description: PHNOM PENH, CambodiaRumors of peace talks blossom endlessly in the hothouse atmosphere of Phnom Penh.

title: A Correction
description: The New York Times on Saturday incorrectly reported that Alex Smollock, business manager of Passaic County Vocational and Technical High School, had admitted, through his lawyer, taking kickbacks from contractors doing business with the school. Mr. Smollock, who will appear voluntarily before an investigating grand jury in Trenton on Sept. 5, and his lawyer have always denied the kickback charges.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: CITIBANK SAID TO ACT AS GRUMMAN AGENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  The First National City Bank has agreed to act as the Grumman Corporation's agent in obtaining nearly $100million needed to maintain F14 fighter production, informed sources said today.

title: Israel Charges Soviet Ships Violated Waters Off Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 26Israel complained to United Nations truce supervision officials tonight that Soviet vessels clearing mines from the southern approach to the Suez Canal had violated waters under Israeli control.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 0.4% IN WEEK
description: Steel production last week fell to 2.66 million net tons, the lowest production level since December of 1972, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: East River's Bridges to Glow Again

title: HIGH COURT IS ASKED TO UPSET RAIL CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  The Supreme Court was asked today to overrule a lower court decision blocking rehabilitation of bankrupt railroads under an act passed by Congress last year. Arguments are expected to be heard early in the high court's next term, starting Oct. 7.

title: Stadler Upset in U.S. Golf
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 26 With water to the right of them and out of bounds to the left 144 golfers teed off on the first hole of Ridgewood Country Club's East course today in the 74th annual United States amateur championship. When the shooting subsided after the first round of match play, the defending champion, Craig Stadler, was on the casualty list.

title: Suspect in Village Strangling Was Paroled as a Good Risk
description: A spokesman for the State Board of Parole said yesterday that Charles W. Yukl, arrested Saturday in the strangling of an aspiring actress in Greenwich Village, had been considered good risk when he was released from prison last year after serving six years and eight months for a nearly identical murder.

title: MURDERER ESCAPES FROM REFORMATORY
description: ANNANDALE, Aug. 26 (AP)A convicted murderer escaped from Annandale Reformatory this morning when prison officials opened the main gate for a delivery of cattle feed.

title: G.M.'s Price Increases Range Up to $1,31.6
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that it was raising prices of some of its 1975 Models hundreds of dollars more than the average $426 increase it announced last week for its new cars and trucks.

title: PepsiCola Plant Is Struck
description: NEWAURGH, N. Y., Aug. 26 (UP1)About 80 employes at the PepsiCola bottling plant serving the lower Hudsoh Valley went on strike today. A spokesman for Local 812 of the Soft Drink Workers Union, a temsters affiliate, said the employes had been working without a contract since the end of July.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: BUTZ SEES NO NEED FOR PANIC ON FOOD THIS YEAR OR NEXT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The United States will have plenty, of beef in the coming year despite disappointing fall crops of livestockfeed grains, but lower supplies of pork and broiler chickens will be available, a panel of administrators led by Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today.

title: PepsiCola Plant Is Struck
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 26 (UPI)About 80 employes at the PepsiCola bottling plant serving the lower Hudson Valley went on strike today. A spokesman for Local 812 of the Soft Drink Workers Union, a temsters affiliate, said the ernployes had been working without a contract since the end of July.

title: New U.S. Ambassador To Cyprus Is Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 26 (UPI)William R. Crawford Jr. was sworn in today as United States Ambassador to Cyprus to replace Rodger P. Davies, who was shot to death a week ago during a demonstration by Greek Cypriotes outside the embassy in Nicosia.

title: WALDHEIM MEETS CYPRUS LEADERS; ARRANGES TALKS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 26Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations and the heads of the Greek and Turkish Cypriote administrations conferred here today and said afterward they had achieved some progress toward an eventual progress toward an eventual solution of the crisis on the island.

title: Common Market Is Said To Weigh $5Billion Loan
description: PARIS, Aug. 26  The European Common Market is considering floating an international loan of about $5billion to help two of its hardpressed members, Britain and Italy, according to high European central banking sources.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Feminists Open Own Credit Union

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Miranda Is Arrested On Weapons Charge
description: TEIVIPE, Ariz., Aug. 26 (UPI)  Ernesto Miranda, whose 1963 conviction for kidnap and rape was overturned by the United States Supreme Court in a landmark decision, was ordered today to stand trial on a weapons charge.

title: 2 Die in Plane Crash
description: RANDOLPH, N. H., Aug. 26A California couple died in the crash of a private plane on Mount Madison in New Hampshire's White Mountain's over the weekend. The authorities said the bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Titcomb was found yesterday.

title: State Welfare Aide Named
description: ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP)Stuart M. Patterson Jr. of Lansing, Mich., has been appointed head of the State Department of Social Services Office of Management Planning and Data Processing.

title: Ailing Connors Will Play in U.S. Open; Talbert Offers Him an Extra Day Off
description: Jimmy Connors, stricken with a stomach disorder that forced him to default in the final at South Orange, will be ready for his first match in the $271,000 United States Open here tomorrow.

title: Promoters Are Getting Worried About All Fight
description: With the costliest title, fight in history only one month away, promoters are becoming increasingly worried that Muhammad Ali may have scared away Americans from traveling to the bout in Zaire, the African country once known as the Belgian Congo.

title: Body of a Drug Suspect Found in Burning Auto
description: The body of a reputed narcotics dealer was found in the trunk of a burning car in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning.

title: Prices Are Raised On Color TV Tubes
description: Price increases were announced yesterday on color TV picture tubes, automobile antiknock compounds and lithiumderived chemical and mineral products. One price reduction was announceda 5centagallon cut by the Union Oil Coinpany of California in the wholesale price of propane gas. The reduction, effective immediately, brought the price of the fuel down from 19 cents to 14 cents a gallon and was in line with recent cuts by other suppliers.

title: Franklin New York Sued by ExOfficial
description: Peter R. Shaddick, a former executive vice chairman of the Franklin New York Corporation, parent of the beleaguered Franklin National Bank, has filed suit in Federal Court here for $583,333.33 in compensation and fringe benefits.

title: KUH, MORGENTHAU GET BAR APPROVAL
description: Both District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan and Robert M. Morgenthau, his opIponent in the Sept, 10 Democratic primary, have been rated as approved by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the bar group announced yesterday.

title: Compassion and Justice
description: In parroting the view of Senate Minority Leader Hugh Scott that, since former President Nixon has been hung ... it doesn't seem ... that in addition he should be drawn and quartered, Vice Presidentdesignate Rockefeller has beclouded the imperatives of a legal system grounded in justice and equity.

title: President Leads the Nation in Tribute to Lindbergh
description: Among the tributes to Charles A. Lindbergh were the following:

title: TURKEY IS INSISTING ON 28% OF CYPRUS
description: LONDON, Aug. 26 HalukUlman, foreignaffairs adviser to Premier Bulent Ecevit of Turkey, said here today: that Turkey would accept not less than 28 per cent of Cyprus in a settlement with the Greek Cypriotes.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Mills Vows to Defeat Gasoline Tax Increase
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 26 (UN)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that there, would be no 10centagallon increase in gasoline taxes as long as he is chairman of the taxwriting House Ways and Means Committee.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has announced that it will present five ballet companies during its 197475 season. The American Ballet Theater will appear at the Center from Oct. 22 through Nov. 3 and from May 13 through May 18. The repertory will include a new production of La Bayadere as well as appearances by Mikhail Baryshnikov, Gelsey Kirkland and Fernando BuJones, recent winner of the Verna Gold Medal. Natalia Makarova will appear as a guest artist during the spring engagement.

title: People in Sports
description: Sam Jones, the former Boston Celtics star, sent a telegram to his alma mater, North Carolina Central, yesterday resigning as head basketball coach of the school after one season, Dr. Albert Whiting, the N.C.C. chancellor, said the telegram contained no explanation. The school has not named a successor and there were no assistants on Jones's staff. Before the N.C.C. job, Jones spent four years as head coach at Federal City College in Washington.

title: It's First Day of School and Met Stirs
description: Like some quasimythological creature that hibernates in the summer, the Metropolitan Opera starts to stretch and stir about this time of year. Even in this age of 52week contracts, there remains a summer break, and now is the time that work begins in earnest in preparation for the winter season opening Sept. 23.

title: WOUNDED KNEE TRIAL RESUMES IN ACCORD
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 26 (AP)The trial of two leaders of the American Indian Movement, Russell Means and Dennis Banks, resumed today with Federal District Judge Fred J. Nichol reading a statement of regret over an outburst in the courtroom last Friday.

title: NIXON PROSECUTION IS URGED BY DASH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Samuel Dash, chief counsel of the Senate Watergate committee, said today he believed that former President Richard M. Nixon should be prosecuted for obstruction of justice in the coverup.

title: A Red Rash Annoys Fire Island Swimmers
description: An official of the Suffolk County Health Department said yesterday that some physicians at Fire Island reported a worse than usual incidence of swimmers rash among ocean bathers this month.

title: Portuguese Guinea Wins Independence
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 26Portugal today began the dissolution of her colonial empire in Africa with the signing of an agreement granting independence to Portuguese Guinea on Sept. 10.

title: Fire Hero Seized at City Hall For Questioning in Fatal Arson
description: Wilberto Diaz went to City Hall yesterday morning to be honored for rescuing four children from a burning tenement, but instead of shaking hands with the Mayor, he was handcuffed and taken into custody for questioning about a fire five hours earlier in which one man was killed.

title: Looking for the Bottom
description: Wall Street lives by numbers and by moods and one of its worries now is whether the Dow Jones industrials will test that low of May, 1970, before the sun truly shines again. It isn't all that far away, you know, one broker said yesterday as the D o w squeaked through with gain of 1.33 points to finish at 688.13. It marked only the second up day in the last 13 sessions. Taking the edge off that token advance was a 17year low in the utility average.

title: Notes on People
description: A delegation of seven members of Congress will leave Washington next Monday for a twoweek tour of China, if was announced yesterday by J. F. terHorst, press secretary to President Ford. The group, the sixth to make such a tr?? since 1972, will be headed by. J. W. Fullbright, Democrat of Arkansas, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen, Republican of New Jetsey, who is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: Notebooks, Looseleaf Paper, Reinforcements, Protractors, Etc., All Up
description: While the thought of soon returning to school may pain the heart of many a child, many a parent can honestly say this season, This hurts me more than it does you.

title: Ford Said to Plan Curbs On Access to Tax Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Representative Jerry Litton, Democrat of Missouri, said today he had learned that President Ford would shortly issue an executive order restricting the access that the White House has to tax returns.

title: EXPERTS ASK SENATE TO KILL ATEST PACT
description: A citizens' group comprising scientists and former Government officials called on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday to reject the limited nuclear test ban treaty signed in Moscow last July by former President Richard M. Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, head of the Soviet Communist party.

title: MANY CITIES GAIN ON HOUSING FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 26Final figures prepared by the Department of Housing and Urban Development on community development block grants authorized for the next three years by the new $11.9billion Housing and Community Development Act show substantial gains for a number of cities over earlier estiniates.

title: Ford Recalls 282,000 Cars For Faulty Emission Control
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling 282,000 of its 1973 and 1974 model cars to replace a part in the emission control system that could fail after extended use.

title: Michigan Skipper Leads
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 26 (UPI)Susan Corbett of Pontiac, Mich., was the leader today after two races in the Adams Cup women's sailing championship at Lake Murray. Tied for second place with 11 points were Laurie Wilcox of Seattle and Tyke Gibley of Wickford, R.I. Carolyn Newcomb of Balboa, Calif., was in fourth place.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Filing of PhoneRate Brief Postponed

title: Notebooks, Looseleaf Paper, Reinforcements, Protractors, Ets., All Up
A Glimpse Into Remote SouthWest Africa
description: KATIMA MULILO, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 20Terrified hippopotamuses lunged through the waters of the broad, swampy lake and herds of lyrehorned red lechwe antelope stampeded as the plane landed on the airstrip at Mpacha.

title: Montreal Transit Strike Spreads to Bus Services
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (AP)The 20dayold transit strike that has left the subway system paralyzed spilled over today into the only public transportation left to commutersbuses.

title: Attorney General Opposes Prison for Draft Evaders
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Attorney General William B. Saxbe, who was asked by President Ford to study the amnesty problem, indicated today that he would recommend against any prison terms for draft evaders when a Justice Department panel offers its final report to the President next week.

title: Moses Rips Into Venomous Biography
description: With liberal citations from Victorian poets, Gilbert and Sullivan, Chaucer, and Leo Durocher, Robert Moses yesterday issued an acerbic 3,500word rebuttal to The Power Broker, the biography of him written by Robert A. Caro and serialized as a profile in The New Yorker.

title: Chess: Hort and Benko Share Title As Open Closes With a Bang
description: Vlastimil Hort, a Czech grandmaster, and Pal Benko, a United States grandmaster, stormed their way into a tie for the United States Open championship with equal 102 scores.

title: Lawyerless Divorce Case Saves Couple Costly Fee
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 26 (AP) A Woodstock couple have obtained a divorce for the price of a $45 court fee, thus becoming the first couple in Connecticut to handle their divorce without lawyers, according to court officials.

title: ARCHBISHOP LEAVES MOZAMBIQUE POST
description: ROME, Aug. 26 A Portuguese prelate who for 12 years has been Archbishop of Lourengo Marques, the capital of Mozambique, has resigned and been assigned to a vaguely defined post in Rome, the Vatican announced today.

title: Key to the Kingdom Reopens Belmont
description: The name of the race was the Stymie and the Rokeby Stable's Key to the Kingdom won it like Stymie as the thoroughbreds returned to Belmont Park yesterday.

title: SCREVANE SEEKS OTB PACT INQUIRY
description: Paul R. Screvane, chairman of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, has asked the city's Investigation Commissioner to check the awarding of a contract for telephone racing results while Howard J. Samuels, a Democratic aspirant for Governor, headed the betting agency.

title: Dutch Space Shot Planned
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP)A Dutch satellite will be rocketed aloft from the space test centere here next week. The Space agency said yesterday that the 298pound spacecraft would be powered into a 300milehigh orbit next Tuesday by an American Scout rocket. It will be the Netherlands' first satellite flight.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 35

title: 1.6 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
description: The Health Department announced yesterday that 16 more food outlets had been cited for having failed second inspections. Further violations upon a final inspection could result in closing orders.

title: Joseph Durso
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 26He probably didn't say it at the breakfast table, and he certainly didn't have the Hambletonian in mind, but Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes was striking a blow for us poor people in sports 110 years ago. That was before they had parimutuel machines, but Holmes still saw critical differences between racing horses and trotting horses, besides their gait.

title: GUILTY PLEA MADE IN IMPORT SWINDLE
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va. Aug. 26 (UPI)Robert D. Johnson, a McLean businessman, pleaded guilty today to mail and security fraud charges arising from a multimilliondollar wine importing swindle.

title: RESIDENTS SUING ON POSTAL GARAGE
description: Hilda Regier, who is leading the battle against a $35million Postal Service garage in Chelsea, tells a story about the plight of her Mennonite ancestors.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: By Reuters

title: President Selects 5 Goals For 2Day Inflation Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26President Ford's summit conference on inflation will be held here Sept. 27 and 28 and will be preceded by a series of preliminary meetings between the Administration and leaders of individual sectors of the nation's economy.

title: Convict Killed, 2 Seized As Texas Manhunt Ends
description: STEPHENVILLE, Tex., Tuesday, Aug. 27Three escaped convicts who had terrorized the Texas ranch country were cornered by police last night. One convict was killed and the others were captured.

title: Soybean Booklet Published By Agriculture Department
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  The Agriculture Department has published a new 26page booklet to tell consumers how to prepare soybeans for family meals.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: George Foreman and Muhammad Ali will break training next week and face each other before taking off for their $35million heavyweight title fight in Zaire, Africa, on Sept. 24. Both have agreed to appear at Project Survival Sept. 3 in Salt Palace in Salt Lake City, an event designed to raise funds for droughtridden African nations.

title: 3 Runs in 9th Beat AstrosKoosman Gets His 13th
description: These are the times when the Mets need miracles to get back into the National League's Eastern Division pennant race. And they came up with one last night at Shea Stadium, scoring three runs in the ninth to beat the Houston Astros, 54, in the opener of a fourgame series.

title: People in Sports
description: Sam Jones, the former Boston Celtics star, sent a telegram to his alma mater, North Carolina Central, yesterday resigning as head basketball coach of the school after one season. Dr. Albert Whiting, the N.C.C. chancellor, said the telegram contained no explanation. The school has not named a successor and there were no assistants on Jones's staff. Before the N.C.C. job, Jones spent four years as head coach at Federal City College in Washington.

title: Savings Study Cites Risk in U.S. Issues
description: The giant savings and loan industry, waging an uphill battle to head off a further heavy outflow of funds into other investments, opened a nationwide campaign yesterday to point out the risks of dealing with one of its biggest competitors  the United States Treasury.

title: Correction Officers Back 2Year Contract With City
description: Members of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association have approved a twoyear contract with the city by a vote of 1,517 to 443, Leo C. Zeferetti, president, announced yesterday.
