description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) President Ford signed today a bill extending for three years the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which aids private business groups and individuals in making investments abroad.

title: Slow Going in Population Talks
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 27  Air pollution can be just as bad for a Bombay beggar as for Boston Brahmin, so it isn't so difficult to get an international consensus on the importance of abating it. But the problem of mankind's doubling its numbers every 35 years and threatening to overload the globe is far more complex and is viewed quite differently by different nations, making agreement on any uniform response virtually impossible.

title: Financing Costs Unlit Of Bell Telephone Record 10.14%
description: The grindstones of inflation and tight credit crushed another major interestrate record yesterday when the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company paid 10,14 per cent to borrow $150million on 40year debentures. It was the highest interest cost ever paid by a Ma Bell unit. The previous record interest cost by a Bell unit was 9.91 per cent paid by the Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company on $175million of 9.75 per cent debentures three weeks ago.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The Broadway revival of Eugene O'Neill's drama A Moan for the Misbegotten starring Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst and directed by Jos Quintero, will be brought to television next May as a twohour ABCTV special.

title: People and Business
description: The possible combining of the Kaiser Steel Corporation with the Kaiser Industries Corporation appeared to move a step closer yesterday with the election of William R. Roesch as president, chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee of Kaiser Steel.

title: 19 CANDIDATES GET ON LIBERAL LINE
description: The city's Board of Elections overruled its staff yesterday and declared that 19 Democratic and Republican candidates for public offices in Manhattan who were endorsed by the Liberal party were legally entitled to appear on that party's ballot line in the November election.

title: Changing Room Gets a Woman's Touch
description: In the noise and litter of hockey locker room, a referee turned to another official and said, I was about to take my pants off. I'm glad I saw her just in time.

title: CABOT,CABOTWEIGHS ICM REALTY SHARES
description: BOSTON, Aug. 27, (Reuters) Cabot, Cabot & Forbes Land Trust disclosed today that some of the five banks from which it has agreed to acquire ICM Realty shares do not feel bound to consummate the agreements as currently in effect.

title: Prince Junio Borghese, 68, Dies; Italian War Hero and Neofascist
description: ROME, Aug. 27Prince Junio Valerio Borghese, a World War II hero who later became the leader of an extreme rightwing movement and was known as the Black Prince, died in Cadiz, Spain, yesterday, ANSA, the Italian national news agency, reported tonight. He was 68 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: A lawyer representing Otto Kerner said that the former Governor of Illinois and former Federal, judge, now in Federal prison in Lexington, Ky., would seek a parole in October. Thomas Patton, of Washington; said that although Mr. Kerner began serving his term on July 29, he was entitled to a parole hearing so soon because of a unique circumstance of his sentence.

title: COURT ASKED TO DENY OFFSHORE OIL RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The Supreme Court was told today that the Atlantic Coast states should have no rights over oil exploration and drilling beyond the threemile limit.Albert B. Maris, a special master appointed by the Court to recommend a solution in a fiveyear dispute between 13 coastal states and the Federal Government, said control of the seabed sites, potentially worth billions of dollars in oil revenue, was in the hands of the Federal Government.

title: U.S. and Australia In Senior Net Final
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 27The United States, the defending champion, and Australia reached the final of the sevennation Stevens Cup senior tennis competition at the Concorde Hotel's courts today.

title: Petit to Walk on Wire Over Park Lake Tonight
description: Phillipe Petit, the exuberant French highwire artist, who was arrested on Aug. 7 after he took an unauthorized stroll between the 1,350foot towers of the World Trade Center, will pay his debt tonight by tightrope walking over Belvedere Lake in Central Park, near 81st Street.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Like pirates on the prowl for buried treasure, children wander through The Container/A Children's Store on Pier 16 of the South Street Seaport in search of nautical trinkets at allowance  level prices.

title: Lucia Opens Music Season Tonight
description: The fanfares blare, beacons crisscross in the sky, the velvet drapes are removed andShazzamhere before us stand the 197475 music season. (Please feel free to sit in the bucket seats and kick the tires, sir.) Up front, as hood ornament of this new model, we have the New York City Opera's performance tonight of Lucia di Lammermoor, opening the fall season with Beverly Sills as the poor, mad bride.

title: Match Race Canceled
description: BOSTON, Aug, 27 (UPI)Suffolk Downs canceled today a $10,000 winnertakeall match race scheduled for Saturday after a veterinarian's report showed one of the horses was injured. Sneaky Pal, slated to meet Sweet Mouth in a battle of 2  year  olds, suffered a pinched shoulder muscle during a weekend workout.

title: Screen: 'The Saphead':Buster Keaton Shines in 1920 Feature The Cast
description: Waiting for someone who will never come: it makes an easy poignancy on screena solitary, expectant figure who grows mutely more forlorn can milk almost any spectator's fears of rejection. The image recalls Charlie Chaplin in "The Gold Rush" (1925), as he waits for the girl who won't be coming to dinner. The Chaplin scene is sheer pathos. But Buster Keaton in the same situation is far funnier, thanks to the kind of mistake that's so easy to make: the beloved's train arrives at Grand Central, while he stands with his armful of flowers at Penn Station. It's one of the passages worth cherishing in "The Saphead," which is playing today to Saturday at the Elgin Cinema.The movie was made in 1920, anddue to a snarl of legal problems  it hasn't been shown for almost 50 years. It was Keaton's first feature-length film, and was adapted from a Broadway-play of 1913 that was based on a play of 1887. The print is marvelously clear."The Saphead" is a fairly straight melodrama that drags occasionally, but there are some choice glimpses of Keaton. He plays a rich young drone who's convinced that the woman he loves will spurn him unless he's a wild sport. He studies a manual on "How to Win the Modern Girl," which advises that women prefer daredevils. Striving for decadence in his oriental morning costume, trying and failing to get arrested in a gambling palace, lighting a huge cigar that he can't manage, he makes a most unlikely rake. Now and then, he seems like a forebear of Dustin Hoffman in "The Graduate."Even though Keaton was only 25 years old when "The Saphead" was made, his genius for impassivity was already flourishingthere's no response when the love-object embraces him, not even when she has twins. The sublime somersaults and the stoicism enhance a hazing scene where men knock one another's hats off on the floor of the Stock Exchangea refreshing view of that institution.The theme of Keaton's role is solitude  of being alone when someone else should be with him. When his marriage is briefly foiled, he's doused with rice though he's still brideless, and the grains remain on his hair and shoulders as he sits down to eat his wedding feast alone. But where others might have played for pity, Keaton maintains what James Agee called his "mulish imperturbability."Also on the program are two fine shorts: "Convict 13" (1920) and "The Bellboy" (directed by Roscoe Fatty Arbuckle in 1918). The latter evokes a world of disasters where elevator cables snap, cars and trolleys run through buildings, and a bystander can be hurled into the air and find himself seated on a giant stuffed moosehead upon a hotel wall.

title: Ayala 40th Player to Hit a Homer in First AtBat
RENTALS TO RISE FOR XEROX UNITS
description: Copying equipment, ironore pellets and oceanfreight rates were among items on which rental and price increases were announced yesterday. One decrease  on solid, paperinsulated lead cable, which utilities use for underground transmission of medium  voltage electric currentalso was announced.

title: 400,000 Renters Here Face Up to 12% Rise for New Lease
description: The city's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday authorized landlords to collect rent increases of up to 8.5 per cent for renewal of oneyear leases in the 400,000 apartments here that the Legislature placed under stabilization in the spring.

title: Federal Intervention Seen as Needed For InvestorOwned Electric Utilities
description: Federal relief is needed if the nation's investorowned electric utilities are to survive their current financial trauma and build for future energy needs, participants in a seminar on the electricutility business said here yesterday.

title: Wall St. in Somber Mood As Stock Decline Persists
description: Stock prices plunged again yesterday, sending the Dow Jones Industrial index to its lowest level in four years. In the last three weeks, the widely watched market indicator has lost 102.24 points, and the mood of Wall Street recalls Depression days.

title: U.N.Group Supports Women's Equality At Bucharest Talks
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 27Delegates to the World Population Conference decided today make the equality of women one of a dozen basic principles designed to guide nations in formulating population policies.

title: BEAN PRESSES FOR TRANSIT BILL
description: Rising fares forced by an inadequate Federal masstransit bill will cause a chain reaction of Federal budget increases and stimulate inflation, Mayor Beame warned in telegrams to Washing ton yesterday.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Electric Joins Eclectic in Music From the Incredible String Band
description: The Incredible String Band has come a long way since its Scottish beginnings back in 1965. Always eclectic, the group concentrated on acoustic material in the sixties, but in recent years has branched out into electric, as well, including some downright heavy rock n roll. Diversity is often a euphemism for fuzziness of focus in pop, but the String Band usually makes it work.

title: Passing of a Hero
description: Charles A. Lindbergh, lifted into instant and lifelong fame by his soulstirring New YorktoParis flight 1927, was both the beneficiary and the victim of a celebrity experienced by no other American in this century.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (Reuters)The Commerce Department reported today that the value of foreign direct investment in the United States rose $3.5billion in 1973 to $17.7billion.

title: Marcos Turns Over An Accused Priest To Church Leaders
description: MANILA, Aug. 27A Jesuit priest accused of rebellion against the martiallaw Government of the Philippines was turned over to the custody of his religious superiors today by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Ehrlichman Case Expected To Go to Coast Court Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 (UPI)The California Supreme Court will probably deliberate tomorrow on whether to suspend John D. Ehrlichman from practicing law because of his Federal conviction in the Ellsberg burglary case, a court spokesman said.

title: Oil Spill Closes Beaches On Outer End of Cape Cod
description: TRURO, Mass., Aug. 27A minor offshore oil spill closed several oceanside beaches to swimming on the outer end of Cape Cod yesterday and today, but officials said they expected all of the affected beaches to be open tomorrow. The incident, it was said, will not interfere with bathing over the Labor Day weekend.

title: N.F.L. Owner Offer Rejected by Players
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) The striking National Football League Players Association voted tonight to remain in camp but rejected a new offer from the owners, sources close to the negotiations disclosed.

title: President Is Planning Holiday, at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)  President Ford and his family are planning to spend the Labor Day weekend at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains.

title: Airline Postpones Plans to Provide CutRate Service
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27Under pressure from the United States Government, the president of an airline that was scheduled to begin cutrate jet flights yesterday between Tijuana, Mexico, 115 miles south of here, and Luxembourg said today that the service had been postponed indefinitely.

title: Eximbank Approves Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (Reuters)The United States ExportImport Bank announced the approval today of a direct credit of $8.8million to Canadian Pacific, Ltd. The money is to help finance the purchase of two Boeing 727 jets at a total cost of $22million by the company's whollyowned subsidiary, Canadian Pacific Air Line, Ltd.

title: If Wife Earns More Than Her Husband, How Do Both Feel?
description: As more and more women move into the wellpaying jobs that were once denied them, a newand sometimes sticky  phenomenon is emerging in the American family. The wife who earns more than her husband.

title: DISMISSAL OPPOSED IN WESTGATE CASE
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 28 (AP) Federal prosecutors opposed motions by C. Arnholt Smith and Philip A. Toft to have the indictment against them dismissed and evidence in the case against them suppressed.

title: Aussie Boat Becomes Challenger
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28With the ease of a fighter hitting a punching bag, Southern Cross routed bluehulled France again today and earned the right to challenge for the America's Cup.

title: 0.7 Inches of Rain Falls On City in 15 Minutes
description: A thunderstorm drenched the city with rain last night, flooding some highways and subways and causing the postponement of a highwire show in Central Park by Philippe Petit, the clandestine aerialist of the World Trade Center.

title: No Contract But Players Stay in Camp
description: The 14day coolingoff period in the National Football League players' strike passed yesterday without any settlement.

title: Maud Muller Takes Gazelle at Belmont; Knee Injury Forces Rotz to Quit Riding
description: Lou Rondinello was able to convey to John Galbreath yesterday some good news that he had been hoping to express all season. Rondinello trains Maud Muller, who is owned by Galbreath andthe filly won the Gazelle Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. The good news that Rondinello was able to convey to Galbreath who was in Canada was that Maud Muller finally finished in front of Quaze Quilt, Fred Hooper's filly. The Florida homebred had beaten Galbreath's filly in three previous races.

title: Sutton and McCall Are Accused on Harlem Project
description: State Senator Sidney A. Von Luther charged yesterday that his Democratic primary opponent, Carl McCall, and Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan were involved in a contract for the undeveloped part of the State Office Building site in Harlem that raises serious questions of conflict of interest and fraud.

title: RICKEL DEFEATED, IN ALASKAN RACE
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 28 (AP) Jay Hammond, a conservationist known for his poetry, won the Republican nomination for Governor in Alaska's primary elections yesterday, defeating former Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel.

title: Open, Friendly Mood In First News Session
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28They call it an open Administration, and the people at President Ford's White House did their best today to convey that feeling at his first news conference.

title: Contract Awards
description: The British Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had received $190million in export orders for a new, more powerful version of the Jaguar fighter aircraft from two countries, neither, of which was identified. Several other countries, B.A.C. said, are considering purchasing the new fighter. The Jaguar was jointly developed by France and Britain.

title: Pothole Wasn't Con Ed's
description: Because of an error by Mayor Beame's office, a hole in the street that a vacationing Tennessee family's automobile fell into was reported to have been dug by the Consolidated Edison Company. A mayoral spokesman said yesterday that a streetpaving contractor, and not the utility, had dug the hole.

title: Consumer Unit to Seek Ads Warning of a Light Danger
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission is going to ask Federal court to force sellers of a potentially fatal household warning light to buy national advertising to warn the public about the product.

title: Brooklyn Girl Wounded In a Crossfire by Police
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn girl was wounded in a police crossfire yesterday afternoon as the police shot and captured an armed man they had sought to question about a slaying in a Bay Ridge gas station on Monday.

title: Coal Strike Expected
description: ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 28 (AP)John P. Fishwick, president of the coalhauling Norfolk & Western Railway, said today, that the line's customers expected a coal mine strike in November and perhaps on into December. He said they were trying to build up their coal stockpiles before the United Mine Yorker's contract expired on Nov. 12.

title: Circus Employe Injured
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 28 (AP)Cary Griffith, a circus employe was injured yesterday when an elephant picked him up, slammed him to the ground and pummeled him with its feet, head and trunk, police reported. He was released from a hospital after treatment. Mr. Griffith works for the Clyde BeattyCole Bros. Circus.

title: To Our Readers
description: Effective Monday, Sept. 2, the newsstand price of the weekday New York Times will be increased from 15 cents to 20 cents in the New York metropolitan area and Long Island. Sharply higher operating casts, particularly the, cost of newsprint, have made this price increase necessary. Beyond a 50mile radius of New York City, the newsstand price of The Times will remain at 20 cents.

title: ROCKEFELLER WOOS SOUTHERN G O. P.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, on his way to dinner and an overnight stay at the White House, met privately today with the Southern Republican state chairmen in an apparently successful effort to reconcile the conservative group to his becoming Vice, President.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS PUSH FOR PACTS
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28(AP)Although the opening day for many public schools is only a week away, 228 school districts in the state have yet to reach contract agreements with teachers.

title: Amex in 14th Straight Decline; OvertheCounter Issues Mixed
description: Lacking any encouraging news, prices on the American Stock Exchange declined again yesterday, marking the 14th consecutive session, to show a drop. Prices in the overthecounter market were mixed.

title: GERMAN BANKERS PAYING REFUNDS
description: BONN, Aug. 28 (UPI)Banking officials took action to restore confidence in West German financial institutions today, paying out refunds following the closing of the fourth private bank within the last few weeks.

title: Bronx Youth's Death Sifted
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Aug. 28 (UPI)  Policemen in Jamaica were investigating today the drowning of a 20yearold Bronx student in the swimminiapool of a local hotel. The body of Melvin Miller war pulled from the pool yesterday by hotel employes. The victim's home address was given as 852 East 216th Street.

title: Trot Classic Is Put Off Day by Rain
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 28They don't often postpone horse races because of bad weather, but they did it here today when rain forced a 24hour delay in the $160,150 Hambletonian, the prestige event of the, trotting world.

title: Gibson Will Accept Proposal To Raise His Pay $15,000
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark said yesterday he would accept the report of a special businessmen's committee that the Mayor's salary be raised from $35,000 to $50,000 annually between this year and, 1976. The Mayor noted: I am the head of a $300million corporation here and I can't think of a single other head of a similar size corporation who gets paid what I get paid.

title: OIL FIND REPORTED BY SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28The first traces of oil have been discovered off, the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CATERPILLAR SUITS REPORTED SETTLED
description: PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 28 (AP)Suits filed by five companies alleging antitrust violations by the Caterpillar Tractor Company have been settled out of court, a Caterpillar spokesman said today.

title: BOSTON TEACHERS ACCEPT 5.5% OFFER
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)Boston schoolteachers agreed today to accept a 5.5 per cent wage increase, effective Sept. 1.

title: Queens Youngsters Enjoy Waning Vacation
NEWS INDEX
Bridg e :
description: Three topranked New York experts will be missing when the traditional Knickerbocker Championships begin tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel. Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag will be in Washington, competing for the right to represent North America in the 1975 World Team Championship. Edgar Kaplan will also be at the International Team Playoff matches, serving as nonplaying captain of the Vanderbilt champions.

title: Sand in My Shoes
description: WASHINGTON  Nothing succeeds like succession.

title: JOHN M'DOWELL
description: John McDowell, who retired a year ago a sdirector for social welfare of the National Council of Churches' department of social justice here, died Tuesday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 223 Hillside Avenue, Bergenfield, N. J.

title: Yanks Beat Twins, 50, On 7Hitter by Dobson
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 28A few hours before tonight's game between the Yankees and Twins, Pat Dobson, the 32yearold New York righthander, said he thought he did his best pitching in warm weather.

title: POPULATION TALKS REVISE PROPOSALS
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 28After dealing with 340 proposed amendments, delegates to the World Population Conference tonight were completing a plan of action, a set of suggested guidelines for nations in formulating population policies.

title: Intrepid Scores a 52Second Triumph By Outmaneuvering Courageous at Start
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 23 The United States' part of the America's Cup racing here has turned completely around in the last 24 hours. Courageous, the new yacht owned by a syndicate of 151 members out of the heart of the New York Yacht Club, was on top going into yesterday's race while Intrepid, the older vessel, was at the threshold of elimination after a valiant fight. At stake is the honor of defending the cup challenger, Southern Cross.

title: Julius Adler Weds Deirdre Elliott
description: Deirdre Spencer Elliott was married here yesterday afternoon to Julius Ochs Adler. State Supreme Court Justice Sidney H. Asch performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment in the presence of members of the immediate families and a few close friends.

title: Open, Friendly Mood In First News Session
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28They call it an open Admin' istration, and the people at President Ford's White House did their best today to convey that feeling at his first news conference.

title: O'Dwyer Deplores Granting Of Contract to Jersey Outfit
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer yesterday deplored the award of a contract for bread and rolls to a New Jersey company.

title: Classes Tests Urged for Show Judges
description: The 6foot5inch darkbearded Derek Rayne is an imposing figure in the ring. Operagoing fanciers agree he could be cast as the traditional Mephistopheles in Faust, especially after he has failed to give their entries a placement.

title: Steve Cady
description: NEWPORT, RI, Aug, 28Heads turn as a rented Impala whips around a corner and lunges to a polopony stop in the narrow driveway at Newport Shipyard.

title: Soviet Navy Has Edges' On U.S., Jane's Says
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (UPI)The Soviet Union has a numerical edge of more than three to one over the United States in submarines, has more than five times as many cruisers and has started to challenge America's long supremacy in aircraft carriers, the authoritative Jane's Fighting Ships says in its 197475 edition, to be issued tomorrow.

title: Commissioner Samuel Hepburn Of Salvation Army Dies at 73
description: Commissioner Samuel Hep burn, who retired in 1971 as national: commander of the Salvation Army in the United States, died yesterday in Los Gatos (Calif.) Community Hospital.Commissioner Hepburn had served with the organization for 52 years. In recognition of his record, he was presented with the Salvation Armys gold medal of honor.

title: Argentine Explosion Kills 5
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 (UPI)An explosion at a meatpacking plant in the southern Argentine town of Cipolletti, yesterday killed five persons, including the owner of the plant, his wife and two sons. Police spokesmen said the blast was accidental.

title: Goy. Hall Deleated in Oklahoma; McSpadden and Boren in Runoff
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 28Late returns from the Democratic primary in Oklahoma yesterday brought defeat to Gov. David Hall's effort to succeed himself in office and to gain a national political reputation.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: F.B.I. in Newark Seizes A Suspect in 5 Murders
description: NEWARK, Aug. 28 (UPI)Eight F.B.I. agents broke down the door of an apartment here early today and arrested John Patrick Tully, sought for more than two years by state, county and Federal authorities on murder, armed robbery and narcotics charges.

title: Lutheran Moderates to Stay in Synod
description: About 1,200 members of the Evangelical Lutherans In Misision ended a threeday convention here by soundly rejecting (proposals for, a voluntary schism and the formation of a new church.

title: Joseph Foster, Art Critic And Author, Is Dead at 69
description: Joseph Foster, a critic and author of works on Chagall, Picasso and other artists, died Tuesday of cancer in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 430 East 65th Street.

title: Accused G.I. Refuses Food
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 28 (AP)A former Air Force sergeant awaiting retrial on an espionage charge was in the 13th day of a hunger strike today pt RichardsGebaur Air Force Base, where he was being held for the delayed trial. Base officials said that Raymond DeChamplain, 43 years old, of Lisbon, Conn., started the hunger strike Aug. 16 in protest against his continued confinement.

title: Bread Price Rises Cent More to New High of 60c
description: The average price of bread in the New York area last week rose another cent to 60 cents, setting a record.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 28John Matuszak, giant 23yearold defensive tackle, switched from the Houston Oilers of the National Football League to the Houston Texans of the World Football League this afternoon.

title: Law Officers Are Found to Be Usually of Dogfighting
description: Investigators of the Cook County State's Attorneys' office are looking into allegations and reported evidence that three police officers in the Chicago area are involved in a dogfighting ring known to operate there.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 28  It has been taken for granted that Jim Dent is the longest driver on the pro golf tour and today, for the sake of formality and $5,000, Dent proved it.

title: Portuguese Army Is Discharging Black Soldiers in Guinea
KISSINGER IS TOPIC OF ISRAELI DEBATE
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 28Secretary of State Kissinger was criticized and defended in the Israeli Parliament here today.

title: Soybeans Rise the Limit; Record Sugar Price Set
description: The farm commodity markets finished with a strong rally yesterday after a tentative opening, and irregular movements until the last minutes of trading.

title: Music: Boris Godunov at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28The Saratoga Festival could hardly be accused of thinking small when it got around last night to mounting the first fully staged opera in its nineyear history.

title: New OilPrice Increase Expected in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  The price of Venezuelan oil will go up again in September, following the rise last month in the exportreference price to $14.43 a barrel from $14.08, Mines Ministry sources said today.

title: Consolidated Foods Net Off 10% In Year Despite 14% Sales Gain
Wheeling Pittsburgh Renews Dividends For Common Stock
description: Directors of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel producer, yesterday declared the company's first dividend on its common stock in 10 years.

title: Surgery for Hankinson
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)Phil Hankinson, Boston Celtics forward, underwent surgery on his left knee today and probably will not be able to play for three months. He reinjured the knee in a scrimmage Saturday.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, AUGUST 29, 1974,
description: President Ford said that any United States move to improve relations with Cuba would be taken in concert with the Organization of American States. He said it was up to Cuba to change her policy firth. His reply to a question at his first formal Presidential news conference came as moves were under way in the O.A.S. to lift its 1974 embargo on trade and diplomatic relations with the Castro regime in Cuba. [1:4.]

title: Soviet Astronauts Land Safely; Space Docking Apparently Fails
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28  The manned spaceship Soyuz 15 returned abruptly to earth today, apparently having failed to achieve a linkup with the Soviet orbital station Salyut 3.

title: Alaskans Vote to Move Capital Inland
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 28Alaskans decided yesterday that it was time to move the Governor's mansion, state office buildings and seat of government inland.

title: Malone Nearer a Pact as Plot Thickens
description: A 19yearold player who has had the basketball world in a turmoil all week is expected to formally sign a multiyear contract with the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association here this afternoon.

title: Dominican Order Chooses Frenchman as New Leader
description: ROME, Aug. 28  The 758yearold Dominican Order today chose a new head, or master general.

title: 4 Abduct Kinsman Of Mexican Leader
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Aug. 28A band of terrorists kidnapped President Luis Echeverria Alvarez's 83yearold fatherinlaw today, according to the Mexican police.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The case against former, Police Officer William R. Phillips, charged with the 1968 Christmas Eve slaying of an East Side pimp and a prostitute, was reopened yesterday at a pretrial hearing in which the existence of three new witnesses was revealed by the prosecution.

title: HEALTHCARE AIM DRAWS CRITICISM
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28  Proposed regulations governing establishment of healthmaintenance organizations  prepaid comprehensive healthcare plane  throughout the state were criticized at a public hearing here today for not including psychiatric care and basic health services.

title: FORD LINKS A SHIFT ON CUBA TO O.A.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 President Ford said today that the United States would act in concert with the rest of the Organization of American States in any moves to improve relations with Cuba.

title: U.S. Seniors Win Stevens Cup Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 28  The United States retained the Stevens Cup by defeating Australia, 21, in the final of the international senior tennis competition at the Concord Hotel today.

title: WBAIFM TO DROP PROGRAMS IN TEST
description: WBAI, the FM radio station supported by listener contributions, will drop most of its regular programs during Sepstember and the early part of October, in order to reexamine all of its programing.

title: Notes on People Gierek to Visit Ford
description: Edward Glerek, chief of the Communist party in Poland and that country's leader, will make an official visit to President Ford on Oct. 89, the White House announced yesterday. There has not been a comparable visit in the past by a leader of the Polish People's Republic, said John W. Hushen, deputy press secretary.

title: 4 Abduct Kinsman Of Mexican Leader
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Aug. 28A band of terrorists kidnapped President Luis Echeverria Alvarez's. 83yeapold fatherinlaw today, according to the Mexican police.

title: Just Be Sure Not to Eat the Shampoo
description: Careful, that may be soap soup bubbling on Rose Goldemberg's kitchen stove; the dinner stew is on the other burner. It's not uncommon for Mrs. Goldemberg to be cooking a family meal at the same time she's simmering a batch of cream or shampoo. (The soap soup is a base of some of her cosmetics).

title: Business Briefs
description: Saudis Shift Gold Held at Fed Bank

title: OTB to Open 133d Office
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation will open its 133d branch office tomorrow at 564 West 181st Street.

title: Personal Finance: StudentLoan Squeeze
description: Student loans are widely considered very difficult to obtain. But a spot check of major lenders in the area showed that while it may be quite difficult to get one in New Jersey such a loan may be fairly easy to obtain in New York and Connecticut.

title: Marine Casualty Identified
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 28 (UPI)  The Marine Corps identified yesterday marine who fell to his death from a rope beneath a helicopter. He was Hospital Corpsman 3d Cl. Gregory Joseph Zane, of Warren, Mich.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The warnings about illusory savings to be had by buying meat in bulk have been around for some time, but now, finally, there are some downtoearth, practical facts and figures that should make the consumer think, twice before buying that way.

title: Mr. Ford Stands Pat
description: President Ford gave no slightest evidence in yesterday's news conference that he has even begun to rethink the economic policies he inherited from the Nixon Administration. While insisting on his openness to new and. realistic suggestions for dealing with the nation's economic problems, Mr. Ford has thus far preached nothing but the oldtime religion of budgetcutting, monetary. restraint and handsoff wages and prices. His holdover team of economic true believers has now been shifted even further to the right with the replacement of Herbert Stein by Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Autopsy Finds 2 Texas Convicts Were Shot by Lawmen in Break
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug, 28 (UPI)An autopsy report released today said that Fred Gomez Carrasco and Rudolfo Dominguez were shot and killed by law officers in their attempt to escape from the Texas State Prison after holding 12 hostages for days.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market declined again yesterday in active trading as investors showed a mostly negative reaction to President Ford's news conference.

title: Tanker Construction Rules Called Lax
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Coast Guard and its parent organization, the Department of Transportation, have come under intense attack for proposing regulations for construction of Americanbuilt coastal oil tankers that, critics say do not provide the maximum protection possible for the marine environment.

title: Striking Workers At Western Electric To Study Pay Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 28 (AP)The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers agreed today to submit for membership approval a modified wage package covering 60,000 striking Western Electric Company workers nationwide.

title: 4,000 GO ON STRIKE AT UNITED PARCEL
description: Union employes struck th?? United Parcel Service last nigh in a dispute over a new contract, halting today's packag?? deliveries in Manhattan, Brook lyn, Queens, the Bronx an?? Westchester, Nassau and Suf folk Counties.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WAY LIFE WAS. Text by Jeffrey Simpson. Pictures by 18 photographers. 220 pages. Praeger. $19.95.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: SOUTHWEST MIRAMICHI RIVER, New Brunswisk, CanadaHaving caught only two grilse on a salmon fishing trip to the Miramichi River earlier this summer, I embraced the opportunity to return to that lovely stream with Jack Samson, Hugh Grey and Dave Newell.

title: I GOTCHA SQUAD IN STATE IS DENIED
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28Charges that an lite squad of state poAlice officers was systematically intimidating local politicians and businessmen in southern New Jersey were described here today by Attorney General William F. Hyland as false and irresponsible.

title: 6 Seized on Gambling Charges In Raids at 4 S.I. Wire Rooms
description: Plainclothes police officers smashed their way into a house in a wooded section of Staten Island yesterday and raided three nearby sites to break up what they said was a gambling operation that handled $7millionayear in sports bets.

title: 3 Seized After Protest In Office of V.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Two young men and a young woman forced their way into the office of the Administrator of Veterans Affairs today, nailed his door shut, talked to him, and then were arrested.

title: DR. ALVIN R. HARNES
description: Dr. Alvin R. Harnes of 730 Park Avenue, who practiced medicine here for 40 years until his retirement 10 years ago, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 80. Dr. Harnes is survived by a son, Jack R. Harnes, and three grandchildren.

title: City Finds It Can't Police Private Refuse Cartnien
description: City officials have conceded that they do not have the manpower to police adequately the operations of private refuse cartmen.

title: DECISION PUT OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28President Ford said today that he subscribed to the belief that former President Richard M. Nixon had been punished enough for the Watergate scandals, and that he was leaving open the option of granting Mr. Nixon protection from prosecution or granting him a pardon.

title: Newcombe, Rosewall, Nastase Lead Advance of Favorites at Forest Hills
description: Opening day at the United States Open tennis championships in Forest Hills, Queens, provided surprises, tiffs and sultry weather yesterday, but not the sort a fan had come to expect.

title: F. LEDBETTER, BOSTON UROLNISI
description: Dr. Wyland F. Leadbetter who retired in 1969 chief of urology at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and clinical Professor of surgery at the Harvard Medical School died yesterday at the hospital. He was 67 years old..

title: Jersey Official Asks End To Jail for Drug Addicts
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that he would support legislation that decriminalized drug addiction and the personal use of marijuana in New Jersey.

title: LIGHT, AIRY PHRASES ON KONITZ ALTO SAX
description: Lee Konitz, the alto saxophonist who was one of the major figures of the cool jazz movement in the late nineteenforties, has been an elusive figure on the jazz scene here for many years. He has been playing in rather obscure situations and for only one or two nights at a time. Now, however, he is playing four nights a week, every week  at Stryker's Pub, 103 West 86th Street, on Wednesdays and Thursdays, and at Gregory's, First Avenue at 63d Street, on Mondays and Tuesdays.

title: COURT AGAIN BACKS DUMPING OF IRON ORE
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP)A threejudge Federal Appeals Court granted today continuance of an order that will, in effect, allow the Reserve Mining Company to keep open its ironore plant on Lake Superior until at least December.

title: Carnegie Hill Gains Backing as Historic District
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday backed the designation of two sections of townhouses and other lowrise residential buildings in the East Nineties as the Carnegie Hill historic district.

title: Lindsay Era Retires to Archives
description: Harassed by the complexities of a new job, Mayor John V. Lindsay dashed off a letter in February, 1966, complaining about a political compatriot who had been complaining about him.

title: Rail Hearings Put Off
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The state announced today that public hearings concerning two railroads had been postponed indefinitely because negotiations between the rail lines and the state were still under way. The hearings had been set for Thursday in New Brunswick for the Penn Central Railroad, and for Sept. 5 in Ocean City for the PennsylvaniaReading Seashore Line.

title: Southmen Inflict Loss On Blazers
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP)  John Harvey scored on a 49yard run and ran 137 yards tonight, leading the Memphis Southmen to a 2618 World Football League victory over the Florida Blazers.

title: PORTUGAL BREAKS STRIKE ON AIRLINE
description: LISBON, Aug. 28The Government imposed martial law early today on striking ground personnel who had paralyzed Portugal's national airline, T.A.P., since late Monday.

title: Penn Central Bronx Yard Sought as Industrial Park
description: The city is negotiating with the bankrupt Penn Central Raliroad to buy the line's 100acre Mott Haven Yard in the Sonth Bronx and turn it into an industrial park.

title: U.S. Education Aide Quits, Citing Personal Reasons
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28(Thomas K. Glennan Jr., the first director of the National Institute of Education, said today that he was resigning, largely for personal reasons.

title: EHRLICHMAN PLEA DENIED BY BURGER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Chief Justice Warren E. Burger denied today a request by John D. Ehrlichman that the Watergate conspiracy trial be postponed until next year. The Move virtually assured that the trial will open here Sept. 30.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium; Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 4:15 P.M. (Radio  WHN, 4:15 P.M.) (Television  Channel 9, 4:15 P.M.)

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh said yesterday he was extremely optimistic about shortly receiving a $168,110 Federal grant to set up a sexcrime prosecution unit. Mr. Kuh based his optimism on conversations with the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services and the city's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council, which administer locally Federal lawenforcement assistance administration funds.

title: JOSEPH S. RESNICK, 71, CAMP DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Joseph S. Resnick, for many years a director with his wife, the former Molly Schmelnik, who died in 1968, of children's camps in the Northeast, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Stanfordville, N. Y., where he lived. He was 71 years old.

title: Saudi Minister Is in U.S. For Talks With Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Omar Saqqaf of Saudi Arabia arrived here today for talks, on the Middle East with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Housing Industry Hope's for Action by U.S.
description: Leaders in the, beleaguered housing industry said yesterday that only vigorous action by the Ford' Administration provided a prospect for, prompt recovery from the industry's severe slump.

title: Congress Study Backs Research on Weather
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  Government research on weather modification may make it possible to alleviate drought, reduce destructive forces of hurricanes, suppress lightning and damaging hail and dissipate fog a report to Congress says.

title: Bread Price Rises Cent More to 60c
description: The average price of bread in the New York area last week rose another cent to 60 cents, setting a record.

title: U.S. Seniors Win Stevens Cup Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 28  The United States retained the Stevens Cup by defeating Australia, 21, in the final of the international senior tennis competition at the Concord Hotel today.

title: KARL KELLER
description: Karl Keller, who retired in 1955 as chairman of the Keuffel & Esser Company, manufacturer and importer of scientific instruments, died on Tuesday at his home, 20 Beacon Road, Summit, N. J. He was 94 years old.

title: TURKS HAIL ECEVIT IN CYPRUS VICTORY
description: IZMIT, Turkey, Aug, 28Premier Bulent Ecevit urged today that national excitement over Turkey's military success in Cyprus be turned toward overcoming this country's problems in economic development and social justice.

title: On Both Sides in Cyprus, Little Hope for Peace
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 28 Although the killing has subsided on this beautiful island, politicians and diplomats maneuver in other countries to arrange another round of Cyprus negotiations and most people hereTurks and Greeksfeel that it is only a matter of time before the bloodshed will start again.

title: OIL FIND REPORTED BY SOUTH VIETNAN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28The first traces of oil have been discovered off the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Cousins, Home, Charged As Juvenile Delinquents
description: RIDGEFIELD PARK, Aug. 28 The two 12yearold cousins who were found in the shore community of Wildwood last night after they had been missing from home since Saturday were charged with juvenile delinquency today by the Ridgefield Park police.

title: For Keeping the Heat On
description: HOUSTONSince Richard M. Nixon's resignation, several themes have dominated public discussion of the departed Administration.

title: 299Day Bills Sold By U.S Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Treasury sold today $2billion of 299day bills at an average rate of 9.767 per cent. The statistics on the auction follow:

title: Putting the Outside Inside the Fence of Law
description: LOS ANGELESThe notion of extending legal rights; to environmental objects  oceans, rivers, forests sounds absurd and unthinkable when first encountered. But viewed historically, it is not so. The entire history of the law has been an everwidening extension in those things accorded legal rights, and thus constituted persons within the law.

title: PRESIDENT BARS USE OF CONTROLS TOCURB INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28President Ford said today that he would approach a massive public employment program with compassion and action if it became necessary, but he firmly rejected any return to wage and price controls to curb inflation.

title: Ode to Joy Adopted As Rhodesia's Anthem
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Rhodesia has annnced a new national anthemthe Ode to Joy from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

title: City and Election Workers Split On New Pact as Primary Nears
description: With the Sept. 10 primary election less than two weeks away, the city and the union representing fulltime employes of the Board of Elections were still far apart yesterday on settlement of a new labor contract two months after the old one expired.

title: Burns Averts U.S. Golf Upset at 19th
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 28 George Burns, far from being an old golfer at 25, said, Gee, the whole year would have gone down the drain if I'd lost to a 17yearold kid out here. But I'm sorry, sort of, that it ended that way.

title: ROSE D. SELIGSBERG
description: Mrs. Rose D. Seligsberg, widow of Albert J. Seligsberg, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firms of Seligsberg & Co. and Hirsch & Co., died Tuesday at her home, 737 Park Avenue.

title: CHARGE BY SEOUL IRKS NORTH KOREA
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28  North Korea has increased its denunciations of the South Korean Government in reaction to charges from Seoul that it was responsible for the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee on Aug. 15.

title: Philippines Arrest 57 in Sabotage Case
description: MANILA, Aug. 28  The Philippine Defense Department said today that 57 people had been arrested in a crackdown on underground Communist units that had been smuggling in arms and manufacturing explosives to sabotage the Government.

title: Europe to Reduce Imports Of American Feed Grains
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Agricultural Commissioner of the European Economic Community, ending two days of talks with, Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, said today that good wheat crops in the member countries would make it possible for them to restrain imports of United States corn and other livestock feed grains.

title: Presidential Clemency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, got the word today from the President of the United States. The word was: Let justice take its course in the case of Richard M. Nixonup to a point. That point will apparently be when and if President Ford decides to exercise his Presidential option of extending clemency to the former President.

title: Reservation System Ended At Federal Park Campsites
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  The National Park Service announced today that it was abandoning its reservation system for national park campsites.

title: DR. ALVIN R. HARNES
description: Dr. Alvin R. Hames of 730 Park Avenue, who practiced medicine here for 40 years until his retirement 10 years ago, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 80. Dr. Hames is survived by a son, Jack R. Harnes, and three grandchildren.

title: New Zealand Leader III
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 28Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk has been hospitalized again and ordered to take a complete break of six Weeks from work. Mr. Kirk, 51 years old first entered a hospital in early April for surgery on varlcose veins in his legs.

title: U.S. Reports Economic Outlook Showed an Improvement in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The Government's measure of future trends in the economy rebounded in July on the strength of an improved job picture and labor costs, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LATIN FLAIR The Chateau Madrid is one of the leaders of the establishment when it comes to Spanish and Latinflavored entertainment. For 16 years it was on West 58th Street, and then six years ago it moved to the Lexington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and 48th Street: Last week, the ownership changed hands, and the Chateau Madrid (PL 28080) decided to bask in its success by keeping its doors open Tuesday evenings.

title: EVIDENCE IS GIVEN ON FUND EVASION
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 28An opinion poll on voter sentiment taken prior to the May 14 municipal elections in Paterson was produced at a hearing by the Election Law Enforcement Commission here today as evidence seeking to show that Mayor Lawrence Kramer tried to evade state campaignspending limits.

title: $75,000 Big Board Seat
description: The New York Stock Exchange sold a membership yesterday at $75,000, unchanged from the previous sale on Aug. 22. Seats currently are quoted at $60,000 bid and $95,000 offered.

title: M'CORD SUBPOENAS PRESIDENTIAL TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 James W. McCord Jr., one of the men convicted in the Watergate breakin, has subpoenaed Presidential tapes for use in his civil lawsuit.

title: Opera: Season Opener
description: The City Opera led off its land) series of the last few izetti's Lucia di Lammermoor last night at the New York State Theater. This breaks Beverly Sills's QueenofEngland (or maybe Scotland) series of the last few years. It was good to see her back as Lucia, and equally pleasant to see her with a really good partner. Jos Carreras an the last few years has been heading steadily for the big time, and last night's performance shows that he is ready to sing against Miss Sills or anybody else.

title: WESTERNERS FLEE BLAZE IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28A fire swept through a pavilion at MOSCOW'S principal exhibition grounds today, burning out the structure and forcing Western businessmen and Soviet workmen to leap through windows to safety.

title: EXIMBANK LOANS SET ON BUYING OF 10 JETS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  The United States ExportImport Bank said today it had approved loans to help finance the purchase of six McDonnell Douglas Corporation jets valued at $108.5million and four Lockheed Aircraft Corporation planes valued at $68million to three foreign airlines.

title: PRICES MARKED UP ON QUALITY BONDS
description: Prices of the bettergrade corporate and taxexempt bonds were marked up a halfpoint or so early yesterday as the sales of the week's big offerings progressed beyond expectations. Late in the day, however, prices were shaved somewhat as the market failed to find any constructive news in the President's news conference or any significant institutional interest in their wares.

title: Cyprus Preliminaries
description: It has long been obvious that a satisfactory Cyprus solution would have to be worked out at several different levels; and it would be well, therefore, if everyone concerned would stop quibbling about different forums and get on with essential preliminaries. One such preliminary is the convening of the United Nations Security Council today to take up the problem of the 200,000 Cypriotes displaced by Turkey's military advance.

title: FIGHTING NEAR HUE IS FIRST IN MONTHS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug, 29 (AP)The South Vietnamese command today reported heavy fighting for the first time in several months near the old imperial capital of Hue on the northern coast.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CanAm Race Canceled

title: Upstate Fort to Be Rebuilt
description: WASHINGTON, (UPI)  The Interior Department has announced it has contracted for the reconstruction of Fort Stanwix, a milestone on the road to American independence. A $4.3million contract has been awarded to B.S. McCarey Company of Rome, N.Y., to rebuild the 1758 log fort in the Mohawk Valley.

title: Courageous vs. Intrepid : Results in final Trials
description: Club selection committee and at this late date about all one can do it fiddle with sails.

title: Can Rock and Pop Be Folk Music?
description: After a weekend absorbing the musical smorgasbord offered by the Philadelphia Folk Festival, one's idea of what constitutes folk music can be left in a state of some confusion.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: On Both Sides in Cyprus, Little Hope for Peace
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 28 Although the killing has subsided on this beautiful island, politicians and diplomats maneuver in other countries to arrange another round of Cyprus negotiations and most people hereTurks and Greeksfeel that it is only a matter of time before the bloodshed will start again.

title: Croup Led by Hamilton Fish Sr. Appeals for Leniency for Nixon
description: An organization called Operation Freedom, headed by tormer Representative Hamilton Fish Sr., placed a halfpage advertisement in three newspapers Tuesday and yesterday urging that former President Richard M. Nixon not be prosecuted for his involvement in the Watergate coverup.

title: Fuel Outlook Bright For Holiday Travel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 28 (AP)  Labor Day holiday travelers should have little trouble finding gasoline, according to the American Automobile Association.

title: Transcript of Ford's First News Conference Since He Assumed the Presidency
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's first news conference from the East Room of the White House in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CBS Abandons Plans For TV of Knievel Leap
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 28 (AP) The concern that is promoting the leap across the Snake River canyon by Evel Knievel, the motorcycle stuntman, won a showdown today when the CBS network abandoned plans to bid for live television coverage.

title: CLASSIFIED  ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: In Germany the Prices Stay High
description: ALTENMITTLAU, West GermanyFifty thousand tons of surplus beef are sitting in refrigerated warehouses in West Germany.

title: The Screen:' Savage Sisters' Views the Right to Fight
description: It was a bit rum to see "Savage Sisters" on the 54th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote. The movie, which is more concerned with the right to fight, opened yesterday at the Penthouse and RKO 86th Street Twin I theaters.Entangled in a plot of staggering complexity, three women "subversives"including an American dropout from the Social Registerwage the revolution on a nameless leafy island. The inhabitants of this mango republic appear to be the result of an awesome genetic break-through: some seem Oriental, some Latin-American, and others suggest Arabs. Reeling in pursuit of a million dollars that no one wants to share is John Ashley, the co-producer as well as a member of the movie cast. His voice rises frequently to a squawk, and that desperate note sounds like an anticipation of the rushes.Jail is the place for sexual games, and no woman can wield a rifle unless her shirt's unbuttoned. But the movie's just too silly to be offensive. If forgiveness is the national mood of August, 1974, we might as well extend some to "Savage Sisters."

title: New Jersey Sports
description: UNION, Aug, 29When you mention Al LoBalbo's name, basketball comes to mind almost immediately.

title: Cyprus Impasse: A Test of the Alternatives to Force
description: ATHENS, Aug. 28When Greece accepted the Soviet proposal for an international conference on Cyprus, she warned the Russians that she did not want to participate in another propaganda forum. Any new meeting, the Greeks said, should consider specific ways and means for carrying out the United Nations Security Council resolutions that have called for removal of foreign troops from the island.

title: ACUTE SHORTAGES IN INDUSTRY CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Major American industries are blaming the energy crisis, economic and environmental controls and high interest rates for shortages of critical materials that could further increase the prices of consumer goods.

title: Move to Study Foreign Investing in U.S. Reflects Concern on Rising Trend and Lack of Fresh Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The legislation that was passed overwhelmingly by the House of Representatives last week authorizing the Government to study all foreign investments in the United States was supported by various people for various reasons. But both its Congressional and Administration backers had an important consideration in common: The increasing trend in foreign investment in this country coupled with the fact that the information available on it is simply and badly outdated.

title: City Wavers on Bill To License Sellers Of Hearing Aids
description: Witnesses at a City Council Consumer Affairs Committee hearing yesterday agreed that legislation requiring the licensing of hearingaid, dealers was needed, but they disagreed on the substance of the law and whether it should be state or local.

title: Florida Agency Seeks Owners Of Millions in Bank Accounts
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP)Attention Harry Peters or his descendants: Call 9044882543. It could be worth more than $33,000 to you.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Black Lawmaker Sues U.S. Over South African Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28A black Representative filed suit here today, charging Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent with violating international obligations and United States laws by permitting discussions with South African authorities on the import of fur seal skins from SouthWest Africa.

title: Lindsay Era Retires to Archives
description: Harassed by the complexities of a new job, Mayor John V. Lindsay dashed off a letter in February, 1966, complaining about a political compatriot who had been complaining about him.

title: North American Phillips Seeks Magnavox Shares
description: The North Americal Phillips Corporation announced yesterday that it would make an offer for all common shares of the Magnavox Company at $8 a share. The acquisition, if completed, would require an outlay of more than $142million for the 17.7million Magnavox common shares outstanding.

title: 7 Men Shot in Morocco For Plot to Oust Hassan
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Seven men have been executed by a Moroccan firing squad for their part in an armed uprising against King Hassan II last year, defense lawyers said today.

title: Wilson Poses With Beauty Queens, Hails Feminists
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 27After repeatedly posing for pictures lat the side of two continuously smiling beauty queens  Miss Dairy Printess and Miss New York State Governor Wilson journeyed westward to Seneca Falls to pay solemn tribute to the village's new role as a feminist shrine where the women's suffrage fight was born.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Advertising: Face Lift at J.W.T.
description: Don Johnston, who was elected president of the world's largest advertising agency in the same month that another man from Michigan became President of the United States, also has his work cut out for him.

title: Simple Service for Lif dbergh Held at Tiny Church in Hawaii
description: HANA, Hawaii, Aug. 28 (AP) A simple memorial service was held yesterday for Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: In NerveRacking Times, Everybody Looks for His Own Remedy
description: Labor Day is almost here, and that means the impending end of the lazy days of summerthe little red wagon at the Fire Island house will have to be stored; the Adirondack vacation days are all spent. Another tense bout with Future Shock is almost upon us! And September's song will surely be. sung to the tune of jangling nervesunless, of course, there's some way to calm them...

title: Soviet Astronauts Land Safely; Space Docking Apparently Fails
description: MOSCOW, Aug., 28  The manned spaceship Soyuz 15 returned abruptly to earth today, apparently having failed to achieve a linkup with the Soviet orbital station Salyut 3.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: SOUTHWEST MIRAMICHI RIVER, New Brunswisk, CanadaHaving caught only two grilse on a salmon fishing trip to the Miramichi River earlier this summer, I embraced the opportunity to return to that lovely stream with Jack Samson, Hugh Grey and Dave Newell.

title: To Our Readers
description: Effective Monday, Sept. 2, the newsstand price of the weekday New York Times will be increased from 15 cents to 20 cents in the New York metropolitan area and Long Island. Sharply higher operating costs, particularly the cost of newsprint, have made this price increase necessary. Beyond a 50mile radius of New York City, the newsstand price of The Times will remain at 20 cents.

title: IRANIAN MIDSHIPMAN IS FREED IN MICHIGAN
description: PETOSKEY, Mich, Aug. 28 A Michigan judge has released from custody an Iranian midshipman after getting a signed document from Iranian officials assuring that the 22yearold would get only light punishment for deserting his training unit at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas.

title: 16 HURT AS BUS HITS CARS IN CONNECTICUT
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP)Sixteen persons were in* jured tonight when the bus in which they were riding crashed into two unoccupied parked cars on a shoulder of Interstate 84 here, the state police said.

title: Chess: Hort Points Out the Holes In the Swiss Pairing System
description: Early in the United States Open Championship, Vlastimil Hort, the top. Czech grandmaster who emerged as cochampion with Pal Benko, complained to me about Swiss system events, saying that they involved handicaps.

title: WENTWORTH HuBBARD
description: Wentworth P. Hubbard, vice president for sales with the General Indicator Corporation Pardeeville, Wis., died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 53 years old and Hired at 232 West 32d Street:

title: British Airways Sets Profit Of 38.5Million in 1974 Year
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP)British Airways reported today its new Profit jumped to $38.5million in the year ended March 31, from $12.8million a year earlier.

title: Starr Says City Is Losing 36,000 Apartments a Year
description: Landlords are abandoning about 300 buildings a month in the city, for a loss of about 36,000 aparments a year, according to Roger Starr, the Housing and Development Administrator.

title: Com merce in Dolphins
description: Between a profitminded fishing industry p g try and a footdragging bureaucracy, the dolphinthat delightful and highly developed creature of the seascontinues to suffer wholly needless extermination.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 28  Instead of a calm repetition of last week's 4310 rout of the Houston Texans, the New York Stars ran into a bizarre and emotionally charged situation tonight and suffered a 1411 defeat, which ended their fivegame winning streak in the World Football League.

title: 450 Holiday Deaths Forecast
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) The National Safety Council estimates that 450 to 550 persons may die in traffic accidents over the Labor Day weekend. The fatality toll will be counted from 6 P.M. local time Friday to midnight Monday  a 78hour period.

title: Tired of the Same Old Cookout? Try an Oriental Barbecue
description: For better or for worse (and we consider it our loss), we have never been in Vietnam. For a long time, however, we have been intrigued with the brief glimpses and flavors of Vietnamese cooking we have experienced on occasional visits to Paris, which boasts several very good Vietnamese restaurants. We are still haunted by the foods we have dined on there including the rouleaux du printemps, or spring rolls; the canard lacque or lacquered duck; and the various and exotic vegetable dishes that frequently contain poussebambou or bamboo shoots and germesde soja or bean sprouts.

title: JOHN M'DOWELL
description: John McDowell, who retired la year ago as director for soi cial welfare of the National Council of Churches department of social justice here, died Tuesday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He, was 65 years old and lived at 223 Hillside Avenue, Bergenfield, N. J.

title: Bell Defends a Clause That Passes Costs On
description: NEWARK, Aug. 28  The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, in a brief aimed at defending a controversial costadjustment clause against a challenge by the Public Advocate, contended today that the clause had enabled it to put off a request for a rate increase by 18 months.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The warnings about illusory savings to be had by buying meat in bulk have been around for some time, but now, finally, there are some downtoearth, practical facts and figures that should make the consumer think twice before buying that way.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Decreased vehicular traffic since the beginning of the energy crisis last fall has resulted in marked declines in accident and fatality rates on the New Jersey Turnpike, officials said. A spokesman for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority said accident and fatality rates declined 31.5 per cent and 50 per cent, respectively, between last November and July 31, compared with the comparable period in 197273. The number of accidents dropped from 1,796 to 1,230 while the number of fatalities declined from 50 to 25, the spokesman said. The decrease was attributed to fewer motorists and lower speed limits.

title: Refrigerator Prices Increased By PhilcoFord 3d Time in '74
description: The PhilcoFord Corporation of Blue Bell, Pa., announced yesterday an averaged price increase on its refrigerators of 9.3 per cent, the third increase this year. The rise is effective Sept. 1. An earlier increase of 6.2 per cent was applied at the beginning of July and another of 5 per cent in March.

title: Navy Lags in Recruiting, With 86% of Its July Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)  Unlike the Army, the Navy failed to come anywhere near its recruiting goals in July, Pentagon statistics showed today.

title: ROSE D. SELIGSBERG
description: Mrs. Rose D. Seligsberg, widow of Albert J. Seligsberg, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firms. of Sagsberg &, Co. and Hirsch & Co., died Tuesday at her home, 737 Park Avenue.

title: Fund for the Elderly Pits Newark Against County
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Aug. 28 Newark and Essex County clashed today over which should administer funds for the city's elderly the dispute came at a public hearing at Rider College on allocation of $5.7million in Federal funds for elderly people in the state during the 1975 fiscal year.

title: PAPER SHUT DOWN IN BUENOS AIRES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28The Argentine Government has closed down the only newspaper of the Peronist left, heightening further the confrontation between President Isabel Martinez de Pern and the more radical, youthful followers of her late husband, Gen, Juan Domingo Pern.

title: KARL KELLER
description: Karl Keller, who retired in 1955 as chairman of the Keuffel & Esser Company, manufacturer and importer of scientific instruments, died on Tuesday at his home, 20 Beacon Road, Summit, N. J. He was 94 years old.

title: Stadium Repairs Touch All Bases
description: The most valuable player at Yankee Stadium this season may be Gene Marconi or Richard Muller.

title: TIMES TO INCREASE DAILY PRICE TO 20C
description: The newsstand price of The New York Times on weekdays will be increased on Monday to 20 cents from 15 cents in New York City and in suburban areas within a 50mile radius of the city, as well as on all of Long Island.

title: SAMUELS BACKED BY 6 UNION CHIEFS
description: Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers of America, and five other presidents of national unions endorsed Howard J. Samuels yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Borden and Chase Plan Tokyo Exchange Listing
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (UPI)Two United States concerns today asked the Finance Ministry for permission to list their stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, ministry sources reported.

title: Nixon's New Lawyer Herbert John Miller Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug: 28He's a natural, Richard Moore said. The job description fits him.

title: Boy Scouts Ask Dismissal Of N.A.A.C.P. Racial Suit
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 28 (AP)The Boy Scouts of America has denied allegations of racial discrimination in troops spensored by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints and asked for dismissal of a lawsuit by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: DECISION PUT OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 President Ford said today that he subscribed to the belief that former President Richard M. Nixon had been punished enough for the Watergate scandals, and that he was leaving open the option of granting Mr. Nixon protection from ptosecution or granting him a pardon.

title: Joseph Foster, Art Critic And Author, Is Dead at 69
description: Joseph Foster, a ethic, and author of works on Chagall, Picasso and other artists, died Tuesday of cancer in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 09 years old and lived at 430 East 65th, Street.

title: LOAN OF NAVY CRAFT TO TURKS PROTESTED
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 28 (AP) Concern over Turkish military intervention in Cyprus transformed the routine loan today of an old United States amphibious landing craft to Turkey into a controversial move assailed by citizens and members of Congress.

title: Polluted Blood
description: The latest Governmentsponsored study of the effects of air pollution, particularly in the nation's largest cities, shows that automobile fumes are causing what appalled medical researchers call an astonishing threat to the health of vast numbers of persons.

title: U.N. Sets Cyprus Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 (Reuters)The United Nations Security Council will resume debate on the Cyprus crisis tomorrow, it was announced today. Delegates decided to go ahead with the meeting, requested last night by the Cypriote Ambassador, Zenon Rossides, despite a sudden illness of Secretary General Waldheim, who returned from the eastern Mediterranean yesterday.

title: Brazil Epidemic Toll at 500
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 28 (AP)Health officials said today that 12 deaths from men. ingitis were recorded Monday. It was the highest 24hour death toll since the outbreak of meningoccal meningitis here two months ago. Official statis. tics indicate that more than 500 persons have died in the epidemic.

title: W. F. LEADBETTER, BOSTON UROLOGIST
description: Dr. Wyland F. Leadbetter, who retired in 1969 as chief of urology at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and clinical professor of surgery at the Harvard Medical School, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Fund Influx a Worry
description: Legislation passed recently to authorize the Government to study all foreign investments in the United States reflects both the concern with the trend of rising foreign investment and the fact that, the information on it is badly outdated. Page 44.

title: People and Business
description: The American economy stands in danger of the worst recession of the postwar period, Otto Eckstein, Harvard University economist and president of Data Resources, Inc., said yesterday.

title: G.E. Nuclear Division Weighs Closing Midwest Fuel Plant
description: The General Electric Company's nuclear division has told the Atomic Energy Cornmission that it has extensive problems with the advanced technology being used in its fuelrecovery plant near Chicago and may decide to scrap the project.

title: New Coal Dispute Recalls Bloody Harlan
description: HARLAN, Ky., Aug. 28Men like Dock Farley are as much a part of the natural order of the Appalachian coal country as the sharptoothed, bluegreen mountains, shrouded now in a soft that haze, that march ridge upon magnificent ridge into the distance and crown this sometimes harsh land near the Virginia state line with an almost breathtaking beauty.

title: Sadat Says He Will Give Up Premiership Held Since '73
description: CAIRO, Aug. 28 (Reuters) President Anwar elSadat announced plans today to resign from the premiership he assumed last year in addition to the presidential post at the time when his country was preparing For the October war with Israel.

title: Stadium Repairs Touch All Bases
description: The most valuable player at Yankee Stadium this season may be Gene Marconi or Richard Muller.

title: PRESIDENT BARS USE OP CONTROLS TO CURB INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28President Ford said today that he would approach a massive public employment program with compaision and action' if it became necessary, but h?? firmly rejected any return to wage and price controls to curt inflation.

title: Drug Runners Described As a Hazard to Mariners
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 Congressional and Coast Guard investigators agreed today that drug runners bent on hijacking yachts and other pleasure boats to use in plying their trade were a definite menace to mariners, particularly in the Caribbean and adjacent waters.

title: FORD LINKS A SHIFT ON CUBA TO O.A.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 President Ford said today that the United States would act in concert with the rest of the Organization of American States in any moves to improve relations with Cuba.

title: Penn Central Bronx Yard Sought as Industrial Park
description: The city is negotiating with the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to buy the line's 100acre Mott Haven Yard in the South Bronx and turn it into an industrial park.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Tims

title: Nixon Is Said to Be Open To $2MiIlion for Memoirs
description: Roger W. Straus Jr., the book publisher, said yesterday that his company, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, had been told by a reliable intermediary. this month that former President Richard M. Nixon would entertain an offer of $2million for the rights to publish his memoirs.

title: WENTWORTH HUBBARD
description: Wentworth P. Htibbard, vice president for sales with the General Indicator Corporation of Ptirdeeville, Wis., died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 232 West 32d Street.

title: Group Decries Treatment Of 4 Jailed in an Arms Plot
description: The IrishAmerican Legal Aid Fund charged yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Prisons was persecuting, as political prisoners, four men convicted last May of conspiring to send arms to Northern Ireland.

title: Ford Signs $3.2Billion Bill For Transportation Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) President Ford has signed a bill appropriating $3.2billion for the Department of Transportation and related agencies, a spokesman announced today.

title: CONSUMERS POWER FILES NUCLEAR SUIT
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug28 (AP)  The Consumers Power Company filed suit today seeking at least $300million in damages from five companies that supplied equipment for and built its troubled Palisades nuclear plant.

title: Simple Service for Lindbergh Held at Tiny Church, in Hawaii
description: HANA, Hawaii, Aug. 28 (AP) A simple memorial service was held yesterday for Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: British Soccer Results
NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: Hyland Urges End To Jail for Addicts
description: TRENTON, Aug, 28State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that he would support legislation that decriminalized drug addiction and the personal use of marijuana in New Jersey.

title: Israell Patrol Confronts Soviet Minesweeper Again
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 28 (AP)A Soviet minesweeper entered waters off Israellheld territory for the fourth consecutive day today and was turned back by an Israell patrol boat, the military command said.

title: Justice for Mr. Nixon
description: President Ford struck just the right balance yesterday in responding to questions about his views on future litigation affecting former President Nixon. Mr. Ford recognized Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's obligations as a lawenforcement officer of the United States to explore all aspects of the Watergate cases, including Mr. Nixon's involvement. The President also noted his own pardoning power, but refused to make an untimely commitment as to how he would use that power.

title: 3 New Witnesses Revealed At Phillips' Retrial Hearing
description: The case against former Police Officer William R. Phillips, charged with the 1968 Christmas Eve slaying of an East Side pimp and a prostitute, was reopened yesterday at a pretrial hearing in which the prosecution said it had three new witnesses.

title: People and Business
description: Directors, of pie International Telephone, and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that Harold S. Geneen, chairman and chief executive officer, had agreed to a new employment contract that extends his active, fulltime service for a twoyear period, effective next January.

title: 13Month Strike is Ended By Kentucky Mine Accord
