description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Striking mine workers and the Eastover Mining Company reached agreement today to end a 13month strike that had caused one death and economic hardship to the communities of Harlan County, Ky.

title: Mes Triumph, 70, On Seaver 5Hitter
description: A moment of panic set in for one of the 42,814 fans at Shea Stadium yesterday when she thought Toni Seaver's picture wasn't in her Photo Album Day portfolio. However, she found It soon enough and stayed on to see, a live Seaver, pitch the Mets to a 70 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: For Closer Scrutiny of the F.B.I.
description: BOSTONIt was wellknown in the early days of the civil rights movement that rights organizations were under close Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance.

title: Cabalte to Have Surgery
description: Montserrat Caball, a Metropolitan Opera soprano, will undergo abdominal surgery in Europe this fall and has canceled her appearances with the company for the first part of the season. The Spanish artist was to have sung in the openingnight performance of Verdi's I Vespri Siciliani on Sept. 23. She will be replaced by Cristina Deutekom in the role of Duchess Alena.

title: It's Intrepid Again With 3d Straight
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 29While her seagoing cheering section shouted c'mon old girl, aging Intrepid beat brandnew Courageous for the third straight time today in theft battle for the role of America's Cup defender.

title: Red Smith
description: Herb Washington can run 100 yards In 9.2 seconds, 60 yards in 5.8 seconds and 50 yards in 5 seconds flat, so he probably can do 90 feet in a tick over three seconds Charlie Finley, the lovable character who owns the Oakland A's pays Washington something like $35,000 a year to undergo onthejob training as a base runner. If this seems a princely wage for an apprentice, well, there is a man down in Washington, D.C., named Gerald R. Ford who is taking onthejob training, too, and he gets $200,000 plus fringe benefits. Having held his job several months longer than Gerald Ford has had his, Herb ought, by now, to know at least as much about running bases as Gerry does about running countries. If both make mistakes occasionally, that is only to be expected of rookies. For example, four of Washington's first five attempts to steal a base were mistakes, but then he began to learn. He stole five straight before he got caught again, and by yesterday he had brought off 21 thefts in 30 attempts.

title: Kaufman & Broad Sets Up AnticipatedLosses rand
description: Kaufman & Broad, Inc., said yesterday it will make a $13.5million provision against continuing operations mainly because of the extraordinary economic environment affecting the United States housing industry and a loss in the West German housing subsidiary. Also due to the sharp slowdown recently in mobile home orders and production, the company said it would also provide $3.5million after taxes for additional anticipated losses from its discontinued mobilehome business.

title: The Game's Over at the Kickoff
description: WASHINGTONWell, that's it for the honeymbon between me and Gerald Ford. It didn't take long. One state dinner and I've had it.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES STUDY ON WEST SIDE ROAD
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has criticized as deficient a draft statement on the environmental impact of the proposed replace. ment of the West Side Highway from the Battery to 42d Street and called for more comprehensive data in the final statement.

title: Gregory Joins Giants
description: Pro football's version of Jack and The Beanstalk took a happy turn yesterday when Jack Gregory left his Mississippi soybeans and joined the New York Giants' training camp.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: August 29, 1974

title: Connecticut Oil Spills Rise
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 29 (AP)  Oil spills in Connecticut waters increased slightly in number and volume during the first half of 1974 over the preceeding six months, according to the Coast Guard. A total of 15,793 gallons of oil leaked into the state's inland and coastal waters as a result of 114 spills, compared with nearly 13,000 gallons in 110 case during the last half of 1973.

title: Horrell Is ReElected
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 29 (UPI) Steve Horrell of San Diego, was reelected today president of the American Golf Sponsors, an association of the sponsors of major golf tournaments.

title: Presidential Leniency
description: Despite a drumfire of dissent by hardliners on both sides since his speech before the. Veterans of Foreign Wars, President Ford is sticking to his policy of leniency for Vietnam war draft evaders and deserters. At his news conference this week, he reiterated that his goal is to let these men earn or work their way back a course he is convinced is good for the country. That sensible view deserves national support.

title: Assemblyman's Suit Challenges City's Rent Guidelines
description: A suit challenging the rent guidelines set by the city this week for rentcontrolled apartmerits vacated by tenants was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan.

title: Soldier Gets Year Term For Helicopter Incident
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 29 (AP)  The young Army private who landed a stolen helicopter on the White House lawn last Feb. 17 was sentenced by a courtmartial today to a year at hard, labor and fined $2,400.

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP. INCREASES DIVIDEND
description: Directors of the Union Pacific Corporation, whose railroad of the same name is the most profitable in the industry, yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 70 cents a share, payable Oct. 1 to holders of record Sept. 9.

title: 39% Rebound Is Indicated In Capital Appropriations
description: Capital appropriations, the money set aside for improvement of plant and equipment, rebounded strongly in the second quarter, according to survey by The Conference Board.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jury Selection Set in Phillips Trial

title: Schoolboy Accepts $3Million Pro Offer
description: Moses Malone became the highest salaried teenage athlete in the United States yesterday by choosing a sevenyear professional basketball deal, with a potential value of $3 million, instead of playing for the University of Maryland.

title: Redskins Receive Thomas Apology
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP)Duane Thomas, the talented but controversial running back, met with Coach George Allen today in an attempt to rejoin the Washington Redskins. He had been released because of an altercation with an assistant coach. Thomas and an attorney met with Allen for two hours in which, according to Allen, Duane wanted to express how sorry he is.

title: Connecticut Road Builders Outflank Environmentalists
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.In an apparent end run that outmaneuvered environmental groups and sent bulldozers crashing through a protected wetlands here, state highway officials began work this summer on the first link of the controversial new U.S. Route 7 expressway.

title: 2 Indicted in Murder
description: MAYS LANDING, Aug. 29 (AP)  An Atlantic County grand jury indicted two brothers from Elwood, N. J., today in the rape and murder of a 79yearold woman April 5. James Hyson, 22, and Amply, 29, were also indicted on charges of robbery and breaking and entering with intent to rob. The victim, Lillian A. Woods was found dead in her ransacked house in Dorothy.

title: 21 Economists Get Bid to Summit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP)President Ford today invited 21 economists to the first in a series meetings leading to his twoday inflation summit conference next month.

title: The Rise in Air Fares
description: When international airlines agreed last weekend to raise fares on scheduled transAtlantic jet trips Nov. 1, for the fifth time this year, their decision was looted in the expectation that they would soon achieve something that they were wrongly accused of doing long agooperating a cartel.

title: Storms Twice Interrupt Play in Opening Round
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 29J. C. Snead shot a soggy eightunderpar 64 today and led the raincurtailed firstround of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: Saigon Reports Its Troops Counterattacking Near Hue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 29 (AP)South Vietnamese troops began counterattacks southeast of Hue today to drive off Communist forces menacing the area along Route ?? the Saigon command said.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: PHILIP L. RHODES, NAVAL ARCHITECT
description: Philip L. Rhodes, a naval architect and marine engineer who designed the 12meter yacht Weatherly, successful defender of the America's Cup in 1962, died Wednesday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 527 Fowler Avenue, Pelham, N.Y.

title: Toll Collectors Get 2d Tentative Pact; Strike Threat Ebbs
description: A second tentative agreement reached yesterday is expected to end the threat of a strike by toll collectors and other uniformed officers of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

title: MARSHALL UPHOLDS DENVER SCHOOL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall declined today to block an order integrating public schools in Denver.

title: Bluefish Still Abundant For Weekend Anglers
description: The unusually warm surface water of the ocean this summer  sometimes reaching the, high 70's off New Englandis probably the basic reason for the unusual, at least in modern times, number of bluefish along much of the Maine coast.

title: Connecticut Road Builders Outflank Environmentalists
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.In an apparent end run that outmaneuvered environmental groups and sent bulldozers crashing through a protected wetlands here, state highway officials began work this summer on the first link of the controversial new U.S. Route 7 expressway.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CLERIDES SEEKING TO EXPAND POWER
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 29Amid widespread speculation about the political plans of the deposed President, Archbishop Makarios, President Glafkos Clerides is trying to strengthen his own position as leader of the Greek Cypriote part of Cyprus.

title: Chicago Board Extending Trading by Half Hour
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 29 (AP) A Securities and Exchange Commission spokesman said today the commission would not object to a proposal front the Midwest Stock Exchange in Chicago to extend its trading hours by 30 minutes to 4 P.M. (Eastern Time).

title: Ash Says Ford Will Test Congress on Budget Cuts
ISRAEL MAY CALL UP EXEMPT OLDER MEN
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 29 (AP)Israel is mounting a campaign to recruit men previously exempt from service in the armed forces, a high officer announced today.

title: CITY CHIEF IN ERROR ON 4 DRUG PROGRAMS
description: Jerome Hornblass, commissioner of the city's Addiction Services Agency, has apologized to four cityfinanced drug programs for having included them in a list of 12 programs dosed by the agency because of unsatisfactory services.

title: Securities of U. S. Show Price Gains As Trading Climbs
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday in acfive trading, sending yields tumbling.

title: Rising Costs May Reduce U.S. Role in Indonesia
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29 (AP) Sharply rising costs may keep two large. American companies from joining a Japanese consortium that plans to build an aluminum smelte and power plant in Indonesia, according to Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an economic newspaper.

title: Court Dismisses Challenge to Convention Center
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a lawsuit that had challenged the proposed $200million convention center on Manhattan's West Side on various technical financial, environmental and procedural grounds.

title: World Sea Law Conference Ends With Little Achieved
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29 (Reuters)The third United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, billed as one of the most vital debates in history, ended today with little to show, beyond an agreement to meet again in Geneva next March.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 29  The Hambletonian, the prestige even of harness racing, was postponed again by bad weather today leaving 22 of the best trotters in the country with another 24hour wait before, chasing the purse of $160,150. The race is now scheduled for tomorrow in two divisions of 11 horses each and in three four elimination heats, if the clay track at the Illinois Fair Grounds dries out by then. But clouds still hung over the corn country of southern Illinois.

title: People in Sports
description: The Rangers yesterday made their second major deal since being eliminated in the semifinal round of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup playoffs, giving up Larry Sacharuk and a firstround draft choice to acquire Greg Polls from the St. Louis Blues.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF FOR 15TH SESSION
description: The failure of President Ford to announce antiinflationary steps at his flews conference Wednesday, coupled with uneasiness about inflation, sent prices lower again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. It Was the fifteenih consecutive drop.

title: British Are in an Uneasy Mood as Fail Election Looms
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 Six months after one national election, the British, are preparing for another in a mood of bewilderment and disquiet over the nation's problems and with a notable lack of enthusiasm for another campaign.

title: Carey and Samuels Pick Up More Endorsements Here
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey and Howard J. Samuels picked up additional support yesterday in their battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Judge Orders F.B.I. to Destroy All Records on Jersey Girl, 17
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29Lori Paton, the teenager who became the subject of a Federal investigation as the result of a classroom exercise, won her fight today to force the Federal Bureau of Investigation to destroy all records pertaining to the incident.

title: Dates and Places Listed For Preliminary Parleys
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)The White House today announced the dates and locations of 12 preliminasy meetings leading up to the economic summit conference that President Ford has scheduled for Sept. 27 and 28 in an effort to slow down inflation.

title: Ali Beating Drums for TV Tickets
description: Scowling, shuffling, sneering and scolding, Muhammad All returned to Madison Square Garden yesterday to launch the sale of closedcircuit telecast tickets for his championship bout next month against the heavyweight king, George. Foreman.

title: Alexander Sees Disaster If Clark Wins the Primary
description: Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse said yesterday that he was the underdog, hardpressed for campaign money in the Democratic primary race for the United States Senate, and warned that a victory for Ramsey Clark would mean disaster for the entire Democratic state ticket in November.

title: DECLINE CONTINUES IN STOCK MARKET
description: The stock market yesterday continued its sharp decline as most prices sagged in slower trading.

title: MARY TRAVERS, DION SING IN RAIN IN PARK
description: Rain again tested the faithful at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Wednesday as the singer Dion opened the evening, in the middle of the most torrential downpour pet in this summer's festival. In the true showbiz tradition the show went on.

title: Aim Is to Counteract Action by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29The Ford Motor Company said today it was putting six of its 1975 lines of cars on sale a month early to stay competitive with the General Motors Corporation.

title: Business Briefs
description: The value of construction contracts in July at $9.29billion rose 3 per cent compared with July, 1973, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: The Last Mile
description: Few pupils are likely to resist change as the metric system at long last inches, or should we say centimeters, its way into greater numbers of classrooms in the coming school year. They can be expected to see more readily than many of their elders why measurements that are easy to learn, remember and figure in one's head make more sense than this country's complex English inheritance of a system that has little to recommend it other than long usage. All of which makes it good news that the newly enacted Federal bill to aid elementary and secondary education authorizes the expenditure of $40 million over the next four years to help the schools lead the nation's longdelayed move toward metric modernity.

title: Mexico Bars Deal With Group Holding Kinsman of President
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Auk. 29 (UPI)The Mexican Gbvernment said today that it would refuse to deal with the kidnappers of Jos Guadalupe Zeno Hernandez, fatherinlaw of President Luis Echeverria Alvarez.

title: State Accused of Shunning City's Disturbed Children
description: New York City has been compelled to send 150 seriously retarded and disturbed children to expensive private institutions outside the state because the State Department of Mental Hygiene refuses to take them into its own institutions and, in fact, has no place for them if they are from Manhattan.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 30, 1974

title: 1 Million in the Area Watched First News Conference by Ford
description: Preliminary television rating figures indicate that about one and onehalt million people in the metropolitan area watched part of President Ford's news conference on Wednesday.

title: Giants Beat Pirates in 11th, 3 to 2
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP)Dave Kingman singled, with men on first and second in the bottom of the 11th inning, lifting the San Francisco Giants to a 32 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

title: Ilene Bailen Is Bride Of Lawrence Karson
description: Ilene. Doris Bailen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Bailen of New Hyde Park, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married Yesterday evening to Lawrence Paul Karson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Karson of Fairlawn, N.J.

title: MARCOS FREES 14 HELD AT NOVITIATE
description: MANILA, Aug. 29 (AP) Fourteen of the 21 persons arrested at a Roman Catholic novitate near here Saturday have been released by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Plan for Snake River Dam Stirs New Controversy
description: HELL'S CANYON, Idaho, Aug. 29The Snake River boils through North America's deepest gorge and rushes unimpeded through 100 miles of wild country here at the IdahoOregon state line.

title: Red Sox Top White Sox, Lead Yanks by 5 Games
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29The Red Sox who have shown signs of faltering as the pennant race nears its final month, gained a shaky 32 triumph over the White Sox tonight behind some fine relief pitching by Diego Segui.

title: Pocono Developer Agrees To Sell Lots to Minorities
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29 (UPI)A Pennsylvania land developer, one of two companies cited by the Government for alleged housing discrimination, agreed today to sell Pocono Mountain lots to blacks and,Puerto Pticans.

title: $850,000 Nixon Expenses Are Sought by President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate $850,000 for former President Richard M. Nixon to cover the Presidential transition, his pension and other expenses between now and next June 30.

title: Strike Idleness Is Up.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)  American workers, were idle because of strikes more during the first seven months of 1974 than during either of the two previous years, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: APPALOOSA MARE8 yrs & filly 5 months. Foundation registry. Excel temp. Must sell at sacrifice $1,500 for both. Also Quarter Horse filly, 17 months 13 bars), sorrel with blond mane & tall, halter broke, $3,000. Call wkdays, 95PM, 201 4272500.

title: U.S. TO ESTABLISH EAST GERMAN TIES NEXT WEDNESDAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The United States and East Germany will formally announce the establishment of diplomatic relations next Wednesday, State Department officials said today.

title: Stage: Off Off Openings
description: As Off Off Broadway drama, could anything have more impact than the tragic case history of the Donner Party, the pioneer wagon train that was stranded below the Sierras and survived on cannibalism? The answer is yesthe story of two gentle New Yorkers, the last tenants to leave an Upper East Side tenement before demolition.

title: Aerialist a Hit in Central Park
description: Philippe Petit, the lithe French acrialist who three weeks ago cavorted on a cable between the pinnacles of the World Trade Center, took his highwire act to Central Park last night and tiptoed across the broad, muddy expanse of Belvedere Lake to the delight of thousands of spectators.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summery and Index, Page 31

title: Herbert BeaufoyLane, 79, Queen Mary Officer in War
description: Herbert John BeaufoyLane, who served in World War II as military commandant of the Queen Mary, at the time a transport vessel carrying thousands of American troops between this country and Britain, died last Friday in Montclair, N. J. He was 79 years old.

title: Tireless Mediator Willie Julian Usery Jr.
description: Willie Julian Usery Jr., an Assistant Secretary of Labor, took all the worn arid haggard negotiators into his Washington office around 4 A.M. yesterday and passed out a few of the cigars that have become trademarks of the veteran mediator.

title: Petty Gains Pole For Southern 500
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., Aug. 29 (UPI)Richard Petty drove his Dodge to a speed of 150132 miles an hour today to beat Buddy Baker for the pole position for the 25th running of the Southern 500 stock car race on Monday.

title: TEACHER IS CLEARED OF CONFLICT CHARGE
description: TRENTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)The State Education Department dismissed a complaint today charging a member of the Bogota Board of Education with conflict of interest for being a teacher in a neighboring school district.

title: Mrs. Ammond Scores Hyland On Gotcha Squad Investigation
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28 (AP)State Senator Alene S. Ammond, Democrat of Camden, today strongly criticized the Attorney General's investigation of charges of a state police gotcha squad in South Jersey, saying the report contained enormous contradictions, was extremely shallow and had editorializing statements.

title: 3 Young Brothers' Bodies Found Off Queens Beach
description: The bodies of three young brothers who ran away from their Queens home last Tuesday were found early yesterday, floating off the rubblestrewn beach of a Sanitation Department dump just five blocks from their home in Far Rockaway.

title: Rothko Trial Off Until Sept. 10; More Witnesses Are Due Then
description: Another round ended yesterday in a bitter legal battle focusing on millions of dollars Paintings left by the artist Mark Rothko when he died 1970.

title: Schoolboy Accepts $3Million Pro Offer
description: Moses Malone became the highest salaried teenage athlete in the United States yesterday by choosing a sevenyear professional basketball deal, with a potential value of $3 million, instead of playing for the University of Maryland.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: State Urges Action By U.S. to Prevent NaturalGas Crisis
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29 (UPI)Further delays in hooking up naturalgas wells off the Gulf Coast with pipelines to New Jersey could worsen an expected gas shortage in the state this winter, authorities said today.

title: Talkathons
description: Winston Churchill once observed that jawjaw is, better than warwar. So it is. But there are times when the United Nations puts an intolerable strain on that simple truth. In Caracas, U.N. conferees have wound up ten weeks of talks about a Law of the Sea with little more achievement than a decision to hold another conference in Geneva next spring and then return to Caracas for a third next summer.

title: Judge Orders F.B.I. to Destroy All Records on Jersey Girl, 17
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29Lori Pato; the teenager who became the subject of a Federal investigation as the result of a classroom exercise, won her fight today to force the Federal Bureau of Investigation to destroy all records pertaining to the incident.

title: No Penalty for Children
description: Through a series of lapses in communications between City Hall and Albany, several thousand city children are in danger of becoming ineligible for day care next week under the new guidelines of the State Department of Social Services. Since the families of most of these prischool youngsters could not pay the fees imposed on them by the new regulations, the result would not only be to deprive the children of the necessary care but also to force many of their mothers to give up their own jobs and go on welfare.

title: Bette Davis Strains Back
description: Bette Davis has suffered a mild back strain while rehearsing the Broadwaybound musical Miss Moffatt. As a result, the scheduled outoftown engagement in Baltimore Seat, 921 has been canceled, and the first showing is now scheduleil, for Philadelphia on Sept 23.

title: U.S. WEIGHS RISE IN OIL IMPORT FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A high Treasury official said today that if world oil prices did not decline the United States and other importing countries would have to adopt tougher conservation measures. These, he said, might include higher oil prices to the consumer to discourage demand.

title: CHARLES P. SMITH
description: Charles Pennypacker Smith, president and chief executive of the Pacific Gas Transmission Company, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on Tuesday. He was 63 yews old. He had been visiting drilling sites of his company.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.07billion, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $1.01billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.61billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $9.64billion.

title: TRUCK KILLS MAN IN PARCEL STRIKE
description: A teamster union official was, fatally injured yesterday afternoon when he was hit by a truck crossing a picket line at the United Parcel Service distribution center in Secaucus, N.J. He dide within an hour al North Hudson Hospital in nearby Weehawken, the police reported.

title: Film Action and Mockery In '99 and 44/100% Dead'
description: A lot of talent has gone into making "99 and 44/100% Dead" the sort of movie that wants to have its cake and eat it, too.The film, playing on Broadway at the Victoria and at other theaters in and around the city, is directed by John Frankenheimer, boasts a sardonic score by Henry Mancini and has a cast headed by Richard Harris, Edmond O'Brien, Bradford Dillman and Chuck Connors.On one level it is a shoot-'em-up of comic-strip proportions. Mr. Harris as the granite-visaged Harry Crown and Mr. Connors as Marvin (The Claw) Zuckerman, equipped with an artificial left arm fitted with a hilarious array of implements, play the professional killers who are the champions in a gang war between Mr. O'Brien (Uncle Frank) and Mr. Dillman (Big Eddie).On this level "99" overflows with corpses in cement pedestals, black-suited, black-hatted henchmen, ambushes, gunplay and wholesale killing, chases and the plentiful trashing of expensive cars, to say almost nothing of the presence of a copious supply of beautiful women, who make handy sex objects and hostages.On another level, "99" mocks the whole genre, and some of the touches are superb. Marvin's artificial arm, with its shiny scissors, its whip, its feather duster; an excursion through a sewer where those legendary alligators flushed down toilets have grown to full length; an underwater gardens of corpses; a final shoot-out in a laundry, where all the workers go about their business as though nothing extraordinary were happening.Moviegoers who insist on utter fealty to the demands of the shoot-'em-up are going to be disturbed by the strong undercurrent of irreverence. Those who find the shoot-'em-up immoral in the first place won't be satisfied by the injection of humor as an antidote.It may not be dumb enough to be the flawless action movie and it may not be sharp enough to be a sparkling spoof, but in a summer when so much witless trash is being dumped on the movie market, "99" merits praise for its ambitiousness more than derision for its shortcomings.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOP BRASS The best place to hear the heavenly sounds of brass ensembles is said to be in St. Mark's Cathedral in Venice. But inflation being what it is, It's not that easy to get there these days, and you'll have to make do. Tonight and tomorrow night, there's an opportunity to make do rather handsomely.

title: Holdup Victim Fires In Vain at 2 Ganmen
description: Two armed men robbed West Side public relations agency of $440 yesterday, then were forced to flee when one of three victims they tied to tie up seized one or their guns and began firing. He apparently missed.

title: Ramiro Artasanchez Madrigal Marries Pamela A. Marquard
description: In the Brick Presbyterian Church here last evening Pamela Ann Marquard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs., William A. Marquard of New York and Quogue, L.I., was married to Ramiro Artasanchez Madrigal, son of Marcella Madrigal de Artasanchez of Mexico City and the late Alberto Artasanchez Romero.

description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29The Indian Government, in the midst of grave food shortages and with worse to come, is debating whether to ask the United States for emergency help.

description: ABERDEEN, Miss., Aug. 29 (UPI)  Allen, Cox, a retired Federal district judge, died of cancer yesterday. He was 87 years old.

Bridge:

Mr. Morgenthau, who faces the incumbent, Richard H. Kuh, in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, charged that victim's of crime are victimized twice: first by the criminal and then by the system that is supposed to help them.

description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)The undefeated Birmingham Americans scored their eighth World Football League victory tonight as a blend of George Mira's passing and a solid running game fashioned a 228 triumph over the Chicago Fire.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 29 (UPI) Gov. Dolph Briscoe of Texas ordered today a special court of inquiry int othe prisonescape attempt by Fred Gontez Carrasco after reports that Mr. Carrasco and another inmate may have been killed by the police.

title: Japan Will Keep Money Supply Tight
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29A senior Japanese economic official said today that his Government, confronted with continuing inflationary pressures, expected to retain severe restraints on the economy for about another year.

title: Democracy at Stake?
description: LONDON, Aug. 29It seems an extreme and even silly question to be asked in Britain, of all places, but actually it is being asked and discussed here by serious men and women: Can democracy long survive the present rate of inflation?

title: CHEMICAL EXPRESS WILL RAISE PRICES
description: Price increases on cement and antiknock compounds were announced yesterday.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Aug. 29The United Nations Security Council met for three hours and 40 minutes today to consider a proposal by Cyprus that it action the Cypriote refugee problem, But the Council adjourned until 10:30 A.M. tomorrow without holding a public session.

description: The Board of Education agreed in Federal Court yesterday to establish a major new program to improve the education of all Spanishspeaking pupils here whose difficulties with English impede their learning.

title: Mimi Green Is Wed To T. C. Dillenberg
description: Mimi Jane Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Russell Green of New York and Klosters, Switzerland, was married here yesterday morning to Thomas Coleman Dillenberg son of Mrs. Walter D. Yankhouer and the late D. Alan Dillenberg.

description: India hopes to scrape through the oil shortage this year by nearly doubling the foreign exchange she allocates for oil imports and by taking stringent conservation measures: Story on Page 39.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Fortune Society, a group staffed by, and for, exconvicts, is viewing the nation's debate about imprisonment for political felons of the recent Presidential Administration with interest. The verbiage among academia, the media, and the remains of the legal aristocracy, seems to he way off target.

title: Parental Consent Need Is Ending for Boys at 18
description: Starting Tuesday, young men 18 years old or older can get married without the consent of their parents. The age for girls without parental consent remains 18.
