description: August 29, 1974

title: Strange
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 29 Only three of golf's young pro prospects remained in the 74th United States Amateur championship today when the field was cut to the eight quarterfinalists at the Ridgewood Country Club. The three were Curtis Strange, 19yearold National Collegiate champion from Wake Forest; Gary Koch, the national junior champion from the University of Florida, and Jerry Pate, 205 a, University of Alabama senior, who turned in the day's biggest upset by eliminating George Burns of Port Washington, L. I.

title: Dodgers. Widen Gap
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP)Andy Messersmith and Mike Marshall combined on a threehitter tonight, giving Los Angeles its fifth straight victory, a 31 decision over the Chicago Cubs that widened the Dodgers' lead in the West to 3 games over Cincinnati.

title: About New York The New York Spirit
description: The Labor Day weekend starts late today when the first surge of cars realizes a traffic commissioner's dream everything's going but of the city. Labor Day marks the end of summer much more than astronomical calculations do. After Labor Day the city theoretically comes to life. Most people are back from vacation, except for the fortunate few who can actually go away when everyone else is back at work, It thus marks the end of the twomonth drought of local activity that began on July when newsmakers went off to the Cape or to the Hamptons or the Cotswolds. However, life has not stood still. To illustrate the continuity of New York spirit during the dog days, here are few notes about pity people at work and play.

title: Screen: 'Marketa Lazarova' Opens:Czech Production Is a Medieval Hodgepodge The Cast Savage Koslik Clan Is Noted for Brutality
description: Ever wonder who is responsible for the sorry state of the world? Well, the answer is: the Kosliks.At least, that is, according to "Marketa Lazarova," a Czechoslovak film of epic grasp and butter fingers playing today and tomorrow at noon and midnight at the First Avenue Screening Room."Marketa Lazarova" is a colossaland very nearly interminablehodgepodge of medieval mayhem and myth, leaden symbolism and bloated piety directed by Frantisek Vlacil and photographed by Bedrich Batka as though they had taken vows to supersede the dictionary as the ultimate source of definition for the word "excess."As for the Kosliks, and the pageant of brutish half-wits who people their retinue, they are a 13th-century Bohemian clan of such unmitigated savagery that next to them the Visigoths would resemble a Red Cross mercy mission.For a Koslik, nothing is too bad. Robbery, murder, kidnapping, rape and incest are to the list of Koslik baseness what two handkerchiefs, a couple of undershirts and a pair of socks are to a Sears, Roebuck catalogue.The business of "Marketa Lazarova" originates from the kidnapping of a young German traveler named Christian, who is destined to become a bishopif the Kosliks do not gut him first. This leads in turn to the kidnapping and rape of the daughter of the Kosliks' smarmy neighbor, Lazar. The daughter, Marketa, as pious as she is beauteous, is headed for the nun's life, until carried off and ravished by one of the Koslik boys, Nikolas, while Christian yields up his virtue to one of the Koslik girls, Alexandra.All this ruttishness to the neglect of fouler deeds so enrages old man Koslik that he forces its addicts to sleep chained on the ground outside his redoubt during the melty season.The melty season is one of the two seasons during which the action of "Marketa Lazarova" takes place. The other season is the snowy season, and sometimes the seasons change every five minutes.During the snowy season the camera never misses a chance to show stark figures against the white landscape or the shadow of a horse against the snow. During the melty season, the sun slants through bare branches onto the forest floor. Sometimes it snows during the melty season, mainly when snow will look good on someone's face or hair.During both seasons, the camera likes to peep at everyone through slats or closing doors, and occasionally it wanders down a corridor in search of a good-looking shadow. Sometimes it goes looking for a symbol. Snakes, hawks and stags are favorites.Busy though it is, the camera finds time for other things. The High Sheriff mounts a campaign against the Kosliks; nuns sing; a holy man wanders over the landscape accompanied by a lamb until the lamb encounters the Kosliks and is served for dinner. The holy man then acquires a goat, which wanders off while he is attempting to induce Marketa to wander the world with him.Marketa, by this time, is a pregnant widow, her lover having been skewered while attempting to free old man Koslik from prison. With the old man in attendance, the High Sheriff marries Marketa to Nikolas who thereupon keeps a long overdue date with the local headsman. Christian's love, Alexandra, is also pregnant. Christian is also dead, having been rewarded for searching for Alexandra after her father's capture by having her dash his brains out with a handy rock.A postscript to all this tells us that the children of Marketa and Alexandra were boys, and in them  and in the generations of mankind that followed themwere mixed both love and cruelty."Marketa Lazarova" is a lesson to us all.

title: India May Give Sikkim State Role in Parliament
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29The Indian Government is seeking to amend the Constitution to provide representation for Sikkim in Parliament, thereby making the tiny Himalayan protectorate a virtual part of India. Approval by Parliament is expected next week.

title: Mexico Asks U.S. Aid in Ending O.A.S. Ban on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Foreign Minister Emilio O. Rabasa of Mexico asked the United States today to support moves in the Organization of American States to lift the 10yearold trade and diplomatic sanctions against Cuba.

title: Explosion Destroys a City Block In Chattanooga
description: CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 29 (UPI)An explosion wiped out a city block in this city's black nightclub district today, killing one man and injuring at least 13.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the last week totaled an estimated 15.1 billion tonmiles, 10.9 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period which included a miners' holiday totaled 481,570 cars, 12.1 per cent below last year, The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 5.8 per cent below list year.

title: City's Personnel Chief Retiring for Health Post
description: Harry I. Bronstein, the city's Personnel Director since 1970, will retire to be come a senior: vice president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation on Tuesday.

title: Top Indian Leader Backs Young Navajos on Rights
description: FARMINGTON, N.M., Aug. 29 A major American Indian leader, Peter McDonald, the chairman of the Navajo tribe, aligned himself tonight with the angry young Indians who have been protesting what they term racism and discrimination in Farmington and in other towns adjoining the Navajo reservation.

title: Big North Sea Oil Find Announced by Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 29 (AP)Officials announced today the discovery of the biggest oil and gas field in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ENGLEWOOD, Aug. 29  Many people go to Niagara Falls to see the sights. Others go there on their honeymoons. Bob Heidenberg was there last week for neither of these pleasant reasons but he also had a good time.

title: Strikes Dash Hopes of Peak Car Output
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29  The United States auto industry's hopes for nearrecord car production in the third quarter have been dashed by strikes that have cut into 1974 model output and delayed the changeover to 1975 models at several plants.

title: MARSHAL SERVES NIXON A SUBPOENA IN COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Justice Department announced today that a United States marshal had served two subpoenas on former President Richard M. Nixon at his estate in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Saxpe and Schlesinger Meet on DraftEvader Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger and Attorney Genoral William B. Saxbe met today to work out details of their joint report to the President on the question of treatment for draft evaders and deserters.

title: In Connecticut, It's a Restaurant to Look Forward To
description: Traveling north of Danbury on busy Route 7 it is wise to ignore the shopping centers and fast food operations because there are better things ahead.

title: Advertising: Furor at D.D.B.
description: James R. Heekin Jr., presidentdomestic operations of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., for slightly more than five months, resigned yesterday with a strong blast at the agency.

title: Proxmire Says Rockefeller Has Weakness on Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire said today that Vice President designate Nelson A. Rockefellet's potential shortcomings in dealing with inflation stand out like a skunk at a family picnic.

title: Higher Profits Cited By RollsRoyce, Ltd.
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  The Governmentowned RollsRoyce company's profits for 1973 will be higher than the previous year and this year's profits should be even higher, the company's deputy chairman, Sir William Nield, said today.

title: Scapino Reopens Sept 27 Under New Sponsorship
description: Scapino, the Broadway comedy that has been involved in a management dispute, closes Sunday but is to reopen Sept. 27, under new sponsorship, at the Ambassador Theater.

title: Blast at Noon Hits Downtown Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 30An explosion in the Tokyo business district during the noon rush today killed at least five persons and injured a great number, the police reported.

title: Isidor Bieber, OwnerBreeder of Race flows, ls Dead at 87
description: Isidor Bieber, the owner and breeder of race horses, died yesterday in a nursing home in Hollywood, Fla. He was, 87 years old and lived at 14 Herrick Drive, Lawrence, L.I.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts in Good Health; First Night Landing Hailed in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29Two Soviet astronauts who had been aboard Soyuz 15 were pronounced in good health today following their sudden return to earth late yesterday in what was hailed here as the first landing of a spacecraft at night.

title: Ford Will Mat Doctor For Chat Each Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)  President Ford will meet each week with his personal physician for 15minute chats to check on his weight and calorie count, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Body of Kidnapping Victim Is Discovered in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29 (AP)  The body of a former army captain who had been kidnapped was discovered today in a vacant lot near here, the police reported.

title: News Summary and Index
description: State Department officials said that the United States arid East Genitally would establish diplomatic relations next Wednesday The first American Ambassador to East Germany reportedly will be John Sherman Cooper, a former Republican Senator from Kentucky, who has been Ambassador to India. This will leave Canada as the only member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that has not established diplomatic ties with East Germany. [1:5.]

title: CHARLES BLOCH DIES; SEGREGATIONIST, 80
description: MACON, Ga., Aug. 29 (UPI)Charles Bloch, an advocate of states rights who represented his state and local governments in many efforts to prevent integration, died Tuesday, night. His age was 80.

title: Marathon Softball Game Scoring Big, for Charity
description: PARSIPPANY, Aug. 29What is being billed as the world's longest softbal game started at Smith Field here yesterday at 4:30 P.M. and is scheduled to continue for 120 hours, through Monday.

title: State Clears City College Of Racial Quota Charges
description: The State Division of Human Rights said yesterday that it had found no racial quota system, as had been charged, in admissions to City College's accelerated medicaltraining program.

title: Mrs. King Winner In 2 Sets
description: The rain fell and the sun set on the second half of the Chris and Jimmy Show yesterday at the United States Open Tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Ash Says Ford Will Test Congress on Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Roy L. Ash, the Budget Director, disclosed today that Eresident Ford planned to make an initial test next week of the willingness of Congress to go along with cuts in the nondefense budget.

title: Saxbe and Schlesinger Meet on DraftEvader Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Secretary, of Defense James R. Schlesinger and Attorney General William B. Saxbe met today to work out details of their joint report to the President on the question of treatment for draft evaders and deserters.

title: Malone Signing Ends Tall Tale Of How to Grow Into Pro at 19
description: He was the boy with the big head, the one they called Jughead and laughed at. He was ashamed to smile because of a broken tooth. In class, he mumbled when he was asked to speak, or muttered some excuse and sat down.

title: SINCLAIR REFINING WINS COURT APPEAL
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 29The Sixth United States: Circuit Court of Appeals today reversed a $2.9million judgment against the Sinclair Refining Company. The court ruled on a private antitrust suit in which the Champion Oil Service Company of Hamilton, Ohio, alleged restraint of trade.

title: Longing for the Woman And Child Left Behind
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug, 22Following is a recent exchange of letters between a former American serviceman and a Vietnamese woman, mother of his child. The letters are printed as they were written, with no attempt made to correct the spelling or the grammar.

title: $850,000 Nixon Expenses Are Sought by President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate $850,000 for former President Richard M. Nixon to cover the Presidential transition, his pension and other expenses between now and next June 30.

title: Overseas Investments Of U.S. Rose in 1973
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  The Commerce Department said today that the recorded net international investment position of the United States increased $12billion to $63billion in 1973.

title: Sate Accused of Shunning Ciry's Disturbed Children
description: New York City has been compelled to send 150 seriously retarded and disturbed children to expensive private institutions outside the state because the State Department of Mental Hygiene refuses to take them into its own institutions and, in fact, has no place for them if they are from Manhattan.

title: Business Loans Up $105Million
description: Business loans at major New York City banks increased $105million during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Court Postpones the Start Of Sherwin's Prison Term
description: FREEHOLD, Aug. 29Former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two others convicted in 1972 for briberyconspiracy charges succeeded here today in winning another brief stay of their impending prison sentences.

title: The Missing Delegation
description: American higher education is in a state of financial and emotional depression. Inflationary costs and declining enrollments have aggravated the, budget squeeze faced by private and public colleges and universities alike. Even more serious than the economic pressures, however, may be the prevailing defeatist mood in academic circles.

title: Books of The Times
description: Like America itself, America's great cities tame of age with haste and abandon. Many of them were little more, than sleepy trading posts before the Industrial Revolution swept them up into a period of violent expansion. At the very least, American cities lacked the accumulation of hundreds of years of civilization that in Europe, where industrialization was just as brutal, cushioned, the trauma of urban growth.

title: Ramsey Clark's Rise
description: Ten weeks ago, when the Democtatic State Committee designated statewide candidates, Ramsey Clark got a polite reception but less than one per cent of the state committee vote. Many Democratic leaders tagged him as a radical who, if nominated for the United States Senate, would drag the entire Democratic ticket down to defeat in November.

title: India Battles to Meet Oil Needs
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29 India will scrape through the oil shortage this year by stretching foreign  exchange resources for maximum imports, drastically cutting domestic consumption of petroleum products and reorganizing the production pattern of the petroleum refineries, a Government official said today.

title: LOANS ARE REFUSED INVESTORS FUNDING
description: A lending group headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank refused yesterday to grant additional loans to the Investors Funging Corporation. The financially troubled real estate concern had sought the funds to meet a $6million payment due the bank on Oct. 1.

title: BILINGUAL CLASSES AGREED UPON HERE
description: The Board of Education agreed in Federal Court yesterday to establish a major new program to improve the education of all Spanishspeaking pupils here whose difficulties with English impede their learning.

title: Indians Here Get U.S. Funds To Help Them in Urban Life
description: There are now an estimated 10,000 to 12,000 American Indians living in New York Citymore than when Peter Minuit bought Manhattan Island in 1626.

title: MARSHAL SERVES NIXON A SUBPOENA IN COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Justice Department an nounced today that a United States marshal had served two subpoenas on former President Richard M. Nixon at his estate in San Clemente, Calif.

title: KUH FINDS NO LOSS FROM CITY VAULT
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh said yesterday that there was not a scintilla of evidence that anyone had sneaked securities out of, and back into, the City Controller's muchinvestigated vault.

title: War Children: Now Old Enough to Express Own Sadness
description: SAIGON, South VietnamThe mixed children left by American G.I.s are now growing up in South Vietnam. Wisps of blond can be seen bobbing and darting among the rivers of blackhaired women and children in the street markets. Round blue eyes peer out of thatched huts. Along dusty paths, some of the faces that beam up at strangers are black, others are fairskinned.

title: Franklin Sees Its Future As a Long Island Bank
description: The Franklin National Bank, which has been retrenching after losing some $83million in the first six months of the year, has submitted a plan to continue in existence on its own, without merging but operating as a Long Island regional bank.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Sharon Pinkham, who was not allowed to graduate from South River High School because she had failed a written test on badminton for girls only, has received two diplomas, including one from her high school. Miss Pinkham said she would enter a college nursingtraining program.

title: Hambletonian Off Again Until Today
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 29  The Hambletonian, the prestige even of harness racing, was postponed again by bad weather today  leaving 22 of the best trotters the country with another 24hour wait before chasing the purse of $160,150. The race is now scheduled for tomorrow in two divisions of 11 horses each and in three four elimination heats, if the day track at the Illinois Fair Grounds dries out by then. But clouds still hung over the corn country of southern Illinois.

title: Cards Win OneHitter By Curtis
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 29 (AP) John Curtis pitched a onehitterFred Kendall's single in the eighth inningand Jim Dwyer and Mike Tyson hit runscoring singles in the ninth tonight to give St. Louis a 31 victory over the San Diego Padres. It moved the Cards within a game of firstplace Pittsburgh In National League East.

title: KUH FINDS NO LOSS PROM CITY VAULT
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh said yesterday that there was not a scintilla of evidence that anyone had sneaked securities out of, and back into, the City Controller's muchinvestiga vault.

title: CALM REAPPEARS ON COMMODITIES
description: Relative calm settled over the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after a hectic finish the day earlier brought on by a weather forecast that proved to be false.

title: Miners Are Jubilant and Harlan Relaxes
description: HARLAN, Ky., Aug. 29We got a contract, you hear? the jubilant miner yelled to his friend across from the courthouse square here in the seat of Harlan County. Off he hurried, his step brisk and jaunty, off on some errand, not pausing to give his name.

title: TV: Life in South. More Than a Dream on NBC
description: Last night on NBC (that phrase won't be used too often in the future next week the network drops its longstanding policy against reviews of a program before it goes on air), More Than a Dream examined life in the South, specifically in Nashville, 20 years after the Supreme Court's historic school desegregation ruling. Choosing to accentuate the positive but not ignore the negative, the documentary convincingly demonstrated social, changes for the good among not only poor blacks out poor whites as well.

title: DealerManager Named By North American Philips
description: The North American Philips Corporation said yesterday that it lad appointed Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., as dealermanager for its tender offer for all common shares of Magnavox Company.

title: Stanton Griffis, Noted Diplomat And Financier, Is Dead at 87
description: Stanton Griffis, who had served as a special envoy under President Franklin D. Roosevelt and as an ambassador under President Truman, died of pneumonia last evening in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: New England to Get Job Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 29 (AP) The Labor Department has announced that the six New. England States will receive about $596,000 to be used for training programs for migrant and other seasonal farmworkers The final amount will be depend on how much is appropriated by Congress for the fiscal year 1975 under the Comprehensive Employment Training Act.

title: High Levels of Cancer Are Found in Arsenic Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29High levels of cancer have been found among men who have worked in factories processing inorganic arsenic, thus raising a serious new health question for the one and a half million workers the Government estimates are now exposed to it in the United States.

title: City Planners Urge Rezoning Industrial District In Greenpoint to Bring Area More New Housing
description: A City Planning Commission study of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn calls for rezoning big patches of the heavily industrial area to encourage more new housing and the sprucing up of old housing.

title: Profits From Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  So much was crammed Into six days in South Vietnam that one must really remove oneself from the country to sort out adequately facts and impressions. Vietnam has the same languorous, seductive ambience that often assails Westerners in Southeast Asia. It is easy to fall under its sway. Certain facts stand out, however:

title: A Good Man Is Not Enough
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  In his speech to Congress and again in his news conference, President Ford failed to provide leadership in behalf of the reforms required to prevent a future Watergate scandal.

title: Study Finds Poor Blacks Mainly in Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Seventy per cent of the white people who live in poverty areas of the country live outside metropolitan centers, but 70 per cent of the blacks who live in poverty areas are in metropolitan areas.

title: Warfare in Cambodia Reels On in Confusion
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia As the war in Cambodia grinds malignantly on through its fifth year, eroding all the normal patterns of life, events here become more and more bizarre, more and more surrealistic.

title: Market Place: Pan Am's Grief Engulfs Others
description: It was back in early 1969 when highfliers were the stocks that were the most extravagantly priced in a stock market that just kept going up, There was enough drama to please the most demanding speculator and enough action to line the pockets of Wall Street's thousands of ebullient salesmen.

title: Jersey City Will Ask Hearing on Change In School Financing
description: TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) Mayor Paul Jordan of Jersey City said today that the city would seek a hearing before the State Supreme Court on the court's mandate to the legislature to replace the property tax as the chief support for public education in New Jersey.

title: Spirits Eye Robertson
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP)The Spirits of St. Louis today obtained American Basketball negotiating rights to Oscar Robertson, who became a free agent Aug. 1 when the Milwaukee Bucks failed to sign him.

title: Soviet ATeat Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union conducted a major underground nuclear test today with a yield of one to three megatons, the Atomic Energy Commission reported.

title: Maddox Links Rival to a Black Leader
description: ATLANTA, Aug, 29Lieut, Gov, Lester G, Maddox, faced with a strong white moderate contender for the Democratic nomination for Governor, has harked back to race and radicalism as his campaign cry.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and ?? ?? 31

title: British Police Disperse Windsor Pop Festival
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)A police operation to break up a popmusic festival ended today with 220 fans under arrest, more than 50 persons injured and a demand by Home Secretary Roy Jenkins for a special report on the incident.

title: S.E.C. Lays Fraud to 7 Brokers In Promoting Stock of Devon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Securities and Exchange Commission initiated administrative action today against seven New York brokerdealers and securities salesmen on staff allegation of fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws involving the common stock of Devon International, Ltd.

title: Sports Today
JOHN VANDER GHEYNST
description: John R. Vander Gheynst, assistant eastern regional manager of the Chevrolet Motor division of the General Motors Corporation, died Wednesday in Naples, Fla. He was 57 years old and formerly lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Notes on People
description: The spokesman for Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago denied widespread rumors there that the Mayor now has a speech impediment as a result of the stroke he suffered May 6. The spokesman said the Mayor had recuperated so satisfactorily that he would be back in City Hall by Sept. 11. Frank Sullivan, the press secretary, said that Mr, Daley was coming along very well in his recovery from the stroke, which Mr. Sullivan described as mild, and from the surgery the Mayor underwent June 2 to remove blockage from an artery in his neck.

title: The Pop Life
description: One sign of rock's maturity or its decadenceis the increasing attention it has attracted from other, more serious arts. Once upon a time, when symphonic composers wanted to dip their toes into the giddy energies of pop, they turned to jazz. But thirdstream music is being challenged these days by rockclassical amalgams, and more and more groups are reversing the polarity by using orchestras as grandiose backup bands. PoetsPatti Smith comes to mind preeminently  have begun to shape their sensibilities around the imagery of rock, as the foremost artistic manifestation of a whole generation. And now, the visual arts have entered the fray.

title: Indians Here Get U.S. Funds To Help Them in Urban Life
description: There are now an estimated 10,000 to 1,2,000 American Indians living in New York Citymore than when Peter Minuit bought Manhattan Island in 1626.

title: SAMUELS IS NAMED IN $2MILLION SUIT
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 30 (AP)Howard J. Samuels, Democratsi gubernatorial aspirant, was named today in a $2.15million lawsuit that accused him of being an active director of firm that had allegedly de ceived a California investor.

title: 31 Halo Takes U.N. Handicap on Turf
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 Halo enabled the combination of E. P. Taylor, MacKenzie Miller and Jorge Velasquez to make a second consecutive trip to the win net's circle in the $100,000 United Nations Handicap. The 13/16 mile race on the turf was won today by the 5yearold campaigner, who was recently purchased by. Taylor, a Canadian industrialist, for $600,000.

title: A.E.C. Says Motors at 7 Plants Failed Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters)The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed today that Westinghouse Electric Corporation motors failed to meet contract specifications in seven nuclear power plants, but, it said that this did not violate the agency's safety requirements.

title: Miss Whitworth 69 Sets Pace by a Shot
Sports News Briefs
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Aug. 30 (UPI)  The Atlantic Coast Conference is continuing to investigate the recruitment of Moses Malone and also is investigating three other basketball recruitment cases, said the conference commissioner, Robert James.

title: Fuchsberg and Hirschfeld Cleared of CampaignLaw Violations
description: The State Board of Elections said yesterday that it had found no basis for a further investigation of charges of improper or illegal conduct in the campaigns of Jacob D. Fuchsberg, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Court of Appeals, and Abraham Hirschfeld, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

title: The Fragile Financial System
description: ST. LOUISWhen Gerald R. Ford became President, the stock market reflected appreherision about the economy rather than elation that Watergate was over. This apprehension is warranted, as there is a greater likelihood of a serious financial crisis now than at any time since the nineteenthirties.

title: Welcome Vacancies ...
description: For almost three decades, school boards across the nation faced the opening of each new academic year with the specter of overcrowded classrooms, bulging schoolhouses and double or triple sessions. Suddenly, what seemed to be a neverending problem of excessive growth has changed to an opposite situation of excessive space. Elementary school enrollments peaked in 1970 with a total of 36.7 million, and have since been declining toward what is expected to be a low plateau near 34 million by 1976. High school enrollments, though still rising, will also reach their peak in a year or, two.

title: Aussie Outpoints Heair
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Aug. 30 (AP)Hector Thompson, 135 pounds, of Australia, outpointed Jimmy Heair, 135, Los Angeles, in a 10round boxing match today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ORADELL, Aug. 30Instead of choosing a relaxing vacation, Glenn Tashjian, who will be a senior at River Dell High School this fall, was one of four New Jersey boys who paid $100 for a week at the Distance Running Camp at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Fleet of 97 Sails In Vineyard Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30.The last of the East Coast sailing season's long distance races out of Long Island Sound and into open water began today when a fleet of 97, headed eastward in the Stamford Yacht Club's 40th annual Vineyard race.

title: Women Are Moving Into ManagementBut How Many? And How Far?
description: More than ever before in the nation's history, there is a widespread and conscious effort to move women into management: the Federal Government has ordered it, companies say they are trying to accomplish it, and women say they are willing and eager to start climbing.

title: 2 Housing Officers Pelted With Bottles By a Harlem Crowd
description: Two Housing Authority policemen were injured last night when violence erupted for the second straight day after an arrest at an East Harlem housing project, the police reported.

title: 20,000 Bronx Riders Getting Bus Service After 9Week Strike
description: Express bus service for 20,000 commuters between the Bronx and Manhattan will resume by Sept. 9, the Riverdale Transit Corporation announced yesterday, after a settlement of the nineweekold strike by members of Local 225 of the Transport Workers Union.

title: Parcel Talks Postponed After Truck Kills Picket
description: Negotiations were postponed indefinitely yesterday morning between the striking Teamsters Local 804 and the United Parcel Service following the death Thursday of a union official who was hit by a truck while picketing in New Jersey.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 21

title: SEIDMAN'S EXFIRM FACING S.E.C. ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering sanctions against the accounting firm formerly headed by L. William Seidman, a key economic adviser to President Ford, according to Business Week magazine.

title: SAMUELS SCORED BY CAREY AGAIN
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey urged Howard J. Samuels yes terday to consider returning any campaign contributions he had received from any private corporation or individual that did business with the Offtrack Betting Corporation, which Mr Samuels formerly headed.

title: AIDE FEARS NIXON IS ALMOST BROKE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI) Richard M. Nixon's money problems have left him almost broke, according to the former President's chief financial adviser.

title: Sadecki Subdues Braves Again, on 6Hitter
description: Despite the fact that he shut out the awesome top half of the Atlanta batting order on the way to a 42 victory over the Braves at Shea Stadium last night, Ray Sadecki, of the Mets insists he wasn't trying any harder against the first four batters.

title: Gilbert Osofsky, 39, Taught and Wrote on Black History
description: A funeral service was held Tuesday at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, Queens, for Dr. Gilbert Osofsky, author and professor of black history at the Chicago center of the University of Illinois. Dr. Osofsky, who formerly taught at Hunter College, Columbia versity and Cornell University died in Washington. He was 39 years old.

title: Editor's Kidnapper, Sobbing, Is. Given 40 Years in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 (UPI)William A. H. Williams, sobbing at times and contending that the press had sold out the American people, was sentenced today to 40 years in prison for the kidnapping of Reg Murphy, an editor of The Atlanta Constitution.

title: OCCIDENTAL CLAIM BY ALLEN REJECTED
description: A claim by the investment banking firm of Allen & Co. that it was entitled to a 25 per cent working interest in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's oil concessions in Libya was rejected yesterday by Judge Edward Weinfeld of the Federal District Court here.

title: Ford Said to pick Expert for Latin Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 President Ford was reported today to have chosen a former top LatinAmerican specialist in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations as the new Assistant Secretary for InterAmerican affairs, the senior LatinAmerican policymaking position in the State Department.

title: Christopher T. Takes Hambletonian In Straight Heats
description: DU QUOIN, El., Aug. 30After two days of rain de lays and three heats of racing, the $160,150 Hambletonian was finally won today by Christopher T.a 3yearold trotter with bad knees, owned by a pharmacist from Minnesota and driven by a hungry man with with 3,864 victories.

title: Capt. Owen. Cunningham, London Restauranteur, 64
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) Capt. Owen Cunningham, London's oyster king, who started with $2,000 and built an establishment that included the royalty among its custom ers, died Wednesday, lie yeas 64 years, Old.

title: Saints, Population Explosion Face Jets
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 The Jets, who won Super Bowl III, arrived in New Orleans today for Exhibition Game V, hoping to earn a return trip four months from now for Super Bowl IX.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BOLIVIA CHIEF DROPS THREAT TO RESIGN
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30 (AP)President Hugo Banzer Suarez, who has been embroiled in a dispute with backers for a week over election plans, threatened to resign today. But after his military colleagues objected and the labor unions threatened to strike, he changed, his mind.

title: PRICES END. MIXED FOR COMMODITIES
description: Farm commodity futures closed quietly for the week, despite a bullish export booking report by the Agriculture Department that showed export commitments sharply higher.

title: Shea and Scott Dismissed By Police in Killing of Boy
description: Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, who was acquitted last June by a jury of murdering a 10yearold Queens boy, was found guilty by the Police Department yesterday of wrongfully and without just cause firing the shots that caused the death. Officer Shea was dismissed from the force after the department verdict.

title: Brooklyn Children Get Final Meal of 8Week Summer Lunch Program
description: At the Monroe Block Association in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, at the Goodwill Church of God and Christ in the East. New York section and at the Iglesia Asamblea Pentacostal in the Sunset Park section, a host of schoolchildren lined up at noon yesterday for the final lunch in a $1million summer program sponsored by the Brooklyn Urban League.

title: The Dance
description: With the spectacular hors d'oeuvre of the highwire walker Philippe Petit as a curtain raiser, the 12th annual New York Dance Festival played Thursday night to a capacity crowd at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: ExAide to Daley Acquitted By Jury on 10 of 21 Counts
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (UPI)Earl Bush, former press aide to Mayor Richard J. Daley, was acquitted today of nine counts of mail fraud and one count of extortion, but a Federal jury failed to reach a verdict on 11 other counts of mail fraud.

title: Ties With East Germany
description: Once East Germany stopped harassing travelers on the roads that link West Germany with West Berlin, there was no reason for the United States to delay the, opening of diplomatic relations with the socalled German Democratic Republic. The scheduled signing in Washington on Wednesday of an agreement to exchange ambassadors will clear the way for former Senator John Sherman Cooper to take up his post as this country's first envoy in East Berlin.

title: Ford Will Support His Fiscal Allies in Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 President Ford will campaign in the fall Congressional elections, speaking at selected Republican rallies while stressing nation ally that he supports candidates of both parties who favor fiscal restraint, the White House said tonight.

title: Assertion of Rape and Unwritten Law Form a Coast Woman's Murder Defense
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 30 A 30yearold woman is on trial for firstdegree murder in the killing of a 300pound man who she says helped another man rape her. She faces life imprisonment if convicted.

title: Art: Manguin, Matisse and Fate
description: Nothing in the plays of Anton Chekhov is more true to life than the moment in The Seagull in which Trigorin, the storyteller, foresees that no matter how hard he tries, people will still say of him: Pretty good, but not as good as Turgenev. To be good but not quite good enough is the fate of almost everyone; and it is particularly the fate of painters who were around at the time of a spectacular breakthrough by one or more of their contemporaries.

title: The New TugofWar in Portugal
description: LISBON, Aug. 30Who ex ercises the political power in Portugal? Lisbon's leading review, Expresso, asked this week.

title: PHILLIPS DISCLOSES GIFTS TO CAMPAIGNS
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Aug. 30 (AP)The Phillips Petroleum Company disclosed tonht) that it contributed $685,000 in;corporate funds to political campaigns in the last 10 years.

title: Group Auto Insurance Set
description: Group auto insurance as an employe benefit will be offered on an experimental basis in Michigan, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company said yesterday. It said employes could expect to save money but gave no figures.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, proposed legal and administrative changes to aid policyholders with companies that become insolvent. Mr. Sheeran said the new approach was prompted by the state's experience with the Gateway Insurance Company, a Pennsylvania concern that was declared insolvent last week. The state is helping Gateway policyholders get new coverage through an organization of all 460 property liability companies that do business in New Jersey.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS EDUCATORS' HELP ON U.S PROBLEMS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30President Ford called today for a real partnership between the academic community and the rest of our society.

title: Price of Aluminum Ingots, Advanced by 3 Producers
description: The second price increase in a month on aluminum raw materials developed rapidly yesterday as three companies, the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the Aluminum Company of America and the Anaconda Company's aluminum division, announced that they would raise prices of primary ingot prices 3 cents, from 36 cents to 39 cents a pound effective Tuesday.

title: Panel Focuses on Founding Fathers' Other Papers
description: The Founding Fathers not only founded, they wrote letters, speeches, diaries, articles, essays and expense accounts.

title: U.N. Calls on 2 Cypriote Groups to Resume Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30The Security Council adopted unanimously today reolution calling on the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes to reWine direct negotiations and to work with the United Nations to solve the problem of the island's refugees.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS EDUCATORS' HELP ON U.S. PROBLEMS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30President Ford called today for a real partnership between the academic community and the rest of our society.

title: Economists Hopeful on Summit Meeting
description: Many of the economists invited to President Ford's presummit economic conference next week said yesterday that the session would provide the President with a variety of weapons to use in his battle against inflation.

title: Tenants at Stella Wright Preparing to Run Project
description: NEWARK, Aug. 30  The success of our victory is still with the people, Toby Henry, president of the Stella Wright Tenants Association, said today as he supervised a lunch program for 1,500 children of the public housing project.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses, to Halt Arrest of Teacher Pickets
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 30 (UPI)Federal District Judge Hugh Bownes refused today to grant an immediate temporary junction to halt the arrest of pickets in the Timberlane School District, scene of the nation's longest teacher strike.

title: Woman, 92, Beaten to Death In Robbery of Dunkirk Home
description: DUNKIRK, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) A 92yearold woman was beaten to death last night in her home during an apparent robbery, the police said.

title: Bride:
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The two most experienced teams were strongly placed in the semifinals of the international team playoff matches at the Washington Hilton hotel here tonight.

title: Exchange Students Shun Cities of U.S.
description: GREENVALE, L. IBack home in Turkey, people worried when they heard that Kursat Onder would spend he coming year in New York.

title: Alirror Shows Slim View Before Loss of Weight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30A mirror trademarked SelectaSize shows how a person standing in front of it would look after a considerable loss of weight. The upper part of the mirror remains flat, providing a true reflection of the head, but the curvature of the lower portion can be changed to present a flattering view of the body.

title: People and Business
description: Edward Allen Eap Pierce, the Pierce in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, will quietly observe his 100th birthday today in a Park Avenue hotel where he lives with his wife, Luella, who is 102. The couple have no children but a nephew and his family are expected in for the occasion from his native state of Maine.

title: Air Force Officer Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) President Ford signed a law today that extends until Oct. 1, 1976, the temporary authorization for increased numbers of officers who may serve in the grades of colonel and lieutenant colonel in the Air Force.

title: Enough Punishment for Mr. Nixon
description: HONOLULUToday, all America is debating whether Citizen Nixon should be prosecuted and punished for the Watergate crimes of President Nixon. Some hold that he has been punished enough. Others wish him jailed to prove that Justice is impartial.

title: Bridal of Emily Warner Carey And Robert Cronin Held Here
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday afternoon, Emily Warner Carey, a greatgranddaughter of the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith, was married to Robert Neil Cronin, cochairman of the drama department of the New Orleans Center for the Creative Arts.

title: Electrical Union Ordered To Resume School Jobs
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered electrical workers who had been refusing to work at school construction sites to call off their strike until school opens Sept. 9.

title: First Wisconsin Files Unaudited '73 Report,
description: The First Wisconsin Mortgage Trust, Milwaukee, has filed an unauditied 10K annual 1973 report with the Securities and Exchange Commission and has requested the commission to continue the suspension of trading in its stock until the 1973 audit is completed and made public.

title: BUTTERFLY SOUNDS FRESH AT CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera's production of Madama Butterfly, which had its first performance of the fall season on Thursday night, continues to be one of the most telling demonstrations of how to integrate music and drama that any company has put forward here in recent years.

title: Commodity Price Index Showed Drop Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index, of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 236.3 from 238.6 last week.

title: Chaplain Denies 2 Were Executed In Texas Shootout
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 30 (UPI)A prison chaplain who was wounded in the shootout that ended an 11day siege of the Texas state penitentiary denied today allegations that Fred Gomez Carrasco and Rudolfo Dominguez, rebel inmates, ?? by officers at pointblank range.

title: Paterson Festival Will Be Looking Up
description: PATERSON; Aug. 30Silk City began its Fourth Annual Great Falls Festival here tonight. The threeday celebration is scheduled to reach its finale when Phillipe Petit, the French aerialist, dances his way across a wire over, the Great Falls of the Passaic River at 1 P.M. oh Labor Day.

title: TRAIN CRASH KILLS 100 IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Saturday, Aug. 31At least 100 people were killed and 150 injured when all the coaches of an express train bound for West Germany jumped the rails and overturned near Zagreb in northern Yugoslavia late last night.

title: FARM PRICES RISE BY 3% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The prices of farm products rose 3 per cent in the month ended Aug. 15, led by meat animals and the grains that are used to fatten them, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Rev. Dr. George WrightDead; An Archeologist, Bible Scholar
description: The Rev. Dr. George Ernest Wright, Near Eastern archeologist, Biblical scholar and Parkman Professor of Divinity at Harvard University, died Thursday in Jaffrey, N. H. He was 164 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: A Film Maker in Senegal Stresses African Culture
description: YOFF, Senegal At 50, El Hadji Abdou Kader Beye seemed to have the best of his two worlds.

title: 4 Concerns Join to Use Solar Energy
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP) Four companies are banding together to create what they call the first commercial complex to use solar energy for heating and cooling, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reports.

title: Christopher T. Takes Hambletonian In Straight Heats
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30After two days of rain de lays and three heats of racing, the $160,150 Hambletonian was finally won today by Christopher T.a 3yearold trotter with bad knees, owned by a, pharmacist from Minnesota and driven by a hungry man with with 3,864 victories.

title: Amex Prices End 2Week Slide And Rise in Decreased Trading
description: Ending a 15session slide, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday On slightly decreased trading. On the overthecounter market, prices also rose on increased volume.

title: 7 Hurt in TruckCar Crash
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) A truck and car collided today and then crashed into a nearby home, crumbling a wall of the house and injuring seven persons, three critically, the police said. According to the police, the brick front of the house collapsed on top ?? the wreckage, trapping a woman and two girl inside the car.

title: Magnavox Opposes Philips's Stock Bid
description: The Magnavox Company said yesterday that it had decided not to recommend to its shareholders acceptance of the North American Philips Corporation's tender offer of $8 a share for all the outstanding common shares of Magnavox.

title: Funeral Service for Griffis
description: A funeral service for Stanton Griffis, former special envoy and Ambassador, will be held tomorrow at the Presbyterian Church of Westfield,. N. Y. Mr. Griffis died of pneumonia at Lenox. Hill Hospital on Thursday evening at the age of $7.

title: WALTER BESTERMAN, IMMIGRATION AIDE
description: Walter M. Besterman, deputy director of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration from 1964 to 1970, died, yesterday in Geneva. He was 71 years old.

title: DEADLINE EXTENDED FOR OPEN DATING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) 11Processors and retailers with programs for open dating the meat and poultry they sell will have three additional months to make their procedures conform to new, voluntary Federal guidelines.

title: Bridge: 2 of Top Team Well Placed In the Playoff Tournament
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The two most experienced teams were strongly placed in the semifinals of the international team playoff matches at the Washington Hilton Hotel here tonight.

title: GREECE ASKS U.S. TO DISCUSS BASES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 30 Greece sent notes to the United States and other Atlantic alliance members today informing them that Athens wanted to begin talks on the future of foreign military installations in Greece.

title: Forest Fire in California, Worst of Year, Contained
description: PINECOVE, Calif., Aug 30 (AP)California's most severe forest fire of the year was con tained today after burning alost 17,500 acres of brush and timber in the San Jacinto mounains, officials said.

title: Holy Moses
description: Moses Malone was supposed to start his freshman course of classes at the University of Maryland on Tuesday. Instead, he signed a contract with the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association, which reportedly could bring him as much as $3 million.

title: Thailand Reports on Oil Strike, Believed First in Gulf of Siam
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Aug. 31 (Agence FrancePresse)The director of Thailand's Mineral Resources Department announced last night that the American Oil Company had struck crude oil in the Gulf of Siam.

title: A JUDGE EXPLAINS MURDER SENTENCE
description: FARMINGTON, N.M., Aug. 30 The judge who sentenced three white teenagers to short terms in a reform school for murdering three Navajo men list spring told the New Mexico advisory committee to the United States Civil Rights Commission today that the sentences were those prescribed by law.

title: World Conference Adopts Population Plan of Action
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 30The twoweeklong United Nations World Population Conference ended today by approving without further debate what it called a Plan of Action.

title: Agnew Denies That He Got Leniency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, in a letter to The Washington Post, took issue today with the newspaper's use of the word leniency in the headline of an article regarding his legal problems.

title: School Prayer Suit Filed
description: BOSTON, Aug, 30 (AP)Mrs. Rita F. Warren, of Brockton, has filed a suit, in Suffolk County Superior Court charging that State Education Commissioner Gregory R. Andrig has failed to enforce a state law on school prayer. The law requires a minute of silence in every public school classroom at the beginning of each school day.

title: Norman P. Smith, 74, Dies; ExPartner in Merrill Lynch
description: Norman P, Smith, a former partner and vice president in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith who had headed its syndicate department, died yesterday in Venice (Fla.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: SAXBE THREATENS SUIT TO SHUTDOWN STATE LOTTERIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Attorney General William B. Saxbe threatened today to seek court order shutting down state lotteries operated by New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and 10 other states.

title: DEATH POSTPONES THE PARCEL TALKS
description: Negotiations were postponed Indefinitely yesterday morning between the striking Teamsters Local 804 and the United Parcel Service following the death Thursday of a union official who was hit by a truck while bicketing in New Jersey.

title: People in Sports
description: Maurice Lucas would like to play one more season of basketball for Marquette, but the 6foot8inch center may be prevented from doing so by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Martha Graham, StartingAsian Tour, a Hit in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 30The Martha Graham Dance Company, on the first leg of 10country Asian tour sponsored by the State Department, today opened a series of five performances in Taiwan before art enthusiastic sellout audience at Taipei's Sun Yatsen Memorial Hall.

title: Manhattan Beach Shut By Sewage Plant Snag
description: Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn will be closed to bathers today and possibly tomorrow because of a breakdown in a nearby sewagetreatment plant, the Parks Department announced.

title: PENTAGON DRAFT ASKS PUBLIC DUTY FOR WAR EVADERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Pentagon, concluding that a substantial majority of Americans favor conditional amnesty for draft evaders and deserters, will recommend to President Ford that they reaffirm allegiance to the United States and work 18 months of alternate service, it was learned today.

title: Aussie Outpoints Heair
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Aug. 30 (AP)Hector Thompson, 135 pounds, of Australia, outpointed Jimmy Heair, 135, Los Angeles, in a 10round boxing match today.

title: Excerpts From Report of Population Talks
Germany Seeks to Help Banks With ForeignExchange Curb
description: BERLIN, Aug 30 (UPI)West Germany introduced foreignexchange controls for the first time today in a move to prevent further bank failures. Four West German banks have failed in the last two months.

title: Dolphins Conquer Packers
description: MIAMI, Aug. 30 (AP)Larry Csonka, the fullback, scored twice from the 1yard line tonight, leading the Miami Dolphins to a 2110 National Football League exhibition victory over Green Bay.

title: U.N. Calls on 2 Cypriote Groups to Resume Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30The Security Council, adopted unanimously today a resolution calling on the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes to resume direct negotiations and to work with the United Nations to solve the problem of the island's refugees.

title: Gunmen in Cyprus Attempt to Murder Prominent Supporter of Makarios
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 30Gunmen tried today to assassinate a prominent political leader and one of the most powerful supporters of the deposed president, Archbishop Makarios. The intended victim, Dr. Vassos Lyssarides, was slightly wounded, but a journalist was killed and three other people were injured.

title: ALBERT W. TOLMAN JR.
description: Albert; W. Tolman Jr., a former partner in Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., public accountants, died Wednesday in Houston, where he lived. His age was 70.

title: Inventory Buildup Continued in July; Dollar Value Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The rapid buildup of inventories in the manufacturing sector of the economy continued in July with the, largest rise in dollar value of inventories so far this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Cup Trial Is Abandoned Because of Heavy Squall
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 30A promising bid by Intrepid to gain her fourth straight victory over Courageous was thwarted today when their yacht race had to be abandoned because of severe thunder squalls.

title: People in Sports
description: Maurice Lucas would like to play one more season of basketball for Marquette, but the 6foot8inch center may be prevented from doing so by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: HENRY N. MULLER
description: Henry N. Muller, former vice president and technical director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, died of cancer Thursday in Hanover, N.H. He was 60 years old.

title: Policeman's Wile Kills Her Husband's Slayers
description: ST. ANNE, Ill., Aug. 30 (UPI) The wife of St. Anne's police chief watched as her husband was shot to death today, then picked up his revolver and killed two of his assailants as they scrambled to disarm her.

title: Bombing Tokyo Kills at Least 8, Injures Hundreds
MRS IRVING DRUCKER
description: Ella Jaslow Drucker, the widow of Irving Drucker, a men'sclothing retailer who died in 1956, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home at the age of 84.

title: 70,000 Kurds Flee to Iran From Big Iraqi Offensive
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30More than 70,000 Iraqi Kurds are believed to have fled to Iran from attacks by the Iraqi Army and Air Force.

title: Crowds in Bus Terminal Begin Holiday Weekend
description: I don't know where the summer's gone, the manager of the Port Authority Bus Terminal said yesterday as thousands of travelers queued up for the summer's last escape from the sweltering city.

title: Vorster Expects to Cooperate With Mozambique
description: CAPE TOWN, Aug. 30Prime Minister John Vorster told Parliament today that the creation of a black government in neighboring Mozambique was inevitable and that he would take the earliest opportunity to establish contact with it and to come to an understanding with it.

title: Books of The Times
description: Every important American, English, French and Hungarian author in the world worked for MetroGoldwynMayer during the studio's heyday, writes Anita. Loos in Kiss Hollywood Goodby. The list runs from Zoe Akins to John Van Druten and includes Robert Benchley, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Moss Hart, Ben Hecht, Aldous Huxley, Christopher Isherwood, George S. Kaufman, Ferenc Molnar, Dorothy Parker and S. J. Perelman. But as Miss Loos quickly points out in her disrespectful memoirs, not all these literary, big shots could master the knack (not art) of screenwriting. For, example, the scripts Scott Fitzgerald wrote just wouldn't play. The most reliable screenwriters, she says, were women: Francis Marion, Bess Meredith, Sonja Levine, Vicki Baum and Jane Murfin and, as she knows, and as we know, Anita Loos. Miss Loos had two careers in Hollywoodas a writer of hundreds of silent movies, including the titles for Intolerance (discussed In the first volume of her autobiography, A GirlLike I), and as a writer of talkies (volume two). Her first film, released in 1913, The New York Hat, starred Mary Pickford Lionel Barrymore and Lillian and Dorothy Gisb, and her last, in 1953 (after writing for Fairbanks, Harlow, Gable, Tracy and Crawford), starred. Marilyn Monroe as Lorelei Lee. Gentleman Prefer Blondes brought her early and continuing fame, but it was far from the of her career.

title: Giants to Battle a New Flock of Eagles
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 30 One year ago, the Philadelphia Eagles, under a new coach and new system, had trouble lining up with 11 man on the field in a 4221 loss to the blew York Giants.

title: SOVIET PATRIARCH PLANS TRIF TO U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30  Patriarch Pimen of Moscow, head of the Russian Orthodox Church here, wilt visit the United States next February, church sources reported today.

title: It's August So We Haven't Had a Blizzard, Yet
description: Katie Kelly, managing editor of a woman's magazine in New York City, wrote the following letter to her parents in Albion, Neb.

title: Tokyo Seeks Leftists For Blast That Killed 8
description: TOKYO, Aug. 30Japanese. policemen began searching tonight for extreme leftists suspected of having bombed the main office of a leading indystrial company here, leaving it least eight dead and about 330 hospitalized with injuries.

title: TV NETWORKS FILM TROUBLE LIGHT PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)  Responding to a Federal judge's personal request, three major television networks filmed today a demonstration of a household trouble light that the Government says could be deadly.

title: September Showdowns Start Baseball Season
description: Those who have spent the past five months poring over the baseball standings and statistics may be surprised to learn that the season really won't begin until tomorrow. Says Willie Stargell of the Pittsburgh Pirates: The race doesn't start until Sept. 1, like always. Then it will be up to the pitching, like it always is.

title: Chairman Pressing F.T.C. To Expand Antitrust Role
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Lewis A. Engman, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, has concluded that enforcing the law against pricefixing and other anticompetitive business practices should become the central effort of the coinmission.

title: Lou Graham Takes Georgia Golf Lead By Shot on 134
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 30Lou Graham, a worried Tennessee pro Who has been painfully working his way out of a long slump, shot another 67today to take the lead in the second round of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: John S. Radosta
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 30  The young golf pros competing here in the Tournament Players Championship are bigger, stronger and better nourished than their granddaddies in Bobby Jones's day, and their equipment is more sophisticated. But how much effect do those factors have in killing golf courses with scores in the low and mid60's? Some, but not much. Fans tend to forget there were low scores in Jones's day, and some authorities note that the old pros had some shotmaking skills that today's young lions don't have. Conditions were different in that generation, but it is risky to argue they were better or worse, because for every plus there is an opposing minus, and it all sort of evens out.

title: SUSPECT IS HEED IN HOFSTRA RAPES
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 30  A 122yearold Hempstead man was arraigned today on two charges of rape and one of attempted assault in connection with attacks on three Hofstra University students during a sixmonth period.

title: Oilers Drop Curry, Head Of Union
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 30 (AP)The Houston Oilers said today that Bill Curry, president of the National Football League Players Association, had been put on waivers by mutual consent.

title: Hitachi Plans Layoffs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 30 (Reuters)Citing poor sales of color TV sets and some other home appliances, Hitachi, Ltd., has announced that it is adopting a layoff system. Under the system, workers would take three or four days leave a month, beginning in September. Three factories are involved, where picture tubes, semiconductors, airconditioners and heaters are produced.

title: Beall Is Apologetic For Use of Article Without Attribution
description: BALTIMORE, Aug, 30 (AP)United States Attorney George Beall has apologized' to a University of North Carolina professor for using some of his material without attribution in a speech before the American Bar Association.

title: Business Briefs
description: 2 Banks Hold Base Rates at 12%

title: Markets Shut Monday
description: All securities and commodities exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed Monday in observance of Labor Day. Banks and government offices also will be closed. Overseas exchanges, however, will be open as usual.

title: Pate, Grace Gain Final In U.S. Golf
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 30  Pate, the tournament's giantkiller, and John Grace, who was given no chance to win four days ago, Will meet in the final of the 14th annual. United States Amateur golf championship tomorrow. It could be a des sic duel between the young, longhitting Pate and, the short but accurateshooting Orate, who will decide the title at. Ridgewood Country Club in a 36hole match.

title: 31 Halo Takes U.N. Handicap on Turf
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 Halo enabled the combination of E. P. Taylor, MacKenzie Miller and Jorge Velasquez to make a second consecutive trip to the win net's circle in the $100,000 United Nations Handicap. The 13/16 mile race on the turf was won today by the 5yearold campaigner, who was recently purchased by. Taylor, a Canadian industrialist, for $600,000.

title: White House to Press for High Energy Post for Former Oil Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Despite Justice Department reservations, the White House has decided to send to the Senate the longdelayed nomination of Melvin A. Conant, a former Exxon Corporation executive to an important post in the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although our new President's, spirit of openness, conciliation and humanity is a source of great relief, one cannot help feeling disappointed that his thinking in the economic area appears to be shackled by what John Kehneth Galbraith called almost thirty years ago conventional wisdom.

title: Shea and Scott Dismissed By Police in Killing of Boy
description: Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, who was acquitted last June by a jury of murdering a 10yearold Queens boy, was found guilty by the Police Department yesterday of wrongfully and without just cause firing the shots that caused the death. Officer Shea was dismissed from the force after the department verdict.

title: Steinbrenner Spared Jail, Fined for Campaign Gifts
description: CLEVELAND, Aug, 30 George M. Steinbrenner 3d, an industrialist who is the principal owner of the New York Yankees, was fined $15,000 here today on charges stemming from the illegal expenditure of corporate campaign contributions to former President Nixon and several Democratic members of Congress. However, he was spared a jail sentence.

title: Turnpike's ParkRide Program Is Off to a Slow Start
description: RIDGEFIELDThere were only 15 passengers on the 10 A.M. bus out of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's new parkride lot here the other day and only about 155 automobiles parked in an area designed to hold 950.

title: WINE TALK
description: As harvest time in the vineyards grows near so does the beginning of the wine season in New York and just about everywhere else.

title: Part of Turnpike Shut As Propane Track Tips
description: HIGHTSTOWN, Aug. 30 (AP)A 28mile stretch of the New Jersey, Turnpike was closed for three hours today after a propane truck ran off the roadway and overturned in an adjacent field, the police said.

title: Profits Show Drop At RapidAmerican

description: TRENTON, Aug. 30 (AP)A study report that alleged widespread abuse of tranquilizing drugs in state institutions has been disavowed by the New Jersey branch of the National Association of Social Workers. The report was prepared for the association.

title: Official PriceBooster
description: President Ford correctly recognizes that a major responsibility for inflation rests on Government itself. This responsibility extends beyond the excessive creation of money and swollen Federal expenditures, of which the defense budget is a prime example. The Government's pernicious role as a feeder of inflation also embraces a host of activities designed to prop up increase prices and institutionalize inefficiencies.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Federal Energy Administration proposed today a crudeoil price equalization plan intended to lower costs and prices of independent refiners and make them more competitive with the major oil companies.

title: RETARDED BOY, 14, IS FOUND BY POLICE
description: After a 21hour search, the police yesterday found a 14yearold retarded boy in the Bronx who had wandered out of the adolescent psychiatric ward at Elmhurst General Hospital, in Queens on Thursday night.

title: Experts Are Confident ImportExport Deficit Has Peaked
description: Leading experts in foreign trade say they are confident that the country's rising export  import deficit has reached RS high mark for the year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Greece sent notes to the United States and other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization informing them that Athens wanted to begin talks on the future of foreign military installations in Greece. Washington officials said that the note stressed the Greek. Government's desire, in view of the Cyprus crisis, to assert its sovereignty over all installations, but that it was not explicit about whether Greece would demand the withdrawal of American and other NATO forces from Greece. 11:2.]

description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30It isn't often that a Republican in Kansasespecially an incumbent United States Senator, is in much trouble politically at this time in an election year.

title: Ailing Sicilian Attains Citizenship Goal
description: PASSAIC, Aug. 30A 37yearold Sicilian immigrant, in a hospital here critically ill with cancer of the throat, realized a sixyearold dream today by taking the citizenship oath of the United States.

title: World Conference Adopts Population Plan of Action
JOEL P. MORKAN
description: Joel P. Morkan, a professor of English at Florida State University in Tallahassee, died Tuesday at the Tallahassee Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 33 years old and lived in Tallahassee since last September.

title: Richardson Backs Sargent
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Former United States Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson endorsed today the reelection bid of his distant cousin, Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts.

title: Yields on Bills Decline In Sale of $4.8Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Yields on Treasury bills declined today as the Government auctioned $4.8billion of shortterm securities in a financing moved ahead from Monday because of Labor Day.

title: Courant Raises Sunday Price
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 30 (AP)The Hartford Courant will raise the price of its Sunday edition to 40 cents from 35 cents Sept. 1, the paper's president, Edmund W. Downes, announced today. He blamed the rising price of newsprint and production costs. The price of the daily paper will remain at 15 cents.

title: ... Union Squeeze Here
description: New York City apparently won't have to worry about what to do with excess space when its public schools open Sept. 9. A jurisdictional war between two electrical unions is taking care of any problem that might have existed on that score, The interunion competition for jobs threatens to block completion of work on eighteen schools and to force reassignment of 18,000 pupils.

description: Mary Hart Homer Crawford, the widow of Raymond S. Crawford and the mother of Homer Crawford, secretary of the St. Regis Paper Company, died in Sarasota, Fla., on Friday. She was 85 years old.

title: New York Gains a Game in East on 85 Victory

description: Boy, oh boy! It was a great trip, said Capt. John Cahill of Clifton, N.J. He was speaking from Southampton, England, which was not where he expected to wind up after boarding Queen Elizabeth 2 a few days earlier in his capacity, of New York harbor pilot.

Solarz was handing out brochures in his bathing trunks on Brighton Beach and Robert Chira was distributing booklets in a Kings Highway cafeteria.

title: Inflation in Wes Germany: 2 Sides of the Coin
description: BONN  West Germany, with 7 per cent, has the lowest rate of inflation of any major industrial power this year, possibly because the problem of constantly, rising prices has become virtually, a national preoccupation.

The younger sister goes first, of course, and the City Opera has now opened the opera season with her usual grace and bounce. Her musical presentation is exuberant, and this weekend offers selection of old favorites that, true to the City Opera style, entertain and inspire with fluid, theatrical productions.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30A Lithuanian seaman serving a 10year prison term here for having attempted to defect to a United States Coast Guard cutter in 1970 has been freed by Soviet authorities, the dissident nuclear physicist Anflrei D. Salmi hatov reported today.
